alphabetical letter b b
The second letter of the alphabet: called baA='N and baA; (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np;) the latter of which forms is used in spelling; like as are its analogues, as tA [and vA] and HA [and xA and rA] and TA [and ZA and fA and hA] and yA; because in this case they are not generally regarded as nouns, but as mere sounds: (Sb, M:) [these are generally pronounced with imáleh, i. e. bé, té, &c., with the exception of HA, xA, TA, and ZA; and when they are regarded as nouns, their duals are bayaAni, tayaAni, &c.:] the pl. of baA='N is baA='aAtN; and that of baA is A^abowaA='N (TA ubi suprà.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrah [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; and of those termed $afahiy~ap [or labial]; and of those termed *uloq [or pronounced with the extremity of the tongue or the lips]: Kh says that the letters of the second and third classes above mentioned [the latter of which comprises the former] are those composing the words rub~a mano laf~a; and on account of their easiness of utterance, they abound in the composition of words, so that no perfect quinqueliteral-radical word is without one or more of them, unless it is of the class termed muwal~ad, not of the classical language of the Arabs. (TA at the commencement of bAb AlbA='.) ― -b2- In the dial. of Mázin, it is changed into m; (TA ubi suprà;) as in bak~apu, which thus becomes mak~apu [the town of Mekkeh]. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.) -A2- bi is a preposition, or particle governing the gen. case; (S, Mughnee, K;) having kesr for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a letter after which one makes a pause; (S;) or, correctly speaking, having a vowel for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a quiescent letter; and having kesr, not fet-h, to make it accord with its government [of the gen. case], and to distinguish between it and that which is both a noun and a particle. (IB.) It is used to denote adhesion (Sb, T, S, M, Mughnee, K) of the verb to its objective complement, (S,) or of a noun or verb to that to which it is itself prefixed; (TA;) and adjunction, or association: (Sb, T:) and some say that its meaning of denoting adhesion is inseparable from it; and therefore Sb restricted himself to the mention of this meaning: (Mughnee:) or Sb says that its primary meaning is that of denoting adhesion and mixture. (Ibn-Es-Sáïgh, quoted in a marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) It denotes adhesion [&c.] in the proper sense; (Mughnee, K;) as in A^amosakotu bizayodK, (M, Mughnee, K,) meaning I laid hold upon, or seized, [Zeyd, or] somewhat of the body of Zeyd, or what might detain him, as an arm or a hand, or a garment, and the like; whereas A^amosakotuhu may mean I withheld him, or restrained him, from acting according to his own free will: (Mughnee:) and it denotes the same in a tropical sense; (Mughnee, K;) as in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd]; (S, Mughnee, K;) as though meaning I made my passing to adhere to Zeyd; (S;) or I made my passing to adhere to a place near to Zeyd: accord. to Akh, it is for mararotu EalaYi zayodK; but mararotu bihi is more common than mararotu Ealayohi, and is therefore more properly regarded as the original form of expression: (Mughnee:) accord. to F, the vowel of this preposition is kesr [when it is prefixed to a noun or a pronoun]; or, as some say, it is fet-h when it is with a noun properly so called; as in mar~a bazayodK: so in the K; this being the reverse of what they have prescribed in the case of [the preposition] l: but in the case of b, no vowel but kesr is known. (MF.) It denotes the same in the saying bihi daA='N [In him is a disease; i. e. a disease is cleaving to him]: and so [accord. to some] in A^aqosamotu bA@ll~`hi [I swore, or, emphatically, I swear, by God; and similar phrases, respecting which see a later division of this paragraph]. (L.) So, too, in A^a$oraka bA@ll~`hi, because meaning He associated another with God: and in wak~alotu bifulaAnK, meaning I associated a wakiyl [or factor &c.] with such a one. (T.) [And so in other phrases here following.] Ealayoka bizayodK Keep thou to Zeyd: or take thou Zeyd. (TA voce EalaY.) Ealayoka bika*aA Keep thou to such a thing: (El-Munáwee:) or take thou such a thing. (Ham p. 216.) fabahaA wanaEomato Keep thou to it, fbhA meaning faEalayoka bihaA, (Mgh in art. nEm,) [or let him keep to it, i. e. faEalayohi bihaA,] or thou hast taken to, or adopted and followed, or adhered to, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, i. e. fabiA@ls~un~api A^axa*ata, (Mgh,) or he hath taken to, &c., i. e. fabiA@ls~un~api A^axa*a, (IAth, TA in art. nEm,) or by this practice, or action, is excellence attained, or he will attain excellence, i. e. fabih`*ihi AlxaSolapi A^awi AlfaEolapi yunaAlu AlfaDolu, or yanaAlu AlfaDola; (IAth ubi suprà;) and excellent is the practise, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, wnEmt meaning waniEomati AlxaSolapu Als~un~apu, (Mgh,) or and excellent is the practice, or the action, i. e. waniEomati AlxaSolapu, (S and K in art. nEm,) or waniEomati AlxaSolapu A^uwi AlfaEolapu: (IAth ubi suprà:) and it also occurs in a trad., where the meaning is [He who hath done such a thing hath adhered to the ordinance of indulgence; and excellent is the practice, or action, &c.: for here fbhA is meant to imply] fabiA@lr~axoSapi A^axa*a. (TA in the present art. See also art. nEm.) ― -b2- It is also used to render a verb transitive; (Mughnee, K;) having the same effect as hemzeh [prefixed], in causing [what would otherwise be] the agent to become an objective complement; as in *ahabotu bizayodK syn. with A^a*ohabotuhu [I made Zeyd to go away; or I took him away]; (Mughnee;) and hence, [in the Kur ii. 16,] *ahaba A@ll~`hu binuwrihimo [God taketh away their light]; (Mughnee, K;) which refutes the assertion of Mbr and Suh, that *ahabotu bizayodK means [I went away with Zeyd; i. e.] I accompanied Zeyd in going away. (Mughnee.) J says that any verb that is not trans. you may render so by means of bi and A [prefixed] and reduplication [of the medial radical letter]: you say, TaAra bihi and A^aTaArahu and Tay~arahu [as meaning He made him to fly, or to fly away]: but IB says that this is not correct as of common application; for some verbs are rendered trans. by means of hemzeh, but not by reduplication; and some by reduplication, but not by hemzeh; and some by b, but not by hemzeh nor by reduplication: you say, dafaEotu zayodFA biEamorKw [as meaning I made ' Amr to repel Zeyd, lit. I repelled Zeyd by ' Amr], but not A^adofaEotuhu nor daf~aEotuhu. (TA.) ― -b3- It also denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument; (S, M, * Mughnee, K; *) as in katabotu biAlqalami [I wrote with the reed-pen]; (S, Mughnee, K;) and najarotu biAlqaduwmi [I worked as a carpenter with the adz]; (Mughnee, K;) and Darabotu bAls~ayofi [I struck with the sword]. (M.) And hence the bi in bisomi A@ll~`hi, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to some, because the action [before which it is pronounced] is not practicable in the most perfect manner but by means of it: (Mughnee:) but others disallow this, because the name of God should not be regarded as an instrument: (MF, TA:) and some say that the b here is to denote beginning, as though one said, A^abotadaA^u bisomi A@ll~`hi [I begin with the name of God]. (TA.) ― -b4- It also denotes a cause; as in A_in~akumo Zalamotumo A^anofusakumo biA@t~ixaA*ikumu A@loEijola [Verily ye have wronged yourselves by, i. e. because of, your taking to yourselves the calf as a god (Kur ii. 51)]; and in fakul~FA A^axa*onaA bi*anobihi [And every one of these we have punished for, i. e. because of, his sin (Kur xxix. 39)]; (Mughnee, K) and in lano yadoxula A^aHadakumu Aljan~apa biEamalihi [Not any of you shall enter Paradise by, or for, or because of, his works]. (TA from a trad.) And so in laqaytu bizayodK AlA^asada I met, or found, by reason of my meeting, or finding, Zeyd, the lion: (Mughnee:) or the b in this instance denotes comparison; [i. e. I met, or found, in Zeyd the like of the lion;] as also in raA^ayotu bifulaAnK Alqamara [I saw in such a one the
like of the moon]. (TA.) Another ex. of the same usage is the saying [of a poet],
qado suqiyato A=baAluhumo biAln~aAri
waAln~aAru qado ta$ofiY mina AlA^uwaAri
[Their camels had been watered because of the brand that they bore: for fire, or the brand, sometimes cures of the heat of thirst]; i. e., because of their being branded with the names [or marks] of their owners, they had free access left them to the water. (Mughnee. See also another reading of this verse voce naArN.) [In like manner] it is used in the sense of mino A^ajoli [which means bisababi (Msb in art. Ajl)] in the saying of Lebeed,
gulobN ta$a*~ara biAl*~uHuwli kaA^an~ahaA
jin~u AlbadiY~i rawaAsiyAF A^aqodaAmuhaA
(S) Thick-necked men, like lions, who threatened one another because of rancorous feelings, as though they were the Jinn of the valley El-Bedee, [or of the desert, (TA in art. bdw,)] their feet standing firm in contention and obstinate altercation. (EM pp. 174 and 175.) It is also used to denote a cause when prefixed to A^an~a and to maA as in *`lika biA^an~ahumo kaAnuwA yakofuruwna biA=yaAti A@ll~`hi [That was because they used to disbelieve in the signs of God]; and in *`lika bimaA EaSawoA [That was because they disobeyed]: both instances in the Kur ii. 58. (Bd.) ― -b5- It is also used to denote concomitance, as syn. with maEa; (Mughnee, K;) as in Ai$otarayotu Alfarasa bilijaAmihi wasarojihi [I bought the horse with his bit and bridle and his saddle]; (TA;) and in lam~aA raA=niY biAls~alaAHi haraba, i. e. When he saw me advancing with the weapon, [he fled;] or when he saw me possessor of a weapon; (Sh, T;) and in AihobiTo bisalaAmK [Descend thou with security, or with greeting (Kur xi. 50)]; and in waqado daxaluwA biA@lokufori [They having entered with unbelief (Kur v. 66)]; (Mughnee, K;) bAlkfr being a denotative of state. (Bd.) Authors differ respecting the b in the saying, fasab~iHo biHamodi rab~ika, in the Kur [xv. 98 and ex. 3]; some saying that it denotes concomitance, and that Hmd is prefixed to the objective complement, so that the meaning is, sab~iHohN HaAmidFA lahu [Declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory, praising Him], i. e. declare thou his freedom from that which is not suitable to Him, and ascribe to Him that which is suitable to Him; but others say that it denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and that Hmd is prefixed to the agent, so that the meaning is, sab~iHohu bimaA Hamida bihi nafosahu [declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory by means of ascribing to Him that wherewith He hath praised himself]: and so, too, respecting the saying, suboHaAnaka A@ll~`hum~a wabiHamodika; some asserting that it is one proposition, the, being redundant; but others saying, it is two propositions, the w being a conjunction, and the verb upon which the b is dependent being suppressed, so that the meaning is, [I declare thy freedom from everything derogatory from thy glory, 0 God,] wabiHamodika sab~aHotuka [and with the praising of Thee, or by means of the praise that belongeth to Thee, I declare thy freedom &c.]. (Mughnee. [Other explanations of these two phrases have been proposed; but those given above are the most approved.]) You also say, EalaY~a bihi, meaning Bring thou him, [i. e.] come with him, to me. (Har p. 109.) DaAqato Ealayohimu A@loA^aroDu bimaA raHubato, in the Kur ix. 119, means biruHobihaA [i. e. The earth became strait to them, with, meaning notwithstanding, its amplitude, or spaciousness]. (Bd.) Sometimes the negative lA intervenes between bi [denoting concomitance] and the noun governed by it in the gen. case; [so that bilaA signifies Without;] as in jiy^otu bilaA zaAdK [I came without travelling-provision]. (Mughnee and K in art. lA.) ― -b6- It is also syn. with fiY before a noun signifying a place or a time; (Mughnee, * K, * TA;) as in jalasotu biAlmasojidi [I sat in the mosque]; (TA;) and walaqado naSarakumu A@ll~`hu bibadorK [And verily God aided you against your enemies at Bedr (Kur iii. 119)]; and naj~ayonaAhumo bisaHarK [We saved them a little before daybreak (Kur liv. 34)]: (Mughnee, K, TA:) and so in biA^ay~ikumu A@lomafotuwnu (T, K,) in the Kur [lxviii. 6], (TA,) accord. to some, (T, Mughnee,) i. e. In which of you is madness; or in which of the two parties of you is the mad: (Bd:) or the b is here redundant; (Sb, Bd, Mughnee;) the meaning being which of you is he who is afflicted with madness. (Bd. [See also a later division of this paragraph.]) ― -b7- It also denotes substitution; [meaning Instead of, or in place of;] as in the saying [of the Hamásee (Mughnee)],
falayota liY bihimu qawomFA A_i*aA rakibuwA
$an~awA AlA_igaArapa furosaAnFA warukobaAnaA
[Then would that I had, instead of them, a people who, when they mounted their beasts, poured the sudden attack, they being horsemen and camel-riders]; (Ham p. 8, Mughnee, K;) i. e., badalFA bihimo (TA:) but some read $ad~uwA AlA_igaArapa, [and so it is in some, app., the most correct, of the copies of the Mughnee,] for $ad~uwA liloA_igaAripi [hastened for the making a sudden attack]. (Ham, Mughnee.) So, too, in the saying, AiEotaDotu bih`*iA Alv~awobi xayorFA minohu [I received, in the place of this garment, or piece of cloth, one better than it]; and laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]; and h`*aA bi*aAki [This is instead, or in the place, of that; but see another explanation of this last phrase in what follows]. (The Lubáb, TA.) ― -b8- It also denotes requital; or the giving, or doing, in return; (Mughnee, K;) and in this case is prefixed to the word signifying the substitute, or thing given or done in exchange [or return; or to the word signifying that for which a substitute is given, or for which a thing is given or done in exchange or return]; (Mughnee;) as in the saying, Ai$otarayotuhu biA^alofi dirohamK [I purchased it for a thousand dirhems]; (Mughnee, K; *) [and in the saying in the Kur ix. 112, A_in~a A@ll~`ha A@$otarY mina A@lomuw^ominiyna A^anofusahumo waA^amowaAlahumo biA^an~a lahumu A@lojan~apa Verily God hath purchased of the believers their souls and their possessions for the price of their having Paradise;] and kaAfaA^otu A_iHosaAnahu biDiEofK [I requited his beneficence with a like beneficence, or with double, or more], (Mughnee,) or kaAfA^otuhu biDiEofi A_iHosaAnihi [I requited him with the like, or with double the amount, or with more than double the amount, of his beneficence], (K,) but the former is preferable; (TA;) [and xadama biTaEaAmi biTonihi (S and A &c. in art. wgd) He served for, meaning in return for, the food of his belly;] and
h`*aA bi*aAka walaA EatobN EalaY Alz~amani
[This is in return for that, (an explanation somewhat differing from one in the next preceding division of this paragraph,) and no blame is imputable to fortune]: and hence, AudoxuluwA A@ljan~apa bimaA kunotumo taEomaluwna [Enter ye Paradise in return for that which ye wrought (Kur xvi. 34)]; for the b here is not that which denotes a cause, as the Moatezileh assert it to be, and as all [of the Sunnees] hold it to be in the saying of the Prophet, lano yadoxula A^aHadukumu Aljan~apa biEamalihi [before cited and explained]; because what is given instead of something is sometimes given gratuitously; and it is evident that there is no mutual opposition between the trad. and the verse of the Kur-án. (Mughnee.) ― -b9- It is also syn. with Eano; and is said to be peculiar to interrogation; as in faA@soA^alo bihi xabiyrFA [And ask thou respecting Him, or it, one possessing knowledge (Kur xxv. 60)]; (Mughnee, K;) and accord. to IAar in the Kur lxx. 1; (T;) and in the saying of ' Alkameh,
faA_ino tasoA^aluwniY biAln~isaA='i faA_in~aniy
baSiyrN biA^adowaA='i Aln~isaA='i xabiyru
[And if ye ask me respecting the diseases of women, verily I am knowing in the diseases of women, skilful]: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or it is not peculiar to interrogation; as in wayawoma ta$aq~aqu A@ls~amaA='u biA@logamaAmi [And the day when the heavens shall be rent asunder from the clouds (Kur xxv. 27)]; (Mughnee, K) and maA gar~aka birab~ika (K) i. e. What hath beguiled thee from thy Lord, and from believing in him? in the Kur lxxxii. 6; and so in the same, lvii. 13: (TA: [but see art. gr:]) or, accord. to Z, the b in bAlgmAm means by, as by an instrument; (Mughnee;) or it means because of, or by means of, the rising of the clouds therefrom: (Bd:) and in like manner the Basrees explain it as occurring in faA@soA^alo bihi xabiyrFA, as denoting the cause; and they assert that it is never syn. with Eano; but their explanation is improbable. (Mughnee.) ― -b10- It is also syn. with EalaYi; as in A_ino tiA^omanohu biqinoTaArK (Mughnee, K *) or bidiynaArK (S) [If thou give him charge over a hundredweight or over a deenár (Kur iii. 68)]; like as EalaY is sometimes put in the place of bi as after the verb raDiYa: (S, TA:) and so in lawo tusaw~aY bihimu A@loA^aroDu [That the ground were made even over them], in the Kur [iv. 45], (TA,) i. e. that
they were buried; (Bd) and in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd], accord. to Akh, as before mentioned; (Mughnee, in the first division of the art. on this preposition;) and in zayodN biAls~aToHi [Zeyd is on the roof]; (TA;) and in a verse cited in this Lex. voce vaEolabN. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- It also denotes part of a whole; (Msb in art. bED Mughnee, K;) so accord. to As and AAF and others; (Msb, Mughnee;) as syn. with mino (Msb, TA:) IKt says; the Arabs say, $aribotu bimaA='i ka*aA, meaning minohu [I drank of such a water]; and AZ mentions, as a saying of the Arabs, saqaAka A@ll~`hu mino maA='i ka*aA, meaning bihi [May God give thee to drink of such a water], thus making the two prepositions syn.: (Msb: [in which five similar instances are cited from poets; and two of these are cited also in the Mughnee:]) and thus it signifies in EayonFA ya$orabu bihaA EibaAdu A@ll~`hi [A fountain from which the servants of God shall drink, in the Kur lxxvi. 6; and the like occurs in lxxxiii. 28]; (Msb, Mughnee, K;) accord. to the authorities mentioned above; (Mughnee;) or the meaning is, with which the servants of God shall satisfy their thirst (yarowaY bihaA); (T, Mughnee;) or, accord. to Z, with which the servants of God shall drink wine: (Mughnee:) if the b were redundant, [as some assert it to be, (Bd,)] the meaning would be, that they shall drink the whole of it; which is not right: (Msb:) thus, also, it is used in waA@mosaHuwA biruw^u=sikumo [in the Kur v. 8], (Msb, Mughnee, K,) accord. to some; (Mughnee;) i. e. [And wipe ye] a part of your heads; and this explanation has been given as on the authority of EshSháfi'ee; but he is said to have disapproved it, and to have held that the b here denotes adhesion: (TA:) this latter is its apparent meaning in this and the other instances: or, as some say, in this last instance it is used to denote the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and there is an ellipsis in the phrase, and an inversion; the meaning being, AimosaHuwA ruw^u=sakumo biAlmaA='i [wipe ye your heads with water]. (Mughnee.) ― -b12- It is also used to denote swearing; (Mughnee, K;) and is the primary one of the particles used for this purpose; therefore it is peculiarly distinguished by its being allowable to mention the verb with it, (Mughnee,) as A^uqosimu biA@ll~`hi laA^afoEalan~a [I swear by God I will assuredly do such a thing]; (Mughnee, K) and by its being prefixed to a pronoun, as in bika laA^afoEalan~a [By thee I will assuredly do such a thing]; and by its being used in adjuring, or conjuring, for the purpose of inducing one to incline to that which is desired of him, as in bA@ll~`hi halo qaAma zayodN, meaning I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by God, to tell me, did Zeyd stand? (Mughnee.) [See also the first explanation of this particle, where it is said, on the authority of the L, that, when thus used, it denotes adhesion.] ― -b13- It is also syn. with A_ilay as denoting the end of an extent or interval; as in A^aHosana biY, meaning He did good, or acted well, to me: (Mughnee, K:) but some say that the verb here imports the meaning of laTafa [which is trans. by means of b, i. e. he acted graciously, or courteously, with me]. (Mughnee.) ― -b14- It is also redundant, (S, Mughnee, K,) to denote corroboration: (Mughnee, K:) and is prefixed to the agent: (Mughnee:) first, necessarily; as in A^aHosino bizayodK; (Mughnee, K;) accord. to general opinion (Mughnee) originally A^aHosana zayodN, i. e. SaAra *aA HusonK [Zeyd became possessed of goodness, or goodliness, or beauty]; (Mughnee, K; *) or the correct meaning is Hasuna zayodN [Good, or goodly, or beautiful, or very good &c., is Zeyd! or how good, or goodly, or beautiful, is Zeyd!], as in the B: (TA:) secondly, in most instances; and this is in the case of the agent of kafaY; as in kafaY biA@ll~`hi $ahiydFA [God sufficeth, being witness, or as a witness (Kur xiii., last verse; &c.)]; (Mughnee, K [and a similar ex. is given in the S, from the Kur xxv. 33;]) the b here denoting emphatic praise; but you may drop it, saying, kafaY A@ll~`hu $ahiydFA: (Fr, TA:) thirdly, in a case of necessity, by poetic licence; as in the saying,
A^alamo yaA^otiyka waAlA^anobaA='u tanomiY
bimaA laAqato labuwnu baniY ziyaAdi
[Did not what the milch camel of the sons of Ziyád experienced come to thee (yaA^otiyka being in like manner put for yaA^otika) when the tidings were increasing?]. (Mughnee, K.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the objective complement of a verb; as in walaA tuloquwA biA^ayodykumo A_ilaY A@lt~aholukapi [And cast ye not yourselves (bA^ydykm meaning biA^anofusikumo) to perdition (Kur ii. 191)]; and in wahuz~iY A_ilayoki biji*oEi Aln~axolapi [And shake thou towards thee the trunk of the palm-tree (Kur xix. 25)]: but some say that the former means and cast ye not yourselves (A^anofusakumo being understood) with your hands to perdition; or that the meaning is, by means, or because, of your hands: (Mughnee:) and ISd says that huz~iY, in the latter, is made trans. by means of b because it is used in the sense of juz~iY: (TA in art hz:) so, too, in the saying,
naDoribu biAls~ayofi wa narjuw biAlfarajo
[We smite with the sword, and we hope for the removal of grief]: (S, Mughnee:) and in the trad., kafay biAlmaro'i ka*ibFA A^ano yuHad~iva bikul~i maA samiEa [It suffices the man in respect of lying that he relate all that he has heard]. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the inchoative; as in biHasobika [when you say, biHasobika dirohamN, meaning A thing sufficing thee is a dirhem; a phrase which may be used in two ways; as predicating of what is sufficient, that it is a dirhem; and as predicating of a dirhem, that it is sufficient; in which latter case, bHsbk is an enunciative put before its inchoative, so that the meaning is, a dirhem is a thing sufficing thee, i. e. a dirhem is sufficient for thee; as is shown in a marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee: in the latter way is used the saying, mentioned in the S, biHasobika qawolu Als~awo'i A thing sufficing thee is the saying what is evil: and so, app., each of the following sayings, mentioned in the TA on the authority of Fr; Hasobuka biSadiyqinaA A person sufficing thee is our friend; and naAhiyka biA^axiynaA A person sufficing thee is our brother: the b is added, as Fr says, to denote emphatic praise]: so too in xarajotu faA_i*iA bizayodK [I went forth, and lo, there, or then, was Zeyd]; and in kayofa bika A_i*aA kaAna ka*aA [How art thou, or how wilt thou be, when it is thus, or when such a thing is the case?]; and so, accord. to Sb, in biA^y~ikumu A@lomafotuwnu [mentioned before, in explanation of bi as syn. with fiY]; but Abu-l-Hasan says that bA^y~km is dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, denoting the predicate of Aalmftwn; and some say that this is an inf. n. in the sense of finonapN; [so that the meaning may be, bA^ay~ikumu Almafotuwnu musotaqir~N In which of you is madness residing?]; or, as some say, bi is here syn. with fiY [as I have before mentioned], (Mughnee.) A strange case is that of its being added before that which is originally an inchoative, namely, the noun, or subject, of layosa, on the condition of its being transferred to the later place which is properly that of the enunciative; as in the reading of some, wujuwhakumo] layosa A@lbir~a biA^ano tuwal~uwA [qabala A@loma$oriqi wa A@lomagoribi [Your turning your faces towards the east and the west is not obedience (Kur ii. 172)]; with Albr~ in the accus. case. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the enunciative; and this is in two kinds of cases: first, when the phrase is not affirmative; and cases of this kind may be followed as exs.; as layosa zayodN biqaAy^imK [Zeyd is not standing]; and wamaA A@ll~`hu bigaAfilK Eam~aA taEomaluwna [And God is not heedless of that which ye do (Kur ii. 69, &c.)]: secondly, when the phrase is affirmative; and in cases of this kind, one limits himself to what has been heard [from the Arabs]: so say Akh and his followers; and they hold to be an instance of this kind the phrase, jazaA='u say~iy^apK bimivolihaA [The recompense of an evil action is the like thereof (Kur x. 28)]; and the saying of the Hamásee,
wamanoEukahaA bi$aYo'K yusotaTaAEu
[And the preventing thee from having her (referring to a mare) is a thing that is possible]: but it is more proper to make bmvlhA dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, as the enunciative; [the meaning being, jazaA='u say~ay^apK musotaqir~N bimivolihaA, or yasotaqir~u bimivolihaA, i. e. the recompense of an evil action is a thing consisting in the like thereof]; and to make b$Y' dependent upon mnEkhA; the meaning being, wa manoEukahaA bi$aYo'K m~aA yusotaTaAEu [i. e. and the preventing thee from having her, by something, is possible: see Ham p. 102 ]: Ibn-Málik also [holds, like Akh and his followers, that bi may be redundant when prefixed to the enunciative in an affirmative proposition; for he] says, respecting biHasobika zayodN, that zyd is an inchoative placed after its enunciative, [so that the meaning is, Zeyd is a person sufficing thee,] because zayodN is determinate and Hasobuka is indeterminate. (Mughnee. [See also what has been said above respecting the phrase biHasobika dirohamN, in treating of bi as added before the inchoative.]) It is also redundantly
prefixed to the denotative of state of which the governing word is made negative; as in
famaA rajaEato bixaAy^ibapK rikaAbN
Hakiymu bonu Almusay~abi munotahaAhaA
[And travelling-camels (meaning their riders) returned not disappointed, whose goal, or ultimate object, was Hakeem the son of El-Museiyab]; and in
famaA A@nobaEavota bimazow^udK wa laA wakali
[And thou didst not, being sent, or roused, go away frightened, nor impotent, committing thine affair to another]: so says Ibn-Málik: but AHei disagrees with him, explaining these two exs. as elliptical; the meaning implied in the former being, biHaAjapK xaAy^ibapK [with an object of want disappointed, or frustrated]; and in the second, bi$axoSK mazow^uwdK, i. e. ma*oEuwrK [with a person frightened]; the poet meaning, by the mzw^wd, himself, after the manner of the saying, raA^ayotu minohu A^asadFA; and this is plain with respect to the former ex., but not with respect to the second; for the negation of attributes of dispraise denoted as intensive in degree does not involve the negation of what is simply essential in those attributes; and one does not say, laqiytu minohu A^asadFA, or baHorFA, [or raA^ayotu minohu A^asadFA, as above, or baHorFA,] but when meaning to express an intensive degree of boldness, or of generosity. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the corroborative nafosN and EayonN: and some hold it to be so in yatarab~ana biA^anofusihin~a [as meaning Shall themselves wait (Kur ii. 228 and 234)]: but this presents matter for consideration; because the affixed pronoun in the nom. case, [whether expressed, as in this instance, in which it is the final syllable na, or implied in the verb,] when corroborated by nafos, should properly be corroborated first by the separate [pronoun], as in qumotumo A^anotumo A^anofusukumo [Ye stood, ye, yourselves]; and because the corroboration in this instance is lost, since it cannot be imagined that any others are here meant than those who are commanded to wait: [the preferable rendering is, shall wait to see what may take place with themselves:] bA^nfshn~ is added only for rousing them the more to wait, by making known that their minds should not be directed towards the men. (Mughnee.) Accord. to some, it is also redundantly prefixed to a noun governed in the gen. case [by another preposition]; as in
fA^aSobaHona laA yasoA^alonahu Eano biA^abihi
And they became in a condition in which they asked him not respecting his father; which may perhaps be regarded by some as similar to the saying,
yaDoHakona Eano kaAlbaradi Almunoham~i
but in this instance, ka is generally held to be a noun, syn. with mivol]. (The Lubáb, TA.) ― -b15- Sometimes it is understood; as in All~`h lAfEln~ [i. e. All~`hi laA^afoEalan~a and All~`ha laA^afoEalan~a By God, I will assuredly do such a thing; in the latter as well as the former, for a noun is often put in the accus. case because of a preposition understood; or, accord. to Bd, in ii. 1, a verb significant of swearing is understood]: and in xayorK [for bixayorK In a good state], addressed to him who says, kayofa A^aSobaHota [How hast thou entered upon the time of morning? or How hast thou become?]. (TA.) ― -b16- [It occurs also in several elliptical phrases; one of which (fabihaA wa niEomato) has been mentioned among the exs. of its primary meaning: some are mentioned in other arts.; as biA^abiY and binafosiY, in arts. Abw and nfs: and there are many others, of which exs. here follow.] Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, after hitting a butt with an arrow, A^anaA bhaA A^anaA bhaA, meaning A^anaA SaAHibuhaA [I am the doer of it! I am the doer of it!]. (Sh, T.) And in another trad., Mohammad is related to have said to one who told him of a man's having committed an unlawful action, laEal~aka bi*`liki, meaning laEal~aka SaAHibu AlA^amori [May-be thou art the doer of that thing]. (T.) And in another, he is related to have said to a woman brought to him for having committed adultery or fornication, mano biki, meaning mano SaAHibuki [Who was thine accomplice?]: (T:) or mani AlfaAEilu biki [Who was the agent with thee?]. (TA.) A^anaA bika walaka, occurring in a form of prayer, means I seek, or take, refuge in Thee; or by thy right disposal and facilitation I worship; and to Thee, not to any other, I humble myself. (Mgh in art. bwA.) One says also, mano liY bika*aA, meaning Who will be responsible, answerable, amenable, or surety, to me for such a thing? (Har p. 126: and the like is said in p. 191.) And similar to this is the saying, kaA^an~iY bika, meaning kaA^an~iy A^aboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be to-morrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition. (Idem p. 126.) [You also say, kaA^an~aka bihi, meaning Thou art so near to him that it is as though thou sawest him: or it is as though thou wert with him: i. e. thou art almost in his presence.] ― -b17- The Basrees hold that prepositions do not supply the places of other prepositions regularly; but are imagined to do so when they admit of being differently rendered; or it is because a word is sometimes used in the sense of another word, as in $aribona bimaA='i AlbaHori meaning rawiyna, and in A^aHosana biY meaning laTafa; or else because they do so anomalously. (Mughnee.) -A3- [As a numeral, b denotes Two.]
baA bA and baA='N: see the letter b, and arts. bwA^ and bY

R. Q. 1 baA^obaA^ahu * , (Lth, T, S, M, K,) and bA^bA^ bihi, (Fr, M, K,) inf. n. baA^obaA=apu (Lth, T, M) and bay^obaA='N; (Fr, M;) [as also bA^abiY; see art. biA^abiY A^anota;] He said to him, biA^abiy, (Fr, M,) or bA^abaA, (M,) or biA^abiY A^anota, (Lth, T, K,) [all meaning With my father mayest thou be ransomed! or] meaning A^afodiyka biA^abiY [I will ransom thee with my father]; (Lth, T;) or he said to him, biA^abiY A^anota waA^um~iY [With my father mayest thou be ransomed, and with my mother! or I will ransom thee &c.; see art. Abw]; (S;) the current phrase of the Arabs being that which includes both parents: (TA:) i. e., a man said so to another man, (Lth, T, M,) or to a child; (Fr, S, M;) and in like manner to his horse, for having saved him from some accident: (IAar, T:) the verb is derived from biA^abiY. (Lth, T, M.) Hence AlbiA^abo, in an ex. cited voce A^abN, in art. Abw, q. v.; (M;) or Albiy^abo; (TA in art. Abw;) or Albiyabo. (S in that art.) ― -b2- And [hence,] baA^baw^uwhu They made a show of treating him with graciousness, courtesy, or blandishment; as also Ealayohi ↓ tabaA^obaw^uwA. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] ↓ baA^obaA='N, with medd, [used as an inf. n.,] A woman's dandling, or dancing, of her child. (AA, T.) -A2- baA^obaA^a also signifies He (a child) said ↓ baA^obaA^o (M, K) [in some copies of the K written baAbaA, both meaning Papa, or Father,] to his father. (M.) [Accord. to the TA, the verb is trans. in this sense, as in the senses before explained; but I think that baA^obaA^ahu has been there erroneously put for baA^obaA^a.] ― -b2- And He (a stallion [meaning a stallion-camel]) reiterated the sound of the letter b [or b] in his braying. (M.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] ↓ baA^obaA^N [or, more probably, ↓ baA^obaA='N, with medd, agreeably with analogy, used as an inf. n.,] The chiding of the cat, or act of chiding the cat; (AA, T, Sgh;) also termed gas~N. (AA, T.) -A3- Also He hastened, made haste, or sped: and ↓ tabaA^obaA^onaA we hastened, &c.: (marginal note in a copy of the S:) or ↓ tabaA^obaA^a signifies he ran. (ElUmawee, T, K.)

R. Q. 2
see above, in three places.
baA^obA^o * and baA^obaA^N: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

buw^obuw^N * The source, origin, race, root, or stock, syn. A^aSolN, (AA, Sh, T, S, M, K,) of a man, (Sh, T,) whether noble or base. (AA, T.) You say, huwa kariymu Albuw^obuw^i He is of generous, or noble, origin; lit., generous, or noble, of origin. (TK.) And fulaAnN fiYbuw^obuw^i Alkarami Such a one is of [a race] the source (A^aSol) of generosity, or nobleness. (S. [In the PS, mn is here put in the place of fY: but fY is often used in phrases of the same kind and meaning as that above, in the sense of mino.]) IKh cites from Jereer,
fiY yuw^obuw^i Almajodi wabuHobuwHi Alkaramo
[Of a race the source of glory, and the very heart of generosity, or nobleness]: but Aboo-'Alee El- Kálee quotes the words thus;
fiY Diy^oDiy^i Almajodi wa buw^obuwo'i Alkaramo
[which may be rendered, of a race the source of glory, and the very root of generosity]; whence it appears that buw^obuw'N is a dial. var. of buw^obuw^N in the sense here given. (TA.) ― -b2- The middle of a thing; (K;) [and app. the heart, or very heart, thereof; the middle as being the best part of a thing;] like buHobuwHN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, perhaps,]
The pupil, or apple, or the image that is seen reflected in the black, (Eayor AA, T, or A_inosaAn K,) of the eye. (AA, T, K.) Whence the saying, huwa A^aEaz~u EalaY~i mino buw^obuw^i EayoniY [He is dearer to me than the apple of my eye; a saying common in the present day, with the substitution of A_inosaAn for buw^obuw^]. (TA.) ― -b4- A generous, or noble, (ISk, T,) or a clever, an ingenious, or an accomplished, or a well-bred, or an elegant, (M, K,) and a light, an active, or a sprightly, (M,) lord, master, chief, or personage: (ISk, T, M, K:) fem. with p. (IKh, TA.) ― -b5- Also, (AA, T, S, * [but I find it only in one of three copies of the S,]) or ↓ buw^obuw^o'N, and ↓ baA^obaA='N, (K,) the last from the M, (TA, [but it is not in the M as transcribed in the TT,]) A learned man (AA, T, S, K) who teaches; (AA, T;) but the teaching of others is not a condition required in the application of the epithet; (TA;) like sarosuwrN. (S [in which this last word is evidently given as a syn.: but in the K it is given to show the form, only, of buw^obuwo'N].) ― -b6- Also The body of a locust, (K,) without the head and legs. (TA.) ― -b7- And, accord. to the K, The head, or uppermost part, of a vessel in which [the collyrium called] kuHol is kept: but it will appear, in art. yA^, that this is [perhaps] a mistranscription for yuw^oyuw^N. (TA.)
baA^obaA='N * : see R. Q. 1, in two places: -A2- and see buw^obuw^N.
buw^obuw'N * : see buw^obuw^N, in two places.
Albiy^abo * : see A^abN, in art. Abw.

baAbiliY~N A_bl A_bly bA_bly bAbl bAblY bAbly
Of, or belonging to, or relating to, baAbil [i. e. Babel], a place [well known] in El-'Irák: it is an epithet applied to enchantment, [which is said to have been there taught by two fallen angels, Hároot and Mároot, (see the Kur ii. 96,)] and to wine. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) Poison: [and, accord to the CK, wine;] as also ↓ baAbiliy~apN. (K, TA.) ― -b3- In the original language of the place above mentioned, AlbaAbiliY~u is a name of Almu$otariY [The planet Jupiter]. (TA.)
baAbily~apN A_bly bA_blyh bA_blyp bAbly bAblyh bAblyp : see above.

baAbuwnajN bAbwnj [from the Persian baAbuwnaho Chamomile; or chamomile-flowers: both called by these names in the present day]: a certain herb, of several different colours; yellow-flowered, and whiteflowered, and purple-flowered: (Avicenna [Ibn-Seenà] i. 139:) i. q. A^uqoHuwaAnN: (S, Msb, K, all in art qHw:) i. e. the AqHwAn is the bAbwnj with the Persians: (Msb in that art.:) or the flower of the AqHwAn: (S in art. qrS:) or of the yellow AqHwAn, (TA in art. qrS,) when it has become dry: (S, TA, both in art. qrS:) a well-known flower, of great utility, (K, TA,) or of which the oil is of great utility: (CK:) commonly known in El-Yemen by the name of mwns [app. muw^onisN, because of its pleasant odour, or its medical properties]. (TA.)

baA^ojN * , also pronounced baAjN, without ', (IAar, S, Msb, K,) but the former alone is mentioned by Th in the Fs, and is the chaste word, (TA,) arabicized, from the Persian baAhaA, (S,) A sort, or species, (S, K,) of food, or viands. (S.) Hence the saying, AijoEali AlbaA^ojaAt baA_ojAF waAHidFA [Make thou the sorts, or species, of food, or viands, to be one sort, or species]: (S, K:) occurring in a trad., in which it is without ' in each case, accord. to IDrst: several different sorts of food being brought to 'Omar, he asked respecting them, and it was said, [They are] sikobaAj and zirobaAj and A_isofiydobaAj; whereupon he ordered that the bowls should be brought, and their contents were emptied into one; he saying the words above. (Marginal note in a copy of the S.) IKh says that a man would bring various sorts [of food], and one would say, AijoEalohaA bA^ojAF waAHdiA [Make thou them to be one sort]. (TA.) The pl. is [baA^ojaAtN, as shown above, as though the sing. were baA^ojapN, and] A^abowaAjN. (Msb, TA.) laA^ajoEalan~a Aln~aAsa kul~ahumo baA^ojFA waAHidFA is [likewise] a saying of 'Omar, (Msb, TA,) meaning [I will assuredly make the people, all of them, to be] one body or assemblage; baA^ojN signifying a state of assembling, or collecting together: (Kz, TA:) or [of] one uniform way or mode or manner, (Msb, TA,) as El-Fihree says in the Expos. of the Fs, on the authority of ISd in the book entitled El-'Awees; (TA;) i. e., in respect of gifts, or allowances: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, it is from baA^ojN or baAjN signifying a uniform line of road. (TA.) You say also, Aln~aAsu baA^ojN waAHidN The people are [as] one thing. (TA.) And humo fiY A^amorK baA^ojK They are [in one and the same, or] in an equal, or a uniform, case. (K.) And jaEala AlkalaAma baA^ojAF waAxidFA He made the speech, or language, to be [uniform, or] of one mode, or manner. (TA.) And AijoEalo h`*A Al$~aYo'a baA^ojFA waAHidFA Make thou this thing to be [uniform, or] of one way, or mode, or manner. (ISk.) And AijoEali AlA^amora baA^ojFA waAHidFA Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr.)

baA*anojaAnN * , [or baA*inojaAnN, commonly pronounced in the present day baAdnojaAn and bayodinojaAn and biydinojaAn, from the Persian baAdinokaAno,] a word of well-known meaning, often mentioned by the author of the K, [in explaining the words A^anabN and HadaqN and magodN and wagodN,] but not in its proper place in the lexicon. (TA.) [It signifies The solanum melongena, mad-apple, or egg-plant; both the black, distinguished by the epithet A^asowadu, and the white, distinguished by the epithet A^aboyaDu. And the solanum lycopersicum, or solanum Aethiopicum; also called love-apple, and so by the Arabs, tuf~aAHN AlHub~Ni; and golden apple, tuf~aAHN *ahabiY~N; and tomato; and distinguished from the former species by the epithet A^aHomaru, and by the appellation bA*njAn quwTap.] ― -b2- [baA*anojaAnN tiroyaAqiY~N Xanthium.]

1 baA^ara * , (S, M, K,) aor.
baAa^a , (M, K,) He sunk, or dug, (S, M, K,) a well; (S, M;) as also ↓ AbtA^r. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. baA^orN, He dug a [hollow such as is termed] buw^orap, (AZ, S, M,) in which to cook. (AZ, S.) ― -b3- Also, (T, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (M, K,) and so the inf. n.; (M;) and ↓ AbtA^r; (T, S, M, K;) He hid, or concealed, a thing: (T, M, K:) and he stored it, or laid it up, for a time of need. (T, S, K.) Hence a hollow dug in the ground is termed buw^orapN. (T.) ― -b4- You say also, xayorFA ↓ AbtA^r, (T, M, K,) and baA^arahu, (M, K,) He did good beforehand: (T, M, K:) or, accord. to some, he, as it were, did good beforehand for himself, having laid it up, or concealed it, for himself: (T, TA:) so says El-Umawee: or he laid up for himself in store concealed good: (TA:) or he did good concealedly: (M, K:) and Ay^tbr signifies the same. (T, TA.)

(of pauc., S, Msb) A^abow^urN (S, M, Msb, K) and (by transposition, Fr, Msb) A=burN (Fr, Msb, K) and A^aboA=rN and (by transposition, Yaakoob, T, S, M) A=baArN and (of mult., S, Msb) biy^aArN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and pl. of pauc. baA^~==rN * , (T, TA, and so in some copies of the K,) or A^ab~aArN, (as in other copies of the K and so in the CK,) the latter formed by transposition, and the former [said to have been] not heard, (M,) A well-sinker, or well-digger. (T, M, K.)

baA^ozN *
i. q. baAzK [which see in art. bzw; and baAzN]: pl. [of pauc.] A^abow^uzN, and [of mult.] buw^uwzN and biy^ozaAnN. (K.) IJ holds that the A^ is substituted for A, and that it remains in Abw^z and by^zAn like as is the case in A^aEoyaAdN [in which the Y is substituted for w
and remains in the pl. because it is substituted for w in the sing. EiydN]. (TA.)

1 baw^usa * , aor. yabow^usu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. baA^osN, (S, Msb, K,) or baA^osapN; (M; [so I find in a copy of the M, but perhaps it is a mistranscription for baA=sapN;]) and bay^isa, [aor. yaboA^asu,] inf. n. baA^osN; (M;) He was, or became, mighty, or strong, in war or fight; (K;) courageous, or valiant: (M, Msb, K:) or very mighty or strong in war or fight. (AZ, S.) -A2- bay^osu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaboA^asu (S, M, K) and yaboy^isu, the latter extr., like yanoEimu aor. of naEima, (M,) [and some other instances, (see Hasiba,)] inf. n. buw^osN (S, Msb, * K) and buw^uwsN and buw^osaY (K) and baA^osN (TA) and bay^ysN, (S, K,) [in measure] like A^amiyrN, (TA,) [accord. to the CK biy^osN, which is a mistake,] and bay^iysaY, (TS, TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K biy^osay; (TA;) or baw^usa; (A;) or both these forms; (M;) He was, or became, in a state of distress; straitened in his means of subsistence, or in the conveniences of life; (M, Msb;) in a state of poverty: (M, A, Msb, * TA:) or in a state of pressing want: (S, K, TA:) and baw^usa, inf. n. baA=sapN and bay^iysN, whence the subst. baw^osaY, he was, or became, in a state of trial, or affliction: (M:) and [in like manner,] ↓ A^aboA^asa, (inf. n. A_iboA=sN,S,) distress, or poverty, or misfortune, or calamity, (AlbaA^osaA='u,) befell him. (IAar, S, * M, TA.) -A3- biy^osa, also written bay^isa and biy^isa and baA^osa, (S, K,) is a word of dispraise or blame, (S,) implying all kinds of dispraise or blame, (TA,) [or superlative dispraise or blame; signifying, Very evil or bad is he, or it: or superlatively evil or bad is he, or it:] contr. of niEma: (S, M, TA:) a pret. verb, imperfectly inflected, (S, K,) like niEoma, (S,) [having only one variation of form, namely, the fem. biy^osato, though the masc. is more commonly used even when the agent is fem. or pl.,] because it is translated from its original application, (S, K,) i. e. from bay^isa fulaAnN signifying A^aSaAba buw^osFA [he found, met with, or experienced, distress, &c.], to signify dispraise or blame. (S, TA.) When it is accompanied by a gen. n. without the article Al, this is always in the accus. case: but when the n. has the article Al, it is always in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, biy^osa rajulFA zayodF [Very evil or bad, or superlatively evil or bad, as a man, is Zeyd; rjlA being a specificative]: (K:) and biy^osa Alr~ajulu zayodN [Very evil, &c., is the man, Zeyd]; and biy^osati AlmaroA^apu hinodN [or more commonly biy^osa AlEayoru in this case also, Very evil, &c., is the woman, Hind]. (S.) Some argue that it is a noun, from the saying, niEoma Als~ayoru EalaY biy^osa AlEayoru, because it has a prep.; but this is explained as elliptical, and meaning, niEama Als~ayoru EalaY EayorK maquwlK fiyhi biy^osa AlEyoru [Excellent is the journeying upon an ass of which it is said Very evil, &c., is the ass]. (I 'Ak p. 232.) Zj says that when it is followed by maA, then maA, with it, is regarded as occupying the place of an indeterminate noun; [namely, $ayoy^FA, as a specificative; as in the Kur ii. 84,biy^osa maA A@$otarawA bihi A^anofusahumo, or biy^osamaA, &c., Very evil, &c., as a thing, is that for which they have sold, or exchanged, themselves:] (TA:) but some say that it is the agent, and is a determinate noun; and this is the opinion of Ibn-Kharoof, which he ascribes to Sb. (I 'Ak ubi suprà.) [For further illustration, see niEoma.]

He feigned the lowliness, or submissiveness, of poverty, humbling, or abasing, himself, (K,* TA,) with men; and ↓ tabaA^~asa is allowable in the same sense. (TA.)

8 AbtA^s bihi * , (M, A,) and minohu, (S, TA,) He was distressed by it, or at it; it does not signify dislike: (IB, TA:) or he grieved at it, (S, M, A,) and humbled and abased himself: so in the Kur xi. 38 and xii. 69. (M, A, TA.) It is said of a man when a thing that he dislikes becomes known to him. (AZ, TA.)

baA^osN *
Might, or strength, (S, A, Msb, K,) in war or fight: (S, A, K:) courage; valour, or valiantness; prowess. (M, K.) ― -b2- War, or fight; (M, Msb;) as also ↓ bay^iyosN (M) and ↓ baA^osaA='u: (TA:) pl. of the first,A^abow^asN. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence, (M,) (assumed tropical:) Fear, (M, TA,) in the saying, laA bA^osa Ealayoka, (M, TA, *) and bika, (M,) [(assumed tropical:) There is no fear for thee: lit., there is no war against thee, or with thee]: the saying of which to an enemy implies the granting him security, or protection: and in the same sense it is used in a trad., in the phrase Ai$otad~a AlbaA^osu [(assumed tropical:) Fear became vehement]. (TA.) ― -b4- I. q. DararN (assumed tropical:) [Harm, injury, &c.]: so in the phrase laA baA^osa [There is, or will be, no harm, &c.; and laA baA^osa bika*aA, and fiY ka*aA, (assumed tropical:) There is, or will be, no harm in such a thing]. (Har p. 311.) It is said in a trad., laA baA^osa biA@loginay limani A@t~aqay [There is no harm in wealth to him who is pious]. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee.) baAs also occurs for baA^os; the being suppressed, agreeably with analogy; not altered by permutation. (M, TA.) ― -b5- Punishment: (S, A, K:) or severe punishment; (TA;) as also ↓ bay^isN, in measure like katifN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b6- See also buw^osN, in two places.

buw^osN * (also written buwsN, with the suppressed, Msb) Distress; straitness of the means of subsistence, or of the conveniences of life; poverty: (M, Msb,* TA:*) or a state of pressing want: (S, K:) or misfortune; calamity: (A:) and ↓ buw^uwsN and ↓ buw^osaY (K, TA) and ↓ baA^osaA='u (M, A) and ↓ baA^osN (TA) and ↓ bay^iysN (S, K) and ↓ bay^iysaY (TA) and ↓ maboA^asapN (M, TA) [all of which, except ↓ baA^osaA='u and ↓ maboA^asapN, are said to be inf. ns. (see bay^isa)] signify the same as buw^osN: (S, M, A, K, TA:) ↓ buw^osaY and ↓ baA^osaA='u are both from buw^osN [with which they are syn. accord. to authorities indicated above]; (Zj, IDrd, TA;) the former is contr. of nuEomaY, (S, TA,) and in like manner the latter is contr. of naEomaA='u: (TA:) the latter is of the measure faEolaA='u without any A^afoEalu, because it is a subst.; like as A^afoEalu occurs among substs. without any faEalaA='u, as in the instance of A^aHomadu: (Akh, S:) or ↓ buw^osaY signifies a state of trial or affliction, and is a subst.; and ↓ bay^iysN and ↓ baA=sapN signify the same, but are inf. ns.: (M:) and ↓ baA^osaA='u is syn. with $id~apN [like buw^osN in the first of the senses explained above]; (S, TA;) and ma$aq~apN [meaning distress, or difficulty]: (TA:) or it signifies misfortune, or calamity, (A, K,) like buw^osN; (A;) and so A^abow^usN: (S, K:) or rather this last signifies misfortunes, or calamities; for it is pl. of ↓ baA^osN, i. e., a pl. of pauc.; not of buw^osN, as J asserts it to be; for the pl. of pauc. of buw^osN is A^aboA=sN: (IB, TA:) but A^abow^usN may be used as pl. of ↓ baA^osaA='u. (Fr, in S, voce Dar~aA='u, q. v.) [See exs. of these two pls. in what follows.] You say yawomu buw^osK wayawomu nuEomK [A day of distress, or poverty, &c., and a day of ease and plenty]. (S, TA.) And buw^osFA lahu [May distress, or poverty, &c., befall him]: a form of imprecation. (Sb, M, TA.) And buw^osa A@boni sumay~apa, app. an expression of pity [meaning Alas for the distress, &c., of Ibn-Sumeiyeh!]. (TA, from a trad.) And EasaYa Alguwayoru A^abow^usFA Perhaps the little cave [may be attended with] calamities; not calamity, as in the S [and K]: (IB:) a prov.; (S;) originating from a cave's having collapsed upon some men in it; or from an enemy's having come to some men in a cave, and slain them; wherefore it is applied to anything whence evil is feared: (As, S, K, in art. gwr:) or it is applied to him who is suspected of a thing: (IAar, TA:) or Alguwayoru was the name of a certain water, which belonged to the tribe of Kelb, and the words of this prov. were said by Ez-Zebbà, when Kaseer turned aside from the plain road, and took the way to Alguwayoru: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, S, K, in art. gwr:)Abw^sA is in the accus. case by reason of yakuwnu understood. (Mughnee.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94.] ElKumeyt also says,
qaAluwA A^asaA='a banuw kurozK faqulotu lahumo
EasaY Alguwayoru biA^aboA=sK waA^gowaAri
[They said, Benoo-Kurz have done evil: and I said to them, Perhaps the little cave may be attended with calamities and connected with other caves]: A^aboA=s is here pl. of buw^os. (IB, TA.) [In the S, the last words are written biA_iboA=sK waA_iEowaArK, in one copy: in another, wA_igowaAri: both of which are app. wrong.] ― -b2- See also baAy^isN.
biy^osN * and biyosN and bayosN and bay~isN: see bay^iysN. ― -b2- banaAtu biy^osK Calamities; misfortunes. (K.)
bay^isN * : see baA^osN, last signification: -A2- and see bay^iysN.
buw^osaY * : see buw^osN, in three places.

baA^osaA='u * : see baA^osN: and buw^osN: the latter, in five
places. ― -b2- Zj explains it as signifying, in the Kur vi. 42, Hunger. (M, TA. *) ― -b3- Also The act of beating, or striking. (Lth, TA.)
baw^uwsN * One in whom buw^os [i. e. distress &c.] is apparent, or manifest. (M, TA.)
buw^uwsN * : see buw^osN

bay^ysN * : see baA^osN: and buw^osN: the latter, in two places. -A2- Mighty, or strong, in war or fight; (A;) courageous, or valiant. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Ea*aAbN by^iysN, (S, M, K,) and ↓ biy^iysN, agreeably with a general rule applying to words of this description, (M,) and ↓ biy^osN, (M, K,) and ↓ bay^isN, (M,) and ↓ bayoy^asN, (M, K,) and ↓ bay^oy^asN, (M,) and ↓ bay~isN, and ↓ bayosN, which last, however, is of no authority, (M,) or ↓ biysN, and bayiysN, with the changed into Y, (TA,) A vehement punishment: (S, M, K:) so in the Kur vii. 165. (TA.)
biy^iysN * : see bay^ysN.
baA=sapN bA=sh bA=sp : see buw^osN.
bay^iysay * : see buw^osN.

baAy^isN *
Distressed; straitened in his means of subsistence, or in the conveniences of life; (Msb;) or poor: (A, Msb: *) or one who is in want, and an object of pity for what he suffers: (TA:) or in a state of pressing want: (S:) or in a state of trial, or affliction: (M, TA:) or one who is crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by disease, or who suffers from a protracted disease, and is in need: (Mgh:) an epithet denoting pity, (Sb, M, TA,) or grief: (Mgh:) ↓ buw^osN occurs as its pl.; (M, TA;) or is for *awuwbuw^osK. (M.)
bayoy^asN * and bayoy^isN: see bay^iysN. ― -b2- The former also signifies Strong. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) Albayoy^asu The lion. (K, TA.)

AlA_ibaA=A_u AlA^aboA^asu *
The most vehement refusal. (Th, M.)
maboA^asapN * : see buw^osN, in two places.

mubotay^isN *
Disliking, or hating: (S, M, K:) and grieving: (S, K:) or rather, distressed, by, or at, a thing; not disliking, or hating: (IB, TA:) or grieving, and humbling and abasing himself. (Zj, M, TA.)
maA baA^ahotu lahu * : see bahaA^a.

baborN bbr br
A certain beast of prey, (M, K,) well known; (K;) a certain animal, (Msb,) namely, the furaAniq [or lion's provider], (S,) that emulates, or vies with, the lion in running, or that is hostile to the lion: [so may be rendered the words yuEaAdiY AlA^asada; and in the uncertainty that exists respecting the animal in question, the meaning of this expression is doubtful: an animal may be called (as the jackal is) the lion's provider merely because the lion follows it and deprives it of its prey:] (S, Msb:) or a certain Indian animal, stronger than the lion, between which and the lion and leopard, or panther, (namir,) exists hostility (muEaAdaApN); when it attacks the leopard, or panther, (nmr,), the lion aids the latter; but the scorpion is on friendly terms with it, and sometimes makes its abode in its hair: (Kzw:) the word is foreign, or Persian, (A^aEojamiY~N,) [app. the Persian babaro, which is said to be applied to the tiger, leopard, and lion,] arabicized: (M, K:) Az thinks it to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language: (Msb:) pl. bubuwrN. (S, Msb, K.)

babogaA='u bbgA=' (Msb, K) and bab~agaA='u (K, Kzw) [in modern vulgar Arabic babagaAn, The parrot;] a certain well-known bird; (Msb;) a certain green bird, (Sgh, K, TA,) well known; (TA;) the bird called in Persian TuwTiy, beautiful in colour and form, mostly green, but in some instances red, and yellow, and white; having a thick bill and tongue: it hears the speech of men and repeats it, without knowing its meaning; and utters letters rightly: when they desire to teach it, they put a mirror in its cage, so that it sees therein its own form, and they speak to it from behind the mirror, and when it hears, it repeats, desiring to do as its like; and thus it learns quickly: one of the wonders relating to it is [said to be this], that it never drinks water; for if it drank, it would die: (Kzw:) the affix renders fem. the word, but not the thing named thereby, like the p in HamaAmapN and naEaAmapN; for the word applies to the male and the female, so that one says, babogaA='u *akarN [a male parrot] and babogaA='u A^unovaY [a female parrot]: and the pl. is babogaAwaAtN [or bab~agaAwaAtN], like as SaHoraAwatN is pl. of SaHoraA='u. (Msb.)

batu3a and

bati3a ; the last having but one form [of aor.]; (S;) inf. n. bat~N: (Lth, T, S, M, A, &c.:) and ↓ Abt~hu, (M,) inf. n. A_ibotaAtN: (Mgh, K:) He cut it off, severed it, separated it, or disunited it, (Lth, T, S, M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K, *) entirely, or utterly; (Lth, T, M;) namely, a thing; (M;) a rope, or cord; (Lth, T;) and a tie, or bond, of union between two persons. (M.) ― -b2- [bat~ahu and ↓ Abt~hu, accord. to the TA, app. signify also He, or it, caused him (a man) to become unable to proceed in his journey, his camel that bore him breaking down, or stopping from fatigue, or perishing: for Anbt~ as signifying “he became so” is there said to be quasi-pass. of those two verbs when it has this sense. Hence,] bat~ahu Als~afaru [The journey caused him to become cut off, &c.]. (A.) And saAqa daAb~atahu Hat~ay bat~ahaA [He urged on his beast so that, or until, he caused it to become cut off, &c.]: (A:) and baEiyrahu ↓ A^abat~a He caused his camel to become cut off, &c., (qaTaEapu,) by travel: (M, TA:) this is not said but of a man who has forced on his camel at a hard pace, or by laborious journeying. (TA.) ― -b3- bat~a TalaAqa A@moraA^atihi, (T, Msb, TA,) or TalaAqa AlmaroA^api, (Mgh,) and ↓ A^abat~ahu, (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb,) He made the divorce of his wife, or of the woman, to be absolutely separating, (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb, TA,) so as to cut her off from return. (Msb.) Lth, with whom AZ agrees, has erred in asserting that bat~a is intrans. and ↓ A^abat~ trans.: (T, TA:) both are trans. and intrans., (T, Msb, TA,) as En-Nawawee asserts in the Tahdheeb el-Asmà wa-1-Loghát. (TA.) You say, AlT~aloqapu AlwaAHidapu tabut~u, and ↓ tubit~u, i. e. The single divorce cuts the matrimonial tie, or bond, of the woman, (taqoTaEu EiSomapa Aln~ikaAHi, T, Mgh, *) when the period during which she must wait before contracting a new marriage has ended. (T.) [See also bat~N.] ― -b4- bat~a Ealayohi AlqaDaA='a, (T, S, M, A,) inf. n. bat~N; (M;) and ↓ A^abat~ahu; (T, S, M;) He (the judge, T) decided the judgment, or sentence, against him. (T, S, * M.) ― -b5- bat~a Ealayohi Al$~ahaAdapa, and ↓ A^abat~ahaA, He decided against him by the testimony, [or pronounced the testimony decisive against him,] and compelled, or constrained, him to admit it. (M.) ― -b6- bat~a $ahaAdatahu, and ↓ A^abat~ahaA, He gave his testimony decisively. (Msb.) ― -b7- A^abut~u A^an~ahu qaAla I know, or declare, decidedly, not [merely] thinking it, that he said thus. (Saheeh of Muslim.) ― -b8- bat~a Aln~iy~apa He made the intention decided; or fixed it decidedly. (A.) It is said in a trad., laA SiyaAma limano AlS~yaAmi mina All~ayoli ↓ lamo yubit~a, (T, S, Mgh,) or lamo yabut~a, accord. to different recitals, (Mgh,) i. e. There is no fasting to him [meaning his fasting is null] who does not decisively impose it upon himself, by intention, from the night: (S, * Mgh:) or, who does not form the intention of fasting before daybreak, and thus cut it off from the time in which there is no fasting, namely, the night: the intention is termed bat~N [and A_ibotaAtN] because it makes a division between non-fasting and fasting: (T, TA:) lamo yubit, from AlA_ibaAtapu, is a mistake; but lm yubay~it, from Alt~aboyiytu, [see bay~ata,] is correct. (Mgh.) And it is said in another trad., nikaAHa h`*ihi Aln~isaA='i ↓ A^abit~uwA, i. e. Decide ye the affair respecting the marriage of these women, and confirm it by its [proper] conditions: an oblique prohibition of the kind of marriage termed nikaAHu AlmutoEapi, because it is a marriage not [absolutely or lawfully] decided, [being] made definite as to duration. (TA.) ― -b9- bat~a also signifies He made to have, or take, effect; he executed, or performed; (Har p. 210;) and so ↓ Abt~, as in the phrase, Abt~ yamiynahu He made his oath to have, or take, effect; he executed, or performed, it. (M.) ― -b10- sakoriAnu maA yabut~u kalaAmFA, (Ks, T, M,) and mA yabit~u, (M,) and ↓ mA yubit~u, (Ks, T, M,) One who is drunk, who does not speak plainly, or distinctly; lit., who does not make speech plain, or distinct; (Ks, T;) or who does not articulate speech; syn. maA yaqoTaEuhu: (M:) or,
as As says, (T,) sakoraAnu maA yabut~u, (T, A,) or laA yabut~u, (S, K,) and lA yabit~u, and ↓ lA yubat~u, (K,) which last form of the verb is disallowed by As, but both are correct accord. to Fr, (T, S,) meaning one who is drunk, who does not, or will not, [i. e. cannot,] decide an affair. (As, T, S, K.) [See also baAt~N.] -A2- See also 7. ― -b2- [Hence,] bat~to yamiynuhu, (M, Msb,) aor.
bati3a only, inf. n. butuwtN, (Msb,) His oath bad, or took, effect; was executed, or performed; syn. wajabato: (M:) it was, or proved, true: (Msb:) a phrase mentioned by AZ, and, if correct, not needing any explanation. (M.) [See Abt~ yamiynahu, above.] -A3- bat~a, aor.
bati3a , inf. n. butuwtN, He was, or became, lean, or meagre. (M, K.) [See baAt~N.] -A4- bat~N [inf. n. of bat~a] also signifies The selling, and the weaving, a [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn [or bat~, q. v.]. (KL.)

It was, or became, cut off, severed, separated, or disunited, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) entirely, or utterly; (Lth, T, M;) namely, a thing; (M;) a rope, or cord; (Lth, T;) and a tie, or bond, of union between two persons: (T, M: *) as also ↓ bat~a, (Lth, AZ, T, M, Msb,) aor.
bati3a and
