[See also munobat~N.] ― -b3- His maA=', (A,) the mA=' of his back, (Ks, T, K,) [i. e. his seminal fluid,] became cut off, or stopped, or ceased, (Ks, T, A, K,) by reason of age: (A:) said of a man. (Ks, T, A.)

bat~N bAt bt btt inf. n. of 1, q. v. (Lth, T, S, M, &c.) [It is sometimes used as an inf. n.; as also ↓ bat~pN and ↓ bataAtN, explained in the M as syn. with qaToEN: and sometimes, as is often the case with inf. ns., in the sense of the act. part. n. of its verb, namely ↓ baAt~N, trans. and intrans.; as also ↓ bataAtN; both of which are masc. and fem., because originally inf. ns.; but bat~N has also bat~apN for its fem. The following are exs.] ― -b2- A^aEoTayotuhu h`*ihi AlEaTiy~apa bat~aA batolFA [I gave him this gift, cutting it off from my property so as to make it irrevocable; or, it being cut off &c.]. (Lth, T.) And taSad~aqa ↓ fulaAnN SadaqapF bataAtFA, and SadaqapF bat~apF batolapu, (T, S,) Such a one bestowed an alms, or a gift for the sake of God, cut off from his property; (T, TA;) and therefore, (TA,) parted from himself. (S, TA.) Such a gift is termed SadaqapN bat~apN, (A, * Nh,) and Sdqp bat~apN batolapN. (M.) ― -b3- Tal~aqahaA, (Mgh, K,) and ↓ bataAtFA, (K,) and Albat~apa, (T,) and TaloqapF bat~apF, (Msb,) and ↓ TalaAqFA baAt~aA, (Lth, T, Msb, * TA, [in one copy of the T simply baAt~aA,]) He divorced her by a separating divorce; (K;) by a divorce cutting her off from returning: and such a divorce is also termed ↓ TlAq mubit~N: (Msb:) or the first of these phrases signifies he divorced her by a divorce either cut off, [meaning decided and irrevocable,] or cutting off. (Mgh.) And Tal~aqahaA valaAvFA bat~apF, (As, T, S, M, Msb,) and ↓ bataAtFA, (M,) He divorced her by three divorces so as to cut her off from returning: (M, Msb:) or by three divorces cut off from himself [so as to be irrevocable]: (S:) or by three divorces cutting off [from returning]. (TA.) ― -b4- Halafa bat~aA, and bat~apF, and ↓ bataAtFA, [may mean He swore decidedly, or decisively; or irrevocably: or] he swore with effect, or execution, or performance; [see 1, near the end of the paragraph;] from the signification of “ cutting ,” or “ cutting off, ” &c.: (M:) [or, as also] Halafa yamiynFA bat~FA, and bat~apF, (Msb, TA,) and ↓ baAt~apF, (Mgh, * Msb,) and ↓ bataAtFA, (TA,) he swore an oath that was, or proved, true. (Msb.) ― -b5- TaHana biAlr~aHaY bat~FA He ground with the mill, turning it, (AZ, T,) or beginning the turning, (S,) from his left: (AZ, T, S:) [i. e., making it to turn in the contrary way of the hands of a watch: the last word is app. an inf. n.; as though meaning effectually; for this is the general and easier or more powerful way of turning the handmill:] the contrary way is termed $azorFA: (AZ, T, S: *) or TaHana bat~aA signifies he began in the turning [of the mill] with the left [hand]. (K: [but biAlyasaAri is here evidently put by mistake for Eani AlyasaAri.]) -A2- A kind of TayolasaAn [q. v.] called saAj, (Lth, T,) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', (M, Mgh,) square, or four-sided, (Lth, T, M,) thick, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) loose, or uncompact, in texture, (M,) and green [or rather of a dingy ash-colour, or dark dust-colour, for such is the general meaning of A^axoDaru, the term here used, when applied to a garment of this kind]; (Lth, T, M;) or, as some say, (M,) of [the soft hair termed] wabar, and of wool; (M, Mgh;) and thus described in the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh: (TA:) or a TylsAn of [the material termed] xaz~, (S Mgh, K,) and the like: (S, K:) pl. butuwtN, (Lth, T, S, Mgh,) or bitaAtN, (M,) but the former occurs in trads. [&c.], (TA,) and [pl. of pauc.] A^abut~N. (M.)

bat~apN bAt bt bth btp btth : see bat~N. ― -b2- laA A^afoEaluhu A@lobat~apa, (S, M, K,) as also bat~apF, (S, K,) the latter mentioned by IF, (Msb,) but IB says that Sb and his companions allow only the former, and that only Fr allows the latter, (TA,) and some say that the former has been heard pronounced with the disjunctive. [Aalobat~apa], (MF,) and thus it is written in a copy of the K, (TA,) but others greatly disapprove of this, (MF,) [meaning I will not do it, decidedly, or absolutely,] is said of anything in respect of which there is no returning, or revoking; (S, IF, M, Msb, K;) Alabt~apa being said of a thing to be done, or performed, irrevocably, and from which there is no abstaining by reason of sluggishness; (T;) as though the speaker cut off the doing of the thing: (M:) the last word is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: (S:) Sb says, it is a corroborative inf. n., and is not used without Al. (M.) It is said in a trad., A^aHosibuhu qaAla juwayoriyap A^awi A@lobapa qaAla [I think he said Juweyriyeh, or decidedly he said so]; as though the speaker doubted of the female's name, and said, “ I think it was Juweyriyeh; ” then corrected, and said, “ or I know, ” or “ declare, ” “ decidedly, (A^abut~u, i. e. A^aqoTaEu,) that he said Juweyriyeh: I do not [merely] think. ” (Saheeh of Muslim.)

bataAtN btAt btp btyp : see bat~N, in seven places. ― -b2- A man is said to be EalaY bataAti A^amorK, meaning On the point of [accomplishing, or deciding,] an affair. (S, A, K.) A rájiz says,
waHaAjapK kunotu EalaY bataAtihaA
[Many a needful affair I was on the point of accomplishing]. (S.) -A2- Travelling provisions: (S, M, A, K:) and requisites, equipments, or furniture; syn. jahaAzN: (S, K:) pl. A^abit~apN. (S.) A verse of Tarafeh cited voce baAEa exhibits an ex. of the former signification. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The utensils and furniture of the house or tent; or household goods: (S, M, K:) pl. as above. (K.) It is said in a trad., laA yuw^oxa*u minokumo Eu$oru AlbataAti [The tithe of the utensils &c. of the house or tent shall not be taken from you]: (S:) i. e., no poor-rate shall be levied upon such utensils &c. that are not for traffic. (A 'Obeyd.)
bat~aY~N bt btY bty : see what next follows.
bat~aAtN btAt btp btyp (S, Mgh, K) and ↓ bat~iY~N (S, K) A maker, (S,) or seller, of the kind of garment called bat~. (S, Mgh, K.)

baAt~N bAt b|t |ty : see bat~N, in three places. ― -b2- Cut off from [the possession of] reason, or intellect, by drunkenness: (AHn, M:) or drunken: (K:) and stupid, or foolish: (S, K:) and A^aHomaqu baAt~N signifies very stupid or foolish, (T, M,) accord. to Lth; but [Az adds,] what we remember to have heard from those deserving of confidence is taAb~N, from Alt~abaAbu, meaning AlxasaAru; like as one says, A^aHomaqu
xaAsirN daAbirN daAmirN [explained in art. xsr]. (T.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.] ― -b3- Also Lean, or meagre, (S, M, K,) and unable to rise, or stand. (TA.)
TalaAqN mubit~N TlAq mbt : see bat~N.
mabotuwtapN mbtwt mbtwth mbtwtp A woman absolutely separated by divorce, so as to be cut off from return: originally mabotuwtN TalaAquhaA. (Mgh, Msb.)

munobat~N mnbt A man unable to proceed in his journey, his camel that bore him having broken down, or stopped from fatigue, or perished; (T, M, * TA;) syn. munoqaTaEN bihi: (S, Mgh, TA:) or who remains on his road unable to attain the place to which he is directing his course, the beast or camel that bore him (Zahoruhu) having broken down, or stopped from fatigue, or perished. (TA.)

1 batara A^btr btr , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor
batura , (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. batorN; (T, S, M, &c.;) and ↓ Abtr; (T;) He cut, or cut off, a thing before it was complete: (S, A, L, Msb:) or he cut, or cut off, (M, Mgh, K,) in any manner: (M:) or he cut off (a tail or the like, T) entirely, or utterly. (Aboo-Is-hák, T, M, K.) ― -b2- batarahu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) or ↓ Abtrhu; (M, L;) He cut off his tail: (K:) or he cut, or amputated, his tail in any place. (M, L.) ― -b3- batara raHimahu, (M,) aor. as above, (M, K,) and so the inf. n., (M,) (assumed tropical:) He cut, or severed, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; he disunited himself from his relations. (M, K. *) -A2- batira, aor.
batara , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. batarN, (S, Msb,) He (any beast, M) had his tail cut off: (S, Msb, K:) or [had either the whole or a part of his tail cut off;] had his tail cut, or amputated, in any place. (M.)
4 A^abotara see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Abtrhu said of God, He made him to be. or become, A^abotar, (S, K,) i. e., without offspring, or progeny. (TA.)
5 tabat~ara see 7.

7 Anbtr A^nbtr Anbtr {nbtr
It (a tail or the like, T) became cut, or cut off, (T, S, M, K, TA,) in any place, (M,) or entirely; (T, M;) and ↓ tbt~r signifies the same. (TA.)
butaArN btAr : see baAtirN
batuwrN btwr : see baAtirN
butayoraA='u btyrA=' : see A^abotaru.
bt~ArNa btAr : see baAtirN

baAtirN bAtr A cutting, or sharp, sword; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ bat~aArN (T, M, K) and ↓ batuwrN (M) and ↓ bataArN. (K.) [But all of these except the first are app. intensive epithets, signifying very sharp.] ― -b2- See also A^ubaAtirN.

A^abotaru * A tail cut off entirely. (T, L.) ― -b2- Any beast (M) having the tail cut off: (T, S, A, Msb, K:) or [having either the whole or a part of the tail cut off;] having the tail cut, or amputated, in any place: (M:) fem. batoraA='u; with which ↓ mabotuwrapN is syn.: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. butorN. (A, Msb.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A certain malignant, or noxious, serpent: (K:) or a short-tailed serpent: (Mgh; and EdDurr en-Netheer, an abridgment of the Nh of IAth, by El-Jelál:) or a certain species of blue serpent, having its tail [as it were] cut off, which none in a state of pregnancy sees without casting her burden: (ISh:) or the kind of serpent called $ayoTaAn, having a short tail: no one sees it without fleeing from it, and no one in a state of pregnancy beholds it without casting her young: it is thus called only because of the shortness of its tail, as thought its tail were cut off. (M.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A leathern water-bag, and a bucket, having no loop. (M, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Defective, deficient, incomplete, or imperfect. (Mgh.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) In want, or poor. (M, K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Suffering loss; syn. xaAsirN. (M, K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) One from whom all good, or prosperity, is cut off. (M.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) Having no offspring, or progeny; (Aboo-Is-hák, T, S, M, IAth, K;) as also ↓ A^ubaAtirN (M, K) and ↓ munobatirN. (IAth.) [The dim., ↓ A^ubayotiru, occurs in a trad., in this sense, or in some other sense implying contempt.] ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) Anything cut off, (K,) or anything of which the effect is cut off, (S,) from good, or prosperity. (S, K.) [See an ex. in a trad. cited voce baAlN.] ― -b11- xuTobapN batoraA='u (assumed tropical:) A xTbp [q. v.] in which the speaker does not praise God nor bless the Prophet: (S, A, K:) particularly applied to a certain xTbp of Ziyád. (S, A.) ― -b12- rakoEapN batoraA='u, (TA,) and [its dim.] ↓ butayoraA='u, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A single rkEp [q. v.] performed instead of the complete performance of the prayer called Alwitor: or a rkEp cut short, or cut off, after the completion of one rkEp, when both were to have been performed. (TA.) ― -b13- AlA^abotaraAni (assumed tropical:) The ass (AlEayoru) and the slave: (ISK, S, A, K:) so called because of the little good that is in them: (ISk, S:) each is called AlA^abotaru. (K.)

A^ubaAtirN * (assumed tropical:) Short; (M, K;) as though cut off from completion. (M.) ― -b2- See also A^abotaru. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A man who cuts, or severs, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; who disunites himself from his relations; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ baAtirN; (A:) or quick to cut, or sever, the ties, or bonds, between him and his friend. (IAar.)
A^ubayotiru * : see A^abotaru.
mabotuwrapN mbtwr mbtwrh mbtwrp : see A^abotaru.
munobatirN mnbtr : see A^abotaru.

1 batiEa btE , (S, K,) aor.
bataEa , (K,) inf. n. bataEN, (ISh, S, K,) He (a horse, K) was, or became, long in the neck, and at the same time strong in its base: (S, K:) or thick and fleshy in the neck: or strong in the neck. (ISh.) ― -b2- It, (the body,) and he, (a man,) was, or became, strong in the joints. (K, TA.) -A2- bataEa, aor.
batiEa , He prepared, and made, the beverage called nabiy*. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [See bitoEN.]
batoEN btE , with fet-h, [perhaps a mistake for bataEN, (see 1,)] Strength. (TA.)

bitoEN btE (S, Mgh, K) and ↓ bitoEN (S, K) [Hydromel, or] nabiy* of honey, (S, K,) that has become strong; (K;) nby* made of honey, as though it were wine in strength, the drinking of which is disapproved; (El-'Eyn;) an intoxicating beverage made of honey, in El-Y emen: (Mgh:) or wine made of fresh dates: (Ibn-El-Beytár, cited by Golius:) or the pure juice of grapes; (Ibn-' Abbád, K;) said by some to be so called by reason of the strength therein, from bataEN, [inf. n. of batiEa,] meaning “ strength of the neck: ” (TA:) or the former signifies wine: (K:) or wine made of honey: (AHn:) a word of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) the wine of El-Medeeneh is from unripe dates, and from ripe dates; that of the Persians, from grapes; that of the people of El-Yemen is bitoE, and is from honey; and that of the Abyssinians is sukurokap. (Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree.) [See mizorN.] -A2- See also batEN.

batiEN btE A horse long in the neck, and at the same time strong in its base: fem. with p: (As, S, K:) or long in the neck. (IAar.) You say also EunuqN batiEN (ISh, TA) and batiEapN (TA) A strong neck: or an excessively long neck: (TA:) or a thick and fleshy neck: (ISh:) and ↓ A^abotaEu [in like manner] signifies full, applied to a rusog, [app. here meaning a pastern], (K,) accord. to Lth, who cites, from Ru-beh, the phrase rusogFA A^abotaEa: but IB thinks that the right reading is jiydFA A^abotaEa [a full neck]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A tall man: (L, TA:) in this sense, accord. to the K, ↓ bitoEN, which is a mistake: (TA:) fem. with p. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And Strong in the joints, applied to a body, (Lth, K,) and to a man; as also ↓ A^abotaEu: (K:) fem. of the former with p: (TA:) and of ↓ the latter, batoEaA='u: and pl. of the latter, butoEN. (K.)
butaEu btE pl. of batoEaA='u, fem. of A^abotaEu, q. v.
bitaEN btE : see bitoEN.

bat~aAEN btAE
A vintner, in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) [See bitEN.]
baAtiEN bAtE : Strong. (TA.)

A^abotaEu * : see batiEN, in three places. -A2- It is also a word used as a corroborative: you say, jaAw^uwA A^ajomaEuwna A^akotaEuwna A^abotaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: (S:) and jaA='a Alqawomu A^akotaEuwna A^abotaEuwna A^aboSaEuwna [the people, or company of men, came, all of them, or all together]: (AHeyth:) and jaAw^uwA kul~uhumo A^ajomaEuwna A^akotaEuwna A^abotaEuwna [they came, all of them, all together]: these words which follow AjmEwn being imitative sequents to it, not occurring save after it [in the order above]: (O, K:) or one may begin with whichsoever of them he will, after it. (Ibn-Keysán, K.) And [the fem. is batoEaA='u:] you say Alqabiylapu kul~uhaA jamoEaA='u katoEaA='u baSoEaA='u batoEaA='u [The tribe, all of it, all together: in the CK, erroneously, kuvoEA='u (with damm and v) and buSoEA'u and butoEA'u]. (K.) And [the pl. of batoEaA='u is ↓ butaEu, originally batoEaAwaAtN:] you say Aln~isaA='u
kul~uhun~a jumaEu kutaEu buSaEu butaEu [The women, all of them, all together: in the CK, erroneously, jumaEN kutaEN buSaEN butaEN, though it is well known that each of these is determinate, and imperfectly declinable]. (K.) It is only necessary that he who mentions all these words should mention first kul~, and follow it with the word formed from j m E, then add the rest in whatsoever order he will; but the more approved way is to put the word formed from k t E before the rest. (TA.) Fr mentions the phrases A^aEojabniY AlqaSoru A^ajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether], and Ald~aAru jamoEaA='a [the house, all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow A^ajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows A^ajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSal~uwA juluwsFA A^ajomaEiyna and A^ajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, A^aEoniykumo A^ajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]. (K.) [But see A^ajomEu.]

1 batakahu btk btkh btkp tkp , aor.
batika and
batuka , (S, K,) inf. n. batokN, (S,) He cut it; or severed it, or cut it off, (S, K,) entirely, or from its root; (TA;) and in like manner, ↓ bt~khu, (K,) inf. n. tabotiykN; (TA;) but btak is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, of the action, or its application to many objects. (S, TA.) A=*aAna AlA^anoEaAmi, in the Kur [iv. 118], accord. to Abu-l-'Abbás, (TA,) means And they shall assuredly cut, or cut off, the ears of the cattle: (S, * TA:) or, as Az thinks, slit the ears of the cattle, as they did in the time of ignorance. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He plucked it out; he laid hold upon it and pulled it towards him so that it became severed from its root and plucked out; (Lth, S, * TA;) namely, a hair, or feather, or the like. (Lth, TA.)
2 bat~aka see 1, in two places.
5 tabat~aka see 7.

7 Anbtk A^nAb A^nb A^nbp A^nbt A^nbtk A^nbttk Anbtk nbt
It became cut; or became severed, or cut off, (S, * K,) entirely, or from its root; (TA;) and in like manner, ↓ tbt~k. (K.) ― -b2- Also It became plucked out. (Lth, TA.)

bitokapN btk btkh btkp tkp (S, K) and batokapN (K) A piece, or portion, of a thing, cut off, or severed: pl. bitakN. (S, K.) Hence the saying of the poet, (S,) namely, Zuheyr, (TA,)
Hat~aY A_i*aA maA hawatE kaf~u AlgulaAmi lahaA
TaArato wafiy kaf~ihi mino riy$ihaA bitaku
[Until, when the hand of the boy descends to her, she flies, while portions of her feathers, plucked out, are in his hand]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] i. q. juhomapN mina All~ayoli [i. e. A portion at the commencement of the latter parts of the night, accord. to the S and K in art. jhm; or a remaining portion of darkness in the latter part of the night, accord. to the K in that art.]: (S, K:) as though it were a division [or portion cut off] of the night. (TA.)
batuwkN bt btwk tw : see what next follows.

baAtikN bAt bAtk (applied to a sword, S) Sharp, or cutting; (S, K;) as also ↓ batuwkN: (K:) [but the latter is an intensive epithet, signifying very sharp; or cutting much, or keenly]: the pl. [of the former] is bawaAtiku. (TA.)

1 batalahu btl btlh btlp tl tlp , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
batila , (S,) or
batula , (Msb,) or both, (M, K,) inf. n. batolN, (Lth, T, S, &c.,) He cut it off, or severed it; (M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ bt~lhu, (M, K,) inf. n. tabotiylN: (TA:) he separated it (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) from another thing. (Lth, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] batala AlEumorapa He made the performance of the Emrp [or minor pilgrimage] to be obligatory, by itself. (A, TA.) And AlEumoraY ↓ bt~l He made the EmrY to be obligatory [upon himself]; i. e., the saying, I have assigned to thee my house that thou mayest inhabit it to the end of my life. (TA.) -A2- batila, aor.
batala , inf. n. batolN, [but accord. to analogy, this should rather be batlN,] He (a man) was, or became, wide between the shoulders. (T.)
2 bat~ala see 1, in two places: -A2- and see also 5: -A3- and mubat~alN.

5 tbt~lA btl tbtl tbtlA {btl : see 7, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] He was, or became, alone. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S,) or tbt~lA A_ilaY All~`hi, (M, K,) and ↓ bt~l, (S, * K,) inf. n. tabotiylN, (S,) He detached himself from worldly things, and devoted himself to God: (S:) or he devoted himself to God exclusively, and was sincere, or without hypocrisy, towards Him: (M, K:) he forsook every other thing, and applied himself to the service of God: (Fr, T:) he devoted himself exclusively to the service of God: (Aboo-Is-hák, T:) or he abstained from sexual intercourse: (K:) or tbt~l [alone] has this signification; (M, TA;) or he separated himself from women, and abstained from sexual intercourse: and hence, is metaphorically employed to denote exclusive devotion to God. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxiii. 8], watabat~alo A_ilayopi tabotiylFA, (T, S, M,) for tbt~l Alyh tabat~ulFA. (T.) You say also, tbt~lA A_ilaY AlEibaAdapi He applied himself exclusively to the service of God. (Msb.) ― -b4- tabat~lato, said of a woman, She adorned and beautified herself. (TA.)

7 Anbtl A^nbtl Anbtl {nbtl
It was, or became, cut off, or severed; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ tbt~l. (M, K.) You say, Anbtlt Alfsiylapu, (K, [in a copy of the M ↓ Abttlt, probably a mistranscription,]) The shoot, or offset, of the palm-tree was cut off, or severed, mino A^um~ihaA [from its mother-tree]; as also ↓ tbt~lt and ↓ Astbtlt. (M, K.) ― -b2- Anbtl fiY sayorihi He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and made much progress, in his journeying, or pace. (TA.)
8 A_ibotatala see 7.
10 A_isotabotala see 7.

EaTaA='N batolN ETA=' btl
A gift that is [as it were] cut off; i. e., of which there is not the like; or after which another is not given. (M, K.) And SadaqapN batolapN, (M, K,) and Sdqp bat~apN batolapN, (TA,) An alms, or a gift for the sake of God, cut off from its giver: (M, K:) or cut off from all the property [irrevocably], to be devoted to the cause of God. (O, TA. [See also art. bt.]) You say also, A^aEoTayotuhu h`*ihi AlEaTiy~apa bat~aA batolFA: see art. bt. And Tal~aqahaA bat~apF batolapF; (S;) or Tl~qhA TaloqapF bat~apF batolapF; (Msb;) [He divorced her by a separating divorce; or by a decided and irrevocable divorce; (see art. bt;)] the last word being a corroborative of that next preceding it. (TA.) And Halafa yamiynFA batolapF He swore a decided [or an irrevocable] oath. (M, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce bat~u.]) ― -b2- Also Truth; or true: whence batolFA in truth; or truly. (TA.)

batuwlN btwl twly
A shoot, or an offset, of a palm-tree, cut off from its mother-tree, and independent thereof; as also ↓ batiylapN, (As, T, S, M, K,) and ↓ batiylN. (M, K.) ― -b2- A virgin, that is cut off from husbands: (S:) a woman that withholds herself from men, (T,) or that is cut off from men, (M, K,) having no desire for them, (T, M, TA,) nor need of them; (T;) and, with the art. Al, applied to the Virgin Mary; (M, K;) as also ↓ batiylN: (M, K:) with the art. Al, it is applied also to Fátimeh, the daughter of Mohammad, because she was separated from the [other] women of her age and nation by chasteness and excel-lence and religion and [other] grounds of pretension to respect: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, T, K: *) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) a woman detached from worldly things, and devoted to God; (S, K;) as also ↓ batiylN and ↓ batiylapN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

batiylN btyl : see batuwlN, in three places. ― -b2- Also Slender; (Ham p. 589;) applied to a waist; (Ham, TA;) as also ↓ mubat~alN. (TA.) ― -b3- A tree having its racemes pendulous. (K. [See also mubotilN.]) ― -b4- A watercourse (Ibn-'Abbád, M, K) in the lower part of a valley: pl. butulN. (M, K.)

(M.) ― -b4- mar~a EalaY batiylapK mino raA^oyihi, and mn rA^yh ↓ batolaA='i, [He proceeded according to] an irrevocable determination or resolution. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

A^abotalu * ; fem. batolaA='u: for the latter, see what next precedes. ― -b2- EumorapN batolaA='u [A minor pilgrimage] not conjoined with another. (K.) ― -b3- And A^abotalu, applied to a man, Wide between the shoulders. (T.)

[or rather coll. gen. n.] of the second, like as tamorN is of tamrapN, (M,) A palmtree (naxolapN) having a shoot, or an offset, cut off from it and independent of it; (As, T, S, M, K;) and used in like manner as a pl. ; i. e., the
first is also used as a pl.: (S:) or the first signifies solitary, or isolated: (Ibn-Habeeb, TA:) or of which the racemes are pendulous. (TA. [See also batiyylN.])

mubat~alN mbtl mbtly : see batyilN. ― -b2- mubat~alapN, applied to a woman, Beautiful, elegant, or pretty; (K;) as though her beauty were divided into portions (↓ but~ila, i. e. quT~iEa,) [and distributed in due proportions] upon her limbs: (M, * K:) or perfect in make, (S,) whose flesh is not accumulated, one portion upon another, (S, M, K,) but distinctly disposed; this latter being said by some to be the meaning: (M:) or, accord. to Lh, (M, TA,) having a lankness, or looseness, in her limbs; (M, K, TA;) not having them compressed, one upon another; (M:) or as though the flesh were cut off from them: (TA:) and in like manner, mubat~alN applied to a camel: (M, K:) not applied as an epithet to a man: (S, M, K:) or mubat~alapu Alxaloqi signifies distinct in make from the generality of women; excelling them [therein]: (Aboo-Sa'eed, T, TA:) or perfect in make: or having every part beautiful in itself; not dependent [for its beauty] upon another part: (T:) or beautiful in make; not with one part falling short of another [in beauty]; not being beautiful in the eye and ugly in the nose, nor beautiful in the nose and ugly in the eye; but perfect. (IAar, TA.)

Cut off, or severed. (S.) ― -b2- [And hence,] EaziymapN munobatilapN An irrevocable determination or resolution. (TA.)

bavu3a (Lth, T, M, L, K) and

bavu3a ; and A_iy~aAhu ↓ A^abovavatuhu; (tropical:) I revealed, or showed, to him what was in my mind. (A.) (M.) And bav~ahu $uquwrahu (assumed tropical:) He complained to him of his state, or condition. (M, in art. $qr.)

And Anbv~ AljaraAdu fiY AlA^aroDi The locusts spread, or became dispersed, or dispersed themselves, in the land. (M, A, L.)

(S.) -A2- A state, or condition. (S, K.) ― -b2- Grief, or sorrow, (T, S, M,) which one makes known to his companion or friend: (T:) or violent, or intense, grief or sorrow; and violent, or severe, disease or sickness; as though, in consequence of its violence, one made it known to his companion or friend: (T, TA:) or the most violent or intense grief or sorrow. And bijilodihi bavorN $at~aY [In his skin are scattered, or sundry, pimples, &c.]. (A.)

It (water) had vent; or it poured out, or flowed forth: (S, Msb, * K:) or it ran, or flowed, of itself, without the breaking through of a dam or the like. (Mgh.) (K, * TA.) ― -b5- Anbvqt AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The land became abundant in herbage, or fruitful. (TA.)

bavoqN bvq and ↓ bivoqN An opening made for water by breaking through the bank, or the dam that confined it: (Mgh, Msb: *) or the place where the bank of a river, or rivulet, is broken [through] in order that the water may pour out, or flow forth: a place where water has vent, or pours out, or flows forth: (K:) or the latter signifies a place furrowed, or hollowed out, by water: (JK:) pl. buvuwqN. (JK, K.) -A2- Also the former, A disease that affects seed-produce, occasioned by rain. (TA.)

(TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] huwa baAviqu Alkarami (assumed tropical:) He is abundant in generosity. (K.)

(TA.) You say also, bajiEa bihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.

bajaHa ; (Msb, K;) but the latter is of weak authority; (S, K;) He rejoiced in it, or at it; (S, K;) namely, a thing; (S;) as also ↓ tbj~H and ↓ AbtjH: (TA:) or he gloried in it, or boasted of it; and so ↓ tbj~H. It (a thing, or an affair, TA) rejoiced him; made him joyful, glad, or happy; (A, TA;) as also ↓ AbjH~Hu. (TA.) And baj~aHotuhu, (inf. n. tabojiyEN, S, K,) I rejoiced him; made him joyful, &c.: (S, Mgh, K:) or, as some say, magnified him: (TA:) and ↓ bajaHotuhu, aor.
bajiHa , I magnified it; namely, a thing. (Msb.)

Women, or the women, vie, or contend for superiority, one with another, in beauty, or goodliness, and in glorying, or boasting. (A, TA.)

Joyful; [an intensive epithet] applied to a man. (TA.)

Great in estimation; applied to a man: pl. buj~aEN and bujoHN. (TA.)

mabaAjiHu mbAjH [a pl. of which the sing. is app. mabojaHapN, meaning, accord. to analogy, A cause of joy or gladness or happiness]. You say, laqiytu minohu AlmanaAjiHa wAlmabaAjiHa [app. I experienced from it, or him, the causes of success, and the causes of joy &c.]. (A, TA.)

1 bajada biAlmakaAni bjd bAlmkAn , (S, A, L, K, *) aor.
bajuda , (L,) inf. n. bujuwdN (S, L, K) and tabojiydN; (Kr;) and ↓ bj~d, inf. n. tabojiydN; (L, K;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (S, A, L, K,) in the place; (S, A, L;) settled, or remained fixed, in it; not quitting it. (A.) ― -b2- bajadati AlA_ibalu, (L, K,) inf. n. bujuwdN; and ↓ bj~dt; (L;) The camels kept to the place of pasturing. (L, K.)

bajadN bjd jd
A company, or an assembly, of men: and a hundred, and more, of horses: (L, K:) on the authority of El-Hejeree: (TA:) pl. bujuwdN. (L.)

bajodapN bjdh bjdp jd jdp
i. q. A^aSolN [The root, basis, or foundation; or the origin, or source; or the most essential part, or very essence; of a thing]. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of a case or an affair; as also ↓ bujodapN and ↓ bujudapN: (S, L, K:) or the true, or real, state or circumstances thereof; the positive, or established, truth thereof; from bajada baAlmakaAni. (A.) You say, huwa EaAlimN bibajodapi A^amorika, (S, A, L,) and ↓ bibujodatihi, and ↓ bibujudatihi, (S, L,) He is acquainted with the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of thy case or affair: (S, L:) or, with the true, or real, state or circumstances thereof; with the positive, or established, truth thereof. (A.) And Einodihu bajodapu *`lika, (S, K,) with fet-h, (S,) He possesses the knowledge of that. (S, K.) And hence, (S,) hawa A@bonu bajodatihaA, (S, K,) contr. of hw Abn njodatihaA, (A in art, njd,) or, as in the books of proverbs, A^anaA A@bonu bajodatihaA, the [affixed] pronoun referring to AlA^aroD [understood], as is said by Meyd and Z, (TA,) applied to [signify He is, or I am,] the person acquainted with the thing; (S, L, K;) possessing, or exercising, the skill requisite for it; (S, L;) the discriminator, or discerner, thereof; (L;) and one says likewise, huwa A@bonu madiynatihaA waA@bonu bajodatihaA: (TA:) it is also applied to [signify he is, or I am,] the skilful guide of the way [thereof]: (L, K:) and hence, [accord. to some,] it is proverbially applied to any one acquainted with an affair; skilful therein: (TA:) and to [signify he is, or I am,] the person who will not quit, or depart from, his place; from the saying bajada baAlmakaAni: (L:) or the person who will not depart from his saying: (K: [there explained by the words limano laA yaboraHu mino qawolihi: but the TA supplies some apparent omissions in this explanation, making it to agree with that which here immediately precedes it, taken from the L; and adds that, in some copies of the K, En qwlh is erroneously put for mn qwlh: also, that he who remains in a place knows that place:]) or, accord. to some, bajodapN signifies dust, or earth; so that A^anaA A@bonu bajodatahaA is as though it meant I am created of its dust, or earth. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A [desert, such as is termed] SaHoriA='. (K.) Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr uses the phrase Aibonu bajodatahaA as meaning Its male chameleon; the pronoun referring to a desert (falaAp) which he is describing. (TA.) And you say of a land covered with black locusts, A^aSobaHati AlA^aroDu bajodahF waAHidapF [The land became, or has become, one desert, destitute of vegetable produce]. (L.)
bujodahN bjdh bjdp jd jdp and bujudapN: see bajodapN; each in two places.

A striped garment of the kind called kisaA=', (S, A, L, K,) being one of the kinds of kasA=' worn by the Arabs of the desert: (S, L:) or, of which the wool has been spun, or twisted, in the manner termed yasorapF [app. a mistranscription for yasorFA (see fatolN yasorN in art. ysr)], and woven with the instrument called SiySap: pl. bujudN: a single oblong piece thereof is called faliyjN, of which the pl. is fulujN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also A kind of tent, of [the soft hair called] wabar. (Ibn-ElKelbee, TA voce bayotN, q. v.)

Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling,
in a place; (L;) settled, or remaining fixed, in a land. (A.)

bajara , (M, K,) inf. n. bajarN, (S, M,) He (a man, S) had his navel, or the part remaining of the navel-string after it had been cut, protruding, (S, K,) elevated, and hard, (TA,) and thick at the base, (S, M,) and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part. (M.) ― -b2- He was, or became, large in the belly. (Lh, TA.)
