A swelling, or inflation, of the belly; as also ↓ bajarN: (Fr, TA:) or prominence in the belly. (Har p. 639.) -A2- Evil; mischief: a great, terrible, or momentous, thing or case; (AZ, S, K;) as also ↓ bajorN and ↓ bujoriY~N: (TA:) a wonderful thing: (K:) a calamity, or misfortune; (S;) as also ↓ bajorN (TA) and ↓ bujoriY~N (S, K) and ↓ bujoriy~apN: (K:) pl. of bujorN [or pl. pl., being app. pl. of the pl. of pauc. A^abojurN,] A^abaAjiru; and pl. pl. (as though pl. of the pl. A^abojaArN, T) A^abaAjiyru: (K:) and pl. of ↓ bujoriY~N (S, K) and of ↓ bujoriy~apN (K) bajaAriY~N. (S, K.) You say A^amorN bujorN A great, terrible, or momentous, thing or case. (TA.) And qaAla hujorFA wabujorFA [He said a foul and] a wonderful thing. (TA.) And A_in~ahu layajiYo'u biAlA^abaAjiri Verily he brings to pass calamities, or misfortunes. (A.) And laqiytu minohu AlbajaAriY~a I experienced from him calamities, or misfortunes. (AZ, S.) And A_in~amaA huwa ↓ Alfajoru A^awiAlbajoru or Albujoru [It is only the daybreak or misfortune]: a saying of Aboo-Bekr; meaning, if thou wait until the daybreak shine, thou wilt see the way; but if thou journey without a guide in the darkness, it will lead thee to evil: but the saying is recited differently; with AlbHr in the place of Albjr. (L. [See baHorN.]) ― -b2- [See also bujolN.]
bajarN bjr jr inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- See also bujorN.

bajarN bjr jr A man (TA) having his belly full of milk, (K,) or pure milk, (TA,) and of water, without being satiated: (K:) or drinking much milk, or water, and being hardly, or not at all, satiated. (Lh, TA.)

bajorahN bjrh bjrp jr jrp
Prominence, or protrusion, in the navel: (Mgh:) or largeness of the belly: pl. bajaraAtN. (Yákoot, TA.) [See what next follows.]

bujorapN bjrh bjrp jr jrp
A tumour, or swelling, or an inflation, in the navel; the like of which in the back is termed EujorahN: (IAar, IAth:) or the part of the navel-string which remains after it has been cut, when it is thick at the base, and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part; as also ↓ bajarapN: (ISd, L:) or the navel, (L, K,) of a man and of a camel, (L,) whether large or not: (L, K:) and a knot in the belly: (L, K:) or a knotted vein in the belly; the like of which in the back is termed EujorapF: (L:) and (as some say, L) a knot in the face, and in the neck: (L, K:) pl. bujarN. (L.) [See also EujorapN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] *akara Eujarahu wabujarahu (tropical:) He mentioned his vices, or faults, and his whole state or case: (K:) or all his affairs; those which were apparent and those which were hidden: or his secrets: or his vices, or faults. (TA.) And A^afaDayotu A_ilayoka biEujariY wabujariY (tropical:) I have revealed to thee my vices, or faults; meaning, my whole state or case. (S.) And A^axobarotuhu biEujariY wabujariY (tropical:) I acquainted him with my vices, or faults, which I conceal from others, by reason of my confidence in him. (As.) And A^a$okuw A_ilaY A@ll~`hi EujariY wabujariY, said by 'Alee, (tropical:) I complain unto God of my sorrows and my griefs; (IAar, IAth;) meaning, all my affairs or circumstances; those which are apparent and those which are hidden. (IAth.) [See, again, EujorapN.] ― -b3- It is said in a prov., ↓ Eay~ara bujayorN bujarapo nasiYa bujayorN xabaraho, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Bujeyr cast reproach upon] his vices, or faults: [Bujeyr forgot his own state or condition:] or, as some say, they were two men: [so that the meaning is, Bujeyr reproached Bujarah: &c.:] (S:) accord. to El-Mufaddal, Bujeyr and Bujarah were two brothers, in an ancient age: but accord. to the lexicologists, the meaning is, that one affected with what is termed a bujorap in his navel reproached another for that which was in him. (Az, TA.)
bajarapN bjrh bjrp jr jrp : see bujorapN.
bujoriY~N bjrY bjry jr jry : see bujorN, in three places.
bujoriy~apN bjryh bjryp jry : see bujorN, in two places.

bajiyrN bjyr jyr is an imitative sequent to kaviyrN. (Fr, S, K.) Accord. to AA, it signifies Abundant, or much, wealth: [or rather this seems to be the meaning of the phrase maAlN bajiyrN: for it is added,] and in like manner [it is used in the phrase], makaAnN EamiyrN bajiyrN [A place inhabited, peopled, well stocked with people and the like, or in a flourishing state, and large, or ample]. (TA.)
bujayorN bjyr jyr : see bujorapN.
baAjirN A^jr A^jrp bA^jr bAjr : see what follows.

A^abojaru * A man (S) having his navel, or the part remaining of the navel-string after its having been cut, protruding, (S, Mgh, K,) and elevated, and hard, (TA,) and thick at the base, (S, M,) and fleshy at the neck, or slender part, with wind remaining in the enlarged part: (M:) fem. bajoraA='u: (S:) pl. bujorN (S, K) and bujoraAnN. (K.) ― -b2- Large in the belly: pl. as above: and ↓ baAjirN signifies the same: (TA:) or this latter, having a swollen, or an inflated, belly: (IAar, K:) or having a large belly and a protruding navel: and its pl. is bajarapN, occurring in a trad., in which the tribe of Kureysh are described as A^a$iH~apN bajarapN: or bjrp may here mean (tropical:) hoarders and acquirers of wealth. (L.) ― -b3- One says also HaqiybapN bajoraA='u (assumed tropical:) A full [receptacle of the kind called] Hqybp; and SurarN bujorN (assumed tropical:) full purses; and kiysN A^aEojazu [or A^aEojaru?]: but they did not say, HaqiybapN EajozaA='u [or EajoraA='u?]; nor kiysN A^abojaru; though analogy does not disagree to it: it is from bujorN signifying “prominence in the belly.” (Har p. 639.) ― -b4- And A^aroDN bajoraA='u (assumed tropical:) Ground, or land, that is elevated, (K, * TA,) and hard. (TA.) ― -b5- A^abojaru also signifies (assumed tropical:) The rope of a ship; (K;) because of its greatness in relation to ropes in general. (TA.)

1 bajasa AlmaA='a bjs AlmA=' , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
bajusa (S, Msb, K) and
bajisa , (A, K,) inf. n. bajosN, (Msb, TA,) He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; gave vent to it; made it to flow; syn. fajarahu, (S,) or fataHahu, (Msb,) or $aq~ahu: (A, K:) [all of which, in this case, signify the same:] and in like manner one says of a wound; (A, K;) but in this case, the phrase is tropical: (TA:) and AlamA='i ↓ bj~s, inf. n. tabojiysN, He (namely, God, TA) made the water to flow forth, or to flow forth copiously, syn. faj~arahu, (K, TA,) from the cloud or clouds, and from the spring. (TA.) -A2- See also 7, in two places.
2 baj~asa see 1.
5 tabaj~asa see 7, in three places.

7 Anbjs A^nbjs Anbjs {nbjs
It (water) had a way, passage, vent, or channel, opened for it to flow forth; it had vent; it poured forth; (S, A, Msb, K;) [it burst forth;] from a cloud or clouds, and from a spring; (A;) and from a rock; (Kur vii. 160;) as also ↓ bajasa, aor.
bajusa ; (S, TA;) and ↓ tbj~s: (S, K:) syn. of the first, (S, A, K, * TA,) and last, (S,) Ainofajara: (S, A, TA:) or of the last, tafaj~ara [properly signifying it poured forth copiously]: (A, TA:) AinobijaAsN signifies particularly the welling forth [of water] from a spring: or it has a general application: (K:) and ↓ bajosN signifies cracking in a water-skin, or stone, or earth, so that water issues from it. (TA.) You say, Als~aHaAbu yanobajisu biAlmaTari [The clouds pour with rain]. (TA.) And A^ataAnaA bivariydK ↓ yatabaj~asu, (A,) or A^udomFA ↓ yatabaj~asu, (TA,) [He brought us crumbled bread moistened with broth, which streamed with seasoning,] meaning, by reason of the abundance of grease [in it]. (A, TA.)

maA='N bajosN mA=' bjs
Water having a way, passage, vent, or channel, opened for it to flow forth; having a vent; or pouring forth: (K:) and in like manner, saHaAbN bajosN [clouds pouring forth rain]; (TA;) and [so] saHaAy^ibu buj~asN [pl. of ↓ baAjisN and baAjisapN]: (S:) and ↓ maA='N bajiysN flowing water: (Kr, TA:) and ↓ EayonN bajiysN a copious spring. (K, * TA.)
bajysN bjys : see bajosN, in two places.
baAjisN bAjs ; pl. buj~asN: see bajosN.

1 bajula bjl jl , aor.
bajula , inf. n. bajaAlapN and bujuwlN, He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed bajaAl and
bajiyl [i. e. magnified, honoured, &c.]. f[g(K.) -A2- bajala, aor.
bajala ; and bajala, aor.
bajula ; inf. n. bajolN and bujuwlN; He was, or became, in a good state or condition; having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (K.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (K.) -A3- [bajalahu He bled him (namely, a horse, or a camel,) by opening the vein called AlA^abojal: so accord. to analogy; like wadajahu, meaning “he bled him by opening the vein called Alwadaj,” &c.] lamo yubojalo means He had not been bled in the A^abojal. (TA.)

2 bj~lhu bjl bjlh bjlp jl jlp , (Msb, K,) inf. n. tabojiylN, He magnified, honoured, revered, venerated, or respected, him: (S, Msb, K:) or he said to him bajalN, meaning Sufficient for thee (jasobuka) is the place [or condition or rank] which thou hast attained. (K.)

4 Abjlhu A^bjlh Abjlh Abjlp bjl
It sufficed, or contented, him. (S, K.) ― -b2- It rejoiced him. (TA.)
bujolN bjl jl : see bajalN.

bajalo bjl jl is a noun (Mughnee) syn. with Hasobu: (S, Mughnee, K: *) and is also a verbal noun syn. with yakofiY. (Mughnee, K. *) You say bajaliY (S, Mughnee, K) and bajoliY, (S, K,) meaning HasobiY [My sufficiency, or a thing sufficing me, i. e. sufficient for me, is such a thing]: (S, Mughnee, K:) [it is said in the Ham, p. 145, as on the authority of Akh, that they do not say bajolY; but this is a mistranscription for bajaloniY, as will be seen from what follows:] and, using it as a verbal noun, (Mughnee, K,) but this is rare, (Mughnee,) you say bajaloniY, meaning yakofiyniY [It suffices me, or will suffice me]; (Mughnee, K;) and bajaloka, meaning yakofiyka [It suffices thee, or will suffice thee]: (K:) or, accord. to Akh, they say bajaloka, like as they say, qaToka; but not bajaloniY, like qaToniY: (S:) or the n in bajaloniY is absolutely necessary accord. to him who says that bajalN is a verbal noun; and accord. to him who says that this word is syn. with Hasobu, the n is allowable. (MF.) [See, under the words qado and qaTo, what is said respecting qadoniY and qaToniY.] In the saying of Jábir Ibn-Ra-lán Es-Simbisee,
lam~aA raA^ato maEo$arFA qal~ato Hamuwlatuhumo
qaAlato suEaAdu A^ah`*aA maAlukumo bajalaA
[When she saw a company whose beasts of burden were few, So'ád said, Is this your property, sufficing you?] meaning, when she saw the fewness of our camels: the last word occupies the place of a denotative of state, and is made to end thus by poetic license: Abu-l-'Alà says that this word may be put in the accus. case as meaning not exceeding what I see; or it may be for bajaliY, after the manner of some of the Arabs who are related, by Akh and others, to have said gulaAmaA for gulaAmiY. (Ham pp. 299 and 300.) [See also 2: and see bajalN.] -A2- It is also a particle, (Mughnee,) meaning naEamo [Yes; yea; or even so]. (Mughnee, K.)

bajalN bjl jl
Calumny, slander, or false accusation: or this is with damm; (K;) i. e. ↓ bujolN; (T, TA;) meaning a great calumny &c.; (K, * TA;) and Az thinks that this may be a dial. var. of bujorN, with which it is syn.; because l and r are interchanged in many instances. (TA.) ― -b2- A wonderful thing; syn. EajabN. (K.) ― -b3- *uw AlbaHali denotes dispraise; meaning Content with mean things; not desirous of the means of acquiring eminence: (K:) or content that another should manage affairs in his stead, and that he should be a burden upon others, saying, Sufficient for me (HasobiY [or bajaliY]) is that [state or condition] wherein I am: (O, TA:) from a saying of Luk- mán Ibn-'Ád; (O, K;) as is also *uw Albajolapi, which denotes praise. (O, TA.)

bajolapN bjl bjlh bjlp jl jlp
A goodly, or beautiful, from or appearance, figure, person, mien, or external state or condition: (Sh, K:) a pleasing aspect; goodliness, or beauty; grounds of pretension to respect; and excellence; or sharpness, or quickness, of intellect. (TA.) You say, A_in~ahu la*uw bajolapK [Verily he has a goodly, or beautiful, form &c.]. (Sh, TA.) [See the end of the next preceding paragraph.] ― -b2- A small tree: pl. bajalaAtN. (K.)

bajaAlN bjAl and ↓ bajiylN, applied to a man, i. q. ↓ mubaj~alN [Magnified, honoured, revered, venerated, or respected]: (Sh, K:) or bulky, or corpulent; (As, S;) applied to a man; (As, TA;) or to an old man: (S:) or the former signifies an old, or aged, lord or chief: (AA, S:) or a bulky, or corpulent, old man: or, as some say, one beyond the middle age, in whom one sees goodliness of form or appearance, and advancement in years: (Mgh:) or both signify an old man, who is a great lord or chief, endowed with goodliness, and with excel-lence, or sharpness of intellect: (K:) not applied to a woman; (TA;) i. e., a woman is not termed bajaAlapN. (Mgh.)

bajiylN bjyl jyl : see bajaAlN. ― -b2- Also Gross, big, thick, coarse, or rough; applied to anything. (K.) ― -b3- A^amorN bajiylN An affair, an event, or a case, deemed strange, or evil, and great, or formidable. (TA.) xayorN bajiylN Ample, abundant, good or wealth or prosperity. (TA.)

baAjilN A^jl bA^jl bAjl b|jl |jl
Being in a good state or condition; having abundance of herbage, or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life; (K;) applied to a man and to a camel: (TA:) or, as Yaakoob says, on the authority of Abu-l-Ghamr El-'Okeylee, having much fat; applied to a man and a she-camel and a he-camel. (S.) ― -b2- Also Joyful, glad, or happy. (K.)

A^abojalu *
A certain vein, (S,) a thick vein, (K, Ham p. 417,) of the horse and of the camel, (S, TA,) in the thigh and the shank, (Ham ubi suprà,) or in the kind leg or the fore leg, (TA,) corresponding to the A^akomal (S, K) of man: (S:) pl. A^abaAjilu. (Ham ubi suprà, TA.) You say, faSada A^abojalahu [He opened his Abjl]; i. e., the horse's or the camel's. (TA.) And one says of a swift horse, huwa waAhiY AlA^abaAjili [He is lax in the AbAjl]. (Ham ubi suprà.)
mub~j~alN mbjl : see bajaAlN.

1 baH~a bH , (L,) first pers. baHiHotu, aor. yabaH~u, (ISk, S, L, K,) and ISd says, I see, or think, that Lh has mentioned yaboHaHu, which is extr. with respect to rule, (TA,) inf. n. baHaHN; (ISk, S, L, K;) and first pers. baHaHotu, (AO, T, S, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (T, TA,) aor. yabaE~u (AO, S, K) and yabiE~u and yabuE~u, [which last is contr. to analogy,] (L,) inf. n. baE~u (AO, S, K) and baHaHN and baHaAHN and buHuwHN and baHaAHapN and buHuwHapN; (K;) He had a hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, voice; (L;) he was taken with a hoarseness, harshness, roughness, or gruffness, of the voice. (K.) ― -b2- It is tropically used in speaking of inanimate things; as in baE~a AlEuwdu, meaning (tropical:) [The lute] was rough [in sound: see A^abaE~u]. (A.)

4 AbH~hu A^bAH A^bH A^bHh AbHh AbHp bAH
It (crying out, or vociferating,) rendered him hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, in voice. (S, * K.)

8 humo fiY A@botiHaAHK *
They are in a state of amplitude, and of plenty, or of abundance of herbage or of the goods or conveniences or comforts of life. (K.)
R. Q. 1 baHobaEa bHbE : see R. Q. 2, in two places.

R. Q. 2 tabaHobaEa Ald~aAra tbHbE AldAr , (K,) and ↓ baHobaEahaA, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, [established] in the middle, or midst, [which is the best part,] of the dAr [i. e. abode, or district, or country, &c.], (K, TA,) and became possessed of mastery, dominion, or authority, and power, over it. (TA.) Fr, however, makes tabaHobuHN to be from `AlbaAHapu [q. v.], not from a reduplicative root. (TA.) ― -b2- tbHbH also signifies (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, settled, or established, in authority and power, (syn. tamak~ana,) in alighting, and taking up his abode, or sojourning; (S, K, TA;) and was, or became, [established] in the middle, or midst, [or best part,] of the place of abode; (TA;) and so ↓ bHbH. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He took a wide, an ample, or a large, range. (A.) ― -b4- [Hence,] tbHbH AlHayaA (assumed tropical:) The rain became of wide extent, and had influence upon the land. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- And tabaHobaHati AlEarabu fiY lugaAtihaA (tropical:) The Arabs were copious, or took a wide range, in their dialects. (A.) ― -b6- And tbHbH fiY Almajodi (assumed tropical:) He became in an ample state of glory, honour, or dignity. (TA.) ― -b7- An Arab of the desert said, of a woman in labour, tarakotuhaA tabaHobaHu EalaY A^ayodiY AlqawaAbili [app. (assumed tropical:) I left her obtaining delivery by the hands of the midwives]. (AZ, TA.)
buH~apN bHh bHp : see A^abaH~u.

buH~apN bHh bHp (S, A, L, K) and ↓ buHaAHN (L) Hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, of the voice; (E, K;) which is sometimes natural: or the former is applied absolutely, and the latter to that which
arises from disease. (L.) You say, fiY Sawotihi buH~apN [In his voice is hoarseness, &c.]. (S, A.)
buHaAHN bHAH bHp : see buH~apN.
baHobaHiY~N bHbHY bHbHy (assumed tropical:) Ample in expenditure: and having an ample place of abode. (Fr, K.)
buHobuwHN bHbwH : see what next follows.

buHobuwHapN bHbwH bHbwHh bHbwHp (assumed tropical:) The middle, or midst, [or best part,] syn. wasaTN, (A'Obeyd, S, A, K,) of an abode, or a district, or country, (S, A,) or a place, (K,) and of a place where one alights and abides, (TA,) and of Paradise, and of anything, and the best part thereof; (A'Obeyd, TA;) [like wasaTN, by which it is explained; because what is between the two extremes is generally the best: it may be well rendered the heart, or very heart, of a thing;] and ↓ buHobuwHN, also, has the former of these significations [and by implication the other likewise]. (TA, voce buw^obuw^N, where see an ex.) Jereer says,
qawomiY tamiymN humu Alqawomu Al*~ayna humu
yanofuwna tagoliba Eano buHobuwHapi Ald~aAri
[My people are Temeem: they are the people who drive away Teghlib from the middle, or best part, of the country]. (S.) [It is said in the A, that this word, as syn. with wasaTN, in relation to an abode or the like (dAr), is tropical; but I see no reason for this, unless by wsT be meant the “best part.”]

A^abaH~N * , applied to a man, (S, L, K,) or A^abaH~N AlS~awoti, (A,) Having a hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, voice: (L, K:) fem. baH~aA='u; with which ↓ baH~apN is syn.: (S, K:) pl. buH~N. (S.) baAH~N is not allowable. (S.) ― -b2- And A^abaH~u applied to a lute (EuwdN), (tropical:) Rough (K, TA) in sound. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The base, or thick, chord of a lute; syn. bam~u; because of its rough sound. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A [gold coin of the kind called] diynaAr; (K, TA;) because of its harsh sound [when one rings it]. (TA.) -A2- (tropical:) A qidoH [or gaming-arrow] (S, K, TA) by means of which lots, or portions, are divided: (S, TA:) pl. buH~N: (S, K:) or such an arrow that has no sound. (TA.) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh says,
qarawoA A^aDoyaAfahumo rabaHFA bibuH~K
yaEiy$u bifaDolihin~a AlHaY~u sumori
[They entertained their guests with young weaned she-camels, on the superabundant remains of which the tribe lived, by means of tawny-coloured gaming-arrows whereby the lots that determined who should afford the entertainment were divided: or, accord. to the TA, rbHA here signifies fat, as a subst.; but this is inconsistent with the affixed pronoun relating to it]. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Fat, as an epithet, not a subst. (K.) ― -b3- kisorN A^abaH~u (assumed tropical:) [A portion of a limb, &c.,] having much fat. (TA.)

1 baHuta bAH bH bHt , aor.
baHuta , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. buHuwtapN, (K,) or baHotN, (Msb,) It (a thing) was, or became, unmixed, free from admixture, or pure: (S, K:) [and] he was unmixed, or pure, in race, lineage, or parentage. (Msb.)

3 bAHt AlmaA='a bAHt AlmA=' , (A,) inf. n. mubaAHatapN, (TA,) He drank water, or the water, not upon vufol [i. e. without having eaten anything such as flesh-meat or bread or dates or grain]: (A:) or he drank water, or the water, not mixed with honey or any other thing. (TA.) And bAHt Al$~araAba He drank the wine, or beverage, pure, without any mixture. (A.) And bAHt Alr~imova [He (a camel) ate of the shrub called rmv without any other pasture]. (T in art. TlH.) And bAHt daAb~atahu biAlD~ariyEi He fed his beast with DryE, (i. e. dry herbage, TA,) and the like, unmixed [with other pasture]. (K.) ― -b2- bAHthu Alwud~a He regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection: (S, A, K:) or he was pure, or sincere, to him in love, or affection. (M.) And bAHt AlqitaAla He fought with earnestness and energy, unmixed with lenity. (A, * TA.) And bAHt fulaAnFA (inf. n. as above, TA) He acted openly, or undisguisedly, with, or towards, such a one. (K, TA.)

baHotN bAH bH bHt
Unmixed, free from admixture, or pure; (S, A, Mgh, K;) applied to anything: (A, K:) anything that is eaten alone, without seasoning or condiment or any savoury food: and in like manner, seasoning, or condiment, or any savoury food, without bread: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà:) unmixed, or pure, in race, lineage, or parentage; (S, A, Msb;) applied [for instance] to an Arab, (S, A,) and to an Arab of the desert: (TA:) originally an inf. n.; (Msb;) [and therefore] the same as masc. and fem. and dual and pl.: but if you will, you may use baHotapN as a fem. epithet, applied [for instance] to an Arab woman; and may use the dual and pl. forms: (S:) or the fem. is [properly] with p; or, as some say, the word has no dual nor pl. nor dim. form. (K.) You say $araAbN baHotN Unmixed wine or beverage: (S:) and xamorN baHotN and baHotapN and xumuwrN baHotapN [unmixed wine and wines]. (TA.) And xubozN baHotN Bread without anything else [to season it]. (S.) And A^akala Alxuboza baHotFA, and All~aHoma baHotFA, He ate the bread without any seasoning or condiment or savoury food, and the flesh-meat without bread. (TA.) And qad~ama A_ilayohi qafaArFA baHotFA He presented to him food without any seasoning or condiment. (A.) And Ad~ahana biduhonK baHotN He anointed himself with ointment unmixed with any perfume. (Mgh.) And misokN baHonN (A, Msb) [Unmixed, or unadulterated, and therefore] strong [-scented,] musk. (Msb.) And barodN baHotN laHotN Vehement, or intense, cold; (TA;) [as though unmixed with any degree of warmth;] syn. SaAdiqN: (K in art. lHt:) the last word is an imitative sequent. (TA in that art.)

1 baHavahu Hv bHv bHvh bHvp , aor.
baHava , inf. n. baHovN, He scraped it up; [as one who seeks to find a thing therein;] namely, the dust, or earth: (L:) and he searched, or sought, for it, or after it, (namely, a thing,) in the dust, or earth; as also ↓ AbtHvhu: (L, TA:) thus each is made trans. by itself: and authors often say, baHava fiyhi [meaning he searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it]: (TA:) one says, baHava fiY AlA^aroDi he dug up the earth; and thus it is used in the Kur v. 34: (Msb:) but accord. to the usage commonly known and obtaining, (TA,) you say, baHava Eanohu, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (L, Msb, K,) and so the inf. n.; (L, Msb;) as well as baHavahu; (L;) and Enh ↓ AbtHv; (T, S, L, K;) [in some copies of the K AnbHv, which is said in the TA to be a mistake; and ↓ AbtHvhu; (see above;)] and Enh ↓ tbH~v; (T, L, K;) and Enh ↓ AstbHv; (L, K;) and ↓ AstbHvhu; (L;) [he scraped up the dust, or earth, from over it: and hence,] he searched, or sought, for it, after it, or respecting it; he inquired, and sought for information, respecting it; he searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; he inquired respecting it, and searched to the utmost after it; (S, * A, * L, Msb, * K; *) namely, a thing, (S, L,) or an affair, or event. (Msb.) You say also, A^axaAhu Eano sirih~i ↓ AstbHv He examined his brother respecting his secret. (A in art. nbv.)

3 baAoHava [bAHvhu Eano A^amorK, inf. n. mubaAHavapN, He searched, or inquired, with him into a thing; or investigated, scrutinized, or examined, with him a thing, or an affair: and particularly, in the way of disputation.] ― -b2- EaAdatuhu A^ano yubaAHiva wayubaAhita [His custom is to engage with another in mutual scrutiny of secrets, or faults, or the like, and in mutual calumniation, &c.: see 6]. (A in art. bht.)
5 tabaH~ava see 1.

6 tabaAHavuwA Eani AlA^asoraAri *
They searched, or inquired, into each other's secrets. (A in art. nbv.)

8 A_ibotaHava see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AbtHv also signifies He played with the dust, or earth, termed bHAvp; or at the game called AlbHvp. (K.) In a copy of the K, the verb is here incorrectly written AnbHv. (TA.)
10 A_isotaboHava see 1, in three places.

baHovN Hv bHv , (so in the K,) or ↓ bHiyvN, (so in the L,) accord. to Sh, (L,) A mine (L, K) in which one searches for gold and silver. (L.) -A2- Also the former, A great serpent; (K;) because it scrapes up the dust or earth. (TA.)

AlbuHovapu AlbHvh AlbHvp , (as written in the L,) or AlbaHovapu, (as in the K,) accord. to Sh, (L,) and ↓ AlbuH~y~vaY, (L, K,) accord. to ISh, (L,) A certain game with ↓ buHaAvap, i. e, dust, or earth. (L, K.) You say, laEiba AlbuHovapa He played the game thus called. (L.)

A_ibilN baHuwvN Abl bHwv
Camels that scrape up the dust, or earth, with their fore feet, backwards, (AA, T, L, K,) in going; i. e., throwing it behind them; or, as some say, with their feet. (TA.) ― -b2- AlbaHuwvu, (K,) or suwarpu AlbaHuwvi, (L,) thus written in the Fáïk, and if so, baHuwvN is an intensive epithet, applying alike to a masc. and a fem. noun,
like SabuwrN; (TA;) or, accord. to some, suwrapu AlbuHuwvi, (L,) pl. of baHovi; (TA;) a name of The chapter of the Kur-án called suwrapu Alt~awobapi, (L, K,) and AlbaraA='api; (L;) [chap. ix.;] given to it because it inquires respecting the hypocrites and their secrets. (L.)

baHiyvN Hyv bHyv : see baHovN. ― -b2- A secret: whence the prov., badaA baHiyvuhumo [Their secret became apparent, or revealed]. (TA. [But in the S, in art. njv, q. v., we find badaA najiyvu Alqawomi; and so in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 159.])

buHaAvapN bAHv bHAv bHAvh bHAvp
Dust, or earth, (Az, K,) which is scraped up from what is searched for therein. (Az, TA.) See AlbuHovapu.
AlbuHayovaY AlbHyvY AlbHyvy : see AlbuHovapu.

baAHivN bAHv [act. part. n. of 1; Scraping up dust or earth: &c.]. kaAlbaAHivi Eani Al$~aforapi [Like him who is scraping up the dust, or earth, from over the great knife with which he is to be slaughtered,] is a prov.: (S, L:) and so kabaAHivapK Eano HatofihaA biZilofihaA [Like one searching for her death with her hoof]: originating from the fact of a ewe's digging up a knife in the dust, or earth, and then being slaughtered with it. (L.)

baAHivaA='u bAHvA='
Dust, or earth, (L, K,) of the burrow of the Jerboa, (L,) resembling the [hole termed] qaASiEaA='; (L, K;) but it is not this: pl. baAHivaAwaAtN. (L.)

maboHavN mbHv
A place, and a time, of scraping up or digging; of searching, inquiring, investigating, scrutinizing, or examining: pl. mabaAHivu. (KL.) You say, tarakotuhu bimabaAHivi Albaqari (S, K*) [I left him in the places where the wild oxen scrape up the ground]; meaning, in a desert place, destitute of herbage, or of human beings; (S, K;) in an unknown place; (K;) i. e., so that it was not known where he was. (S.)

Q. 1 baHovara bHvr , [inf. n. baHovarapN,] He took, drew, or pulled, a thing out, or forth; and uncovered it, laid it open, or exposed it; (Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K;) as also baEovara. (Abu-l-Jarráh, S.) It is said in the Kur [c. 9], accord. to one reading, buEovira buHovira maA fiY Alqubuwri, [instead of buEovira,] meaning [When that which is in the graves is taken forth and uncovered; i. e.,] when the dead are raised to life; syn. buEiva; and it is not improbable that baHovara may be composed of baHava and A^avara [app. a mistranscription for A^avaAra], accord. to the opinion of those who hold that quadriliteral and quinqueliteral words are composed of two. (TA.) ― -b2- He searched, or sought, for, or after, a thing in the dust or earth, or the like; syn. baHava [which Ibr D thinks may be a mistake for baEava: but see baEovara]. (L, K, and Bd in c. 9.) ― -b3- He separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated, (S, K,) a thing. (S.) He scattered, or dispersed, his household goods, or his commodities, and turned them over, one upon another; as also baEovara. (Fr, S.) -A2- It (milk) curdled, or coagulated, and formed little clots of curd; syn. taqaT~aEa wa taHab~aba. (S, K.)

Q. 2 tabaHovara bHvr tbHvr
It (a thing, S) became separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated. (S, K.)

labanN mubaHovirN lbn mbHvr
Milk curdling, or coagulating, and forming little clots of curd. (K. [See Q. 1.]) When the upper portion is thick and the lower thin, it is termed haAdirN. (TA.)

1 baHara Hr bHr , (TA,) [aor.
baHara ,] inf. n. baHorN, (K,) He slit; cut, or divided, lengthwise; split; or clave; (K, TA;) and enlarged, or made wide. (TA.) Hence the term baHorN [as meaning “ a sea ” or “ great river ”] is said to be derived, because what is so called is cleft, or trenched, in the earth, and the trench is made the bed of its water. (TA.) ― -b2- baHarahaA, (M,) or baHara A^u*unahaA, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
baHara , (M, Msb,) inf. n. baHorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He slit her (a camel's, S, M, A, Msb, and a sheep's or goat's, M) ear, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) in halves, or in halves lengthwise, (M, TA,) widely; (B;) and in like manner, baHarahu he slit his (a camel's) ear widely: (B:) and ↓ bH~r A=*aAna AlA^anoEaAmi, inf. n. taboHiyrN, He slit [&c.] the ears of the cattle. (Az, TA in art. btk.) -A2- [baHura, aor.
baHura , inf. n. baHaArapN, It was, or became, wide, or spacious. The inf. n. is mentioned in the A: see baHorN: and see also 10.]
2 baH~ara see 1.

4 AbHr A^bHr AbHr bHr
He embarked [or voyaged] upon the sea or a great river. (Yaakoob, S, M, K.) [Opposed to A^abar~a.] ― -b2- (tropical:) It (water, K, sweet water S, A) was, or became, salt. (S, A, * K.) ― -b3- A^aboHarati AlA^aroDu The land abounded with places where water stagnated. (T, K. * [In the latter, manaAfiEuhaA is put by mistake for manaAqiEuhaA. See baHorapN.]) -A2- (assumed tropical:) He found water to be salt; not easy, or pleasant, to be drunk. (K, TA. [In some copies of the K, for lamo yasugo, we find lamo yamotaniEo, which is evidently a mistake.]) -A3- He met, or met with, a man unintentionally: (M, K:) from the phrase, laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa. (TA.)

5 tbH~r A^bHr bHr tbHr : see 10. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a pastor) took a wide range in abundant pasturage. (TA.) ― -b3- tbH~r fiY AlmaAli (tropical:) He enlarged himself, or he became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in wealth, or camels, or the like; (K, * TA;) as also fyh↓AstbHr. (TA.) ― -b4- tbH~r fiY AlEilomi (tropical:) He went deep into science, or knowledge, and enlarged himself, or took a wide range, therein, (S, A, K,) wide as the sea; (TA;) and in like manner one says with respect to other things: (S:) and so fyh ↓AstbHr. (A, TA.)

10 AstbHr A^stbHr AstbHr {stbHr (tropical:) It (a place) became wide, or spacious, like the sea: (A:) it spread wide; became expanded; (K;) as also ↓ tbH~r. (TA.) [See also baHura.] ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a poet, A, K, and a xaTiyb, [i. e. a speaker, an orator, or the like,] A) expatiated in speech; was, or became, diffuse therein. (M, A, K.) ― -b3- See also 5, in two places.

baHorN Hr bHr [A sea: and a great river:] a spacious place comprising a large quantity of water; (B;) a large quantity of water, (K, TA,) whether salt or sweet; (TA;) contr. of bar~N; (S, A;) so called because of its depth (S, TA) and large extent; (S, Msb, TA;) from AlbaHaArapu; (A;) or because its bed is trenched in the earth; see 1: (TA:) or a large quantity of salt water, only; (K;) and so called because of its saltness: (El-Umawee, TA: [but accord. to the A, this word as an epithet meaning “ salt ” is tropical:]) or rather this is its general meaning: (TA:) for it signifies also any great river; (S, M, TA;) any river of which the water does not cease to flow; (Zj, T, TA;) such as the Euphrates, for instance; (S;) or such as the Tigris, and the Nile, and other similar great rivers of sweet water; of which the great salt baHor is the place of confluence; so called because trenched in the earth: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aboHurN and [of mult.] biHaArN and buHuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) The dim. is ↓A^ubayoHirN, (K,) which is anomalous; and ↓buHayorN, which is the regular form: accord. to the K, the latter is not used; but this is untrue; for it is sometimes used, though rare. (MF.) ― -b2- Hence its application in the saying of the Arabs, yaA haAdiYa All~ayoli jurota A_in~amaA huwa AlbaHoru A^awi Alfajoru, which Th explains by saying that the meaning is, (tropical:) [O guide of the night, thou hast deviated from the right way:] it is only destruction or thou wilt see the daybreak: the night is here likened to the sea [and with the night is associated the idea of destruction]: but accord. to one recital, it is Albajoru, instead of AlbaHoru. (TA. [See art. bjr.]) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Salt; as an epithet, applied to water. (S, A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (As, K;) that runs much; (As, TA;) that takes a wide range in his running; (S, A, Msb, B;) that runs like the sea, or a great river; or like the sea, or a great river, when it rolls wave over wave. (Niftaweyh;, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A generous man; (K, TA;) one who takes a wide range in his beneficence, bounty, or kindness; who abounds therein. (TA.) You say, laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA (tropical:) [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]: b here denoting substitution. (The Lubáb cited in the TA voce bi.) And laqiytu minohu baHorFA (tropical:) [I found him to be a man of exceeding generosity]; a phrase expressing an intensive degree of generosity: and raA^ayotu minohu baHorFA [signifies the same]. (Mughnee in art. bi.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A man of extensive knowledge or science; one who takes a wide range in his knowledge or science. (B.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Any person, or thing, that takes a wide range in a thing. (B.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Land of seed-produce and fruitfulness; or a tract, or region, in which are green herbs or leguminous plants, and waters; or the part of a country near to water; syn. riyfN: (Aboo-' Alee, K:) and the dim. ↓ buHayorN is used in the same sense; or, by poetic licence, for ↓ buHayorapN. (TA.) So in the Kur [xxx. 40], Zahara AlfasaAdu fiY Albar~i wa AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) [Corruption hath appeared in the desert, or deserts,
and in the land of seed-produce and fruitfulness; &c.]: (Aboo-'Alee, TA:) or the meaning here is, [in the desert, or deserts, and in the towns, or villages, in which is water: (see bar~N:) or in the open country and] in the cities [or towns] upon the rivers; by sterility in the former, and scarcity in the latter: (Zj, TA, and T in art. br:) or in the land and the sea; i. e., the land has become sterile, or unfruitful, and the supply of the sea has become cut off. (Az, TA.) See also baHorapN. ― -b9- Also, AlbaHoru, (S, K,) or baHoru Alr~aHimi, (A, Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) The bottom (Eumoq, S, A, Mgh, K, or qaEor, IAth, TA) of the womb; fundus uteri: (S, A, Mgh, K:) whence blood of a pure red colour, (S,) or intensely red, (Mgh,) is termed baHoraAniY~N (S, Mgh) and baAHirN. (S.)

baHorapN Hr Hrp bHr bHrh bHrp
A wide tract of land: so accord. to Aboo-Nasr: but in one place he says, a small valley in rugged land: pl. biHaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- A land, country, or territory, belonging to, or inhabited by, a people; syn. balodapN. (S, K.) One says, h`*ihi baHoratunaA This is our land, &c.; syn. A^aroDunaA. (S.) It occurs also in the dim. form [↓ buHayorapN], as in the Towsheeh of El-Jelál. (TA.) ― -b3- Any town, or village, that has a running river and wholesome water: (K:) and [absolutely] any town, or village: of such the Arabs say, h`*ihi baHoratunaA This is our town, or village: and the pl. biHaArN they apply to cities, as well as towns, or villages. (TA.) ― -b4- Low, or depressed, land: (IAar, K:) occurring also in the dim. form [↓ buHayorapN]. (TA.) ― -b5- A meadow; or a garden; syn. rawoDapN: (T, TA:) or one that is large, (K,) and wide. (TA.) ― -b6- A place where water stagnates. (Sh, K.) ― -b7- The pl. is ↓ baHorN, (as in some copies of the K, [or this is a coll. gen. n. of which baHorapN is the n. un.,]) or biHarN, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) or buHorN, (as in the CK,) and biHaArN. (K.) -A2- laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa, (S, K,) and ↓ SuHorapa buHorapa, as in the Expositions of the Tesheel, &c., (MF,) and SaHorapF baHorapF, (K,) and ↓ SuHorapF buHorapF, (MF,) I met him out, with nothing intervening between me and him; (S, L;) both of us being exposed to open view; (TA;) without anything concealing, or intervening. (K, TA.) SHrpa bHrpa, without tenween, is a compound denotative of state; not, as some say, consisting of two inf. ns.: and sometimes naHorapF is added; in which case each of the three words is with tenween, decl.; and they do not form a compound. (MF. [But see SaHorap.)]
SuHorapa buHorapa SHrp bHrh SHrp bHrp and SuHorapF buHorapF: see baHorapN.

baHoriY~N Hr HrAn Hry bHr bHrY bHry bHryy
Of, or relating to, or belonging to, the sea, or a great river; rel. n. of baHorN. (S, K.) ― -b2- A seaman; a sailor; (TA;) as also ↓ baH~aArN: (K:) and [↓ baHoriy~apN and] ↓ baH~aArapN seamen; sailors. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [In the dial. of Egypt, North; northern; because the Mediterranean Sea lies on the north of that country: like as, in Hebrew, יָם signifies “ west; ” because that sea lies on the west of Palestine.]
baHoriy~apN Hr Hry Hryp bHr bHry bHryh bHryp : see baHoriY~N.

buHoraAnN HrAn bHr bHrAn , a post-classical word, (S, K,) used by the physicians, signifying The crisis of a disease; the sudden change which happens to a sick person, (S, TA,) and the commencement of convalescence, (TA,) in acute diseases; (S, TA;) at a time fixed by some motion in the heavenly bodies, mostly by a motion of the moon; being a change to health or to the contrary: a word [said to be] of Greek origin. (The Nuzheh of the sheykh Dáwood El-Antákee, cited in the TA.) [Pl. baHaAriynu.] They say, h`*aA yawomu buHoraAnK and yawomN ↓ baAHuwriY~N [This is the day of a crisis of a disease]: bAHwrY~ being anomalous: (S, K:) [perhaps from AlbaAHuwru signifying “ the moon, ” because the crisis of a disease is thought to be mostly fixed by a motion of the moon: or] as though it were a rel. n. of baAHuwrN and baAHuwraA='u meaning the “ vehemence of heat in [the month of] tam~uwz. ” (S.)

damN baHoraAniY~N dm bHrAnY dm bHrAny (assumed tropical:) Blood of the menses; accord. to El-Kutabee: or (assumed tropical:) intensely red blood: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) intensely red, and thick, and abundant, menstrual blood: (IAth:) or (tropical:) black blood: (A:) or, as also ↓ damN baAHirN, (S, M, Msb, K,) (assumed tropical:) blood of the womb: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) blood of a pure red colour: (S, M, K:) or (assumed tropical:) such blood from the belly: (M:) or (assumed tropical:) pure blood of an intensely red colour: (Msb:) both from AlbaHoru signifying “ the bottom of the womb: ”: (S:) the former is a rel. n. therefrom, (A, IAth, Msb,) in which the A and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification, (IAth,) or to distinguish it from the rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense]: (Msb:) or it is a rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense], because of its abundance. (IAth.) ― -b2- A^aHomaru baHoraAniY~N, and ↓ baAHirN, (TA,) and ↓ baAHiriY~N, (IAar, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Intense red. (TA.)
buHayorN Hyr bHyr dim. of baHorN, which see, in two places.

baHiyrapN Hyr Hyrp bHyrh bHyrp A she-camel having her ear slit: (S, * A, Msb, K *:) [and, as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] a she-camel of which the mother was a saAy^ibap; (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e., of which the mother had brought forth ten females consecutively before her, and of which the ear was slit; (Mgh;) or of which the mother had brought forth five, of which five the last, if a male, was slaughtered and eaten, but if a female, her ear was slit and she was left with her mother; (Mgh, * Msb;) the predicament of which was the same as that of her mother; (Fr, S, K;) i. e., what was unlawful with respect to her mother was unlawful with respect to herself: (TA:) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, that had brought forth five young ones, and of which the fifth, if a male, was slaughtered, and its flesh was eaten by the men and women; but if a female, her ear was slit, and it was unlawful to the Arabs to eat her flesh and to drink her milk and to ride her; but when she died, her flesh was lawful to the women: (K:) so says Az, on the authority of Ibn-'Arafeh: (TA: [but it appears from the explanation in the Msb, quoted above, that it was the slit-eared young she-camel here mentioned, not the mother, that was thus termed:]) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, which, having brought forth ten young ones, had her ear slit, (K,) and no use was made of her milk nor of her back, (TA,) and she was left at liberty to pasture, (K,) and to go to water, (TA,) and her flesh, when she died, was made unlawful to the women of the Arabs, but was eaten by the men: (K:) or one that was left at liberty, without a pastor: (K:) or, as some say, syn. with saAy^ibapN; i. e., say they, a she-camel which, having brought forth seven young ones, had her ear slit, and was not ridden, nor used for carrying: (Msb:) or a she-camel that had brought forth five young ones, the last of which was a male, in which case her ear was slit, and she was exempted from being ridden and from carrying and from being slaughtered, and not prevented from taking of any water to which she came, nor from any pasturage, nor even ridden by a weary man who, having become unable to proceed in his journey, his means having failed him, or his camel that bore him stopping with him from fatigue or breaking down or perishing, might chance to find her: (Aboo-Is- hák the Grammarian, TA: [and the like, but less fully, is said in the Mgh:]) or, applied specially to a ewe, or she-goat, one that, having brought forth five young ones, had her ear slit: (L, K, TA: [in the CK, for buHirat is put nuHirat:]) it also signifies a she-camel (L) abounding in milk: (L, K:) the pl. is baHaAy^iru and buHurN; (L, K;) the latter a strange form of pl. of a fem. sing. such as bHyrp; and said to be the only instance of the kind except SurumN pl. of SariymapN, meaning “ having her ear cut off. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad., that the person who instituted the practices relative to the bHyrp and the HaAmiY, and the first who altered the religion of Ishmael, was 'Amr the son of Loheí the son of Kama'ah the son of Jundab; and these practices are forbidden in the Kur v. 102. (TA.)

buHayorapN Hyr Hyrp bHyrh bHyrp
A small sea; a lake: as though they imagined the word baHorapN [as syn. with baHorN]: otherwise there is no reason for the p. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also baHorN: and see baHorapN, in two places.
baH~aArN HAr bHAr bHr : see baHoriY~N.
baH~aArapN HAr HArp bHAr bHArh bHArp bHr : see baHoriY~N.
baAHirN A^Hr bAHr bA^Hr : see baHoraAniY~N, in three places.
baAHiriY~N A^Hr A^HrY bAHrY bAHry bA^HrY bA^Hry bA^Hryy : see baHoraAniY~N, in three places.

baAHuwrN A^Hwr bAHwr bA^Hwr and ↓baAHuwraA='u The vehemence of heat in [the Syrian month of] tam~uwz or tamuwz [corresponding to July, O. S.]: (S, K:) [pl. of the former bawaAHiyru:] both are [said to be] post-classical words: (S:) but they are [classical words,] arabicized; for they occur in verses of the kind called rajaz of some of the [early] Arabs. (MF.) -A2- AlbaAHuwru The moon. (Aboo-' Alee, K.)
baAHuwraA='u bAHwrA=' : see baAHuwrN.
baAHuwriY~N A^Hwr bAHwrY bAHwry bA^Hwry bA^Hwryy : see buHoraAnN.
A^ubayoHirN * : dim. of baHorN, q. v. (K.)

R. Q. 1 baxobaxa bxbx , (S, K,) inf. n. baxobaxapN and bixobaAxN, (TA,) [a verb imitative of the sound
which it signifies,] He (a camel [in a state of excitement]) brayed, (S, K,) so that his $iqo$iqap [or faucial bag] filled his mouth: (S:) or, as some say, began to bray. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] He (a man) said [baxo] or baxo baxo [&c.]. (TA, and Har p. 556.) ― -b3- And [hence,] baxobaxa biSuHobatiY He rejoiced in my company. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b4- And baxobaxa Alr~ajula He said baxo or baxo baxo &c. to the man. (S.)

baxo bx , (S, A, K, &c.,) [in some copies of the K written bax~a, which is wrong, for it is] like balo, (A,) [i. e.] like qado, (TA,) [perhaps, as I have suggested above, from the sound made by a hecamel in a state of excitement,] a word used on the occasion of praising; (S, A;) on praising one from whom has proceeded a good and wonderful action; (Har p. 142;) on approving a thing; (T, S, Msb, K;) on being pleased with it, or having one's admiration excited by it; (A, K;) or on the occasion of glorying and of praising; (K;) in pronouncing a thing great in estimation, (IAmb,) or excellent; (AHeyth;) in deeming a thing great in estimation, (AHei,) or good; (Mgh;) or it means wonder, or admiration; (R;) and sometimes it is used [ironically] to denote disapproval; also, as an exhortation to gentleness with a thing, and to taking extraordinary pains; (TA;) and in a case of expertness, or skilfulness: (AHei:) it means niEoma Alr~ajulu and niEoma AlfiEolu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the man! and, the deed!]; (Har p. 142;) [or simply, excellent! or most excellent! how good! how goodly! well done! bravo! and the like;] or EaZuma AlA^amoru and faxuma [great in estimation is the thing, or affair, or event, or case!]: (K:) MF observes, [probably from finding bax~a in the place of baxo in his copy or copies of the K,] that this explanation is like an express assertion that it is a verb in the pret. tense, which requires consideration. (TA.) It is used alone; and in this case you say, baxo, (K,) and baxi, (Msb, K,) with kesr for its invariable termination, (Msb,) and baxK, and baxN; (K, TA; [but in the CK, in the place of baxK and baxN, we find buxN;]) without tesh-deed, (T, Msb,) in most cases; (Msb;) but also with teshdeed, (T, S, A,) like a noun; so that one says, baxK laka and bax~K [&c., meaning I say excel-lent! &c., to thee]: (S:). and one repeats it, (S, A, K, &c.,) for the sake of emphasis; (S, A;) saying, baxo baxo, (IAmb, S, A, K, &c.,) with the x quiescent like the l in halo and balo, (IAmb,) and baxK baxK, (S, A, R, K,) pronounced in the latter manner, with tenween, when in connexion with a following word, [and in this case only, whereas it is pronounced in the former manner in any case,] (S, A,) and bax~K bax~K, (S, * A, * R, K,) and baxK baxo, (K,) and bax~i bax~i. (R.)

jamalN baxobaAxu Alhadiyri jml bxbAx Alhdyr
A camel that fills his mouth with his $iqo$iqap [or faucial bag] when he brays. (S.)

A_ibilN muboxobaxapN Abl mbxbxh Abl mbxbxp
Camels to which one says baxo baxo; being pleased with them: (ISd, TA:) or largebellied camels; (K;) as also muxaboxabapN, which is formed from the former by transposition; from baxo baxo, or baxK baxo, which is said by the Arabs in praising a thing; as though, by reason of their greatness, the people, seeing them, said, How goodly are they! (TA.)

1 baxatahu bAx bx bxA bxt bxth bxtp
He beat, struck, or smote, him; (JK, K;) namely, a man. (JK.) [See also bakatahu.]

2 taboxiytN tbxyt [inf. n. of bax~atahu] The overcoming another with an argument or the like; or reducing him to silence, through inability to reply; i. q. tabokiytN: and the addressing an adversary in a dispute or litigation with speech so as to put a stop to his plea, or allegation: from the author of the Tekmileh. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, as a term of the theologians, The believing at first view, without consideration of a thing: so in Sal~aY EalaY Alt~aboxiyti [he prayed according to the belief which he formed at first view, without consideration]; said of a person when the kibleh is doubtful, and he cannot work out a solution of the difficulty. (Mgh.)
Q. Q. 2 tabaxotaY tbxtY tbxty : see tabaxotara.

baxotN bAx bx bxA bxt
Fortune; or particularly good fortune; syn. jad~N, (S, A, K,) and HaZ~N: (Msb, TA:) a foreign, or Persian, word, (Msb,) arabicized: (S, K:) or post-classical: accord. to the 'Ináyeh, not a chaste Arabic word: but in the Shifá el-Ghaleel said to have been used by the Arabs in ancient times; and the like is said in the L: Az says, “ I know not if it be Arabic or not. ” (TA.)

buxotu bAx bx bxA bxt [a coll. gen. n.] A species of camels; (S, * Msb;) the Khurásánee [or Bactrian] camels; (K;) begot between an Arabian she-camel and a faAlij [which is a large two-humped camel brought from Es-Sind for the purpose of covering]; (TA;) long-necked; (Nh;) [large and strong, accord. to Ibn-Maaroof; and two-humped, accord. to Leo Africanus: the Mauritanian Arabs call thus all camels promiscuously; but accord. to the more common use of the word are to be understood hairy camels, fit for winter-work; generally of Turhumán or Bactrian breed; distinct from the Arabian, which are accustomed to bear bardens in winter and summer: (Golius:)] they are also called ↓ buxotiy~apN: (K:) n. un. ↓ buxotiY~N; (S, Msb;) fem. ↓ buxotiy~apN: (S:) pl. baxaAtiY~u, (S, Msb, K,) imperfectly decl., (S,) and baxaAtaY (K, TA [in the CK baxaAtiY]) and baxaAtK, (K,) and you may say [with the article] AlbaxaAtiY, without tenween: (S, Msb:) it is a foreign, or Persian, word, (TA,) arabicized: but some say, it is Arabic: (S, TA:) some hesitate as to its being Arabic because baxotN, meaning xaZ~N, is not. (Msb.)
buxotiY~N bxt bxtY bxty and buxotiy~apN: see buxotN; for the latter, in two places.
baxiytN bxyt , not thought by IDrd to be a chaste word, (TA,) Fortunate; possessed of good fortune; (A, K, TA;) as also ↓maboxuwtN. (S, A, K.)
bax~aAtN bxAt One who acquires, as his permanent property, camels such as are termed buxot: (K:) and one who makes use of such camels. (TA.)
maboxuwtN mbxwt : see baxiytN.
Q. 1 baxotara bxtr xtr : see what next follows.

Q. 2 tabaxotara bxtr tbxtr , (L,) inf. n. tabaxoturN; (JK, S, L, K;) and ↓ baxotara, (L,) inf. n. baxotarapN; (L, K;) He walked in a certain manner; (S;) with an elegant gait; (JK, K;) with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, (L, TA, TK,) with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (TK;) or with a twisting of the back, (Fr, in TA, voce tamaT~aTa, and Bd in lxxv. 33,) and with extended steps. (Bd ibid.) You say also, fulaAnN yatabaxotaru fiY mi$oyatihi and yatabaxotaY [Such a one carries himself in an elegant and a proud and self-conceited manner, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, in his gait; or with a twisting of his back, and with extended steps]. (L.)

baxotariY~N bxtrY bxtry xtr and ↓ bixotiyrN Elegant, or beautiful, in gait and in body; (L, K: in [some of] the copies of the K, instead of waAljisomi, is erroneously put waAljasiymu: TA:) applied to a man: (L:) or (so accord. to the L and TA, but in the K “ and ”) proud and self-conceited: (L, K:) or who walks in the manner termed tabaxoturN [see Q. 2.]: (JK, L:) the former epithet is also applied to a camel: (L:) the fem. of the former is with p. (JK, L.)

buxoturiY~N bxtrY bxtry xtr a subst. signifying The gait denoted by Alt~abaxoturu [inf. n. of Q. 2]: (JK:) [and so ↓ baxotariy~apN: whence the phrase] fulaAnN yamo$iY Albaxotariy~apN Such a one walks in the manner termed tabaxoturN. (S, L.)
baxotariy~apN bxtryh bxtryp : see what next precedes.
bixotiyrN bxtyr : see baxotariY~N.

baxura , (Msb,) or
baxara , (K,) inf. n. baxorN (Msb, K) and buxaArN, (TA,) The cooking-pot sent up fume, vapour, steam, or an exhalation. (Msb, K. *) -A2- baxira, (S, K,) aor.
baxara , (K,) inf. n. baxarN, (TA,) He had a stinking mouth [or breath; he exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour from his mouth]. (S, L, K.) You say, baxiratN EalayonaA She exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour upon us from her mouth. (A. [But in my copy of that work, and in the TA, it is erroneously written baxarato.]) And baxira Alfamu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The mouth stank; exhaled a stinking, or fetid, odour. (Msb.) [See baxarN, below.]

She perfumed [or rather fumigated her own or another's person or clothes &c. with baxuwr]. (A.)

It (a thing) caused him to have a stinking mouth [or breath]. (K, * TA.)

K.) One says, fulaAnN yatabax~aru wa yabaxotaru [Such a one fumigates himself with perfume, and walks with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side]. (A.)

baxarN bxr xr
Stench, or fetor, of the mouth [or breath] (S, A, K) &c.: (AHn, K:) and any odour that rises and diffuses itself, (K, TA,) whether stinking or not; as also ↓ buxaArN. (TA.)

buxaArN bxAr [Fume, vapour, steam, or exhalation;] what rises from water, like smoke; (S;) any fume (K, TA) that rises and diffuses itself (TA) from what is hot, (K, TA,) or from hot water; (TA;) anything that rises and diffuses itself from hot water or from damp earth: pl. A^aboxirapN and buxaAraAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also The stench of a noiseless emission of wind from the anus. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baxarN.

baxuwrN bxwr xwr
Incense, or a substance for fumigation; syn. duxonapN; (Msb;) that with which one fumigates himself: (S, A, Msb, K:) aloes-wood used for that purpose. (TA in art. qtr.) ― -b2- baxuwru maroyama [Arthanita, or sow-bread; the common cyclamen; also called Alwalofu; the latter name, accord. to Golius, on the authority of Zeyn El-'Attár, given to it by the Syrians;] a certain plant, (K,) originally called EaroTaniyvaA; hot; dry; (TA;) having the property of clearing the complexion, or skin; aperient; diuretic; (K;) laxative; (TA;) and very useful: (K:) it is a laxative when used in the form of a suppository, or applied as a liniment below the navel. (TA.)

A^aboxaru *
Having a stinking mouth [or breath]: (S, Msb, K:) fem. baxoraA='u: and pl. buxorN. (Msb.)

maboxarapN mbxrh mbxrp
A thing that occasions one's knowing, or inferring, or suspecting, stench, or fetor, of the mouth [or breath; a cause of stench, or fetor, of the mouth or breath]: such is said to be the sleeping between daybreak and sunrise, or in the first part of the day. (TA.)

miboxarapN mbxrh mbxrp
A vessel for fumigation; a censer; syn. mijomarapN [q. v.: pl. mabaAxiru]. (Msb in art. jmr.)
mubax~arN mbxr A garment perfumed [or rather fumigated with perfume]. (A.)
maboxuwrN mbxwr [Affected by the fumes of wine &c.; or] affected with pain and headache occasioned by wine, or with the remains of intoxication. (IAar, K.)

1 baxasahu bxs bxsh bxsp xs xsp , aor.
baxasa , inf. n. baxosN, He diminished it; lessened it; made it deficient, or defective: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he made it faulty. (Msb.) You say, baxasa Alkay~aAlu [for baxasa Alkay~aAlu Alkayola The measurer made defective measure]. (A.) And of a just sale, laA baxosa fiyhi wa laA $aTaTa, (S,) or walaA $uTuwTa, (T, TA,) [There is no deficiency in it nor excess.] And it is said in the Kur [lxxii. 13], falaA yaxaAfu baxosFA walaA rahaqFA He shall not fear diminution of the reward of his actions, nor wrong, or injustice. (TA.) And in this sense, [as also in the next,] the verb is doubly trans. (Msb.) You say, baxasahu Haq~ahu He diminished to him his right, or due; deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part of it. (S, A.) And it is said in the Kur [vii. 83 and xi. 86 and xxvi. 183], walaA taboxasuwA Aln~aAsa A^a$oyaA='ahumo [And ye shall not diminish unto men their things]: (Msb:) or the verb in this instance has the signification next following. (TA.) ― -b2- He wronged him; acted wrongfully, or unjustly, towards him. (A, K.) -A2- baxasa Eayonahu: see baxaSa.

6 tbAxswA tbAxswA
They defrauded one another in a sale. (K.)

baxosN bxs xs
Deficient; defective. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 20], wa$arawohu bivamanK baxosK And they sold him for a deficient, or defective, price: (S, * Msb, * TA:) or for a price less than was incumbent: or for an insufficient price: or for an unjust price; accord. to Zj; because the sale of a man that has been found is unlawful. (TA.) -A2- Land that produces herbage without being [artificially] watered: (JK, S, K:) or land which is watered by the rain; because it has deficient watering: (Mgh:) pl. buxuwsN. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (TA, as from Ibn-Málik,) or ↓ baxosiY~N, [which is more probably the correct form,] a rel. n. from baxosN in the sense immediately preceding, explained in the T as signifying, (Mgh,) Seed-produce that is not irrigated with water from a spring or well or the like, but only by the rain. (Mgh, and TA from Ibn-Málik.)
baxosiY~N bxs bxsY bxsy xs : see baxosN.

baAxisN bAxs Any one who acts wrongfully, or unjustly. (TA.) It is said in a prov., taHosibuhaA HamoqaA='a wa hiYa baAxisN; (S, A, K;) so runs the prov.; but accord. to Th, (S,) you may also say baAxisapN; (S, K;) i. e., [Thou thinkest her stupid,] but she is wrongful, or unjust: applied to him who feigns himself to be of weak understanding when he is crafty and cunning. (K, TA.) The origin of the prov. was this: a man of the Benu-l-' Ambar, of Temeem, mixed his property with that of a woman, coveting the possession of it, and thinking that she was stupid, and that she did not take care of her property nor know it: then he made a division with her, after he had mixed; but she was not content with the division until she took her property: she complained of him to those in authority, so that he released himself from her by giving her what she desired of the property: and the man was reproved for his conduct; it being said to him, “ Thou cheatest a woman: is not this wrongful conduct (baxos)? ” whereupon he replied in the words above, which became a proverb. (Th, K, * TA.)

1 baxaSa Eayonahu bxS Eynh bxS Eynp , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
baxaSa , (S, Mgh, K,) inf. n. baxoSN, (S, Mgh,) He put out his eye; syn. faqaA^ahaA, (Mgh,) and Eaw~arahaA: (A, Mgh:) or he pulled out his eye [altogether, i. e.,] with its bulb: (S, K: [in the former, maED $aHomatihaA: in the latter, not so well, bi$aHomihaA:]) or he put his finger into his eye: (Msb:) Yaakoob says that you should not say baxasa; (S;) and so says ISk: (TA in art. bxs:) but accord. to As, as related by Aboo-Turáb, you say baxaSa Eayonahu and baxazahaA and baxasahaA, all as meaning he put out his eye; syn. faqaA^ahaA: (TA:) and IAar says that baxasahaA and baxaSahaA signify alike: (Msb:) the former of these two is a dial. var. of the latter; (TA in art. bxs;) and signifies he put it out (faqaA^ahaA) with his finger or some other thing: (Lth, As, and K in art. bxs:) but baxaSa is the better word. (Lh, IAar, Msb.)

1 baxaEa Al*~abiyHapa * , (Z, in the Fáïk,) or Al$~aApa, (Z, in the A,) or biAl$~aApi, (O, K,) [aor.
baxaEa , inf. n. baxoEN,] He slaughtered the beast for slaughter, or the sheep or goat, with much, or extraordinary, effectiveness, or energy, (Z, K,) so that he reached the back of the neck, (Z, in the A,) or so that he reached the bixaAE, (K, TA, [in the CK nuxaAE,]) cutting the bone of the neck. (TA.) This is the primary signification; and hence the verb is used to denote the doing anything to a great extent, in a great degree, egregiously, or with much or extraordinary effectiveness or energy or the like. (Z, K.) ― -b2- [Hence you say,] baxaEa nafosahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baxaEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. baxoEN (S, Msb) and buxuwEN, (TA,) (tropical:) He killed himself with grief, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or with wrath, or rage. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And baAlaguwA fiY baxoEi A^anofusihimo (tropical:) They exceeded the ordinary bounds in subduing and abasing themselves by obedience. (TA.) ― -b4- And baxaEotu laka nafosiY wa nuSoHiY, aor.
baxaEa , inf. n. buxuwEN, (tropical:) I exerted for thee myself and my good advice, or counsel, laboriously, earnestly, or with energy: (TA:) and baxaEa lahu nuSoHahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. baxoEN, (TA,) (tropical:) He acted sincerely towards him, and took extraordinary pains, in giving him good advice, or counsel. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And baxaEa lahu, biAlHaq~i, (S, * K, * TA,) inf. n. buxuwEN; and baxiEa, inf. n. buxuwEN and baxaAEapN; (tropical:) He confessed, or acknowledged, to him the right, or due, and humbled himself to him: (S, K, TA:) or you say, baxaEaniY biAlHaq~i, inf. n. buxuwEN, meaning (assumed tropical:) he submitted himself to me, and gave the right, or due, freely: (Msb:) and baxaEotu lahu (assumed tropical:) I became submissive and obedient, and made confession, or acknowledgment, to him: or, accord. to the A, baxaEa signifies (tropical:) he made confession, or acknowledgment, with the utmost submissiveness. (TA.) ― -b6- And baxaEa fulaAnFA xabarahu (tropical:) He related his information, or news, truly to such a one. (K.) ― -b7- Also, baxaEa Alr~akiy~apa, aor.
baxaEa , inf. n. baxoEN, (assumed tropical:) He dug the well until its water appeared. (Ks, K.) ― -b8- And hence the saying of 'Áïsheh, speaking of 'Omar, baxaEa AlA^aroDa faqaA='ato A^ukolahaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He subdued and abased the people of the earth, [so that it disclosed] and he drew forth the treasures that it contained, and the possessions of the kings. (TA.) And baxaEa AlA^aroDa biAlz~iraAEapi, (K,) inf. n. baxoEN, (TA,) (tropical:) He exhausted the strength of the land by sowing,
tilling it continuously, and not giving it rest for a year. (K, TA.)

AlbixaAEu AlbxAE
A certain vein, or nerve, (Eiroq,) in the Sulob [or back-bone], (Z in the Fáïk and Ksh, and K,) lying within the qafaA [or back of the neck]; (Z in the Ksh, and TA;) Bd says, lying within the faqaAr [or vertebræ]; but it is said that this is a mistranscription, and that the right reading is the qfA, as in the Ksh; and it is said in the K to be running into the bone [or, as in the CK, bones,] of the neck; but this is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to an assertion of Z, (K,) in his Fáïk and Ksh, (TA,) it is different from the nuxaAE, with n, which is the white cord in the interior of the bone of the neck, extending to the back-bone: but IA th says, I have searched long in lexicons, and in books of medicine and anatomy, but have not found AlbxAE, with b, mentioned in any of them. (TA.)

falaEal~aka baAxiEN nafosaka flElk bAxE nfsk , in the Kur [xviii. 5], (S,) means (tropical:) And may-be thou wilt hill thyself (S, K) with grief, (S,) being beyond measure eager for their becoming Muslims. (K, TA.) These words imply an incitement to abstain from regret. (B.)

A^aboxaEu * [More, and most, effectual to kill, and destroy]. (K voce A^axonaEu, q. v.) ― -b2- humo A^aboxaEu TaAEapF (tropical:) They are more sincere and more energetic in obedience than others; as though they exceeded the ordinary bounds in subduing and abasing themselves by obedience. (TA, from a trad.)

baxaqa ; and baxaqa, aor.
baxuqa ; He had that affection of an eye which is termed baxaqu, explained below. (K.) [And,] accord. to ISd, baxaqato Eayonuhu, and baxiqato, His eye went away; or perished: and i. q. EaArato [his eye became blind; or became wanting; or sank in its socket]: the more approved form is [baxaqato,] with fet-h [to the medial radical]: and it is also explained as meaning fuqiy^ato [it was put out; or was blinded; &c.]: (TA:) or, accord. to the Mj, baxiqati AlEayonu signifies the flesh [app. meaning the bulb, which is also termed the $aHomap,] of the eye disappeared: and the epithet applied to the eye in this case is ↓ baxoqaA='u. (Mgh.) -A2- baxaqa Eayonahu, aor.
baxaqa , (S, K,) inf. n. baxoqN, (S,) i. q. Eaw~arahaA [He put out his eye; or made it to sink in its socket]; (Lth, S, K;) as also ↓ A^aboxaqahaA: (TA:) or the former, (Mgh,) and ↓ the latter, (AA, K, TA,) i. q. faqaA^ahaA [he put it out; or blinded it; &c.]. (AA, Mgh, K.)

baxaqN bxq [app. inf. n. of baxiqa: and, as a simple subst.,] The worst, or most unseemly, kind of Eawar [or blindness of one eye, or loss thereof, &c.], and that in which there is most [of the foul matter termed] gamaS: [in the CK, for A^akovaruhu gamaSFA, is erroneously put Aakovaruhu gamoDFA; and so I find in the JK:] or the state in which the edge of one's eyelid ($uforu Eayonihi [in the CK $uforu Eayonayohi]) will not meet the black, or part surrounded by the white: (Lth, K:) or blindness of one eye (EawarN) by the disappearance, in the head, of the black, or part surrounded by the white: (S:) or the disappearance of that part of the eye, in the head, after blindness of the eye: (Sh, TA:) or the having the sight gone, but the eye remaining open, blind, or white and blind, but still whole. (IAar, TA.)
baxiyqN bxyq , and with p: see A^aboxaqu, in three places.
baAxiqu AlEayonu bAxq AlEyn : and EayonN baAxiqapN: see A^aboxaqu, in two places.

rajulN A^aboxaqu * , and ↓ baxiyqN and AlEayoni ↓ baAxiqu and AlEayoni ↓ maboxuwqu all signify the same; (K;) i. e. A man blind of one eye; or wanting one eye; or having one of his eyes sunk in its socket; or having one of his eyes dried up; syn. A^aEowaru: (TA:) [or having that affection of an eye which is termed baxaqN:] and in like manner baxoqaA='u applied to a sheep or goat for sacrifice on the occasion of the pilgrimage signifies EaworaA='u [blind of one eye; &c.]; (Mgh, TA;) or, as some say, having an eye of which the black, or part surrounded by the white, has disappeared in the head. (Mgh.) And EayonN baxoqaA='u and ↓ baAxiqapN and ↓ baxiyqN and ↓ baxiyqapN i. q. EaworaA='u [An eye that is blind; &c.]: (K:) see also 1.
maboxuwqu AlEayoni mbxwq AlEyn : see A^aboxaqu.
