baxala , inf. n. baxalN; (JK, Msb, K;) and baxula, aor.
baxula , inf. n. buxolN; (Msb, K;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: see buxolN, below. (K, TA.) You say, baxila bika*aA, (S, TA,) and baxula bihi, He was, or became, niggardly, &c., of such a thing. (TA.) And baxila Eanohu [He withheld, with niggardliness, from him]: and baxila Ealayohi [he was niggardly to him]. (Bd and Jel in xlvii. last verse.)

2 bx~lhu bxl bxlh bxlp xl xlp , (S, K,) inf. n. taboxiylN, (K,) He attributed, or imputed, to him buxol [or niggardliness, &c.]: (S:) or he accused him thereof: (K:) or he called him baxiyl [or niggardly, &c.]. (TA.)

4 Abxlhu Abxlh Abxlp
He found him to be baxiyl [or niggardly, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.)
baxolN bxl xl : see what next follows.

buxolN bxl xl and ↓ baxalN, [both of which are properly inf. ns.,] (JK, S, K,) and ↓ baxolN, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) which is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ↓ buxulN (K) and ↓ baxilN and ↓ bixolN (TA) and ↓ buxuwlN, (K,) of all which, the first is that which commonly obtains, (TA,) are syn., (JK, S,) signifying Niggardliness, tenaciousness, stinginess, penuriousness, or avarice; contr. of karamN (K, TA) and juwdN; and its definition is the withholding of acquired articles of property from that wherefrom it is not lawful to withhold them: (TA:) or the debarring the asker, or beggar, from what one has that is superabundant: (Msb:) and in the law, the refusal of what is incumbent, or obligatory. (Msb, TA.)
bixolN bxl xl : see what next precedes.
baxalN bxl xl : see buxolN: ― -b2- and see also baxiylN.
baxilN bxl xl : see buxolN.
buxulN bxl xl : see buxolN.

baxolapN bxl bxlh bxlp xl xlp
A single act, or instance, of buxol [or niggardliness &c.]. (JK, TA.)
baxaAlN bxAl xAl xAly : see what next follows.

baxiylN A^xyl bxyl xyl (JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓ baAxilN (S, Msb, K) Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; (K;) i. e. *uw buxolK; (Msb;) epithets from 1: (S, Msb: *) or one from whom niggardliness is experienced much or often: (TA: [appin explanation of the former:]) and so ↓ baxalN, in inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore implying more than the possession of the simple attribute of niggardliness &c., being a kind of personification]; (Abu-l-'Omeythil El-Aarábee, K;) and ↓ bax~aAlN (S, K) and ↓ baxaAlN (K) and ↓ mubax~alN (JK, K) i. e. $adiydu Albuxoli [very, or vehemently, niggardly &c.]: (S, TA:) pl. of the first, buxalaA='u; (Msb, K;) and of the second, bux~alN (K) and bux~aAlN. (TA.)
buxuwlN bxwl xwl : see buxolN.
bax~aAlN bxAl xAl xAly : see baxiylN.
baAxilN bAxl : see baxiylN.

maboxalapN mbxlh mbxlp
A cause of, or a thing that incites to, buxol [or niggardliness &c.]: (K:) a word of the same class as majobanapN and maholakapN and maEoTa$apN and mafaAzapN &c. (TA.) So explained as occurring in the trad., (TA,) Alwaladu maboxalapN majobanapN [Children are a cause of niggardliness and a cause of cowardice]; (S, TA;) because on account of them one loves property, and continuance of life. (S in art. jbn.)
mubax~alN mbxl : see baxiylN.

1 bad~a bd , aor.
badu3a , inf. n. bad~N: see 2. ― -b2- bad~a rijolayohi He parted his legs, or straddled, (S, M, K,) in the stocks, or otherwise. (M.) ― -b3- bad~ahu, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He removed with it, withdrew with it, drew away with it, [or drew it away, from its place,] (M, K,) namely, a thing. (M.) ― -b4- He made him (namely, his companion, M) to retire, or withdraw, far away; and to refrain, forbear, or abstain; (M, K;) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing. (M.) ― -b5- A^anaA A^abud~u bika Eano *`lika AlA^amori I will defend thee from that thing, or event, by repelling it, or averting it, from thee. (M, L.) ― -b6- bud~a Eano dabari Ald~aAb~api It (a felt cloth) was cut, or slit, so as to be clear of the galls, or sores, on the back of the beast. (M, TA.) -A2- bad~a, (M,) second pers. badidota, (S, K,) aor. yabad~u, (M,) inf. n. badadN, (T, S, M, K,) He (a man) was, or became,
wide between the thighs, (ISk, T, S, M, K,) by reason of abundance of flesh: (ISk, S, M:) or wide between the arms; (K;) having the arms far from the sides: (M:) or wide between the shoulder-joints: (M:) or large in make, having one part far from another. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also He (a quadruped, ISk, T, S, or a horse, M) had his fore legs far apart: (ISk, T, S, M:) or he (a horse) had his fore legs far from his sides: (Lth, T:) and he (a camel) had his elbows far from his sides. (T.) -A3- bad~a qatabahu, aor.
badu3a , He furnished his camel's saddle with what are called bidaAdaAni and badiydaAni (S.) [See bidaAdN]

2 bd~d bdd , inf. n. tabodiydN, He separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated; (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K;) as also ↓ bad~a, aor.
badu3a , inf. n. bad~N: (S, L:) or the latter has this meaning, and the former signifies he separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated, much. (Msb.) ― -b2- He (a man) gave his equal share of the expenses for a journey. (IAar, T.) [See also 3.] -A2- He (a man) was, or became, weary, tired, or fatigued: (IAar, T, M, K:) or he drowsed, or slumbered, while sitting, without sleeping. (K.)

3 bAd~ Alqawomu bAd Alqwm , (T, K,) inf. n. mubaAd~apN (M, K) and bidaAdN, (T, M, K,) with which the subst. ↓ badaAdN is syn., (M, and mentioned also in a MS. copy of the K, and in the CK, and in the TA, but not as from the K,) as also ↓ bidaAdapN, (TA, as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,) The people, or company of men, contributed what was necessary to be expended (in a journey, T, M, L), each man giving something, and then collected the sum, and expended it among themselves. (T, M, L, K.) In a copy of the K, for yunofiquwnahu, is erroneously put yuboquwnahu. (TA. [In the CK, yaboquwnahu.]) Accord. to IAar, bidaAdN signifies The contributing equally for the purchasing of corn, or food, to eat: and also a people's having money, or property, divided into lots, or portions, and distributed in shares among them: (L:) [and] accord. to the same, the dividing property among a people in shares. (T. [See also 4.]) ― -b2- Also, bAd~hu, (M, A, K,) or bAd~hu fY AlbayoEi, (S,) inf. n. mubaAd~apN, (S, A, K,) or mubaAdadap, (TA,) and bidaAdN; (S, M, A, K;) and so ↓ baAyaEahu badadFA, (S M, K,) or mubaAd~apF; (A;) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him; syn. EaAraDahu biAlbayoEi, (M, A, * L,) and baAEahu muEaAraDahF: (S, K:) from the saying, `h`*aA bi*~uhu, and bid~uhu, “ this is the like of it: ” (L:) from IAar. (M.) ― -b3- [See also bud~N.]

4 Abd~ fiyhimu AlEaTaA=' Abd fyhm AlETA=' , (As, T,) and Abd~ bayonahumo AlEaTaA='a, (S, M, L, K,) and A^abad~ahumo AlEaTaA='a, (M, A, Mgh,) He divided among them the gift, giving to each of them his lot, or share, or portion, (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K,) singly, not giving a portion to be shared by two: (As, T, M, * Mgh, L:) said with respect to food and property and any other thing. (M.) You say, A^abodadotuhumo AlmaAla wa AlT~aEaAma I divided among them, in shares, the property and the food. (IAar, T.) [Hence,] A^abid~iyhimo tamorapF tamorapF (T, S, A, Mgh, from a trad.) [Give thou to each of them a date; or] distribute thou among them to each a date: (T:) said by Umm-Selemeh, (T, A, Mgh,) to a slave-girl, when beggars had become numerous. (A.) A_ibodaAdN in relation to a gift signifies The giving [persons] one by one; and qiraAnN, the “ giving two by two. ” (A 'Obeyd, T.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- yubid~uhumo is used by a poet, referring to a saying, and is explained by IAar as meaning It (the saying) shall be distributed among them (yuf~arqu fiyhimo); opposed to yajomaEu [i. e. yajomaEuhumo; which shows that the former means it shall be addressed to them one by one, or separately]. (M, TA. [The author of the former adds, “ I know not, in discourse, A^abodadotuhu as meaning far~aqotuhu: ” but this is not what I Aar means.]) ― -b3- A^abid~ahumaA naEojatayona Allot thou to them (namely, two lambs,) two ewes, to each lamb a ewe, to suckle it: said when one ewe is not sufficient for both the lambs. (T, * S.) ― -b4- Abd~ DaboEayohi He extended his upper arms, separating them from his sides, in prostrating himself in prayer. (T, A, Mgh, L.) ― -b5- Abd~ yadahu A_ilay AlA^aroDi He extended his arm, or hand, to the ground, or earth, (T, S, Mgh, L,) as one does when he takes up something from it. (L.) ― -b6- Abd~ naZarahu He prolonged his look. (T, L.) And Abd~hu baSarahu (T, A, L) He prolonged his look at him, or it; as one does when he sees a thing that he dislikes. (T, L.)

5 tbd~d bd bdd tbdd
It (a thing, S, M, L, and a people, or company of men, T, L) became separated, disunited, dispersed, or dissipated; (T, S, M, L, K;) [as also ↓ badobada, for its inf. n.] badobadapN likewise signifies the being separated, disunited, &c. (AA, T.) -A2- tbd~dwA $ayoy^FA They divided a thing among themselves in lots, shares, or portions, (K,) equally. (TA.) ― -b2- tbd~d Sadora AljaAriyapi It (an ornament) occupied the two sides, (A,) or the whole, (K,) of the bosom of the girl. (A, K.) [See an ex. voce jaliyfF.]

6 tbAd~wA A^bAd bAdY tbAdwA
They removed to a distance, one from another. (Ham p. 823.) ― -b2- They went, or passed, two by two, each one of a pair removing, or withdrawing, with the other, or making the other to retire, or withdraw, far away. (M.) ― -b3- They went forth into the field [of battle], one to another: (A:) or they took their adversaries, or opponents, [with whom to fight,] (T, S, K,) each man his man; as also ↓ laquwA badaAdahumo: (K:) or this latter signifies they met their numbers, to each man a man. (T, S.)

8 Abtd~Ahu biAAlD~arobi AbtdAh bAAlDrb
They two took him on both sides of him, (T, S, K,) or came to him on both sides of him, (K,) with beating. (T, S.) ― -b2- Als~abuEaAni yabotad~aAni Alr~ajula The two wild beasts come upon both sides of the man. (S, A.) ― -b3- Alr~aDiyEaAni yabotad~aAni A^um~ahumaA (T, S, A *) The two sucklings suck their mother on either side, one from one breast and the other from the other breast. (T, A, * TA.) You do not say, yabotad~uhaA A@bonuhaA, but yabotad~uhaA A@bonaAhaA. (T, S.)

10 Astbd~ A^stbd Astbd {stbd
He was, or became, alone; independent of others; (S, M, L, Msb, K; in the first and last expl. by tafar~ada; and in the others, by Ainofarada;) exclusively of others; (L;) without any to share, or participate, with him; or he had none to share, or participate, with him: (Msb:) bihi [in it; i. e. he had it, or kept it, to himself, exclusively, with none to share with him in it]: (K:) and bika*aA [in such a thing]: (S, L:) and biraA^oyihi [in his opinion; i. e. he followed his own opinion only, with none to agree with him; or he was singular in his opinion]: (M, L:) and biA^amorK [in a thing, or an affair]: (L, Msb:) and biA^amorihi [in his affair]; meaning he obtained [absolute] predominance, or control, over his affair, so that people would not hear [or obey] any other. (A.) It is said in a trad., kun~aA naray A^an~a lanaAfiYi h`*aA AlA^amori Haq~aA faA@sotabadotumo EalayonaA [We used to opine that we had a right to act in this affair, and ye have been alone the actors, predominant over us]. (L.) And you say, Astbd~ AlA^amoru bifulaAnK, meaning (tropical:) The thing, or affair, overcame such a one, so that he could not manage it well, or thoroughly. (A.)
R. Q. 1 badobada bdbd , inf. n. badobadapN: see 5.

budN bd as signifying A separating oneself, or an artifice whereby one may avoid a thing or escape from it, (MF,) or an avoiding a thing, (Msb,) is not used but in negative phrases, (Msb, MF,) except by post-classical writers. (MF.) You say, laA bud~a mino ka*aA (T, S, M, &c.) There is no separating oneself from such a thing: (AA, T, S, A, K:) or there is no artifice whereby one may avoid it, or escape from it: (M, K:) or there is no avoiding it: (Msb:) it is absolutely necessary: it is not possible to separate oneself from it, nor is there anything that can serve in its stead. (TA.) And maA laka minohu bud~N [Thou hast not any means, or way, of separating thyself from it, or avoiding it]. (M, L.) And layosa lih`*aA AlA^amori bud~N There is no artifice for this affair. (T.) [It is also said, with reference to the first of these phrases, that] bud~N signifies Amplitude; from A^abad~u meaning “ wide between the legs. ” (Ham p. 348.) -A2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ bid~N (M) and ↓ bidaAdN (IAar, T, M, K) and ↓ budaAdN, (K, TA,) or ↓ badaAdN, (CK,) and ↓ bud~apN, (IAar, T, M, K,) or ↓ bid~apN, (S, A, IAth, and mentioned also in a copy of the K,) but J has been charged with error in writing it thus, (K,) by Sgh, (TA,) A lot, share, portion, or set portion; (T, S, M, A, IAth, K;) of anything: (M, K:) [or] the last signifies a piece, or portion, separated, disunited, or dispersed: (Ham p. 823:) the pl. of bidaAdN is bududN; and of budadN bud~apN; (IAar, T, M;) and of bidadN bid~apN. (IAth, and Ham p. 823.) ― -b2- Also the first, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in the place of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. EiwaDN: (S, L, TA:) it is said to have this signification. (S.) [In the copies of the K, AlbaEuwDu is put in the place of AlEiwaDu: but this is said in the TA to be a mistake.] -A3- bud~N is also an arabicized word, from buto, (T, S, M, K, [in a copy of the M, but~,]) which is Persian; (T, S;) meaning An idol; (IDrd, S, M, K;) pl. badadapN (S, K) and A^abodaAdN: (K:) and (or accord. to some,
TA) the house of an idol: (K:) or a house in which are idols and images or pictures. (M.)

bid~N bd : see bud~N. ― -b2- Also, and ↓ badiydN (T, K) and ↓ badiydapN, (K,) A like; a fellow; an equal. (T, K.) You say, huwa bid~uhu and ↓ badiyduhu He, or it, is the like, &c., of him, or it. (T.) And huma bid~aAni They two are likes, or fellows, or equals. (TA.) And fatukal~imaniY ↓ maA A^anota liY bibadiydK Thou art not my like, or fellow, or equal, that thou shouldst speak to me. (TA.)
bad~apN bd bdh bdp : see badadN.

bud~apN bd bdh bdp : see bud~N. -A2- Also A distance; a space; an interval; an extent, or an extreme extent; a long space, or any space, of time. (M, K, * TA.) So in the saying, bayoniY wa bayonaka bud~apN [Between me and thee is a distance, &c.]. (M, TA.)
bid~apN bd bdh bdp : see bud~N, and bidaAdi: -A2- and see also badadN.

badada bdd and badadFA: see badaAdi, in three places: -A2- and see also 3. -A3- maA laka bihi badadN and ↓ bad~apN and ↓ bid~apN Thou hast not power, or ability, to do it, or to bear it, or to cope with him. (S, M, K.)

jaA='ati Alxayolu badaAdi jA='t Alxyl bdAd ; (T, S;) in which bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination because it deviates from its original form, i. e., the inf. n. badadN; and it is indecl. because it deviates from its original form and is of the fem. gender and has the quality of an epithet; for two of these causes render it imperfectly decl., and the three render it indecl.; (S;) or badaAdi badaAdi, and badaAda badaAda, (Lh, M, K,) the last indecl. with fet-h for its termination, (TA,) and ↓ badada badada, (Lh, M, K,) also indecl., with fet-h, (TA,) and composed in the same manner as xamosapa Ea$ara, (Lh, M, TA,) and ↓ badadFA badadFA; (Lh, M, K;) all of these indecl. except the last, and each virtually in the accus. case as a denotative of state, except the last, (MF,) which is literally in the accus. case, as an inf. n.; (M, MF;) The horses, or horsemen, came in a state of dispersion: (T, S, M, K:) or one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) And taf~r~aqa Alqawomu badaAd The people, or company of men, became separated, in a state of dispersion. (S.) And *ahaba Alqawomu badaAdi badAdi The people, or company of men, went away [in a state of dispersion; or] one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) [See also A^abaAdiyd.] It is said in a form of prayer, Aall`hum~a A^aHoSihimo EadadFA ↓ A@qotulohumo badadFA [O God, slay them one by one, and reckon them by number]: (M:) or A^aHoSihimo EadadFA wa A@loEanohumo bidadFA, or, accord. to one recital, waA@qotulohumo bidadFA, pl. of ↓ bid~apN, the meaning being [reckon them by number, and] curse them, or slay them, with a cursing, or slaughter, distributed among them by shares. (Mgh.) ― -b2- yaA qawomi badaAdi badaAdi means O my people, take each one of you his adversary, or opponent [with whom to fight]. (As, T, S, K. *) Here bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is an imperative verbal noun, and the imperative is alike uninfluenced with respect to its termination by any governing word; and it is said to be with kesr because two quiescent letters would otherwise occur together, [and] because it occupies the place of an imperative verb [which in like manner is terminated with kesr when it is necessary to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together]. (S.) ― -b3- With the article, you say, AlbadaAdu, (As, T,) which signifies The going forth to encounter another in fight, or to single combat; as in the saying, lawo kaAna AlbadaAdu lamaA A^aTaAquwnaA Had we gone forth to encounter them in fight, (As, T, S, K,) man to man, [they had not been able to cope with us;] (As, T;) or man by man. (S, K.) You say also, laquwA badaAdahumo, explained above: see 6. -A2- See also bud~N. -A3- And see 3.
budaAdN bdAd dAyd : see bud~N.

bidaAdN bdAd dAyd : see bud~N. -A2- Also A stuffed lining put beneath a [camel's saddle of the kind called] qatab, to defend the animal's back from being hurt thereby: there is one such on each side: (T:) or, of a horse's saddle, and of a qatab, (S, M, K,) the stuffed thing, or pad, that is placed beneath, in order that it may not gall the animal's back; (M, K;) as also ↓ badiydN: (K:) or the bidaAdaAni and ↓ badiydaAni are two bags (xariyTataAni), which are stuffed, and placed under the curved pieces of wood, in order that the wood may not gall the animal's back; derived from bad~a rijolayohi “ he parted his legs: ” (S:) [see also badiydN:] or the bidaAdaAni of a qatab are two things like provender-bags, 'which are stuffed, and bound with strings, or cords, to the pieces of wood called the ZalifaAt and A^aHonaA=': (T:) or they are, to the qatab, like the kar~ to the raHol, except that they do not appear before the Zalifap, being only within [it]: (M:) [see also HidojN:] pl. [of pauc.] A^abid~apN (T, S) and [of mult.] badaAy^idu. (S.) ― -b2- Also A piece of felt cloth, that is bound upon a beast which has a galled, or sore, back, (L, K,) cut, or slit, so as to be clear of the galls, or sores. (L.)

badiydN bdyd : see bid~N, in three places. -A2- Also A saddlebag; syn. xurojN: (K:) [and] badiydaAni a pair of saddle-bags; syn. xurojaAni. (S.) ― -b2- See also bidaAdN, in two places. -A3- Also A wide [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap: (S, K:) or falaApN badiydN [a desert, or waterless desert,] in which is no one. (T, L. [In a copy of the former written bado badN.])
bidaAdapN bdAdh bdAdp dAdp : see 3.
badiydapN bdydh bdydp : see bid~N.

baAd~N A_d bA_d bAd bAdy The inner side of the thigh: (M, A, K:) or the part of the horseman's thigh that is next the saddle: (T, M, A, L:) or the part between the legs: (M, L:) the inner sides of the two thighs are called the baAd~aAni, (S,) because the saddle separates them; (IAar, M;) and if so, baAd~N is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be a possessive epithet [meaning *uw bad~K]. (M, L.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlbaAd~i EalaY Als~arji, meaning He is a good rider upon the saddle. (A.) ― -b2- Also the part of a horse's back upon which the thigh of the rider presses. (Kt, T, L.)

A^abad~N * A man wide between the thighs, (ISk, S, M, K,) by reason of abundance of flesh: (ISk, S, M:) or wide between the arms; (K;) having the arms far from the sides: (M:) or wide between the shoulder-joints: (M:) or (so in the K; but accord. to the S, “and”) large in make, (T, S, M, K,) having one part far from another: (M, K:) and wide in the breast: (Aboo-Málik, T:) fem. bad~aA='u: (S:) which also signifies a woman (M, L) large in the A_isokataAni [or labia majora of the vulva], (M, L, K,) having their edges far apart: (M, L:) or having much flesh in the thighs. (T, L.) AlA^abad~N is used to signify The weaver, (T, M, K,) because of the distance between his thighs. (M.) The following saying, (K,) quoted by J, from the rájiz Aboo-Nukheyleh Es-Saadee,
A^alad~u yamo$iY mi$ayapa AlA^abad~i
is incorrect, and should be thus,
bad~aA='u tamo$iY mi$oyapa AlA^abad~i
[A woman of large make, walking in the manner of the man of large make; or a woman wide between the thighs, &c.]; (K;) for it is descriptive of a woman, as IB and Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee have observed before the author of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A horse [or any quadruped (see bad~a)] having the fore legs far apart: (M, K:) or having the fore legs far from the sides: (TA:) or wide between the legs: (Ham p. 348:) and a camel having the elbows far from the sides: (TA:) and the fem. bad~aA='u, a cow having her fore legs far apart. (S.) [Hence,] AlA^abad~u Alz~aniymu [in the CK Alr~aviymu] The lion; (M, K;) the former epithet being applied to him because his fore legs are far apart, and the latter because he is [often] alone. (M.) ― -b3- katifN bad~aA='u A broad shoulder-blade, the sides of which are distant, one from another. (M, L.)

TayorN A^abaAdiydu * , (Fr, S, K,) and ↓ tabaAdiydu, (K, TA,) [in the CK nabAdiydu,] erroneously written by J ↓ yabaAdiydu, (K,) [but see what follows; like A^anaAdiydu and yanaAdiydu;] Birds in a state of dispersion. (S, K.) In the following verse of 'Otárid Ibn-Kurrán, quoted by J,
kaA^an~amaA A^ahulu HajorK yanoZuruwna mataY
yarawonaniY xaArijFA TayorN yabaAdiydu
[As though the people of Hajr, watching when they should see me going forth, were birds in a state of dispersion], (K,) thus related also by Yaakoob, and thus in the handwriting of Az, (TA,) the last two words should be Tayoru AlyanaAdiydi, the latter with n, and governed by the former in the gen. case, the rhyme being with kesr: (K:) so says Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee. (TA.) ― -b2- *ahabuwA A^abaAdiydu, (M, K,) and ↓ tabaAdiydu, (K,) or ↓ yabaAdiydu, (as in the T, from Fr, and in the M and L, and in some copies of the K, [but see above,]) [as also A^anaAdiydu, and yanaAdiydu, or tanaAdiydu,] They went away in a state of dispersion. (M, L, K.)
tabaAdiydu tbAdyd : see A^abaAdiydu, in two places.

mubid~N mbd mbdy [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. The following words of 'Omar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah,
A^amubid~N suw^aAlaka AlEaAlamiyna
are said to signify Dost thou distribute thy petition
among mankind one by one, so as to include them universally? or dost thou constrain them by thy petition? from the saying, maA laka minohu bud~N [“ thou hast no means, ” or “ way, ” “ of separating thyself from it, ” or “ avoiding it ”]. (M, L.)
$amolN mubad~adN * [A united state of affairs]. become disunited [or discomposed or disorganized]. (S, L.)

AimoraA^apN mutabad~idapN *
An emaciated woman, [as though] having one part far from another. (M, L.)
yabaAdiydu ybAdyd : see A^abaAdiydu, in two places.

1 badaA^a bihi * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
badaAa , (Mgh, K,) inf. n. bado'N, (T, S, M, Msb,) i. q. bh ↓ AbtdA^; (S, Msb, K;) [He began with it;] he made it to have precedence, or to be first; gave precedence to it; syn. qad~amahu: (Mgh, Msb:) in the dial. of the Ansár, badiy^a bh is used in this sense of qd~mh; (M;) or badiYa bh [without ']; (IKtt, TA; [see badp'N;]) [and badaY bh; see art. bdY;] and bh ↓ AbdA^ signifies the same. (Msb.) [So in the Kur xii. 76, fabadaA^a biA^awoEiyatihimo qabola wiEaA='i A^axiyhi And he began with their bags, before the bags of his brother. And badaA^ahu is sometimes used in the sense of badaA^a bihi; whence, in the Kur ix. 13, wahumo badaw^uwkumo A^aw~ala mar~apK And they, it was, began with you the first time; i. e., as Bd says, by acting with hostility, and fighting.] You say also, bad~aA vum~a EaAda He began, or did a first time, or the first time: then repeated, or did a second time. (Az, TA in art. Ewd.) And badaA^a fiYi AlA^amori [He began, or made a beginning, in the affair.] (M.) ― -b2- badaA^a also signifies It (a thing) began; began to be; originated; or came into existence. (Msb.) [See also 5.] -A2- badaA^a Al$~ayo'a, (S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He began the thing; commenced it; set about it; as also ↓ AbtdA^hu: accord. to the Mgh, the latter has this meaning, or, agreeably with the authority of the M and K, the meaning which here next follows:] he did the thing first, for the first time, by way of beginning, or originally; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ AbdA^hu and ↓ AbtdA^hu; (M, K;) i. e., not after the example of anything preceding. (TA. [But this addition seems rather to belong to another explanation to be mentioned below.]) One does not say, zayodFA ↓ AbtdA^ nor badaA^ahu, because these two verbs [signifying as last explained above] do not have for their objects corporeal things. (Mgh.) [El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee uses the phrase saA^aboduw^uhumo bima$omaEipK I will begin with them (meaning his guests) by sporting and jesting; like the phrase in the Kur ix. 13 cited above: but different from these is the saying in the Kur xxxii. 6, wabadaA^a xaloqi A@loA_inosaAni mino TiynK And He began the creation of man from clay.] The saying, ↓ faA_ino kaAna Als~abuEu A@botadaA^ahu means AbtdA^ A^axo*ahu A^awo EaD~ahu [But if the beast, or bird, of prey has begun the seizing of him, or the biting of him]; the noun that is prefixed [to the pronoun] being suppressed. (Mgh.) You say also, kaAna *`lika fiY AlA^amori ↓ A@botidaA='i That was in the beginning, or first, of the affair. (Msb.) [See also bado'N, below.] ― -b2- He originated the thing; brought it into being or existence; made it, or produced it, for the first time, it not having been before; (Mgh;) [and] so ↓ AbdA^hu, said [of God, and] of a man, as the agent; (Msb;) and ↓ AbtdA^hu. (Mgh in art. bdE.) [Hence,] badaA^a A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa, and ↓ A^abodaA^ahumo, God created, or brought into existence, mankind, or the created beings: (M, Msb, K:) both signify the same. (S.) AlbaATilu wamaA yuEiydu ↓ maA yubodiy^u [in the Kur xxxiv. 48, means What doth that which is false, or the Devil, originate, or produce in the first instance? and what doth it, or he, reproduce after it hath perished?]: Zj says that maA, here, is in the place of an accus., meaning in each Instance A^aY~a $aYo'K: or it may be a negative; and AlbATl here is Iblees; i. e., Iblees createth not, nor raiseth to life after death. (M.) You say also, wamaA yuEiydu ↓ maA yubodiy^u, meaning walaA ↓ maA yatakal~amu EaAy^idapK, (S, K,) i. e. He does not say anything for the first time, nor anything for the second time; or anything original, nor anything in the way of repetition; AlkalaAmi ↓ baAdiy^apu signifying what is said for the first time; and EaAy^idapu AlkalaAmi, what is said for the second time, afterwards: (TA:) or he says not anything: (A in art. Ewd:) and he has no art, artifice, or cunning. (IAar, TA in art. Ewd; and A in the present art.) ― -b3- badaA^a Albiy^ora He dug the well [for the first time: see badiYo'N]. (Msb.) -A3- badaA^a mino A^aroDK A_ilaY A^aroDK, (T,) or mino A^aroDihi, (K,) He went forth from a land to a land, or from his land; as also ↓ AbdA^. (T, K.) -A4- budiy^a, (inf. n. as above, S, M, K,) He (a man, S, M) had the small-pox: (AZ, As, T, S, M, K:) or the HaSobap [i. e. measles, or spotted fever]: (S, M, K:) or, as AZ says, and the HSbp: (T:) or, as Lh says, there came forth upon him pustules resembling the small-pox: but he adds, some say, the small-pox itself: (M:) the epithet applied to a person affected therewith is ↓ maboduwo'N. (AZ, As, Lh, T, S, M.) ― -b2- Also He fell sick. (IAth, TA.) In a trad. of ' Áïsheh occur the words, fiY Alyawomi Al~a*iY budiy^a fiyhi rasuwli A@ll~`hi [meaning In the day in which the Apostle of God fell sick]: and IAth says, mataY budiy^a fulaAnN meaning When did such a one fall sick? is a phrase used in inquiring respecting the living [who has been attacked by illness] and respecting the dead. (TA.)

4 AbdA^ * : see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- Also He did a new thing; a thing unknown before; or a strange, or wonderful, thing. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- And He voided excrement, or ordure; or broke wind; syn. najaA; [as also A^abodaY;] said of a man. (M.) ― -b4- And He put forth his second teeth; said of a child; (M;) and of a colt. (TA voce A^aHofara, q. v.)

5 tbd~A^ *
He, or it, began, or made a beginning. (KL.) [See also 1. Golius mentions, but without giving the authority, and without the vowel-signs, the saying, haAti AlqiS~apa mino *iY tubud~iy^ato; but writing the last word tbdyt, stating only that it is in the passive form; as meaning Relate thou the story, or history, from the beginning.]
8 A_ibotadaAa see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- AbtdA^hu biwaEodK He made him a promise in anticipation; without his asking it of him. (M in art. Anf.)

bad'N bd' inf.n. of 1; (T, S, M, Msb;) [The act of beginning;] or the doing a thing first. (M.) You say, laka Albado'u, (M, K,) and ↓ Albudo'u, (As, TA,) and ↓ AlbadoA^apu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ AlbudoA^apu, (S, M, K,) and ↓ AlbidoA^apu, (L,) and ↓ AlbadaA='apu, (M, K,) and ↓ AlbudaA='apu, (S, M, K,) and AlbudaAhapu, with h substituted for ', (M, Mtr,) and ↓ AlbidaA='apu, (Mtr, TA,) and, accord. to IKtt, AlbidaAyapu, but see what follows, (TA,) and ↓ Albadiy^apu, (M, K,) and ↓ Albud~aA='apu, (AZ, TA,) It is for thee to begin, (S, M, Msb, K,) before any other, in shooting or casting, &c.: (S:) as to AlbidaAyapu, mentioned above, accord. to Mtr [and Fei], (TA,) it is a vulgar word, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) as IB and several others have stated, (Msb, TA, *) a corruption of ↓ AlbidaA='apu, (Mgh, Msb,) signifying the first; as also ↓ AlbudaA='apu; and ↓ AlbadoA^apu: (Msb:) but IKtt says that it is a word of the dial. of the Ansár; badaA^otu biAl$~aYo'i and badiytu bihi signifying qad~amotuhu: [see 1:] and he cites the following verse of Ibn-Rawáhah:
walawo EabadonaA gayorahu $aqiynaA
biA@somi A@loA_ilaAhi wa bihi badiynaA
[In the name of God, and with it we begin; and if we worshipped any other than Him, we should be miserable]: see art. bdY. (TA. [This verse is also cited in the S in art. bdw, where, in one copy I find it as above; in another, with badayonaA instead of badiyonaA.]) And you say, faEalahu Eawo*aA wabado'FA, (T, S,) and Eawodahu Ealay badoy^ihi, (M,) and fiY Eawodihi wabadoy^ihi, and ↓ fiY Eawodatihi wabadoA^atihi, (S, M,) [He did it returning and beginning again; or returning to his beginning; i. e. he did it again from the beginning; he recommenced it: or you say this] meaning like as is meant by the saying next following. (TA.) rajaEa Eawodahu EalaY badoy^ihi, (S, K,) and EawodFA EalaY bado'K, in both of which [and in the last following] the verb may be trans., and the noun following therefore in the accus. case, (TA,) and fiY Eawodihi wabadoy^ihi, and ↓ fiY Eawodatihi wabadoA^atihi, [in both of which, if correct, the verb must be intrans.,] and EawodFA wabado'FA, [as though meaning EaAy^idFA wabaAdiy^FA, used as a phrase denotative of state,] (K,) [but in this last, and the two next preceding, accord. to the TA, the verb should be faEalahu, as in the next preceding sentence, instead of rajaEa, and this is confirmed by what is said in the K in art. Ewd,] He returned in the way whence he had come: (S, K:) [accord. to the TA, the literal meaning of the first and second may be he made his returning to revert to his beginning, and he made a returning to revert to a beginning:] or the meaning of the first, (Sb, TA in art. Ewd, and K in that art.,) and of the second, (K in that art.,) is, he returned without stopping after he had gone away: (Sb, K:) and sometimes it signifies the stopping in one's coming and then returning: (Sb:) [and it returned to its first state; it recommenced:] and you say, rajaEotu EawodiY EalaY badoy^iY, meaning I returned like as I had come.
(Sb ubi suprà.) ― -b2- Also First, or former; preceding all others, or preceding another; as also ↓ Albado'u badiYo'N; and AlbadiY'u being syn. with AlA^aw~alu. (S, K.) Hence the saying, AifoEalohu baAdiY bado'K, and ↓ baAdiY badiYo'K, meaning Do thou it the first thing, or the first of everything; [accord. to different copies of the S;] the Y in bAdY being quiescent, in the place of the accus. case, accord. to usage; and sometimes they omit the [altogether], on account of frequent use [of the phrase], as will be stated in art. bdw, (S in the present art.,) saying baAdiY badK, and baAdiYbadiY (S in art. bdw.) You say also, AifoEalohu bado'FA, and A^aw~ala bado'K, (Th, M, K,) and bado'a bado'K, (CK,) and badaA bado'K, (M, K,) and bado'K ↓ baAdiy^a, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and baAdiYa badK, (K,) and baAdiYo badFA, (M, K, [in the CK baAdiYo badK,]) and baAdiYo badFA, (M,) and badiYo'K ↓ baAday^a, (K,) and baAdiYo badaA, (M, K,) and ↓ badiYo'K ↓ baAdiy^a, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, CK,) and badiY~K ↓ baAdiy^a, which is anomalous, (M,) or baAdiYa bad~iYi, (K,) and baAdiYo badiy~K, (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, M,) and ↓ badiy^K ↓ baAdiy^a, (S, CK,) or ↓ baAdiYa badiy^K, (K, TA,) and baAdiYo ↓ badoA^apa, (M, K, TA,) the former word being the act. part. n. of badiYa, which is of the dial. of the Ansár, as mentioned above, and the latter being indecl., with fet-h for its termination, (TA, [in the CK the latter word is written bado'ap,]) and bado'K ↓ badoA^apa, (CK,) and ↓ badoA^apa badoA^apa, (M, K,) and ↓ badiYo'K ↓ badoA^apa, (S,) and bado'K ↓ badiYo'a, (S, CK,) and bado'a *iY bado'K, (Fr, T,) and *iY bado'K ↓ badoA^apa, (Fr, T, S, K,) and ↓ badoA^apa *iY badoA^apK, and ↓ *iY badiYo'K ↓ badoA^apa, (S, K,) and ↓ *iy badaA='apa ↓ badaA^apa, (K, TA,) not bdA'p [as in the CK], (TA,) and ↓ badiYo'a *iY badiYo'K, (S, K, TA, [in the CK the last word is written bado'K,]) and ↓ *iY badiYo'K ↓ badaA='api, (K,) meaning Do thou it the first thing; (Fr, T, K;) so in a correct copy [of the K, and so I find in a MS. copy of the K and in the CK]: accord. to another copy, the first of everything: (TA:) or the first of first; (S;) thus in the L: (TA:) the words here put in the accus. case [literally or virtually] are so put [in some instances] as adverbial nouns; or, accord. to MF, they may be [in some instances] denotatives of state, with respect to the agent; the meaning being AifoEalohu HaAlapa kawonika baAdiy^FA, i. e. mubotadiy^aA bihi [lit. do thou it in the state of thy being beginning it]. (TA.) [In like manner,] you also say, bado'a Alr~aA^oYi, and [more commonly] Alr~aA^oYi ↓ baAdiy^a, At first thought; or on the first opinion: (Lh, M:) [bado'u Alr~aA^oYi and] Alr~aA^oYi ↓ baAdiy^u signifying the first, and beginning, of the idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; or what is perceived before considering well or thoroughly: (M:) [and bado'N alone signifying a first idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; as is implied in the A, voce Say~uwrN, q. v.:] hence, Alr~aA^oyi ↓ faEalahu fiY baAdiy^i [He did it at first thought, &c.]: (M:) and Alr~aA^oYi turiydu ↓ A^anota baAdiy^a ZulomanaA, and AlrA^Y ↓ mubotadaA^a, i.e. Thou at first thought, &c., desirest to wrong us: and one says also, baAdiYa AlrA^Y, without; meaning on the occasion of what appeared of opinion; i. e. at the first of what appeared thereof; [or at the first opinion's presenting itself;;] in which case, the phrase does not belong to this art. [but to art. bdw]: it occurs in the Kur xi. 29: (M:) AA alone there read baAdiy^a, with; all the other readers pronounced it without ' (TA.) ― -b3- Also A chief, or lord, (S, M, Msb, K,) who occupies the first place in chieftainship or lordship: (S:) or, as some say, a youth, or young man, whose judgment, or opinion, is deemed good, and who is consulted: (M:) or it signifies also an intelligent youth or young man: (K:) pl. buduwo'N. (M.) A poet (namely, Ows Ibn-Maghrà Es-Saadee, TA) says,
vunoyaAnunaA A_ino A^ataAhumo kaAna badoA^ahumu
wabadow^uhumo A_ino A^ataAnaA kiAna vunoyaAnaA
[Our second chief, if he came to them, would be their first chief; and their first chief, if he came to us, would be a second chief]. (S.) ― -b4- Also, and ↓ badoA^apN, A share, or portion, of a slaughtered camel: (S, K:) or the best share or portion thereof: (T:) or the former word has the latter signification; and the latter word, the former signification: and the former signifies also a bone with the meat, or flesh, that is on it: (M:) and a joint; syn. mafoSilN; (AA, T, M;) and so badFA q.v.: (AA, T:) the pl. [of pauc.] of bado'N is A^abodaA='N (S, M, K) and [of mult.] buduwo'N; (S, K;) the former of which is the more common: (TA:) or this is pl. of badFA. (AA, T.) The shares abovementioned [as commonly divided for the game called Almayosir q. v.] are ten; namely, the two haunches, the two thighs properly so called, the two thighs commonly so called (i. e. the tibiæ), the two shoulders, and the two arms; which last are the worst, because of the many veins [therein]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also badiYo'N.
bud'N bd' : see bado'N; second sentence.
badiy^N * : see baAdiy^a badiy^K, or baAdiYa badiy^K, voce bad'N.

badoA^apN * : see bado'N, in thirteen places. ― -b2- Also The beginning, or outward course, of a military expedition; opposed to rajoEapN, meaning the returning, or homeward course, thereof: occurring in a trad., in which it is said that the Prophet gave, in the case of the former, a fourth [of the spoil], and in the case of the latter, a third; i.e., when a troop went forth from the main body of the army and attacked a party of the enemy, they were to have a fourth of the spoil that they took, and the rest of the army was to share with them the remaining three fourths; and if a troop did so in returning, they were to have a third of all the spoil that they took, because of the greater difficulty and danger attending this case. (T, Mgh.) ― -b3- kaAna *`lika fiY badoA^atinaA, and ↓ budoA^atinaA, and ↓ bidoA^atinaA, (K,) and ↓ badaA='atinaA, (Lh, M, TA,) and ↓ budaA='atinaA, and ↓ bidaA='atinaA, (TA,) and ↓ badaA^atinaA, (Lh, M, K,) but [ISd says,] I know not how that is, (M,) and ↓ muboday^inaA, and ↓ muboday^inaA, (K,) and ↓ mabodaA^atinaA, (Lh, M, and so in some copies of the K,) or mabodaAtinaA, (so in other copies of the K,) thus in the baAhir of Ibn-'Odeys [in the CK Ibn-'Adebbes], (K,) which is said to indicate that we should hesitate respecting them [before admitting them to be of classical authority], are phrases meaning That was in the first of our state, and in our adolescence. (TA.) -A2- Also, (so in a copy of the M, there written badoA^ap,) or ↓ budoA^apN, with damm, (K,) A certain plant; (M;) a black thing, resembling a truffle (kamo'), of which no use is made: so says AHn. (M.)
budoA^apN * : see bado'N; second sentence: and see badoA^apN, in two places.
bidoA^apN * : see bado'N; second sentence: and see badoA^apN
badaA^apN * : see badoA^apN.
badaA='N bdA=' , with medd; [Excrement from the anus; as also bad~aA;] a subst. from A^abodaA^a, as meaning najaA. (M.)

badiYo'N bdY' bdy' bdy^ : see bado'N, as signifying First, or former; in eight places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a thing, or an affair, i. q badiyEN, (S, and so in a copy of the K,) or mubodaEN: (so in other copies of the K:) [thus it signifies] Originated; brought into being or existence; made, or produced, for the first time, not having been before, or not after the similitude of any former thing: (TA:) and created: (M, K:) and wonderful: (M, Msb, TA:) and strange, or extraordinary, as not being after the similitude of any former thing. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, as is implied in the Mgh,] biy^orN badiYo'N A well newly dug; (T, Mgh, Msb;) i. q. badiyEN; (M;) or dug since the era of ElIslám (S, K;) not ancient; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ bado'N: (S:) the former epithet [in this sense] is generally pronounced [badiY~N] without ': (T:) the well thus called is one dug in a waste land that has no owner: (TA:) AO says, (TA,) this epithet, and badiyE, are applied to a well when thou hast dug it; but if thou findest it to have been dug before thee, it is termed xafiy~ap; and thus the well of Zemzem is termed xfy~p, because it was Ismá'eel's, and was filled up or covered over [after his time]: (T, TA:) the term qaliyb is [said to be] applied to an ancient well of which neither the owner nor the digger is known: (TA:) it is said in a trad., that the Hariym of a well such as is termed bdY' [i. e. the space surrounding it and belonging to it] is five-and-twenty cubits: (T, S: [but see HariymN:]) the pl. is buduwo'N: (M:) and AO says that buwdaAnN is pl. of badiYo'N applied to a well, and is syn. with qulobaAnN [a pl. of qaliybN which I have not found elsewhere] and rakaAyaA, being formed by transposition of letters from budoyaAnN [which is for budoA=nN, as badiY~N is for badiYo'N; the d and Y being transposed, the word becomes buyodaAnN, and this, by a rule of permutation, becomes buwdaAnN]. (TA.)
badaA='apN bdA='h bdA='p : see bado'N, in three places: and see badoA^apN: and badiy^apN, in two places.
budaA='apN bdA='h bdA='p : see bado'N, in two places: and see badoA^apN: and for the former, see also badiy^oapN.
bidaA='apN bdA='h bdA='p : see bado'N, in two places: and see badoA^apN: and for the former, see also badiy^apN.

badiyoy^apN * : see bado'N; second sentence. ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ badaA='apN, (K,) or ↓ budaA='apN, (M,) i. q. badiyhapN, (K,) and badaAhapN, (TA,) or budaAhapN, i. e. The first occurrence of a thing, that happens to one unexpectedly: (M:) [or the first of anything: and an occurrence thereof by which one is taken unawares: accord. to explanations in the K in art. bdh:] pl. of the first, badaAyaA. (TA.) ― -b3- [And all app. signify The faculty of extemporizing; like badiyhapN (q. v.) &c.] You say, jay~idapK ↓ fulaAnN *uw badaA='apK, i. e. badiyhapK HasanapK, [meaning] Such a one has a good faculty of extemporizing; or of uttering, or relating, things by means of the promptness of his intelligence. (TA.)
bud~aA='apN bdA='h bdA='p : see bado'N; second sentence.
baAdiy^N * [act. part. n. of 1]: see bado'N, in nine places.
baAdiy^apN * : see 1, in two places.

mabodaA^N * [originally noun of place and of time from 1; A place, and a time, of beginning, &c. ― -b2- ] See badoA^apN. ― -b3- [Also A principle, or first rule, of a science &c.: pl. mabaAdiy^u. ― -b4- And The primary import of a word; opposed in this sense to gaAyapN.]
mubodaA^N * : see badoA^apN.

Almubodiy^u * , applied to God, The Creator, or Originator, of the things [that exist], who hath produced them at the beginning, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (Nh.) And Almubodiy^u AlmuEiydu, so applied, He who createth mankind, and who returneth them after life to death in the present world and after death to life on the day of resurrection. (TA in art. Ewd.) ― -b2- mubodiy^u muEiydN A man who has gone on warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions, time after time, and is experienced in affairs: (A 'Obeyd, and K in art. Ewd:) and a horse upon which the owner has gone time after time on warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions; (TA in that art.;) or well trained and exercised, (K and TA in that art.) so as to be obedient to his rider. (TA in that art.) ― -b3- [For other significations of mubodiy^N, see its verb (4); and see A^aHofara.]
mabodaA^apN * : see badoA^apN
maboduwo'N mbd mbdw' [pass. part. n. of 1; Begun, &c. -A2- ] See budiy^a.
mubotadaA^N * : see bado'N. ― -b2- [In grammar, as correlative of xabarN, An inchoative.]

1 badara bdr dr , aor.
badura , inf. n. badorN, It (the moon) became full. (Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a boy) became full-grown and round; implying comparison to the full moon. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (fruit) attained to maturity. (TA, from a trad.) [See also 4.] ― -b4- It rose like the full moon. (Er Rághib.) -A2- See also 3, in six places. ― -b2- badarato minohu bawaAdiru gDabK: and badarat bawaAdiru Alxayoli: see baAdirapN. ― -b3- badarati AlA_ibila She (a camel) brought forth at an earlier period of the year than the other camels. (TA.) [See badoriy~apN, voce badoriY~N.] ― -b4- xarajotu A^aboduru (tropical:) I went forth to make water. (A.)

3 bAdrhu bAdr bAdrh bAdrp , inf. n. mubaAdarapN and bidaArN; and ↓ Abtdrhu; He hastened, or made haste, or strove to be first or beforehand, in doing [or attaining or obtaining] it; (M, K, TA, TK;) namely, a thing: (M:) and gayoruhu A_ilayohi ↓ badara, (M, K,) aor.
badura ; and bAdrhu Alyh; (M;) He hastened with another, or vied or strove with him in hastening, to it [or to do or attain or obtain it]: syn. EaAjalahu, (M, K, TA,) and A^asoraEa A_ilayohi. (TA.) bAdr [as well as ↓ badara and ↓ Abtdr] denotes mutual effort only when it is immediately trans.: when it is trans. by means of A_ilaY [or bi (the former in the TA written by mistake ElY], there is nothing to show that it denotes this. (MF.) [But it is often immediately trans. without its denoting such effort.] One says, bAdrhu He hastened to do it [&c., as explained above]; meaning, a thing that he desired, or wished for: (TA:) [and bAdrbihi signifies the same; or he hastened with it: and the former signifies also he betook himself early to him or it:] and bAdr A_ilayohi he hastened to it; (S, A;) as also Alyh ↓ badara, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
badura , (S,) inf. n. buduwrN: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to Zj, agreeably with its derivation, [see badorN,] he employed the fulness of his power, or force, to hasten [to it]: (TA:) and AlA^amorN ↓ badarahu, and ↓ badara A_ilayohi, (aor.
badura , inf. n. badorN, TA, [or buduwrN, as above,]) the thing, or event, came to him, or happened to him, hastily, quickly, or speedily; and, beforehand [or before he expected it]; syn. Eajila, (M, K,) and sabaqa, (M,) or Aisotabaqa: (K:) [and minohu qawolN ↓ badara, and fiEolN, a saying, and an action, proceeded from him hastily, without premeditation: see baAdirapN.] It is said in a trad., baAdiruwA biAloA^aEomaAli haramFA [Strive ye to be before decrepitude with good works; i. e., to perform them before decrepitude]. (El-Jámi' es- Sagheer.) And in another, baAdiruwA AlS~uboHa biAlowitori [Strive ye to be before daybreak with the prayers termed wtr; i. e., to perform them before daybreak]. (Idem.) And in another, baAdiruwA biSalAapi Almagoribi qabola TuluwEi Aln~ajomi [Hasten ye with, or to perform, the prayer of sunset before the rising of the star]. (Idem.) You say also, fulaAnN yubaAdiru fiY A^akoli maAli Alyatiymi [Such a one hastens in consuming the property of the orphan before the latter is of full age]. (A.) And baAdara kibara Alyatiymi [He hastened to be before the orphan's attaining to full age in expending his property]; said of a guardian; i. q. fiy maAli Alyatiymi ↓ A^abodara: (K:) and thus, bidaArFAA^ano yakobaruwA, in the Kur [iv. 5], means hastening to be before their attaining to full age in expending their property. (Bd, * Jel.) And bAdrhu AlgaAyapa and A_ilaY AlgaAyapi [He strove with him in hastening, or strove to get before him, to the goal]. (A.) And AlgaAyapa ↓ Abtdr and A_ilaY AlgaAyapi [He strove in hastening, or strove to get first, to the goal]. (Ham p. 46.) And baAdara baEoDuhumo baEoDFA A_ilaY A^amorK, and A^amorFA ↓ AbtdrwA, and ↓ tbAdrwhu, They vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening to a thing, or an affair, trying which of them would be first. (T.)

(A.) nd tbAdrwA A^amorFA=: see 3, last sentence. ― -b2- h`*aA maA yatabaAdaru minohu (assumed tropical:) [This meaning is what appears from it (namely, the phrase, or sentence,) at first sight]. badorN bdr dr , (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) originally an inf. n., (Msb,) The full moon; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ baAdirN; (L, K;) the moon in its fourteenth night: (S:) or the latter signifies [simply] the moon: (IAar, T:) the moon in its fourteenth night is called bdr because it hastens to rise before the sun sets; (S, M;) and to set before the sun rises: (TA:) or because of its fulness; (S, TA;) as being likened to a badorap: or, as Er-Rághib thinks to be most probable, it is itself a primitive word: (TA:) pl. buduwrN. (M, A.) Hence, layolapu Albadori [The night of the full moon; which is] the fourteenth night [of the lunar month]. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A lord, master, or chief, (M, K,) of a people: so called as being likened to the full moon. (M.) ― -b3- Applied to a boy, (Zj, M, K,) (tropical:) Full of youthful vigour and of flesh: (Zj:) or full, or plump: (M:) or i. q. ↓ mubaAdirN [precocious]. (T, K.) [In this sense, an epithet; and so its fem. badorapN (q. v.), applied to an eye.] ― -b4- (tropical:) A cover; or a dish or plate; syn. TabaqN: (Ibn-Wahb, K:) because resembling the full moon, being round: so Az thinks. (TA.) ― -b5- See also badorapN, in two places.

badorapN bdr bdrh bdrp dr drp , applied to an eye (EayonN), Quick-sighted; or that sees before others: (As, T, S, K, TA:) or that sees before [the eyes of] other horses; applied to a horse's eye: (IAar, T, M:) or sharp-sighted: or round and large: (M:) or full like the full moon: (S, K:) but the correct meaning is [said to be] that [mentioned above as] given by IAar: (M:) or, accord. to IAar, full; not defective. (T.) -A2- Also, (S, M, K,) and ↓ badorN, (K,) The skin of a lamb or kid (S, M, K) when it has been weaned, (AZ, S, M,) used for milk: for [when it is killed] while it continues sucking, its skin, if used for milk, is called $akowapN; and for clarified
butter, Euk~ap: when it has been weaned, its skin for milk is called badorap; and for clarified butter, misoA^ad: and when it is in its second year, its skin for milk is called waTob; and for clarified butter, niHoY: (AZ, S:) pl. (of the former, M) bidarN and buduwrN: (M, K:) the former said by El-Fárisee to be the only instance of the kind except hiDabN pl. of haDobapN, and biDaEN pl. of baDoEapN [or this may be pl. of biDoEapN]. (M. [But the assertion of El-Fárisee is incorrect (see HayoDapN), unless it be meant to apply only to sound words; and in this case, at least one addition should be made, namely qiSaEN pl. of qaSoEapN.]) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) the former word, (S, M, A, K, &c.,) and ↓ the latter also, (K,) The sum of ten thousand dirhems: (S, A:) or a purse containing a thousand, (T, M, K,) or ten thousand, dirhems, (T, M, * A, K,) or seven thousand deenárs: (K:) pl. buduwrN, (TA,) and pl. of pauc. bidaraAtN. (T.)

badoriY~N bdr bdrY bdry dr dry Rain that is before (qabola), or a little before (qubayola), or in the first part of (qubula), winter. (K, accord. to different copies: the second reading is that followed in the TA.) ― -b2- badoriy~apu A she-camel whose mother has brought her forth at an earlier period of the year than that when the others brought forth, and therefore more abundant in milk than others, and of a more generous quality. (M.) ― -b3- And the former, A fat young camel weaned from its mother. (K.)
badaAriY~N bdArY bdAry bdAryy bdrp dAr dAry A lamb brought forth a little before winter. (TA.)
baAdirN bAdr : see badorN.

bayodarN bydr a word of the dial. of El-'Irák, (A 'Obeyd in art. rbd in the TA,) A place in which wheat, (S, Mgh, K,) or grain, (Msb,) is trodden out. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- It may also mean, tropically, (tropical:) The wheat and straw therein: (Mgh:) or rather, as Az says, on the authority of IAar, it signifies [also] (Mgh) reaped grain collected together; or wheat collected together in the place in which it is trodden out; syn. kudosN, (M, Mgh, K,) and EaramapN: (Mgh:) Kr restricts it to wheat. (M.) ― -b3- Accord. to the Towsheeh, it is [A place] for [drying] dates. (TA in art. jrn.)

baAdirapN bAdr bAdrh bAdrp
Hastiness of temper; passionateness: (S:) or a hasty saying, or action, that suddenly proceeds (yaboduru, in the CK yaboduw,) from one in anger: (M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, * K:) and a slip; a mistake; an error; (S, Msb;) on an occasion of one's being angry: (S:) or a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word or saying: and a quick fit of anger: (IAar, T:) pl. bawaAdiru, (S, A.) You say, A^axo$aY Ealayoka baAdiratahu I fear for thee his hastiness of temper, or passionateness: (S:) or what may hastily proceed from him in his anger. (A.) And minohu yawaAdiru gaDabK ↓ badarato Slips, mistakes, or errors, on an occasion of his being angry, hastily proceeded from him. (S.) And baAdirapu Al$~ar~i signifies What hastily, or suddenly, befalls one, of evil, or mischief. (M.) ― -b2- An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; or a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; or a faculty of extemporizing; syn. badiyhahN. (S, K.) You say, fulaAnu Hasanu AlbaAdirapi Such a one has a good intuitive knowledge, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- The point of a sword. (M, K.) ― -b4- The extremity of an arrow, next the head. (A.) ― -b5- The head of a plant; (M;) the first part thereof from which the earth cleaves asunder. (M, K. *) ― -b6- The first that appears of the [plant called] Hin~aA='. (M.) ― -b7- The leaves of the [herb called] Huw~aA='ap. (K.) ― -b8- The best, and freshest in growth, of the [plant called] waros. (M, K. *) ― -b9- Also, (M, K,) or bawaAdiru, (S, A,) which is the pl., (K,) of a man &c., (S, M,) The portion of flesh, (S, M, K,) or the portions thereof, (A,) between the shoulder-joint and the neck, (S, M, K,) or between the necks and the shoulderjoints: (A:) or the former, (K,) or its dual, (M,) of a man, the two portions of flesh that are above the rugavaAwaAni and below the vanoduwap: (M, K:) or the dual, [relating to a camel, signifies] the two sides of the kirokirap [or callous lump on the breast]: or two veins on either side thereof. (M.) ― -b10- bawaAdiru Alxayoli ↓ badarato The first, or fore parts, (A^awaAy^il,) of the horses appeared [or suddenly came in view]. (Msb.)

badorapN mubad~arapN bdrp mbdrh bdrp mbdrp [A sum such as is termed bdrp aggregated, made up, or completed]: the latter word is a corroborative; like the latter in qanaATiyru muqanoTarapN, (Ksh and Bd in iii. 12,) and in A^alofN muw^al~afapN. (Ksh ibid.)
mubaAdirN mbAdr applied to a boy: see badorN.

baduEa , inf. n. badaAEapN and buduwEN, He became superlative in his kind; or it became so in its kind; (Ks, K;) in good or in evil. (Ks.) -A3- badiEa, aor.
badaEa , He was, or became, fat. (As, K.)

2 bd~Ehu bdE bdEh bdEp dEp , (S, K,) inf. n. tabodiyEN, (K,) He attributed to him, imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, innovation, or what is termed bidoEap; expl. by nasabahu A_ilaY AlbidoEapi [which means nasaba A_ilayohi AlbidoEapa]. (S, K.)

4 AbdEhu A^bdE A^bdEh AbdEh AbdEp bdE
He originated it; invented it; devised it; excogitated it; innovated it; made it, did it, produced it, caused it to be or exist, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing; syn. AixotaraEahu laA EalaY mivaAlK, (S,) and Asotaxorajahu, and A^aHodavahu, (Msb,) and A^abodaA^ahu; (K, TA; but in both without the pronoun;) as also ↓ AbtdEh; (Msb;) syn. AibotadaA^ahu, and A^aHodavahu, (Mgh,) and A^ano$aA^ahu, (K,) and badaA^ahu; (TA;) and so ↓ badaEahu, aor.
badaEa , (K, TA,) inf. n. badoEN; (TA;) but A^abodaEa is more commonly used than badaEa. (TA.) You say, AbdE A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa God created the creation, not after any similitude. (Msb.) And in the Kur [lvii. 27], we find, ↓ wa rahobaAniy~apF A@botadaEuwhaA And monkery which they originated, or innovated. (TA.) And you say, ↓ badaEa Alr~akiy~apa, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. badoEN, (IDrd,) He produced, or fetched out, by his labour in digging, the water of the well; (IDrd, K;) and originated it; or made it to be for the first time, it not having been before. (IDrd.) And AbdE Alr~ajulu The man introduced an innovation, or what is termed a bidoEap; [the object being understood;] as also ↓ AbtdE. (TA.) And AbdE Al$~aAEiru The poet produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- AbdEt Alr~aAHilapu, (S, K,) or Alr~ikaAbu, (Ks, Mgh,) The ridden camel, or travelling camel, became fatigued, or jaded, and broke down, or perished; (Ks, S, Mgh, K;) as though doing a new thing: (Ks, Mgh:) or the former phrase, (K,) followed by bihi, (TA,) she limped [with him], halted, or was slightly lame: (K, TA:) or she lay down upon her breast in the road, by reason of emaciation or disease: or she ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue, or of limping, or halting, or slight lameness; as though she did a new and unaccustomed thing: (TA:) or AbdAE is not without limping, or halting, or slight lameness, (K, TA,) accord. to certain of the Arabs of the desert; but, says AO, this is not at variance with the explanations given. (TA.) And A^ubodiEa biAlr~ajuli The man's camel which he rode became fatigued, or jaded: (S:) or A^ubodiEa bifulaAnK (Mgh, K) such a one's camel which he rode ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue or lameness: (Mgh:) or broke down, or perished, (K, TA,) or became fatigued, or jaded, (TA,) and he became unable to prosecute his journey; (K, TA;) and his beast became so fatigued that it was left to remain where it was; or stood still with him. (TA.) [See also A^uEobida bihi.] It is said in a proverb, A_i*aA Talabota AlbaATila A^ubodiEa bika [When thou seekest what is vain, or false, thou wilt be prevented from attaining thine object]. (TA.) ― -b3- A^abodaEa fulaAnN bifulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one prevented such a one from attaining his wish, (qaTaEa bihi,) and abstained from aiding, or assisting, him, and did not undertake the accomplishment of his want, (Lh, K, TA,) and was not [at hand] when he thought he would be. (TA.) ― -b4- A^abodaEato Huj~atuhu (tropical:) His argument, or plea, or the like, was, or became, vain, or false, or ineffectual: (Aboo-Sa'eed, K:) or was, or became, weak. (A, TA.) And A^ubodiEato Huj~atuhu (tropical:) His argument, or plea, &c., was rendered vain, or ineffectual. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, * TA.) A^abodaEa bir~uhu bi$ukoriY wafaDoluhu wa A_yjaAbuhu biwaSofiY (assumed tropical:) [His kindness has crippled my power of thanking, and his bounty, and the obligation which he has imposed, my power of description]: so in the L; but in the O and K, qaSoduhu [his intention] is put in the place of fDlh; and in the K, wAyjAbh is omitted: (TA:) said when one thanks another for his beneficence, acknowledging that his thanks are inadequate to his beneficence. (K.) -A2- AbdE biAlHaj~i, and biAls~afari, He determined,
resolved, or decided, upon pilgrimage, and upon journeying. (TA.) ― -b2- AbdE yamiynFA He rendered an both binding, or obligatory. (IAar.) -A3- AbdEwA bihi They beat him, or struck him. (TA.)

[If thou be, towards God, the pious, the very obedient, it is not the right way that thou shouldst turn innovator]. (TA.)

He reckoned it badiyE [i. e. new, wonderful, unknown before]. (S, K.)

bidoEN bdE bdEp
i. q. ↓ badiyEN, q. v., and ↓ mubotadaEN; (S;) [but generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; signifying] A novelty; or thing existing for the first time: (K:) and i. q. ↓ badiyEN and ↓ mubotadiEN, a first doer; as though meaning one who has none among his fellows to share, or participate, with him in a thing, or an affair: (Msb:) pl. A^abodaAEN. (Akh, S.) You say, fulaAnN bidoEN fiY h`*A AlA^amori, (S, Msb,) i. e. ↓ badiyEN, (S,) meaning Such a one is the first doer in this affair; the first who has done it. (Msb.) And hence the saying in the Kur [xlvi. 8], qulo maA kunotu bidoEFA mina Alr~usuli (S, Msb, TA) Say thou, I am not the first who has been sent of the apostles: (Msb, TA:) or the meaning is, I am not an innovator among the apostles; inviting you to that to which they do not invite you; or able to do that which they were not able to do: and accord. to one reading, it is ↓ bidaEFA; as being [a sing. epithet] like qiyamN; or for *aA bidaEK [in which the latter word is pl. of bidoEapN]. (Bd.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (TA,) Superlative (Ks, K) in his kind (Ks) in anything; (K;) in good and in evil; (Ks;) or in knowledge, or courage, or nobility: (K:) fem. with p: pl. of the mase. A^abodaAEN [a pl. of pauc., which is also, as is said in the L, applied to women,] and buduEN [a pl. of mult.]; and pl. of the fem. bidaEN. (K.) ↓ A man liberal in disposition; syn. gamorN. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- A full body. (K.)
bidaEN bdE bdEp : see bidoEN. ― -b2- It is also pl. of bidoEapN, [both as a subst. and] as fem. of bidoEN. (K.)

bidoEapN bdE bdEh bdEp dEp
An innovation; a novelty; anything originated, invented, or innovated; anything made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (ISK:) a dissentient state or condition: (Msb:) a subst. from AibotidaAEN, like rifoEapN from AirotifaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) and xilofapN from AixotilaAfN: (Mgh:) subsequently and generally applied to an addition, or an impairment, in religion: (Mgh, Msb:) or a novelty, or an innovation, in religion, after the completion [thereof]: (S, K:) or an opinion declining, or swerving, from the right way, and an action, innovated after [the time of] the Prophet: (Lth, K:) or an action at variance with the Sunneh: (KT:) [generally a heretical innovation; or a new heresy: but] there is a bdEp not disapproved, termed bidoEapN mubaAHapN [an allowed, or allowable, innovation]; which is that whereof the goodness is attested by some principle in the law, or which is required to prevent some cause of evil; such as the Khaleefeh's seclusion of himself from the promiscuous classes of the people: (Msb:) there are two kinds of bdEp; namely bidoEapN hudFY [an innovation of a right kind], and bidoEapN DalaAlK [an innovation of an erroneous kind]. (IAth.)

badiyEN bdyE
i. q. bidoEN, which see in three places, (S, Msb,) and ↓ mubotadaEN; [i. e. Originated; invented; innovated; made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing;] (S, Msb, K;) new; wonderful; unknown before. (TA.) You say, jiy^ota biA^amorK badiyEK Thou hast done a new thing; a wonderful thing; a thing unknown before: and ↓ A^amorN baAdiEN signifies the same as A^amorN badiyEN. (TA.) And jaA='a biA lbadiyEi, (S,) or A^ataY biAlbadayEi, (K,) said of a poet, (S, K,) He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA.) And HabolN bad$yEN A new rope: (AHn:) or a rope begun to be twisted, not being yet a rope, but undone, then spun, then twisted again. (K.) And zimaAmN badiyEN A new nose-rein of a camel. (TA.) And rakiy~apN badiyEN A newly-dug well. (TA.) [See also badiYo'N.] And badiyEN alone, A skin for wine &c.: (S:) or a new skin for wine &c.: (K:) and a new skin for water or milk: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) Hence the trad., A_in~a tihaAmapa kabadiyEi AlEasali HulowN A^aw~aluhu HulowN A=xiruhu [Verily Tihámeh is like the skin, or new skin, of honey: the first part thereof is sweet: the last part thereof is sweet]: (S, K *:) because honey does not change in flavour, whereas milk does change. (S.) ― -b2- Fat; as an epithet: (As, K:) pl. budoEN. (K.) -A2- Also i. q. ↓ mubotadiEN [An originator, inventor, or innovator; one who makes, does, produces, causes to be or exist, or brings into existence, newly, for the first time, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing]: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, like qadiyrN in the sense of qaAdirN; from badaEa. (TA.) [See also bidoEN.] You say, Aall~`hu badiyEN Als~am`waAti waAlA^aroDi God is the Creator of the heavens and the earth, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (Aboo-Is-hák, S. *) And hence AlbadiyEu is a name of God, meaning The Originator of the creation, according to his own will, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (TA.)

baAdiEN bAdE : see badiyEN.
mubotadaEN mbtdE : see bidoEN and badiyEN, each in two places.
