3 mubaAdalapN mbAdl mbAdlh mbAdlp and ↓ tabaAdalN signify the same, (S,) namely, The act of exchanging with another or others. (PS.) You say, bAdlhu, inf. n. mubaAdalapN and bidaAlN [in the CK erroneously written with fet-h to the b], He exchanged, or made an exchange, with him; or] he gave him the like of that which he took, or received, from him; (IDrd, * M, K;) for instance, a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place of another; (Lth, T, Msb, * in explanation of the former inf. n.;) and a brother in the place of a brother. (Lth, T.) And ↓ tabaAdalaA They exchanged, or made an exchange, each with the other; or each gave to the other the like of that which he took, or received, from him. (TA.) nubaAdiluho, ending a verse of El-Kulákh, means for whom we would take a substitute: El-Marzookee says, it is for nubaAdilu bihi Aln~aAsa [for whom we would make an exchange with the people]; the preposition being suppressed. (Ham p. 465.)
4 Abdlhu A^bdl A^bdlh Abdlh Abdlp bdl , inf. n. A_ibodaAlN: see 2, in five places.

5 tbd~l A^bdl bdl tbdl
It (a thing, M) became changed, or altered. (M, K.) ― -b2- In the saying of the rájiz,
fabud~ilato waAld~ahoru *uw tabad~uli
the meaning is, *w tabodiyl [i. e. the meaning of the whole is, And, or but, she was changed, or altered; for time has the property of changing, or altering]. (M.) -A2- See also 10, in three places.
6 tabaAodala see 3, in two places.

10 Astbdl Al$~aYo'a 10 and biAl$~aYo'i , and ↓ tbd~lhu and bihi, (M, K, *) He took a substitute, or a thing in exchange, for the thing. (M.) You say, Astbdl Al$~aYo'a bigayorihi, and bihi ↓ tbd~lhu, He took the thing [as a substitute, or in exchange, for another; or] in the place of another. (S.) And Astbdl vawobFA makaAna vawobK [He took a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place, or in lieu, of a garment, &c.]; and A^axFA makaAna A^axK [a brother in the place, or in lieu, of a brother]. (Lth, T.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 58], A^atasotabodiluwna A@l~a*iY huwa A^adonaY biAl~a*iY huwa xayorN Will ye take in exchange that which is worse for that which is better? (Jel. [See also other exs. in the Kur ix. 39 and xlvii. last verse.]) And Alkufora biAloA_iymaAni ↓ mano yatabad~ali [Whoso adopteth infidelity in lieu of faith]. (Kur ii. 102. [See also other exs. in the Kur iv. 2 and xxxiii. 52.]) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence but one.
bidolN bdl bdlp dl : see the next paragraph, in four places.

badalN bdl bdlp dl and ↓ bidolN, (Fr, T, S, M, Msb, K,) like mavalN and mivolN, and $abahN and $ibohN, (Fr, T, S,) and nakalN and nikalN, the only other instances of the kind, i. e. of words of both these measures, that have been heard, accord. to AO, (S, TA, [but in one copy of the S, I find A'Obeyd,]) and ↓ badiylN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) all signify the same; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. xalafN, (M, K,) and EiwaDN: (Kull:) badalu Al$~aYo'i [and Albadalu mina Al$~aYo'i] and ↓ bidoluhu ↓ badiyluhu meaning Alxalafu minohu [the substitute for the thing; &c.]; (M, K;) i. e., another thing: (S:) pl. A^abodaAlN, (IDrd, Msb, K,) which, as pl. of ↓ badiylN, has few parallels. (IDrd, TA.) Sb says, [making a distinction between badalN and ↓ badiylN,] you say, A_in~a badalaka zayodN, i. e. Verily Zeyd is in thy place: but if you put badal in the place of badiyli, you say, A_in~a badalaka zayodN, i. e. ↓ A_in~a bidaylaka zayodN [Verily thy substitute is Zeyd]: and a man says to another, Go thou with such a one; and he replies, maEiYa rajulN badaluhu, i. e. With me is a man who stands in his stead, and is in his place, or who will stand &c. (M.) You say also, bala ka*aA [and badalFA mino ka*aA], meaning Instead of, in the place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, such a thing. (Kull.) [And badala A^ano tafoEala ka*aA Instead of thy doing thus.] ― -b2- AlA^abodaAlu (IDrd, S, M, K, &c.) and AlbudalaA='u (TA) [The Substitutes, or Lieutenants;] certain righteous persons, of whom the world is never destitute; when one dies, God substituting another in his place: (S:) certain persons by means of whom God rules the earth; (M, K;) consisting of seventy men, (IDrd, M, K,) according to their assertion, of whom the earth is never destitute; (IDrd, TA;) forty of whom are in Syria, and thirty in the other countries; (IDrd, M, K;) none of them dying without another's supplying his place, (M, K,) from the rest of mankind; (K;) and therefore they are named AbdAl: (M:) accord. to Abu-lBakà, as stated by El-Munáwee, it seems that they meant [by this appellation] the substitutes and successors of the prophets; and accord. to some, they were seven, neither more nor fewer, by means of whom God takes care of the seven climates; one being successor of Abraham (ElKhaleel), and to him pertains the first climate; the second, of Moses (El-Keleem); the third, of Aaron; the fourth, of Idrees; the fifth, of Joseph; the sixth, of Jesus; and the seventh, of Adam: (TA: [in which is also mentioned a treatise denying their existence, and disapproving of the assertion that by means of them God takes care of the earth:]) the sing. is badalN and ↓ bidolN, (T,) or ↓ badiylN. (IDrd, S.) ― -b3- Huruwfu Albadali (M, K) The letters of substitution; those which are substituted for other letters; not those which are substituted in consequence of idghám. (M.) [The letters included under this appellation differ accord. to different authors: see De Sacy's Gram. Ar. 2nd ed. i. 33.] ― -b4- ↓ bidolN (Kr, M, K) and badalN (M, K,) applied to a man, also signify Generous, and noble: (Kr, * M, K:) and used in these senses, [says ISd,] they are, in my opinion, not devoid of implication of the meaning of a substitute: (M:) the pl. is A^abodaAlN (M, K.)
badiylN bdyl : see badalN, in six places

bad~aAlN bdAl dAl
A seller of eatables (A Heyth, T, K) of every kind: thus he is called by the Arabs; (A Heyth, T;) because he changes one sale for another; selling one thing to-day and another to-morrow: (AHát, TA:) the vulgar say, baq~aAlN. (A Heyth, T, K.) ― -b2- Also One who has no more property than is sufficient for his purchasing one thing, and who, when he sells this, buys another thing in exchange for it. (TA in art. jdl.) [Hence,] h`*aA raA^oYu Aljad~aAliyna waAlbad~aAliyna is a phrase used as meaning This is flimsy opinion. (TA in the present art. and in art. jdl, [but in the latter without the w,] on the authority of AHeyth.)
mubodalN mbdl : see 2.
mabodalN mbdl : see 2.

1 baduna bAd bdn bdnn bdyn , (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
baduna ; (T, S;) and badana, aor.
baduna ; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) inf. n.
badaAnapN (T, S, M, &c.,) of the former, (ISk, T, S, &c.,) and budonN, (T, S, M, K,) also of the former, (ISk, T,) or of the latter, (S,) and badonN, (M, K,) accord. to AZ, (T,) and badaAnN, (M, K,) or buduwnN is the inf. n. of the latter verb; (Msb;) said of a man, (ISk, T, S,) and of a camel; (Msb;) and badunato and badanato, said of a woman, (AZ, T, M, K,) and of a badanap, q. v.; (Zj, T, &c.;) He, and she, was, or became, big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) abounding in flesh; (T;) fat: (Zj, T, M:) or the former verb has this last signification, that of fatness; and the latter verb is syn. with bad~ana q. v. (Ham p. 158.) [See also budonN, below.]

2 bd~n bAd bdn bdnn bdyn , inf. n. tabodiynN, He (a man, T, S, M) was, or became, aged, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and weak: (M, K:) or he was, or became, heavy by reason of age; as also ↓badana. (Ham p. 158.) -A2- He clad a man with a badan, i. e. a diroE [or coat of mail]. (K,* TA.)

budonN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn [properly an inf. n.; see 1:] Fatness and compactness; as also ↓ budunN. (S.) ― -b2- And Fat; i. e. the substance termed $aHomN. (M, TA.) -A2- It is also a pl. of badanapN: (T, S, &c.:) ― -b2- and of baAdinN. (M, TA.)

badanN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn The body, without the head and arms and legs; (M, Msb, K;) so says Az: (Msb:) or the body without the arms and legs: (Mgh:) or [the part] from the shoulder-joint to the posteriors [inclusive]: (TA [as from the Mgh, in my copy of which it is not found]:) or the jasada [generally meaning the body together with the members] of a man; (S;) often applied. to the whole of the jasad; (Az, TA;) and in the Kur x. 92 it is said to mean the body without soul: (S:) pl. A^abodaAnN; (M, Msb;) whence the phrase, mentioned by Lh, A_in~ahaA laHasanapu AlA^abodaAni [meaning Verily she is beautiful in respect of the body], as though the term badanN were applied to every portion of her. (M.) $irokapu AlA^abodaAni is originally $irokapN biAlA^abodaAni, meaning Copartnership in bodily labours for the acquirement of gains. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) The part of a shirt, (Mgh, Msb,) and of a [garment of the kind called] jub~ap, (Mgh,) that lies against the back and the belly, [i. e. the body thereof,] without the sleeves and the daxaAriyS [or gores with which it is widened]: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A short diroE [or coat of mail], (S, M, K,) of the measure of the body: (M:) or it is [a coat of mail] like a diroE, except that it is short, only such as covers the body, with short sleeves: (T:) or, as some say, any diroE: (M:) and so it is said to mean in the Kur x. 92 by IAar (T) and by Th; (M;) but Akh says that this assertion is of no account: (S:) pl. as above. (M, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A small [garment of the kind called] jub~ap; as being likened to a coat of mail. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to Kr, (M,) A limb, or member: or, specially, the limbs, or members, of a slaughtered camel: (M, K: [in the latter of which, the former of these two explanations is improperly connected with the first in this paragraph by the conjunction Aw:]) to these he specially applies it in one instance: pl. as above. (M.) ― -b6- Also An old, or aged, man: (K:) or so rajulN badanN. (T, S, M.) [In like manner, ↓ baAdinN and ↓ badinN are said by Golius, as on the authority of the S, to signify annosus et senior, applied to a man, and also to a woman; but this explanation is wrong; and the latter word I do not find in any lexicon.] ― -b7- And An old mountain-goat: (M, K:) or so waEilN badanN: (S:) [in the present day, badan is applied to the wild goat of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; the capra jaela of Hamilton Smith; called by some an ibex; as is also tayotal, properly vayotalN:] pl. [of pauc.] A^abodunu (M, K [in the CK, erroneously, A^abodanN]) and [of mult.] buduwnN, which is extr. [with respect to rule], on the authority of IAar. (M, TA.) The rájiz says, describing a bitch (S, M) and a mountain-goat, (M, TA,)
qado qulotu lam~aA badati AlEuqaAbu
waDam~ahaA waAlbadana AlHiqaAbN
jid~iY likul~i EaAmilK vawaAbu
Aalr~aA^osu waAlA^akoruEu waAlA_ihaAbu
(S, * M, * TA,) [I had said, when El-' Ikáb appeared, and El-Hikáb comprised her and the old mountain-goat, “Exert thyself: for every worker there is a recompense: the head and the shanks and the hide shall be thine”]: AlEqAb is the name of a bitch, and AlHqAb is a certain mountain: he says, “Catch thou this goat, and I will make thy recompense to be the head and the shanks and the hide.” (TA.) [Hence Golius has been led to mistake AlHiqaAb for a signification of Albadanu.] ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The lineage, or parentage, of a man, and his grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (M, K.)
badinN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn : see badanN
budunN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn : see budonN. -A2- It is also a pl. of badanapN. (M, K, &c.)

badanapN bAd bdn bdnh bdnp bdyn
A she-camel, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and a male camel, (T, M, Mgh, K,) and a cow, (T, S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K,) and a bull, (M, K,) accord. to some, (Msb,) or properly the first of these, (Mgh, Msb,) and the second, (Mgh,) but made by the Sunneh to apply to a cow also, (Mgh, * Msb,) that is slaughtered at Mekkeh, (S,) or that is, (M, K,) or may be, (T,) brought thither for sacrifice; (T, M, K;) so called because they used to fatten them, (S,) or because of their greatness, or bulkiness: (T, Mgh, Msb:) not applied to a sheep or goat: (T, Msb, TA:) En-Nawawee erroneously cites the T as asserting that it is thus applied; misled, it is said, by an omission in his copy: (MF, TA:) pl. badanaAtN, (T, Mgh, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (Mgh,) and budonN, (T, S, M, Msb,) or budunN, (Mgh, K,) or both, (M, Msb, TA,) the former being a contraction of the latter, which seems to be pl. of badiynN: (Msb:) one should not use badanN as a pl. of badanapN; though they used to say xa$abN and A^ajamN &c. (M, TA.)

[
badaniY~N A^dnY bd bdn bdnY bdny bdyn dny
Of, or relating to, the badan, or body; corporeal. ― -b2- See also baAdinN.]
badiynN bdyn dyn : see baAdinN, in four places.

baAdinN bAdn , applied to a man, Big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ badiynN (Msb, K) and ↓ mubad~anN (M, K) [and ↓ badaniY~N]: and fat; as also ↓ mubad~anN: (T, M:) or heavy in body; heavy by reason of age: and ↓ badiynN signifies fat: (Ham p. 158:) baAdinN is likewise applied to a woman, (S, M, Msb, K,) as are also baAdinapN (M, Mgh, K) and ↓ badiynN (S, K) and ↓ mubad~anapN: (T, M:) the pl. is bud~anN (M, Msb, K) and budonN (M, TA) and budunN; (Msb, K;) the first of these being pl. of baAdinN, (M, Msb,) and so the second; (M;) and the third being pl. of ↓ badiynN. (Msb.) See also badanN.
mubad~anN mbdn , and with p: see baAdinN, in three places.

mibodaAnN mbdAn
That becomes fat quickly, with little fodder [or food]. (M, K.)

1 badahahu bdh bdhh bdhp , (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor.
badaha , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. bado'N, (JK, S, Msb,) He, or it, came upon him, or happened to him, suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (JK, S Msb, K;) as also ↓ bAdhhu, inf. n. mubaAdahapN: (JK, Msb:) the former verb has this signification said of an affair, or event. (S, K.) And badahahu biA^amorK, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (JK, TA,) signifies Aisotaqobalahu bihi, (JK, T, S, K,) i. e. He met him, or encountered him, with a thing, or an affair, or an action, (TK,) suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it: (T, TA:) or he began with him by it, or with it; syn. badaA^ahu bihi; (K;) the h being a substitute for the A (TA:) and bihi ↓ bAdhhu, (S,* K,) inf. n. mubaAdahapN and bidaAhN, (K,) he came upon him suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (S, K;) with it. (K.) ― -b2- See also 2.
2 bd~h bd bdh bdp , inf. n. tabodiyhN, He answered, or replied, quickly: (IAar, TA:) and ↓ badaha he answered, or replied, or he spoke, extempore; without premeditation. (Har p. 64.)
3 baAodaha see 1, in two places.
6 huma yatabaAdahaAni biA l$~iEori * (S, TA) They two dispute, or contend together [extemporaneously, or extemporizing, with verses or poetry]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8.

8 Abtdh AlxuTobapa Abtdh AlxTbh Abtdh AlxTbp (K, TA) He extemporized the discourse, or sermon, or oration; spoke it, or composed it, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation. (TA.) And ↓ humo yatabaAdahuwna AlxuTaba (K, TA) They extemporize discourses, &c.: here the measure tafaAEulN has not its proper quality [of denoting participation in the manner of contention, though it has in a phrase mentioned before]. (TA.)
badohN bd bdh bdp and budohN: see budaAhapN.
EalaY badiypK Ely bdyh Ely bdyp , and badiyhFA: see badiyhapN
badaAhapN bdAhh bdAhp : see budaAhapN, in two places.

budaAhapN bdAhh bdAhp (S, K) and ↓ badaAhapN (Sgh, K) and ↓ badiyhapN (JK, S, K) and ↓ badohN and ↓ budohN (K) substs. from badahahu biA^amorK, (JK, S,) meaning The first of anything; and an occurrence thereof by which one is taken unawares: (K:) or the first occurrence of a thing, that happens to one unexpectedly. (M, in explanation of the first word, in art. bdA^.) ― -b2- Also the first (S, TA) and ↓ second (JK) and ↓ third (TA) The first part of the running of a horse; (JK, S, TA;) opposed to EulaAlapN, signifying [the “remaining part of the running,” or “an afterrunning,” or] “a running after a running.” (TA.) You say, waEulaAlapK ↓ huwa *uw badiyhapK, and budaAhapK, [He has a first running and an after-running, differing, the one from the other]. (Az, TA.) And laHiqahu fiY budaAhapi jaroyihi [He overtook him in the first part of his running]. (Z, TA.) ISd thinks that in all these cases the h is a substitute for '. (TA.) [Hence,] ↓ gamoru Albadiyohapi [properly Fleet in the first part of his running; meaning] (tropical:) a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA, in art. gmr.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph. in three places.

badiyhapN bdyhh bdyhp : see budaAhapN, in four places. You say, laka Albadiyhapu, (K,) in which ISd thinks the h to be a substitute for ', (TA,) It is for thee to begin; (K;) and so ↓ lk AlbudaAhapu, with h substituted for '. (M, Mbr, TA art. bdA^.) And A^ajaAba EalaY Albadyhapi (K) He answered, or replied, on the first of his being taken unawares. (TA.) [↓ EalaY badiyhK is mentioned by Freytag, but on what authority he does not say, as meaning Unpreparedly, suddenly, or unexpectedly; and so ↓ badiyhFA by Golius, as on the authority of J, but I do not find it in the S in the present article.] And raA=hu badiyhapF, signifies He saw him suddenly, or unexpectedly. (TA.) And badiyhapu Alr~aA^oYi, Suddenly formed, unpremeditated, judgment or opinion. (Msb.) ― -b2- badiyhapN and ↓ budaAhapN both signify The coming, of speech, without premeditation: and the coming suddenly, unexpectedly, or unawares. (KL.) ― -b3- And ↓ the latter, [and more commonly the former,] An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; such as that one is the half of two; being, with respect to knowledge, like badiyEN with respect to intellect: (Kull:) [or] the former signifies the faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence: [intuition, or intuitive perception:] accord. to ' Alee-Ibn-Dháfir El-Haddád, it signifies primarily AirotijaAlN fiY AlkalaAmi [i. e. the faculty of extemporizing: or speaking, or composing, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation]: and predominantly, the poetizing, or versifying, impromptu, without premeditation or consideration: except that ArtjAl is quicker than bdyhp. (TA.) You say, huwa *uw badiyhapK (K) He has a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence. (TA.) And fulaAnN *uw badiyhapK HasanapK Such a one has a good faculty of extemporizing; or of uttering, or relating, things by means of the promptness of his intelligence. (TA, in art. bdA^: see badiyoapN.) And h`*aA maEoluwmN fiY badaAy^ihi AlEuquwli [This is known among the intuitive notions of intellects; i. e., intuitively]. (K, * TA.) badaAy^ihu seems to be pl. of badiyhapN, as in the phrase, (TA,) lahu badaAy^ihu, i. e. badaAy^iEu [He has new, or admirable, things that he utters], (K, TA,) in speech, or language, and poetry, and in answering, or replying: but here it is not improbable that the h may be a substitute for the E. (TA.)

badiyhiY~N bdyhY bdyhy [Intuitive knowledge;] such that its origination does not rest upon speculation, and acquisition by study, whether it do, or do not, require some other thing, as conjecture or experience &c.; (KT, Kull;) so that it is [sometimes] syn. with DaruwriY~N [and opposed to naZariY~N]: and sometimes it means such as does not require anything whatever after the intellect has directed itself; so that it is more particular than DaruwriY~N: (KT:) as the conception of heat and cold, and the assent of the mind to the position that negation and affirmation cannot be co-existent, nor be simultaneously non-existent, in the same instance. (KT, Kull.) ― -b2- [And hence,] A mere simpleton or fool: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

rajulN mibodahN rjl mbdh rjl mbdp (S) A man possessing in a large degree the faculty of extemporizing, or of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; firm, or steady, in speech or discourse, or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions, when he is taken unawares. (Har p. 64.)

1 badaA bd bdA , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaboduw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. buduw~N (S, M, Msb, K) and badowN and badaA='N (M, K) and badaA='apN (K) and badFA, (M, on the authority of Sb,) for which last we find, in [some of] the copies of the K, buduw~N, a repetition, (TA,) or buduwo'N, (so in other copies of the K,) It appeared; it became apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and ↓ tbd~Y [signifies the same; or he showed himself, or it showed itself; (see an ex. in art. jy$, voce jaA$a, last sentence;) or] he, or it, came in sight, or within sight. (KL.) ― -b2- badaA lahu fiY AlA^amori, (T, M, Msb, K, and Har p. 665,) inf. n. badowN (M, K) and badFA (M, and so in a copy of the K) and badaA='N, (T, M, and so in the CK,) or badaA='apN and badaApN; (as in some copies of the K;) or ↓ badaA lahu fiY AlA^amori badaA='N, (S, IB,) the last word being in the nom. case because it is the agent; (IB, TA;) An opinion presented itself, or occurred, to him, or arose in his mind, syn. na$aA^a, (S, K, and Har ubi suprà,) or appeared to him, (M,) [respecting the affair, or case,] different from his first opinion, so that it turned him therefrom: (Har ubi suprà:) or there appeared to him, respecting the affair, or case, what did not appear at first: (Msb:) accord. to Fr, ↓ badaA liY badaA='N means another opinion appeared to me: accord. to Az, badaA liY badFA means my opinion changed from what it was. (TA.) Esh-Shemmàkh says,
laEal~aka wa AlmawoEuwdu Haq~N wafaAw^uhu
badaA laka fiY tiloka AlqaluwSi badaA='u
[May-be (but it is right that the promise be fulfilled) an opinion different from thy first opinion hath arisen in thy mind respecting that youthful she-camel]. (M, TA.) vum~a badaA lahumo mino baEodi maA raA^awuA A@loA=yaAti layasojunan~ahu, in the Kur [xii.35], means badaA waqaAluwA layasojunun~ahu ↓ lahumo badaA='N, [i.e. Then an opinion arose in their minds, after they had seen the signs of his innocence, and they said that they should certainly imprison him,] because lysjnn~h, being a proposition, cannot be the agent: so says Sb. (M.) badaA lil~hi A^ano yaqotulahumo, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) God determined that He would slay them: for, as IAth says, badaA='N signifies the deeming to be right a thing that is known after its having been not known; and this may not be attributed to God: but as is said by Suh, in the R, one may say, [of God,] badaA lahu A^ano yafoEala ka*aA, [properly signifying It occurred to him, or appeared to him, that he should do such a thing,] as meaning (tropical:) He desired to do such a thing; [as also badaA lahu fiY fiEoli ka*aA;] and thus the phrase in the trad., here mentioned, has been explained. (TA.) [One says also, AifoEalo ka*aA maA badaA laka Do thou thus as long as it seems fit to thee: see, a verse of El-Ahmar cited voce jal~a.] ― -b3- badaA Alqawomu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. badowN, (S,) or badaA='N; (M, K;) [the latter of which is said in the TA to be the right;] or badaA A_ilaY AlbaAdiyapi, inf. n. badaAwapN and bidaAwapN; (Msb;) The people, or company of men, went forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M, Msb, K:) or, the former, went forth to their baAdiyap: (S:) or went forth from the region, or district, of towns or villages or of cultivated land, to the pasturingplaces in the deserts: (T:) [ISd says,] badowN may be used as meaning bidaAwapN, which is the contr. of HiDaArapN: (M:) [J says,] badaAwapN and bidaAwapN signify the dwelling, or abiding, in the baAdiyap [or desert]; the contr. of HiDaArapN: but Th says, I know not badaAwapN, with fet-h, except on the authority of AZ alone: (S:) As says that bdAwp and HDArp are with kesr to the b and fet-h to the H; but AZ says the reverse, i. e. with fet-h to the b and kesr to the H: (T:) both are also explained as signifying the going forth to the baAdiyap: and some mention budaAwapN, with damm; but this is not known: (TA:) ↓ tbd~Y like wise signifies he went forth from the constant sources of water to the places where herbage was to be sought [in the desert]; (T;) or he dwelt, or abode, in the baAdiyap. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. He who abides in the desert becomes rude, rough, coarse, or uncivil, like the desert-Arabs. (S.) And in another, kaAna yaboduw A_ilaY h`*ihi Alt~ilaAEi [He used to go forth to these water-courses in the desert, or these high grounds, or low grounds, &c.]. (TA.)― -b4- [Hence,] badaA He voided his excrement, or ordure; (M, K;) as also ↓ AbdY (T, K) [and AbdA^]: because he who does so goes forth from the tents or houses into the open country. (T.) -A2- badaAniY bika*aA, aor. yaboduw, is like badaA^aniY [i. e. He began with me by
doing such a thing]. (M, TA.) -A3- badiyati AlA^aroDu The land produced, or abounded with, badaAp, i. e. truffles: (K, * TA:) or had in it truffles. (TK.) ― -b2- And The land had in it badaAp, meaning dust, or earth. (K, * TK.)

2 bd~Y bd bdY bdy , inf. n. tabodiyapN, He showed, or made apparent, a want that occurred, or presented itself, to him. (TA.) [See bdaA='apN.] ― -b2- He sent forth a horse [or beast] to the place of pasture [app. in the baAdiyap, or desert]. (TA, from a trad.)

3 mubaAdaApN mbAdAh mbAdAp The going, or coming, out, or forth, in the field, to encounter another in battle, or war. (TA.) ― -b2- And [more commonly] The showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: (KL, TA:) [a meaning more fully expressed by the phrase mubaAdaApN biAlEadaAwapi: for you say,] baAdaY biAlEadaAwapi He showed open enmity, or hostility, [with another;] syn. jaAhara bihaA; (S, K; *) as also ↓ tbAdY: (K:) or you say, bAlEdwAp ↓ tbAdwA they showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tajaAharuwA bihaA. (S.) You say also, bAdY Aln~aAsa biA^amorihi He showed, or revealed, to the people, or to men, his affair, or case. (TA.) [Thus, bAdAhu biAlA^amori and lahu AlA^amora ↓ AbdY signify the same; i. e. He showed, or revealed, to him the affair, or case.] ― -b3- And bAdY bayonahumaA He measured, or compared, them both together, each with the other. (A, TA.)

4 AbdAhu A^bd A^bdAh A^bdY AbdAh AbdAp
He made it apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, exhibited, manifested, evinced, discovered, or revealed, it; (S, M, Msb, K;) and it has been said [correctly, as will be seen below,] that AbdY Eanohu signifies the same. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yubodi lanaA SafoHatahu naqama Ealayohi kitaAbu A@ll~`hi, i. e. (tropical:) Whoso showeth, or revealeth, to us his deed [or crime] which he was concealing, [the book of God shall execute vengeance upon him, meaning] we will inflict upon him the punishment ordained by the book of God. (TA.) AbdY lahu SafoHatahu also means (tropical:) He showed open enmity, or hostility, with him. (A and TA in art. SfH.) And AbdY Eano qaEorihi, said of water, means It showed its bottom, by reason of its clearness. (L in art. mkd.) See also 3. ― -b2- A^abodayota fiY manoTiqika Thou deviatedst, or hast deviated, from the right way in thy speech. (S.) ― -b3- See also 1.
5 tbd~Y A^bdY bd bdA tbdY tbdy : see 1, in two places. -A2- In the common dial. of the people of El-Yemen, it signifies He ate the morning-meal; syn. tagad~aY. (TA.)
6 tbAdY A^bAd bAdY tbAdY tbAdy : see 3, in two places. ― -b2- Also He affected to be like, or imitated, the people of the baAdiyap [or desert]. (S, K.)
badK bd : see badowN, in two places.

badFA bd bdA The excrement from the anus (M, K *) of a man. (M.) [And badaA='N, from A^abodaA^a, signifies the same.] ― -b2- A joint (mafoSil) of a man; (AA, M, K;) as also bado'N: (AA, M:) pl. A^abodaA='N. (AA, M, K.) -A2- badaA for badFA: see badowN, in two places.

badowN bdw bdwy : see baAdiyapN: -A2- and see also baAdK. -A3- Also The first of a thing; originally [bado'N,] with hemzeh: (Har p. 583:) and ↓ badiY~N, also, [originally badiYo'N,] signifies the first: (TA:) [and ↓ badK and ↓ badaA, the latter for badFA, are used for bado'K. Hence,] one says, ↓ AifoEalo *`lika baAdiY badK, (S,) or baAdiYa badK, (M, K,) and ↓ baAdiY badiY, (Fr, S, M,) or baAdiYa badiY, (as in some copies of the K,) or ↓ bAdY badiYK, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) and ↓ baAdaYa badFA, (M, K,) mentioned by Sb, who says that it is without tenween, though analogy does not forbid its being with tenween, (M,) meaning Do thou that first; (S, TA;) or, the first thing: (Fr, TA:) originally [baAdiy^a bado'K, &c.,] with hemz. (S, K. [See bado'N.]) Hence also the phrase, ↓ AlHamodulil`hi badiy~FA [Praise be to God in the first place]. (TA.)
badiy bd bdY bdy for badK: see badowN.

badaApN bd bdAh bdAp bdwy dAhy : see badaA='N: ― -b2- and see also baAdiyapN. -A2- Also, (K, TA,) like qaTaApN, (TA, [but in the CK badoA^ap, q. v.,]) Truffles; syn. kamoA^apN. (K.) ― -b2- And Dust, or earth. (K.)
badowapN bd bdA bdwh bdwp bdwy Either side of a valley. (AHn, M, K.)

badawiY~N bdwY bdwy dwAyp dwY dwy [Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the badow, or desert: and, used as a subst., a man, and particularly an Arab, of the desert:] a rel. n. from badowN, (S, M, K,) extr. [with respect to rule], (M, K,) for by rule it should be badowiY~N; (ElTebreezee, TA;) or it is an irregular rel. n. from baAdiyapN: (Msb:) and ↓ badaAwiY~N and ↓ bidaAwiY~N are similar rel. ns., (M, K,) from badaAwapN and bidaAwapN, as syn. with badowN and baAdiyapN, agreeably with rule; or the former of these two may be a rel. n. from badowN and baAdiyapN, and therefore extr. [with respect to rule]; but it is said that when a rel. n. may be regarded as regular or irregular, it is more proper to regard it as regular; (M;) or the former is a rel. n. signifying of, or belonging to, or relating to, AlbadaAwap as meaning the dwelling, or abiding, in the desert, (S, TA,) accord. to the opinion of AZ; and the latter is a rel. n. from AlbidaAwap accord. to the opinion of As and others; and is held by Th to be the chaste form: (TA:) but badawiY~N is the only one of these rel. ns. that is known to the common people: (M:) it is opposed to a townsman or villager. (TA.) [The pl. is badaAwaY, and vulg. bidowaAnN. See also baAdK, often applied to a man as syn. with badawiY~N.]
badawaAtN bdAp bdwAt : see badaA='N, in three places.

badaA='N bdA=' [An opinion that occurs to one, or arises in the mind; and particularly one that is different from a former opinion;] a subst. from badaA in the phrase badaA lahu fiY AlA^amori. (Msb.) See 1, in four places. One says also, ↓ huwa *uw badawaAtK He is one who has various opinions occurring to him, or arising in his mind, (IDrd, S, * K, * and Har p. 665,) of which he chooses some and rejects others: (IDrd, TA:) it is said in praise, (IDrd, TA, and Kzz in Har ubi suprà,) and sometimes in dispraise: (Kzz in Har ubi suprà:) badawaAtN is pl. of ↓ badApN, [which is therefore syn. with badaA='N,] like as qaTawaAtN is pl. of qaTaApN. (IDrd, TA, and Har ubi supra.) One says likewise ↓ A^abuw AlbadawaAti, meaning The father [i. e. originator] of opinions that present themselves to him. (IDrd, TA.) And ↓ Als~uloTaAnu *uw EadawaAtK wa*uw badawaAtK (S, [in which the context indicates it to mean The Sultán is characterized by deviations from the right way:] but accord. to SM, it is) a trad., meaning the Sultán ceases not to have some new opinion presenting itself to him. (TA.)
bidaA='N bdA=' , in the common dial. of the people of ElYemen, signifies The morning-meal; syn. gadaA='N. (TA.)

badiYN bd bdY bdy : see baAdiyapN: ― -b2- and see badowN, in three places. ― -b3- Also, [or biy^orN badiY~N,] originally badiYo'N, q. v. in art. bdA^, (TA,) A well: (T:) or a well that is not ancient: (TA:) pl. buwdaAnN, formed by transposition from budoyaAnN. (T.)

badaA='apN bdA='h bdA='p
What appears, or becomes apparent, of wants, or needful things: pl. badaAA=tN; for which one may also say, badaAwaAtN. (T.) These two pls. also signify Wants that appear, or become apparent, to one. (TA.) [The latter of them is likewise pl. of what next follows.]
badaAwapN bdAwh bdAwp and bidaAwapN: see baAdiyapN. ― -b2- The former also signifies The first that appears, or becomes apparent, of a thing. (Lh, M, K.) [See badaA='apN.]
badaAwiY~N bdAwY bdAwy and bidaAwiY~N: see badawiY~N.

baAdK A_d bA_d bAd bAdy
Appearing, or apparent; or becoming, or being, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident. (Msb.) [Hence,] baAdiYa Alr~aA^oYi At the [first] appearance of opinion; (Fr, Lh, M;) or according to the appearance of opinion; (Zj, S, K; *) which may mean either insincerely or inconsiderately: (Zj, TA:) so in the Kur xi. 29; (Zj, S;) where only AA read it with hemz: (TA:) if with hemz, it is from badaA^otu, and means at first thought, or on the first opinion. (S; and Lh in M, art. bdA^: see bado'N.) For baAdiY badK, or baAdiYa badK, and baAdiY badiY, &c., see badowN, in four places. ― -b2- baAdiY badiY is sometimes used as a name for Calamity, or misfortune: it consists of two nouns made one, like maEodiYo kariba. (S.) ― -b3- baAdK also signifies A man going forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M, * Msb, K, * TA:) or one who is in the baAdiyap, dwelling in the tents, and not remaining in his place: (TA:) pl. baAduwna and bud~FA [in the TA erroneously said to be budFY like hudFY] and bud~aA='N: (M, K:) and ↓ badowN is a quasi-pl. n. of baAdK; (M, TA;) or is for A^aholu badowK, meaning people who go forth to the desert; (M;) or it means dwellers in the desert, or people of the desert: (MF:) ↓ baAdiyapN also signifies the same as baAduwna, i. e. people migrating from the constant sources of water, and going forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; contr. of HaADirapN; and bawaAdiY [or bawaAdK] is pl. of baAdiyapN. (T.)
baAdaApN A^dAp bA^dAp bAd bAdAh bAdAp bAdY : see what next follows.

baAdiyapN bAdy bAdyh bAdyp (T, S, &c.) A desert; so called because of its being open, or uncovered; (TA;) contr. of HaDarN; (M, K;) as also ↓ badowN, (S, * M, Msb, K,) and ↓ baAdaApN, (M, K,) or ↓ badaApN, (TA, [thought by SM to be the correct form because found by him in the M, in which I find bAdAp,]) and ↓ badiY~N, said to be used as syn. with baAdiyapN in a verse of Lebeed cited among the exs. of the preposition bi, p. 142, (TA,) and ↓ bdaAwapN (M, K) and ↓ bidaAwapN; (M;) [of which the last two and the second (namely, badowN,) seem to be originally inf. ns.; see 1:] or a land in which are no towns or villages or cultivated soil: (Lth, T:) or the places to which people migrate from the constant sources of water, when they go forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; also termed mabaAdK, which is syn. with manaAjiEu, contr. of maHaADiru, and pl. of ↓ mabodFY, (T,) this last signifying the contr. of maHoDarN: (S:) the pl. of baAdiyapN is bawaAdK. (T, Msb.) ― -b2- See also baAdK.
mabodFY mbdY mbdy mbdyy : pl. mabaAdK: see baAdiyapN.

rakiY~N mubodK 1
Wells showing their water; having it uncovered by dust or earth; contr. of rakiYN gaAmidN. (A in art. gmd.)

1 badiytu biAl$~aYo'i * and badayotu bihi
i. q. [badaA^otu and] AibotadaA^otu [I began with the thing; or made it to have precedence, or to be first]; (M, K;) of the dial. of the Ansár: (M:) the people of ElMedeeneh say, badayonaA, or badiynaA, [accord. to different copies of the S,] in the sense of badaA^onaA: (S:) [the right reading seems to be badayonaA; for] IKh says, none says badayotu in the sense of badaA^otu, except the Ansár: all others say, badiytu and badaA^otu; when the hemzeh is suppressed, the d is pronounced with kesr, and therefore the hemzeh is changed into Y. (IB, TA.) [See a verse of Ibn-Rawáhah cited voce bado'N.]
bidaAyapN rky mbd , said by Mtr to be a vulgar word, and by IB to be erroneous, but by IKtt to be of the dial. of the Ansár: see art. bdA^ [voce bado'N, second sentence, in two places]. (TA.)

1 ba*~a * , (M,) sec. pers. ba*i*ota, (S, Mgh, K,) aor. yaba*~u, (L, K,) inf. n. ba*aA*apN (S, M, Mgh, K) and bu*uw*apN (S, M, K) and ba*a*N (M, Mgh, K) and ba*aA*N, (K,) or bi*aA*N, with kesr, (TA,) [of all which, the third is the regular form,] He (a man) was, or became, threadbare, and shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel, (Ks, S, M, Mgh, L,) and in an evil condition; (M, L, K;) slovenly with respect to his person: (Ks, M, L:) or he neglected the constant adornment of himself: or he adorned himself one day, and another day left his hair in a shaggy or dishevelled, or matted and dusty, state: (T, L:) or he was humble in his apparel, not taking pleasure therein. (IAth, L.) ba*aA*ap is said in a trad. to be a part of religion; (Ks, T, M, Mgh, L;) meaning, in this instance, The being humble in dress, and wearing that which is not conducive to self-conceit and pride. (Mgh.) -A2- ba*~ahu, aor. yabu*~u, (T, S, M, L,) inf. n. ba*~N (S, M, L, K) and ↓ ba*iy*apN, (K,) [or this may be a simple subst.,] He overcame him; (T, S, M, L, K;) he surpassed him in goodliness or beauty, or in any deed: (T, L:) he outstripped him. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., ba*~a AlqaAy^iliyna He outstripped, or surpassed, and overcame, the speakers. (L.)

3 bA*~hu *
He hastened with him; made haste, or strove, to be, or get, before him: (K, * TA:) he vied with him in glory or excellence. (TA.)

8 Abt*~ Haq~ahu *
He took his (i. e. his own) right, or due. (K.)

10 Astb*~ biAlA^amori *
He was alone, with none to share, or participate, with him, in the affair; (K, * TA;) i. q. Astbd~ (K) and Astql~. (TA.)

ba*~N * [perhaps from the Persian bado] A man slovenly with respect to his person, and poor. (IAar, T, L.) And ba*~u Alhayoy^api, and Alhayoy^api ↓ baA*~u, A man threadbare, and shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel; (Ks, T, * S, Mgh, L;) and in an evil condition with respect to it; (L, K;) slovenly with respect to his person: (Ks, L:) or one who neglects the constant adornment of his person: or who adorns himself one day, and another day leaves his hair in a shaggy or dishevelled, or matted and dusty, state: (T, L:) or humble in his apparel, not taking pleasure therein. (IAth, L.) ― -b2- ba*~u Albaxoti A man having evil fortune. (Kr, M, L.) ― -b3- hayoy^apN ba*~apN A threadbare, and shabby, or mean, state of apparel. (M.) ― -b4- HaAlN ba*~apN, (S,) and HaAlapN ba*~apN, (TA,) An evil state or condition. (S, TA.) ― -b5- tamorN ba*~N Dates that are separate, each one from another, not sticking together; like fa*~N: (IAar, M:) or that are scattered. (K.) ― -b6- fa*~N ba*~N Single; sole; that is alone, or apart from others: (IAar, K:) and so A^aHa*~u ↓ A^aba*~u. (K.)

fiY hayoy^atihi ba*~apN * , and ba*aA*apN, [the latter an inf. n. (of ba*~a) used as a simple subst.,] In his state of apparel is slovenliness, and threadbareness, and shabbiness, or meanness. (T.) ↓ ba*iy*apN, also, (sometimes written ↓ ba*oba*apN, TA, and so in the TT but without vowel-signs,) signifies Slovenliness with respect to one's person; or neglect of cleanliness. (T, L, K.)
ba*iy*apN * , or ba*oba*apN: see ba*~apN. -A2- And for the former, see also ba*~ahu.
baA*~N * : see ba*~N. -A2- Also Any one overcoming, or surpassing. (M, L.)
A^aba*~N * : see ba*~N.

1 ba*uw^a * , (T, M, K,) with and without ', (Mgh,) aor.
ba*uAa , (T,) inf. n. ba*aA='N and ba*aA='apN, (M, K,) the former written in one copy of the K ba*aA^N, and the latter in some copies written ba*oA^apN; (TA;) and ba*aA^a, and ba*iy^a, (K,) aor. of both
ba*aAa ; (TA;) and some say ba*iYa, aor. yabo*aY, inf. n. ba*aA='N; (T;) or, accord. to the Msb, only ba*aA^a is with ', and the others are properly written ba*iYa and ba*uwa; (TA;) He (a man) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or obscene, (T, M, K, TA,) in tongue; (TA;) evil in speech. (T.) And ba*aA^a EalaY Alqawomi, aor.
ba*aAa , inf. n. ba*o'N and ba*aA='N, He behaved in a lightwitted, weak, stupid, or foolish, manner, or ignorantly, towards the people, or company of men; and uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against them; and so though with truth. (Msb.) ― -b2- ba*aA^a also signifies He was, or became, evil in disposition. (Fr, T.) ― -b3- And, said of a place, It became devoid of pasture, barren, or unfruitful. (TA.) -A2- baA*aA^ahu faba*aA^ahu: see 3. ― -b2- ba*aA^ahu, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
ba*aAa , (T,) inf. n. ba*o'N, (T, S,) also signifies He dispraised it; discommended it; (T, M, K;) namely, a thing: (M:) and be despised him: (T, K:) and he saw in him (a man, S) a state, or condition, that he disliked, or hated: (S, K:) he did not approve him; and was not pleased with his aspect. (TA.) And ba*aA^atohu EayoniY, (T, S, M, Msb, *) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) My eye did not approve him, or it; (T, S;) I was not pleased with his, or its, aspect; (S;) and I saw in him, or it, a state, or condition, that I disliked. or hated: (T:) or my eye despised, or regarded as of light estimation, him, or it: (M, Msb:) accord. to AZ, this is said when a thing has been praised, or greatly praised, to thee, and in thy presence, and then thou dost not see it to be as it has been described: but when thou seest it to be as it has been described, thou sayest, maA tabo*aw^uhu AlEayoni. (T.) One says also, ba*aA^a AlA^aroDa He dispraised, or discommended, the pasture of the land. (S, M, K.) And in like manner, ba*aA^a AlmawoDiEa (S) He did not praise the place. (TA.)

3 bA*A^hu * , (T,) inf. n. mubaA*aA^apN, (T, K,) in some copies of the K without ', (TA,) and bi*aA='N, (T, K,) [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language: and he held such discourse with him: these significations being indicated by the following exs., and by the saying that] the inf. ns. are syn. with mufaAHa$apN. (T, K.) You say, ↓ baA*aA^ahu faba*aA^ahu [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language, and he surpassed him therein: in this case, the aor. of the latter verb is
ba*uAa , notwithstanding the final faucial letter]. (TA.) And Esh-Shaabee says, A_i*a EaZumati AlHaloqapu faA_in~amaA huwa bi*aA='N wa nijaA='N [i. e. When the ring of people becomes large, it is only an occasion of holding foul, unseemly, or obscene, and secret, discourse]: it is said that b*A=' here signifies mfAH$p: (T:) the meaning is, that there is much b*A' and njA', i. e. munaAjaAp, therein. (TA in art. njw. [But there, in the place of faA_in~amaA huwa, I find fahiYa; and in the TA in the present art., faA_in~amaA bihi.]) ― -b2- Also He contended with him in an altercation. (T.)

4 Ab*A^ *
He uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (TA.)

ba*iYo'N * A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, (T,
M, K, TA,) in tongue; (TA;) evil in speech. (T.) [See also art. b*w.] ― -b2- A place in which is no pasture: (K:) and A^aroDN ba*iyoy^apN a land in which is no pasture. (S, M.)
