ba*axa , inf. n. ba*axN; (Msb;) and ba*axa, [aor.
ba*axa and
ba*uxa , (see what follows,)] inf. n. bu*uwxN; (L;) It (a mountain) was high, or lofty. (L, Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, (Msb,) ba*ixa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ba*axa , (K,) inf. n. ba*xN; (S, K;) and ba*axa, aor.
ba*axa and
ba*uxa , but the former is the more approved, inf. n. ba*oxN and bu*uwxN; (L;) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, proud, and lofty, or haughty; (S, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ tb*~x: (S, K:) (tropical:) he exalted himself above others, (L, TA,) as also ↓ tb*~x, (A,) by his speech, and his glorying, or boasting. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And ba*axa, aor.
ba*axa , inf. n. ba*axaAnN, (tropical:) He (a camel) brayed in the most vehement manner, (L, TA,) and put forth his $iq$iqap [or faucial bag]. (TA.) -A2- ba*axa, aor.
ba*axa , inf. n. ba*oxN, He split, clave, rifted, slit, or rent, a thing. (Msb.)
3 bA*xhu * (assumed tropical:) He vied, or competed, or contended, with him in glorying or boasting, or in glory or excellence, or for superiority in nobleness. (L, TA.)
5 taba*~axa see 1, in two places.
bi*oxN * : see baA*ixN.

bi*ixo * and ba*axo [for the latter of which, in the CK, we find ba*ixo,] i. q. baxo [Excellent! &c.]; (JK, T, K, TA;) and wonderful! (T, TA.) ― -b2- bi*ixo bi*ixo is also said in chiding a camel that brays in the most vehement manner, (see ba*axa,) or in imitating his braying. (L.)
ba*ixN * : see baA*ixN.

bu*aAxiy~N *
Great; syn. EaZiymN. (K.)
ba*~aAxN * : see what next follows, in four places.

baA*ixN *
High, or lofty; (JK, A, Msb;) applied to a mountain: (JK, Msb:) [and] a high, or lofty, mountain; an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (L, TA:) pl. bawaA*ixu (JK, S, A, L, Msb) and baA*ixaAtN [both fem. forms]: (JK:) and the former pl. applied as an epithet to mountains. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN baA*ixN, (JK, L,) and ↓ ba*~aAxN, (JK, A, L,) [the latter an intensive epithet,] (tropical:) A proud, and lofty, or haughty, man, who exalts himself above others, (JK, A, L,) by his speech, and his glorying, or boasting: (JK, L:) pl. of the former bu*axaA='u, like as EulamaA='u is pl. of EaAlimN, and bu*~axN. (L.) You say, In speech, he is ↓ ba*~aAxN; and in poetry, baA*ixN. (L.) ― -b3- And $arafN baA*ixN (tropical:) High, or exalted, nobility. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- baEiyrN baA*ixN, (L,) and ↓ ba*~aAxN, (L, K,) or Alhadiyri ↓ ba*~aAxu, (A,) and ↓ bi*oxN, and ↓ ba*ixN, (K,) (tropical:) A camel that brays much, (K,) or in the most vehement manner, (L,) and puts forth his $iqo$iqap [or faucial bag]. (K.)
bayo*axN * A large-bodied, or corpulent, woman; (S, K;) as also bayodaxN. (TA.)

1 ba*ara * , (T, S, A, Msb,) aor.
ba*ura , (Msb,) inf. n. ba*orN, (T, Msb, K,) He sowed seed; (S, TA;) he cast grain upon the ground to sow it; (Msb;) he cast grain upon the ground, scattering it; (A;) he scattered seed (T, MF) upon the ground; as also ↓ b*~r, [but app. in an intensive sense,] (MF,) inf. n. tabo*iyrN (T, MF) and tabo*irapN: (T:) this is the primary signification. (MF.) ― -b2- Also, (M,) inf. n. as above, (M, K,) He sowed land; (M, L, K;) and so ↓ b*~r, (M, L,) inf. n. tabo*iyrN. (L, K.) ― -b3- Also, (M,) inf. n. as above, (M, K,) He scattered, or dispersed, (M, K,) a thing; (M;) and so ↓ b*~r, [or rather he scattered, or dispersed, much,] inf. n. tabo*iyrN. (K.) ― -b4- ba*ara A@ll~`hu Alxaloqi, (M, A,) inf. n. as above, (M,) God scattered, or dispersed, mankind (M, A) in the earth. (A.) ― -b5- ba*ara AlkalaAma (tropical:) He disseminated, scattered, or diffused, talk, or speech, (Msb, TA,) bayona Aln~aAsi among the people, or mankind, like as seed is scattered: (TA:) and ↓ b*~rhu he did so much. (Msb.) ― -b6- ba*arati AlA^aroDu, (M, A,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (M, K,) (tropical:) The land put forth its plants, or herbage, (As, M, A, K,) in a scattered state: (As, M, A:) or put forth its ba*or. (M.) -A2- ba*ura, aor.
ba*ura , inf. n. ba*aArapN, (tropical:) He divulged what was secret; he revealed what he had heard. (T, L.) -A3- ba*ira, [aor.
ba*ara ,] inf. n. ba*arN, He talked much; was loquacious. (M.)

2 ba*~ara see 1, in four places. ― -b2- b*~r, inf. n. tabo*iyrN, also signifies He was extravagant in expenditure; and so ↓ bA*r, inf. n. mubaA*arapN: (TA:) or the former, he dissipated, or squandered, (his wealth, or property, S, M, and any other thing, M, TA,) by extravagant expenditure, (S, M, K, TA,) and destroyed, consumed, wasted, or ruined, it: (M, K, TA: [in the CK, jar~abahu is here put for xar~abahu: in the M it is A^afosadahu:]) or he expended his wealth, or property, so largely as not to leave of it that whereby he might subsist: or he expended it in acts of disobedience: (TA:) or he dissipated, or squandered, his wealth, or property, in a way that was not right: (Msb:) or in a way that did not behoove: it includes the meaning of A^asorafa in common, or conventional, acceptation, and is used in the proper sense of this latter verb: or, as some say, tabo*iyrN denotes excess in respect of the right objects of expenditure, which is ignorance of the [right] manner, and of things that should prevent it; and A_isoraAfN denotes excess with respect to quantity, and is ignorance of the values of the right objects. (MF.) [See also ba*aAr~apN.]
3 baAo*ara see 2.

5 tb*~r *
It became scattered or dispersed; or much scattered or dispersed. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (talk, or speech,) became much disseminated or scattered or diffused. (Msb.)

ba*orN * (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ bu*orN, (M,) the former either an inf. n. used as a proper subst. or of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Msb,) Grain that is set apart for sowing; (Lth, M, K;) any seed, or grain that is sown; as also bizorN or bazorN: (Kh, Msb:) or grain such as wheat, that is sown; distinguished from bzr, which is applied to the seed of sweet-smelling plants and of leguminous herbs: and this distinction commonly obtains: (Msb:) or [so accord. to the M, but in the K “and,”] the first that comes forth, of seed-produce and of leguminous and other plants, (M, K, *) as long as it has but two leaves: (M:) or ba*orN signifies any plant, or herbage, when just come forth from the earth: (M:) or such as has assumed a colour, (M, K,) or shown its kind or species: (M:) pl. bu*uwrN and bi*aArN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ba*orN signifies also (tropical:) Progeny; (T, M, K;) and so ↓ bu*aArapN. (M, K.) One says, A^in~a h`w^ulaA='i laba*oru sawo'K (tropical:) Verily these are a progeny of evil, or an evil progeny. (T, A. *)
bu*orN * : see ba*orN.

tafar~aquwA $a*ara ba*ara * and ↓ $i*ara bi*ara They dispersed, or became dispersed, in every direction: (S, M, K:) [namely, men: and] the like is said of a man's camels: (S:) b*r is an imitative sequent to $*r: (S:) some say that the b in the former is a substitute for m [in ma*ara or mi*ara]; but others hold that in each case the word is an original. (TA.)

ba*irN * : see tibo*aArapN. ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) and ↓ bayo*aArN and ↓ bayo*aArap and ↓ tibo*aArN and ↓ bayo*aAraAniy~N, (K,) (tropical:) A man who talks much; loquacious; (M, K;) and so ↓ hu*arapN bu*arapN (IDrd, M) and ↓ hayo*aArapN bayo*aArapN: (M:) irrationally, or vainly, or frivolously, loquacious; a great babbler. (TA.) ― -b3- See also ba*uwrN. ― -b4- TaEaAmN ba*irN [Wheat, or food,] in which is bu*aArap, i. e. increase, redundance, exuberance, plenty, or abundance. (T, * M, L, K. *)
$i*ara bi*ara * : see $a*ara ba*ara, above.
hu*arapN bu*arapN * : see ba*irN.

Albu*ur~aY *
What is false, vain, or ineffectual; syn. AlbaATilu: (Seer, M, L, K:) [like AlHu*ur~aY:] the radical idea denoted by it is that of dispersion. (M, L.)

ba*uwrN * (S, M, A, K) and ↓ ba*iyrN (M, K) (tropical:) A man who divulges secrets; (S, M, A;) as also ↓ ba*irN, of which the fem. is with p: (L:) or one who cannot keep his secret: (T, K:) pl. of the first bu*urN. (T, S, M.) ― -b2- Also, both the first and second, (tropical:) A calumniator; a slanderer: (K, TA:) pl. of the former as above. (TA.)

ba*iyrN * is [said to be] an imitative sequent to kaviyrN; (M, K;) like baviyrN, of which it is [held to be] a dial. var., or a corruption occasioned by mispronunciation. (Fr, S.) [But I think it is more probably syn. with ↓ mabo*uwrN, as signifying Scattered, or dispersed, like naviyrN in the sense of manovuwrN, &c.; and that for this reason it is used as a corroborative of kvyr.] -A2- See also ba*uwrN.
ba*aArapN * : see ba*aAr~apN.

bu*aArapN *
Increase, redundance, exuberance, plenty, or abundance, in wheat, or food. (Lh, * T, * M, L, K. *) You say, TaEaAmN kaviyru Albu*aArapi Wheat, or food, in which is much increase, &c. (T, TA.) ― -b2- See also ba*orN.

ba*aAr~apN * , and sometimes ↓ ba*aArapN, (Lh, M, K,) and ↓ yabo*arapN, (AA,) and ↓ nabo*arapN, with n, (T, K,) i. q. tabo*iyrN, (M, K,) The dissipating, or squandering, of wealth, or property, in a way that is not right. (T, TA.)
bayo*arapN * : see what next precedes.
bayo*araAniY~N * : see ba*irN.
bay*aArN * : see ba*irN.
bayo*aArapN * : see tibo*aArapN: ― -b2- and see also ba*irN, in two places.
tibo*aArN * : see ba*irN.

tibo*aArapN * A man who dissipates, or squanders, his wealth, or property, by extravagant expenditure, and consumes, destroys, wastes, or ruins, it; (AZ, S, M, K;) as also ↓ muba*~irN and ↓ mubaA*irN and ↓ b*irN and ↓ bayo*aArapN. (TA.)
muba*~irN * : see what next precedes.
A^aroDN mibo*aArN Aln~abaAti * [or more probably mibo*aArN liln~abaAti] (tropical:) Land that yields increase. (A.)
mabo*uwrN * : see ba*iyrN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Many; much; abundant: (K, TA:) water that is abundant; or blessed with abundance, plenty, or increase. (A.)
mubaA*irN * : see tibo*ArapN.
nabo*arapN * : see ba*aAr~apN.
ba*oqN * : see bayo*aqN, in two places.

baA*aqN * (Mgh, K) and ↓ baA*iqN (K) [in my copy of the Msb erroneously written bA*yq] a Persian word, arabicized; originally baAdaho, which signifies Wine: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or juice of grapes cooked in the least degree, so as to be strong (Mgh, Msb, K) and intoxicating; an arabicized word; (Msb;) said to have been introduced by the Benoo-Umeiyeh, (TA,) and to have been unknown to the Prophet; (Mgh;) but there is a trad. of I' Ab which is understood to mean that the Prophet forbade what is thus called: (Mgh, TA:) some assert it to mean that it existed not in his time; (TA;) but this latter assertion is weak. (Mgh.)
baA*iqN * : see above. -A2- It is also an imitative sequent to HaA*iqN. (K.)

bayo*aqN * [meaning A pawn] in the game of chess is from ↓ bayaA*aqapN; (TA;) which latter signifies footmen, as opposed to horsemen, (AO, K, TA,) and is an arabicized word, from the Persian, (AO, TA,) originally PiyaAdaho: (TA:) the pl. of by*q is bayaA*iqu; for which a poet uses bu*uwqN, as though he suppressed the Y [in the sing.], making by*q to become ↓ ba*oqN: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) or, accord. to El-Khárzenjee, (JK, TA,) ↓ ba*oqN signifies a guide in a journey; as also bayo*aqN: (JK, K, TA:) or [in the CK “and”] small and light or active: (K, TA:) or, as in the Tekmileh, (TA,) short and light or active: (JK, TA:) and its pl. is bu*uwqo. (JK, K.)
bayaA*iqapN * : see bayo*aqN.

1 ba*alahu * , aor.
ba*ula (S, M, * Msb, K) and
ba*ila , (M, K,) inf. n. ba*olN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He gave it, and was liberal, or bountiful, with it; he gave it liberally, bountifully, unsparingly, or freely; (S, Msb, K, TA;) he gave it willingly, of his own free will or good pleasure: (TA:) and he made it allowable, or lawful, to be taken or possessed or done, willingly, or of his own free will or good pleasure: (Msb:) ba*olN is the contr. of manoEN. (M.) [Hence,] saA^alotuhu faA^aEoTaAniY ba*ola yamiynihi I asked him, and he gave me what he was able to give. (TA.) [And ba*ala lahu nafosahu. (assumed tropical:) He gave up himself to, or spent himself for, him or it; he gave, or applied, himself, or his mind, unsparingly to it, namely, an undertaking &c.: a phrase of frequent occurrence. And ba*ala jahodahu, and majohuwdahu, (assumed tropical:) He exerted, or put forth, or expended, unsparingly, or freely, his power, or ability, or his utmost power or ability or endeavour: also of frequent occurrence.] And farasN lahu SawonN wa ba*olN (tropical:) A horse that reserves a portion of his run, and is unsparing with a portion thereof; not putting forth the whole at once: (TA:) or that has a run which he reserves [for the time of need], and a run which he performs unsparingly: (A in art. $hd: see $aAhidN:) and ↓ farasN *uw SawonK waA@boti*aAlK a horse that has a running pace (HuDorN) which he has reserved for the time of need, and a run (EadowN) less quick which he has performed freely, or without reservation (qadi A@bota*alahu). (T.) [In the K these phrases are given in a mutilated state, and with a mutilated explanation.]) And Sawonuhu xayorN mino ba*olihi (tropical:) His interior state, or disposition of mind, is better than his apparent state &c. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8.

5 tb*~l *
He neglected the preserving of himself or his honour or reputation [from disgrace]; i. q. taraka Alt~aSaAwuna (S) or Alt~aSaw~una; (TA;) he was careless of himself or his honour or reputation; contr. of taSaAwana; (Msb in the present art,;) as also ↓ Abt*l. (Msb in art. Swn.) You say, karuma wa lamo yataba*~alo [He was generous, and was not careless of his honour or reputation]. (M and L in art. wfr.) ― -b2- tb*~l fiY Eamali ka*aA, and nafosahu fiyhi ↓ Abt*l and bihi, He employed his own self in the doing of such a thing. (T.)

8 Aiboti*aAlN * is the contr. of SiyaAnapN; (M, K;) [i. e.] Abt*lhu signifies He held it in mean estimation; namely, a garment or other thing; (TA;) [he was careless of it; he used it, or employed it, on, or for, ordinary, mean, or vile, occasions, or purposes;] he used it for service and work; namely, a garment &c.; syn. Aimotahanahu; (S, Msb;) he wore it (a garment) in times of service and work; as also ↓ ba*alahu; (Msb, TA;) or, as IKoot says, ba*alahu, [aor.
ba*ula and
ba*ila ,] inf. n. ba*olapN and bi*olapN, signifies he did not preserve it, lay it up, take care of it, or reserve it; namely, a garment. (Msb.) See also 5, in two places. You say also, Abt*l Eadowahu (assumed tropical:) [He (a horse) performed his run freely, or without reservation; opposed to SaAnahu]. (T.) See 1.

10 Astb*lhu *
He sought, or demanded, of him a liberal, free, or willing, gift. (TA.) And Aisotabo*alotu fulaAnFA $ayoy^FA I asked of such a one that he would liberally, freely, or willingly, give me a thing. (T.)

ba*olN *
A thing that is given liberally, freely, or willingly: and inf. n. [or 1, q. v.], used as a proper subst.: pl. bu*uwlN. (Har p. 206.)
ba*olapN * : see what next follows, in two places.

bi*olapN *
A garment that is worn (T, S, Msb) in service, or work; (S, Msb;) that is not preserved, laid up, taken care of, or reserved; (T, M, K;) as also ↓ ba*olapN (Msb) and ↓ mbo*alN, (T,) or ↓ mibo*alapN, (S, M, K,) the pl. of which is mabaA*ilN: (S:) and an old and worn-out garment; (TA;) as also ↓ mibo*alN and ↓ mibo*alapN; (M, K;) the last of which is mentioned on the authority of AZ, but is disapproved by 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, who asserts it to be without p: (IB, TA:) bi*olapN sometimes has bi*alN as pl. (TA.) You say, ↓ jaA='a naA fulaAnN fiY mabaA*ilih, i. e. fiY viyaAbi bi*olatihi or ↓ ba*olatihi [Such a one came to us in his garments that he wore in service, or work]. (S, accord. to different copies. [I have shown that bi*olapN and ba*olapN are dial. vars., both as inf. ns. (see 8) and as proper substs.]) The word badolapN, with fet-h, and with the unpointed d, applied by the vulgar to [a suit of] new clothes, is a mistake for bi*olapN, and this is correctly a name for old and worn-out clothes. (TA. [But this is doubtful; for badolapN commonly signifies, in modern Arabic, a change of clothes; and hence, a suit of clothes, whether new or old.]) ― -b2- IJ uses it metaphorically, in relation to poetry; saying, Alr~ajazu A_in~amaA yusotaEaAnu bihi fiY Albi*olapi wa Einoda AlAiEotimaAli wa AlHudaA='i wa Almihonapi (tropical:) [The metre termed rejez is only used as an aid in the ordinary, or meaner, business of life, and on the occasion of doing one's work, and singing to camels for the purpose of urging them on, and performing service of any kind: but in this case it may be regarded as an inf. n.: see 8]. (M.)
ba*uwlN * : see ba*~aAlN.

ba*aAlapN *
i. q. ba*olN [inf. n. of 1, The act of giving liberally, &c.]. (TA.)

ba*~aAlN * A man wont to give property liberally, freely, or willingly; or who so gives it much, or frequently; as also ↓ ba*uwlN (T, TA) [and app. ↓ mibo*aAlN, (like misomaAHN &c.,) of which the pl. occurs in the following saying]. ↓ humo mabaA*iylu lilomaEoruwfi [They are very liberally disposed to the exercise of beneficence, or bounty]. (TA.)
baA*ilN * Any one who gives [liberally,] freely, or willingly. (M.)
mibo*ilN * : see bi*olapN, in two places.
mibo*alapN * ; and its pl. mabaA*ilu: see bi*olapN, in three places.
mibo*aAlN * ; pl. mabaA*iylu: see ba*~aAlN.

mubota*alN *
Held in mean estimation: as in the saying, maAluhu maSuwnN wa EiroDuhu mubota*alN [His wealth is preserved, or taken care of, and his honour, or reputation, is held in mean estimation]. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Language, and a proverb, which one is wont to speak or mention, or which one is fond of speaking or mentioning. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN Sadoqu Almubota*ali Such a one is strong, or sturdy, in the work in which he employs himself: (T:) or sharp, vigorous, or effective, in nature, or disposition; one who, when employed in a work, is found to be strong, or sturdy. (TA.) And sayofN Sadoqu Almubota*ali (tropical:) A sword sharp, or penetrating, in the part with which one strikes. (K, TA.)

mubota*ilN * , (K,) or ↓ mutaba*~ilN, (M, [so in a copy of that work, accord. to the TT, but this is probably a mistranscription,]) Wearing a mibo*al, i. e. [a garment used in service or work, or] an old and worn-out garment: (M, K:) and the latter, [if not a mistranscription for the former,] neglecting the adorning of himself, by way of humility. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- See also what follows.
mutaba*~ilN * (T, M, K) and ↓ mubota*ilN (M, K) A man who employs his own self in doing a thing; (T;) a man who performs his own work. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also what next precedes.

1 ba*uwa * , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yabo*uw, (T, S,) inf. n. ba*aA='N (S, M, Msb, K) and ba*aA='apN, (K,) or the latter is the original form, but the p is elided, as in jamaAlN, inf. n. of jamula, (S,) or ba*aA='apN is an inf. n. of the verb with ', but that of b*w is ba*aA='N; (IB;) and some say, ba*iYa, (T,) which is a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) aor. yabo*aY, inf. n. ba*aA='N; (T in art. b*A^;) He (a man) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or obscene [in tongue]; (T, S, M, K;) evil in speech; (T in art. b*A^;) as also ba*uw^a, (T, M, K, in that art.,) and ba*aA^a, (Msb and K in art. b*A^,) and ba*iy^a: (K in that art.:) and ↓ Ab*Y he uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (TA.) And ba*awotu EalaY Alqawomi, (S, M, Msb, * K,) aor.
ba*uwa , inf. n. ba*aA='N; (Msb;) and ↓ A^abo*ayotu Ealayohimo, (S, Msb, *) or A^abo*ayotuhumo, (M, IB, K,) or both, (TA,) I uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against the people, or company of men: (S, M, K, TA:) or behaved in a lightwitted, weak, stupid, or foolish, manner, or ignorantly, towards them; and uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against them; and so though with truth. (Msb.) And ba*aA also signifies He (a man) was, or became, evil in disposition. (TA.)

3 bA*y * , (S, TA,) inf. n. mubaA*aApN, (TA,) [He vied with another, or strove to surpass him, in foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language: or he held such discourse with another:] the inf. n. is syn. with mufaAHa$apN. (TA.)
4 A^abo*awa see 1, in two places.
ba*aA='N * [inf. n. of 1, used as a subst,] Foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. (S, M, K.)

ba*iYN * , (T, M, Msb, K,) or ba*iYN All~isaAni, (S,) A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue: (T, S, M, * K: *) or lightwitted, weak, stupid, or ignorant, in behaviour; and foul, unseemly, or obscene, in speech; and so though speaking truth: (Msb:) fem. with p: (S, Msb:) and pl. A^abo*iyaA='u. (T.)

1 bar~a br , [first pers. barirotu,] aor. yabar~u, (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. bir~N, (M, Msb, K,) He was pious [towards his father or parents, and (tropical:) towards God; (see the explanations of the verb as used transitively;) and was kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and kind, or good, in his dealings with strangers]: (Msb:) he was good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (T, Msb:) [or he was amply, largely, or extensively, good or beneficent:] and he was true, or veracious. (M, Msb, K.) [Authorities differ as to the primary signification of this verb, and as to the subordinate meanings: see bir~N below.] You say also, bar~a fiY qawolihi, (Msb, TA,) and fiY yamiynihi, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) first pers. barirotu (T, A, Mgh, K) and bararotu, (K,) aor. yabar~u (M, Msb) and yabir~N, (M,) inf. n. bir~N (S, M, K) and bar~N, (K,) or buruwrN, (Msb,) He was true, or veracious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) in his saying, (Msb, TA,) and in his oath. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- bar~a Eamalahu, and bur~a, inf. n. bir~N and buruwrN; and ↓ A^abar~a; [His deed, or work, was, or proved, good; or was well, or sinlessly, performed;] all signify the same. (M.) And bur~a AlEamalu, i. e. AlHaj~u, a form of benediction, said to a person come from pilgrimage, May the deed, or work, i. e. the pilgrimage, have been sinlessly performed. (TA.) And bar~a Haj~uhu, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yabar~u, (T,) inf. n. bir~N (S, Msb,) or buruwrN; (T;) and bur~a Haj~uhu, (Fr, T, S, M, K,) aor. yubar~u, inf. n. bir~N; (T;) His pilgrimage was sinlessly performed: (Sh, T:) or was characterized by the giving of food, and by sweetness of speech; as explained by Mohammad himself: was accepted: was rewarded. (TA.) ― -b3- bar~a, (A, Msb, K,) aor. yabar~u (T, M, K) and yabir~u, (M, K,) inf. n. bir~N (M, Msb, K) and bar~N and buruwrN, (M, K,) It (a saying, Msb, and an oath, T, A, M, Msb, K) was, or proved, true. (M, A, * Msb, * K, * TA.) [See an ex. voce A^aliy~apN, in art. Alw.] ― -b4- bar~ato biY siloEatuhu, inf. n. bir~N, (tropical:) His commodity, or article of merchandise, was easy of sale to me, (Aboo-Sa'eed, T, A, *) and procured me gain: (A:) originally meaning it recompensed me, by its high price, for my care of it. (T.) [See also bar~ahu, below.] -A2- bar~a waAlidahu, (M,) [and app. biwaAlidihi, (see bar~N,)] first pers. barirotu (S, M, Msb, K) and bararotu, (M, K,) aor. yabar~u (S, M, Msb, K) and yabir~u, (M, K,) inf. n. bir~N (S, M, Msb, K) and mabar~apN (S, K, Msb *) and buruwrN, (Msb,) He treated, or behaved towards, his father with filial piety, duty, or obedience; (TA;) or with ample obedience; (B;) the inf. ns. signifying the contr. of EuquwqN: (S, M, A, K:) he treated, or behaved towards, his father with good obedience, and with gentleness, or courtesy, striving to do the things that were pleasing to him, and to avoid what were displeasing to him. (Msb.) And [hence, app., for accord. to the A it is tropical.] bar~a xaAliqahu, (S,) or rab~ahu, (A,) aor. yabar~u, (S, A,) inf. n. bir~N; (T, S, M, K;) and ↓ tbr~rhu; (S, K; *) (tropical:) He obeyed his Creator, or his Lord; (S, M, * A, K; *) [was pious towards Him;] served Him; rendered religious service to Him: (TA:) or rendered Him ample obedience: the obedience here meant is of two kinds; namely, that of belief and that of works; and both these kinds are meant by Albir~ in the Kur ii. 172. (B.) [And app. bar~ato waladahaA, or biwaladihaA, She behaved with maternal affection towards her child, or offspring. (See bar~N.)] And bar~ahu, (M,) and bar~a raHimahu, (T,) first pers. barirotu, (T, M,) inf. n. bir~N, (T, M, K,) He behaved towards him, and towards his kindred, or relations, with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his, or their, circumstances; syn. waSalahu [and waSalahumo]: (T, M, K:) such is said to be the signification of the verb as use in the Kur lx. 8. (M, B, TA. [See also 3.]) And Aall~`hu yabar~u EibaAdahu (assumed tropical:) God is merciful to his servants: (M, TA:) or bar~ahu, inf. n. bir~N, said of God, means He recompensed him, or rewarded him, for his obedience. (B, TA.) [bar~ahu bika*aA (occurring in the S and K in explanation of A^aloTafahu bika*aA) may be rendered He showed kindness, &c., to him by such a thing, or such an action, &c.: and also he presented him with such a thing; like waSalahu bika*aA.] ― -b2- bar~a A@ll~`hu Haj~ahu, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yabar~u, (Msb,) inf. n. bir~N, (S,) or buruwrN, (Msb,) God accepted his pilgrimage; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ Abr~hu: (T, S, M, Msb:) the latter alone is allowed by Fr: (M, TA:) [though bur~a Haj~uhu and Eamaluhu, mentioned above, are well known; as is the pass. part. n. maboruwrN, which see below:] and one says, [in like manner,] A@ll~`hu Eamaluhu ↓ Abr~ [God accepted his deed, or work, as good; approved it]. (M.) ― -b3- See also 4, in three places. -A3- bar~a, (TK,) inf. n. bir~N, (S, K,) He drove sheep or goats: (IAar, S, K:) or he called them. (Yoo.) [See also bir~N below.]

3 bAr~hu bAr bArh bArp b|rh |r , inf. n. mubaAr~apN, He behaved towards him with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances; or he did so, experiencing from him the same behaviour; syn. of the inf. n. mulaATafapN. (S and K in art. lTf: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned. [See also 1.])

4 Abr~ Eamaluhu Abr Emlh Abr Emlp : see 1. -A2- Abr~ Haj~ahu, and Eamalahu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- Abr~ Alqawola,
(Msb,) and Alyamiyna, (T, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He executed, or performed, the saying, and the oath, truly. (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) Accord. to El-Ahmar, one also says, qasamiY ↓ barirotu; but none other asserts this. (T, TA.) ― -b3- AbrA@ll~`hu qasamahu, (T, TA,) inf. n. A_iboraArN; and ↓ bar~ahu, inf. n. bir~N; God verified his oath. (TA.) ― -b4- Abr~ fulaAnN qasama fulaAnK Such a one assented, or consented, to the conjurement of such a one: A^aHonavuhu signifies “ he assented not, ” or “ consented not, thereto. ” (T, TA.) -A3- Abr~ Ealayohimo, (S, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (T, TA,) He overcame them: (T, S, M, K:) he subdued them, or overcame them, by good or other actions; (TA;) by actions or sayings; (TA;) as also ↓ bar~ahumo, aor. yabur~u: (T, K, TA:) he was refractory, or stubborn, and overcame them. (TA, from a trad.) You say, Abr~ EalaY xaSomihi [He overcame his adversary]. (A.) And Abr~ Ealayohimo $ar~FA [He overcame them in evil]: and hence Abr~ is used in the sense of fajara [he transgressed, &c.]; as in the saying of a poet,
falasotu A^ubaAliY mano A^abar~a wa mano fajaro
[Then I care not who acts wickedly and who transgresses]. (IAar, M.) -A4- Abr~ [from bar~N] He rode, or journeyed, upon the land. (ISk, S, A, K.) Opposed to A^aboHara. (A.)

5 tbr~r A^br br brr tbrr [He affected, or endeavoured to characterize himself by, bir~, i. e. filial piety, &c.]. ― -b2- qado tabar~arota fiY A^amorinaA Thou hast abstained from crime, or sin, or the like, in our affair, or business, or case. (T, TA.) -A2- tbr~r xaAliqahu: see 1.

6 tbAr~wA A^bAr bArY tbArY tbArwA
They practised mutual bir~ [meaning kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for each other's circumstances]. (S.)

R. Q. 1 barobara brbr brbry , inf. n. barobarapN, He talked much, and raised a clamour, or confused noise, (M, K,) with his tongue: (M:) he cried, or cried out, (S, K,) and talked in anger, (S,) or talked confusedly, with anger and aversion. (TA.) And barobara fiY kalaAmihi He was profuse and unprofitable in his talk. (Fr.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He (a goat) uttered a cry or cries, [or rattled,] (M, K,) being excited by desire of the female. (M.)

bar~N br [originally barirN] (M, Msb, K) and ↓ baAr~N (Msb) Pious [towards his father or parents, and (tropical:) towards God; (tropical:) obedient to God, serving God, or rendering religious service to God; (see 1;) and kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and good in his dealings with strangers]; good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (Msb:) true, or veracious: (M, Msb, K:) and both signify also abounding in bir~ [or filial piety, &c.]: (K:) the former is [said to be] a stronger epithet than the latter, like as EadolN is stronger than EaAdilN: (B:) [but its pl. shows that it is not, like EadolN, originally an inf. n.: it is a regular contraction of barirN, like as baAr~N is of baArirN:] the fem. of each is with p: (Lh, M:) the pl. (of the former, S, M, Msb, or of the latter, B) is A^aboraAN; and (of the latter, S, M, Msb, or of the former, B) bararapN: (S, M, Msb, K:) the former pl. is often specially applied to saints, those who abstain from worldly pleasures, and devotees; and the latter, to the recording angels. (B.) You say, A^anaA bar~N biwaAlidiY, and ↓ baAr~N, I am characterized by filial piety, dutifulness, or obedience, to my father: (S, M, A: *) the latter is mentioned on the authority of Kr; but some disallow it. (M, TA.) And AlA^um~u bar~apN biwaladihaA [The mother is maternally affectionate to her child, or offspring]. (S.) And rajulN bar~N bi*iY qaraAbatihi, and ↓ baAr~N, A man who behaves towards his kindred with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for their circumstances. (T.) And rajulN bar~N sar~N A man who treats with goodness and affection and gentleness, and rejoices, or gladdens, his brethren: pl. bar~uwna sar~uwna. (S, * K, * TA, in art. sr.) And bar~N fiY qawolK, and fiY yamiynK, and ↓ baAr~N, True, or veracious, in a saying, and in an oath. (Msb.) And yamiynN bar~apN and ↓ baAr~apN [A true oath; or an oath that proves true]. (Ham p. 811.) Albar~u is also a name of God; (M, K;) meaning (assumed tropical:) The Merciful, or Compassionate: (M:) or the Very Benign to his servants; (IAth;) the Ample in goodness or beneficence: (B:) AlbaAr~u is not so used. (IAth.) It is said in a trad., tamas~aHuwA biAlA^aroDi faA_in~ahaA bar~apN bikumo (assumed tropical:) Wipe yourselves with the dust, or earth, [in performing the ceremony termed Alt~ayam~umu,] for it is benignant towards you, like as the mother is to her children; meaning, ye are created from it, and in it are your means of subsistence, and to it ye return after death: (IAth:) or the meaning is, that your tents, or houses, are upon it, and ye are buried in it. (M.) -A2- bar~N Land; opposed to baHorN [as meaning “ sea ” and the like]: (S, Msb, K:) from bir~N signifying “ ampleness, ” “ largeness, ” or “ extensiveness; ” (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF;) or the former word is the original of the latter. (B, TA. [See the latter word.]) [Hence, bar~FA wa baHorFA By land and by sea.] ― -b2- A desert, or deserts; a waste, or wastes. (T, TA. [See also bar~iy~apN, voce bar~iy~N.]) So, accord. to Mujáhid [and the Jel] in words of the Kur [vi. 59], wa yaEolamu maA fiY Albar~i wa AlbaHori And He knoweth what is in the desert, or deserts, and the towns, or villages, in which is water, (T, TA,) or which are upon the rivers. (Jel.) [So too in the phrase nabaAtu Albar~i The plants, or herbage, of the desert or waste; the wild plants or herbage. And Easalu Albar~i Honey of the desert; wild honey. And HayawaAnu Albar~i The animal, or animals, of the desert; the wild animal or animals.] ― -b3- A wide tract of land. (Bd in ii. 41.) ― -b4- [The open country; opposed to baHorN as meaning the “ cities, ” or “ towns, ” “ upon the rivers: ” see the latter word.] ― -b5- Elevated ground, open to view. (T.) ― -b6- The tract, or part, out of doors, or where one is exposed to view; contr. of kin~N: used by the Arabs indeterminately; [without the article Al;] as in the phrase, jalasotu bar~FA (Lth, T) meaning I sat outside the house; (A;) and xarajotu bar~FA (Lth, T) meaning I went forth outside the [house or] town, (A,) or into the desert: (TA:) but [Az says,] these are post-classical phrases, which I have not heard from the chaste-speaking Arabs of the desert. (T.) ― -b7- You say also, A^ariydu jaw~FA wa yuriydu bar~FA I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A.)

bur~N br
Wheat; and the grain of wheat; syn. qamoHN, (S, * Msb,) or HinoTapN; (M, K;) but it is a more chaste word than qamoHN and HinoTapN: (M:) pl. of bur~apN; (S, M;) or [rather] bur~apN is the n. un. [signifying a grain of wheat, like qamoHapN]: (IDrd, Msb:) the pl. of bur~N is A^aboraArN; (K;) or this pl. is allowable on the ground of analogy, accord. to Mbr, but is disallowed by Sb. (S.) It is said in a prov., (TA,) huwa A^aqoSaru mino br~apK [He, or it, is shorter than a grain of wheat]. (A, TA.) And you say, A^aToEmanaA A@bona bur~apK He fed us with bread. (A.)

bir~N br inf. n. of 1: (T, S, M, &c.:) it is said by some to signify primarily Ampleness, largeness, or extensiveness; whence bar~N as opposed to baHorN: then, ― -b2- Benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct [to parents and others; i. e. piety to parents; and (tropical:) towards God]: and goodness, or beneficence: and kindness, or good and affectionate and gentle behaviour, and regard for the circumstances of another: (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF:) or bar~N, as opposed to baHorN, [or as signifying “ a wide tract of land, ” (Bd in ii. 41,)] is the original of bir~N, (Bd in ii. 41, B, TA,) which signifies ample, large, or extensive, goodness or beneficence, (Z, in the Ksh, ii. 41, [but he regards it as the original of bar~N,] and Bd on the same passage, and B, K, TA,) to men; (TA;) or comprehending every kind of goodness: (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà:) and hence it is said to be in three things: in the service of God: in paying regard to relations; acting well to them: and in dealing with strangers: (Bd ubi suprà:) or every deed that is approved: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 172:) and [particularly] obedience to God: (T, S, M, &c.: [see also bar~apu:]) [and every incumbent duty: and hence,] the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (K:) and fidelity to an engagement: (TA:) also a gratuitous gift, or favour; and a bounty, or benefit; syn. faDolN; (Msb;) and A_iHosaAnN; as also ↓ mabar~apN [an inf. n., but when used as a simple subst. its pl. is mabaArN and mabar~aAtN]. (Har p. 94.) In the Kur [ii. 172], where it is said, lukin~a Albir~a mano A=mana biAA@ll~`hi, by Albr~ is meant *aA Albir~i [i. e. But the pious, or obedient to God, is he who believeth in God]; (T, M, Ksh, Bd, Jel;) and some read AlbaAr~a: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) or the meaning is, lkn~ Albir~a bir~u mn A=mn bA ll~`h i. e. but the obedience of which it behooveth one to be mindful is the obedience of him who believeth in God: (Sb, T, IJ, M, Ksh, Bd:) and this explanation is preferable to the former. (Bd.) It is said in a prov., (T, S,) laA yaEorifu hir~FA mino birK, (S, A, K, but in the T and M maA is put in the place of lA,) meaning He knows not him who dislikes him, or hates him, from him who behaves
towards him with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances: (S, M, A, K, * TA:) or undutiful conduct to a parent from gentleness, or courtesy: (ElFezáree, T, K:) or altercation, (T,) or dislike, or hatred, (K,) from honourable treatment: (T, K:) or the calling of sheep, or goats, from the driving of them: (IAar, S, K:) or the driving of sheep, or goats, from the calling of them: (Yoo, T:) or the calling of them to water from the calling of them to fodder; (K;) which last rendering is agreeable with an explanation of bir~N by IAar [mentioned in the T]; (TA;) and ↓ birobirN, also, has the signification here assigned to bir~N: (K, * TA:) or Alharoharap from Albarobarap; (A'Obeyd, T, K;) i. e. the crying of sheep from the crying of goats: (A'Obeyd, T:) or the cat from the rat, or mouse: (IAar, T, M, K:) and bir~N also signifies the [species of rat called] jura*: (Aboo-Tálib, T, K:) or a small animal resembling the rat or mouse: (M:) and the young of the fox. (K.) ― -b3- Also Good, as a subst., not an adj.; syn. xayorN; (Sh, T, Mgh, Msb, K;) which comprises all that has been said in explanation of bir~N (Sh, T, Mgh) as used in the saying of Mohammad, Ealyokumo biAlS~idoqi faA_in~ahu yahodiY A_ilaY Albir~i [Keep ye to truth; for it guides to good, or to a good, or right, state]: some render it in this instance by Alxayor; and some, by AlS~alaAH. (Sh, T.) It signifies also The good of the present life, consisting in spiritual and worldly blessings, and of that which is to come, consisting in everlasting enjoyment in Paradise: so in the Kur iii. 86: (T:) or [simply] Paradise. (K.) ― -b4- Also The heart; or the mind. (K.) So in the saying, huwa muTomay^in~u Albir~i [He is quiet, or at rest, in heart, or mind]. (TA.)

bar~apu br brh brp a subst. in the sense of Albir~u, (S, M, K,) meaning Obedience [&c.]; (K;) determinate, (S, K,) being a proper name; for which reason, combined with its being of the fem. gender, it is imperfectly decl. (M.) [It is opposed to fajaAri. See a verse of En-Nábighah in the first paragraph of art. Hml.]

bariyrN bryr [a coll. gen. n.] The fruit of the A^araAk [q. v.], (S, M,) in a general sense: (M:) or the first thereof; (K;) [i. e.] the first that appears, or when it first appears, and is sweet: (M:) or when it has become hard: (Msb:) or when it is larger in its berries (Hab~) than such as is termed kabaAv, and smaller in its clusters; having a round, small, hard stone, a little larger than the Him~aS; its cluster filling the hand: (AHn, M:) n. un. with p. (AHn, S, M, Msb.)

bur~aY br brY bry ry
A good, sweet, or pleasant, word or expression or saying: (K:) from bir~N signifying “ benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct. ” (TA.)

[
bar~iY~N br brY bry ry
Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the land as opposed to the sea or a great river. ― -b2- And Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the desert or waste; growing, or living, or produced, in the desert or waste; wild, or in an uncultivated state. ― -b3- And hence,] A^aroDN bar~iy~apN Uncultivated land; without seed-produce, and unfruitful; without green herbs or leguminous plants and without waters; contr. of riyfiy~apN. (IAar, M, K. *) And, simply, ↓ bar~ay~apN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ bar~iytN, (A'Obeyd, IAar, Sh, S, K,) the latter a variation of the former, the Y being made quiescent, and the p therefore being changed into t, as in EiforiytN, originally EiforiyapN, (S,) a rel. n. from bar~N, (Sh, T, Msb,) A desert; a waste; a spacious tract of ground without herbage; syn. SaHoraA='u: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) [see also bar~N:] or a tract nearer to the desert (Albar~) than it is to water: (Sh, T:) [but some write the latter word ↓ bir~iytN; and it is said that] bir~iytu, (T and K in art. brt,) of the same measure as sik~iytN, (K in that art.,) signifies flat, even, or level, land: (T, K:) or a barren, flat, even, or level, land: a poet says,
bir~iytu A^aroDK baEodahaA bir~iytu
[A barren, flat land, after which is a second barren, flat land]: (T:) ISd says that bir~iytN, in a poem of Ru-beh, [from which the ex. given above is probably taken,] is of the measure fiEoliytN from Albar~u; and that art. brt is not the place in which it should be mentioned: (TA:) Lth says, Albar~iytu is a noun derived from Albar~iy~apu; the Y becoming quiescent, and the p becoming an inseparable t, as though it were a radical letter, as in the case of EiforiyapN, which thus becomes EiforiytN: (T, TA:) the pl. of br~y~p is baraAriY~u; and that of br~yt is baraAriytu. (S.)
bar~iy~apN bry bryh bryp ry ry^p and bar~iytN and bir~iytN: see bar~iY~N.
bar~aArN brAr as signifying A possessor of bur~, i. e. wheat, though agreeable with prevailing analogy, is not allowable, not being sanctioned by usage. (Sb, M.)

bar~aAniY~N brAnY brAny brY brnyp
External; or outward: apparent; public. (T.) Hence the saying of Selmán, (T,) mano A^aSolaHa jaw~aAniy~ahu A^aSolaHa A@ll~`hu bar~aAniy~ahu (T, A, K) Whoso maketh his inner man (sariyratahu) to be good, God will make his outward man (EalaAniyatahu) to be good. (T.) bar~aAniY~N is a rel. n., irregularly formed, (K,) from bar~N signifying “ elevated ground, open to view; ” and jaw~aAniY~N, from jaw~N signifying “ any low, or depressed, part of the ground. ” (T.) You say, AfotataHa AlbaAba Albar~aAniY~a He opened the outer door. (A.)

barobaru brbr brbry , (S, K,) or Albarobaru, (Mgh, Msb,) [a coll. gen. proper name, of which the n. un., or rel. n., is ↓ barobariY~N,] a foreign word, (S,) [probably of African origin, the primary form of which is the source of βάρβαρος, &c.,] arabicized; (Msb;) or, as some say, from barobarapN in speech; (TA; [see R. Q. 1;]) and AlbaraAbirapu, (S, M, Msb, K,) the pl. of barobaru, (K,) or of Albarobaru, (Msb,) [or of barobariY~N, agreeably with what follows and with analogy,] the p being added because the sing. is a foreign word, or [so in the M and TA, but in the S “ and, ”] a rel. n., (S, M,) but it may be elided; [so that one may say AlbaraAbiru;] (S;) A certain people, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the inhabitants of El-Maghrib [or Northern Africa west of Egypt], (Mgh, * Msb, K, *) like the Arabs of the desert in hardness, and coarseness, or rudeness, (Mgh, * Msb,) and in slightness of religion, and littleness of knowledge: (Mgh:) and another people, [the Colobi mentioned by Diodorus Siculus and Strabo,] between the Abyssinians and the Zinj, who amputate [the glans of] the penis, and make it a dowry for a wife. (K.) [There are various opinions of the origins of these races. The appellation of AlbaraAbirapu, sing. ↓ barobariY~N, is also applied by late historians, and in the present day, to The races inhabiting the portion of the valley of the Nile which we commonly call Nubia.]
buroburN brbr brbry : see barobaArN.
birobirN brbr brbry : see bir~N.
barobariY~N brbrY brbry : see barobaArN: ― -b2- and see also barobaru, in two places.

barobaArN brbAr One who talks much, and raises a clamour, or confused noise, (M, K,) with his tongue: (M:) who cries, or cries out, (S, K,) and talks in anger, (S,) or talks confusedly, with anger and aversion: (TA:) who vociferates much; (TA;) as also ↓ buroburN: (K:) and ↓ barobariY~N signifies one who talks much and unprofitably. (Fr.) ― -b2- AlbarobaAru The lion; as also ↓ Almubarobiru: (K:) because of the confused noise that he makes, and his aversion and anger. (TA.) ― -b3- dalowN barobaArN A bucket that makes a noise (M, K) in the water. (M.)

burobuwrN brbwr
What is termed ja$iy$ [i. e. coarselyground flour, &c.], (M, CK, [in MS. copies of the K, and of the S also, Ha$iy$, which is evidently a mistranscription,]) of wheat. (S, M, K.)
baAr~N bAr b|r |r ; fem. with p: see bar~N, in five places.

A^abar~N * [accord. to analogy signifies More, and most, pious &c.: see bar~N. But the only meaning that I find assigned to it in any of the lexicons is that here following. -A2- ] More, and most, distant in the desert, (T, K,) as to habitation. (T.) So in the saying, A^afoSaHu AlEarabi A^abar~uhumo The most chaste in speech of the Arabs are the most distant of them in the desert, as to habitation. (T, K. * [In the latter, instead of AfSH, we find A^aSolaHu.])
mubir~N mbr One who overcomes. (TA.) [See 4.] ― -b2- A_in~ahu lamubir~N bi*`lika means Verily he is a prudent, or sound, manager of that; syn. DaAbiTN lahu. (M, K. *)
mabar~apN mbrh mbrp : see bir~N.

maboruwrN mbrwr , applied to a pilgrimage, Sinlessly performed: (Sh, T, Mgh:) or characterized by the giving of food and by sweetness of speech; as explained by Mohammad himself: accepted: rewarded. (TA.) maboruwrN maA^ojuwrN [Thou art accepted, or approved, and rewarded] and maboruwrFA maA^ojuwrFA [Go thou accepted, or approved, and rewarded] are forms of benediction: the former, of the dial.
of Temeem; A^anota being understood: the latter, of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; Ai*ohabo being understood. (M.) ― -b2- Applied to a sale, Truly and honestly executed. (Sh, T, Mgh.)
Almubarobiru Almbrbr : see barobaArN.

baraAa , inf. n. generally buro'N or baraA='apN,] He was, or became, clear, or free, of, or from, a thing; in the manners which will be explained below: (Bd ii. 51:) he was, or became, in a state of freedom or immunity, secure, or safe. (T.) [Hence,] bariy^a mina AlmaraDi, and baraA^a, (T, Msb,) aor.
baraAa ; and baruw^a, aor.
baruAa ; (Msb;) inf. n. buro'N: (T, Msb:) or bariy^a mn AlmrD, inf. n. buro'N, with damm; and the people of El-Hijáz say baraA^a, inf. n. baro'N, with fet-h: (S:) accord. to As, bariYa mn AlmrD is of the dial. of Temeem; and baraA^a of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz: or, accord. to AZ, the people of El-Hijáz say baraA^a; and the rest of the Arabs say bariy^a: (T:) or baraA^a [alone], said of a sick man, aor.

baraAa ,] inf. n. buro'N and buruw^N: (M:) or baraA^a, (K,) said by IKtt to be the most chaste form, (TA,) aor.

baraAa , inf. n. baro'N and buruw^N, (K, TA,) or buro'N, (CK,) and buruwo'N; (K, TA;) He became free from the disease, sickness, or malady: (T:) or [he recovered from it:] he became convalescent; or sound, or healthy, at the close of disease, but was yet weak; or he recovered, but not completely, his health and strength; syn. niqaha; (M, K;) i. e., he acquired that slight degree of soundness, or health, which comes at the close of disease, but with disease remaining in him. (TA.) [And bariy^a Aljuroju, or baraA^a, The wound healed; or became in a healing state: of frequent occurrence.] And bariy^a mina AlA^amori, [the only form of the verb used in this case, and in the other cases in which it is mentioned below,] aor.
baraAa and
baruAa , the latter extr., (M, K,) or rather it is very strange, for IKoot says that naEima, aor. yanoEumu, and faDila, aor. yafoDulu, are the only instances of this kind, (TA,) inf. n. baraA='apN (M, K) and baraA='N (Lh, M, K) and buruw^N, (M,) or buro'N, (K, TA,) or buruwo'N; (CK;) and ↓ tbr~A^; (S, * M, K, Mgh; *) [He was, or became, free from the thing, or affair; or clear, or quit, thereof; clear of having or taking, or of having had or taken, any part therein; guiltless of it: and also, irresponsible for it; as in an ex. q. v. voce EiDaADN:] said in relation to [a fault or the like, and] a debt, and a claim, and religion [&c.]. (Lh, M.) You say, bariy^a mina AlEayobi, (Mgh, Msb,) or AlEuyuwbi, (S,) inf. n. baraA='apN, (Mgh,) He was, or became, free (Msb) [from the fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice], (Mgh, Msb,) [or faults, &c.]. (S.) And bariy^a mina Ald~ayoni, (T, Mgh, Msb,) or Ald~uyuwni, (S,) aor.
baraAa , (T, Msb,) inf. n. baraA='apN, (T, Mgh, Msb,) He was, or became, clear, or quit, of the debt; (or debts; S;) irresponsible for it [or them]: or in a state of immunity with respect to it [or them]; i. e., exempt from the demand thereof. (Msb.) And bary^a A_ilayoka mino Haq~ika, inf. n. baraA='apN and baraA='N (Lh, M) and buruw^N, [He was, or became, clear, or quit, to thee, of thy claim, or due, or right; or exempt from the demand thereof;] as also ↓ tbr~A^. (M.) And bariy^otu A_ilayoka mino fulaAnK, inf. n. baraA='pN, [I was, or became, or have become, clear, to thee, of having or taking, or of having had or taken, any part with such a one; or, irresponsible to thee for such a one:] (AZ, T, S: * [in one copy of the S, I find the phrase bariy^otu minoka, commencing the art.; but not in other copies:]) this is the only form of the verb used in this case, and in relation to debt [and the like]. (AZ, T.) ― -b2- He removed himself, or kept, far, or aloof, [from unclean things, or things occasioning blame; followed by mino, with which it may be rendered he shunned, or avoided;] syn. tanaz~ahu and tabaAEada. (T.) [You say, bariy^a mina AlA^aqo*aAri He removed himself, or kept, far, or aloof, from unclean things.] ― -b3- He manifested an excuse, [or asserted himself to be clear or quit or irresponsible, like ↓ tbr~A^,] and gave warning; syn. A^aEo*ara and A^ano*ara. (T.) Hence, in the Kur [ix. 1], baraA='apN mina A@ll~`hi warasuwlihi A manifestation of excuse, and a warning, from God and his apostle. (T.) -A2- baraA^a A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa, (Fr, T, S, M, K,) or Alxaliyaqapa, (Msb,) aor.
baraAa , (T, M, &c.,) inf. n. baro'N (T, S, M, K) and buruwo'N, (AZ, Lh, M, K,) God created mankind, or the beings, or things, that are created, syn. xalaqa, (Fr, T, M, Msb, K,) after no similitude, or model, (TA,) [but, properly, though not always meaning so, out of pre-existing matter; for] Bd says [in ii. 51] that the primary meaning of the root br' is to denote a thing's becoming clear, or free, of, or from, another thing; either by being released [therefrom], as in bariy^a AlmariyDu mino maraDihi and Almadoyuwnu mino daynihi [both sufficiently explained above]; or by production [therefrom], as in baraA^a A@ll~`hu A=dama mina AlT~iyni [God produced, or created, Adam, from, or out of, clay]. (TA.) This verb relates to substances [as in the exs. given above] and to accidents; and hence, [in the Kur lvii. 22,] mino qboli A^ano naboraA^ahaA [Before our creating it, if hA refer to muSiybap, preceding it; but, as Bd says, it may refer to this, or to AlA^aroD, or to A^anofus]: (M:) but Albaro'u has a more particular application than Alxaloqu; the former being particularly applied to the creation of animate beings, with few exceptions: you say, baraA^a A@ll~`hu Aln~asamapa wa xalaqa Als~am`waAti waAlA^aroDa [God created, or produced, man, or the soul, and He created the heavens and the earth]. (TA.) [To this verb, or perhaps to baray, or to both, בָּרָ is the Hebrew equivalent, properly (though not necessarily always) signifying “ he created out of pre-existing matter, ” or “ he fashioned. ”]

2 br~A^hu * , inf. n. tabory^apN: see 4, in four places. [Hence,] laA Alt~aboriy^api The lA that denies in a general manner, absolutely, or to the uttermost; i. e. the lA that is a universal negative. (Mughnee &c.) ― -b2- Also He verified his being free [from a thing], clear, or quit, [of it,] guiltless [of it], or irresponsible [for it]. (Mgh, TA.)

3 bArA^hu * , (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) inf. n. mubaAraA^apN (T, M, Mgh) and biraA='N, (M,) He made him (his copartner) free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, the latter doing to him the same: (Mgh:) he compounded, or made a compromise, with him (his hired man, T, M) for their mutual separation: (M:) he separated himself from him (his copartner, S, O), the latter doing the same. (S, O, K.) And baAraA^otu Alr~ajula I became free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, to the man, he becoming so to me. (M.) And bArA^ AlmaroA^apa, (T, M, K,) or A@moraA^atahu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He compounded, or made a compromise, with the woman (or his wife, S) for their mutual separation; (M, K;) i. e. he divorced her for a compensation [which she was to make him, such as her giving up a portion of her dowry remaining due to her, in order that they might be clear, each of the other]: it occurs also [without '] in art. brY. (TA.)

4 AbrA^hu *
He (God, S, M, K) [recovered him, or] restored him to convalescence, (M, K,) mina AlmaraDi [from the disease, sickness, or malady]. (S.) ― -b2- A^aboraA^aka mina AlA^amori and ↓ bar~aA^aka (M, K *) He (i. e. God, TA) made thee, pronounced thee, or held thee, or hath made thee, &c., or may He make thee, &c., to be free from the thing or affair, or clear or quit thereof, or guiltless thereof, or irresponsible for it; (TA;) [or He acquitted thee, or hath acquitted thee, or may He acquit thee, thereof; or He showed thee, or hath showed thee, or may He show thee, to be free from it, &c.: see also 2, above:] said in relation to [a fault or the like, and] a debt, and a claim, and religion [&c.]. (M.) You say, mina AlEayobi ↓ bar~aA^otuhu I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be free from the fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 69], ↓ fabar~aA^ohu A@ll~`hu mimaA qaAluwA (M) But God showed him to be clear of that which they said. (Bd.) You say also, A^aboraA^otuhu mina Ald~ayoni I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of the debt; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e., exempt from the demand thereof: (Msb:) and A^aboraA^otuhu mim~aA liY Ealayohi; and ↓ bar~aA^otuhu, inf. n. taboriy^apN; [I acquitted him of that which he owed me:] (S:) and A^aboraA^otuhu [alone] I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of a claim that I had
upon him, or a due or right that he owed me. (Mgh.) -A2- AbrA^ [in the T (as on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee) A^aboraY] He entered upon [the night, or day, called] AlbaraA=', q. v. (K.)

5 tabar~aAa see 1, in three places. tbr~A^ minohu also signifies He asserted himself to be free from it; or clear, or quit, of it; namely, a fault, or the like. (Mgh.) [And He declared himself to be clear of him; to be not connected, or implicated, with him; he renounced him: see Kur ii. 161 and 162, &c:]

6 tabaAraA^onaA *
We separated ourselves, each from the other. (TA.) [See 3.]

10 AstbrA^ * , (T,) or AstbrA^ mina Albawoli, (Msb,) He took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the orifice of his penis from the remains of urine, by shaking it and pulling it and the like, until he knew that nothing remained in it: (T:) or he purified, or cleansed, himself from urine; syn. tanaz~ahu Eanohu: (Msb:) or AstbrA^, (M,) or AstbrA^ Al*~akara, (K, TA,) signifies he took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the penis from urine; or he cleansed it entirely from urine; (M, * K, * TA;) and so AstbrA^ Alfaroja: and in like manner, AstbrA^ti Alfaroja said of a woman: (El-Munáwee, TA:) but the lawyers make a distinction between AsotiboraA='N and AisotinoqaA='N [which are made syn. in the M and K]: see the latter word. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstbrA^ AljaAriyapa, (T, S, Mgh,) or AlmaroA^apa, (M, Msb, K,) He abstained from sexual intercourse (T, M, K) with the girl whom he had purchased or whom he had taken captive, (T,) or with the woman, (M, K,) until she had menstruated (T, M, K) at his abode, once, and then become purified: (T:) the meaning is, (T,) he sought to find her free from pregnancy. (T, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) AstbrA^ Al$~ayo'i, (Z, Mgh, Msb,) or AlA^amora, (TA,) He searched, searched out, or sought to find or discover, the uttermost of the thing, or affair, (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in order that he might know it, (Mgh,) to put an end to his doubt. (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, AisotaboraA^otu maA Einodaka [I searched, or sought to find or discover, or I have searched, &c., the uttermost of what thou hast, of knowledge &c.]. (S, TA.) And AstbrA^ A^roDa ka*aA famaA wajada DaAl~atahu [He searched the uttermost of such a land and found not his stray beast]. (TA.) It is said in the Expos. of the Jámi' es-Sagheer that AisotiboraA='N is an expression denoting The seeking, or seeking leisurely and repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of a thing, until one knows it; considering it with the endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of it; taking, in doing so, the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or good judgment. (Mgh.)

buruA^apN *
A hunter's lurking-place or covert: (T, S, M, K:) pl. buraA^N. (T, S, M.) El-Aashà says,
bihaA buraA^N mivolu Alfasiyli Almukam~ami
[At it (a source of water mentioned in the context) were hunters' lurking-places, like young palmtrees covered over: for tender young palm-trees are often covered over with a kind of coarse matting]. (T, S, M.)

baraA='N brA=' : see bariYo'N, in six places. ― -b2- AlbaraA='N The first night of the [lunar] month; (El-Mázinee, T, S, K;) called thus, (S,) or layolapu AlbaraA='i, (M,) because the moon has then become clear of the sun: (S, M:) or the first day of the month: (AA, T, K:) or the last night thereof: (As, T, K:) or the last day thereof; (IAar, T, K;) a fortunate day; every event happening therein being regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing; (IAar, T;) but most hold that the last day of the month is termed Aln~aHiyrapN; (TA;) as also Aibonu AlbaraA='i: (K:) or this is the first day of the month: (IAar, T, TA:) pl. A^aboriy^apN. (Th, M.)
buraA='u brA=' : see bariYo'N, in two places.

bariYo'N brA^ brY' bry' bry^
Free, (Msb,) minohu from it; namely a fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice; (Mgh, Msb;) and, also followed by minohu, clear, or quit, of it; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e. exempt from the demand thereof; namely a debt, (Msb,) or a claim, or due, or right; (Mgh;) as also ↓ baAriYN and ↓ baraA='N. (Msb.) You say, A^anaA bariYo'N minohu [I am free from it, &c.]; (T, * S, M, K; *) and ↓ baraA='N, used alike as sing. and dual and pl. (Fr, T, S, M, K) and masc. and fem., (Fr, T, M, K,) because it is originally an inf. n.; (Fr, T, S;) and ↓ buraA='N: (S, M:) the pl. of bariYo'N is bariyw^uwna (T, S, K) and buraA^'u (T, S, M, K) and buraA='N, (T, M, K,) of the measure fuEaAlN, (T,) like ruxaAlN, (M, K,) of an extr. measure, disapproved by Suh, who says, in the R, that it is a contraction of buraA^'u, and has tenween because it resembles [words originally of the measure] fuEaAlN, and that the rel. n. formed from it is ↓ buraAwiY~N, (TA,) but it is mentioned by AAF as a pl. of bariYo'N, and as being like ruxaAlN, and Fr mentions buraA='u as a pl. of the same, imperfectly decl., with one of the two hemzehs suppressed, (M,) and biraA='N (S, M, K) and A^aboraA='N (S, K) and A^aboriy^aA='u, (T, S, K,) the last two anomalous: (TA:) the fem. of bariyo'N is bariyoy^apN; pl. bariyoA=tN (T, S, M, K) and bariy~aAtN (Lh, M, K) and baraAyaA. (T, S, M, K.) You say, A^anaA bariYo'N minohu and xaliY~N minohu [I am free from it; or, more commonly, I am clear, or quit, of it, or him]; and minohu ↓ A^naA baraA='N and xalaA='N minohu; (S;) and minohu ↓ A^anaA AlbaraA='u: (M:) and ↓ naHonu minoka AlbaraA='u and AlxalaA='u [We are clear, or quit, of you]; (Fr, T;) i. e., *awuw AlbaraA='i: so says Aboo-Is-hák; and As says the like of what Fr says. (T.) It is said in the Kur [xliii. 25], mim~aA taEobuduwna ↓ A_in~aniY baraA='N [Verily I am clear of that which ye worship]; (T, M;) or bariYo'N, or ↓ buraA='N; accord. to different readers. (Bd.) bariYo'N occurs in several places in the Kur. (M.) Accord. to IAar, it signifies Clear of evil qualities or dispositions; shunning what is vain and false; remote from actions that occasion suspicion; pure in heart from associating any with God: and it signifies sound in body and intellect. (T.) See also baAriy^N, in two places.

baraA='apN brA='h brA='p
A writing of [i. e. conferring] immunity or exemption: from bariy^a mina Ald~ayoni and AlEayob, of which it is the inf. n.: pl. baraAA=tN, with medd: baraAwaAtN is [pl. of baraApN, and both of these are] vulgar. (Mgh.)
buraAwiY~N brAwY brAwy brAwyy rAwy : see bariYo'N.

Albariy~apu Albryh Albryp bry bryp
The creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created; or, particularly, mankind; syn. Alxaloqu: (T, S, M:) pronounced without '; (T, S;) originally with ', like nabiY~N and *ur~iyapN; (M;) and the people of Mekkeh differ from the other Arabs in pronouncing these three words with ': (Yoo, T, M:) Lh says that the Arabs agree in omitting the ' in these three instances; and he does not except the people of Mekkeh: (M:) it is of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of mafoEuwlapN, (Msb,) from baraA^a A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa, meaning xalaqahumo: (Fr, T:) or, if derived from AlbaraY [“earth” or “dust”], it is originally without ': (Fr, T, S:) pl. baraAyaA and bariy~aAtN. (S in art. brw and brY.)

baAriy^N * , (K,) or baAriy^N mino maraDihi, (Lh, S, M,) [Recovering from his disease, sickness, or malady: or] convalescent; or becoming sound, or healthy, at the close of his disease, but being yet weak; or recovering, but not completely, his health and strength: [see 1:] (M, K:) as also ↓ bariy^o'N: (Lh, M, K:) but whether the latter be properly used in this sense is disputed; while the former is said to be the act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses: (TA:) pl. biraA='N, (M, K,) like as SiHaAHN is pl. of SaHiyHN, accord. to Lh, so that he holds it to be pl. of bariYo'N; or it may be pl. of baAriy^N, like as jiyaAEN is pl. of jaAy^iEN, and SiHaAbN of SaAHibN. (M.) ↓ bariYo'N is sometimes written and pronounced bariY~N [in all its senses]. (Kz.) ― -b2- See also bariyo'N. -A2- AlbaAriy^u, applied to God, The Creator; (T, S, Msb;) He who hath created the things that are created, not after any similitude, or model; (Nh;) or He who hath created those things free from any incongruity, or faultiness, (Mgh, and Bd in ii. 51,) and distinguished, one from another, by various forms and outward appearances: (Bd:) or the Former, or Fashioner; syn. AlmuSaw~iru [q. v.]. (M.)

barobaxN brbx The passage, or conduit, of water, called A_irodab~ap and baAluwEap [q. v.], made of baked clay: (K:) or baraAbixu [the pl.] signifies the baked-clay conduits of privies, which convey [the water &c.] from the house-top to the ground. (S, but omitted in some copies.) ― -b2- brobaxu Albawoli The canal of the urine [from the kidney to the bladder; i. e. the ureter]: (L, KL, TA:) of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

barobaTN brbT rbAT rbT [The Persian lute;] a certain musical instrument (Lth, Msb) of the Eajama [or Persians]; (Msb;) i. q. EuwidN: (Lth, K:) an arabicized word, (K,) from baribato, (IAth,) or baribaTo; meaning “the breast of the duck, or goose;” because of its
resemblance thereto; (K;) for baro in Persian, signifies the “breast;” (TA;) [and bato and baTo or baT~o, like the Arabic baT~N, “a duck,” or “goose;”] or because the player upon it places it against his breast: (IAth:) or it is said to be arabicized because it is the name of a musical instrument of the Ejm. (Msb.)

burovunN brvn , of the lion, (AZ, T,) and of any animal of prey, (AZ, As, T, S, M, K,) and of birds, (As, S,) [The toe; i. e.] what corresponds to the A_iSobaE of a man; (AZ, As, T, S, M, K;) [in the Lex. of Golius, as on the authority of the S, and in that of Freytag, idem quod Anmlp in homine; but this is a mistake, app. occasioned by a mistranscription in a copy of the S;] and the mixolab is its claw, i. e., nail: (AZ, As, T, S:) or the paw (kaf~), (M, K,) altogether, (M,) with the A^aSaAbiE [or toes]: (M, K:) or the claw, i. e. nail, of the lion, (Lth, T, M, K,) likened to the instrument for perforating leather; (Lth, T;) and of [all] animals of prey, and of birds that do not prey, corresponding to the Zufor of man: Th says, of man, it is [termed] the Zufor; of animals having the kind of foot called xuf~, the manosimo; of solidhoofed animals, the HaAfir; of cloven-hoofed animals, the Zilof; of beasts and birds of prey, the mixolab; and of birds that do not prey, and of dogs and the like, the burovun; though it may be also used [in like manner] of all animals of prey: (Msb:) [but properly] it is of birds that do not prey, as the crow-kind, and the pigeon; (M;) and sometimes, of the [lizard called] Dab~, (S, M,) and of the rat, or mouse, and of the jerboa: (M:) and is, in the pl. form, (M, TA,) which is baraAvinu, (T, S, M, TA,) metaphorically applied, by Sá'ideh Ibn-Jueiyeh, to the fingers of a man gathering honey [deposited by wild bees in a hollow of a rock]. (M, * TA.) ― -b2- burovunu AlA^asadi also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels, (K, TA,) in the form of the claw of the lion. (TA.) ― -b3- This, also, is the name of a sword of Marthad Ibn-'Alas. (K.) ― -b4- [burovunapN seems to signify the same as burovunN or baraAvinu: for] Temeem are termed in a trad. the burovumap and burojumap of the tribes of Mudar; and El-Khattábee says that it should be the burovunap, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The claw, or] the claws; meaning thereby their impetuous valour, and strength: but brvmp may be a dial. var. of brvnp, or the m may be substituted for the n for the purpose of assimilation [to brjmp]. (TA.)

1 barija brj rj [written in the TA without the vowel-signs, but the context seems to show that it is thus, and that the inf. n. is barajN] It (anything) was, or became, apparent, manifest, or conspicuous, and high, or elevated: whence burojN, applied to a certain kind of structure. (TA.) ― -b2- barija, [aor.
baraja ,] inf. n. barajN, [also signifies] He had that quality of the eye which is termed barajN, explained below. (M, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or barija A^amoruhu, (TA,) aor.
baraja , His state, condition, or case, became ample in respect of eating and drinking. (IAar, K, TA.)
2 bar~aja see 4.

4 Abrj Abrj
He (a man, TA) built a buroj [or tower, &c.]; as also ↓ br~j, inf. n. taboriyjN. (K.)

5 tabar~ajato tbrj tbrjt
She (a woman) showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, (S, Msb, K,) and beauties of person or form or countenance, (S, Msb,) to men, (S, K,) or to strangers, or men distantly related to her; (Msb;) to do which is culpable; but to do so to the husband is not: (TA:) or she showed her face: or she showed the beauties of her neck and face: or she did so exhibiting a pretty look: (TA:) or she showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and what excites a man's lust. (A boo-Is-hák, TA.) Fr, referring to verse 33 of ch. xxxiii. of the Kur, says that in the time when Abraham was born, the women used to wear a shirt of pearls, not sewed at the two sides; or, as some say, they used to wear garments which did not conceal their persons. (TA.)

burojN brj rj [Gr. πύργος, (Golius,) A tower;] an angle, syn. rukon, (S, K,) of a fortress, (S,) or of a city: (TA:) and sometimes a fortress itself: (S, K:) so called from its conspicuousness and construction and height: (TA: [see 1:]) or the primary signification of brj is strength; whence A^aboraju in a sense explained below: (Har p. 286:) pl. [of mult.] buruwjN and [of pauc.] A^aboraAjN: (S:) the buruwjN of the wall of a city or fortress are chambers (buyuwt [meaning towers]) built upon the wall: and such chambers (bywt) built upon the sides of the angles of a qaSor [i. e. pavilion or palace &c.] are sometimes thus called. (Lth.) [Hence,] buroju HamaAmK [A pigeon-turret; a pigeon-house; being generally constructed in the form of a turret, or of a sugar-loaf;] a lodging-place of pigeons: pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) [A sign of the Zodiac;] one of the buruwj of the heaven; (S, K;) which are twelve in number; every one having a distinct name: (TA:) the Arabs in ancient times did not know them: (Ham p. 560:) pl. A^aboraAjN as well as buruwjN: (Msb, TA:) these are meant by the buruwj mentioned in the Kur xv. 16 and xxv. 62 and lxxxv. 1: (Bd, Jel:) or in the last of these instances, (Bd,) by the brwj in the heaven are meant the Mansions of the Moon: (Bd, Msb:) or the stars or asterisms or constellations: (TA:) or the great stars or asterisms or constellations; (Bd, Msb;) and so, accord. to Zj, in the second of the said passages of the Kur: (TA:) or the gates of heaven: (Bd, Msb:) or, as some say, i. q. quSuwr [i. e. pavilions &c.]. (TA.)

barajN brj rj
Such a constitution of the eye that the white entirely surrounds the black, (S, M, K,) no part of the black being concealed: (S, M:) or width of the eye: or width of the white of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball, and beauty of the black part: or clearness of the white and black parts theeeof: (M, TA:) or width of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball: (Ham p. 560:) or width of the eye with intense whiteness of the person: (TA:) and distance between the eyebrows. (L, TA.) [See also balajN.] -A2- Goodly, elegant, or pretty; beautiful of face: or [so in copies of the K, and in the TA, but in the CK “and”] shining, or splendid; conspicuous; and well known. (K.)

xuluqN baArijN xlq bArj
A large, or liberal, disposition; syn. waAsiEN. (Ham p. 560.)

A^aboraAjN * A man having that quality of the eye which is termed barajN: (M, TA:) fem. barojaA='u; applied to a woman; (S) and also to an eye (EayonN) having the quality termed barajN: (M, TA:) pl. burojN. (Ham p. 560.) -A2- h`*aA A^aboraju mino h`*aA This is stronger than this. (Har p. 286.)

A_iboriyjN Abryj The vessel, or receptacle, [generally a skin,] in which milk is churned, or beaten and agitated, or in which the butter of the milk is extracted, or fetched out, by putting water in it, and agitating it; syn. mimoxaDapN. (S, K.)

vawobN mubar~ajN vwb mbrj
A garment whereon are figures of buruwj [or towers]: (Zj, TA:) or whereon are depicted figures resembling the buruwj [or towers] of the wall of a city or the like: (T, A, TA:) or figured with eyes, of the garments termed HulalN; from Albaraju (S.)

burojumapN brjmh brjmp rjm rjmp (in the Ham p. 352 burojumN) is the sing. of baraAjimu (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and burojumaAtN; (T, TA;) and signifies [A knuckle, or finger-joint;] the outer, or the inner, joint, or place of division, of the fingers: and (as some say, TA) the middle toe of any bird: (K:) or baraAjimu signifies all the finger-joints; (A'Obeyd, K;) as also rawaAjimu [a mistranscription for rawaAjib]: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or the parts of the fingers that are protuberant when one clinches his hand: (Ham ubi suprà:) or the backs of the finger-bones: (K:) or the finger-joints (S, Mgh) that are between the A^a$aAjiE and the rawaAjib; (S;) i. e. (S, Mgh) [the middle knuckles; (see A^a$ojaEu and raAjibapN;)] the heads of the sulaAmayaAt, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) on the back, or outer side, of the hand, (S, Msb,) which become protuberant when one clinches his hand: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as in the Kf, the heads of the slAmyAt; and their inner and outer sides are termed the rawaAjib: (Msb:) accord. to the T, the wrinkled parts at the joints of the fingers; the smooth portion between which is called raAjibapN: or, as in another place, in the backs of the fingers; the parts between them being called the rawaAjib: in every finger are three burojumaAt, except the thumb: or, as in another place, in every finger are two of what are thus termed: it is also explained as signifying the joints in the backs of the fingers, upon which the dirt collects. (TA.) The phrase AlA^axo*u biAlbaraAjimi, meaning The seizing
with the hand, is one requiring consideration [as of doubtful character]. (Mgh.) [See also burovunN.]

1 bariHa brH is syn. with zaAla [in two senses; i. e. as an attributive verb, and also as a non-attributive verb; as will be shown by what follows]. (S, A, Mgh.) [Using it as an attributive verb,] you say, laA A^aboraHu Hat~aY taqoDiYa HaAjatiY I will not go away, or depart, or withdraw, (laA A^azuwlN, and laA A^atanaH~aYi,) until thou accomplish my want: from bariHa AlmakaAnu, inf. n. baraAHN, he went away, or departed, from the place; syn. zaAla minohu: and to be distinguished from the phrase in the Kur [xviii. 59, similar as to words,] mentioned below. (Mgh.) You say, bariHa makaAnahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
baraHa , (K,) inf. n. baraAHN (S, L, K) and buruwHN (L, TA, and Ham p. 250) and baraHN, (L,) or baroHN, (as in a copy of the TA,) He went away, or departed, from his place; (S, L, K, and Ham ubi suprà;) and he became in the baraAH [or wide, uncultivated, or uninhabited, tract]. (S, L, K.) And maA bariHa makaAnahu He did not quit his place. (Msb.) And bariHa [alone], aor.
baraHa , inf. n. baraAHN, It (a thing) went away, or departed, (zaAla,) from its place; (Msb;) as also ↓ tbr~H. (L.) In the phrase laA baraAHa [There is, or shall be, no quitting of place, or going away, or departing], the noun is in the accus. case, as in laA rayoba: but it is allowable to put it in the nom. case, so that lA is used in the manner of layosa; (S, K;) as in the following saying of Saad Ibn-Málik, [in the TA, in one place, Ibn-Náshib,] in a poem of which the rhyme is with refa, (S, IAth,) alluding to El-Hárith Ibn-'Abbád, who had withdrawn himself from the war of Teghlib and Bekr the sons of Wáïl: (IAth, TA:)
faA^anaA A@bonu qayosK laA baraAHu mano far~aEano niyraAnihaA
[Whoso fleeth from its fires, (i. e. niyraAni AlHarobi the fires of the war,) let him do so: but as for me, I am the son of Keys: to me there is not, or shall not be, any quitting of place]. (S, IAth. [See also Ham p. 250, where, for man far~a, we find mano Sad~a whoso turneth away.]) [Hence,] bariHati Alr~iyHu biAlt~uraAbi The wind carried up, raised, or swept up and scattered, [lit. went away with,] the dust. (Msb.) [Hence also, accord. to some,] bariHa AlxafaA='u, (T, S, K, &c.,) and baraHa, (Ibn-ElLihyánee, Z, and TA, [thus written in a copy of the A,]) (tropical:) The state of concealment departed, or ceased: or (tropical:) what was in a state of concealment became apparent; from baraAHN meaning “what is open and apparent” of land: or (tropical:) what I was concealing became apparent: (T, TA:) or (tropical:) the affair, or case, became manifest, (S, A, K,) and its concealment ceased, (A,) [or] as though the secret departed, and ceased: (S:) or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) the secret became apparent: (TA in art. xfY:) or, lit., the low ground became high and apparent; meaning (assumed tropical:) what was concealed became revealed: (Har pp. 133—4:) the first who said it was Shikk the Diviner. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b2- [Using it as a non-attributive verb,] you say, laA A^aboraHu A^afoEalu *`lika I will not cease, or I will continue, (laA A^azaAlu,) to do that: (S, A: *) and maA bariHa yafoEalu ka*aA [he ceased not to do thus; or] he persevered in, or kept to, doing thus: (Msb:) and maA bariHa zayodN qaAy^imFA [Zeyd ceased not to be, or he kept, or continued, standing]: in this case, the verb is of the category of kaAna; (Mgh;) relates to time; and requires a predicate: and its inf. n. is baraAHN. (Ham p. 250.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xviii. 59], laA A^aboraAHu Hat~aY A^aboluga majomaEa AlbaHorayoni, but the predicate is suppressed: it may be maA naHonu fiyhi ka*`lika [i. e. I will not cease in that wherein we are thus engaged until I reach the place of meeting of the two seas]: (Mgh:) or it means laA A^azaAlu A^asiyru [I will not cease journeying]: (Bd, Jel:) or lA AbrH here may mean I will not depart (laA A^azuwlu) from that upon which I am intent, namely journeying and seeking; and I will not relinquish it; so that it does not require the predicate. (Bd. [He gives a third explanation, paraphrastic and strained, which I omit.]) -A2- baraHa, (S, K,) aor.
baraHa , (L, TA, [but it is implied in the K that it is
baruHa , which is contr. to rule,]) inf. n. buruwHN, It (a gazelle, S, K, and a bird, and any wild animal, that is hunted or shot, TA) turned its left side towards the spectator, passing by (S, K *) from the direction of his right hand towards that of his left hand: (S:) or passed by from the direction of the spectator's left hand towards that of his right hand: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, L, Msb, in art. snH:) [the former appears to be accord. to the usage of the Hijázees; and the latter, accord. to that of the Nejdees, in general: see baAriHN:] contr. of sanaHa. (S.) -A3- baraHa, aor.
baruHa , [contr. to rule,] (K,) inf. n. baroHN, (TA,) He was angry. (K.) When a man has been angry with his companion, one says, maA A^a$ad~a maA baraHa Ealayohi [How violently angry was he with him!]. (L.)

2 bar~aHato biya AlHum~aY brHt by AlHmY brHt by AlHmy
The fever affected me with its severity, violence, or sharpness, termed buraHaA='u. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) from buraHaA='u, (S, K,) br~H bihi, inf. n. taboriyHN, It (an affair, an event, or a case,) affected him severely; afflicted, distressed, or harassed, him: (S, K:) said also of anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind: (A:) and of a beating, meaning it hurt him severely, or greatly. (Msb.) Also said of a man, meaning He importuned him, or pressed him, with annoyance, or molestation: (A, TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by importuning or pressing; as also ↓ AbrH: (TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by distressing importunity or pressing: (T, TA:) and he punished, tormented, or tortured, him. (TA.) taboriyHN signifies The act of annoying, molesting, or hurting: (Mgh:) and in a trad., (in which it is forbidden, TA,) the killing, or putting to death, in an evil [or a cruel] manner; such as throwing live fish, and lice, into the fire. (Mgh, TA.) -A2- bar~aHa A@ll~`hu Eanoka May God remove from thee AlbaroH [i. e. difficulty, distress, affliction, &c., or the difficulty, &c.]. (A, TA.)

4 AbrHhu A^brH A^brHh AbrHh AbrHp brH
He made him, or caused him, to go away from, depart from, or quit, his place. (A, * L.) -A2- He, or it, pleased, or rejoiced, him; excited his admiration and approval; induced in him wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy. (S, K.) One says also, maA A^aboraHa h`*aA AlA^amora How greatly does this affair, or event, please, or rejoice! how greatly does it excite admiration and approval! or how greatly does it induce wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy! (S.) ― -b2- He treated him with honour, or honoured him, and magnified him: (S, K:) or, as some say, he found him to be generous, or noble. (TA.) ― -b3- He judged him, or it, i. e. a man, (A, TA,) and a horse, (A,) or anything, (TA,) to be excellent, or to excel, (A, TA,) and wondered at, or admired, him, or it. (A.) -A3- AbrH also signifies He exceeded the usual bounds, degree, or mode. (As, S, * TA.) You say, A^aboraHota karamFA, and luw^omFA, (A, TA,) Thou hast done a thing exceeding the usual bounds [in generosity, or nobleness, and in meanness, or ignobleness]; or extravagant; or excessive. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.
5 tabar~aHa see 1.

baroHN brH
Difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; evil, or mischief; (K, TA;) annoyance, molestation, or hurt; severe punishment; trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue; (TA;) a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing or event: (Ham p. 135:) and annoyance, or molestation, by distressing importunity or pressing; a subst. from 2: (T, TA:) and binotu baroHK, [and app. Aibonu baroHK also,] a calamity, misfortune, or disaster; or a great, or terrible, thing, affair, or case; (TA;) as also ↓ binotu baAriHK, and ↓ Aibonu bariyHK; (K;) pl. banaAtu baroHK and banuw baroHK. (TA.) [See also taboriyHN.] You say, laqiytu minohu baroHFA ↓ baAriHFA I experienced from him, or it, [great] difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; [great] annoyance, molestation, or hurt; (S, A, * K; *) a phrase having an intensive signification, (K, TA,) like layolN A^aloyalu [and layolN laAy^ilN]; and so baroHFA ↓ mubar~iHFA. (TA.) When used as an imprecation, the more approved way is to put the two words in the accus. case: but sometimes they are put in the nom. case; as in the saying of a poet, ↓ baroHN laEyonaka baAriHN [May great difficulty, &c., befall thy two eyes!]. (TA.) You say also, laqiytu minohu banaAti baroHK, (S, A,) and baniy baroHK, (S,) I experienced from him, or it, difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adverse events; and calamities, misfortunes, or disasters: (S:) and, in the same sense, ↓ lqyt mnh AlbiraHiyna, and ↓ AlburaHiyna, (S, K,) and ↓ AlbaraHiyna; (K;) or, accord. to some copies of the K, ↓ AlbiroHayni, and ↓ AlburoHayoni, and ↓ AlbaroHayoni, as duals; but the former reading is the more correct: (TA:) [MF disapproves of the form baraHiyna, and it is not mentioned in the
L; but the dual form baroHayoni is there mentioned:] it seems as though the sing. of bariHiyna [or buraHiyna] were biraHapN [or buraHapN], and that the pl. is formed by the termination wn to compensate for the rejection of the p, as is virtually the case in A^araDuwna; [or because the signification is regarded as that of a personification;] and that the pl. only is used. (L.) It is said in a prov., binotu baroHK $arakN EalaY raA^osika [Calamity is, or be, a snare upon thy head]. (TA.)
bariHN brH : see mubar~iHN.
SaroHapa baroHapa SrHp brHh SrHp brHp , or SaroHapF baroHapF, &c.: see art. SrH.

buroHapN brH brHh brHp The best of anything: (TA:) and [particularly] one of the best of she-camels: (S, K:) or, of he-camels: (T:) pl. buraHN. (T, S, K.)
