You say, h`*ihi buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (S, K, *) or huwa buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (T,) This is a she-camel, (S, K, *) or he is a camel, (T,) of the best of camels. (T, S, K.)
baroHay brHY brHy rHY a word that is said when one misses the mark in shooting or casting; like as maroHay is said when one hits the mark. (S, ISd, A, K.)

buraHaA='u brHA='
Severity, violence, or sharpness, (As, A, TA,) or vehement molestation, (S, K,) of a fever (As, A, S, K) &c.: (S, K:) [a paroxysm; used in this sense by modern physicians:] and vehement distress of mind arising from the oppression caused by inspiration or revelation; such as is said to have affected the Prophet; [but most probably a paroxysm of that species of catalepsy which physicians term ecstasy;] occurring in a trad. (TA.) You say of one suffering from fever, when it is intense, A^aSaAbatohu AlburaHaA='u [The paroxysm, or severe fit, has befallen him]. (TA.)
AlbiraHiyna AlbrHyn and AlburaHiyna &c.: see baroHN

baraAHN brAH rAH inf. n. of bariHa, q. v.; whence the phrase laA baraAHa, explained above. (S, L, K.) -A2- A wide, or spacious, tract of land, (S, A, K,) kaving in it no seed-produce nor trees: (S, K:) or land having in it no building nor habitation: (Ham p. 237:) and applied as an epithet to land, signifying wide, or spacious, open, or conspicuous, and having in it no herbage nor habitation: and what is open, uncovered, and wholly apparent, of land: (TA:) or a place having no trees nor other things to cover or conceal it; as though such things had departed; (Mgh;) a place free from trees &c.: (Msb:) or an elevated and open tract of land. (Har p. 134.) ― -b2- Habiylu baraAHK is an appellation given to (tropical:) A lion: and (assumed tropical:) a courageous man: as though each of them were bound with ropes, (K, TA,) and did not quit his place. (TA.) -A3- An affair, a thing, or a case, that is plain, evident, or manifest; (K, TA;) or open, or public. (TA.) You say, jaA='anaA biAlA^amori baraAHFA [He told us, or did to us, the thing] plainly [or openly]. (S.) And jaA='a biAlkufori baraAHFA wa biAl$~ar~i SuraAHFA [He uttered, or committed an act of, infidelity plainly, or openly, and evil, or mischief, unmixedly]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Counsel, or an opinion, that is disapproved, or deemed evil. (K.) -A4- baraAHi, (El-Mufaddal, S, A, &c.,) and baraAHu, with damm and without tenween, (AZ, El-Mufaddal,) a name of The sun: (S, A, &c.:) determinate [and the former indecl.]: the sun is so called because of the spreading of its light, and its conspicuousness; or, being applied to the sun when it sets, brAH means baAriHapN; like as kasaAbi, a name applied to a hunting-bitch, means kaAsibapN. (TA.) You say, dalakato baraAHi The sun set [or declined from the meridian]. (A, TA.) For this phrase, occurring at the end of a verse cited by Ktr, Fr reads dalakato biraAHi; rAH being pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of raAHapN, meaning the “hand” [or “palm of the hand”]: (S, TA:) accord. to which reading, the poet means The sun had set, or had declined from the meridian, while they put their hands, or the palms of their hands, over their eyes, looking to see if it had set, or had declined from the meridian: or he who says, dalakati Al$~amosu biraAHi means the sun had almost set: the two readings barAH and birAH are mentioned by A'Obeyd and Az and Hr and Z and others: AZ says, dlkt biraAHK, with tenween, and baraAHN, without tenween. (TA.) [See also raAHapN, in art. rwH.]
baruwHN brwH rwH : see baAriHN.

bariyHN bryH ryH : see baAriHN. -A2- Also The croaking of the guraAb [or crow, of whatever species, as raven, carrion-crow, &c.]. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aibonu bariyHK: so in the K: in the S, A^um~u bariyHK; but IB and Aboo-Zekereeyà say that only the former is right: (TA:) [in one copy of the S, however, I find both of these:] The guraAb [or crow, as a generic term, applying to the raven, carrion-crow, &c.]: (S, K, &c.:) so called because of its cry: a determinate appellation: for the pl., the expression used is banaAtu bariyHK. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baroHN. -A3- qawolN bariyHN A saying by which one pronounces a person to have said, or done, right. (L.)

baAriHN bArH , (S, K, &c.,) as also ↓ baruwHN and ↓ bariyHN, (K,) applied to a gazelle, (S,) or what is hunted or shot, (K, TA,) of gazelles and birds and wild animals [in general], (TA,) Turning his left side towards the spectator, (S,) passing from the direction of the right hand of the latter towards the direction of his left hand: (S, K:) or turning his right side towards the spectator, passing from the direction of the latter's left hand towards that of his right: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, A, * L, Msb, * in art. snH:) contr. of saAniHN: (S, * TA:) pl. bawaAriHu. (L in art. snH.) The Arabs [who apply the epithet in the latter sense] regard the bArH as an evil omen, and the sAnH as a good omen; because one cannot shoot at the former without turning himself: (S:) but some of them hold the reverse: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee and L in art. snH:) the people of Nejd hold the sAnH to be a good omen; but sometimes a Nejdee adopts the opinion of the Hijázee [which is the contrary]. (IB in that art.) The first of these epithets is also applied to a bird as meaning Inauspicious; ill-omened. (A.) It is said in a prov., mano liY biA ls~aAniHi baEoda AlbaAriHi (TA) i. e. [Who will be responsible to me] for a fortunate, or lucky, event, after an unfortunate, or unlucky? (K in art. snH:) applied in the case of a man's doing evil, and its being said, “He will at a future time do good to thee:” originally said by a man on the occasion of gazelles' passing before him in the manner of such as are termed baAriHap, and its being said to him, “They will present themselves to thee in the manner of such as are termed saAnHap.” (TA.) And in another prov. it is said, A_in~amaA huwa kabaAriHi AlA^arowaY [It, or he, is only like the mountain-goat passing in the manner of such as is termed bArH]: for it dwells on the tops of the mountains, and men scarcely ever see it passing with the right or left side towards them save once in the course of ages: (S, K:) applied in the case of an extraordinary occurrence: (K:) [or in the case of a benefit conferred by a man who very rarely confers benefits on others: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 35:)] or when a man has delayed, or been tardy in, visiting [but has come at last]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, fitolapN baAriHapN i. q. $azorapN [i. e. (tropical:) A manner of twisting contrary to that which is usual: see $azara]. (A.) ― -b3- And h`*ihi faEolpN baAriHapN (tropical:) This is an action that has not happened rightly. (A.) ― -b4- [Hence,] binotu baAriHN: and [perhaps] laqiytu minohu baroHFA baAriHFA: and baroHN liEayonaka baAriHN: see baroHN. ― -b5- [And hence, perhaps, because of its evil effect; or because it comes, accord. to some, from the left, i. e. northerly direction, or, accord. to others, from the right, i. e. southerly direction; or] from baroHN as signifying “a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing, or event;” (Ham p. 135;) baAriHN signifies also A hot wind: (S:) or a hot wind in the SayofN [i. e. summer or spring]: (K:) or a hot wind coming from the direction of El-Yemen: (Ham p. 135:) or a wind that carries up, raises, or sweeps up and scatters, the dust: (Msb:) pl. bawAriHu: (S, K, &c.:) or the bwArH are hot north, or northerly, winds in the Sayof: (AZ, Az, S:) this Az found to be the sense in which the term was used by the Arabs in his time: (TA:) or violent winds that carry with them the dust by reason of their violence: (TA:) or this name (the pl.) was given by the Arabs to all winds in the time of the stars of the qayoZ [or summer]: they mostly blow in the time of the stars of Libra; [app. meaning when Libra is on, or near, the meridian at nightfall, agreeably with a statement in modern Arabic almanacs, that the periods of the beginning and end of the winds thus called are the 30th of May and the 9th of July;] and these winds are what are termed the samaAy^im [pl. of samuwmN]. (Ibn-Kunáseh, TA.) ― -b6- AlbawaAriHu is also said by some to signify AlA^anowaA='u [pl. of nawo'N, q. v.]; as mentioned by AHn; but he repels their assertion. (TA.)

AlbaAriHapu AlbArHh AlbArHp bArH bArHp
The next, or nearest, past, or preceding, night; yesternight: (S, A, Mgh, * Msb, * K:) from bariHa signifying zaAla [“he, or it, went away” &c.].
(S, A.) [In modern Arabic, Yesterday; as also AlbaAriH.] It has no dim. formed from it. (Sb, in S, in art. A^ms; and TA.) You say, laqiytuhu AlbaAriHap [I met, or met with, him, or it, last night, or yesternight]: and laqiytuhu AlbaAriHapa AlA^uwlay [I met, or met with, him, or it, the night before last; this being the sense in which the phrase is now used by the learned: but the vulgar expression is A^aw~al AlbaAriHap, generally pronounced A^aw~al AamobaAriHaho or A^aw~al AamobaAriHo, agreeably with a peculiarity of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, or of Teiyi and Himyer, by the substitution of Aamo for Aalo: see art. Am]. (S) From daybreak to the time when the sun declines from the meridian, one says, raA^ayotu All~ayolapa fiY manaAmiY [I saw to-night in my sleep (such a thing)]; but when the sun has declined, one says, raA^ayotu AlbaAriHapa [I saw last night, or yesternight]: (AZ, Th: [and the like is said in the Mgh and Msb:]) or one says, kaAna ka*aA wa ka*aA All~ayolapa [Such and such things happened to-night] until the sun is somewhat high and the day has become bright; but after this, one says, kaAna AlbaAriHapa [It happened last night, or yesternight]. (Yoo, Seer.) The Arabs say,
maA A^a$obaha All~ayolapa biA lbaAriHapi
How like is this night wherein we are to the former night that has departed! (TA:) [or, this night to yesternight!]: originally occurring in a poem of Tarafeh: used as meaning “how like is the child to the father!” and applied to [any] two things resembling each other. (Har p. 667.)

A^aboraHu * is formed [from baraHa for bar~aHa] by the rejection of the added letter: [for a word of this kind is regularly formed only from an unaugmented triliteral-radical verb:] or it is like A^aHonaku, having no proper verb. (L.) You say, h`*aA A^aboraHu EalaY~a mino *aAka (A, * L, Msb *) This is more difficult, distressing, or afflicting, to me than that. (L, Msb. *) And h`*aA= AlA^amoru A^aboraHu mino h`*aA This affair, event, or case, is more difficult, or distressing, than this. (S.) And qataluwhumo A^aboraHa qatolK [They slew them with a most severe slaughter]. (S.)

taboriyHN tbryH [inf. n. of 2, used as a simple subst.,] is said by some to be sing. of tabaAriyHu, and has been used as such by post-classical authors, but is not of established authority: accord. to others, the latter has no sing.: (MF:) the pl. signifies Difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adversities: [see also baroHN:] or the difficulties, or obligations, incurred by troublesome, or inconvenient, means of obtaining subsistence: (TA:) and tabaAriyHu Al$~awoqi the burning, or fierce burning, [or the burnings, &c.,] of the yearning, or longing, of the soul, or of longing desire. (S, K.)

A^naA mubar~aHN biY *
I am importuned, or pressed, with annoyance, or molestation. (A, TA.) [See the verb (2).]

mubar~iHN mbrH and ↓ bariHN, applied to an affair, an event, or a case, signify the same; (K, TA;) i. e. Severe, afflicting, distressing, or harassing: (TA:) and the former, to a beating, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) meaning the same; (TA;) or hurting (S, Mgh) severely: (S:) and to a man, meaning annoying, or molesting, by importuning, or pressing. (TA.) [See 2.] laqiytu minohu baroHFA mubar~iHFA: see baroHN.

yaboruwHN ybrwH , (K,) thus correctly written, with the Y before the b; [not byrwH, as in the CK; in Chald. יַבְרוּחַ, the word corresponding to the sing. of the Hebr. דּוּרָאִים in Gen. xxx. 14 and 16, accord. to the paraphrase of Onkelos;] or yaboruwHN SanamiY~N [the idol-like ybrwH]; (TA;) The root, or lower part, of the wild luf~aAH [or mandrake, not to be confounded with another plant to which the name of luf~aAH, q. v., is also applied], (K,) which is known by the names of faAwaAniyaA and Euwdu AlS~aliybi [names now given to the peony], and called by MF tuf~aAHu Albar~i, [or the wild apple, but perhaps this is a mistranscription for luf~aAHu Albar~i,] said by him to be an appellation used by the vulgar; (TA;) resembling the form of a man; (K;) and of two sorts, male and female; called by the people of Greece Eabodu Als~alaAmi: (TA:) it torpifies, (K,) and strengthens the two appetites [namely that of the stomach and that of the generative organ): (TA:) if ivory is cooked with it for six hours, it renders it soft; and if a part affected by [the disease termed] bara$ is rubbed with its leaves for a week, (K,) without interruption, (TA,) it removes it without causing ulcers, or sores: (K:) the root of the wild luf~aAH is the yaborwH: it has the form of a human being; the male like the male, and the female like the female; and they pretend that he who pulls it up dies; wherefore, when they desire to do so, they tie a dog or some other animal to it. (Kzw, voce luf~aAH.)

1 baruda brd rd , aor.
baruda , inf. n. buruwdapN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and barada, aor.
baruda , (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. barodN; (M, Msb;) It (a thing, S, Msb, and the latter said of water, Msb) was, or became, cold, chill, or cool; [see barodN below;] (S, M;) its heat became allayed. (Msb.) The latter verb is also used transitively, as will be shown below. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baruda maDojaEahu [lit. His bed, or place of sleep, became cold; meaning] (tropical:) he went on a journey. (A.) ― -b3- barada also signifies (tropical:) He died; (As, T, S, A, K;) because death is the non-existence of the heat of the soul; (L;) or it is allusive to the extinction of the natural heat; or to the cessation of motion. (MF.) For ― -b4- barada, (MF,) aor.
baruda , (Mgh,) inf. n. barodN, (MF,) likewise signifies (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, still, quiet, or motionless; (Mgh, MF;) for instance, a slaughtered sheep or goat [&c.]. (Mgh.) And (assumed tropical:) It (beverage of the kind called nabiy*) became still, and without briskness. (TA, from a trad.) You say, ruEiba fabarada makaAnahu [(assumed tropical:) He became frightened, and remained motionless in his place; makaAnahu meaning fiY makaAnahu: and hence,] (tropical:) he became amazed, or stupified. (A.) And baradato Eayonuhu (assumed tropical:) The pain in his eye became allayed, or stilled. (L.) And barada A^amorunaA (assumed tropical:) Our affair, or case, became easy. (TA, from a trad. [See also baAridN.]) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. barod, [which see below,] (assumed tropical:) He slept. (T.) ― -b6- And hence, (tropical:) It remained, or became permanent, or fixed, or settled. (T.) So in the saying, lamo yaborudo biyadiY minohu $ayo'N (tropical:) There did not remain, or become permanent or fixed or settled, in my hand, thereof, anything. (T, L. *) You say also, barada A^asiyrFA fiY A^ayodiyohimo (tropical:) He remained safely a captive in their hands. (A.) And barada fiY A^ayodiyhmo salomFA (tropical:) He became a permanent captive, remaining in their hands, not to be ransomed nor liberated nor demanded. (L.) And barada Almawoti EalaYmuSoTalaAhu (tropical:) Death fixed, or settled, [upon his face and extremities, or] upon his limbs, or upon his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire. (AHeyth, L.) And barada Almawoti Ealayohi [(tropical:) Death became impressed upon him;] the marks, or signs, of death became apparent upon him. (A.) ― -b7- [And hence, app.,] (tropical:) It (a right, or due,) became incumbent, or obligatory, (M, K, TA,) and established. (TA.) You say, barada liY Haq~iY EalaY fulaAnK (tropical:) My right, or due, became incumbent, or obligatory, on such a one, and established against him. (M, * A, * TA.) And maA barada laka EalaY fulaAnK (tropical:) What hath become incumbent, or obligatory, to thee, on such a one, and established against him? or what hath become owed, or due, to thee, by, or from, such a one? as also maA *aAba laka Ealayohi. (S.) And barada liY Ealayohi ka*aA mina AlmaAli (tropical:) Such an amount of the property, or of property, became incumbent, or obligatory, to me, on him, and established against him; or became owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (S.) ― -b8- Also, (K,) aor.
baruda , inf. n. barodN, (TA, [but see the next sentence,]) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, weak; and so burida, a verb like EuniYa. (K.) And, inf. n. buraAdN and buruwdN, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, languid, (K,) or weak and languid, from leanness or disease: (M:) or weak in the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) And barada mux~uhu, (A, K,) aor.
baruda , inf. n. barodN, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated; (A, K;) and so baradato EiZaAmuhu. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) It (a sword [or the like]) was, or became, blunt. (M, K.) -A2- baradahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baruda , (Msb,) inf. n. barodN; (K;) and ↓ br~dhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taboriydN; (S;) He made it, or rendered it, (for ex., water, M, Msb, K,) cold, chill, or cool: (S, &c.:) but the latter has an intensive signification [he made it, or rendered it, very cold, or very cool]: (Msb:) or both signify, (K,) or the former signifies, (M, TA,) he mixed it with snow: (M, K:) one does not say ↓ Abrdhu, except in a bad dialect. (S.) bar~idiyhi, being used by a poet for balo ridiyhi, has been erroneously supposed to mean “Make thou it hot.” (M.) You say, baradanaA All~ayolu, (aor. and inf. n. as above, M,) and barada EalayonaA, The night affected us with its cold. (M, K.) And saqayotuhu $arobapF baradato fuw^aAdahu, (S, M, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) I gave him to drink a draught
that cooled his heart: (S, M:) or baradotu bihaA fuw^aAdahu [with which I cooled his heart]. (So in the T.) And fuw^aAdaka bi$arobapK ↓ bar~ido Cool thy heart by a draught. (A.) And AisoqiniY sawiyqFA A^aborudo bihi kabidiY [Give thou me to drink swyq with which I may cool my liver]. (T.) And barada Eayonuhu biAlokuHoli, (A'Obeyd, T, M,) or biAlobaruwdi, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He cooled his eye with the collyrium, or] he applied the cooling collyrium to his eye, (T, * S, M, * Msb, K, *) and allayed its pain. (M.) The following words, cited by IAar,
baraduwA gawaAriba A^ayonuqK Hudobi
[lit. They cooled the fore parts of the humps, or the backs, of humped she-camels], mean (tropical:) they put off from them their saddles, that their backs might become cool. (M.) You say also, ↓ bar~ido Zahora farasika saAEapF (tropical:) Relieve thy horse from riding [lit. cool his back] awhile. (A.) And ↓ laA tubar~ido Eano fulaAnK (tropical:) Do not thou alleviate the punishment [in the world to come] due to the offence of such a one by thy reviling him, or cursing him, when he has acted injuriously to thee. (T, S, * M, * A, * L.) And barada Alxuboza, (T, L, K,) biAlomaA='i, (T,) He poured [cold] water upon the bread, (T, L, K,) and moistened it [therewith: see baruwdN]. (T, L.) ― -b2- burida (a verb like EuniYa, K) It (a company of men) was hailed upon. (S, M, K.) And buridati. AlA^aruDu The land, or ground, was hailed upon. (S.) -A3- barada, (S, M, &c.,) aor
baruda , (TA,) inf. n. barodN, (Mgh, TA,) also signifies He filed (M, Mgh, K) iron, (S, M, &c.,) and the like, (M,) with a miborad.(S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) -A4- baradahu and ↓ Abrdhu He sent him as a bariyd [or messenger on a postmule or post-horse]. (K.) And barada barydFA, (M,) and ↓ Abrdhu, (A,) He sent a bryd. (M, A.) And A_iloyahi ↓ Abrd, (S,) or Alyh bariydFA ↓ Abrd, (T, TA.) He sent to him a bryd. (T, S.)

2 bar~ada see baradahu, in four places. ― -b2- br~dhu Ealayohi (tropical:) He made it incumbent, or obligatory, on him. (M, A.) ― -b3- And br~dhu, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) inf. n. taboriydN; (TA;) and ↓ Abrdhu; (M, K;) (tropical:) It (a thing, M) made him, or rendered him, weak; weakened him; (K;) or made him, or rendered him, weak and languid. (M.) -A2- [br~d also signifies, as is indicated in the TA voce HubaAHibN, It (a locust) spread forth its wings; which are termed its burodaAni: see burodN.]

4 Abrd A^brd Abrd brd
He entered upon a cold, or cool, time: (Mgh, Msb:) he entered upon the last part of the day: (M, K:) he entered upon the time when the sun had declined: (Mohammad Ibn-Kaab, T:) and he entered upon the cool season, at the end of the summer. (Lth, T.) [Hence,] A^aboriduwA biAlT~aEaAmi Delay ye to eat food until it is cool: occurring in a trad. (El-Munáwee.) And A^aboriduwA biAlZ~uhori (T, A, Mgh, Msb) Defer ye the noon-prayers until the cooler time of the day, when the vehemence of the heat shall have become allayed. (Mgh, Msb.) And A^aborido Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyripa Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (M, and L in art. fyH.) ― -b2- Abrdlahu He gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (M, K.) You say also, saqayotuhu faA^aboradotu lahu, meaning I gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b3- Abrdhu He brought it cold, or cool. (M, K.) ― -b4- See baradahu, first sentence. ― -b5- And see 2. -A2- See also 1, in four places; last three sentences.

5 tbr~d fiyhi tbrd fyh tbrd fyp
He descended into it, (i. e., into water, TA,) and washed himself in it, to refresh himself by its coolness. (M, K.) See also 8. ― -b2- tbr~d also signifies (assumed tropical:) He became weakened. (TA.)

8 Abtrd A^btrd Abtrd {btrd
He washed himself with cold water: (S:) and likewise, (S,) or AbtrdAlmaA='a, (K,) he drank water to cool his liver: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he poured the water cold upon himself, (M, K,) meaning, upon his head: (M:) and biAlomaA'i ↓ tbr~d, (T, A,) and Abtrd, (A,) he washed himself with water, or with the water. (T.)
10 Astbrd Ealayohi lisaAnahu Astbrd Elyh lsAnh Astbrd Elyh lsAnp (tropical:) He let loose his tongue and used it like a file against him. (A.)

barodN brd rd and ↓ buruwdapN [originally inf. ns.] Cold; coldness; chill; chilness; cool, as a subst.; coolness; the former, contr. of Har~N; (S, M, A, Msb;) and the latter, of HaraArapN. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former, (tropical:) Pleasantness; enjoyment; ease; comfort: as in the saying, nasoA^aluka Aljan~apa wa barodahaA (tropical:) We ask of Thee Paradise and its pleasantness, &c. (L.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Sleep: (T, S, M, A, K:) [an inf. n. used as a subst.:] so in the Kur lxxviii. 24: (S, M, K:) for sleep cools a man: (TA:) or, accord. to I'Ab, it there means the coldness, or coolness, of beverage. (T.) You say, manaEa Albaradu Albaroda (assumed tropical:) The hail prevented sleep. (A.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Saliva: (Th, T, M, K:) so, accord. to Th, in the saying of El-'Arjee,
wa A_ino $iy^oti lamo A^aToEamu nuqaAxFA wa laA barodaA
And if thou desire, I will not taste sweet water, nor saliva [from any lips but thine]. (T, M, * TA. [But this is cited in the S as an ex. of barod signifying sleep.]) ― -b5- See also baAridN. ― -b6- [Hence,] AlbarodaAni: see AlA^aboradaAni, voce A^aboradu.

burodN brd rd
A kind of garment; (S;) a kind of striped garment: (M, K:) accord. to some, of the description termed wa$oYN [or variegated]: (M:) or particular kinds thereof are distinguished by such terms as burodu EaSobK and burodu wa $oYK: (Msb:) also, (as a coll. gen. n., TA,) garments of the kind called A^akosiyapN, [pl. of kisaA='N,] which are wrapped round the body; (K;) one of which is called ↓ burodapN: (M, K:) or, as Lth says, the burod is [a] well-known [garment], of the kind called buruwdu AlEaSobi and buruwdu Alwa$oYi; (T;) but the ↓ burodapN is a garment of the kind called kisaA='N, four-sided, black, and somewhat small, worn by the Arabs of the desert: (T, S, Mgh, * Msb, * TA:) or this latter (the brdp) is a striped garment of the kind called $amolapN: (T:) or it is an oblong piece of woollen cloth, fringed: (M:) Sh says, I saw an Arab of the desert wearing a piece of woollen cloth resembling a napkin, wrapped round the body like an apron; and on my saying to him, What dost thou call it? he answered, burodap: (T:) [the modern brdp, in every case in which I have seen it, I have observed to be an oblong piece of thick woollen cloth, generally brown or of a dark or ashy dust-colour, and either plain, or having stripes so narrow and near together as to appear, at a little distance, of one colour; used both to envelop the person by day and as a night-covering: the brdp of Mohammad is described as about seven feet and a half in length, and four and a half in width, and in colour either A^axoDar or A^aHomar, i. e. of a dark or ashy dust-colour or brown; for such are the significations of these two epithets when applied to a garment of this kind, and in some other cases:] the pl. of burodN is A^aborudN (M, K) and A^aboraAdN [both pls. of pauc.] and buruwdN (S, M, K) and buradN, (IAar, T,) or this last is pl. of burodapN, (S, M,) and biraAdN, like as qiraATN is pl. of quroTN, or this, also, is pl. of burodapN, like as biraAmN is pl. of buromapN. (M.) ― -b2- *uwburodK, as opposed to *uw kisaA='i, means (assumed tropical:) A rich man. (S in art. Ej.) ― -b3- waqaEa bayonuhumaA qad~u buruwdK yumonapK, (so in copies of the K, in the TA yumanapK,) or buruwdK vamiynapK, (so in a copy of the A,) (tropical:) [There happened between them two the rending of buruwd of the fabric of El-Yemen, accord. to the reading in the K, or of costly buruwd, accord. to the reading in the A,] means they arrived at a great, or severe, state of affairs; (K;) or is said of two men who have contended together in vehement altercation so that they have rent each other's garments; (A;) [accord. to the reading in the K,] because yumanN, [in the CK yumon,] which are buruwd of El-Yemen, are not rent save on account of some great, or severe, thing, or affair. (K.) ― -b4- ↓ humaA fiY burodapi A^axomaAsK means (assumed tropical:) They two do one deed; or act alike; (IAar, M, K;) and resemble each other, as though they were in one burodap: (IAar, M:) or they two have become near together, and in a state of agreement. (K in art. xms, q. v.) ― -b5- And ↓ salaba AlS~ahobaA='a burodatahaA(tropical:) He, or it, deprived the wine of its colour. (A.) ― -b6- And burodaA AljaraAdi, (T,) or Aljunodabi, (S,) (assumed tropical:) The two wings [of the locust, or of the species called jndb]. (T, S.) ― -b7- And ↓burodapu AlD~aA^oni(assumed tropical:) A certain sort of milk. (K.)

baradN brd rd
Hail; what descends from the clouds, resembing pebbles; (M, Msb;) frozen rain; (Lth, T;) what is called Hab~u AlgamaAmi (S, A, Msb, K) and Hab~u Almuzoni (Msb) [i. e. the grains, or berries, of the clouds: a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, signifying a hailstone].

baridN brd rd
Possessing coldness or coolness: an epithet applied to the [plant called] Sil~iyaAn. (S.) ― -b2- saHaAbN baridN, (T, S, M, K,) and ↓ A^aboradu, (S, K,) Clouds containing hail (T, S, M, K *) and cold. (T.) You say also saHaAbapN baridapN A cloud containing hail (T, S, M, A *) and cold; (T;) but not sHAbp barodaA='u. (M.)

barodapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp : see baAridN: -A2- and see also baradapN. -A3- hiYa laka barodapa nafosahaA She is purely thine; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, M;) syn. xaAliSapF: (M:) A'Obeyd explains it by xaAliSFA, (T, S, M,) not in the fem. form, (TA,) on the authority of Fr. (T.) ― -b2- huwa liY barodapa yamiyniY,
(A'Obeyd, M,) or huwa libarodapi yamiyniY, (S,) He, or it, is known to me. (A'Obeyd, S, M.) -A4- barodapu a proper name applied to The ewe. (K.)
burodapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp : see burodN, in five places.

baradapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp (T, S, M, A, &c.) and ↓ barodapN (T, M, K) Indigestion; a malady arising from unwholesome food: (S, M, A, L, Msb, K:) or heaviness of food to the stomach: (IAar, T, L:) so termed because it makes the stomach cold. (T, L, Msb.) It is said in a trad., A^aSolu kul~i daA='K Albaradapu [The origin of every disease is indigestion]. (T, S, M, * A.) -A2- Also, the former, The middle of the eye. (K.)

buradaA='u brdA='
An ague; i. e. a fever attended by a cold fit, (K,) or by shivering. (TA.)

barodiy~N brd brdY brdy rd rdY
A well-known kind of plant, (S, M, * K,) of which the kind of paper termed qiroTaAs is made; (TA in art. qrTs, q. v. ;) [namely, papyrus; and] of which mats are made; (Msb;) [app. meaning rushes in general: but the former is generally meant by it in the present day, and is probably the proper signification: anciently, mats, as well as ropes and sails &c., were made of the rind of the papyrus; and even small boats were constructed of its stalks bound together; and of such, probably, was the ark in which the infant Moses was exposed: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. barodiy~apN. (M, TA.) Hence, qaTonu AlbarodiY~ The cotton of the papyrus, which, resembling wool, is gathered from the stalk, and, mixed with lime, composes a very tenacious kind of cement. (Golius, from Ibn-Maaroof.) ― -b2- [Also, a rel. n. from the same, meaning Of, or belonging to, or resembling, the plant so called. Hence the saying,] lahaA saAqN barodiy~apN [She has a shank like a papyrus-stalk]. (A.)

burodiY~N brd brdY brdy rd rdY
One of the most excellent sorts of dates: (S, Msb:) an excellent sort of dates, (AHn, M, K,) resembling the baroniY~: (AHn, M:) or a sort of dates of El-Hijáz. (TA.)

[
barodaAnN brdAn
Feeling cold or chilly or cool: fem. with p: perhaps post-classical; for I have not found it mentioned in any of the lexicons.]
buraAdN brAd : see baAridN. -A2- Also Weakness of the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) [See also 1.]

baruwdN brwd rwd : see baAridN. ― -b2- Beverage that cools the heat of thirst. (T.) ― -b3- Also, (T, L, K,) and ↓ maboruwdN, (T, M, A, L, K,) Bread upon which water is poured; (T, L, K;) which is moistened with cold water: (A:) eaten by women to make them fat. (M, A, L.) The subst. applied to such bread is ↓ bariydN (A.) ― -b4- baruwdN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] also signifies Cold water which one pours upon his head. (M.) ― -b5- Anything with which a thing is rendered cold, or cooled. (S, M.) ― -b6- A collyrium which cools the eye; (Lth, T, M, Msb;) also termed baruwdu AlEayoni. (T, S.) ― -b7- baruwdu AlZ~il~i (assumed tropical:) Pleasant in social intercourse: applied alike to the male and the female. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- vawobN baruwdN A garment without nap: (K:) and a garment that is not warm nor soft. (TA.)

bariydN bryd : see baruwdN. -A2- Also A mule appointed [for the conveyance of messengers] in a ribaAT [or public building for the accommodation of travellers and their beasts, or in a sik~ap, which is a house or the like specially appropriated to messengers and the beasts that carry them: thus it signifies a postmule: afterwards, it was applied also to a posthorse, and any beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers]: (Mgh:) [this is what is meant by the words in the S and K, Albariydu Almurat~abu:] it is a word of Persian origin, (Z in the Fáïk,) arabicized, from buriydaho dumo, (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh,) i. e. “docked,” or “having the tail cut off;” for the post-mules (bigaAlu Albariydi) had their tails cut off in order that they might be known: (Z in the Fáïk:) [or perhaps it is from the Hebrew פֶּרֶד “a mule:”] or it is applied to the beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers (daAb~apu Albariydi) because he traverses the space called bariyd [defined below: but the reason before given for this appellation is more probable: it is like the Lat. “veredus”]: (T, Msb:) pl. burudN (Z, Mgh, Msb) and burodN, which is a contraction of the former, like as rusolN is of rusulN. (Z.) You say, Humila fulaAnN EalaY Albariyid [Such a one was borne on the postmule or post-horse]. (S.) Imra-el-Keys speaks of a bryd of the horses of Barbar. (S.) ― -b2- Having been originally used in the sense first explained above, it was afterwards applied to A messenger borne on a post-mule [or post-horse]: (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh:) or messengers on beasts of the post: (M, K:) or a messenger that journeys with haste: (A:) or [simply] a messenger: (S, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (M, * Z.) Hence the saying, AlHum~aY bariydu Almawoti Fever is the messenger of death: (T, Msb:) because it gives warning thereof. (T.) Hence also Albariydu applied to The animal called AlfuraAniqu, (said to be the jackal, but some say otherwise, TA,) because he gives warning before [the approach of] the lion. (T, S, K.) And SaAHibu Albariyid [The master of the messengers that journey on post-mules or post-horses]. (S.) [And xayolN Albariyid, occurring in many histories &c., The post-horses, that carry messengers and others.] ― -b3- Also, having been applied to a messenger on a post-mule [or post-horse], it then became applied to The space, or distance, traversed by the messenger thus called; (Mgh, Msb; *) the space, or distance, between each sik~ap and the sik~ap next to it; the sk~p being a structure of either of the kinds called bayot and qub~ap, or a ribaAT [explained above], in which the appointed messengers lodge; (Z in the Fáïk;) the space, or distance, between two stations, or places of alighting; or two parasangs, or leagues; (M, K;) [six miles;] each parasang, or league, being three miles, and each mile being four thousand cubits: (TA:) or twelve miles; (S, A, Msb, K;) i. e. four parasangs, or leagues: (Mgh, TA:) [for] the space, or distance, between each station termed sik~ap and the next to it is either two parasangs or four: (Z in the Fáïk:) the distance of twelve miles is [also] termed sik~apu Albariyid: (T:) the pl. is as above. (T, Z.) A journey of four burud, or forty-eight miles, renders it allowable to shorten prayers; which miles are of the Háshimee measure, such as are measured on the road to Mekkeh. (T.) ― -b4- Also The course, or pace, of a camel along the space thus called: so in the following verse of Muzarrid, in praise of 'Arábeh El-Owsee:
fadatoka EaraAba Alyawoma A^um~iY wa xaAlatiY
wa naAqatiYa Aln~aAjiY A_ilayoka bariyduhaA
[May my mother, and my maternal aunt, and my she-camel that is swift in her course to thee from one station to another, be ransoms for thee, O 'Arábeh, (the name being contracted,) this day!]. (S.)

buraAdapN brAd brAdh brAdp
Filings; (M, Mgh, K;) what falls from iron [&c.] when filed. (S.)
buruwdapN brwd brwdh brwdp rwd : see barodN.

bar~aAdapN brAd brAdh brAdp
A vessel which cools water: (M, K:) or a kaw~aAzap [app. meaning either a stand, or a shelf, upon which mugs (kiyzaAn, pl. of kuwz,) are placed; erroneously in the K, kuw~aArapN, and kuwaArapN, as I find it in different copies;] upon which water is cooled: (Lth, T, K: *) but [Az says,] I know not whether it be a classical or a post-classical word. (T.) Hence the saying, baAtato kiyzaAnuhumo EalaY Albar~aAdapi Their mugs passed the night upon the br~Adp. (A, TA.)

baAridN A^rd bA^rd bArd (S, M, Msb, K) Cold; chill; cool; (S, Msb;) applied to water [&c.]; (M, K;) as also ↓ barodN, [originally an inf. n., like EadolN, used as an epithet,] (M, K,) and ↓ baruwdN, (S, M, K,) and ↓ buraAdN; (M, K;) but the last two are intensive forms [signifying very cold or chill or cool]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Anything loved, beloved, liked, or approved. (TA.) [Hence,] Eayo$N baArdN (tropical:) An easy and a pleasant life, or state of life. (ISk, * T, * M, A, L, K.) And layolapN baAridapN AlEayo$i, and AlEayo$i ↓ barodapu, [the latter written in the TT baradapu AlEy$,] (tropical:) A night of easy and pleasant life. (M, L.) And ganymapN baAridapN: see the latter word. ― -b3- samuwmN baAridN (tropical:) A hot wind that is constant, continual, permanent, settled, or incessant. (S, L.) ― -b4- liY Ealayohi A^alofN baAridN (tropical:) A thousand [pieces of money &c.] are incumbent, or obligatory, on him, to me, and established against him; or are owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (S, M. *) ― -b5- jaA='a fulaAnN baAridFA mux~uhu, and baArida AlEiZaAma, (tropical:) Such a one came in a lean, or an emaciated, state: in the contr. case, one says, HaAr~aA mux~uhu, and HaAr~a AlEiZaAmi. (A, TA.) ― -b6- [baAridN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Blunt; applied to a sword and the like: see 1. ― -b7- And, contr., (assumed tropical:) Sharp: for you say,] murohafaAtN bawaAridu [pl. of baAridapN, meaning] (assumed tropical:) Sharp, or cutting, swords: (TA:) or slaying swords. (S.)

baAridapN A^rd bA^rdh bArd bArdh bArdp (assumed tropical:) Spoil acquired without fatigue; (IAar, T;) also termed ganiymapN baAridapN; and to this is likened, by the Prophet, fasting in winter. (T.) Also (assumed tropical:) Gain made by merchandise at the time of one's buying it. (IAar, T.)

A^aboradu * [More, and most, cold, or chill, or cool]. ― -b2- [Hence,] AlA^aboradaAni and ↓ AlbarodaAni The morning,
between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; (T, S, M, K;) also called AlEaSoraAni (S, K) and AlS~aroEaAni and Alr~idofaAni: (T:) or (as in the S, but in the M and K “and”) the morning-shade and evening-shade: (S, M, K:) so called because of their coldness, or coolness. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baridN. ― -b4- vaworN A^aboradu A bull upon which are spots, or patches, of white and black: (S, M:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.) ― -b5- And AlA^aboradu The leopard: fem. with p: (T, K: [but in the TT, the fem. is written like the masc.:]) pl. AlA^abaAridu. (T, K.) The female is also called Alxayovamapu. (T.)

A_iboradapu A^brd A^brdh Abrdh Abrdp brd , (S, M, &c.,) with kesr (S, Mgh, K) to the ' and the r (Mgh, TA,) [in the CK Aiboradap,] Cold in the belly, or inside; (M, K;) a well-known malady, arising from the prevalence of cold and humidity, and preventing one, by languor, from performing the act of coition: (S, Mgh:) and a dripping of the urine, which prevents a man's taking pleasure in women. (T, L.) ― -b2- Also Coldness of the damp earth, and of rain. (M, L.) An Arab says, A_in~ahaA labaAridapN Alyawoma [Verily it (the morning, AlgadaApu, L) is cold to-day]; and another says to him, layosato bibaAridapK A_in~amaA hiYa A_iboridapu Alv~araY [It is not cold: it is only the coldness of the damp earth]. (S, L.)
muboradN mbrd [pass. part. n. of 4]. You say, A^aroDN muboradapN: see maboruwdN.

muboridN mbrd [act. part. n. of 4]. You say, jiy^onaAka muboridiyna We came to thee when the heat had become allayed. (T.) -A2- Also One sending, or who sends, a bariyd [or burud, i. e., a messenger on a post-mule or posthorse, or messengers on post-mules or post-horses]. (S.)

miboradN mbrd (S, K, &c.) A file; (M;) syn. suwhaAnN; (M, K;) which is a Persian word: (M:) pl. mabaAridu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaEala lisaAnihi Ealayohi muboridFA (tropical:) [He made his tongue like a file upon him; i. e.] he annoyed him, or hurt him, with his tongue, and vituperated him. (A.) [See a saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir voce jin~N.]

maboradapN mbrd mbrdh mbrdp [A cause of coldness or coolness]. You say, h`*aA Al$~aYo'u maboradapN lilobadani [This thing is a cause of coldness, or coolness, to the body]: and As relates that he said to an Arab of the desert, “What induceth thee to take a sleep in the morning while the sun is yet low?” and he answered, A_in~ahaA maboradapN fiY AlS~ayofi masoxanapN fiY Al$~itaA='i [Verily it is a cause of coolness in the summer, and a cause of warmth in the winter]. (S, A.)
mubar~adN mbrd : see what follows.

maboruwdN mbrwd
Made, or rendered, cold or chill or cool: (S, Msb, K:) [and ↓ mubar~adN signifies the same in an intensive manner:] applied to water [&c.: or signifying mixed with snow: see baradahu]. (K.) ― -b2- $ajarapN maboruwdapN A tree deprived of its leaves by the cold. (AHn, M.) ― -b3- A^aroDN maboruwdapN (M, A, K) and ↓ muboradapN (K) Land, or ground, hailed upon: (M, K:) or snowed upon. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also baruwdN.
barodaEapN brdEh brdEp rdE : see baro*aEapN.
baro*aEN * : see what next follows.

baro*aEapN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and barodaEapN (Msb, K) A [cloth of the kind called] Hilos which is put beneath the [saddle called] raHol (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of the camel: (Mgh:) pl. baraA*iEu (Mgh, Msb) and baraAdiEu (Msb.) Ru-beh says, [using the sing. without the p as a coll. gen. n.,]
↓ wa taHota A^aHonaA='i Alr~iHaAli Albaro*aEu
[And beneath the curved pieces of wood of the camels' saddles are the bardha'ahs]. (TA.) ― -b2- This is the primary signification: but in the conventional language of our time, it is applied to An ass's saddle; the thing upon which one rides on an ass, like the saroj to the horse; (Msb;) [i. e. a pad, or stuffed saddle; generally stuffed with straw; and used for a mule as well as for an ass;] or an ass's br*Ep is a saddle like the raHol and qatab. (TA voce A_ikaAfN, q. v.) -A2- baro*aEapN also signifies Land which is neither hard nor soft: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.)

baraA*iEiY~N *
A maker of baraA*iEu, pl. of baro*aEapN: a rel. n. similar to A^anomaATiY~N. (TA.)

Q. 1 baro*ana * , (M, K,) inf. n. baro*anapN, (T,) He (a horse) went in the manner of the biro*awon, q. v. (T, M, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish: whence IDrd thinks biro*awonN to be derived: (M, Msb:*) but this opinion is of no account. (M.) ― -b3- He was unable to reply, (T, K,) when asked respecting a thing. (T.) ― -b4- He subdued, overpowered, or overcame: (K: [expl. by qahara and galaba; but I think that the right reading may be quhira and guliba, meaning he was, or became, subdued, &c.:]) said of a man. (TA.)

biro*awonN * [A horse of mean breed, or of coarse make; a jade: but commonly applied to a hack, or hackney; a horse for ordinary use, and for journeying:] a daAb~ap, (S, K,) not in an absolute sense, but of a particular sort, namely, (MF,) a horse that is not of Arabian breed: (T, MF:) or a heavy, or sluggish, dAb~p: (so in a copy of the S:) or a coarse horse: (Towsheeh, TA:) or a horse of coarse make, hardy so as to endure travel upon the mountain-roads and rugged ground, not of Arabian breed, mostly brought from Er-Room [meaning Asia Minor or Greece]: (TA, from the Expos. of the 'Irákeeyeh of Es-Sakháwee:) or a horse of large and coarse make, with thick limbs; whereas those of Arabian breed are light of flesh, lank in the belly, and more slender in the limbs: (El-Bájee, TA:) or a Turkish horse; opposed to Arabian: (Mgh, Msb:) or a pacinghorse; syn. rahawaAnN: (TA voce himolaAjN:) fem. with p; (Ks, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) sometimes; but without p it is applied to the female as well as the male: (IAmb, Msb:) pl. baraA*iynN (T, S, Mgh, K.)

mubaro*inN *
An owner of a biro*awon: (K:) or a rider thereon. (TA.)

1 baraza brz rz , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
baruza , (S, TA,) inf. n. buruwzN, (S, Msb, TA,) He (a man, S) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth; he issued. (S, A.) He (a man, TA) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (K:) or did so to satisfy a want of nature: (TS, TA:) as also, in the former sense, (K,) or in the latter, (S,) ↓ tbr~z; (S, K, TA;) and bariza; (Sgh, TA;) and so, in the former sense, ↓ br~z inf. n. taboriyzN; (Har p. 510;) [and in the latter sense, ↓ bArz accord. to an explanation of its part. n. mubaArizN in Har p. 566:] or ↓ tbr~z signifies he voided his excrement, or ordure. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, barazaA_ilaY Alqironi fiY AlHarobi He went, or came, out, or forth, into the field to his adversary in battle or war. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, (a man, TA, or thing, Msb, or anything, Fr,) appeared, or became apparent, (Fr, Sgh, Msb, K,) after concealment, (Fr, K,) or after obscurity; (Sgh;) as also bariza (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- [It was, or became, prominent, or projecting: often used in this sense.] -A2- baruza, (Msb, K,) inf. n. baraAzapN, (Msb,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed barozN q. v.: (Msb, K:) and in like manner, baruzato, inf. n. as above, she (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed barozapN (A.)

2 br~zhu brz brzh brzp rz rzp , (inf. n. taboriyzN, S, K,) He made it apparent, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, or manifested, it; (S, A, K;) namely, a writing, or book, (A,) or other thing; (S, A;) as also ↓ Abrzhu: (A, Msb:) or AlkitaAba ↓ Abrz signifies he put forth, or produced, the writing, or book; syn. A^axorajahu: (TA:) and [as it often signifies in the present day,] published, it; syn. na$arahu. (K, TA.) [See also 4 below.] It is said in the Kur [xxvi. 91 and lxxix. 36], wa bur~izati AljaHiymu, meaning And Hell shall be uncovered. (A.) ― -b2- br~z raAkibahu He (a horse) saved his rider. (K.) -A2- See also 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] br~z Alfarasu, (S, Msb,) or br~z EalaY Alxayoli, (K,) inf. n. taboriyzN, (Msb,) The horse outstripped (S, Msb, K) the [other] horses (Msb, K) in the race-ground: (Msb:) it is said of a horse that outstrips in a race: and, accord. to some, the like is said of whatever outstrips: (TA:) and br~z EalaY AlgaAyapi [He (a horse) passed beyond the goal]. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, br~z fiY AlEilomi, inf. n. as above, He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows in knowledge. (Msb.) And [simply] br~z He surpassed his companions (S, K) in excellence, or in courage. (K.) And br~z EalaY A^aqoraAnihi [He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows, or his opponents]. (A.) -A3- See also 4, last signification.

3 bArzhu fiY AlHarobi bArzh fy AlHrb , (A, Msb,* K*) inf. n.
mubaArazapN and biraAzN (S, A, Msb, K,) He went, or came, out, or forth, in the field, to [encounter] him (i. e. his adversary) in battle, or war. (K,* TA.) -A2- See also 1.

4 Abrzhu A^brz A^brzh Abrzh Abrzp brz
He made, or caused, him (a man) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth: (S:) [or to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (see 1:)] and he made, or caused, it (a thing) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth; or he put it, or took it, or drew it, out, or forth; syn. A^axorajahu; as also ↓ Astbrzhu. (K.) See also 2, in two places. -A2- Abrz He determined, resolved, or decided, upon journeying: (IAar, K:) the vulgar say ↓ br~z (TA.)
5 tabar~aza see 1, in two places.

6 humaA yatabaArazaAni hmA ytbArzAn
They two (meaning two adversaries) go, or come, out, or forth, into the field, each to [encounter] the other, in battle or war. (K,* TA.) ― -b2- tbArzA They both separated themselves, each from his company, and betook themselves each to the other. (K.)
10 A_isotaboraza see 4.

barozN brz rz A man characterized by pleasing or goodly aspect, and by intelligence: fem. with p: (S, TA:) or a man of open condition or state: (TA:) or pure in disposition; (TA;) abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous; (S, A, Msb:) of great dignity or estimation: (Msb:) fem. with p: (A, Msb:) pl. fem. barozaAtN: (A:) or, as also ↓ baroziY~N a man who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and in whose intelligence, (K,) or, as in some copies of the K, in whose excellence, bifaDolihi, but this is app. a mistranscription, or, as some say, in whose abstinence from what is unlawful and indecorous, (TA,) and his judgment, confidence is placed: (K:) and barozapN a woman whose good qualities or actions, or whose beauties, are apparent: (K:) or open in her converse; syn. mutaAjirapN: or, as in some correct lexicons, disdainful of mean things; syn. mutajaAl~apN: or of middle age, (kaholapN,) who is not veiled or concealed like young women: (TA:) or of great dignity or estimation: (AO, TA:) or who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit, and of whom they talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and is intelligent: (TA:) or who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and goes or comes forth to men, and talks with them, and is advanced in age beyond those women who are kept concealed: (Mgh, Msb:) or open in her converse, (mutajaAhirapN,) of middle age, (kaholapN,) of great dignity or estimation, who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit and talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous: (K:) or in whose judgment, and her abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous, confidence is placed: (TA:) or who does not veil her face from a man and bend her head down towards the ground. (IAar, on the authority of Ibn-EzZubeyr.)
baroziY~N brzY brzy rz : see barozN

baraAzN brAz
A field, plain, or wide expanse of land, (S, Msb, K,) without trees; (Msb;) as also ↓ biraAzN; but this latter form is rare: (Msb:) or an open tract of land destitute of herbage and trees and without hills or mountains: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, S:) an open place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, S:) an open place in which is no covert. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaraja A_ilaY AlbaraAzi (tropical:) He went forth to satisfy a want of nature. (A.) And A_i*aA A^araAda AlbaraAza A^aboEada (tropical:) [When he desired to satisfy a want of nature, he went far off]: a trad.; respecting which El-Khattábee says that the relaters of traditions err respecting the word, pronouncing it with kesr, for ↓ biraAzN is an inf. n.: but (SM says that) authorities differ as to this point. (TA.) ― -b3- [It is further said,] baraAzN, (Mgh, Msb,) or ↓ biraAzN (S, K,) is metonymically applied to (tropical:) Excrement; human ordure; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the feces of food. (S.)
biraAzN brAz : see baraAzN, in three places.

baArizN A^rz bA^rz bArz rz act. part. n. of baraza [q. v.]. ― -b2- Wholly, or entirely, apparent or manifest. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aroDN baArizapN Land that is apparent, open, or uncovered, (Bd and Jel in xviii. 45, and TA,) upon which is no mountain nor any other thing, (Jel,) or that has no hill nor mountain nor sand. (TA.)
A_iboriziY~N A^brz A^brzy A^brzyy AbrzY Abrzy : see what next follows.

A_iboriyzN A_bryz Abryz (Sh, IAar, A, Msb, K) and ↓ A_iboriziY~N, (Sh, IAar, K,) the latter of which is incorrectly written in [some of] the copies of the K A_iboriyziY~N, (TA,) Pure gold: (Sh, Msb, K:) or an ornament of pure gold: (IAar:) the former an arabicized word [app. from the Greek ὄβρυζον, as also the latter]: (Msb:) of the measure A_ifoEiylN; the ' and Y being augmentative. (IJ.)

maborazN mbrz [lit. A place to which one goes forth in the field, or plain, or open tract or country;] a privy, or place where one performs ablution; syn. mutawaD~aA^o; (S;) [as also ↓ mutabar~azN, occurring in the TA in art. jwz.]

kitaAbN muborazN ktAb mbrz , (K,) and ↓ maboruwzN, (S, Msb, K,) A writing, or book, put forth, or published; syn. mano$uwrN: (S, K:) or made apparent, shown, or manifested: (Msb:) ↓ the latter anomalous; (S, Msb;) being from A^aboraza; (Msb;) and AHát disapproved it; and thought that it might be a mistake for mazobuwrN, meaning “written;” but it [is said that it] occurs in two poems of Lebeed: (S:) in one of these instances, however, for Almaboruwzu, some read Almuborazu; and Sgh says that he found not the other instance in the poems of Lebeed: IJ says that ↓ AlmaboruwzN is for AlmaboruwzN bihi. (TA.) You say, ↓ qado A^aEoTawohu kitaAbFA maboruwzFA They had given him a writing, or book, published; i. e., mano$uwrFA. (TA.)
maboruwzN mbrwz : see muborazN, throughout.
mutabar~azN mtbrz : see maborazN.

barozaxN brzx
A thing that intervenes between any two things: (L:) or a bar, an obstruction, or a thing that makes a separation, between two things: (S, A, L, K:) so in the Kur lv. 20: pl. baraAzixu. (L.) ― -b2- The interval between the present life and that which is to come, (S, A,) from the period of death to the resurrection, (S, A, K,) upon which he who dies enters; (S, K;) the period, or state, from the day of death to the day of resurrection: so in the Kur xxiii. 102. (Fr.) ― -b3- baraAzixu AlA_iymaAni What is between the beginning of faith, (L, K,) which is the acknowledgment, or confession, of God, (L,) and the end thereof, (L, K,) which is the removal of what is hurtful from the road: (L:) or what is between doubt and certainty. (L, K.)

Q. 1 burosima brsm rsm
He (a man) was affected with the disease termed birosaAm; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also bulosima. (TA.)

birosaAmN brsAm rsAm , (in the T with fet-h, [barosaAmN,] Mgh,) A certain malady, or disease, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (S, Msb,) attended by delirium: (K:) [in the present day, this term is applied to the pleurisy, as also *aAtu Aljanobi; and so it is explained by Golius and Freytag; or, as the latter adds, accord. to Avicenna, pleurodyne: but] in some of the books of medicine, it is said to be a tumour, (Msb,) or a hot tumour, (TA,) that is incident to the septum which is between the liver and the bowels, [app. meaning the upper parts of the greater and lesser omentum,] and then reaches to the brain: (Msb, TA:) also pronounced bilosaAmN: (ISk, Msb:) i. q. muwmN: (M, TA:) it is an arabicized word; (IDrd, Mgh, Msb;) or seems to be so; composed of baro and saAmo; the former of these, in Persian, signifying the “breast,” or “chest;” and the latter, “death” [and “fire” and “a swelling;” of which three meanings, the second and third are agreeable with the two explanations of brsAm given above]: so says Az. (TA.)

birosiymN brsym , with kesr, (K,) vulgarly pronounced with fet-h to the b, [barosiym,] (TA,) [Alexandrian trefoil or clover; trifolium Alexandrinum; described by Forskål in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 139; the most common and the best kind of succulent food for cattle grown in Egypt: it is sown when the waters of the inundation are leaving the fields; and yields three crops; the second of which is termed rib~apN; and so is the third; but this is generally left for seed: when dry, it is termed dariysN: if his words have not been perverted by copyists, F explains it as] the grain of the quroT, (Hab~u AlquroT [but I think it probable that this is a mistranscription, for xayoru AlquroTi, i. e., the best of the (species of trefoil, or clover, called) quroT,] resembling the ruTobap [or raTobap], or superior to this latter in size, or quality (A^ajal~u minohaA): (K:) the quroT resembles the ruTobap, [written in the TA without the vowel signs,] but is superior to this latter in size, or quality (Ajl~ mnhA), and larger in the leaves, and is what is called in Persian $abo*ar [or $abodar]: (AHn, TA:)
it is one of the best kinds of herbage for horses and the like, which fatten upon it. (TA.)
