(K.) ― -b8- bariqa said of a skin, aor.
baraqa , (JK, K,) inf. n. baraqN, (JK,) so in the O, in which, as in the K, the part. n., being bariqN, indicates that the verb is like fariHa; (TA;) and baraqa, (K,) so in the L, (TA,) aor.
baruqa , (K,) inf. n. baroqN and buruwqN; thus in the L, which indicates that the verb is like naSara; (TA;) It became affected by the heat so that its butter melted and became decomposed, (As, JK, K,) and did not become compact. (K.) -A2- baraqa TaEaAmFA, (JK,) or baraqahu bizayotK A^awo samonK (S, K,) aor.
baruqa , (JK,) inf. n. baroqN (JK, S) and buruwqN, (L,) He poured upon the food, (JK,) or put into it, (S, * K,) somewhat, (JK,) or a small quantity, (S, K,) of olive-oil (JK, S, K) or of clarified butter. (S, K.) And baraqotu lahu I made his food [somewhat] greasy for him with clarified butter. (TA.) And A^uboruquwA AlmaA='i bizayotK Pour ye upon the water a little olive-oil. (S.) -A3- bariqati Alganamu, aor.
baraqa , (S, K,) inf. n. baraqN, (S,) The sheep, or goats, had a complaint in their bellies from eating the barowaq: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlA_ibilu the camels. (TA.)

2 br~q biEayonayohi brq bEynyh brq bEynyp , (JK,) or br~q baSarahu, (TA,) He glistened with his eyes by reason of looking hard, or intently. (JK, TA. *) And br~q Eayonayohi, inf. n. taboriyqN, He opened his eyes wide, and looked sharply, or intently. (Lth, S, K.) ― -b2- br~qt, said of a woman: see 1. ― -b3- And br~q He decorated, or adorned, his place of abode. (El-Muärrij, K.) ― -b4- bar~aqota wa Ear~aqota Thou madest a sign with a thing, that had nothing to verify it, [app. meaning thou madest a false display, or a vain promise,] and didst little (IAar.) ― -b5- Also br~q, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He (a man) journeyed far. (El-Muärrij K.) ― -b6- br~q fiY AlmaEaASiY He persisted, or persevered, in acts of disobedience. (El-Muärrij, K.) ― -b7- br~q biYa AlA^amoru The affair was unattainable, or impracticable, to me. (K.)

4 A^aboraqa see 1, in eight places. ― -b2- Abrq, (Aboo-Nasr, S, K,) or Abrq bisayofihi, (JK,) said of a man, (Aboo-Nasr, JK, S,) He made a sign with his sword [by waving it about so as to make it glisten]. (Aboo-Nasr, JK, S, K.) ― -b3- And Abrq He betook himself, or directed his course, towards the lightning. (TA.) ― -b4- He entered into [a tract wherein was] lightning. (TA.) ― -b5- He saw lightning. (TA.) Tufeyl uses the phrase A^aboraqona Alxariyfa as meaning They (women borne in vehicles upon camels) saw the lightning of [the season, or the rain, called] the xryf. (AAF, TA.) ― -b6- He was smitten, or assailed, or affected, by lightning. (S, K.) -A2- Abrqhu AlfazaEu [app. Fright, or fear, made him to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right way: see bariqa]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, perhaps,] Abrq AlS~ayoda He roused the game, or chase. (K.)
5 tabar~aqa see 1, in two places.

10 Astbrq A_stbrq Astbrq
It (a place, and the horizon,) shone, or gleamed, with lightning. (TA.)

baroqN brq rq [Lightning;] what gleams in the clouds, (TA,) or, from the clouds; from baraqa [in the first of the senses explained above], said of a thing, inf. n. [baroqN and] bariyqN: (Bd in ii. 18:) or an angel's smiting the clouds, and putting them in motion, in order that they may become propelled, so that thou seest the fires [issue from them]: (Mujáhid, K:) or a whip of light with which the angel drives the clouds: (I'Ab, TA:) sing. of buruwqN, i. e., of the brwq of the clouds: (S, K:) or it has no pl., being originally an inf. n. (Bd ubi suprà.) baroqu Alxul~abi and baroqu xul~abK and baroqN xul~abN signify That [lightning] which is without rain. (S. [See also art. xlb)]

buroqN brq rq [Lizards of the species called] DibaAb, pl. of Dab~N. (IAar, K.) It is app. pl. of baruwqN or of A^aboraqu: more probably, I think, of the former; from the raising of the tail, which is a habit of those lizards.] -A2- See also buroqapN.

baraqN brq rq
A lamb; syn. HamalN [q. v.]: (S, K:) a Persian word, (S,) arabicized; (S, K;) originally baraho: (K:) pl. [of mult.] buroqaAnN (S, K) and biroqaAnN and [of pauc.] A^aboraAqN. (K.)
bariqN brq rq [part. n. of bariqa: and particularly explained as meaning] A skin affected by the heat so that its butter melts and becomes decomposed, (JK, O, K,) and does not become compact. (K.)

baroqapN brq brqh brqp rq rqp [app. an inf. n. of un., signifying A flash of lightning]. (M, TA in art. wbS.) -A2- A fit of confusion, or perplexity, affecting one in such a manner that he is unable to see his right course. (K, * TA.)

buroqapN brq brqh brqp rq rqp
A quantity of lightning: (Bd in xxiv. 43, TA:) pl. ↓ buroqN; (TA;) or [this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.; or, probably, it is a mistranscription, and] the pl. is buraqN, also pronounced buruqN. (Bd ubi suprà.) -A2- Rugged ground in which are stones and sand and earth mixed together, (S, K, TA,) the stones thereof mostly white, but some being red, and black, and the earth white and of a whitish dust-colour, and sometimes by its side are meadows (rawoD); (TA;) as also ↓ A^aboraqu and ↓ baroqaA='u: (S, K, TA:) or a portion of such land (A^aroD) as is termed ↓ baroqaA='u, which consists of tracts containing black stones mixed with white sand, and which, when spacious, is termed ↓ A^aboraqu: (JK:) [and] a mountain mixed with sand; as also ↓ A^aboraqu: (IAar, TA:) the pl. of buroqapN is buraqN (K, TA) and biraAqN; (JK, S;) and that of ↓ Abrq is A^abaAriqu, (JK, S, K,) after the manner of a subst., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it; (TA;) and that of ↓ brqA=' is baroqaAwaAtN. (As, IAar, S, K.) The buraq of the
country of the Arabs are more than a hundred; and are distinguished by particular adjuncts, as buroqapN AlA^avomaAdi and buroqapu AlA^ajaAwili &c. (K.) One says qunofu*u buroqapK [A hedge-hog of a brqp], like as one says Dab~u kudoyapi (S) ― -b2- [The colour denoted by the epithet A^aboraqu: in a mountain, a mixture of blackness and whiteness: see HaqobaA='u, voce A^aHoqabu.] -A3- Paucity of grease or gravy (JK, TA) in food. (TA.)

buroqaAnN brq brqAn
Shining much in the body: (JK, K:) applied to man. (JK.) -A2- Locusts when they become yellow, and have variegated stripes or streaks: (JK:) or locusts that are variegated (K TA) with white and black: (TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (K.) ― -b2- [See also baraqN of which it is a pl.]

buroquwqN brqwq rq , (K,) with damm, (TA,) [vulg. baroquwq, The plum; or] small A_ij~aAS [or plums]; (K;) known in Syria by the name of jAbzk: (TA:) and (as some say, TA) the mi$omi$ [or apricot]: a post-classical word [probably arabicized from the Persian baroquwqo, which is applied to both the fruits above mentioned]. (K.)

AlburaAqu AlbrAq brAq
A certain beast which Mohammad rode on the night of the ascension [to heaven]; (S, Msb, * K;) or which the apostles ride in ascending to heaven; resembling a mule; (Msb;;) or less than the mule, but greater than the ass: (K:) so called because of the intense whiteness of his hue, and his great brightness; or because of the quickness of his motion; in respect of both of which he is likened to lightning. (TA.)

baruwqN brwq rwq a she-camel raising her tail, and feigning herself pregnant, not being so; as also ↓ muboriqu: (S, K:) and ↓ baAriqN a she-camel Putting her tail between her thighs, making it to cleave to her belly, not being pregnant: (IAar, TA:) pl. of the first buroqN (TA;) and of the second mabaAriyqu. (S, K.) The Arabs say, daEoniY mino tako*aAbika wa taA^ovaAmika $awalaAna Albaruwqi [Let me alone and cease from they lying and thy sin like the she-camel's raising of her tail and feigning herself pregnant when she is not so]: $wlAn being in the accus. case as an inf. n. : i. e., thou art in the predicament of the she-camel that raises her tail so as to make one imagine her to be pregnant when she is not so. (TA.) The pl. buroqN is also applied to scorpions, as meaning Raising their tails like the she-camel termed brwq (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, Fearful, or timid; (JK;) or cowardly. (TA.)

barwaqN brwq rwq
A certain kind of plant (JK, S) which camels do not feed upon except in cases of necessity; (JK;) a small, feeble tree, which, when the sky becomes clouded, grows green: (K:) n. un. witIh p: (S, K:) it was described by an Arab of the desert to AHn as follows: a feeble, juicy plant, having slender branches, at the heads of which are small envelopes (qamaAEiylu SigaArN) like chick-peas, in which is a kind of black grain: its feebleness is such that it withers on the spot when the sun becomes hot upon it: and nothing feeds upon it; but men, when they are afflicted with dearth, or drought, express from it a bitter juice, then work it together, or knead it, with habiyd [or colocynths, or the pulp, or seeds, thereof], or some other thing, and eat it; but it is not eaten alone, because it occasions excitement: it is one of the plants that are plentiful in time of drought and scarce in time of fruitfulness; when copious rain falls upon it, it dies; and when we see it to have become abundant, and coarse, or rough, we fear drought: accord. to another of the Arabs of the desert, the barowaqap is a bad kind of herb, or leguminous plant, that grows among the first of the herbs, or leguminous plants: it has a reed like the sbAT [so I render lhA qSbp mvl AlsbAT, but I thing that the right reading is, lahaA quDubN mivolu Als~iyaATi it has twigs like whips, agreeably with the description next preceding, in which it is said to have slender branches,] and a black fruit, or produce. (TA.) Hence, A^a$okaru mino barowaqapK [More grateful than a barwakah]; (S, K;) because it grows green when it sees the clouds, (S,) or by means of the least moisture falling from the sky: (TA:) a prove. (S.) And A^aDoEafu mino barowaqapK [Weaker than a barwakah]. (TA.)
bariyqN A_bryq bryq ryq [accord. to the Mgh and K an inf. n. of baraqa, but accord. to the S a simple subst.,] A shining, gleaming, glistening, glitter, lustre, brilliancy, or splendour. (S, K, TA.)

bariyqapN A_bryq bryq bryqh bryqp ryq
Milk upon which is poured a little grease or clarified butter: (ISK, S, K:) or food in which is milk: and such as has a little clarified butter, and grease, put into it: (TA:) or food that has a little olive-oil poured upon it: (JK:) or condiment in which is put a little olive-oil or grease: (L:) pl. baraAy^iqu; (JK, S, L, K;) with which ↓ tabaAriyqu [pl. of ↓ taborwqN] is syn., (L, TA,) applied to food (S, TA) in which is put a little olive-oil or clarified butter: (S:) or ↓ taborwqN signifies the grease in a cooking-pot: and water with a little olive-oil poured upon it: and ↓ tabaAriyqu is its pl. (JK.)

bar~aAqN brAq rAq rAqy
Shining, gleaming, or glistening, much, or intensely. (TA.) See also A_iboriyqN, and baAriqN ― -b2- fatFY bar~aAqu Alv~anaAyaA A young man whose middle pairs of teeth are beautiful and bright, glistening, when he smiles, like lightning: meant to imply cheerfulness of countenance. (TA.) ― -b3- bar~aAqapN A woman characterized by beauty and splendour or brilliancy [of complexion or skin]: (K * TA:) or, as some say, who shows her beauty intentionally. (TA.) [See A_iboriyqN.]

barowaAqN brwAq rwAq
A certain plant also called xunovaY [i. e. the asphodel, called by both these names in the present day]: the eating of its fresh, juicy stalk, boiled with olive-oil and vinegar, counteracts jaundice; and the smearing with its root, or lower part, removes the two kinds of bahaq [q. v.]. (K.)

baAriqN A^rq bA^rq bArq b|rq |rq
Shining, gleaming, or glistening. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Clouds (saHaAbN) having, or containing, [or emitting,] lightning. (S.) You say also saHaAbapN baAriqapN[A cloud having, or emitting, lightning]: (S, TA:) and ↓ sHAbp bar~aAqapN signifies the same [but in an intensive manner: see bar~aAqN]. (TA.) ― -b3- baAriqapN (tropical:) Swords: (S, K, TA:) so called because of their shining, or glistening: (TA:) pl. bawaAriqu; (JK, Ham p. 306;) applied to swords and other weapons. (Ham ubi suprà.) Hence the trad. of 'Ammàr, Aljan~apu taHota AlbaAriqapi [Paradise is beneath the swords]; (JK, TA;) meaning, in warring in the cause of God. (JK.) You also say, raA^ayotu AlbaAriqapa meaning I saw the shining, or glistening, of the weapons. (Lh, TA.) ― -b4- See also baruwqN.

baworaqN bwrq wrq , (JK, Mgh,) with fet-h to the b (Mgh,) or buwraqN., with damm, (K,) A certain, thing, or substance, that is put into dough, (JK, Mgh, TA,) and causes it to become inflated; (Mgh;) or into flour; (TA voce buwrakN;) [or this is a particular kind thereof, as appears from what follows: accord. to Golius, nitrum and aphronitrum: but] it is of four kinds; maAy^iY~N [or the water-kind], and jabaliY~N [or the mountain-kind], and A^aromaniY~N [or Armenian], and miSoriY~N [or Egyptian], which is the naToruwn [q. v., i. e. natron]: (K:) the best thereof is the ArmnY; and this is said to be meant by the term when it is used absolutely: this is called also bwrqu AlS~aAgapi [a term now applied to borax, as is bwrq alone, and miloHu AlS~aAgapi], because it polishes silver well [or because of its use in soldering]: the dust-coloured kind thereof is called bwrqu Alxab~aAziyna [the bwrq of the bakers, or makers of bread]: the nTrwn is the red kind thereof: and there is a kind thereof having an oily quality: and a kind consisting of thin butyraceous fragments; and this, if light and hard, is the A_iforiyqiY: and the best thereof is that which is produced in Egypt: (TA:) bruised, or powdered, the belly is smeared with it, near to a fire, and it expels worms: and moistened with honey or with oil of jasmine, the male organs of generation are anointed with it, for it is excellent for the venereal faculty. (K.) -A2- Also A man in whom one does not trust, or confide: pl. bawaAriqu. (JK.)
buwriqiY~N bwrq bwrqY bwrqy wrq wrqy [or baworaqiY~N] A seller of buwraq [or baworaq]. (TA.)

A^aboraqu * A rope (Habol) having two colours; (S, O;) twisted with a black strand and a white strand: (JK:) and in like manner, (JK,) a mountain (jabal, JK, K) in which are two colours, (K, TA,) black and white: (TA:) and (so in the S , but in the K “ or,”) anything having blackness and whiteness together. (S, K.) You say tayosN A^aboraqN and EanozN baroqaA='u [A black and white he-goat and she-goat]: (S, K:) and $aApN baroqaA='u a ewe whose white wool is cleft, or divided, by black flocks [or streaks]: (K:) A^aboraqu and baroqaA='u applied to sheep or goats are like A^abolaqu and baloqaA='u applied to beasts of the equine kind, and A^aboqaEu and baqoEaA='u to dogs. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- baroqaA='u is also a name given to An eye; (S, M;) because it has blackness and whiteness mingled in it: (M, TA:) dual baroqaAwaAni. (TA.) And EayonN baroqaA='u signifies An eye black in the iris, with whiteness [of the rest] of the bulb. (TA.) ― -b3- rawoDapN baroqA='u A meadorc, or garden, in
which are two colours. (TA.) ― -b4- See also buroqapN. in seven places. ― -b5- A^aboraqu also signifies A certain bird. (Tekmileh, K.) ― -b6- And [the pl.] buroqN is used as a name for The [locusts, or crickets, termed] janaAdib. (IB, TA.) -A2- Also A certain Persian medicine, good for the memory. (Sgh, K.)

A_iboriyqN A_bryq Abryq a Persian word, (S, Msb,) arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) originally A=bo riyzo (CK [in a MS. copy of the K and in the TA, incorrectly, A=b riy]) [A ewer, such as is used for wine, and also such as is used for water to be poured on the hands; each having a long and slender spout, and a handle;] a well-known vessel; (TA;) a vessel having a spout (Mgh, and Bd and Jel in lvi. 18) and a handle: (Bd and Jel ibid:) accord. to Kr, a kuwz; and so says AHn in one place; but in another he says that it is like a kwz: (TA:) [it is somewhat like a kwz with the addition of a spout:] pl. A^abaAriyqu (S, Msb) [and sometimes A^abaAriqapN]. -A2- A sword such as is termed ↓ bar~aAq; (K;) i. e. (TA) a sword that shines, gleams, or glistens, much, or intensely: (S, Kr:) or simply a sword: or, as some say, a bow: (JK:) or it signifies also a bow in which are talaAmiyE [or places differing in colour from the rest, and, app., glistening]: (K:) thus, accord. to Az, in a verse of ' Amr Ibn-Ahmar: but correctly, accord. to Sgh, it has there the first of the significations explained in this sentence: and it is said, also, that sayofN A_iboriyqN signifies a sword having much lustre, and much diversified with wavy marks or streaks, or in its grain. (TA.) ― -b2- A woman who is beautiful, and splendid, or brilliant, (Lh, JK, K, TA,) in colour [or complexion]: (Lh, TA:) or, as some say, who shows her beauty intentionally. (TA.) [See also bar~aAqapN (voce bar~aAqN).]
A^ubayoriqN * dim. of A_isotaboraqN, q. v. (S, K.)

A_isotaboraqN A_stbrq Astbrq , (IDrd, S, K, &c.,] sometimes with the conjunctive A, (TA,) Thick diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (Ed-Dahhak, S, K, and so Bd and Jel in xviii. 30, &c.:) or dybAj made [or interwoven] with gold: (K:) or closely-woven, thick, beautiful dybAj made [or interwoven] with gold: (TA:) or closely- woven cloths, or garments, of silk, like dybAj: (IDrd, K:) or thick silk: (IAth, TA:) or a red thong cut from an untanned skin (qid~apN HamoraA='u), as though it were [composed of] pieces of bow-strings, or chords: (Ibn-' Abbád, K:) it is an arabicized word, (IDrd, S, K,) form A_isotarowahN, (IDrd, K,) which is Syriac; (IDrd, TA;) or from the Persian, (S, TA,) in which sitabor and A_isotabor signify “ thick, ” absolutely, whence sitaboraho and A_isotaboraho are particularly applied to signify “ thick dybAj, and then the latter is arabicized by substituting q for the h: so says Esh-Shiháb El-Khafájee: or the A and s and t are augmentative, and it is mentioned in the present art. in the S and K as though this were the case, agreeably with the form of its dim., which is said by J and in the K to be ↓ A^ubayoriqN; for in forming the dim., a word is reduced to its root. (TA.)
taborwqN tbrwq ; pl. tabaAriyqu: see bariyqapN, in four places.

maboraqN mbrq [A shining, gleaming, or glistening: or a time thereof]. You say, jaA'a Einoda maboraqi AlS~uboHi [He came at the shining, &c., or at the time of the shining, &c., of the dawn; or] when the dawn shone, or gleamed, or glistened. (K, TA. [In the latter, mbrq is said to be here a meemee inf. n.])
muboriqN mbrq : see baruwqN.

Q. 1 broqa$ahu * , (S, A, TA,) inf. n. baroqa$apN, (TA,) He variegated it with divers, or different, colours; (S, TA;) from A^abuw baraAqi$a, the bird so called: (S:) or he adorned him, or it. (A.) [See also baroqa$apN, below.] ― -b2- Hence, baroqa$a qawolahu (assumed tropical:) He embellished his saying. (Har p. 235.)

Q. 2 tabaroqa$a *
He adorned himself (A, K) with various colours. (K.) You say, tabaroqa$a lanaA He adorned himself with various colours for us: (K:) or with various colours of every kind. (TA.) And tabaroqa$ato She assumed various colours: or she varied in dispositions: syn. talaw~anato. (A.) And tbrq$ Albayotu The house, or chamber, or tent, became variegated. (TA.) And tbrq$t AlbilaAdu The countries became adorned with various colours; from A^abuw baraAqi$a. (TA.)

biroqi$N *
A certain bird, (S, K,) different from that called A^abuw baraAqi$a, (K, accord. to the TA, [for we there read TaAy^irN A=xaru; the bird called Abw brAq$ having been mentioned before; but in the CK, in the place of A=xaru, we find A^axoDaru, i. e., green;]) of small size, (S, TA,) that assumes various colours, of the kind called Hum~ar, (TA,) like the sparrow, (S, TA,) and called $uro$uwrN (S, K) by the people of El-Hijáz: (S, TA:) but Az states his having heard certain of the Arabs of the desert call it Abw brAq$. (TA.)
baroqa$apN * The diversity of colour of that which is termed A^aroqa$u. (K.) [See also 1.]

A^abuw baraAqi$a *
A certain bird that assumes various colours; (S;) a small wild bird, like the qanofu* [or hedge-hog, but qunofu* is probably a mistranscription for qunobur, or lark], the upper part of whose feathers is dust-coloured (A^agobaru, as in the K, accord. to the TA), or white (A^agar~u, as in some copies of the K), and the middle red, and the lower part black, so that when it is roused, or provoked, it ruffles its feathers and becomes variously changed in colour: (Lth, K:) or a certain bird that is found in the trees called EiDaAh, and the colour of which is between blackness and whiteness, having six qawaAdim [or primary feathers], three on each side, heavy in the rump, that makes a noise with its wings when it flies, and assumes various colours: (IKh:) a certain variegated bird. (TA in art. Abw.) ― -b2- .) ― -b3- [Hence,] huwa A^abuw baraAqi$a (assumed tropical:) He is varying, or variable, in dispositions. (A, TA.)

AljaAru AlbaraAqi$iy~u *
The neighbour that is variable in his actions; like AljaAru AlyarobuwEiYY~u. (IAar Ta in art. jwr.]

Q. 1 baroqaEahu brqE brqEh brqEp rqEp , (S, K,) inf. n. baroqaEapN, (TA,) He attired him with a buroquE: (S, K:) and baroqaEa AlmaroA^apa he attired the woman with a buroquE (Msb.) ― -b2- baroqaEa liHoyatahu [He veiled his beard with a buroquE;] He assumed the guise of such as wear the buroquE; (TA;) i. e. SaAra maA^obuwnFA [he became effeminate, or a catamite]. (K, TA.) A poet says,
A^alamo tara qayosFA qayosa EayolaAna baroqaEato
liHaAhaA wabaAEato nabolahaA biAlmagaAzili
[Dost thou no see that Keys, Keys-'Eylan, have veiled their beards, and sold their arrows for spindles?]. (TA.) ― -b3- baroqaEa fulaAnFA biAlEaSaA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He struck such a one with the staff, or stick, between his ears, (K, TA,) so that it became like the buroquE upon his head. (TA.)

Q. 2 tabaroqaEa brqE tbrqE
He attired himself with a buroquE (S , K:) and tabaroqaEato she (a women) attired herself with a buroquE. (Msb.)
buroqaEN brqE rqEp : see what next follows.

buroquEN brqE rqEp (IAar, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ buroqaEN (IAar, S, Msb, K ,) but some disallow this latter, (Msb,) and ↓ buroquwEN, (IAar, S, K,) but AHát disallows this, as well as the second, (TA,) A thing pertaining to women and to horses or similar beasts, (K,) or to horses or similar beasts and to the women of the Arabs of the desert; (S;) a thing with which a woman veils her face; (Msb;) having in it two holes for the eyes: (Lth:) a small piece of cloth, or rag, pierced for the eyes, worn by horses or similar beasts and by the women of the Arabs of the desert: (Mgh:) [or, accord. to the general fashion of the present time, a long strip of cotton or other cloth, black, blue, or of some other colour, or white, concealing the whole of the face of the woman wearing it, except the eyes, and reaching nearly to the feet, suspended at the top by a narrow band, or other fastening, which passes up the middle of the forehead, and which is sewed, as are also the two upper corners, to a band which is tied round the head, beneath the head-veil: (see my “ Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, ” ch. i.:)] ↓ buroqaEapN, if correct, is a more particular term: (Mgh:) the pl. is baraAqiEu. (Lth, Msb.) [See niqaAbN.] ― -b2- [AlburoquEu The curtain of the door of the Kaabeh.] ― -b3- See also biroqiEu.
biroqaEu brqE rqEp : see what next follows.

biroqaEu brqE rqEp , (S, K, * TA,) imperfectly decl., (S, TA,) and ↓ biroqaEu, (Fr, Az, Ibn-'Abbád,) of a rare form, like hijoraE, (Fr, Az, *) or AlbiroqiEu and ↓ AlburoquEu, (K, * TA,) but perhaps this last is a mistranscription, for biroqaEu, (TA,) a name of The heaven, or sky: (Fr:) or the seventh heaven: (AAF, S, K:) or the fourth heaven: (Lth, Az, K:) or the first heaven; (K;) i. e. the lowest heaven: IDrd says, so they assert; and in like manner says
IF; and he says, the b is augmentative, the radical letters being r q E, for every heaven is termed raqiyEN, and the heavens [together] are termed A^aroqiEapN: (TA:) or the lowest heaven is termed Alr~aqiyEu. (S, TA.) [See an ex. voce sadirN.] buroqaEapN: see buroquEN. buroquwEN: see buroquEN.

farasN mubaroqaEN frs mbrqE , (TA,) or farasN A^agar~N mubaroqaEN, (Mgh,) A horse having what is termed gur~apN mubaroqiEapN: (TA:) or a horse having the whole of his face white. (Mgh.) And $aApN mubaroqaEapN A sheep, or ewe, having the head white. (S, K.)

gur~apN mubaroqiEapN grp mbrqEh grp mbrqEp
A blaze, or whiteness, on the face of a horse, occupying the whole of his face, except that he looks (yanoZuru [for which yunoZaru is erroneously substituted in the CK]) in blackness; (S, L, K;) [i. e.] this whiteness passing downwards to the cheeks without reaching to the eyes. (L, TA.)

1 baraka br brk brkp , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baruka , (S, TA,) inf. n. buruwkN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and taboraAkN, (K,) said of a camel, (S, Mgh, Msb,) i. q. AisotanaAxa [i. e. He lay down, or kneeled and lay down, upon his breast, with his legs folded]; (S, K;) he made his breast to cleave to the ground; (Mgh;) he fell upon his barok, i. e. breast; (Msb;) he threw his brk, i. e. breast, upon the ground; (TA;) and in like manner, ↓ br~k, (TA, and so in some copies of the K,) inf. n. taboriykN. (TA.) And barakati Aln~aEaAmapu The ostrich lay upon its breast. (TA.) And baraka is also said of a lion, and of a man. (K voce rbD.) [Of the latter, one also says, baraka EalaY rukobatayohi He fell, or set himself, upon his knees; he kneeled.] The buruwk of a man praying, which is forbidden, is The putting down the hands before the knees, after the manner of the camel [when he lies down; for the latter falls first upon his knees, and then upon his stiflejoints]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, i. e., from the verb said of a camel, inf. n. buruwkN, (TA,) He, or it, (i. e. anything, S,) was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, or fixed; continued, remained, or stayed; (S, K;) in a place: (TK:) [and so, app., with
barika for its aor.; for] you say, baraka liloqitaAli, aor.
barika , [He was, or became, firm, &c., for the purpose of fighting,] and in like manner barika, aor.
baraka . (TA. [See also a similar signification of 8.]) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (the night) was, or became, long, or protracted; as though it did not quit its place. (A and TA in art. qEs.) ― -b4- See also 8, in two places.

2 bar~aka see 1. -A2- taboriykN also signifies The praying for barakap, (S, K, TA,) for a man, &c. (TA.) You say, bar~akotu Ealayohi, inf. n. taboriykN, I said to him, baAraka A@ll~`ha Ealayoka [or fiyka &c., God bless thee! &c.]. (TA.) And br~k Ely AlT~aEaAmi He prayed for, or invoked, a blessing on the food. (TK.)

3 bArk Ealayohi bArk Elyh bArk Elyp
He kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (Lh, K;) namely, an affair, (TA in art. HfZ,) or commerce, or traffic, &c. (Lh, TA.) -A2- bArk A@ll~`hu fiyka, (Fr, S, Msb, K,) and laka, and Ealayoka, (S, K,) and baArakaka, (Fr, S, K,) inf. n. mubaArakapN, (TK,) [God bless, beatify, felicitate, or prosper, thee;] God put in thee, (TA,) give thee, make thee to possess, (T, K,) barakap [i. e. a blessing, good of any kind, prosperity or good fortune, increase, &c.]. (TA, TK.) baAriko EalaY muHam~idK wa EalaY A=li muHam~adK (in a trad., TA,) means Continue Thou, or perpetuate Thou, (O God,) to Mohammad and to the family of Mohammad the eminence and honour which Thou hast given them: (K, TA:) [or still bless or beatify, or continue to bless or beatify, Mohammad &c.: though it may well be rendered simply bless or beatify &c.:] Az says that it is from baraka said of a camel, meaning “he lay down upon his breast in a place and clave thereto.” (TA.) And Aall~`huma baAriko lanaA fiY Almawoti, in another trad., means [O God, bless us] in the state to which death will bring us. (TA.) The Arabs say to the beggar, buwrika fiyka [Mayest thou be blest; and, in the present day, Aall~`h yubaArik fiyk God bless thee]; meaning thereby to repel him; not to pray for him: and by reason of frequency of usage of this phrase, they have made ↓ buwrik a noun: a poet [in Har $ry$ AlEdwY (app. Sherees, not Shereesh, El-'Adawee), in the TA Aboo-Fir'own,] says,
taZun~u A^an~a buwrikFA yakofiyniY
A_i*aA xarajotu baAsiTFA yamiyniY
[She imagines that the saying “Mayest thou be blest” will suffice me when I go forth stretching out my right hand for an alms]. (Har p. 378. [This verse is differently cited in the TA; for there, instead of tZn~ and xrjt, we find tuHib~u and gadawotu.]) ― -b2- [You also say of a man, bArk fiyhi, and lahu, &c., meaning He blessed him; i. e. he prayed God to bless him.] ― -b3- See also 6.

4 Abrkhu A^brk A^brkh Abrkh Abrkp brk
He made him (namely, a camel,) to lie down [or kneel and lie down] upon his breast. (S, K.) You say, A^aborakotuhu fabaraka I made him to lie down upon his breast, and he lay down upon his breast: but this is rare: the more common phrase is A^anoxatuhu faA@sotan~Axa. (S.) -A2- See also 8. -A3- maA A^aborakahu [How blessed is he, or it!] is an instance of a verb of wonder with a passive meaning [and irregularly derived]. (TA.)

5 tbr~k bihi tbrk bh tbrk bp
i. q. tayam~ana bihi [He had a blessing; and he was, or became, blest; by means of him, or it: so accord. to explanations of tabar~uko in the KL: but very often signifying he looked for a blessing by means of him, or it; he regarded him, or it, as a means of obtaining a blessing; he augured good from him, or it; tym~n bh being opposed to ta$aA^~ama bh; as in the K in art. Tyr, and in Bd in xvii. 14, &c.]: (S, K:) and ↓ tbArk biAl$~ayo'i He augured good from the thing. (Lth, K.) One says so of a man. (K in art. msH.) And one says, tbr~k biA@somi A@ll~`hi [He looked for a blessing by means of uttering the name of God, or saying bisomi A@ll~`hi]. (Ksh, on the bsmlp; &c.)

6 tbArk bArY bArk tbAr tbArk , accord. to Zj, is an instance of tafaAEala [as quasi-pass. of faAEala, i. e., of baAraka, like as tabaAEada is of baAEada,] from Albarakapu; and so say the lexicologists [in general]. (TA.) [Hence,] tbArk A@ll~`hu means [Blessed is, or be, God; or] hallowed is, or be, God; or far removed is, or be, He from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; (K) or highly to be exalted, or extolled, is God; or highly exalted, or extolled, be He; (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA;) greatly to be magnified is God; or greatly magnified be He: (TA:) or i. q. ↓ baAraka, like qaAtala and taqAatala, except that faAEala is trans. and tafaAaEala is intrans.: (S:) accord. to IAmb, it means [that] one looks for a blessing by means of [uttering] his name (yutabar~aku biA@somihi) in every affair, or case: accord. to Lth, it is a phrase of glorification and magnification: (TA:) or tbArk signifies He is abundant in good; from Albarakapu, which is “abundance of good:” or He exceeds everything, and is exalted above it, in his attributes and his operations; because Albarakapu implies the meaning of increase, accession, or redundance: or He is everlasting; syn. daAma; from buruwku AlT~ayori EalaY AlmaA='i [“the continuing of the birds at the water”]; whence Albirokapu, because of the continuance of the water therein: the verb is invariable [when thus used, being considered as divested of all signification of time, or used in an optative sense]; and is not employed [in any of the senses above] otherwise than in relation to God: (Bd in xxv. 1:) it is an attributive peculiar to God. (K.) ― -b2- tbArk biAl$~aYo'i: see 5.

8 Abtrk A^btr A^btrk Abtrk btr
He (a man) threw his barok [i. e. breast upon the ground (as the camel does in lying down), or upon some other thing]. (S.) ― -b2- He (a sword-polisher) leaned upon the polishing-instrument, (K,) on one side. (TA.) And He (a horse) inclined on one side in his running. (TA: [accord. to which, this is from what next follows.]) ― -b3- He hastened, or sped, and strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in running: (S, K:) and ↓ baraka, inf. n. buruwkN, (K,) or, as some say, this is a subst. from the former verb, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or exerted himself. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a cloud) rained continually, or incessantly: (TA:) and Abtrkt Als~amaA='u (assumed tropical:) the sky rained continually; as also ↓ barakat, (K,) and ↓ Abrkt; but Sgh says that the first of these three is the most correct. (TA.) And Abtrkt Als~aHaAbapu (tropical:) The cloud rained vehemently. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Abtrk fiY EiroDihi, and Ealayohi, (tropical:) He detracted from his reputation, censured him, or impugned his character, and reviled him, (K, TA,) and laboured in vituperating him. (TA.) AbtrkwA fiY AlHarobi (tropical:) They fell upon their knees in battle, and so fought one another. (K, TA. [See barakaA='u, below.]) -A2- Aibotarakotuhu I prostrated him, or threw him down prostrate, and put him beneath my barok [i. e. breast]. (S.)

barokN br brk brkp
Many camels: (S, K:) or a herd of camels lying down upon their breasts: (K:) or any camels, males and females, lying down upon their breasts by the water or in the desert by reason of the heat of the sun or by reason of
satiety: (TA:) or all the camels of the people of an encampment, that return to them from pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to whatever number they may amount, even if they be thousands: (K:) one thereof is termed ↓ baArikN; (K;) the two words being like tajorN and taAjirN; (TA;) fem. ↓ baArikapN: (K:) pl. buruwkN, (S, K,) i. e., pl. of barokN. (S.) -A2- Also, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ birokapN, which is with kesr, (S, K,) The breast (S, Msb, K) of a camel: (Msb, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) as some say, the former signifies the breast of the camel with which he crushes a thing beneath it: (TA:) and (K) accord. to Lth, (TA,) the latter is the part next to the ground of the skin of the breast of the camel; (or, as in the 'Eyn, of the skin of the belly of the camel and of the portion of the breast next to it; TA;) as also the former: (K:) or, as some say, the former is the middle of the breast, where [the two prominences of flesh called] the fahodataAni conjoin at their upper parts: (Ham p. 66:) or the latter is pl. of the former, like as HiloyapN is of HaloYN: or the former is of man; and the latter, of others: or the former is the interior of the breast; (or, as Yaakoob says, the middle of the breast; TA;) and the latter, the exterior thereof: (K:) or the former is the breast, primarily of the camel, because camels lie down (taboruku) upon the breast; and metaphorically of others. (Ham p. 145.) ― -b2- Hence, barok Al$~itaA='i (tropical:) The first part of winter; (L, TA; *) and the main part thereof. (L.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) Alburuwku is an appellation applied to (tropical:) The stars composing the constellation of the Scorpion, of which are Alz~ubaAnaY and AlA_ikoliylu and Alqalobu and Al$~awolapu [the 16th and 17th and 18th and 19th of the Mansions of the Moon], which rise [aurorally] in the time of intense cold; as is also Aljuvuwmu: (L, TA: *) or, accord. to IF, to a nawo' of the A^anowaA=' of AljawozaA='; because the AnwA' thereof do not set [aurorally] without there being during their period a day and a night in which the camels lie upon their breasts (taboruku) by reason of the vehemence of the cold and rain. (TA.)
burokN br brk brkp : see burakN.
birokN br brk brkp : see birokapN.

burakN br brk brkp
Remaining fixed (↓ baArikN) at, or by, a thing. (IAar, K.) So in the phrase buraku EalaY janob AlA_inaA='i [Remaining fixed at, or by, the side of the vessel], in a verse describing a [gluttonous] man, who swallows closely-consecutive mouthfuls. (IAar.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Incubus, or nightmare; as also ↓ baAruwkN. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A coward; and so ↓ the latter word. (K, TA.) -A2- Also, [and by contraction ↓ burokN, as in a verse cited in the M and TA in art. wbS,] A name of the month *uw AlHij~ap; (AA, K;) one of the ancient names of the months. (AA.)

burokapN brk brkh brkp rkp , (S, K,) or ↓ burakapN, (Msb,) A certain aquatic bird, white, (S, Msb, K,) and small: (K:) [the former applied in Barbary, in the present day, to a duck:] pl. burakN (S, Msb, K) and burokaAnN and birokaAnN and [pl. of pauc.] A^aboraAkN; (K;) or, in the opinion of ISd, AbrAk and brkAn are pls. of the pl. [burakN]. (TA.)

birokapN brk brkh brkp rkp
A mode, or manner, of buruwk [i. e. of a camel's kneeling and lying down upon the breast]; (S, * O, * K;) a noun like rikobapN and jilosapN. (S, O.) One says, maA A^aHosana birokapa h`*ihi Aln~aAqapi [How good is this she-camel's manner of lying down on the breast!]. (S.) -A2- See also barokN. -A3- A HawoD [i. e. watering-trough or tank]: (K:) or the like thereof, (S, TA,) dug in the ground, not having raised sides constructed for it above the surface of the ground; (TA;) and ↓ birokN signifies the same: (Lth, K:) said to be so called because of the continuance of the water therein: (S:) pl. birakN, (S, Msb, K,) which Az found to be applied by the Arabs to the tanks, or cisterns, that are constructed with baked bricks, and plastered with lime, in the road to Mekkeh, and at its wateringplaces; sing. birokapN; and sometimes a brkp is a thousand cubits [in length], and less, and more: but the watering-troughs, or tanks, that are made for the rain-water, and not cased with baked bricks, are called A^aSonaAEN, sing. SinoEN: (TA:) [birokapN often signifies a basin; a pool; a pond; and a lake: and in the present day, also a bay of the sea: and a reach of a river:] also a place where water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates, or remains long and becomes altered. (ISd, K.)

barakapN brk brkh brkp rkp [A blessing; any good that is bestowed by God; and particularly such as continues and increases and abounds:] good, (Jel in xi. 50,) or prosperity, or good fortune, (Fr, K,) that proceeds from God: (Fr, in explanation of the pl. as used in the Kur xi. 76:) increase; accession; redundance; abundance, or plenty; (S, Msb, K, Kull;) whether sensible or intellectual: and the continuance of divinely-bestowed good, such as is perceived by the intellect, in, or upon, a thing: (Kull:) or firmness, stability, or continuance, coupled with increase: (Ham p. 587:) or increasing good: (Bd in xi. 50:) and abundance of good; implying the meaning of increase, accession, or redundance: (Bd in xxv. 1:) or abundant and continual good: (so in an Expos. of the Jámi' es-Sagheer, cited in the margin of a copy of the MS:) and, accord. to Az, God's superiority over everything. (TA.)
burakapN brk brkh brkp rkp : see burokapN.
baraAki baraAki brAk brAk , (S, K, *) like qaTaAmi, (K,) said in war, or battle, (S,) means A^uborukuwA [Be ye firm, steady, or steadfast: in the CK, erroneously, AaborikuwA]. (S, K.)
baruwkN brY brwk rwk A woman that marries having a big son (S, K) of the age of puberty. (S.)

buruwkN brY brwk rwk
A hasting, speeding, striving, labouring, or exerting oneself, in running; a subst. from Abtrk: and inf. n. of baraka in a sense in which it is explained above with the former verb. (K: but see 8.)
bariykN bry bryk ry : see mubaAraka.

(K.) ― -b2- Also The field of battle: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, brA=kA'u AlHarobi and ↓ baruwkaAw^uhaA signify the place to which the men of valour cleave. (TA.)
baruwkaA='u brwkA=' : see what next precedes, in two places.

brnk brnk :) [in Spanish barangane: (Golius:)] pl. [of all except the first two] baraAniku. (IDrd, K.) barakaAnN, without teshdeed, is not mentioned by any one. (Mgh.)
baronakaA='u brnkA=' and baronakaAnN and bronakaAniY~N: see bar~akaAnN, in four places.
baArikN bAr bArAk bArk b|rk |r , fem. with p: see barokN, in two places: ― -b2- and see burakN.

i. q. buwraqN; (K;) that is put into flour, (TA,) or into dough. (JK and Mgh and TA in explanation of the latter word.)
buwrik bwr bwrk wrk , as a noun: see 3.

maborakN mbrk
A place where camels lie upon their breasts: pl. mabaArikN. (Msb.) You say, fulaAnN layosa lahu miborakN jamalK [Such a one has not a place in which a camel lies; meaning he does not possess a single camel]. (S.)

mubaArakN mbArk mbrp is originally mubaArakN fiyhi [or lahu or Ealayohi, accord. to those who know not, or disallow, baAraka as trans. without a preposition; and signifies Blessed, beatified, felicitated, or prospered; gifted with, or made to possess, barakp, i. e. a blessing, any good that is bestowed by God, prosperity or good fortune, increase, &c.]; (Msb;) abounding in good; (Ksh and Bd in iii. 90;) abounding in advantage or utility: (Bd in vi. 92 and 156, and xxxviii. 28, and 1. 9:) the pl. applied to irrational things is mubaArakaAtN. (Msb.) You say also ↓ bariykN as meaning mubaAraka fiyhi: (K:) or TaEaAmN bariykN is as though meaning mubaArakN [i. e. Blessed food; or food in which is a blessing, &c.]. (S.)

mubotarikN mbtrk , [in the CK mutabar~ikN,] applied to a man, (tropical:) Leaning, or bearing, upon a thing; applying himself [thereto] perseveringly, assiduously, or constantly. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a cloud, (tropical:) Bearing down [upon the earth], and paring off the surface of the ground [by its vehement rain: see 8]. (TA.)
mutabaArikN mtbArk [app. applied to God (see its verb)] High, or exalted. (Th, TA.)

barama ; and ↓ tbr~m; He was, or became, affected with disgust, loathing, or aversion; (M, * K;) he was vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind. (M.) You say, barima bihi, inf. n. baramN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and bihi ↓ tbr~m; (T, S, Msb, K;) He was, or became, disgusted by it, or by reason of it; he loathed it; (T, *, M, * Msb, * K;) he was vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind, by it, or by reason of it. (T, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- barima biHuj~atihi, aor.
barama , (tropical:) [He was unable to adduce, as he had intended, his argument, allegation, or evidence,] is said when one has intended to adduce an argument, allegation, or evidence, and it did not present itself to him. (A, K, TA.)

baruma , inf. n. baromN]: (T:) or he twisted it well; namely, a rope. baruma ,] inf. n. baromN. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He thought, or meditated, upon it; (namely, a thing;) or did so looking to its end, issue, or result; or he did it, performed it, or executed it, with thought, or consideration. (Msb.) -A2- He affected him with disgust, loathing, or aversion; (T, * S, M, * Msb, * K;) caused him to be vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind. (T, S, M, Msb.) 7 Anbrm A^nbrm Anbrm {nbrm [It (a rope, or a thread, or string,) was made of two strands, or distinct twists, and then twisted: or was twisted well: see 4, of which it is quasi-pass. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) It ([a thing, or an affair, or] compact, Msb) was, or became, firm, strong, solid, or sound; it was, or became, established, settled, or arranged, firmly, strongly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly. (Msb, KL.)

barama brm brmp rm The fruit of the [trees called] EiDaAh: (S, M, K:) n. un. with p: (S, M:) in its first stage it is termed fatolapN; then, bal~apN; then, baramapN: AHn has erred in saying that the ftlp is above the brmp [in degree]: (M:) that of every kind of EDAh is yellow, except that of the EurofuT, which is white, (S, M,) as though its filaments, or fringe-like appertenances, were cotton, and it is like the button of a shirt, or somewhat larger: (M:) that of the salam is the sweetest in odour, (S, M,) and this is yellow, and is eaten, being sweet, or pleasant: (M:) accord. to AA, the fruit of the TaloH [or acacia gummifera, which is of the trees called EDAh]: n. un. with p: (T:) sometimes, also, baramapN is applied to a fruit of the A^araAk (M, * K, * TA) before it has become ripe and black; for when ripe, it is called marodN; and when black, kabaAvN: (TA:) and the pl. is biraAmN (M, K) and buramN, (M,) or baramN. (K: [but the last is a coll. gen. n.]) ― -b2- Also Grapes when they are above, (M,) or when they are like, (K,) the heads of young ants. (M, K.) -A2- (tropical:) One who does not take part with others in the game called Almayosir [q. v.], (As, T, S, M, K,) nor contribute with them anything, (TA,) by reason of his avarice, (Har p. 382,) though he eats with them of the flesh-meat thereof; (As, TA;) but sometimes he shuffles, or deals forth, (yufiyDu,) the gaming-arrows for the players: (S in art. jmd:) likened to the barama of the A^araAk, because he is of no use: (Har ubi suprà:) and ↓ baramapN occurs in the same sense; [the man so termed being likened to a baramap of the ArAk; or] the p being added to give intensiveness to the meaning: (M:) the pl. is A^aboraAmN. (T, S, M, K.) And hence, (tropical:) Avaricious, or niggardly; mean, or sordid: (Har ubi suprà:) or heavy, or sluggish; (K, TA;) destitute of good. (TA.) It is said in a prov., A^aboramFA qaruwnFA (tropical:) [Art thou (takuwnu being understood after) one taking no part with others in the game of Almysr, as is implied in the S, or art thou] heavy, or sluggish, (K, TA,) destitute of good, (TA,) yet eating two dates at once each time? (S, K, TA.)
barimN brm brmp rm part. n. of barima [and therefore meaning Affected with disgust, loathing, or aversion; or vexed, grieved, disquieted by grief, or distressed in mind]. (M, Msb.)

buromapN brm brmh brmp rm rmp
A cooking-pot (T, M, &c.) of stone, (T, Mgh, Msb,) or of stones: [see muborimN:] (M, K:) or [simply] a cooking-pot, (S, TA,) as some say, in a general sense, so that it may be of copper, and of iron, &c.: (TA:) pl. biraAmN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and buramN (T, M, &c.) and [coll. gen. n.] buromN. (T, M, K.) -A2- Also A certain thing which women wear upon their arms, like the bracelet. (TA.)
baramapN brm brmh brmp rm rmp [originally n. un. of baramN]: see baramN.

bariymN brym ry^m rym
A rope composed of two twists twisted together into one; as also ↓ muboramN: (S:) or a thread, or string, twisted of two distinct yarns or twists: (T:) or a thread, or string, twisted of white and black yarns: (Ham p. 704:) or a twisted rope in which are two colours, (A'Obeyd, S,) or two threads, or strings, of different colours, (IAar, T, M, K,) red and yellow, (M,) or red and white, (K,) sometimes (A'Obeyd, S) bound by a woman upon her waist, and upon her upper arm: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) a rope of two colours, adorned with jewels, so bound by a woman: (M, K:) or a thread, or string, (Lth, A'Obeyd, T,) with beads strung upon it, (Lth, T,) or of different colours, (A'Obeyd, T,) which a woman binds upon her waist: (Lth, A'Obeyd, T: [see also HawoTN]:) or a string of cowries, which is bound upon the waist of a female slave. (Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee in art. bzm of the TA.) ― -b2- Anything in which are two colours (T, M, K) mixed together: (M, K:) and any two things mixed together and combined. (M.) ― -b3- An amulet (M, K, TA) that is hung upon a boy; because of the colours therein. (TA.) ― -b4- A garment, or piece of cloth, in which are silk (qaz~) and flax. (T.) ― -b5- Also, (K,) or the dual thereof, (AO, T, S,) which latter is the right, (TA,) The liver and hump [of a camel], (AO, T, S, K,) cut lengthwise, and tied round with a string or thread, or some other thing, (S, K,) in some copies of the S, or with a gut; (TA;) said to be thus called because of the whiteness of the hump and the blackness of the liver. (S, K.) So in the phrase, Ai$owi lanaA mino bariyamayohaA [Roast thou for us some of her liver and hump, cut lengthwise, &c.]. (AO, T, S: [in copies of the K, bariymihaA: and in the CK, bariymatihaA.]) ― -b6- Also, the sing., Water mixed with other [water &c.]. (TA.) ― -b7- Tears mixed with [the collyrium termed] A_ivomid; (M, K;) because having two colours. (TA.) ― -b8- A mixed company of people. (M, K.) ― -b9- An army; (S, K;) because comprising a mixed multitude of men; (K;) or because of the colours of the banners of the tribes therein: (S, K, TA:) or an army in which is a mixed multitude of men: (M:) or an army having two colours: (T:) and the dual, two armies, Arabs and foreigners. (IAar, T.) ― -b10- A number of sheep and goats together. (IAar, T, M, K.) ― -b11- The light of the sun with the remains of the blackness of night: (IAar, T:) or the dawn; (M, K;) because of its combining the blackness of night and the whiteness of day: or, as some say, bariymN AlS~uboHi means the tint (xayoT [q. v.]) of the dawn that is mixed with two colours. (M.) ― -b12- (assumed tropical:) Inducing suspicion, or evil opinion; [as though of two colours;] (IAar, T;) suspected. (IAar, T, Sgh, K.)

bar~iymapN brym brymh brymp ry^m rym rymp , with fet-h, and with teshdeed to the r which is meksoorah, A daAy^irap [or feather, or portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled, in a spiral manner, or otherwise,] upon a horse, whereby one judges of its goodness or badness: pl. baraAriymu. (TA: [and used in this sense in the present day.]) ― -b2- See also bayoramN.

bayoramN byrm The [implement called] Eatalap: or particularly the Etlp of the carpenter: (M, K:) [i. e.,] an auger, a wimble, or a gimlet; [called in the present day ↓ bar~iymap; accord. to Mirkát el-Loghah, cited by Golius, who writes the latter word without teshdeed, the former signifies such an implement (“ terebra ”) of a large size;] that with which the carpenter perforates: and also said to signify that with which the saddler perforates leather: (KL:) also a well-known kind of [implement such as is called in Persian] tiy$aho [i. e., a hatchet, or the like]: (PS:) AO said, the bayoramo is the Eatalap of the carpenter: or he said, the Etlp is the byrm of the carpenter: (T:) this word, (M,) the byrm of the carpenter, (S,) is Persian, (S, M,) arabicized. (S.)

muboramN mbrm : see bariymN. ― -b2- Also A garment, or piece of cloth, of which the thread is twisted of two yarns, or distinct twists. (S, K.) And hence, (S,) A certain kind of garments, or cloths. (S, K.) ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) A thing, or an affair, or a compact,
made firm, strong, solid, or sound; established, settled, or arranged, firmly, strongly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly. See its verb, 4. ― -b4- And hence, qaDaA='N muboramN (assumed tropical:) Ratified destiny; such as is rendered inevitable.]

muboramN mbrm [act. part. n. of 4. -A2- And also] A gatherer of baram [q. v.]: (M:) or, of the baram of the EiDaAh: (K:) or, specially, a gatherer of the baram of the A^araAk. (M.) -A3- A maker of biraAm [or stone cookingpots]: (K:) or one who wrenches out the stones of which they are made from the mountain, (M, K, TA,) and fashions them, and hews them out. (TA.) -A4- And hence, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A heavy, or sluggish, man; as though [in the CK lAan~ahu is erroneously put for kaA^an~ahu] he cut off for himself something from the persons sitting with him: (M, K: *) or, as some say, [so in the M; but in the K, “and”] bad, or corrupt, in discourse; (M, K;) who discourses to others of that in which is no profit nor meaning; (TA;) from the same word as signifying “a gatherer of the fruit of the ArAk,” (M, TA,) which has no taste nor sweetness nor sourness nor virtue, or efficacy: (AO, TA:) or one who is a burden upon his companion, without profit and without good; like the baram who takes no part with others in the game of Almayosir, though he eats of the flesh-meat thereof. (As, TA.)
miboramN mbrm sing. of mabaArimu, (TA,) which signifies The spindles with which the twisting termed A_iboraAm is performed. (M, K, TA.) [See 4.]

baroniY~N brnY brny
A sort of dates, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) the best of dates, (M,) or of the best of dates, (Msb,) red, intermixed, or tinged, with yellow, having much liHaA=' [i. e. flesh, or pulp], and very sweet, (T,) or yellow, and round: (M:) n. un. with p: (M:) it is an arabicized word, originally baroniyko, i. e. good, or excellent, fruit: (K:) accord. to AHn, of Persian origin, i. e., baAroniYo; bAr meaning fruit, and nY denoting egregiousness: (M:) accord. to Suh, a foreign, or Persian, word, meaning blessed [or good or excellent] fruit; barN meaning fruit; and hiniY, good or excellent [or wholesome]: the Arabs introduced it into their language: (Msb:) or, accord. to the Moajam of El-Bekree, it is from baronN, the name of a town, or village. (TA.) It is converted by a rájiz into baronij~; the double Y being changed into [double] j. (S, M.) ― -b2- You say also naxolN baroniY~N and naxolapN baroniy~apN [Palm-trees, and a palm-tree, of which the dates are of the sort described above]. (T.)

baroniy~apN brnyh brnyp n. un. of baroniY~N. -A2- Also A kind of vessel, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) well known, (Msb,) of baked clay: (S, Mgh, K:) or, as some say, of those that are termed qawaAriyr [i. e. flasks, or bottles, generally of glass]; such as are used by the seller of perfumes: (Mgh:) or a thing like a vessel of baked clay, big, or bulky, and green: and sometimes of the kind termed qwAryr: (M:) or a thing like vessels of baked clay, big, or bulky, and green; of the kind termed qwAryr that are thick, with wide mouths: (Lth, T:) pl. baraAniY~N. (Mgh.) -A3- And A cock: (IAar, T:) or a young cock, (M, K,) when it attains to maturity, (M,) or when it begins to do so: (K:) of the dial. of El-'Irák: (M:) pl. as above. (T, M, K.)

Q. 2 tabaronasa tbrns
He wore, or clad himself with, a buronus. (S.)

buronusN brns
A long qalanosuwap, (S, Msb, K,) which the devotees used to wear in the first age of ElIslám: (S:) or any garment of which the head forms a part, (M, K,) being joined to it, (M,) whether it be a dur~aAEap or a mimoTar or a jub~ap; (M, K;) and this is said to be the correct explanation: (TA:) [agreeably with the latter explanation, it is applied in the present day to a hooded cloak, mostly of white woollen stuff; but often, of cloth of any colour:] pl. baraAnisu: (Msb:) [some say] it is from Albirosu, meaning “cotton,” and the n is augmentative: or, accord. to some, it is not Arabic. (TA.) ― -b2- buronusu AlHusoni (assumed tropical:) Comely, or goodly, hair. (TA in art. mlA^.)
baronakaA='u brnkA=' and baronakaAnN and baronakaAniY~N: see bar~akaAnN, in art. brk.

1 bariha br brh brp , aor.
baraha , inf. n. barahN, or, as in some copies of the K, barahaAnN, (TA, [and so I find in an excellent copy of the K, but in the CK burohaAn,]) His body returned to a healthy state, or his health of body returned to him, or his bodily condition became good, after having been altered by disease. (IAar, K. *) [The h is perhaps a substitute for ': see bariy^a.] ― -b2- And He was, or became, white in person, or body and members. (K.) ― -b3- See also barahN, below.

4 Abrh A^bAr A^br A^brh A_brh A_brp Abrh Abrp brY
He adduced the evidence or proof: (Msb, K:) but as to ↓ barohana, meaning he manifested the evidence or proof, it is said, on the authority of IAar, to be post-classical; the former being the correct word: (AA, T, Z, Msb, TA:) or the former signifies he adduced, or uttered, or did, wonderful things, and overcame men. (K.) Q. Q., or, as some say, Q., 1. barohana: see 4; and see art. brhn.
barahN br brh brp [perhaps an inf. n., of which the verb is ↓ bariha,] Softness, thinness of skin, and plumpness, (K, TA,) of a woman; as also ↓ barahorahapN. (TA.)
barohapN brhh brhp : see what next follows.

burohapN brhh brhp and ↓ barohapN A long space or period of time: (JK, S:) or a long time: (ISk, K:) or they have a more general sense; (K;) i. e. a space, or period, of time: pl. of the former burahN and burohaAtN and burahaAtN and burahaAtN. (Msb.) You say, A^atato Ealayohi burohapN mina Ald~ahori and barohapN [A long space or period of time, or merely a space or period of time, passed over him]. (S.)
burohaAnN brhAn rhAn : see art. brhn.

barahorahapN brhrhh brhrhp A white (IAar, JK, Msb) girl (IAar, Msb) or female: (JK:) or a woman (S, K,) white and youthful: or soft, or tender: (K:) or that quivers, (K,) or almost quivers, (S,) from sappiness, softness, or tenderness: (S,* K:) or that shines, or glistens, by reason of her clearness [of complexion]: or thin-skinned; appearing as though water were running upon her, by reason of her softness, or tenderness: (TA:) of the measure faEaloEalapN, (S, TA,) from barahN: (TA:) dim. ↓ burayohapN (JK, TA) and ↓ burayorihapN, (JK,) or ↓ burayoriyhapN; but ↓ burayohirahapN is bad, and seldom used. (TA.) Imra-el-Keys says,
barahorahapN ruw^adapF raxoSapN kaxuroEuwyapi AlbaAnapi AlmunofaTiro
[White, or white and youthful, &c., soft, or beautiful, tender, like the shoot of the ben-tree breaking forth with leaves: the last word being made masc. by poetic license, for the sake of the metre.]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] it is said to signify also A white knife, of clear, pure, or bright, iron. (TA.) -A2- See also barahN.
burayohapN bryhh bryhp and burayohirahapN: see barahorahapN.
burayorihapN bryrhh bryrhp , or burayoriyhapN: see barahorahapN.

A^aborahu * [app.] Having the body in a healthy state, or in good condition, after disease: and white in person, or body and members: [but whether it have both these significations, or only the latter of them, is not clear:] fem. barohaA='u. (K.)

Q., or, as some say, Q. Q., 1.
Q. 1 barohana br brhn brhnn rhn
He adduced, (T, Z, Msb,) or established, (S, K, and Ham p. 7,) the burohaAn, (T, Z, Msb, K,) i. e. the evidence or proof [&c.]; (T, S, Msb, &c.;) or he adduced his evidence or proof [&c.]; (T, Msb;) Ealayohi [against him, or it, or (as in Aisotadal~a Ealayohi) of it], (S, K, and Ham p. 7,) and lahu [to him, or for him]: (Ham ubi suprà:) but this verb is said by Az and Z, on the authority of IAar, to be post-classical; the correct word, they say, being A^aboraha: (Msb:) this they assert on the ground of the opinion that burohaAnN [q. v.] is of the measure fuEolaAnN; but J holds the n to be a radical. (TA.)

burohaAnN brhAn rhAn
An evidence, or a proof: (T, S, Msb, K, and Ham p. 7:) and a demonstration; i. e. the manifestation of an evidence or proof: (Msb:) or a decisive and manifest evidence or proof: (TA:) or the firmest, strongest, or most valid, evidence or proof; which is such as ever necessarily implies truth, or veracity, as its consequence, or concomitant; for evidences, or proofs, are of five sorts; whereof this is one; another is that which ever necessarily implies falsity, or falsehood, as its consequence, or concomitant; another, that which is nearer to truth, or veracity; another, that which is nearer to falsity, or falsehood; and another, that which is intermediate between these two: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [pl. baraAhiynu:] some say that the n in this word is augmentative; (Msb, and Ham p. 7;) that it is of the measure fuEolaAnN, from Albrh [app. Albarohu] signifying the “act of cutting:” (Ham ubi suprà:) others, that it is radical: Az mentions both of these opinions: J confines
himself to the latter opinion: Z, to the former, saying, on the authority of IAar, that the word is derived from barahorahapN, meaning “white,” [or “fair in complexion,”] applied to a girl: (Msb:) Abu-l-Fet-h [i. e. IJ] says that he holds it to be of the measure fuEolaAlN, like quroTaAsN and quronaAsN, the n not being augmentative, as is shown by the verb above mentioned: (Ham ubi suprà:) but [it has been stated above that] this verb is said, on the authority of IAar, to be post-classical. (Msb, TA.)

1 barawotuhaA brwp brwthA , i. e. Aln~aAqapa: see 4. -A2- barawotuhu, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
baruwa , (Lth, T,) inf. n. barowN, (M,) I formed it, or fashioned it, by cutting; shaped it out; or pared it; (K;) namely, a reed for writing, (Lth, T, M, Msb, K,) and a stick, or piece of wood, (M, K,) and an arrow, (K,) [&c.;] a dial. var. of barayotuhu, (Lth, T, M, Msb,) used by some, (Lth, T,) but the latter is the more approved: (M, TA:) mentioned by AZ. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] baraAhu, aor.
baruwa , inf. n. barowN, He (i. e. God) created him, or it: (Fr, S, K:) [but] they affirm that it is originally baraA^ahu, with hemz: (MF:) so says IAth: (TA:) or it is from barFA or barFY, signifying “dust,” or “earth.” (Fr, S.) -A3- baraA, aor.
baruwa , is also a bad dial. var. of baraA^a [signifying He, or it, recovered from disease, or became convalescent, &c.], aor. yaboruw^u. (TA.)

4 A^aborayotuhaA * , (S, M, K,) i. e. Aln~aAqapa, (S, M,) I put a [ring such as is termed] burap in her (a camel's) nose; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ barawotuhaA: (IJ, M, K:) and Abrythu, namely, a camel, I put him a burap. (Msb.) -A2- AbrY Dust, or earth, came, or lighted, upon it. (K,* TA, in art. brY.)

burapN br brh brp (in which the final radical letter is elided, [and replaced by p,] Msb) A ring (T, S, M, &c.) of brass, (Lth, Lh, T, S, M, [in a copy of the Msb, mn Swf is erroneously put for mino SuforK,]) or of silver, (Lth, T,) or of some other material, (Lh, M,) slender, and bent at the two ends [lest it should open at the place where the two ends meet], that is put in the nose of a she-camel, (Lth, T,) or put in the nose of the camel, (M, Msb, K,) or in the flesh of the nose of the camel, (Lh, S, M, K,) or, as As says, in one of the two sides of the two nostrils, (S,) app. either for the purpose of ornament or to render the animal obedient; (MF;) [generally for the latter purpose, to attach the rein thereto:] when the ring is of hair, it is termed xizaAmapN; (As, S, Msb;) and when of wood, xi$aA$N: (Msb:) Aboo-' Alee mentions, and explains in like manner, ↓ barowapN and burFY; [the latter as pl. of the former;] but this is extr.: (M:) J says, [in the S,] Aboo- 'Alee says that burapN is originally barowapN, because it has burFY for a pl., like as qaroyap has qurFY; but Aboo-' Alee does not say this; he only desires to show that the final radical letter of burapN is w by the fact that barowapN is a dial. var. thereof: (IB, TA:) some, however, remarking upon J's saying that the original of barapN is barowapN, assert that it is correctly ↓ burowapN: (TA:) burapN also signifies an anklet: (M, K:) or any ring; such as a bracelet and an earring and an anklet and the like of these: (S:) the pl. (in the former and the latter senses, M, TA) is buraAtN, (S, M, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K erroneously written buraApN, (TA,) and burFY, (T, S, M,) and buruwna, contr. to analogy, (Msb,) or buriyna (T, S, M, K, [in all of which, except the last, this is in the accus. or the gen. case, but, as it is the nom. case in the K, it may be that buruwna and buriyna are dial. vars., like sinuwna and siniyna,]) and buriyna. (M, K: [in a copy of the former of which, accord. to the TT, buriY~N and biriY~N are put in the place of the last two of these pls.])

barFA br brA , or barFY, Dust, or earth: (Fr, S, M, Msb, K, mentioned in the M and K in art. brY:) whence baraAhu, [if not originally baraA^ahu,] meaning “He (i. e. God) created him.” (Fr, S.) Hence the saying, bifiyhi AlbaraA, or AlbaraY, [In his mouth be dust, or earth], (S, M,) a form of imprecation against a man. (M.)

barowapN brY brwh brwp
Cuttings, chips, parings, or the like, of a reed for writing, and of a stick, or piece of wood, and of soap, and the like. (TA.) -A2- See also burapN.
burowapN brY brwh brwp : see burapN.

Albariy~apN Albryh Albryp bry bryp
The creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created; or, particularly, mankind; syn. Alxaloqu: originally with ': (S:) but not pronounced with ': (IAth, TA in art. brY:) or, accord. to Fr, if from barFA, or barFY, i. e. “dust,” or “earth,” it is originally without ': pl. baraAyaA and bariy~aAtN. (S.)
muboraApN mbrA mbrAh mbrAp A she-camel (T, S) having a [ring such as is termed] burap put in her nose: (T, S, K:) pl. muborayaAtN. (TA in art. Erf.)
burapN maboruw~apN brp mbrwh brp mbrwp (T, M, K) A burap made, or manufactured. (T, TA.)

1 baraY br brY bry ry , (T, M, K,) first pers. barayotu, (T, S, Msb,) aor.
bariYa , (T, K,) inf. n. baroYN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He formed, or fashioned, by cutting; shaped out; or pared; (As, T, M, K;) a reed for writing, (Lth, As, ISk, T, S, M, Msb,) and a stick, or piece of wood, (Lth, T, M,) and an arrow, (M, K,) &c.; (M;) as also ↓ AbtrY: (M, K:) and barawotu, (Msb,) aor.
baruYa . (Lth, T,) is a dial. var., (Msb,) used by some, who say, huma yaqoluw Albur~a [instead of yaqoliY]. (Lth, T.) ― -b2- And hence, (As, T,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (As, T, M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) fatigued, or jaded, and made to lose flesh, (As, * T, * S,) a she-camel, (As, T,) or a camel: (S:) or it (journeying) rendered him lean, or emaciated: (M, K:) and in like manner one says of a year of dearth or drought. (TA.) And barayotu sanaAmahaA bisayoriY EalayohaA (assumed tropical:) [I wasted her hump by my journeying upon her]: occurring in a poem of El-Aashà. (M.) -A2- See also 3: ― -b2- and see 5, in two places.

3 bArAhu bAr bArAh bArAp bArY , (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAraApN, (T, TA,) He vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with him; emulated, or rivalled, him; or imitated him; i. q. EaAraDahu; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. e., (TA,) he did the like of what he (the latter) did, (ISk, T, S, Msb, TA, and EM p. 64,) striving to overcome him or surpass him; (EM ubi suprà;) as also lahu ↓ baraY, aor.
bariYa , inf. n. baroYN; and lh ↓ AnbrY: (As, T:) and he vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in glory, or excellence, or in beauty, or goodliness; he emulated, or rivalled, him therein; syn. baAhaAhu: (TA in art. bhj:) and he vied, competed, or contended, with him in running; and strove with him to outstrip him, to be before him, to get before him, or to precede him. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yubaAriY Alr~iyHa saxaA='F [Such a one vies with the wind in bounty]: (T, S:) [for] the bountiful man whose gifts are common is likened by the Arabs to the wind because it blows upon all in common, not only upon particular persons. (Ham p. 445.) -A2- bArY A@moraA^atahu He compounded, or made a compromise, with his wife for their mutual separation; (K;) as also baAraA^ahaA [which is the original]. (TA.)

bariYa : (T:) and lh ↓ AnbrY signifies AiEotaraDa lahu, (S, K, and Har p. 558,) meaning [as above; or] he betook himself, and advanced, or went forward, to it, namely, an action; (Har ubi suprà;) and it presented itself to it, as a thought to the heart, or mind, syn. tEr~D: (Ham p. 541:) lahu ↓ baraY, inf. n. baroYN, is syn. with EaraDa lahu [meaning as above, for it is syn. with taEar~aDa and AiEotaraDa; or it happened to him, befell him, or occurred to him]: (M:) and ↓ AnbrY is also syn. with EaraDa [meaning it happened, befell, or occurred]. (Har p. 56.) You say also, tbr~Y limaEoruwfihi, i. e. taEar~aDa lahu (ISk, S, K) or AiEotaraDa lahu (M) [both of which explanations mean He presented, addressed, applied, or betook, himself, or he advanced, came forward, went forward, or attempted, to obtain his favour, or bounty; or he sought it, or demanded it]; as also tbr~Y maEoruwfahu. (M, TA.) And tabar~ayotu wud~ahumo [I addressed, applied, or betook, myself to obtain their love, or affection]. (S, M.) And liTaY~i bisaATihi ↓ AnbrY, i. q. AiEotaraDa, meaning, in this instance, He hastened to cut short his speech. (Har p. 280.) And yuno$idu $iEorFA ↓ AnbrY, i. e. taEar~aDa liA_ino$aA=y^ihi [or liA_ino$aAdihi, meaning He addressed himself to reciting poetry, or verses]. (Har p. 34.) And mina AljamaAEapi ↓ AnbrY, i. q. AiEotaraDa [He presented himself, or advanced, or came forward, from the company]. (Har p. 647.)

[Golius explains it as “Chald. בוּץ, Byssus, seu potius pannus lineus, bombacinus, etiam sericus:” as on the authority of the S and K (though he omits the explanations in both those lexicons) and Meyd and Ibn-Maaroof (who explains it only by the Persian word jaAmaho, meaning cotton or linen cloth, or a garment,) and the Mirkát el-Loghah.
