busorN bsr sr Anything fresh, juicy, moist, not flaccid. (IF, M, Msb, K.) You say nabaAtN busorN A fresh plant: (Msb:) or a plant that has risen from the surface of the ground, but not grown tall; because it is then fresh and juicy: (TA:) or such is called busorapN [fem. of busorN]; as also what is fresh, juicy, moist, or not flaccid, of the plant called buhomaY. (M.) A plant, or herbage, when it first appears in the ground is termed baAriDN; then, jamiymN; then, busorapN; then, SamoEaA='u; and then, [when it is dry,] basorN. (S.) ― -b2- Fresh water, (S, M, K,) recently produced by rain; (S, M;) as also ↓ basorN: (M:) or this latter signifies cold, or cool, water: (K:) pl. of the former bisaArN; (S, K;) like as rimaAHN is pl. of rumoHN. (S.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A young, or youthful, man, and woman: (K, TA:) or young, or youthful, and fresh; fem. with p: (M, A:) applied, respectively, to a man and a woman; (M;) or to a boy and a girl. (A.) ― -b4- And, with p, (tropical:) The sun when it has just risen, (S, K, TA,) and is red, and not yet clear. (A, * TA.) [Accord. to the A, this meaning seems to be derived from that next following.] ― -b5- busorN and ↓ busurN (S, M, K) [the former, only, mentioned in the A and Msb &c., as the latter is rare; coll. gen. ns., signifying Fullgrown] unripe dates; dates before they have become ruTab; (M, K;) dates that have become coloured, but have not become ripe; (TA;) dates that have begun to colour, i. e., to become red or yellow; (Msb in art. bulH;) dates beginning to ripen: (IAth, TA in art. blH:) so called because fresh and juicy, and not flaccid: (M:) n. un. busorapN and busurapN: (S, M, K:) pl. busoraAtN (S) [or busorapN] and busuraAtN: (M:) Sb says that busurapN [or busorapN or each of these] has no broken pl.; but he allows busoraAn and tamoraAn, as meaning two sorts of busor and of takor. (M.) [J says,] busorK in their first stage are termed TaloEN; then, xalaAlN; then, balaHN; then, busorN; then, ruTabN; then, tamorN: (S:) but this saying of J is not good: the original thereof is termed TlE; and when they have become organized and compact (A_i*aA AnoEaqada), they are termed sayaAbN or say~aAbN [accord. to different copies of the K]; and when they have become green and round, jadaAlN and saraAdN and xalaAlN; and when they have become somewhat large, bagowN; and when they have become large, [or full-grown,] busorN; then, muxaT~amo; then, muwak~itN; then, tu*onuwbN; then, jumosapN [in the CK jamiysapN]; then, vaEodahN and xaAliEN and xaAliEapN; and when completely ripe, ruTabN and maEowN; then, tamorN. (K.) ― -b6- [Hence,] busorapN signifies also (tropical:) The head, or extremity, of the penis of a dog. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A kind of bead; syn.xarazapN. (K.)
busurN bsr sr : see busorN.
busorapN bsr bsrh bsrp sr srp fem. of busorN as an epithet, and n. un. of the same as a subst.: explained with the latter.
busurapN bsr bsrh bsrp sr srp n. un. of busurN, a dial. var. of busorN, q. v.

baAsirN A^sr A^srp bA^sr bAsr and ↓ basorN, the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet, A face frowning; or contracted; or grinning, or displaying the teeth, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look. (M.) [See 1, last sentence.] wawujwhN yawomy^i*K baAsirapN, in the Kur lxxv. 24, means And faces on that day shall be excessively frowning or contracted, &c.: (Jel:) or expressive of dislike or hatred, and contracted. (K.) [See also baAsilN.]

baAsuwrN bAswr
A well-known disease; (K;) a swelling, or tumour, which nature drives to every part of the body, from a humour that comes from the anus (AlmaqoEadap), and the testicles, and the edges of the labia majora of the pudendum muliebre, and other parts; and when in the anus, attended by a swelling of the veins; (Msb;) sing. of ; (S, K;) which signifies a certain disease that arises in the anus (AlmqEdp), [namely, the hemorrhoids, or piles, to which this term generally applies when it is used absolutely,] and also in the inside of the nose; (S;) what resembles boils in the anus: (Mgh:) sometimes the s is changed into S: (Mgh, Msb:) and it is said that the word is not Arabic. (Msb.)
mubosirN mbsr : see what next follows.
naxolapN mibosaArN nxlp mbsAr , (M, K,) and ↓mubosirN without p, as though a possessive epithet, (M,) A palm-tree of which the dates do not ripen. (M, K.) [See also 4.]

mabosuwrN mbswr
Affected by the disease termed bawaAsiyr, pl. of baAsuwrN. (TA.)

mubaAsirapN mbAsrh mbAsrp (assumed tropical:) A mare desiring the stallion (AO, K *) when she has only begun to feel the excitement of lust, (AO,) or before she is fully excited by lust. (K.) [See also mubaA$irN.]

1 basaTahu bsAT bsT bsTh bsTp , (M, Msb, K,) aor.
basuTa , (M, TA,) inf. n. basoTN, (S, M, Msb,) contr. of tabosyiTN; (M, TA;) as also ↓bs~Thu, (M,* TA,) inf. n. tabosyiTN. (TA.) [As such,] He spread it; spread it out, or forth; expanded it; extended it; (S, Msb, K, B;) as also ↓bs~Thu: (K:) and he made it wide, or ample: these are the primary significations; and sometimes both of them may be conceived; and sometimes, one of them: and the verb is also used, metaphorically, as relating to anything which cannot be conceived as composed or constructed: (B:) and baSoTN is the same as basoTN, (S, and K in art. bST,) in all its meanings. (K.) You say, basaTa Alv~awoba [He spread, spread out, expanded, or unfolded, the garment, or piece of cloth]. (Msb.) And basaTa rijolahu (tropical:) [He stretched forth, or extended, his leg]. (TA.) And basaTa *iraAEayohi, and ↓bas~aTahumaA, (assumed tropical:) He spread his fore arms upon the ground; the doing of which [in prostrating oneself] in prayer is forbidden. (TA.) And basaTa yadahu (M, Msb, K) (tropical:) He stretched forth, or extended, his arm, or hand; (M, K;) as in the saying basaTa A_iliY~a yadahu bimaA A^uHib~u waA^akorahu (tropical:) [He stretched forth, or extended, towards me his arm, or hand, with, i. e. to do to me, what I liked and disliked]: (M, TA: *) or he stretched forth his hand opened. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [v. 31], lay^ino basaTota A_ilaY~a yadaka litaqotulaniy (assumed tropical:) [Assuredly if thou stretch forth towards me thy hand to slay me]. (M, TA.) basoTu Alyadi and Alkaf~i is sometimes used to denote assaulting and smiting: [as in the last of the exs. given above; and] as in the words of the Kur [lx. 2], wayabusuTuwA A_ilayokumo A^ayodiyahumo waA^alosinatahumo biAls~uwo'i (tropical:) [And they will stretch forth towards you their hands and their tongues with evil]; (TA;) i. e., by slaying, (Bd, Jel,) and smiting, (Jel,) and reviling. (Bd, Jel.) And sometimes to denote giving liberally: (TA:) [as in] basaTa yadahu fiY AlA_anofaAqi (tropical:) He [stretched forth his hand, opened, or] was liberal or bountiful or munificent [in expenditure]: (Msb:) see basiyTN, below. (TA.) And sometimes to denote taking, or taking possession, or seizing: as in the saying, (TA,) busiTato yaduhu Ealayohi (tropical:) [His hand was stretched forth against him]; i. e. he was made to have dominion over him by absolute force and power. (K, TA.) And sometimes to denote seeking, or demanding: [as in basaTa kaf~ayohi fiY Ald~uEaA='i (tropical:) He expanded his two hands in supplication; a common action, in which the two hands are placed together like an open book upon a desk before the face, in supplicating God:] see baAsiTN, below. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] basaTotu lahu A^amoriY (tropical:) I displayed, or laid open, to him my state, or case, or affair; syn. fara$otuhu A_iy~aAhu: (A in art. fr$:) and A^amorahu [his state, &c.]. (TA in that art.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Aall~`hu yabosuTu AlA^arowaAHa fiY AlA^ajosaAdi Einoda AlHayaApi (assumed tropical:) [God diffuses the souls in the bodies at the time of their being animated]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] basaTa A@ll~`hu Alr~izoqa (assumed tropical:) God multiplied, or made abundant, and amplified, enlarged, or made ample or plentiful, the means of subsistence. (Msb, K. *) It is said in the Kur [ii. 246], waA@ll~`hu yabiDu wayabosuTu (Msb and TA in art. qbD, q. v.) And you say, basaTa Ealayohimu AlEadola (tropical:) [He largely extended to them equity, or justice]; as also ↓bs~Thu. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] fulaAnN yabosuTu Eabiydahu vum~a yaqobiDuhumo (tropical:) [Such a one enlarges the liberty of his slaves; then abridges their liberty]. (A in art. qbD.) ― -b6- [Hence also, basaTa wajohahu (assumed tropical:) It unwrinkled, as though it dilated, his countenance: see 7. And basaTa qalobahu (assumed tropical:) It dilated his heart: see remarks on qaboDN and basoTN, as used by certain of the Soofees, near the end of 1 in art. qbD. And] basaTahu, alone, [signifies the same; or] (tropical:) it rejoiced him; rendered him joyous, or cheerful: (M, K, TA:) because, when a man is rejoiced, his countenance becomes unwrinkled (yanobasiTu), and he becomes changed [and cheerful] in [its] complexion: it is wrongly said, by MF, to be not tropical: that it is tropical is asserted by Z, in the A: MF also says that it is not post-classical; and in this he is right; for it occurs in a saying of Mohammad: thus in a trad. respecting Fátimeh, yabosuTuniY maA yabosuTuhaA What rejoices her rejoices me: (TA:) [see also qabaDahu, where this saying is cited according to another relation:] ↓A^abosaTaniY [as signifying (tropical:) it rejoiced me] is a mistake of the vulgar [obtaining in the present day]. (TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] Alxayoru yaqobiDuhu waAl$~ar~u yabosuTuhu (tropical:) [Wealth makes him closefisted, tenacious, or niggardly; and poverty makes him open-handed, liberal, or generous]. (A in art. qbD.) ― -b8- [Hence also,] busaTa mino fulaAnK (tropical:) He rendered such a one free from shyness, or aversion: (S, O, K, TA:) he emboldened him; incited him to [that kind of presumptuous boldness which is termed] daAl~ap. (Har p. 155.) [In the CK, basaTa fulAnAF mn fulAnK is erroneously put for basaTa fulaAnN mino fulaAnS] ― -b9- [Hence also,] basaTa A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA EalaY~a (tropical:) God made, or judged, such a one to excel me. (Z, Sgh, K, TA.) ― -b10- [Hence also,] basaTa AlmakaAnu Alqawoma (tropical:) The place was sufficiently wide, or ample, for the people, or company of men. (K, TA.) And h`*aA firaA$N yabosuTuka (tropical:) This is a bed ample, (S, K,) or sufficiently wide for thee. (A.) And fara$a liY firaA$AF laA yabosuTuniY He spread for me a bed [not wide enough for me, or] that was [too] narrow [for me], (ISk, S.) ― -b11- [Hence also,] basaTa AlEudora, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) (tropical:) He accepted, or admitted, the excuse. (S, K, TA.) ― -b12- All these significations of the verb are ramifications of that first mentioned above. (TA.) -A2- basaTa, aor.
basuTa , (M, K,) inf. n. basaATapN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, free, or unconstrained, (munobasiTN,) with his tongue. (M, K.)
2 bas~aTa see 1, in four places.

3 bAsThu bAsTh bAsTp , inf. n. mubaAsaTapN and bisaATN (tropical:) [He conversed, or acted, with him without shyness, or aversion; boldly; in a free and easy manner; or cheerfully]: (TA:) he met him laughingly, or smilingly, so as to show his teeth. (So accord. to an expl. of the latter of the two inf. ns. in the TA.) [See kaA$arahu.] You say also, bayonahumaA mubaAsaTapN (tropical:) [Between them two is conversation, or behaviour, free from shyness, or aversion; bold; free and easy; or cheerful]. (TA.)
4 A^abosaTa see 1, latter half.

5 tabas~aTa see 7. ― -b2- tbs~T fiY AlbilaAdi (assumed tropical:) He journeyed far and wide in the countries. (S, TA.) ― -b3- xaraja yatabas~aTu (assumed tropical:) He went forth betaking himself to the gardens and green fields: from basaATN signifying "land having sweet-smelling plants." (TA.)

7 AnbsT A^nbsT AnbsT {nbsT quasi-pass. of basaTahu; as also ↓tbs~T is of bas~aTahu; both signifying It became spread or spread out or forth, or it spread or spread out or forth; it became expanded, or it expanded, or it expanded itself; it became extended, or it extended, or it extended itself: [&c.]. (M, K, TA.) You say, AnbsT Al$~ayo'u EalaY AlA^aroDi [The thing became spread or spread out, &c., upon the ground]. (S.) And AnbsT Aln~ahaAru The day became advanced, the sun being high: it became long: (M, K, TA:) and in like manner one uses the verb in relation to other things. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He expatiated. ― -b3- And] AnbsT wajohuhu (assumed tropical:) [His countenance became unwrinkled, as though dilated; i. e. it became open, or cheerful; and so AnbsT alone; or he became open, or cheerful, in countenance, as is said in the KL.]. (TA.) [And AnbsT, alone, (tropical:) He became dilated in heart; or he rejoiced; or
became joyous, or cheerful: see basaTahu.] ― -b4- [Hence also,] AnbsT (tropical:) He left shyness, or aversion; he became free therefrom: (S, TA:) he was, or became, bold, forward, presumptuous, or arrogant: (KL, PS:) he became emboldened, and incited to [that kind of presumptuous boldness which is termed] daAl~ap. (Har p. 155.) And AnbsT A_ilayohi (tropical:) [He was open, or unreserved, to him in conversation: and he acted towards him, or behaved to him, without shyness or aversion; or with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance: and he applied himself to it (namely, an affair,) with boldness, forwardness, presumptuousness, or arrogance.] (TA.)

basoTN bsAT bsT , as signifying A certain intoxicating thing, [a preparation of hemp,] is post-classical. (TA.) busoTN: see basiyTN, in seven places. bisoTN: see basiyTN, in seven places. busuTN: see basiyTN, in seven places.

basoTapN bsAT bsT bsTh bsTp
Width, or ampleness; syn. saEapN: (S, Sgh, Msb:) and length, or height: (Sgh:) pl. bisaATN: (Sgh:) and increase: or redundance, or excess: (TA:) and, (M, K,) as also ↓busoTapN, (K,) excel-lence; (M, K;) in science and in body: (M:) or in science, expatiation, or dilatation: (K:) or profit to oneself and others: (TA:) and in body, height, or tallness; and perfection, or completeness. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 24], wazaAdahu basaTapF fiY AlEilomi Aljisomi [And hath increased him in excellence, &c., in respect of science, or knowledge, and body]: (M,TA:) Zeyd Ibn-'Alee here read ↓busoTapF. (TA.) ― -b2- [An arm's length.] See baAsiTN ― -b3- AimoraA^apN basoTapN. A woman beautiful and sleek in body: and in like manner, ZaboyapN a gazelle that is so. (M.)
busoTapN bsAT bsT bsTh bsTp : see basoTapN, in two places.
A^u*unN basoTaA='u * (tropical:) A wide and large ear. (M, K, TA.)

busoTiY~N bsAT bsT bsTY bsTy
A seller of busoT [or carpets, &c.]: pl. busoTiy~uwna. (TA, but only the pl. is there mentioned and explained.)
basoTaAnu bsTAn : see basiyTN
busoTaAnN bsTAn : see basiyTN

basaATN bsAT Land (A^aroD) expanded and even; as also ↓ basiyTapN: (M, K:) and wide, or spacious; (AO, S, K;) as also ↓ bisaATN, (Fr, K,) in his explanation of which Fr adds, in which nothing is obtained; (TA;) and ↓ basiyTN; (K;) and ↓ basiyTapN: (AO, K:) and in like manner, a place; (S, TA;) as also ↓ bisiATN; (TA;) and ↓ basiyTN: (S, TA;) and land in which are sweet-smelling plants: (TA:) or ↓basiyTpN is a subst., (IDrd, M,) as some say, (M,) and signifies the earth. (IDrd, M, Msb, K.) You say, wasaEap ↓naHonu fiY bisaATK (tropical:) [We are in an ample and a plentiful state]. (TA.) And bayonanaA wabayona AlmaA='i miylN bsATN [the last word thus, without any vowel-sign to the b] (assumed tropical:) Between us and the water is a long mile. (TA.) [See also baAsiTN.] And mivolu fulaAnK ↓maA EalaY AlbasiyTapi There is not upon the earth the like of such a one. (TA.) And ↓*ahaba fiY busayoTapa, a dim., imperfectly decl., He (a man, TA) went away in the earth, or land. (A, O, L, K.) ― -b2- Also A great cooking-pot. (Sgh, K.)

bisaATN bsAT
A thing that is spread or spread out or forth; (S, M, K, B;) whatever it be; a subst. applied thereto: (B:) [and particularly a carpet; which is meant by its being said to be] a certain thing well known; the word being of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like kitaAbN in the sense of makotuwbN, and firaA$N in the sense of maforuw$N, &c.: (Msb:) pl. [of mult.] busuTN (M, Msb, K) and busoTN and [of pauc.] A^abosTapN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also basiyTN; near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b3- AinobaraY liTaY~i bisaATihi. is a phrase meaning (assumed tropical:) He hastened to cut short his speech. (Har p. 280.) -A2- Also The leaves of the tree called samur that fall upon a garment, or piece of cloth, spread for them, the tree being beaten. (M, K.) -A3- See also basaATN, in three places.

basiyTa bsyT , and basiyTapN: see basaATN, in six places. ― -b2- waqaEa Algayovu basiyTFA mutadaArikFA The rain fell spreading widely upon the earth, continuously, or consecutively. (TA.) ― -b3- fulaAnN basiyTu Aljisomi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is tall of body]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- basiyTu Alwajohi (tropical:) A man (M) having the countenance [unwrinkled, or] bright with joy: (M, K, TA:) pl. busuTN (M, K. *) ― -b5- basiyTu Alyadayoni (tropical:) A man large, or extensive, in beneficence; (M, TA;) liberal, bountiful: (K, TA:) pl. busuTN: (M, K:) [and so] basiyTu AlbaAEi (S,) [and] AlbaAEi ↓ munobasiTu. (TA.) And ↓ yaduhu bisoTN (S, K,) like TiHonN in the sense of maToHuwnN, and qiTofN in the sense of maqoTuwfN, (TA,) and ↓ busuTN (Z, K,) like A^unufN and sujuHN, (Z,) and (Z, K) by contraction, (Z,) ↓busoTN, (Z, K,) and ↓mabosuwTapN, (TA,) (tropical:) His hand is liberal; syn. muTolaqapN, (S, K, TA,) and TaloqN; (TA;) or he is large in expenditure. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [v. 69], balo ↓yadaAhu mabosuwTataAni; (TA;) and accord. to one reading, ↓bisoTaAni; (S, K;) and accord. to another, with damm, [as though it were ↓ busoTaAni,] (Z, K, TA,) [but it is said that] in this case it is used as an inf. n., [and therefore ↓busoTaAnN, for an inf. n. is applied as an epithet to a dual and a pl. subst. without alteration,] like guforAnN and ruDowaAnN; or, accord. to some, it is most probably [↓basoTaAnu,] like raHomaAnu; and Talhah Ibn-Musarrif read ↓bisaTaAni: (TA:) the meaning is, (tropical:) Nay, his hands are liberal, or bountiful; the phrase being a simile; for in this case there is no hand, nor any stretching forth. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., limusiYo'i Aln~ahaAri Hat~aY yatuwba ↓yadaA A@ll~`hi busoTaAni biAll~ayoli walimusiYo'i All~ayoli Hat~aY yatuwba biAln~ahaAri, (K, * TA,) or, accord. to one relation, ↓ bisoTaAni, (TA,) meaning (tropical:) God is liberal in forgiveness to the evil-doer of the day-time until he repent [in the night, and to the evil-doer of the night-time until he repent in the day]: for a king is said to be Alyadi↓mabosuwTu when he is (tropical:) liberal in his gifts by command and by sign, although he gives nothing thereof with his hand, nor stretches it forth with them at all. (Sgh. TA.) ― -b6- basiyTN also signifies All~saAni↓munobasiTu, (Lth,) or munobasiTN bilisaAnihi, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) [Free, or unconstrained, in tongue, or with his tongue,] applied to a man: (M:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b7- AlbasiyTu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (S, M, * K;) namely, the third; the measure of which consists of musotafoEiluno faAEiluno eight [a mistake for four] times: (K:) so called because of the extension of its A^asobaAb, commencing with a sabab immediately followed by another sabab, as is said by Aboo-Is-hák. (M.) ― -b8- [basiyTN is also used in philosophy as signifying (assumed tropical:) Simple; uncompounded.]
basiyTapN bsyT bsyTh bsyTp , as an epithet; and as a subst.: see basaATN, in four places. ― -b2- [In philosophy, (assumed tropical:) A simple element: pl. basaAy^iTu.]
*ahaba fiY busayoTapa * : see basaATN.

baAsiTN bAsT act. part. n. of basaTa. ― -b2- It is said in the Kur [vi. 93], waAlmalaAy^ikapu baAsiTuwA A^ayodiyhimo, meaning (tropical:) The angels being made to have dominion over them by absolute force and power (K, * TA.) And again, in the Kur [xiii. 15], kabaAsiTi kaf~ayohi A_ilaY AlmaA='i liyaboluga (tropical:) Like the supplicator of water, making a sign to it [with his two hands], in order that it may [reach his mouth, and so] answer his prayer; (K, * TA;) or, but it will not answer his prayer. (O, TA.) ― -b3- AlbaAsiTu (assumed tropical:) God, who amplifies, or enlarges, or makes ample or plentiful, the means of subsistence, to whomsoever He will, (K, TA,) by his liberality and his mercy: (TA:) or who diffuses (yabosuTu) the souls in the bodies at the time of [their] being animated. (TA.) ― -b4- maA='N baAsiTN (tropical:) Water that is distant from the herbage, or pasturage, (M, K, TA,) but less so than what is termed muTolibN. (M, TA.) And xamosN baAsiTN (assumed tropical:) A difficult [journey of the kind termed] ximosa [i. e. of five days, whereof the second and third and fourth are without water]; syn. baAy^iSN. (Sgh, K.) And EuqobapN baAsiTapN (ISK, S, M, K [in the CK, erroneously, EaqabapN]) (assumed tropical:) [A stage of a journey, or march or journey from one halting-place to another,] that is far, or distant, (ISk, S,) or long: (TA:) or in which are two nights to the water. (M, K.) You say, sironaA EuqobapF baAsiTapF (assumed tropical:) [We journeyed a stage, &c.,] that was far, or distant, or long. (ISk, S, * TA.) ― -b5- rakiy~apN qaAmapN baAsiTapN, [in the CK,] and qAmapu bAsiTapN, as a prefixed n. with its complement imperfectly decl., as though they made it determinate, i. q. ↓qaAmapN wabasoTapN [A well measuring, or of the depth of, a man's stature and an arm's length]. (O, K.) AZ says, Hafara Alr~ajulu qaAmapF baAsiTapF The man dug to the depth of his stature and his arm's length (L, TA.)

mabosaTN mbsT
Width, or extent; syn. mut~asaEN: (K:) as in the phrase baladN EariyDu AlmabosaTi [A region wide in extent]. (TA.) [See also basoTapN.]
mabosuwTu Alyadi mbswT Alyd : and yadahu mabosuwTapN, and yadaAhu mabosuwTataAni: see basiyTN.
munobasiTu AlbaAEi mnbsT AlbAE : and munobasiTu All~isaAni: see basiyTN.

1 basaqa Aln~axolu bsq Alnxl , (aor.
basuqa , Msb,) inf. n. busuwqN, The palm-trees were, or became, tall, (JK, S, Msb, K,) and full-grown: (JK:) or exceedingly tall. (Msb.) ― -b2- basaqa Ealayohimo, (inf. n. as above, TA,) (tropical:) He overcame them, excelled them, or was superior to them; (JK, S, K;) namely, his companions: (S:) he surpassed them in excellence. (TA.) And basaqahumo He became exalted above them in fame, or renown. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- basaqa fiY Eilomihi He was, or became, skilled in his science, knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it. (Msb.) -A2- basaqa, (JK, S, &c.,) [aor.
basuqa ,] inf. n. basoqN, (S, TA,) or busaAqN, (Msb,) [but see the latter below,] i. q. baSaqa (JK, S, * Msb, K) and bazaqa (TA) [He spat]: but some, as on the authority of Kh, disallow it, saying that it has no other signification than that of excessive tallness, as in the case of a palm-tree: (Msb:) or the second of these verbs is the most chaste; the first and last being of weak authority, or rare. (TA.) -A3- basaqati Al$~amosu i. q. bazaqat [and bazagat, i. e. The sun rose]. (TA.)

1 basolN bsl sl (inf. n. of basala, M) is The act of preventing, hindering, withholding, debarring, forbidding, or prohibiting; syn. manoEN; the primary meaning; (Bd in vi. 69;) and A_iEojaAlN (M, K) and HabosN; (AA, K;) [both syn. with manoEN;] and ↓ A_ibosaAlN [inf. n. of 4, q. v. infrà,] signifies the same. (Bd ubi suprà.) You say, basalaniy Eano HaAjatiY, inf. n. as above, He prevented me from accomplishing my want; syn. A^aEojalaniY. (M.) -A2- basala, (M, K,) aor.
basula , (M,) inf. n. busuwlN, He (a man, TA) frowned, contracted his face, or looked sternly or austerely or morosely; or, doing so, grinned, or displayed his teeth; or contracted the part between his eyes; (Eabasa;) by reason of courage, or of anger; as also ↓ tbs~l: (M, K:) and [so in the M, but in the K “or” ] ↓ tbs~l wajohuhu, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or ↓ tbs~l [alone], (so in other copies of the K, and in the TA,) His face, or he, was, or became, odious, and excessively foul or unseemly or hideous, in aspect: (M, K:) and liY ↓ tbs~l He (a man) was displeasing, or odious, in aspect to me. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence], (M, K,) inf. n. busuwlN, (TA,) said of milk, and of nabiy* [or must &c.], (tropical:) It was, or became, strong: (K: [in the CK, bas~ala is here erroneously put for basala; and wabas~alahu, which should next follow, is omitted:]) or, said of the former, it was, or became, displeasing, or odious, in taste, and sour; and, said of the latter, it was, or became, strong, and sour. (M, TA.) Also, said of vinegar, (assumed tropical:) It, having been left long, became altered, or corrupted, in flavour. (Az in art. H*q, TA.) And, said of flesh-meat, (assumed tropical:) It stank, or became stinking. (AHn, M, TA.) -A3- bisula, [aor.
basula ,] inf. n. basaAlapN (S, M, Msb, K) and basaAlN, [respecting which latter see what follows in the next sentence,] (M, K,) He was, or became, courageous, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight: (S, M, Msb, K:) from basolN meaning “forbidden,” or “prohibited;” because he who has this quality defends himself from his antagonist, as though it were forbidden to him [the latter] to do him a displeasing, or an evil, deed. (Ham p. 13.) El-Hoteíah says,
waA^aHolaY mina Alt~amori AljaniY~i wa fiyhimu
basaAlapu nafosK A_ino A^uriyda basaAluhaA
[And sweeter than fresh-gathered dates, and in them is courageousness of soul, if courageousness thereof be desired]: but bsAlhA may be here altered by curtailment from basaAlanuhaA. (M.) You say, maA A^aboyana basaAlatahu [How manifest is] his courage! (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

2 bs~lhu bslh bslp bzlp sl slp , (M, K,) inf. n. tabosiylN, (K,) He made it (a thing) to be an object of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred; syn. kar~ahahu: (M:) or he disliked it, disapproved of it, or hated it; syn. karihahu. (K.)
3 mubaAsalapN mbAslh mbAslp [inf. n. of bAsl] The act of assaulting, or assailing, in war. (S, PS.)

4 A_ibosaAlN AbsAl [inf. n. of Absl] i. q. basolN as explained in the first sentence of this art. ; i. e., The act of preventing, hindering, withholding, debarring, (Bd in vi. 69,] forbidding, or prohibiting. (S, K, and Bd ubi suprà.) -A2- Abslhu (inf. n. as above, TA) He pledged, or gave in pledge, him, or it, (M, Msb, K,) lika*aA [and bika*aA, as will be shown below, both meaning for such a thing]: and he gave in exchange, or as an equivalent, him, or it, lika*aA [and app. bika*aA also, as above, for such a thing]; syn. Ear~aDahu: (M, K:) and he gave him up, delivered him, delivered him over, or consigned him, to destruction, (S, K,) or to punishment. (Az, TA.) 'Owf Ibn-El-Ahwas says,
waA_ibosaAliy baniY~a bigayorijuromK baEawonaAhu wa laA bidamK muraAqi
[And my giving in pledge, or as an equivalent, or giving up to destruction, my sons, not for a crime that we have committed, nor for blood that has been shed by us]: (S, M, TA:) for he had given his sons in pledge for others, seeking peace, or reconciliation. (S, TA.) A^ano tubosala bimaA kasabato, in the Kur [vi. 69], means Lest a soul should be given up, or delivered, &c., (AO, S, Bd, Jel, TA.) to destruction, (Bd, Jel, TA,) or to punishment, (Az, TA,) for that which it hath done, (Az, Bd, Jel, TA,) of evil: (Bd:) or be given in pledge. (Bd, TA.) And A^uwl`y^ika Al~a*iyna A^ubosiluwA bimaA kasabuwA, in the same [ubi suprà], means, in like manner, Those who are given up, or delivered, &c., (to punishment, Bd) for their sins: (El- Hasan, Bd, * TA:) or who are given in pledge: (Msb, TA:) or are destroyed: or, as Mujáhid says, are disgraced, or put to shame, by the
exposure of their sins: or, as Katádeh says, are imprisoned. (TA.) ― -b2- Abslhu liEamalihi and biEamalihi He left him to his work, not interfering with him therein. (M, K.) ― -b3- Absl nafosahu lilomawoti, (M, K,) as also ↓ Astbsl [alone], (M, K, and Ham p. 291), and ↓ tbs~l, and ↓ bsl, [which last may be either basala or basula, or perhaps it is a mistranscription for A^abosala,] (Ham ibid.,) He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to death, (M, K, Ham,) and felt certain, or sure, of it: (Ham, TA:) and in like manner, lilD~arobi [to beating, i. e., to being beaten]: (TA:) and lilomawoti ↓ Abtsl He submitted himself to death: (TA:) and ↓ Astbsl He threw himself into war, or battle, or fight, desiring to slay or be slain, (S K,) inevitably. (S.) -A3- maA A^abosalahu How courageous, or stronghearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight! (TA.)

(MF. [But this derivation seems to be extremely far-fetched.])

1 ba$~a * , first pers. ba$i$otu, aor. yaba$~u, (S, K,) and, accord. to a relation of a verse of Ru-beh, yabi$~u, so that perhaps ba$a$otu was also said, (TA.) inf. n. ba$aA$apN (S, A, K) and ba$~N (A, K) and ba$iy$N, (TA,) He was, or became, cheerful in countenance. (S, A, K.) You say, ba$i$otu bihi I was, or became, cheerful in countenance [by reason of meeting] with him: (S:) or ba$~a bihi (TK,) inf. n. ba$~N (Lth, K) and ba$aA$apN, (K,) signifies he rejoiced in him, or was pleased with him, namely, a friend, (Lth, K,) at meeting: (Lth:) or he showed joy, or pleasure, at meeting him. (TK.) You say
also, biY ↓ laqiytuhu fataba$oba$a [app. meaning I met him and he became cheerful in countenance by reason of meeting with me]; originally ↓ taba$~a$a; the middle $ being changed into b: (Yaakoob, S:) or bihi ↓ taba$oba$a signifies he was, or became, sociable, or companionable, or cheerful, with him; and held loving communion with him: syn. A=nasahu, and waASalahu: (K:) but when said of God, it means (tropical:) He regarded him with favour, and honoured him, (IAmb, K,) and received him graciously, and drew him near to Him. (IAmb.) ― -b2- Also ba$~a lahu, (TK,) inf. n. ba$~N (IDrd, K) and ba$aA$apN, (K,) He presented a favourable aspect to him; or met him kindly, namely, his brother; syn. A^aqobala Ealayohi: (K:) he behaved laughingly towards him; without shyness, or aversion; or boldly; or in a free and easy manner; or cheerfully; syn. DaHika A_ilayohi, (IDrd, K,) and AinobasaTa. (IDrd.) ― -b3- And ba$~a lahu fiY AlmasoA^alapi, (TK,) inf. n. ba$~N (IAar, A, K) and ba$aA$apN, (A, K,) He was courteous, or gracious, to him in asking. (IAar, A, K.) ― -b4- And ba$~a liY bixayori (tropical:) He gave me [something good]. (A, TA.)

ba$ura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. ba$orN; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ Ab$r, (A,) inf. n. A_ibo$aArN; (K;) He pared (S, A, Msb, K) a hide, (S, A, Msb,) removing its ba$arap, (S,) or face, or surface, (A, Msb,) or the skin upon which the hair grew: (TA:) or, as some say, removing its inner part with a large knife: or, accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, some of the Arabs say, ba$arotu AlA^adiyma, aor.
ba$ira , meaning I removed from the hide its ba$arap; and ↓ A^abo$arotuhu as meaning I exposed to view its ba$arap that was next to the flesh; and A=damotuhu I exposed to view its A^adamap upon which the hair grew. And in the same sense ↓ A^abo$iruwA is used in the Kur xli. 30. (S.)

2 b$~rhu * (S, A, Msb, &c.,) the form used by the Arabs in general, (Msb,) inf. n. tabo$iyrN; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) and ↓ ba$arahu, aor.
ba$ura , (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the dial. of Tihámeh and the adjacent parts, (Msb,) inf. n. ba$orN and bu$uwrN (S, K) and bu$orN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and ↓ Ab$rhu; (S, A, Mgh, K;) and ↓ Astb$rhu; (K, TA;) are syn.; (S, K, &c.;) originally signifying He announced to him an event which produced a change in his ba$arap [or complexion]: and hence, (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee,) he announced to him an event which rejoiced him: (A, El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) so in common acceptation [when not restricted by an adjunct that denotes its having a different meaning: see bu$oraY and an ex. below in this paragraph]: (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) or he rejoiced him [by an annunciation]: (Msb:) and he announced to him an event which grieved him: [or he grieved him by an annunciation:] both these significations are proper. (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee.) You say, b$~rhu biAlA^amori [generally meaning He rejoiced him by the annunciation of the event]; and bihi ↓ ba$arahu, aor. and inf. ns. as above; &c. (TA.) And ba$~arotuhu bimawoluwdK [I rejoiced him by the annunciation of a new-born child]. (S.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 20, &c.], ba$~irohumo biEa*aAbK A^aliymK [Grieve thou them by the annunciation, or denunciation, of a painful punishment]. (S.) You say also, of a she-camel, ba$~arato biAll~aqaAHi, meaning (assumed tropical:) She made it known that she had begun to be pregnant. (TA. [See also 4.])

3 bA$r AlmaroA^apa * , (K, &c.,) inf. n. mubaA$arapN (S, Mgh, TA) and bi$aArN, (TA,) He was, or became, in contact with the woman, skin to skin: (TA:) he enjoyed [contact with] her skin: (Msb:) he became in contact with her, skin to skin, both being within one garment or piece of cloth: (K:) he lay with her, [skin to skin; or in the sense of] inivit eam: (S, K:) i. q. waTiy^ahaA, both fiY Alfaroji and xaArijFA minohu: (TA:) [and so ↓ ba$arahaA inf. n. ba$orN; for] ba$orN and mubaA$arapN are syn. [in the sense of congressus venereus, as is shown by an ex. in the S.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- bA$rhu Aln~aEiymu (tropical:) [Enjoyment attended him; as though it clave to his skin]. (A.) ― -b3- fabaA$aruwA rawoHa Alyaqiyni, or ruwHa Alyqyn, is a metaphorical expression, [app. meaning (tropical:) And they felt the joy and happiness that arise from certainty,] occurring in a trad. of 'Alee. (TA.) ― -b4- bA$r AlA^amora, (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. mubaA$arapN, (S,) (tropical:) He superintended, managed, or conducted, the affair himself, or in his own person: (S, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he was present, himself, at the affair: (A, TA:) or, [properly,] he managed, or conducted, the affair with his ba$arap, i. e., his own hand: (Mgh, * Msb:) and hence a later application of the verb in the sense of laAHaZa (assumed tropical:) [He regarded, or attended to, the thing, or affair, &c.]. (Msb.)

4 Ab$r * : see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Ab$r AlA^amoru wajohahu The affair made his countenance beautiful and bright: in the K we read, A^abo$ara AlA^amora Has~anahu wa naD~arahu; but this is a mistake. (TA.) Agreeably with this explanation, AA renders a reading in the Kur [xlii. 22], *`lika A@l~a*iY yubo$iru A@ll~`hu EibaAdahu, meaning That is it with which God will make beautiful and bright the face of his servants: so in the L. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2. ― -b4- [Hence,] A^abo$arati Aln~aAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel conceived, or became pregnant: (K:) as though she rejoiced [her owner] by announcing her conception. (TA. [See 2, last sentence.]) ― -b5- And A^abo$arati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The earth put forth its herbage appearing upon its surface. (S, K.) -A2- See also 1, latter part, in four places.
5 taba$~ara see, latter part.

6 tbA$r Alqawomu *
The people, or company of men, announced, one to another, a joyful event, or joyful events. (S.) And humo yatabaA$aruwna bi*`lika AlA^amori They rejoice one another by the annunciation of that event. (TA.)
10 Astb$r * : see 1, latter part. -A2- Astb$rhu He demanded of him a reward for an annunciation of joyful tidings. (M.) ― -b2- See also 2.
bu$orN * : see bu$oraY. ― -b2- It is also a contraction of bu$urN, which is pl. of ba$uwrN (TA) or ba$iyrN. (TA in art. n$r.)

bi$orN *
Cheerfulness, or openness and pleasantness,
of countenance: (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA:) and happiness, joy, or gladness. (Har p. 192.) You say, huwa Hasanu Albi$ori He is cheerful, or open and pleasant, in countenance. (S.)

ba$arN * : see ba$arapN ― -b2- [Hence,] Alba$aru (assumed tropical:) Mankind: (S, Msb, K:) and the human being: (Msb, K:) applied to the male and to the female; and used alike as sing. and pl. (Msb, K, TA) and dual: (TA:) so that you say, huwa ba$arN He is a human being, and hiYa ba$arN She is a human being, and humo ba$arN They (more than two) are human beings, and humaA ba$arN They two are human beings: (TA:) but sometimes it has the dual form; (Msb, K;) as in the Kur xxiii. 49; (Msb, TA;) though the Arabs may have used the dual form in the sense of the sing.: (MF:) and sometimes it has a pl., namely, A^abo$aArN. (K.) This is a secondary application of the word: (Msb:) i. e., this signification is tropical; or, as some say, the word is so much used in this sense as to be, so used, conventionally regarded as proper; the sense not depending upon its having another word connected with it: but in the S and K, and by the generality of authors, this signification is given as proper. (MF.) Some say that a human being is thus called because his ba$arap is bare of hair and of wool. (MF.) [Hence,] A^abuw Alba$ari [The father of mankind; meaning] Adam. (K.)

ba$arapN * (Lth, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb) and ↓ ba$arN, (S, K,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (Msb, K,) [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] like qaSabahu and qaSabN, (Msb,) and A^abo$aArN is pl. of ba$arN, (K,) [The external skin; the cuticle, or scarf-skin; the epidermis;] the exterior of the skin (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of a human being; (S, A, K;) and, as some say, of other creatures, (K,) such as the serpent; but this is generally disallowed: (TA:) or ba$arapN signifies the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair; as also A^adamapN and $awaApN: (Aboo-Safwán:) or the upper skin (Lth, M) of the head (M) and of the face and body of a human being; (Lth, M;) that upon which the hair grows: (M:) or, as some say, that which is next the flesh. (M.) It is said in a prov., A_in~amaA yuEaAtabu AlA^adiymu *uw Alba$arapi: see A^adiymN. ― -b2- ba$arapN sometimes means The complexion, or hue: and fineness, or delicacy. (TA.) -A2- ba$arapu AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The herbage appearing upon the surface of the earth. (S, A, K.) You say, maA A^aHosana ba$aratahaA (tropical:) How goodly is its herbage appearing upon its surface! (S, A.) And ba$arapN [alone] signifies (tropical:) Leguminous plants; herbs, or herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- ba$arapN is used also as signifying (assumed tropical:) A man's hand. (Msb.) [See 3, last sentence.]

bu$oraY * (imperfectly decl., because it terminates with a fem. alif which is inseparable from it, S) and ↓ bi$aArapN and ↓ bu$aArapN [but respecting this last see bi$aArapN below] (S, Msb, K) and ↓ bu$orN (Msb) are substs. from ba$~arahu (S, Msb, K) [originally signifying An annunciation which produces a change in the ba$arap (or complexion) of the person to whom it is made: and hence, a joyful annunciation; joyful, or glad, tidings; good news]: and ↓ tabaA$iyru [q. v. infrà] signifies the same as bu$oraY: (S, K:) ↓ bi$aArapN, when used absolutely, relates only to good; (S, Msb;) not to evil unless when expressly restricted thereto by an adjunct: [see 2:] (S:) its pl. is bi$aAraAtN and ba$aAy^iru. (A.)

yaA bu$oraAYa * , in the Kur [xii. 19, accord. to one reading, (otherwise, as Bd mentions, bu$oraAYo, or bu$oraY~a, which is a dial. var. of the same, or bu$oraY, which, as some say, was the name of a man,) meaning O my joyful annunciation, or joyful tidings, or good news!], is like EaSaAY: and in the dual you say, yaA bu$orayaY~a. (S.) You say also, ↓ tataAbaEati Albi$aAraAtu and Alba$aAy^iru [The joyful annunciations followed consecutively]. (A.) See another ex. voce ba$iyrN. ― -b2- See also bi$aArapN.

[
ba$ariY~N *
Human; of, or belonging to, or relating to, mankind or a human being.]
bu$aArN * (assumed tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (IAar, K.)
ba$uwrN * : see what next follows, in three places.

ba$iyrN *
i. q. ↓ muba$~irN, (S, Mgh, K,) [and so ↓ ba$uwrN, as will be seen by an ex. in what follows,] One who announces to a people [or person] an event, either good or evil; (TA;) but meaning the former oftener than the latter: (Msb:) [an announcer of a joyful event, or joyful events: one who rejoices another, or others, by an annunciation:] pl. bu$araA='u (A) and bu$urN, (TA in art. n$r,) or this is pl. of ↓ ba$uwrN. (TA in the present art.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 55], wa huwa A@l~a*iY yurosilu A@lr~iyaAHa bu$urFA, and bu$orFA, and ↓ bu$oraY, and ba$orFA; [accord. to different readings, meaning (assumed tropical:) And He it is who sendeth the winds announcing coming rain;] in which bu$urN is pl. of ↓ ba$uwrN, [syn. with ba$iyrN and muba$~irN, but both masc. and fem.,] (TA,) or of ba$iyrN, (Bd,) or of ba$iyrapN; (TA in art. n$r;) and bu$orFA is a contraction of the same; and bu$oraY is syn. with bi$aArapN; and ba$orFA is the inf. n. of ba$arahu in the sense of ba$~arahu (TA. [But the reading commonly followed in this passage is nu$urFA, with n: another reading is nu$orFA: another, na$orFA: and another, na$arFA.]) And ↓ Almuba$~iraAtu, (A,) or muba$~iraAtu Alr~iyaAHi, (S,) signifies (tropical:) Winds that announce [coming] rain: (S, A:) so in the Kur xxx. 45. (TA.) -A2- Also Goodly; beautiful; elegant in form or features; (S, K;) applied to a man, and to a face: (TA:) fem. with p; (S, K;) applied to a woman, and to a she-camel; (S;) and meaning, when applied to a she-camel, neither emaciated nor fat: or, accord. to Aboo-Hilál, neither of generous nor of ignoble breed: or, as some say, half-fattened: (TA:) pl. of the fem. ba$aAy^iru: (S:) and ↓ mabo$uwrapN signifies beautiful in make and colour; (IAar, K;) applied to a girl. (IAar.)

ba$aArapN *
Goodliness; beauty; elegance of form or features. (S, K, TA.)

bu$aArapN *
What is pared off from the face of a hide: what is pared off from its back is called tiHoliy^N. (Lh.) -A2- See also bi$aArapN: ― -b2- and see bu$oraY.

bi$aArapN * ; pl. bi$aAraAtN and ba$aAy^iru: see bu$oraY, in three places; and see also tabaA$iyru. ― -b2- Also A gift to him who announces a joyful event; and so ↓ bu$aArapN: (K, * TA:) or the latter, which is like the EumaAlap of the EaAmil, has this signification; (IAth;) and so ↓ bu$oraY; (M;) and bi$aArapN [has the same meaning accord. to common usage, but, properly,] is a subst. in the sense explained above, voce bu$oraY. (IAth.) You say, A^aEoTayotuhu vawobiY bi$aArapF I gave him my garment as a reward for the joyful annunciation. (TA from a trad.)

huwa A^abo$aru minohu *
He is more goodly or beautiful, more elegant in form or features, and more fat, than he. (K.)

tubu$~irN * , in the hand writing of J tuba$~irN, [and so in my copies of the S,] a word of which there is not the like except in the instances of tunuw~iTN [or tunaw~iTN], a certain bird, and waAdiY tuhul~ika [or tuhal~ika?] and waAdiY tuDul~ila [or tuDal~ila] and waAdiY tuxuy~iba [or tuxay~iba], (TA,) A certain bird, called the SufaAriy~ap: (S, K:) n. un. with p. (K.)

tabaA$iyru * , as though it were pl. of tabo$iyrN, inf. n. of ba$~ara; (A;) a word which has not its like except in the instances of taEaA$iybu and taEaAjiybu and tafaATiyru [and tabaAkiyru and tabaAriyHu, and probably a few others]; (TA;) (tropical:) [Annunciations; foretokens; foretellers; foreshowers; prognostics; earnests; of what is good:] the beginnings of anything: (S, K:) the first of blossoms &c.: (TA:) the beginnings, (S, K,) or first annunciations, (A,) of daybreak; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ ba$aAy^iru: (TA:) it has no verb: (S:) and [is said to have] no sing.: but in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, tabo$iyrN occurs as meaning (assumed tropical:) the commencement of rain. (TA.) One says, fiyhi maxaAyilu Alr~u$odi wa tabaA$iyruhu (tropical:) [In him are indications of right conduct, or belief, and its earnests]. (A.) See also bu$oraY. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Streaks of the light of daybreak in the night. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Streaks that are seen upon the surface of the ground, caused by the winds. (Lth, K. *) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The colours of palm-trees when their fruit begins to ripen; (K;) as also tabaAkiyru. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Such as bear fruit early, or before others, of palm-trees. (K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Marks of galls upon the side of a beast. (K.)

rajulN muw^odamN mubo$arN * (tropical:) A perfect man; as though he combined the softness of the A^adamap [or inner skin] with the roughness of the ba$arap [or outer skin]: (S:) or a man who combines softness, or gentleness, and strength, with knowledge of affairs: (As:) and AimoraA^apN muw^odamapN mubo$arapN (tropical:) a woman perfect in every respect. (TA.) [See also art. Adm.]
muba$~irN * and muba$~iraAtN: see ba$iyrN.
mabo$uwrapN * : see ba$iyrN, last sentence.
HijorNmubaA$irN * [so in two copies of the S: in Golius's Lex. mubaA$irapN:] A mare [so I render Hjr, which Golius renders ‘ vulva, ’] desiring the stallion. (S.) [See also mubaAsirapN, with s.]

1 ba$iEa * , aor.
ba$aEa , (K, TA,) inf. n. ba$aAEapN (S, K) and ba$aEN, (K,) said of a thing, (S,) or of food, (K, TA,) It was, or became, disagreeable in taste, and choking: (S:) or disagreeable, or unpleasant, having in it dryness and bitterness. (K, TA.) ― -b2- ba$iEa Alr~ajulu, (K, * TA,) aor.
ba$aEa , (K,) inf. n. ba$aEN (S, K) and ba$aAEapN, (K,) The man was, or became, disagreeable in the odour of the mouth, (S, * K,) from eating food disagreeable in taste, and choking; (S;) not removing the remains of food from between his teeth, nor cleaning them with the tooth-stick. (K.) You say, ba$iEa minohu [He was, or became, disagreeable in the odour of the mouth from it]; meaning, from eating food such as is described above. (S.) [Or this phrase in the S may have another meaning, which see in what follows.] ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) The man was, or became, evil in his disposition, and in his social intercourse. (Msb.) You say also, fiY xuluqihi ba$aAEapN (tropical:) In his disposition is evilness. (TA.) ― -b4- ba$aEN also signifies, in relation to wood, (tropical:) The abounding in knots. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The fauces' being straitened, or choked, by coarse, or rough, food.(TA.) [And ba$iEa minohu means He experienced a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces from it; namely coarse, or rough, food; or food disagreeable in taste, and choking: see 4: and see another meaning of this phrase above.] ― -b6- And [hence,] ba$iEa [or ba$iEa biAlmaA='i,] aor.
ba$aEa , (tropical:) It (a valley) was, or became, choked, surcharged, or overfilled, with the water. (K.) And ba$iEa biAln~aAsi (tropical:) It [a place] was, or became, choked, or overfilled, with men, or the people. (Z, TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] ba$iEa biAlA^amori, (K,) inf. n. ba$aEN and ba$aAEapN, (TA,) (tropical:) He was unable to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair. (K, TA.) -A2- ba$iEa biAl$~aYo'i, and ba$aEa bihi, inf. n.ba$oEN, He seized the thing in a violent and an abominable manner. (L,TA.)

4 A^abo$aEaniY AlT~aEaAmu *
The food caused me to experience a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces, (HamalaniY EalaY Alba$aEi,) by reason of its coarseness, or roughness. (IAar.) [See 1.]

10 Ast$Ehu *
i. q. Ead~ahu ba$iEFA [He reckoned it disagreeable in taste, and choking; or disagreeable, or unpleasant, as having in it dryness and bitterness]; (S, Msb, K;) namely, a thing. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Astb$E AlmuqaAma fiY maHal~i ka*aA He reckoned unpleasant, or uncomfortable, the remaining in such a place of abode; syn.Aisotaxo$anahu. (TA.) -A2- Aisotibo$aAEN also signifies The being bad, unpleasant, or disapproved. (KL.)

ba$iEN * A thing disagreeable in taste, and choking; or ↓ ba$iyEN has this signification : (so accord. to different copies of the S:) or both, applied to food, have the same signification: (TA:) or the former signifies also disagreeable, or unpleasant, food, having in it dryness and bitterness; (Lth, Z, K;) like the taste of the myrobalan: (TA:) or food rough, or coarse, and disagreeable in taste: or dry food, in which is no seasoning, or condiment: (TA:) or rough, or coarse; applied to food; (Nh;) and so (tropical:) applied to clothing; (IAar, Nh;) and (tropical:) to speech, or language; (Nh;) and ↓ ba$iyEN applied to speech, or language, signifies (tropical:) rough, or coarse, and disagreeable. (IAar.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (S TA,) as is also ↓ ba$iyEN, in the same sense, (TA, [but in what sense is not there said,]) it signifies, Disagreeable in the odour of the mouth, (Msb,ast; K,) who does not remove the remains of food from between his teeth, nor clean them with the tooth-stick; (K;) fem. with p: (TA:) and one who has eaten a thing such as is thus termed, (S K TA,) and not swallowed it easily, (TA,) and has become disagreeable in the odour of the mouth from it, or has experienced a straitened state, or choking, of the fauces from it. (S, TA: [the last words of the explanation being faba$iEa minohu]) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) One whose soul is heavy, or heaving, or agitated by a tendency to vomit. (ISh, K, TA.)― -b4- And (tropical:) Evil in disposition, (K, TA,) and in social intercourse. (TA.) You say also, huwa ba$iEa Alxuluqi (tropical:) He is evil in disposition. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (K, TA,) or ba$iEu AlmanoZari, (Msb,) (tropical:) Foul, or ugly, in aspect; (Msb; K) not pleasing to the eyes. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, (K,) or ba$iEu Alwajohi, (ISh, Msb,) (tropical:) Having a frowning, a contracted, a stern, an austere, or a morose, countenance. (ISh, Msb, K.) ― -b7- xa$abapN ba$iEapN (tropical:) A piece of wood abounding in knots. (K, TA.)
ba$iyEN * : see ba$iEN, in three places.

ba$iqa * , aor.
ba$aqa ; and ba$aqa, aor
ba$iqa ; He struck, smote, or beat, another with a staff or stick. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, K.) -A2- He looked sharply, or intently: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) inf. n. ba$oqN. (JK.) -A3- Also the former verb, He hastened, or was quick; as also ba$aka. (IDrd, TA.) -A4- And the former, [but the aor. is not mentioned,] He cut a garment, or piece of cloth, in a light, or prompt, manner; as also ba$aka. (TA.) -A5- And ba$aqa, inf. n. ba$oqN, He took, or seized. (Msb.)

naZarN ba$oqN *
A sharp, or an intent, look. (JK.)

baA$aqN * (JK, Msb, K) and baA$iqN, (Msb, Es-Suyootee, TA,) the latter being allowable accord. to some for the sake of conformity to the usual Arabic measure, as in xAtm and dAnq and TAbE and the like; (Msb;) perhaps derived from ba$oqN meaning the “ looking sharply, ” or “ intently; ” (JK;) or from ba$aqa meaning “ he took, ” or “ seized; ” (Msb;) or it is arabicized, (Msb, K,) from [the Persian] baA$aho; (K;) A certain bird; (K;) [the musket, or sparrow-hawk; falco nisus;] a bird of beautiful form, the smallest of birds of prey, that preys upon sparrows and other birds of their size: (Kzw:) it is of the birds called Suquwr, [pl. of SaqorN,] as are also the baAziY and the $aAhiyn and the zur~aq and the yuw^oyuw^: (AHát in “ the Book of Birds, ” TA:) pl. bawaA$iqu. (Msb.)

1 ba$ima * , aor.
ba$ama , inf. n. ba$amN, He (a man, S, TA, or an animal, Msb) suffered, or became affected with, indigestion, (S, Msb, K,) in consequence of much eating: (Msb:) or he was heavy in consequence of food: (Ham p. 363:) or he became distressed, or oppressed, by eating much food. (TA.) You say, ba$imotu mina AlT~aEaAmi I suffered indigestion from the food: (S:) or was heavy in consequence of the food. (Ham ubi suprà) And ba$ima AlfaSiylu mino kavorapi $urobi All~abani The young camel suffered indigestion from drinking much milk. (S.) Accord. to IDrd, ba$amN specially relates to beasts: accord. to Kh, it specially arises from greasy food. (Har p. 164.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He became affected with disgust, aversion, loathing, or nausea. (S, K, TA.) You say, ba$imotu mina AlT~aEaAmi, (S,) or Eani AlTEAm, (TA,) (tropical:) I turned away with disgust from the food; was averse from it; loathed it; nauseated it. (S, TA.) And ba$ima AlfaSiylu Eani All~abani (assumed tropical:) [The young camel turned away with disgust from the milk; was averse from it; &c.]. (K in art.dqE.)

4 Ab$mhu *
It (food) caused him to suffer, or be affected with, indigestion: (S, K, * TA:) or (assumed tropical:) loathing, or nausea. (K.)
ba$ima * part. n. of 1, meaning Suffering, or affected with, indigestion. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And (assumed tropical:) Affected with disgust, aversion, loathing, or nausea.]

ba$aAmN * [The tree of the balsam of Mekkeh; amyris opobalsamum; mentioned by Forskål in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. ex. as growing in the middle mountainous region of El-Yemen, and described by him in p. 79 of the same work; in both places as being called in Arabic Abw $Am, which is a mistake for b$Am;] a certain odoriferous kind of tree, (S K,) of sweet taste, (TA,) the leaves of which, (AHn, K) pounded, and mixed with AlHin~aA=' [or the leaves of the Lawsonia inermis], (AHn,) blacken the hair; (AHn, K) it is a kind of tree having a stem and branches, and small leaves, but larger than the leaves of the [species of marjoram called] SaEotar, and having no fruit; [but only, as Forskål states, a blackish seed, which is abortive;] when its leaf or its branch is cut, it pours forth a white milk; (AHn, TA;) and its twigs are used for cleaning the teeth: (S, K:) n. un. with p. (TA.) In a trad., mention is made of persons having no food but the leaves of the b$Am. (TA.)

ba$oniynN * , with fet-h, and then sukoon, and then kesr, I. q. nylwfr [i. e. niyluwfarN and nayoluwfarN or nayolawofarN, the nymphæa lotus, or white lotus: and the nymphæa cærulea, or blue lotus: see art. nylwfr]: a word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

baS~a bS , aor. yabiS~u, inf. n. baSiySN (S, A, K) and baS~N, (TA,) It (a thing, S, as, for instance, a grain of a pomegranate, TA) shone, or glistened. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- huwa yabuS~u liY, [He looks at me] is an expression used by the vulgar [in the present day], and is from AlbaS~aASapu signifying “ the eye. ” (TA.) [By rule it should be yabiS~u.]

2 bS~S bisayofihi bSS bsyfh bSS bsyfp
He made a sign with his sword, waving it, or moving it about [so that it shone, or glistened] (TA.)

R.Q.1 baSobaSa bSbS , (S, K,) or baSobaSa bi*anabihi, (M,) inf. n. baSobaSapN, (TA,) He (a dog, S, M, K, and a beast of prey, and a gazelle, and a camel when urged on by the driver's singing, TA) wagged, or moved about, his tail; (S, K;) which a dog does by reason of cupidity, or fear; (TA;) as also ↓ tabaSobaSa: (S:) or he (a dog) struck with his tail. (ISd.) The inf. n. baSobaSapN has a pl., namely, baSaAbiSu; as in the following ex.:
Hat~aY A_i*aA A^aboSaronahu wa Ealimonahu
Hay~ayonahu bibaSaAbiSi AlA^a*onaAbi
[Until, when they see him and know him, they greet him with waggings of the tails]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., respecting the flight and submissiveness of the coward,
baSobaSona A_i*o Hudiyona biAlA^a*onaAbi
[They wagged the tails when they were urged on by the driver's singing]. (As.) -A2- baSobaSati AlA_ibilu qarabahaA The camels performed quickly their nightjourney to water. (K.) [See baSobaASN.]
R. Q. 2 tabaSobaSa bSbS tbSbS : see R. Q. 1.

[
baS~N bS , and baS~u naArK, Live coals; because they shine, or glisten: n. un. with p: so in the present day; but probably only post-classical: or, accord. to the TA, in art. bSw, the word baS~apN is used by the vulgar, for baSowapN.]

baS~aASN bSAS [Shining, or glistening: or rather, shining, or glistening, much]. ― -b2- [Hence,] AlbaS~aASapu The eye: (S A, K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (TA:) said to be so called (TA) because it shines, or glistens. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence baS~aASN is applied in the present day to An officer employed as an inspector by a police-magistrate.]

buS~aAnN bSAn a name of [The month afterwards called] rabiyEN AlA=xiru: the former was its name in the Time of Ignorance: thus it is written accord. to the Jm: [or it was called, or was also called, waboSaAnu, and wuboSaAni: (see art. wbS:) or wabuSaAnN, and wa biSaAnN: (see art. bSn:)] the author of the K mentions it in art.bSn; [where it is said to be also written buSaAnN, i. e., without teshdeed;] but this is its proper place, for it is from AlbaSiySu [inf. n. of baS~a]. (TA.)

qarabN baSobaASN qrb bSbAS , (T, K,) or ximosN baSobaASN, (S,) A laborious, (T, S, K,) fatiguing, (T,) nightjourney to water, (T, K,) or journey in which the second and third and fourth days are without water; in which is no flagging: (S:) [as also SaboSaAbN.] ― -b2- yawomN baSobaASN A vehemently-hot day. (TA.)

1 baSura bSr , [aor.
baSura ,] (Sb, M, K,) and baSira, [aor.
baSara ,] (Lh, K, ) inf. n. baSarN and baSaArapN and biSaArapN, (M, K,) [He saw; i. e.] he became seeing; syn.SaAra muboSirFA; (Sb, M, K;) with bi prefixed to the noun following. (K.) But see 4, in four places. baSura is seldom used to signify the sense of sight unless to this meaning is conjoined that of mental perception. (B.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baSura, [and baSira.] inf. n. baSaArapN [and baSarN], He was, or became, endowed with mental perception; or belief, or firm belief; or knowledge, understanding, intelligence, or skill. (S, * M, TA.) And baSurabihi, (S Msb, B,) and baSirabihi, and sometimes baSurahu and baSirahu, but more chastely with bi, inf. n. [baSaArapN and] baSarN; (Msb;) and * AbSrhu; (B;) He perceived it mentally; (B;) he knew it [or understood it]. (S, Msb.) baSurotu bimaA lamo yaboSuruwA bihi, in the Kur [xx. 96], means I knew that which they knew not. (S.) -A2- baSara AlA^adiymayoni, aor.
baSura , (T, K,) inf. n. baSorN, (S, M, K,) He put the two hides together, and sewed them, like as the two edges of a garment, or piece of cloth, are sewed, one being put upon the other; which [mode of sewing] is contrary to, or different from, that in which a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed before it is sewed the second time: (S:) or he put together the two edges of the two hides, when they were being sewed, (M, K,) like as a garment, or piece of cloth, is sewed. (M.)

2 bS~r bSr
He (a whelp) opened his eyes. (M, K.) -A2- bS~rhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taboSiyrN; (TA;) or * AbSrhu; (accord. to some copies of the K; [see muboSirN, as confirmatory of the latter; but both seem to be correct;]) It [or he] made him [or caused him] to see, or to have sight: or to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill: syn. jaEalahu baSiyrFA. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the former, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He made him to know. (S, K) You say, baS~arotuhu bihi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) I made him to know it; acquainted him with it. (A, Msb.) And bS~rhu AlA^amora, inf. n. as above and taboSirapN, He made him to understand the affair, or case. (M.) ― -b3- Also He rendered it apparent, or plainly apparent, conspicuous, manifest, or evident. (S, K.) -A3- buS~irato bidimaAmK, said of the feathers of an arrow, They were besmeared biAlbaSiyrapi, i. e. with blood: (S:) or were strengthened and fastened with glue. (M.) -A4- Also bS~r, inf. n. taboSiyrN; (S, K) and ↓ AbSr; (K;) He went, (S,) or came, (M, K,) to the city of El-Basrah (AlbaSorap). (S, M, K.)

3 bASrhu A_Sr bASrh bASrp bA_Srh b|Srp |Srp
He looked with at a thing, trying which of them two would see it before the other. (M.) And baASaraA They two looked, trying which of them would see first. (K.) ― -b2- He elevated himself, or rose up, or stood up, so as to be higher than the surrounding objects, (A^a$orafa,) looking at him, or towards him, from afar. (S.) ― -b3- See also 4.

4 AbSrhu A^bSr A^bSrh AbSrh AbSrp bSr , (Lh S M, A, &c.,) inf. n. A_iboSaArN, (Msb,) He saw him, or it, (Lh, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) biruw^oyapi AlEayoni by the sight of the eye; (Msb;) as also bihi ↓ baSura: (A:) or he looked (M, K) at, or towards, him, or it, (M,) trying whether he could see him, or it; (M, K;) as also bihi ↓ baSura, inf. n.baSarN and baSaArapN and biSaArapN; (M;) and bh ↓baSira; (Lh, M;) and ↓ tb~Srhu; (M, K;) and ↓ bASrhu: (M:) or, accord. to Sb, ↓ baSura [is used when no object of sight is mentioned, and] signifies he [saw, or] became seeing: and AbSrhu is said when one mentions that upon which his eye has fallen. (M.) You say also, A^aboSira A_ilaY~a Look thou at me: or turn thy face towards me. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. -A2- And see 2. -A3- A^aboSiro bihi wa A^asomiEo, in the Kur [xviii. 25], means maA A^aboSarahu wa maA A^asomaEahu (Jel) (tropical:) How clear is his sight! and how clear his hearing! the pronoun relating to God; (Bd, Jel;) and thus used, the phrase is tropical; i. e., nothing escapes his sight and hearing. (Jel.) And A^asomiEo bihimo wa A^aboSiro, in the same [xix. 39], means maA A^asomaEahumo wa maA A^aboSarahumo (S in art. smE, and Jel) How clearly shall they hear! and how clearly shall they see! (S, Bd, Jel:) or the meaning is, do thou make them to hear, and make them to see, the threats of that day which is afterwards mentioned, and what shall befall them therein. (Bd.) -A4- A^aboSara also signifies He relinquished infidelity, and adopted the true belief. (IAar.) -A5- See also 10. -A6- He hung upon the door of his dwelling a baSiyrap, i. e. an oblong piece of cotton or other cloth. (TA.) -A7- See also 2, last sentence.

5 tbS~rhu A^bSr bSr tbSr tbSrh tbSrp
He looked at it; namely, a thing: or looked long at it: or glanced lightly at it: like ramaqahu: (TA:) or he sought, or endeavoured, to see it: (Mgh:) or i. q. A^aboSarahu, in a sense explained above; see 4. (M.) You say also, tabaS~aro liY fulaAnFA [Consider thou, or examine thou, for me, such a one, that thou mayest obtain a clear knowledge of him]. (TA.) And tbS~r fiY $aYo'K He considered a thing, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of it; he looked into it, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, until he knew it: he sought, or sought leisurely, or repeatedly, after the knowledge of it, until he knew it. (S, * K, * TA.) And tbS~r fiY raA^oyihi signifies the same as fiyhi ↓ AstbSr, i. e. He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or discover, what would happen to him, of good and evil. (M.)

6 tbASrwA tbASrwA
They saw one another. (M, K.) ― -b2- [tbASr also signifies He feigned himself seeing, either ocularly or mentally; contr. of taEaAmaY.]

10 AstbSr A^stbSr AstbSr {stbSr [He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or to perceive mentally]. You say, AstbSr fiY raA^oyihi: see 5, last sentence. ― -b2- He had, or was endowed with, [mental perception, or] knowledge, (Msb,) [or understanding, intelligence, or skill: as in the phrase,] AstbSr fiY $aYo'K [He had a mental perception, or knowledge, &c., of, or in relation to, a thing]. (S.) [See musotaboSirN.] -A2- It (a road, TA) was, or became, plain, clear, manifest, or conspicuous; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ AbSr. (A.)
baSorN bSr : see baSorapN, in four places: and see buSorapN.

buSorN bSr The thickness of anything; (M;) as of the heaven, (TA,) or of each heaven [of the seven heavens], (S, A, TA,) and of the earth, [or of each of the seven earths,] and of the skin of a
man, (TA,) and of a garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) You say vawobN jay~idu AlbuSori A thick garment or piece of cloth. (M.) SuborN, formed by transposition, signifies the same. (S in art. Sbr.) ― -b2- A side: (S, M, K:) the edge of anything: (S, K:) formed by transposition from SuborN. (M.) -A2- Cotton: (K:) whence baSiyrapN signifying “an oblong piece of cotton cloth.” (TA.) -A3- See also baSorapN.
biSorN bSr : see baSorapN, in five places.

baSarN bSr The sense of sight, (Lth, S,) or of the eye: (M, K:) or the light whereby the organ [of sight] (AljaAriHap) perceives the things seen (AlmuboSaraAt): (Msb:) pl. A^aboSaArN. (M, Msb, K.) [Hence,] SalaApu AlbaSari The prayer of sunset: or, as some say, of daybreak: because performed when the darkness becomes mixed with the light: (TA:) or because performed when the stars are seen: also called SalaApu Al$~aAhidi: (TA in art. $hd:) or because performed at a time when the eyes see corporeal forms, after the intervention of darkness, or before it. (JM.) And laqiyahu baSarFA He met him when eyes saw one another: or at the beginning of darkness, when there remained enough light for objects to be distinguished thereby: [accord. to some,] the noun is used [in the sense which it here bears] only as an adv. n. [of time]. (M.) And raA^ayotuhu bayona samoEi AlA^aroDi wabaSarihaA (tropical:) I saw him in a vacant tract of land, or of the earth, where nothing but it heard or saw me. (A.) [See also samoEN, in two places.] ― -b2- See also baSiyrapN, first sentence, in four places. ― -b3- Also The eye; [and so ↓ baASirapN;] syn. EayonN; but of the masc. gender: (TA:) pl. as above: (Kur ii. 6, &c.:) but the sing. is also used in a pl. sense [like samoEN]. (TA in art. smE.) See two exs. voce baSiyrpN.

baSorapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp
Soft stones; (AA, M, Msb;) i. q. ka*~aAnu; (AA, M;) as also ↓ biSorN (M, Msb) and ↓ baSorN; or, accord. to Zj, this last is not allowable: (Msb:) or soft stones in which is whiteness: (K:) or in which is some whiteness: (TA:) or soft stones inclining to white; as also ↓ biSorN, with kesr if without p: (S:) [i. e. whitish soft stones:] or soft white stone; as also ↓ biSorN (M) and ↓ baSorN: (TA:) or glistening stones; as also ↓ biSorN: (Fr:) pl. biSaArN: (M:) and rugged ground: (K:) or stones of rugged ground; (TA;) as also ↓ biSorN and ↓ baSorN and ↓ buSorN: (Kz, TA:) or these three words, without p, signify thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (K:) or the same three, hard, or strong, and thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (Lh, M:) and baSorapN signifies, also, land that is as though it were a mountain of gypsum: (ISh, L:) or land of which the stones are gypsum; (M, TA;) as also ↓ baSarapN and ↓ baSirapN; (so in a copy of the M, but accord. to the TA ↓ buSorapN and ↓ biSorapN;) but the last is app. an epithet: (M: [see baSirapN, below; and buSorapN:]) also tough clay in which is gypsum; (TA;) and ↓ baSirapN signifies tough clay: (M, TA:) or baSorapN, (M,) or ↓ baSorN, (TA,) tough and good clay, containing pebbles. (Lh, M, TA.)
buSorapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp [in the TA, as on the authority of ISd, ↓ baSorapN,] Good red land. (M, K.) See also baSorapN.
biSorapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp : see baSorapN.
baSarapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp : see baSorapN.

A^aroDN baSirapN *
Land in which are stones that cut the hoofs of beasts. (TA.) See also baSorapN, in two places.

baSiyrN bSyr
Seeing; i. q. ↓ muboSirN; (M, K;) contr. of DariyrN: (S:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN, (M,) or of the measure faAEilN [i. e. ↓ baASirN] : (TA:) pl. buSaraA='u. (M, K.) One says, A_in~ahu labaSiyrN biAlEayonayoni Verily he is one who sees with the two eyes. (Lh, M.) [Hence,] AlbaSiyru, as a name of God, The All-seeing; He who sees all things, both what are apparent thereof and what are occult, without any organ [of vision]. (TA.) And The dog; (M;) as also A^abuw baSiyrK: (Msb:) because it is one of the most sharp-sighted of animals. (M.) ― -b2- Endowed with mental perception; (B;) knowing; skilful; possessing understanding, intelligence, or skill: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (A.) One says, A^anaA baSiyrN bihi I am knowing in it, or respecting it. (Msb.) And A_in~ahu labaSiyrN biAlA^a$oyaA='i Verily he is knowing, or skilful, in things. (Lh, M.) And rajulN baSiyrN biAlEilomi A man knowing, or skilful, in science. (M.) And huwa mina AlbuSaraA='i biAlit~jaArapi He is of those who are knowing, or skilful, in commerce. (A.) ― -b3- It is also an epithet applied to A blind man; (A'Obeyd, M, B;) and so A^abuw baSiyrK: (TA in art. Ewr:) so applied as meaning endowed with mental perception; (B;) or as meaning a believer; (A'Obeyd, M;) or as an epithet of good omen: (M:) and A^abuw baSiyrK is used as meaning AlA^aEo$aY [the weaksighted, &c.,] for this last reason. (M.) -A2- See also baSiyrapN.

baSiyrapN bSyr bSyrh bSyrp
Mental perception; the perceptive faculty of the mind; as also ↓ baSarN: (B:) knowledge; (Msb;) as also ↓ baSarN (S, Msb) and AisotiboSaArN: (Msb:) understanding; intelligence; skill: (M, K:) AlbaSiyrapu signifies AlAi sotiboSaAru fiY Al$~aYo'i [which implies all the meanings above: see 10]: (S:) and Alqalobi ↓ baSaru [in like manner] signifies mental perception or vision or view; idea, or opinion, occurring to the mind: (M, K:) the pl. of baSiyrapN is baSaAy^ru; (M, B;) and the pl. of ↓ baSarN, as syn. therewith, A^aboSaArN. (B.) [Sometimes it is opposed to baSarN, as in the first and second of the following exs.] A^ahuwnu mino EimaY AlbaSaAy^iri ↓ EamaY AlA^aboSaAri [Blindness of the eyes is a lighter thing than blindness of the perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.) When Mo'áwiyeh said to Ibn-(??)Abbás, yaAbaniY ↓ haA$imK tuSaAbuwna fiY A^aboSaArikumo [O sons of Háshim, ye are afflicted in your eyes], the latter replied, waA^anotumo yaA baniY A^umay~apa tuSaAbuwna fiY baSaAy^irikumo [And ye, O sons of Umeiyeh, are afflicted in your perceptive faculties of the mind]. (M.) And the Arabs say, A^aEomaY A@ll~`hu baSaAy^irapu May God blind his faculties of understanding! And one says, lahu firaAsapN *aAtu baSiyrapK, and baSaAy^ira, (tropical:) He possesses true intuitive perception. (A.) And raA^ayotu Ealayoka *aAta AlbaSaAy^iri (tropical:) [I saw impressed upon thee the signs of perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.) ― -b2- Also Belief, or firm belief, of the heart, or mind. (M, K.) And EalaY baSiyrapK According to, or agreeably with, knowledge and assurance: (TA:) and purposely; intentionally. (M, TA.) And EalaY gayori baSiyrapK Without certainty. (M, TA.) ― -b3- Constancy, or firmness, in religion. (TA.) ― -b4- An evidence, a testimony, a proof, an argument, or the like; as also ↓ maboSarapN (S, K) and ↓ maboSarN. (K.) ― -b5- [And hence,] Blood, (M,) or somewhat thereof, (As, S, K,) by which one is directed to an animal that has been shot, or to the knowledge thereof: (As, AA, S, M, K:) or blood upon the ground; (AZ, S;) what sticks upon the ground, not upon the body: (M:) what adheres to the body is termed jadiy~apN: (AZ, S:) or a portion of blood of the size of a dirhem: (TA:) or what is of a round form, like a shield: or what is of an oblong form: or what is of the size of the firosin [or foot] of the camel: in all these explanations, blood being meant: or blood not flowing: or what flows thereof at one single time: (M:) or a portion of blood that glistens: (B:) and (as some say, M) the blood of a virgin: (M, K:) and blood-revenge: and a fine for homicide: (TA:) pl. baSaAy^iru, as above: (S, M:) and ↓ baSiyrN, which occurs in a verse cited by AHn, may also be a pl. of baSiyrapN, applied to blood, [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which bSyrp is the n. un.,] like as $aEiyrN is of $aEiyrapN; or it may be for bSyrp, the p being elided by poetic license; or it may be a dial. var. of bSyrp, like as one says bayaADN and bayaADapN. (M.) ElAs'ar El-Joafee says,
raAHwA baSaAy^iruhumo EalaY A^akotaAfihimo
wabaSiyratiY yaEoduw bihaA EatadN waA^aY
[They went with their blood upon their shoulderblades; but my blood, a ready and swift and strong horse runs with it]; meaning, they neglected the blood of their father, and left it behind them; i. e., they did not take revenge for it; but I have sought my blood-revenge: (S, M: *) but see another explanation in what follows. (S. [See also Ham p. 59.]) ― -b6- (tropical:) A witness: (Lh, S, * M, Mgh, K:) an observer and a witness. (A.)

bali AlA_inosaAnu EalaY nafosihi baSiyrapN bl AlAnsAn Ely nfsh bSyrh bl AlAnsAn Ely nfsh bSyrp , in the Kur [lxxv. 14], means (tropical:) Nay, the man shall be witness against himself: (S, Mgh:) or it means that his arms, or hands, and his legs, or feet, and his tongue, shall be witnesses against him on the day of resurrection: (M:) Akh says that it is like the saying to a man, A^anota Huj~apN EalaY nafosika: (S:) the p is added because the members are meant thereby; (B;) or to give intensiveness to the signification, (Mgh, B,) as in Eal~aAmapN and raAwiyapN; (B;) or because the meaning is EayonN baSiyrapN. (Mgh.) You say also, AijoEaloniY baSiyrapF Ealayohimo (tropical:) Make thou me an observer of them and a witness against them. (Lh, * M, * A.) ― -b2- An example by which one is admonished: (K:) pl. baSaAy^iru; which is said to be used agreeably with this interpretation
in the Kur xxviii. 43. (TA.) You say, A^amaA laka baSiyrapN fiyhi (tropical:) Hast thou not an example whereby thou shouldst be admonished in him? (TA.) -A2- A shield: (AO, S, M, K:) or a glistening shield: or an oblong shield: (TA:) and a coat of mail: (AO, S, M, K:) and any defensive armour: (M, TA:) and baSaAy^iru Als~ilaAHi any arms that are worn: and biSaArN, as well as baSaAy^iru, is a pl. thereof. (TA.) Accord. to AO, the verse of El-Joafee cited above commences thus:
HamaluwA baSaAy^irahumo EalaY A^akotaAfihimo
and the meaning is, [They bore] their shields [upon their shoulder-blades]; or their coats of mail. (S.) -A3- An oblong piece of cloth (K, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.) [See buSorN.] Such is hung upon the door of a dwelling. (TA.) And you say, raA^ayotu Ealayohi baSiyrapF, i. e. $uq~apF mulaf~aqapF [app. meaning I saw upon him a garment composed of two oblong pieces of cloth joined and sewed together]. (TA.) ― -b2- What is between the two oblong pieces of cloth [i. e. between any two of such pieces] of a bayot [or tent]; (S, K;) and what is between the two pieces of a mazaAdap and the like; what is sewed, thereof, in the manner termed baSorN [inf. n. of baSara: see 1, last sentence]: (B:) pl. baSaAy^iru: (S:) and ↓ baASirN signifies [in like manner] what is joined and sewed together (mulaf~aq) between two oblong pieces of cloth or two pieces of rag. (TA.)

baASirN A_Sr bASr bA_Sr : see baSiyrN. ― -b2- lamoHN baASirN (tropical:) An intent, or a hard, glance: (M, K:) or a very intent or hard glance. (S.) You say, A^arayotuhu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) I showed him a very intent or hard glance: (S, M: *) bASrA being here used for the augmented epithet [muboSirFA]; (M;) or it is a possessive epithet, (Yaakoob, M,) like laAbinN and taAmirN, meaning *uw baSarK, from A^aboSarotu, like mawotN maAy^itN from A^amat~u; and it means I showed him a severe thing. (S.) And laqiYa minohu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) He experienced from him a manifest, or an evident, thing. (M. [See also art. lmH.]) And raA^aY fulaAnN lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) Such a one beheld a terrible thing. (Lth, TA.) And A^araAniY Alz~amaAnu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) Fortune showed me a terrifying thing. (A.) ― -b3- It is said in a prov., xayoru AlgadaA='i bawaAkiruhu waxayoru AlEa$aA='i bawaASiruhu, [the word bawaASiru being pl. of ↓ baASirapN,] meaning [The best kinds of morning-meal are those thereof that are early; and the best kinds of evening-meal are those thereof] in which the food is seen, before the invasion of night. (Meyd. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 442.) ― -b4- baASirapN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]: see baSarN. -A2- See also baSayrapN, last sentence.
baASirapN A_Sr bASrh bASrp bA_Srh b|Srp |Srp : see baSarN: and see baASirN.
baASuwrN bASwr : see baAsuwrN.
binoSirN bnSr nSr : see art. bnSr.
A^aboSaru * [More, and most, sharp-sighted or clearsighted: see an ex. voce Hay~apN].
maboSarN mbSr : see baSayrpN.
muboSarN mbSr and its fem. muboSarapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

muboSirN mbSr : see baSiyrN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A watcher, or guard, set in a garden. (A.) ― -b3- And AlmuboSiru (assumed tropical:) The lion, which sees his prey from afar, and pursues it. (K.) -A2- [Making, or causing, to see, or to have sight: and hence, giving light; shining; illumining: and conspicuous; manifest; evident; apparent: also making, or causing, to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill.] waAln~ahaAra muboSirFA, in the Kur [x. 68, &c. (in the CK ↓ wAln~hAru muboSarFA)], means, And the day [causing to see; or] in which one sees; (K;) giving light; shining; or illumining. (TA.) And falam~aA jaA='atohumo A=yaAtunaA muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xxvii. 13], (assumed tropical:) And when our signs came to them, making them to have sight, or to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill; expl. by tajoEaluhumo buSaraA='a: (Akh, S, K:) or giving light; shining; or illumining: (S:) or being conspicuous, manifest, or evident: or we may read ↓ muboSarapF, meaning having become manifest, or evident. (Zj, M.) And A=tayonaA vamuwda Aln~aAqapa muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xvii. 61], (assumed tropical:) And we gave to Thamood the she-camel, by means of which they had sight, or mental perception, or knowledge, or skill: (Akh:) or a sign giving light, shining, or illumining; (Fr, T;) and this is the right explanation: (T:) or a manifest, or an evident, sign: (Zj, L, K:) and some read ↓ muboSarapF, meaning having become manifest, so as to be seen. (Zj, L.) And jaEalonaA A=yapa Aln~ahaAri muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xvii. 13], (tropical:) We have made the sign of the day manifest, or apparent. (K, TA.) -A3- One who hangs upon his door a baSiyrap, i. e. an oblong piece of cloth (K, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.)
maboSarapN mbSrh mbSrp : see baSiyrapN.

musotaboSirN mstbSr One who seeks, or endeavours, to see a thing plainly or clearly [either with the eyes or with the mind]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- wakaAnuwA musotaboSiriyna, in the Kur [xxix. 37], means, And they were endowed with perceptive faculties of the mind, or of knowledge, or of skill: (Jel:) or they clearly perceived, when they did what they did, that the result thereof would be their punishment. (M.) And you say, huwa musotaboSirN fiY diynihi waEamalihi He is endowed with mental perception, or knowledge, or understanding, intelligence, or skill, in his religion and his actions. (TA.)
1 baSoTN bST , [inf. n. of baSaTa,] i. q. basoTN, in all its meanings: (K:) the s, with T, is changed into S because of the nearness of the places of utterance. (L.)

baSaEa , (K,) inf. n. baSoEN, (S,) He collected: (K:) [J says,] I have heard from certain of the grammarians that AlbaSoEu is syn. with AljamoEu, but I know not what is the truth of the matter. (S.) Hence what here follows. (TA.)

A^aboSaEu * is a word used as a corroborative, and is pronounced by some with the pointed D, but this is not of high authority: you say, A^axa*otu Haq~iY A^ajomaEa A^aboSaEa [I took my right, or due, altogether]: and [the pl. is A^aboSaEuwna:] you say, jaA='a Alqawomu A^ajomaEuwna A^aboSaEuwna [The people, or company of men, came all together]: and the fem. is baSoEaA='u: you say, jamoEaA='a baSoEaA='a: and [the pl. of baSoEaA='u is buSaEu: you say,] raA^ayotu Aln~isowapa jumaEa buSaEa [I saw the women all together]: it is a corroborative occurring in a particular order, never before AjmE. (S.) [See A^abotaEu.]

baSuqa ,] inf. n. baSoqN, (S,) i. q. bazaqa (Lth, S, * K) or basaqa (JK) [He spat]: it is the most chaste of these three verbs. (TA in art. bsq.) baSaqa fiY wajohihi [lit. He spat in his face,] means (assumed tropical:) he held him in contempt, or despised him. (TA.) -A2- He milked a ewe when she was with young. (K.)

4 AbSqt AbSqt
She (a ewe) excerned the milk [or biestings into her udder before bringing forth]; (JK, K;) like Absqt [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- AbSq is also said of the qaSad, or small juicy branches, in the [species of mimosa termed] EurofuT [app. as meaning They excerned a matter like spittle]. (TA.)
