buSaAqN bSAq
Spittle, or saliva, that has gone forth from the mouth: as long as it is in the mouth, it is termed riyqN: (K:) [or saliva that flows: see buzaAqN:] i. q. buzaAqN (S, K) and busaAqN: (K:) but it is more chaste than either of these. (TA.) [buSaAqapN is app. its n. un. And hence,] ― -b2- buSaAqapu Alqamari White glistening stone: (S:) or stone of a clear white colour. (JK, K.) [Also written with s.] -A2- A species of palm-tree. (S, K.) -A3- The best of camels: both sing. and pl. (IDrd, K.)
baSuwqN bSwq A ewe having the least quantity of milk. (K, TA.)

2 taboSiylN tbSyl The act of stripping, or divesting; [like as when one strips an onion (baSalap) of its coats;] (K;) as also ↓ tabaS~ulN. (Fr, K.) You say, baS~alotu Alr~ajula Eino viyaAbihi [and ↓ tabaS~alotuhu] I stripped the man of his clothes. (TA.)

5 tbS~l tbSl
It (a thing) was, or became, several fold, or many fold, like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (Z, TA.) See also mutab~S~ilN. -A2- It is also trans.: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] tabaS~aluwhu (assumed tropical:) They begged of him so much that all that he had became exhausted. (Sgh, K.)

baSalN bSl [The onion; allium cepa: or onions, collectively:] what it signifies is well known: n. un. with p. (S, M, Msb, K.) Hence the prov., A^akosaY mina AlbaSali [Having more coats, or coverings,
than the onion]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also Any kind of bulb, or bulbous plant.] baSalu Alz~aEofaraAni [The bulb of the saffron], which is buried in the ground, is like the baSal [or onion] commonly known. (Mgh.) baSal AlfaA^ori is the same as AlA_isoqiylu and AlA_isoqaAlu and AlEunoSalu, (K in art. sql,) also written AlEunoSulu, (K in art. ESl,) or baSalu AlEnSl, (KL voce zyzN, [and so as written by Golius,]) [Scilla, or squill; particularly scilla maritima, or officinal squill; called by all these names, except, perhaps, AlsqAl, in the present day;] also called ziyzN, and AlbaSalu Albar~iY~u [the wild onion; but from what follows, it seems that there is a confusion here]. (KL ubi suprà.) baSalu Al*~iy^obi, and bSl Alzyr, (Golius on the authority of Zeyn El-Attár,) or bSl Alrnd, (so in the TA in art. blbs,) i. q. blbws Bulbus esculentus, (Golius, from Zeyn El-Attár,) or Albalobuws, with fet-h, [thus generally written, though it would seem to be correctly bulobuws,] the leaves of which resemble those of the sa*aAb [or rue]: (TA in art. blbs:) the balobuws is the wild onion (in Pers. PiyaAzo SaHoraAy^iY). (KL voce blbws. [This last assertion suggests that Alzyr and Alrnd may be mistranscriptions for Alz~iyz; the zyz mentioned before.]) [baSalu AlqYo'a Bulbus vomitorius; mentioned by Golius; and by Dioscorides, (l. ii. c. 201,) as being emetic and diuretic.] ― -b3- Also, (K,) or baSalapN, (M,) (tropical:) A helmet (M, K) of iron, (K,) pointed in the middle; so called as being likened to what is first mentioned above. (M.) Lebeed likens helmets to baSal. (S.)
mutabaS~ilN mtbSl (ISh, K) and ↓ *uw tabaS~ulK (ISh, TA) A covering of any kind (qi$orN) consisting of many coats; thick; (ISh, K;) like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (ISh, TA.)

buSomN A^Sm bSm The space that is between the extremity of the little finger and that of the third finger [when they are extended apart]: (S, M, * K:) mentioned on the authority of AO, (S,) or on that of Aboo-Málik alone. (M.) The Eatab is the space between the third finger and the middle finger; the ratab, that between the middle finger and the first finger; [but see these two words;] the fitor, that between the first finger and the thumb; the $ibor, that between the thumb and the little finger; and the fawot, that between every two fingers, in length. (S.) ― -b2- *uw buSomK Thick, or coarse; applied to a man, (M, K,) or a garment, or piece of cloth: (K:) or you say vawobN lahu buSomN, meaning a garment, or piece of cloth, that is dense, or compact; close in texture. (M.)

buSaAnN bSAn , (M, K,) so accord. to Ktr, (M,) and buS~aAnN, (K,) thus in some of the copies of the Jm of IDrd, (TA,) a name of The month rabiyEN AlA^xiru, (M, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aboSinapN (M, K) and [of mult.] biSonaAnN; (M, TA;) the latter erroneously written in the copies of the K buSaAnaAtN: (TA:) so says Ktr; but other lexicologists hold that it is wabuSaAnN, like sabuEaAn, and wabiSaAnN, like $aqiraAn; and this is the correct opinion: Aboo-Is-hák says that it was so named because of the wabiyS, i. e. gleaming, of the weapons therein: (M:) but it is said in art. wbS of the K to be waboSaAn and wuboSaAn: and Sgh holds buS~aAnN to be correct because baS~a and wabaSa signify the same. (TA.)

1 baDaDota bD bDDt , and baDiDota, (S, TA,) and baDuDota also, (accord. to one copy of the S,) [third pers., accord. to rule, baD~a, (accord. to Golius and Freytag baDaDa or baDiDa, but these are irregular forms, and not admissible without authority,) aor., accord. to rule, of the first yabiD~u, and of the second yabaD~u, and of the third yabuD~u,] inf. n. baDaADapN and buDawDapN, (S, TA,) Thou (O man) wast, or becamest, such as is termed baD~N; i. e. thin-shinned and plump; &c.: (S:) or very white or fair, with fatness: or delicate and clear in complexion, and such that the least thing made a mark, or an impression, upon thee. (TA.) -A2- baD~a AlmaA='u, aor.

yabiD~u bAD bD ybD , inf. n. baDiyDN (S, K) and buDuwDN and baD~N, (K,) The water flowed by little and little: (S, K:) or exuded upon a rock or the ground. (TA.) And baD~ati Alr~akiy~apu, and baD~ato bimaAy^ihaA, The well had, or yielded, little water; or its water became little. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Tabook, waAlEayonu tabiD~u bi$aYo'K mina AlmaA='i [The source, or spring, yielding scantily somewhat of water]. (TA.) And you say, baD~ati AlEayonu, aor. as above, inf. n. baD~N and baDiyDN, The eye shed tears. (TA.) And, of a man when you characterise him as patient under affliction, maA tabiD~u Eayonuhu [His eye does not shed tears]. (TA.) And baD~ati AlHalamapu The nipple streamed with milk. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maA tabiD~u bibalaAlK Having no milk dropping from it, or her. (TA.) And in another trad., saqaTa mina Alfarasi faA_i*aA huwa jaAlisN waEuroDu wajohihi yabiD~u maA='F A^aSofara [He fell from the horse, and lo, he was sitting, with the side of his face exuding yellow water]. (TA.) One should not say, baD~a Als~iqaA='u, nor Alqirobapu: but some say so, urging the authority of Ru-beh. (S.) And you say of a stone, and the like, baD~a, aor. as above, meaning Water flowed from it like sweat; water oozed from it. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, maA yabiD~u Hajaruhu (assumed tropical:) No good is obtained from him; (TA;) i. q. maA tanodaY SafaAtuhu: (S:) a prov. applied to the niggardly. (S, K.) [Hence also,] baD~a lahu, [aor., accord. to the TA, yabuD~u, but this is evidently a mistake,] (assumed tropical:) He gave him a little; as also lh ↓ AbD~, (Sh, K,) inf. n. A_iboDaADN: (TA:) and baD~a lahu bi$aYo'K (assumed tropical:) He did him a small benefit; as also naD~a. (As.)
4 AbD~ lahu AbD lh AbD lp : see 1, last sentence.

I took everything belonging to him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- tabaD~aDotu Haq~iY minohu I took the whole of my right, or due, from him by little and little: (S, K:) [as also tanaD~aDotuhu minohu.]

baD~N bD A man thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: (S:) or a man having a thin, or fine, and plump, skin, upon which the least thing makes a mark, or an impression: (Mgh:) or a man (As) soft, or tender, in body; not particularly implying whiteness: (As, S:) or soft, or tender, in body, thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: (K:) fem. with p; (S, K, &c.;) signifying a girl, (S,) or a woman, thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and soft, or tender, or delicate, (TA,) if tawny or white: (S, TA:) or soft, or tender, in body; not particularly implying whiteness: (As, S:) or fleshy and white: (AA:) or thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, in whom the blood appears [through the skin]: (Lh:) or soft, or tender, or delicate, compact in flesh, and very white or fair in complexion: (Lth:) and ↓ baDiyDapN and ↓ baAD~apN and ↓ baDobaADapN, applied to a girl, signify the same as baD~apN; (K, TA;) compact in flesh, plump, or soft and thin-skinned and plump, with a very white or fair complexion: (TA:) and ↓ baDaADN also is syn. with baD~apN, applied to a woman. (TA.)

baDaDN bDD
Little water. (S, K.)
baDaADN bDAD : see baD~N, at the end of the paragraph.

biy^orN baDuwDN * , (K,) or rakiy~apN baDuwDN, (S,) A well having little water: (S:) or of which the water comes forth by little and little: (K:) pl., in some copies of the K, biDaADN: in others, baDaAy^iDu. (TA.)

maA fiY Als~iqaA='a buDaADapN mA fy AlsqA=' bDADh mA fy AlsqA=' bDADp , (K,) or buDaADapN mino maA'K, (TA,) and ↓ baDiyDapN, (K,) There is not in the skin [even so much as] a small quantity of water: (K, TA:) from Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.)

baDiyDapN bDyD bDyDh bDyDp : see baD~N, near the end of the paragraph. -A2- Rain little in quantity. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- See also buDaADapN. -A3- A thing which the hand possesses. (K.) You say, A^axorajotu lahu baDiyDatiY I produced to him what my hand possessed. (TA.)
baDobaADapN bDbADh bDbADp : see baD~N, near the end of the paragraph.
baAD~apN bAD bADh bADp : see baD~N, near the end of the paragraph.

1 baDaEahu DEp bDE bDEh bDEp , (S, Msb,) aor.
baDaEa , (Msb,) inf. n. baDoEN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He cut it; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, flesh, or flesh-meat: (S, TA:) and it (a sword) cut a piece off from it; namely, a thing: (As, S:) and he cut it in pieces; namely, flesh, or flesh-meat: (K, TA:) and ↓ bD~Ehu, inf. n. taboDiyEN, has the first of these significations: (K: [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned:]) or this latter signifies he cut it much, or in several pieces, or in many pieces. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b2- He slit it; or cut it lengthwise; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely,
flesh, or flesh-meat, (Msb,) or a wound, (S, TA,) and a vein, and a hide. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence,] baDaEahaA, (Sb, Msb, TA,) aor.
baDaEa , (Msb,) inf. n. baDoEN (K, TA) and buDoEN, like $ukorN and $ugolN and kuforN, for fuEolN is not rare as a measure of inf. ns., (Sb, TA,) or accord. to some it is an inf. n. of this verb, (Msb,) but accord. to others it is a simple subst., (TA,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; he lay with her, or compressed her; (Sb, Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ bADEhA, (Msb,) inf. n. mubaADaEapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and biDaAEN: (S, Msb, K:) because in the act which it signifies is a kind of slitting. (Mgh.) You say, malaka buDoEahaA, i. e. jimaAEahaA. (Msb.) And it is said in a prov., ↓ kamuEal~imapi A^um~ahaA AlbiDaAEa (tropical:) [Like her who teaches her mother AlmujaAmaEap]. (S.) ― -b4- baDoEN also signifies (tropical:) The taking in marriage: (K, TA:) and buDoEN, as an inf. n., (assumed tropical:) The making a contract of marriage. (Msb.)
2 baD~aEa see 1.
3 baAoDaEa see 1, in two places.

4 AbDEhA A^bDE A^bDEhA AbDEhA bDE , (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iboDaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) He gave her in marriage. (Mgh, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) tusotaA^omaru Aln~isaA='u fiY A_iboDaAEihin~a (tropical:) Women shall be consulted respecting the giving them in marriage: (T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or, accord. to one relation, ↓ A^aboDaAEihin~a, (Mgh, Msb,) which [virtually] means the same; (Msb;) but this is a pl., namely, of buDoEN. (Mgh, Msb.) -A2- AbDE Al$~aYo'a He made the thing to be biDaAEap [i. e. an article of merchandise], (S, K, TA,) whatever it was; (TA;) as also ↓ AstbDEhu: (S, K:) or Al$~aYo'a ↓ AisotaboDaEotu signifies I made [or took] the thing as bDAEp [an article of merchandise] for myself: and you say, A^aboDaEotuhu gayoriY [I made it, or gave it as, an article of merchandise to another than me]: (Mgh, Msb:) and AbDEhu AlbiDaAEapa he gave him the article of merchandise. (TA.) Hence the phrase, in a trad. relating to El-Medeeneh, accord. to one relation, tuboDiEu TiybahaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) It gives the good that it possesses to its inhabitants; as explained by Z; but accord. to the relation commonly known, it is tanoSaEu, with n and with the unpointed S; [meaning “it purifies;”; (L in art.
nSE nSE ;)] and there are two other relations, which are tanoDaxu and tanoDaxu. (TA.)

7 AnbDE AnbDE
It was, or became, cut, or cut off. (K, TA.)

8 AbtDE minohu AbtDE mnh AbtDE mnp
He took, or received, [merchandise] from him. (TA: [in which the word biDaAEapF requires to be supplied in the explanation, and is indicated by the context.])

10 AisotiboDaAEN AstbDAE denotes a kind of matrimonial connection practised by people in the Time of Ignorance; i. e., A woman's desiring sexual intercourse with a man only to obtain offspring by him: a man of them used to say to his female slave or his wife, A^arosiliY A_ilaY fulaAn faA=sotaboDiEiY minohu [Send thou to such a one, and demand of him sexual intercourse to obtain offspring]; and he used to separate himself from her, and not touch her, until her pregnancy by that man became apparent: and this he did from a desire of obtaining generous offspring. (IAth, TA.) -A2- See also 4, in two places.
baDoEN bDE : see biDoEN, first sentence, and near the end: and see also baDoEapN.

buDoEN bDE
Initus; sexual intercourse: (Mgh, Msb, K:) a subst., (Mgh, Msb, TA,) accord. to some; but accord. to others, an inf. n.; (Msb;) held by Sb to be the latter: (TA:) [see 1:] and marriage; or the taking in marriage; syn. nikaAHN; (ISk, S, Msb, TA;) [which has also the first of the meanings given above;] as in the phrase malaka fulaAnN buDoEa fulaAnapa [explained above (see 1)]: (ISk, S:) or, (K,) in this phrase, (Mgh,) (tropical:) the pudendum muliebre; the vulva; (Az, Mgh, Msb, K, * TA;) and so in the saying, in a trad., Eutiqa buDoEuki faA@xotaAriY (tropical:) Thy vulva hath become freed, therefore choose thou whether thou wilt remain with thy husband or separate thyself from him; (TA;) and in the saying, tusotaA^omaru Aln~isaA='u fiY A^aboDaAEihin~a, accord. to those who thus relate it, others saying A_iboDaAEihin~a; (see 4;) A^aboDaAEN being pl. of buDoEN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The marriage-contract. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A dowry; or gift given to, or for, a bride: (K, TA:) pl. buDuwEN. (TA.) So in the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib,
wafiY kaEobK waA_ixowatihaA kilaAbK
sawaAmiY AlT~arofi gaAliyapu AlbuDuwEi
[And among Kaab, and their brethren Kiláb, are females lofty in look, or] proud, and dear in respect of dowries. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Divorce: (Az, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The authority possessed over a woman by her guardian who affiances her. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) An equal; particularly as a suitor in a case of marriage: as in the saying, in a trad., h`*aA AlbuDoEu laA yuqoraEu A^anofuhu (assumed tropical:) This equal‘s marriage shall not be refused, nor shall it be desired, or wished for; he shall not be rejected. (TA.)

biDoEN bDE (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ baDoEN, (S, Msb, K,) some of the Arabs pronouncing it with kesr, (S, Msb,) [A number under ten; and an odd number, meaning] a number between two round, or decimal, numbers; (AZ, K;) from one to ten [exclusive of the latter]; and from eleven to twenty [exclusive of the latter]; so accord. to Mebremán; (K;) i. e. Mohammad Ibn-'Alee Ibn-Ismá'eel the Lexicologist, Mebremán being his surname: (TA:) or from three to nine; (S, Msb, K [in the first and last the ns. being in the fem. gender; but in the second, masc.];) so accord. to Katádeh; (Mgh;) from three to less than ten: (Fr [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or not less than three nor more than ten; (Sh [the first n. of number in the fem. gender, and the second masc.];) from three to ten: (Mgh [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to seven: (Mujáhid, Mgh:) or to five: (AO, K [the n. of number in the fem. gender]:) or from one to four: (AO, O, K [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to five; an explanation ascribed to AO: (TA:) or from four to nine; (ISd, K [the ns. of number fem.];) and this is the signification preferred by Th: (TA:) or it signifies five: (Mukátil [this n. of number masc.]:) or seven; (Mukátil, K [in the K this n. of number being fem.];) so accord. to some: (AO:) or ten: (Ed-Dahhák [this n. of number masc.]:) or an undefined number; gayoru maHoduwdK; so says Sgh; [and the like is said in the Msb;] in the K, erroneously, gayoru maEoduwdK; (TA;) because it means a portion, (Sgh, K,) which is undefined: (Sgh, TA:) it also signifies, with ten, [in like manner; i. e. ten and a number under ten; or the like: as] from thirteen to nineteen. (Msb.) When used as signifying from three to nine, (Mgh, Msb,) or to ten, or to seven, (Mgh,) [or to signify some number under ten, without another n. of number,] it is masc. and fem. without variation: (Mgh, Msb:) you say biDoEu rijaAlK From three to nine [&c.] men: and biDoEu nisowapK from three to nine [&c.] women: (Msb:) and biDoEu siniyna from three to nine [&c.] years: (S:) and fiY biDoEi siniyna [in from three to nine, &c., years]: (Kur xxx. 3:) and falabiva fiY Als~ijoni biDoEa siniyna [And he remained in the prison from three to nine, &c., years]. (Kur xii. 42.) But when used to denote a number above ten, (Mgh, Msb,) with a masc. n. it is with p, (↓ biDoEap,) and with a fem. n. it is without p: (ISk, Mgh, Msb, K:) you say biDoEapa Ea$ara rajulFA From thirteen to nineteen [&c.] men: and biDoEa Ea$orapa A@moraA^apF from thirteen to nineteen [&c.] women: (S, Mgh, * TA:) like as you say valaAvapa Ea$ara rajulFA and valaAva Ea$orpa A@moraA^apF. (Mgh.) When you have passed the word denoting ten, (S, K,) [i. e.] to denote a number above twenty, (Msb,) it is not used: (S, Msb, K:) you do not say biDoEN waEi$oruwna, (S, K,) but nay~ifN waEi$oruwna; and so in the cases of the remaining numbers: (S:) or you do say biDoEN waEi$oruwna: (Sgh, K:) accord. to AZ, (Msb,) you say biDoEapN waEi$oruwna rajulFA (Mgh, Msb, K) meaning Twenty and odd men: (AZ, TA:) and biDoEN waEi$oruwna A@moraA^apF (Mgh, Msb, K) meaning twenty and odd women: (AZ, TA:) but not the reverse: (K:) ISd says, we have not heard this, but there is no objection to it: (TA:) and Fr says, biDoEN is not mentioned save with ten and twenty to ninety; (IB, K;) not with what exceeds this: (IB:) you do not say biDoEN wamiAy^apN nor biDoEN waA^alofN, (IB, K,) but miAy^apN wanay~ifN [and A^alofN wanay~ifN]: (IB:) it occurs in trads. with Ei$oruwna and with valaAvuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- biDoEN and ↓ baDoEN also signify A part, or portion, of the night: (K:) a time thereof. (Lh.) You say, maDaY biDoEN mina All~ayoli [A part, or portion, of the night passed]. (TA.) J mentions it with S [in the place of D]; and explains it by jawo$N, q. v. (TA.)

baDoEapN DEp bDE bDEh bDEp , (S, Msb, K,) with fet-h, other words of like meaning being with kesr, as qiToEapN and filo*apN and fidorapN, (S,) and sometimes with kesr, [↓ biDoEapN,]
(K,) and ↓ buDoEapN also is mentioned, (TA,) of which the first is the most chaste, though EshShiháb asserts the second to be more common, (TA,) A piece, or lump, or portion cut off; (TA;) particularly of flesh, or flesh-meat, (S, Msb, K,) in a compact, or collective, state: (TA:) pl. ↓ baDoEN, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which baDoEapN is the n. un.,] and biDaEN, (S, Msb, K,) as some say, (S,) but this is disallowed by 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, (TA,) [or it may be a correct pl. of biDoEapN agreeably with analogy,] and biDaAEN, and baDaEaAtN, (Msb, K,) and [quasi-pl. n.] baDiyEN, which is extr., like rahiynN and kaliybN and maEiyzN [&c.]. (TA.) Hence the saying [of Mohammad] in a trad., faATimapu baDoEapN min~aY yariybuniY maA raAbahaA wayuw^o*iyniY maA A=*aAhaA (tropical:) Fátimeh is a part of me: [that displeases and disquiets me which has displeased and disquieted her, and that hurts me which has hurt her:] or, accord. to one relation, he said buDayoEapN [a little part]. (TA.) One says also, A_in~a fulaAnFA la$adiydu AlbaDoEapi HasanuhaA meaning Verily such a one is corpulent and fat. (TA.) ― -b2- See also baDaEapN.
buDoEapN DEp bDE bDEh bDEp : see baDoEapN.
biDoEapN DEp bDE bDEh bDEp : see baDoEapN: and, as a noun of number, see biDoEN, latter half of the paragraph.

baDaEapN DEp bDE bDEh bDEp The sound of cutting of swords: occurring in the saying, samiEotu lils~iyaATi xaDaEapF walils~uyuwfi baDaEapF I heard a sound of falling of the whips, and a sound of cutting of the swords: (TA:) but in the S and A in art. xDE, and by IB, xDEp and bDEp are written xaDoEapN and ↓ baDoEapN; and IB explains the former as signifying the sounds of swords; and the latter, the sounds of whips. (TA in art. xDE.) [See also baADiEN.]

biDaAEN bDAE [The giving and receiving merchandise;] a subst. from A^aboDaEahu AlbiDaAEapa and AibotaDaEa minohu; [or rather an inf. n. of which the verb, baADaEa, is not used;] similar to qiraADN. (TA.)

baDiyEN DyE bDyE
Flesh. (As, S.) You say, daAb~apN kaviyrapu AlbaDiyEi (As, S, TA) A beast abounding in what is distinct from the rest of the flesh of the thigh: n. un. with p. (TA.) And rajulN xaAZiY AlbaDiyEi (As, S) A fat man. (TA.) And saAEidN xaAZY AlbaDiyEi [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] full of flesh. (IB.) [See also baDoEapN, of which it is a quasipl. n.]

biDaAEapN bDAEh bDAEp
Merchandise; or an article of merchandise; (TA;) a portion of one's property which one sends for traffic; (S;) a portion of property prepared for traffic, (Mgh, * Msb,) or with which one traffics; from baDoEN signifying the act of “cutting,” or “cutting off;” and vulgarly pronounced buDaAEapN: (TA:) pl. baDaAy^iEu. (Msb, TA.)

baADiEN bADE A sword that cuts off a piece of a thing that it strikes: (S, TA:) or a sharp, or cutting, sword: (K:) or a sword that cuts everything: (TA:) pl. baDaEapN: (K:) Fr says that baDaEapN signifies swords; and xaDaEapN, whips: but some say the reverse. (TA.) [See also baDaEapN above.] ― -b2- [See also the next paragraph.] -A2- [A broker who acts as an intermediary between the sellers and buyers of camels;] the same with respect to camels as the dal~aAl with respect to houses: (O, L, K:) or one who carries the articles of merchandise of the tribe, and conveys those articles from place to place for sale: (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, K:) it is said in the A that baADiEu AlHaY~i signifies the person who carries the articles of merchandise of the tribe. (TA.)

baADiEapN bADE bADEh bADEp
A wound by which the head is broken, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which cuts the skin, and cleaves the flesh (S, K) in a slight degree, (K,) and brings blood, but does not make it to flow: (S, K:) or which wounds the skin, and cleaves the flesh: (Mgh:) or which cleaves the flesh, but does not reach to the bone, nor cause the blood to flow: (Msb:) that from which the blood flows is termed daAmiyapN [app. a mistake for daAmiEapN]. (S, Msb.) -A2- A large flock (firoqN [in the CK, erroneously, firaq,]) of sheep or goats: (S, Sgh, K:) or a portion separated from the rest of the sheep or goats: (Lth, K:) pl. bawaADiEu: you say, firaqN bawaADiEu. (Lth.)
A^aboDaEu * as a corroborative after A^ajomaEu: see A^aboSaEu, with the unpointed S. Az says that it is an evident mistranscription. (TA.)

miboDaEN mbDE
A lancet; an instrument with which a vein is cut: (S, Mgh, * K, TA:) and [a currier's knife] with which leather is cut: (S, TA:) [pl. mabaADiEu: accord. to the Mirkát el-Loghah, as cited by Golius, it signifies a farrier's fleam; differing from mi$oraTN, which signifies a surgeon's lancet: but this distinction is probably post-classical; for accord. to the TA, these two words signify the same.]
maboDuwEapN mbDwE mbDwEh mbDwEp [used as a subst.] A bow: a bow cut from a branch. (TA.)

musotaboDiEN mstbDE . It is said in a prov., kamusotaboDiEi tamorK A_ilaY hajarK [Like the taker of dates as merchandise to Hejer]; because Hejer is [famous as] the place of production (maEodin) of dates. (S.) mstbDE is here made trans. by means of AlY because it has the meaning of HaAmil. (TA.)

1 baT~a bT , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
baTu3a , inf. n. baT~N, (Mgh, Msb,) He slit a wound, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or an ulcer, (S,) and a purse, (K,) &c. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
2 biT~T bTT , inf. n. taboTiyTN, He trafficked in the birds called baT~, q. v. (K.)
4 AbT~ A^bT A_bT AbT bT , (IAar, K,) inf. n. A_iboTaATN, (IAar,) He purchased [or became possessed of] a baT~ap [q. v.] for oil, or of oil. (IAar, K.)

R. Q. 1 Darabahu fabaTobaTahu Drbh fbTbTh Drbh fbTbTp
He struck him and clave his skin, or his head. (TA.) [See 1.] -A2- See also baTobaTapN, below.

baT~N bT
A kind of water-fowl; (S, O, Msb;) [the duck, or ducks; and the goose, or geese; but generally the former of these birds; agreeably with a statement in the Jm, that baT~N is applied by the Arabs to the small, and A_iwaz~N to the large;] i. q. A_iwaz~N, (K, TA,) both the small thereof and the large: (TA:) a Persian word (EajamiY~N), arabicized; [originally bato, or baTo, or baT~;] or, accord. to IJ, an imitation of its cries: n. un. baT~apN, (S, Msb, K,) which is applied to the male and to the female, (S, Msb,) like HamaAmapN and dajaAjapN: (S:) pl. biTaATN. (TA.)

baT~apN T`h bT bT`h bTh bTp n. un. of baT~N, q. v. ― -b2- Also A kind of bottle, or pot, of glass; syn. dab~apN; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, dub~ap;]) in the dial. of the people of Mekkeh; so called because made in the form of a living baT~ap: (Lth, TA:) or a vessel like the [flask, or bottle, called] qaAruwrap; (K;) [a kind of leathern pot, or bottle, of which the body is nearly globular, with a short and wide neck;] in which oil &c. are put: pl. buTaTN. (TA.)

baT~aATN bTAT
A maker of buTaT, pl. of baT~apN. (TA.)

baTobaTapN bTbT bTbTh bTbTp [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is ↓ baTobaTa,] The crying, or cry, of the baT~; (K;) after which it [the bird] is named, accord. to IJ, as mentioned above: (TA:) or its diving in water. (K.)
mibaT~apN mbT mbTh mbTp The miboDaE [or scarifying instrument] (K, TA) with which a wound is slit. (TA.)

1 baTuw^a * , aor.
baTuAa , inf. n. buTo'N (S, Msb, K) and baTaA='apN, with fet-h and medd, (Msb,) or biTaA='N, like kitaAbN; (K;) and ↓ AbTA^; (S, Msb, K;) He was, or became, slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; contr. of A^asoraEa; (K;) in his going or course, and in his gait [&c.]: (TA:) or the latter is said of a man; (S, Msb;) meaning [as above; or] his coming was late, or backward; (Msb;) [and is app. elliptical, for AbTA^ ma$oyahu he made his pace, or going, slow, &c.; or the like; see AsrE:] and baTuw^a [denotes what is as it were an innate quality; see, again, A^asoraEa; or] is said of one's coming; [meaning it was, or became, slow, &c.;] (S, Msb;) buTo'N being the contr. of suroEapN. (S.) One should not say ↓ A^aboTayota for A^aboTaA^ota. (S.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- baTu'a *aA xuruwjFA: see buToA=na.

2 bT~A^bihi * [and bT~A^hu, inf. n. as below, It made him slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward;] it kept him, or held him, back; or put him back, or backward. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano baT~aA^a bihi Eamaluhu lamo yusoriEo bihi nasabuhu Him whom his evil deeds keep, or hold, back, or put back, or backward, his nobility of lineage will not profit, [or advance, or put forward,] in the life to come, or in the world to come. (TA.) bika ↓ maA A^aboTaA^a and maA baT~aA^a signify the same [What made thee, or hath made thee, slow? &c.]; (S, TA;) and so maA baT~aA^aka. (TA.) And you say, baT~aA^a Ealayohi biAlA^amori, inf. n. taboTiYo'N; and
bihi ↓ AbTA^; He delayed to him [the doing of] the thing, or affair. (K.)

4 A^aboTaAa see 1 and 2; each in two places. ― -b2- A^aboTaw^uwA Their beasts on which they rode were, or became, slow. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b3- maA A^aboTaA^ahu How slow, or tardy, &c., is [he, or] it! (S.)

6 tbATA^ * [accord. to general analogy, He feigned, or affected, to be slow, tardy, &c.: or] he was slow, or sluggish; or he made delay; in going, or pace: and he held back from work, or action. (KL.) You say of a man, tbATA^ fiY masiyrihi [He feigned, or affected, to be slow, &c., in his going, course, or pace]. (S.)
10 AstbTA^hu * (S, TA) He deemed him, or reckoned him, slow, tardy, &c. (KL.) You say, kataba A_ilaY~a yasotaboTiy^uniY [He wrote to me, deeming me, or reckoning me, slow, &c.]. (TA.)

buTo'N bT' inf. n. of 1. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- One says, in the dial. of Benoo-Yarbooa, (TA,) lamo A^afoEalohu buTo'FA yaAh`*aA, and ↓ buToA^aY, [I never did it, lit.] I did it not ever, O thou! i. e. Ald~ahora. (K, TA.)
buToA^aY * : see buTo'N.

buToA=na *aA xuruwjFA * , and baToA=na, (S, K,) but the latter is extr., (TA,) i. q. *aA xuruwjFA ↓ baTuw^a [Slow, or very slow, or how slow, is this in coming forth!]; (S, K;) the fet-hah in [the last syllable of] baTuw^a is transferred to the n of buToA=n, and the dammeh of the T [in the former] to the b [in the latter]; the meaning being one of wonder; i. e. maA A^aboTaA^ahu. (S, TA.) [bTA=n is an enunciative placed before its inchoative: and, being originally baTuw^a, it may be a simple enunciative, or an enunciative having an intensive signification; as that verb signifies simply “ it was slow, ” &c., and may be used as co-ordinate to ramuwa, meaning “ excellent is he in his shooting! ” &c., and qaDuwa “ excellent is he in his judging! ” &c.: or it may be equivalent to maA A^aboTaA^a, as it is said to be in the S. See also saroEaAna.]

baTiYo'N bTY' bTy' bTy^
Slow, tardy, dilatory, late, or backward; applied to a man, (S, Msb, TA,) and to a horse or the like: (S, TA:) pl. baTaA='N. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also an imitative sequent to HaTiYo'N. (S in art. HTA^.)

A^aboTaA^u *
More, and most, slow, &c. (Meyd, &c.)

1 baTaHahu bTH bTHh bTHp , aor.
baTaHa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. baToHN, (Mgh, TA,) He spread it; spread it out, or forth; expanded it; extended it. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) or baTaHahu EalaY wajohihi, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He threw him down upon his face. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b3- See also 2.

2 bT~H Almasojida bTH Almsjd , (TA,) inf. n. taboTiyHN; (K;) and ↓ AbTHhu; (TA;) He strewed pebbles in the mosque, and made it plain, or level [in its ground, or floor]: (K, TA:) and baToHuhu, [inf. n. of ↓ baTaHahu,] occurring in a trad., also signifies the making it plain, or level. (TA.)
4 A^aboTaHa see 2.

5 tbT~H bTH tbTH : see 7. ― -b2- Also It (a torrent) flowed widely: (ISd, A:) or spread widely in the baToHaA='. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also, [and ↓ AnbTH,] It (a place &c.) spread; spread out, or forth; became expanded or extended. (TA.) -A2- And i. q. AinotaSaba [It became set up or upright, erected, &c.: thus the verb bears two contr. significations]. (TA.) -A3- Also He (a man) took the A^aboTaH as a place of abode. (A, TA.)

7 AnbTH A^nbTH AnbTH {nbTH
It (water) went to the right and left in a place. (AA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- He became thrown down upon his face: (S, A, K:) or he lay, or lay as though thrown down or extended, upon his face: (Mgh, Msb:) or he stretched himself; or lay, and stretched himself; upon his face, extended upon the ground; as also ↓ tbT~H. (TA.) ― -b4- It (a valley) became wide; (K, TA;) as also ↓ AstbH. (TA.)
10 A_isotaboTaHa see 7.
baTiHN bTH : see A^aboTaHu, in two places.

baToHapN bTH bTHh bTHp The stature of a man [app. in a lying posture]: as in the phrase huwa baToHapN rajulK [It is of the stature of a man]. (K.) ― -b2- bayonahumaA baToHapN baEiydapN Between them two is a far-extending distance or space or interval. (L.) ― -b3- See also A^aboTaHu.
baToHaA='u bTHA=' : see A^aboTaHu, in four places.

biTaAHN buT~aHN bTAH bTH [Many wide water-courses in which are fine, or minute, or broken, pebbles: the former word is pl. of A^aboTaHu or of baToHaA='u]: a phrase like A^aEowaAmN Euw~amN. (As, A 'Obeyd, S.)
baTiyHapN TyH bTyHh bTyHp : see A^aboTaHu.
baATiHN bATH applied to a man, i. q. ↓ munobaTiHN [part. n. of 7, q. v.]. (Ham p. 244.)

A^aboTaHu * , originally an epithet [and therefore imperfectly decl.], (M, TA,) that is, an epithet converted into a subst., and not used as an epithet, (Ham p. 21,) A wide water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are fine, or minute, or broken, pebbles; (S, A, K, and Ham ubi suprà;) so called because the water goes in it to the right and left; [i. e. spreads widely; see 7;] (AA;) as also ↓ baToHaA='u, (S, A, K, Ham,) fem. of the former, and, like it, an epithet converted into a subst.; (Ham ubi suprà;) and ↓ baTiyHapN, (S, K,) and ↓ baTiHN: (K:) or a water-course, or channel of a torrent, in which are sand and pebbles; as also ↓ baToHaA='u: (Mgh:) or a wide place [app. in a water-course]; as also ↓ bTHp [app. baToHapN, which is explained by Freytag, but without his stating on what authority, as signifying a depressed place through which water flows, abounding with pebbles; as is also biToHapN; and in like manner Golius explains the former, but mentions the latter as a pl. of bTyHp]: (Msb:) or, accord. to AHn, the bottom of a water-course, or channel of a torrent, producing no plants or herbage: (TA:) or ↓ baToHaA='u signifies soft earth of a valley, such as has been drawn along by the torrents: (ISd, TA:) or the soft pebbles in the bottom of the water-course, or channel of a torrent, of a valley; as also A^aboTaHu: (IAth, TA:) or the soft earth, such as has been drawn along by the torrents, in the bottom of a taloEap [meaning a water-course &c.] and of a valley; and the A^aboTaH and ↓ baToHaA=' of a valley are its earth and soft pebbles: (En-Nadr, TA:) and accord. to AA, ↓ baTiHN signifies sand in a baToHaA=': (TA:) the pl. is A^abaATiHu and biTaAHN (S, A, K) and baTaAy^iHu; (K;) the first of these, and the second also, contr. to analogy, being pls. of AbTH; (S;) or both are pls. of bTHA=', contr. to analogy; (Ham p. 251;) or the first is pl. of AbTH, formed after the manner of the pl. of a subst. of this measure, though the sing. is originally an epithet; (M, TA;) and the second, as is asserted by more than one, is correctly pl. of bTHA=', as is also baToHaAwaAtN; (TA;) and the third is pl. of bTyHp. (M, TA.)
munobaTiHN mnbTH [part. n. of 7, q. v.: often applied to anything Spread out, expanded, or flat]: see baATiHN.

4 A^aboTaxuwA *
They had abundance of biT~iyx [or melons, or water-melons]. (S, A, L, K.)

5 tbT~x tbTx
He ate biT~iyx. (A, TA.)

A_ibilN baTixapN Abl bTxh Abl bTxp , and rijaAlN baTixapN, (tropical:) Large, big, bulky, or corpulent, camels, and men: and rajulN ↓ buTaAxiY~N (tropical:) a large, big, bulky, or corpulent, man. (K, TA.)
buTaAxiY~N bTAxY bTAxy : see what immediately precedes.

baT~iyxN bTyx , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) vulgarly and incorrectly pronounced baT~iyxN, (ISk, Msb,) and in the dial. of El-Hijáz called Tib~iyxN, (Msb,) A certain well-known fruit; (Msb;) [the melon, absolutely, as is shown by many passages in the lexicons, and expressly stated in law-books: and, particularly, the water-melon; cucurbita citrullus: or a plant] of the kind called yaqoTiyn, that does not grow tall, but extends itself upon the surface of the ground: (K, TA:) and also the xirobiz [or xarobuz, a Persian word, and applied to the water-melon, by the Turks termed by this name, and in their own language qaAroPuwzo]: (CK: [but not found by me in my MS. copy of the K, nor in the L, nor in the TA:]) or AlbiT~iyxu AlhinodiY~u [the Indian bT~yx] is what is called in Persian the xarobuz: (Mgh:) [the term bT~yx is applied to many varieties of the water-melon, distinguished by different epithets; as AlA^aHomaru the red, AlA^aSofaru the yellow, AlA^aboyaDu the white, AlA^ajorabu the mangy, Aln~amo$u the speckled, Alburul~uY~u that of El-Burullus, &c.: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (S, K.)
maboTaxapN mbTxh mbTxp (S, A, Mgh, &c.) and maboTuxapN (S, L, K) A place where biT~iyx grow: (S, A, Mgh, &c.:) pl. mabaATixu. (A, TA.)

1 baTira Tr bTr , aor.
baTara , inf. n. baTarN, He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or he exulted by reason of wealth, and behaved with pride and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or he behaved with the utmost exultation, &c.: or he rejoiced, and rested his mind upon things agreeable with natural desire: syn. of the inf. n. A^a$arN, (S, A, L, Msb, TA,) and maraHN; (L, TA;) the former of which signifies $id~apN AlmaraHi, (S, A,) and mujaAwazapu AlHad~i fiY maraHK: (A:) he was, or became, stupified, deprived of his reason, confounded, or amazed, (S, K, Er-Rághib,) bearing wealth ill, or in an evil manner, performing little of the duty imposed on him by it, and turning it to a wrong purpose: (Er-Rághib, TA, * TK:) this is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he was, or became, stupified, or confounded, and knew not what to prefer nor what to postpone: (TA:) he was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, by reason of fright: (As, S voce baHira:) he behaved exorbitantly, or insolently, with wealth, (K, TA,) or on the occasion of having wealth: and this, also, is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he had, or exercised, little of the quality of bearing wealth [in a becoming, or proper, manner]: (K:) he behaved proudly: (TA:) he regarded a thing with hatred, or dislike, without its deserving to be so regarded: he was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (K:) accord. to some, he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yanoZuru A@ll~`hu yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mano jar~a A_izaArahu baTarFA [God will not look, on the day of resurrection, upon him who drags along his wrapper of the lower part of the body in exultation and insolence, or pride: meaning one who wears too long a wrapper of the lower part of the body]. (TA.) ― -b2- baTirota Eayo$aka (tropical:) [Thou exultedst, or exultedst greatly, or excessively, and behavedst insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully, &c., in thy manner of life,] is a phrase similar to ra$idota A^amoraka; (S, TA;) and in like manner baTirato maEiy$atahaA, in the Kur [xxviii. 58]; in which the verb is not trans., but the subst. is put in the accus. case because of fiY understood before it. (Aboo-Is-hák.) ― -b3- laA A^aboTaru AlginaY (assumed tropical:) I do not, or will not, domineer, or assume superiority, over others when I am rich. (Ham p. 517.) ― -b4- baTira Aln~iEomapa (tropical:) He held wealth, or the favour, or benefit, in light estimation, and was unthankful, or ungrateful, for it. (A.) ― -b5- baTira hidaAyapa A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) He refused the right direction as to the management of his affair, and was ignorant of it. (TA.) ― -b6- It is said in a trad., that pride is baTaru AlHaq~i, which means (tropical:) The considering as false, or vain, what God has pronounced to be the truth, or our duty; namely, the confession of his unity, and the obligation of rendering Him religious service: or the being confounded at considering truth, or duty, and not seeing it to be true, or incumbent: (TA:) or the disdaining the truth, or right, and not accepting it or not admitting it. (K.) -A2- baTarahu, aor.
baTura (S, K) and
baTira , (K,) inf. n. baTorN, (S, Msb,) He cut it, or divided it, lengthwise; slit it; split it. (S, Msb, K.) Hence the appellation bayoTaArN. (S, Msb.)

4 AbTrhu A^bTr A^bTrh AbTrh AbTrp bTr
It rendered him such as is termed baTir; it (wealth) caused him to exult, or to exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: &c.: [see baTira:] (S, A:) it stupified him, deprived him of his reason, confounded him, or amazed him. (S, K.) You say, maA A^amoTarato Hat~aY A^aboTarato It (the sky) rained not until it caused [men] to exult, or to exult greatly, &c. (A.) ― -b2- AbTr Hilomahu (tropical:) It (the ignorance of a person) caused his (another's) clemency, moderation, or gravity, to become converted into inordinate exultation, and insolence, or the like, and levity. (A.) ― -b3- AbTrhu Hilomahu (tropical:) It stupified, confounded, or amazed, him, so as to turn him from his clemency, moderation, or gravity. (TA.) ― -b4- AbTrhu *aroEahu (tropical:) He imposed upon him more than he was able to do; (S;) what was above his power: (K:) *rEh is here a substitute for its antecedent to indicate an implication therein: (A:) you say this when a slow-paced camel has endeavoured in vain to keep pace with another camel; and when any man has imposed upon another a difficulty beyond his power: (TA:) or the meaning is, he cut off his means of subsistence, and wasted his body: (IAar, K:) *rE signifying the “ body. ” (IAar.)

Q. Q. 1 bayoTara byTr , inf. n. bayoTarapN, He practised [farriery, the veterinary art, or] the art of the bayoTaAr. (Msb.) ― -b2- huwa yubayoTiru Ald~awaAb~a He treats beasts, or horses and the like, medically, or curatively. (TA.)
*ahaba damuhu biTorFA * (tropical:) His blood went unrevenged, (Ks, S, A, K,) being held in light estimation. (A.)

baTirN Tr bTr part. n. of baTira, (Msb, TA,) Exulting, or exulting greatly, or excessively, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or exulting by reason of wealth, and behaving with pride and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or behaving with the utmost exultation, &c.: see its verb. (A, Msb, TA.)

baTiyrN Tyr bTyr
Cut, or divided, lengthwise; slit; split; (K;) as also ↓ maboTuwrN. (TA.) -A2- See also bayoTaArN.

AimoraA^apN baTiyrapN *
A woman who behaves with much baTar, i. e. exultation, and insolence and unthankfulness, or ingratitude, &c.: [see baTira.] (A.) [See also what next follows.]

biToriyrN bTryr
Clamorous; long-tongued: and one who perseveres in error: fem. with p: (K:) but it [the former] is mostly used in relation to women, (TA,) and as signifying a woman who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully, (taboTaru,) and perseveres in error: (ADk:) [it is said in the TA that some say biZoriyrN, and that this is the more approved; but Az says,] Lth cites, from ADk, the phrase AimoraA^apN biToriyrN as meaning a clamorous, long-tongued woman; liA^an~ahaA qado baTirato wA^a$iratN [because of her insolent behaviour]: and says that, accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, it is AmrAp biZoriyrN; her tongue being likened to the baZor: but Lth adds, the saying of ADk is preferable in my opinion, and more correct. (T in art. bZr.)
bayoTarN byTr : see bayoTaArN.

biyaTorN byTr : see bayoTaArN. ― -b2- [Hence,] A tailor. (Sh, S, * K.) A poet says, (calling a tailor a byTr, like as one calls a skilful man an A_isokaAf, Sh, TA,)
$aq~a AlbiyaTori midoraEa AlhumaAmi
[Like as the tailor cuts lengthwise, or slits, the woollen tunic of the valiant chief]. (Sh, S.)
bayoTarapN byTr byTrh byTrp [Farriery; the veterinary art;] the art of the bayoTaAr. (S, K.) [See Q. Q. 1.]

bayoTaArN byTAr (S, Msb, K) and ↓ biyaTorN (S, K) and ↓ bayoTarN and ↓ baTiyrN (K) and ↓ mubayoTirN (S, K) [A farrier; one who practises the veterinary art;] one who treats beasts, or horses and the like, medically, or curatively: (K:) from baTarahu, explained above. (S, Msb. *) A^a$oharu mino raAyapi AlbayoTaAri [More commonly known than the sign of the farrier, app. meaning a sign which, I suppose, the itinerant farrier carried about with him,] (A, TA) is one of the proverbs of the Arabs. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, also, huwa bih`*aA EaAlimN bayoTaArN (tropical:) [He is knowing and skilful in this: see also biyaTorN]. (A.)
maboTuwrN mbTwr : see baTiyrN.
mubayoTirN mbyTr : see bayoTaArN.

biToriyqN Tryq bTryq
A qaAy^id [or leader of an army], in the language of the ruwm [or Greeks of the Lower Empire]; (JK;) one who is to the rwm like the qAy^d to the Arabs; (Mgh, Msb;) [i. e.] a leader of an army (qAy^d) of the rwm; (S, K;) accord. to Kudámeh, (Mgh,) one who is over ten thousand men: (Mgh, K:) next to him is the TaroxaAn [in the CK taroxAn], over five thousand: then, the qawomas, over two hundred: (K:) but in art.

Trx Trx in the K, it is said that TrxAn signifies “ a headman, or chief, of high, or noble, rank, ” in the language of Khurásán; and in art. qms, that qwms signifies “ a commander, ” or the like, syn. A^amiyrN; and. qamaAmisapN, i. q. baTaAriqapN, (TA,) which is pl. of bTryq, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) as also baTaAriyqu, for which baTaAriqu is used in a verse of Aboo-Dhueyb: (TA:) it is an arabicized word; (S, TA;) [app. from the Latin “ patricius; ”] or, as some say, of the language of the rwm and of Syria: or Arabic, agreeing with the foreign word, and of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz: accord. to El-Jawáleekee and others, in the language of the rwm it is btrk: some say that it signifies skilled in war and its affairs, in the language of the rwm; and he who is so has rank, or office, and is sometimes made foremost, among them: (TA:) and (some say, TA) a proud and self-conceited
man; (JK, K;) so says Ibn-'Abbád: (TA:) and fat; applied to a bird (JK, K) &c.: (JK:) pl. baTaAriqapN. (K.) ― -b2- [See also baTorakN, and jaAvaliyqN.]

baTorakN Tr bTr bTrk and biTarokN i. q. biToriyqN, (As, K,) i. e. A leader of the Christians: (TA:) or the chief of the Magians: (K:) [in the present day, the former is applied to a Patriarch of a Christian church; as also ↓ biToriykN: (see jaAvaliyqN:) pl. baTaArikapN and baTaAriyku]: adventitious; not Arabic. (Az, TA.)

[
baTorakiY~N bTrk bTrkY bTrky bTrkyy
Patriarchal; i. e. of, or belonging to, or relating to, a Patriarch of a Christian church; as also ↓ biToriykiY~N: both modern terms.]

[
baTorakiy~apN bTrk bTrkyh bTrkyp
A patriarchate; i. e. the office, or jurisdiction, of a Patriarch of a Christian church; as also ↓ biToriykiy~apN: both modern terms.]
biToriykN Try bTr bTrk bTryk : see baTorakN.
biToriyikY~N bTrk bTrykY bTryky bTrykyy : see baTorakiY~N.
biToriyiky~ahu bTrk bTrykyh bTrykyp : see baTorakiy~apN.

1 baTa$a bihi * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
baTi$a and
baTu$a , (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is that adopted by the seven readers (Msb, TA) in chap. xliv. verse 15 of the Kur, (TA,) inf. n. baTo$N, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He seized him violently; laid violent hands upon him: (S, Msb:) assaulted him: (S:) or he seized him with violence and assault: (A, K:) or he seized him vehemently, in anger: (Mgh:) and he laid hold upon him (Mgh, TA) vehemently, (TA,) in making an assault: (Mgh, TA:) and ↓ A^aboTa$ahu signifies the same as baTa$a bihi, (K,) but is rare, occurring in the words [of the Kur xliv. 15], yawoma nuboTi$u AlbaTo$apa AlkuboraY, accord. to the reading of El-Hasan and Ibn-Rejà, [meaning On the day when we make the greatest assault:] or, accord. to AHát, [and Bd says the like,] the meaning is, [on the day when] we give power over them to such as shall assault them [with the great assault; or make to assault with the great assault]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He took it, namely, anything, or took hold of it, (Lth, K, * TA,) or clung to it, (TA,) strongly. (Lth, K, TA.) In the saying of El- Hulwánee, wa maA laA yaqaEu Ealayohi AlEayonu wa laA yaboTi$uhu Alkaf~u, [meaning And that upon which the eye falls not, and of which the hand does not take hold,] the prep. [bi] is understood; or the verb is thus used as implying the meaning of AlA^axo*u and Alt~anaAwulu. (Mgh.) ― -b3- baTa$ato bihimo A^ahowaAlu Ald~unoyaA (tropical:) [The terrors of the world assaulted them]. (A.) ― -b4- baTa$ati Alyadu The hand worked, wrought, or laboured. (Msb.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yaboTi$u fiY AlEilomi bibaAEK basiyTK (tropical:) [Such a one labours in science with extensive ability]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- baTa$a mina AlHum~aY (tropical:) He recovered from the fever, being still weak. (Aboo-Málik, A, * K.)

3 bAT$hu * , (S, TA,) inf. n. mubaATa$apN (S, K) and biTaA$N, (TA,) He laboured, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, to prevail, or overcome; syn. of the inf. n. muEaAlajapN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- baATa$aA, (TK,) inf. n. mubaATa$apN, (K,) Each of them two stretched forth his hand towards the other to seize him violently (K, TA) and to assault him quickly. (TA.)
4 A^aboTa$a see 1, where two meanings are assigned to it.

5 Alr~ikaAbu tabaT~a$u biA^aHomaAlihaA * , [for tabaT~a$u,] (tropical:) The travelling-camels walk with slow steps (tazaH~afu [for tatazaH~afu]) with their burdens, hardly moving. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Z, Sgh, K.)

baTo$N * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also Might, or strength, in war or fight: or courage; valour, or valiantness; prowess: syn. baA^osN. (K.) You say, rajulN $adiydu AlbaTo$i [A man of great might, &c.]. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And Anger. (Har p. 258.)

baTo$apN *
An assault; a violent seizure. (S.) AlbaTo$apu AlkuboraY [The greatest assault], in the Kur xliv. 15, is applied to the day of resurrection, or to the battle of Bedr. (Bd.)

baTiy$N *
i. q. $adiydu AlbaTo$i; (K;) [see baTo$N;] applied to a man; as also ↓ baT~aA$N. (TA.)
baT~aA$N * : see baTiy$N.

[
maboTi$N * , or maboTa$N, A place of assault, or the like; sing. of mabaATi$u, of which the following is an ex.] salakuwA A^aroDFA baEiydapa AlmasaAliki qariybapa AlmahaAliki wawuqi*uwA bimabaATi$ihaA wamaA A^unoqi*uwA mino maEaATi$ihaA (tropical:) [They traversed a land whereof the roads were farextending, whereof the places of destruction were near, and they were prostrated, or left sick, in its places of assault, and were not saved from its places of thirst]. (A, TA.)

biTaAqapN TAq TAqp bTAqh bTAqp
A piece of paper: (IAar, M, Sgh, TA:) in the K, AlHadaqapu is erroneously put for Alwaraqapu: (TA:) a ticket that is attached to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, S, M, L, K,) bearing the mark, or inscription, of its price; (T, S, L, K;) or a ticket marked, or inscribed, with the weight, and the number, of a thing: (TA:) of the dial. of Egypt (T, S, L) and the neighbouring parts: (T, L:) so called, (K,) or said (by Sh, TA) to be so called, (S,) because it is tied by a twist, or thread, (biTaAqapF,) of the unwoven end of the cloth: (S, K:) but this is a mistake: (ISd, TA:) [in Greek, πιττάκιον, as observed by Freytag; and hence probably derived:] accord. to some, it is [niTaAqapF,] with n, because it tells (tanoTiqu) what is marked, or inscribed, thereon; but this is strange. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that a man will be brought on the day of resurrection, and ninety-nine scrolls, or records, inscribed with his sins will be produced; and there will be produced for him a bTAqp bearing the testimony that there is no deity but God, and it will outweigh the others. (TA.)

1 baTala Tl bTl , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baTula , (S, Msb,) inf. n. buTolN and buTuwlN and buTolaAnN, [of which the last seems to be the most common,] (S, Msb, K, KL, &c.,) It (a thing) was, or became, baATil, as meaning contr. of Haq~; (S;) [i. e.,] it was, or became, false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PS,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Msb;) it went for nothing, as a thing of no account, (S, Msb, K,) or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K.) [It is said of an assertion or allegation and the like, and of a deed, &c.] Hence the saying in the Kur [vii. 115], wa baTala maA kaAnuwA yaEomaluwna [And what they were doing became vain, or null; or went for nothing, as a thing of no account]. (TA.) And *ahaba damuhu buTolFA His blood went for nothing, [unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulet,] as a thing of no account. (S, Msb.) And baTala damuhu [signifies the same; or] He was slain without there being obtained for him either blood-revenge or blood-wit. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- See also the inf. n. buTuwlN below, voce baT~aAlN. ― -b3- labaTula Alqawolu [How false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, &c., is the saying!] is said in wonder at that which is baATil. (TA.) ― -b4- baTala, (S, K,) or baTala mina AlEamali, (Msb,) aor.
baTula , (TA,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (S, Msb, K, KL) and biTaAlapN, which is mentioned by one of the expositors of the Mo'allakát, and said to be the more chaste, and sometimes one says buTaAlapN, to make it accord with its contr. EumaAlapN, (Msb,) He (a hired man, or hireling,) was, or became, idle, unoccupied, or without work. (S, Msb, * K, KL. [See also 5.]) [Hence, yawomu baTaAlapK A day of idleness; a holiday.] ― -b5- biTaAlapN, with kesr, also signifies The being diverted from that which would bring profit in the present life or in the life to come. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 2. ― -b7- baTala fiY Hadiyvihi, (K,) aor.
baTula ; so it seems to be from the context in the K, but correctly baTila, aor.
baTala , as in the Jm; (TA;) inf. n. baTaAlapN (K) [and app. buTuwlN also; see baT~aAlN]; He jested, or joked, or was not serious or in earnest, in his discourse; as also ↓ AbTl. (K.) -A2- baTula, aor.
baTula , (Msb,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (S, Msb, K, KL) and biTaAlapN (Lth, Msb, TA) and buTaAlapN (TA) and buTuwlapN, (S, K, KL,) He (a man) was, or became, courageous, brave, or stronghearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; such as is termed baTalN, q. v.; (S, Msb, K, KL;) as also ↓ tbT~l: (K:) or this last signifies he affected courage, &c.; he made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous, &c.; syn. ta$aj~aEa. (TA.) ― -b2- labaTula Alr~ajulu [How courageous, &c., is the man!] is said in wonder at Alt~abaT~ul [i. e. courage, &c., or the affecting of courage, &c.]. (TA.)

2 Alt~aboTiylu AltbTyl [inf. n. of bT~l] signifies ↓ fiEolu AlbTAlhi, [in which the latter word is written in the TA without any indication of the vowel of the b,] i. e. The pursuit of vain, or frivolous, diversion or sport, and foolish, or ignorant, conduct. (TA.) [See biTaAlapN, above, and the phrase next following it.] -A2- See also 4.

4 AbTl A^bTl AbTl bTl
He said, or spoke, what was false,
or untrue; (Mgh, Msb, K;) [contr. of A^aHaq~a;] he lied: (Mgh:) he made a false, or vain, claim or demand; he claimed, or demanded, for himself that which was not right, or just. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. -A2- AbTlhu [and vulgarly ↓ bT~lhu] He made it, or rendered it, [and he proved it to be,] baATil, i. e. false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (S, * L, K, TA,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Msb, TA;) he nullified it, annulled it, abolished it, cancelled it; whether it was true or false, right or wrong, authentic or spurious, valid or null; (TA;) he made it to go for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K.) Hence, AbTl $ahaAdatahu He annulled his testimony. (TA in art. zwr.) And liyuHiq~a AlHaq~a wa yuyoTila AlbaATila, in the Kur [viii. 8, meaning That He might establish that which is true, and annul that which is false]. (TA.)

5 tbT~lwA bayonahumo tbTlwA bynhm
They took it by turns to say, or to do, that which was false, wrong, vain, futile, or the like; syn. tadaAluwA AlbaATila. (Az, K.) ― -b2- [tbT~l, said in the Mgh to be from AlbaTaAlapu, (see baTala, or baTala mina AlEamali,) app. signifies, as its part. n. (q. v. voce baT~aAlN) indicates, He became unoccupied and lazy.] -A2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.
buTolN Tl bTl [originally an inf. n. of 1, and mentioned therewith, first sentence:] i. q. baATilN, q. v. (Ham p. 114.)

baTalN Tl bTl , said to be the only epithet of its measure except HasanN; (TA in art. Hsn;) applied to a man, Courageous, brave, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; [commonly used as a subst., meaning a man of courage or valour, a brave man, a hero;] (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ baT~aAlN; (K;) one whose wound goes for nothing, so that he does not care for it, (Lth, K,) and it does not withhold him from the exercise of his courage; (Lth, TA;) or the blood of whose adversaries goes for nothing with him, (K,) unrevenged: (TA:) or for this reason he is thus called; (TA;) or because life is annulled, or made to go for nothing, on the occasion of encountering him, and severe misfortunes are annulled by him, (Msb,) or by his sword, and made to be of no account: (TA:) and so ↓ baTalapN applied to a woman; (S, Msb, K;) accord. to one of the expositors of the Hamáseh; (Msb;) but AZ says that this is not allowable: (IDrd, TA:) the pl. of baTalN is A^aboTaAlN. (Msb, K.)
baTalapN Tl bTl bTlh bTlp : see baATilN: -A2- and see also baTalN.
baTolaAnu bTl bTlAn One whose powers have become weak: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)
buT~alaAtN bTl bTlAt (pl. of buT~alN, TA) False, or vain, things; or unprofitable sayings. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, jaA='a biAlbuT~alaAti He uttered false, or vain, things; &c. (El-Moheet, TA.)

baT~aAlN bTAl , applied to a man, signifies bay~inN ↓ *uw baATilK ↓ AlbuTuwli [app. meaning Having a vain, or false, object or pursuit; manifesting the having such an object or pursuit: or, accord. to an explanation of *w bATl by Bd in xxxviii. 26, i. q. muboTilN and EaAbivN, i. e. jesting, or joking; (see baTala fiY Hadiyvihi, or baTila;) or saying what is untrue: and playing, or sporting, and doing that in which is no profit; as also ↓ baATilN, q. v.]: (K:) one who jests, or jokes, in his discourse: one who is diverted from that which would bring profit in the present life or in that which is to come: (TA:) idle; unoccupied: (S, Msb:) or exceedingly, or extremely, idle: (KL:) or unoccupied and lazy; as also ↓ mutabaT~ilN. (Mgh.) [In the present day it is commonly used as signifying Bad, worthless, and useless; applied to a man and to anything.] -A2- See also baTalN.

baATilN bATl
contr. of Haq~N; (S, K;) i. e. False, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PS,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no effect; (Msb;) that proves, when inquired into, or investigated, to be false, wrong, unfounded, unsound, or not established; applying to a saying, and [sometimes] to a deed: (TA:) [going for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that has perished or become lost: (see the verb, 1, first sentence:) often used as a subst., meaning a false, or vain, saying, or assertion, or allegation; a lie; a falsehood: and a false, or vain, deed, or action, or affair, or thing; &c.:] and ↓ buTolN is syn. therewith, (Ham p. 114,) and so are ↓ A^uboTuwlapN and ↓ A_iboTaAlapN: (K:) the pl. of baATilN is bawaATilu; (Msb;) and buTulN occurs as a pl. of the same; (Ham p. 360;) or its pl. is A^abaATiylu, contr. to analogy, (S, Msb,) as though the sing. were A_iboTiylN; (S;) or, accord. to AHát, this is pl. of ↓ A^uboTuwlapN, or, as some say, of ↓ A_iboTaAlapN, (Msb,) or, accord. to As and AHát and IDrd, of both these; (TA;) and signifies false, or vain, sayings and actions or deeds. (K in art. htr, &c.) You say, qado qulota baATilFA [Thou hast said a false, or vain, saying; a lie; a falsehood]; like as you say, qado qulota Haq~FA. (Ham p. 360.) And yaA^okuluwna A^amowaAla Aln~aAsi biAlbaATili [They devour the possessions of men by false pretence]. (Kur ix. 34.) And ↓ bayonahumo A^uboTuwlapN and ↓ A_iboTaAlapN [Between them is false, or vain, speech, or discourse, &c.]; syn. baATilN. (K.) ― -b2- The belief in a plurality of Gods: so explained as occurring in the Kur xlii. 23. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baT~aAlN, in two places. [Hence,] baATilFA In play, or sport; acting unprofitably; or aiming at no profit. (Jel in iii. 188 and xxxviii. 26.) ― -b4- AlbaATilu Iblees: so in the Kur [xxxiv. 48], where it is said, maA yubodiy^u A@lobaATilu wa maA yuEiydu [explained in art. bdA^]: (Katádeh, K:) and again [xli. 42], where it is said, laA yaA^otiyhi A@lobaATilu mino bayona yadayohi wa laA mino xalofihi, [accord. to some,] meaning that Iblees shall not add to the Kur-án nor diminish therefrom: (TA:) ↓ baTalapN [is its pl., and] signifies devils: (A, TA:) or enchanters. (O, K.)
A_iboTaAlapN A^bTAlh A_bTAl A_bTAlh AbTAlh AbTAlp bTl : see baATilN; for each in three places.
A^uboTuwlapN * : see baATilN; for each in three places.

muboTilN mbTl One who says a thing in which is no truth, or reality: (Er-Rághib, TA:) one who embellishes speech with lies: (Bd in xxx. 58:) one who says, or does, false, or vain, things. (Jel ibid.] [See also its verb, 4.]
mutabaT~ilN mtbTl : see baT~aAlN.

buTomN Tm bTm (S, K) and buTumN, (K,) the latter allowable accord. to IAar, (TA,) The Hab~ap xaDoraA=' [or fruit of the terebinth-tree, to which this latter appellation is given in the present day, i. e., of the pistacia terebinthus of the botanists]; (S, K;) so accord. to the people of El-'Áliyeh; and the like is said on the authority of As: (TA:) or the tree thereof; (K;) [which is called buTom in the present day;] so accord. to AHn; and he says, but no one has told me that it grows in the land of the Arabs; but they assert that the Dirow [meaning the cancamum-tree, also called kamokaAm, but said by IAar to be the Hb~p xDrA',] is nearly like it: (TA:) its fruit is heating, diuretic, strengthening to the venereal faculty, good for the cough, and for the [disease of the face called] laqowap, and for the kidney; and the overspreading of the hair with its dry and sifted leaves causes it to grow, and beautifies it. (K.)

1 baTuna Tn bTn bTnn , aor.
baTuna , (K,) inf. n. baTaAnapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, (K, TA,) in consequence of much eating. (TA.) ― -b2- And baTina, aor.
baTana , inf. n. baTanN, He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, in consequence of satiety, (S, TA,) and disordered therein: (TA:) he was, or became, in a state of repletion, or much filled with food. (TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- And [hence,] baTina signifies also (tropical:) i. q. A^a$ira and baTira [He exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: &c.]. (TA.) ― -b5- buTina He (a man, S, TA) had a complaint of, or a disease in, or a pain in, his belly. (S, Msb, TA.) -A2- baTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
baTuna , (S, TA,) inf. n. baTonN, (TA,) He struck, or beat, his belly; as also baTana lahu, (S, K,) accord. to some, or the l is added [only] in verse; (S;) and ↓ bT~nhu, (K,) inf. n. taboTiynN. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a disease) entered into him: [as though it penetrated into his belly: see 10:] in this sense it has for its inf. n. buTuwnN. (TA.) And baTanato bihi AlHum~aY The fever produced an effect within him. (TA.) ― -b3- He entered into it; namely, a valley; (S, TA;) in which sense it has for its inf. n. baTonN; and ↓ tbT~nhu signifies the same: or the latter, he went about in it; namely, the valley; as also ↓ AstbTnhu. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) [He penetrated into it mentally;] he knew it; (Msb, K, TA;) namely, the news or story, or the state or case, of another: (K, TA:) (tropical:) he knew the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances thereof; (S, Msb, TA;) i. e., of a case, or an affair; (S,
TA;) as also ↓ AstbTnhu: (K, A, TA:) and ↓ tbT~nhu (assumed tropical:) he entered into it so that he knew its inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances. (Ham p. 688.) ― -b5- baTana bifulaAnK, accord. to the S and M, but in the K mino fulaAnK, (TA,) (tropical:) He became one of his particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates, (S, K, TA,) entering into his affair [or affairs]: (TA:) or baTana bihi, aor.
baTuna , inf. n. buTuwnN and baTaAnapN, means (assumed tropical:) he entered into his affair [or affairs]. (TA.) ― -b6- And baTana, (Msb, K,) aor.
baTuna , said of a thing, (Msb,) It was, or became, unapparent, hidden, concealed, or covert; (K, TA;) contr. of Zahara. (Msb.) ― -b7- See also 4.

2 bT~nhu Tn bTn bTnh bTnnh bTnp , inf. n. taboTiynN: see 1. ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- He put a biTaAnap, i. e. a lining, to it; namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, K;) as also ↓ AbTnhu. (K.) ― -b4- bT~n liHayatahu, inf. n. as above, He took, or cut off, from that part of his beard which was beneath the chin and lower jaw. (Sh, Nh, TA.) Accord. to the copies of the K, taboTiynu All~iHoyapi signifies the not doing so: but this is wrong. (TA.)

3 baATanotu SaAHibiY bATnt SAHbY bATnt SAHby
i. q. $ddth [app. a mistranscription for $aAwarotuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) I consulted with my companion in order to know what was in his mind]. (TA.)

4 AbTn AlbaEiyra AbTn AlbEyr , (IAar, S, K,) inf. n. A_iboTaAnN, (S,) He bound, or made fast, the camel's biTaAn [or belly-girth]; (S, K;) as also ↓ bT~nhu, accord. to the copies of the K; but this is a mistake for ↓ baTanahu, aor.
baTuna , inf. n. baTonN; which last verb, however, though said by Az to be a dial. var., is disallowed by IAar and by AHeyth. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aboTanotu Als~iyofa ka$oHiY (S, TA) I put the sword beneath my waist. (TA.) And AbTn ka$oHahu sayofahu (assumed tropical:) He made his sword to be his ↓ biTaAnap [app. meaning his secret companion]. (TA.) [This seems to be from the phrase next following.] ― -b3- A^aboTanotu Alr~ajula (assumed tropical:) I made the man to be one of my particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates; (S, TA; *) took him as a biTaAnap. (TA.) One says also, fulaAnFA duwnaka ↓ AisotaboTanotu (Ham p. 688; [there rendered by xAmSth, app. a mistranscription for xaSaSotuhu; meaning (assumed tropical:) I took, or chose, such a one particularly, or specially, for my companion, in preference to thee: it is said in explanation of the phrase musotaboTinFA sayofiY, which seems to mean (assumed tropical:) taking my sword as my special companion, or putting it beneath my waist; so that sayofahu ↓ AstbTn is similar to one, or both, of two phrases mentioned above in this paragraph.]) ― -b4- See also 2.

5 tbT~n A^bTn bTn tbTn tbTnn
He filled the [meaning his] belly. (Har p. 176.) ― -b2- tbT~n jaAriyapF (Sh, S, TA) He made his baTon to be in contact with that of a girl, skin to skin: (Sh, TA:) or inivit puellam; i. e. A^awolaHa *akarahu fiyhaA. (TA.) ― -b3- tbT~n AlkalaA^a He was, or became, in the middle, or midst, of the herbage: (TA:) or he went round about in the herbage. (S.) See also 1, in two places.

6 tbATn tbATn
It (a place) was far-extending; one part thereof being remote from another. (TA.)

8 AibotaTanotu Aln~aAqapa Ea$arapa A^aboTunK *
I assisted the she-camel in bringing forth, or delivered her of her young, ten times. (S, TA. [Golius and Freytag render the verb by “ ventre enixa fuit: ” and the former renders the phrase above (incorrectly printed in his Lex.) by “ peperit camela decem vicibus. ”])

10 AstbTn Alfarasa AstbTn Alfrs
He sought to find what young was in the belly of the mare. (TA.) ― -b2- AstbTn AlfaHolu Al$~uw~ala The stallion covered the she-camels raising their tails, so that they conceived, or received his seed into their wombs; as though [meaning] he deposited his seed in their bellies. (TA.) ― -b3- AstbTnhu He, or it, entered [or penetrated] into his, or its, belly, or interior; [or was, or became, or lay, within it;] like as the vein enters [or penetrates] into [or lies within] (yasotaboTinu) the flesh. (A, TA.) You say, AisotaboTanotu Al$~aYo'a [I entered, or penetrated, into the thing, whether actually or mentally]. (S.) See 1, in two places. ― -b4- See also 4, in two places. ― -b5- AisotiboTaAnN also signifies The having, or holding, [a thing] concealed within. (PS.) [This explanation seems to be given to show that, in the opinion of the author of the PS, AisotaboTanotu Al$~aYo'a in the S means I had, or held, the thing concealed within.]

baTonN Tn bTn bTnn The belly, or abdomen; i. e. the part of the body which is separated from the jawof [i. e. chest, or thorax,] by the HijaAb [i. e. midriff, or diaphragm]; containing the liver and the spleen and the stomach and the lower intestines &c.; (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ” [in which it is erroneously said to comprise also the lungs;]) contr. of ZahorN; (S, Msb, K;) of a man and of any animal: (TA:) of the masc. gender, (S, K,) and, accord. to AO, fem. also: (AHát, S:) pl. A^aboTunN and buTuwnN (Az, Msb, K) and buTonaAnN; (K;) the first a pl. of pauc.; and the second [as also the third] a pl. of mult., applied to more than ten. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] *uw AlbaToni [What is in the belly: but generally meaning] excrement, ordure, or dung. (K, TA.) You say, A^aloqaY *aA baTonihi He (a man) ejected his excrement, or ordure. (TA.) And A^aloqato *aA baTonihaA She (a woman, TA) brought forth; (K;) as also waDaEato *aAta baTonihaA: (TA in art. *w:) and she (a hen) laid an egg. (K.) And navarato *aA baTonihaA, (T and Mgh in art. nvr,) and [elliptically] navarato baTonahaA, (T and A and Mgh in that art.,) She (a woman) brought forth many children. (T in that art.) And it is said in a prov., (TA,) Al*~iy^obu yugobaTu bi*iY baTonihi [The wolf is envied for what is in his belly]: for one never thinks him to be hungry, but only thinks him to be in a state of repletion, because of his hostility to men and cattle, (A'Obeyd, K,) though he is sometimes distressed by hunger. (A'Obeyd. [See various readings of this prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 500 and 501.]) maAtato fiY baTonK, a phrase occurring in a trad., means She (a woman) died in childbirth. (TA.) See also fulaAnN A@bonu baTonihi. baTanN. means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is solicitous for his belly. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnY.) [Many phrases in which the word baTon occurs will be found explained under other words of those phrases; as ZahorN, and A^axa*a, and EuSofuwrN, &c.] baTonu AlHuwti: see Alr~i$aA='u. ― -b2- Also The inside, or interior, of anything; syn. jawofN: and so ↓ baATinN; syn. daAxilN: (K:) pl. of the former as above. (TA.) Thus baTonu waAdK means The interior of a water-course or riverbed [or valley; i. e. its bottom, in which flows, occasionally or constantly, its torrent or river]. (MA.) And baTonu mak~apa means The interior of Mekkeh. (Bd in xlviii. 24.) [Hence,] it is said of the Kur-án, likul~i A=yapK minohaA ZahorN wa baTonN, meaning (assumed tropical:) To every verse thereof is an apparent sense and a sense requiring development. (TA.) [See ZahorN.] See also baATinN. [And its pl. buTonaAnN is also used as a sing., meaning The middle, or midst, of a thing: and the lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation. Thus,] buTonaAnu Aljan~api means The middle, or midst, of Paradise: (S, TA:) and buTonaAnu AlEaro$i, The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of the Er$ [vulgarly held to be the throne of God]. (TA.) You say also [baTonu Alkaf~i and] Alkaf~i ↓ baATinu (assumed tropical:) The palm of the hand [opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: and [baTonu Alqadami and] Alqadami ↓ baATinu (assumed tropical:) The sole of the foot [likewise opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: (Zj in his “ Khalk- el-Insán: ”) and baTonu AlHaAfiru (S in art. nsr) and AlHaAfiri ↓ baATinu (M and K in that art.) (assumed tropical:) [The sole of the solid hoof;] the part of the solid hoof in which is the nasor, q. v. (S and M and K in that art.) baTonu Alr~aAHapi is well known [as another name for baTonu Alkaf~i, explained above; for Alr~aAHap is often used as syn. with Alkaf~]: and Alxuf~i ↓ baATinu is [said to be] (assumed tropical:) The part of the foot of a camel or the like that is next the leg: and one says, ↓ baATinu AlA_iboTi, [meaning (assumed tropical:) The armpit, or hollow of the inner side of the shoulder-joint,] but not baTonu AlA_iboTi: (TA:) [and AlEunuqi ↓ baATinu the throat.] The baTon of a feather is (tropical:) The long, (S,) or longer, (K,) [or wider, i. e. inner,] lateral half: pl. buTonaAnN; (S, K, TA;) which is explained as signifying the parts beneath the shaft: opposed to ZuhoraAnN, pl. of ZahorN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A low, or depressed, tract, or portion, of land, or ground; (S, TA;) and so ↓ baATinN: (TA:) [or a bottom, or low land; or a low, soft flat; i. e.] soft, plain, fine, low land or ground; opposed to ZahorN [q. v.]: (TA in art. Zhr:) pl. of the former, (S,) or of the latter, (K,) buTonaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. of mult., (TA,) and A^aboTinapN, (K,) a pl. of pauc., and anomalous [as pl. of either]: (TA:) the former pl., in relation to land, is also used as a sing., like baTonN: (AHn, TA:) and accord. to ISh, buTonaAnu AlA^aroDi signifies the low, or depressed, tract, or tracts, of land, of the plain, or soft, parts thereof, and of the rugged, and of the meadows, where water rests and stagnates: and such tracts are also called bawaATinu and buTuwnN. (TA.) ― -b4- baTonu Als~amaA='i and Zahoru Als~amaA='i both signify (assumed tropical:) The apparent, visible, part of the sky. (Fr, T voce ZahorN [q. v.].) -A2- Also
(tropical:) A tribe below that which is termed qabiylap: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or next below the EimaArap: (S and TA voce $aEobN, &c.:) or below the faxi* and above the EmArp: (K: [but for this I have found no other authority:]) of the masc. gender: (TA:) or [properly] fem.: but if Hay~N [said by some to signify a tribe, absolutely,] be meant thereby, it is masc.: (Msb:) or fem. if used in the sense of qabiylap: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aboTunN and [of mult.] buTuwnN. (Msb, K.) [See $aEobN.]

baTanN Tn bTn bTnn
Disease of the belly, (K, TA,) being a state of enlargement thereof arising from satiety; and so ↓ baTonN; whence the phrase maAta biAlbaToni He died by the disease of the belly. (TA.)

baTanN Tn bTn bTnn One whose object of care, or anxiety, is his belly: (K:) or who has an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; (S;) whom nothing causes care, or anxiety, but his belly; (S, TA;) as also ↓ miboTaAnN: (TA:) or the former, (TA,) or ↓ the latter, (S,) ever large, or big, in the belly in consequence of much eating: (S, TA:) or ↓ both signify voracious; not ceasing from eating. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) One who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (TA:) or who does so, being abundant in wealth. (K, TA.)

biTonapN Tn bTn bTnh bTnnh bTnp
Repletion; the state of being much filled with food (S, K) and drink. (So in a copy of the S.) It is said in a prov., AlbiTonapu tu*ohibu AlfiTonapa [Repletion banishes intelligence]. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) Exultation, or great or excessive exultation, and insolent and unthankful, or ungrateful, behaviour. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] maAta fulaAnN bibiTonatihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one died with his wealth complete, not having expended, or dispensed, anything thereof: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, this prov. relates to religion, and means (assumed tropical:) he went forth from the present world in a state of integrity, without any infringement of his religion. (TA.) [See also tagaDogaDa, in two places.] [Hence also,] naz~ato bihi AlbaTinapu (assumed tropical:) Richness caused him to exult, or exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TA.)

AlbaTinapu AlbTnh AlbTnp bTnp
i. q. Ald~uburu [The back, hinder part, posteriors, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- baTinaAtu AlwaAdiY The roads, or beaten tracks, of the valley. (TA.)

biTaAnN bTAn [The belly-girth of a camel: or] the girth of the [kind of saddle called] qatab, (S, K,) which is put beneath the belly of the camel, and is like the taSodiyr to the raHol: (S:) or the girth of the [saddle called] raHol: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aboTinapN and [of mult.] buTonN. (K.) [Hence,] Ailotaqato HaloqataA AlbiTaAni [The two rings of the belly-girth met]: said of a case, or an affair, that has become severe, strait, or distressing. (S.) And rajulN EariyDu AlbiTaAni (tropical:) A man in ample and easy circumstances; or in an easy, or a pleasant, state or condition; or easy, or unstraitened, in mind. (K, TA. [See also art. ErD.]) And maAta fulaAnN wahuwa EariyDu AlbiTaAni, meaning, accord. to A'Obeyd, (assumed tropical:) Such a one died broad in the fleshy parts (AlmalaAHim); nothing of him having gone. (TA. [But this seems to be said of a man's dying in a state of opulence: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 601.])

baTiynN Tyn bTyn , applied to a man, (K,) Big, or large, in the belly; (S, K;) as also ↓ miboTaAnN: the former occurs, in a description of 'Alee, used as an epithet of praise: and signifies also big, or large, in the belly in consequence of much eating: and having the belly full; as also ↓ the latter: pl. of the former biTaAnN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) Full; applied to a purse [&c.]. (TA.) You say rajulN baTiynu Alkurozi (assumed tropical:) [lit. A man having the pair of provision-bags full]; meaning (assumed tropical:) a man who conceals his travel-ling-provision in a journey, and eats that of his companion. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Far; far-extending. (S, K, TA.) So in the phrase $aA^owN baTiynN (assumed tropical:) [A farextending heat, or single run to a goal or limit], (S, TA,) and $awoTN baTiynN [signifying the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Wide, and low, or depressed; applied to a tract of land or ground. (Ham p. 506.)

AlbuTayonu AlbTyn bTyn
One of the Mansions of the Moon; (S, K;) namely, the Second; (Kzw, &c.;) three small stars [e and p and n], (S, K,) disposed in the form of an equilateral triangle, (S,) as though they were three stones whereon a cooking-pot is placed, and forming the belly of the Ram; (S, K;) the appellation being made a diminutive because the Ram consists of many stars in the form of a ram; [so I here render Hamal though it properly signifies a lamb;] the $azaTaAni being its two horns; and the buTayon, its belly; [or, accord. to our configuration of Aries, the rump;] and the vuray~aA, its rump, or tail; (S;) three obscure stars, forming the points of a triangle, in the belly of the Ram, between the $araTaAni and the vuray~aA; (Kzw, Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c.;) the three stars of which two are on the tail and one on the thigh of the Ram, forming an equilateral triangle. (Kzw in his description of Aries.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The Arabs assert that it has no nawo' [here meaning effect upon the weather], except wind. (TA.)

biTaAnapN bTAn bTAnh bTAnp The lining, or inner covering, of a garment, or piece of cloth [&c.]; contr. of ZihaArapN; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ baATinapN: (JK in art. Zhr:) pl. of the former baTaAy^nu. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A secret (K, TA) that a man conceals. (TA.) One says, huwa *uw biTaAnapK bifulaAnK, i. e. (assumed tropical:) He is one who possesses knowledge of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of the case, or affair, of such a one. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A particular, or special, intimate, friend, or associate; (S, K, TA;) one who is particularly distinguished by entering into, and becoming acquainted with, the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of one's case or affair; (TA;) an intimate and familiar friend or associate; (Zj, TA;) a confidential friend, who is consulted respecting one's circumstances: (TA:) it is from the same word in the sense first explained above, relating to a garment, or piece of cloth: (Mgh, Er-Rághib:) and is used in a pl. sense, as meaning intimate and familiar friends or associates, to whom one is open, or unreserved, in conversation, and who know the inward state or circumstances [of one's case or affair]: (Zj, TA:) or one's family; and one's particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates. (Mgh.) You say, huwa biTaAnatiY (tropical:) [He is my particular, or special, intimate, &c.]: and humo biTaAnatiY and A^aholu biTaAnatiY (tropical:) [They are my particular, or special, intimates, &c.]. (A, TA.) See also 4. ― -b4- Coupled with EalaAwap, it signifies What is put beneath [the things that compose the main load of a camel], such as a water-skin and the like. (TA.) ― -b5- See also baATinapN.

baATinN bATn
Unapparent; hidden; concealed; covert: (K, TA:) [and inward; inner; interior; internal; intrinsic; esoteric: in all these senses] contr. of ZaAhirN.
