(Msb, TA.) ― -b2- baATinu A^amorK [The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, of a case or an affair]; (TA, &c.;) [and so A^amorK ↓ baTonu; whence the phrases,] A^afora$aniY Zahora A^amorihi wabaTonahu (assumed tropical:) [He displayed, or laid open, to me the outward state or circumstances of his case or affair, and the inward state or circumstances thereof]; and huwa mujar~ibN baTona AlA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) [He is one who possesses experience of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of affairs], as though he hit their bellies by his knowledge of their true, or real, states or circumstances. (TA.) ― -b3- AlbaATinu [The internal, inward, or intrinsic, state, condition, character, or circumstances, of a man: and the heart, meaning the secret thoughts; the recesses of the mind; the state of mind; the inward, or secret, disposition of the mind: opposed to AlZ~aAhiru. ― -b4- Also,] an epithet applied to God, meaning He who knows the inward, or intrinsic, states or circumstances of things: (S:) or He who knows the secret and hidden things: or He who is veiled from the eyes and imaginations of created beings. (TA.) ― -b5- [baATinFA Covertly; secretly.] ― -b6- See also baATinapN, in eight places. ― -b7- biTaAnapN also signifies A water-course, or place in which water flows, in rugged ground: pl. buTonaAnN (K) and buTonN. (TA.)

baATinapN bATn bATnh bATnp : see biTaAnapN. ― -b2- Also The middle, and the retired part, of a kuwrap [i. e. province, or district, or city]: in the copies of the K erroneously written ↓ biTaAnap, and explained as meaning the “ middle of a kwrp. ” (TA.)

AlA^aboTanu *
A certain vein in the interior of the arm of the horse; one of two veins which are called AlA^aboTanaAni: (S:) accord. to AO, these are two veins that penetrate into the interior of the arm until they become hidden among the sinews of the shank. (TA.)
mubaT~anN mbTn , applied to a man, Lank in the belly: (S, K, TA:) fem. with p. (S.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, White in the back and belly. (K.) ― -b3- Lined; having a biTaAnap put to it. (TA.)
miboTaAnN mbT mbTAn : see baTiynN, in two places: and see baTinN, in three places.

maboTuwnN mbTwn
Having a complaint of, or a disease in, or a pain in, his belly: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) one who dies of disease of his belly, as dropsy and the like: such is reckoned a martyr. (TA.)

div2.head: bTw or bTY
div2.entryFree: 1 baTaA bT bTA , aor. yaboTuw, is said by Z and Meyd to signify He, or it, was, or became, wide: and hence baATiyapN, meaning a naAjuwd. (TA.)
4 A^a1o2a3a see what next follows.

biToyapN Ty Typ bTyh bTyp , with kesr, is a word mentioned by Sb; (K;) but ISd says, “ I know not to what it is applied, unless ↓ A^aboTayotu be a dial. var. of A^aboTaA^otu, (K, TA,) like as AiHobanoTayotu is of AiHobanoTaA^otu; in which case it is thence derived as meaning The state [of being slow, &c.]; and is not to be regarded as formed by substitution [of Y for '], because that would be extr.: ” so in the M: (TA:) it is asserted, however, in the S and the Fs and the Jámi' el-Loghah of Kz and in other lexicons, that one should not say, AbTyt, with Y, but AbTA^t, with '. (MF, TA.)
baATK A^T bAT bA^T part. n. of baTaA, mentioned above, accord. to Z and Meyd. (TA.)

baATiyapN bATyh bATyp
A certain vessel; (S;) a naAjuwd [or vessel into which wine is put]; (AA, S, Mgh, K;) a large vessel of glass, which is filled with wine, or beverage, and placed amid the drinkers, who ladle out from it [into their cups], (Az, Mgh, TA,) and drink: (Az, TA:) [a wine-vase, of glass or of earthenware; an amphora; an earthen jar; now applied to a vessel of this kind into which wine and oil &c. are put:] said to be an arabicized word: (TA:) [J says,] “ I think it to be arabicized: ” (S:) but accord. to Z and Meyd, it is from 1, as mentioned above. (TA.)

1 baZirato bZrt , [aor.
baZara , inf. n. baZarN,] said of a woman, [She had a baZor (q. v.), or a long baZor; or] she was uncircumcised. (Msb.) [But see baZarN, below.] ― -b2- And baZir, inf. n. baZarN, He had what is termed a buZaArap [q. v.] in his upper lip. (S.)
2 baZ~arato bZrt , inf. n. taboZiyrN, She circumcised a female. (K.) ― -b2- huwa yumiS~uhu wayubaZ~iruhu (M, K) He says to him, AumoSuSo baZora fulaAnapa: (K:) a prov. of the Arabs. (TA.)

baZorN Zr bZr , (Lh, T, S, M, &c.,) also pronounced baDorN, (T,) and ↓ buZaArapN [which see below] (Lh, T, S, M, K) and ↓ baZaArapN (M, K) and ↓ bayoZarN (Lh, T, M, K) and ↓ bunoZurN, (K,) A certain thing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or piece of flesh, (A,) between the two sides of the vulva (AlA_isokataAni, S, M, K, or Al$~uforaAni, A, or $uforaA Alfaroji, Mgh) of a woman, (M, A, Mgh, K,) which is cut off in circumcision, (A,) not yet cut off; (S;) a piece of flesh between the two sides of the vulva (Al$~uforaAni) of a woman; i. e. the prepuce (quloqap) that is cut off in circumcision; (Msb;) also called kayonN and raforafN and nawofN (Lh, T) and qunobN [which last properly signifies the “ prepuce, ” or “ sheath, ” of a beast or horse or the like]; (A and K in art. qnb;) and likened to a cock's comb: (Msb in art. Erf:) [the last of these explanations plainly shows that what is meant thereby is the prepuce of the clitoris; which, it seems, in the Arabian and Egyptian races, and others throughout Eastern Africa, and still more so in the Hottentot race, grows to an extraordinary size; and this may be the reason why the bZr is described by some travellers as a caruncle for which we have no name: or it may, perhaps, be a distinct excrescence from the prepuce of the clitoris: it has been described to me as a caruncle a little in front of the meatus urinarius: many of the Egyptians assert that it is the clitoris itself that is amputated, (as Ludolph also does in his Comment. to his Ethiop. Hist. p. 273, finding fault with those who say otherwise;) and they affirm that this is done for the purpose of lessening the libidinous passion: such, indeed, appears to be the case in some instances, but not generally; and it may have led to a misapplication of the term bZr in post-classical times: an analogous practice, one still more barbarous, is said to have obtained among an African race hence called the Colobi: see barobaru: Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zahráwee speaks of the amputation of the redundance of the bZr when preternaturally large, and also of an excrescence in the vulva: the former he describes in such a manner as plainly shows that he means thereby the clitoris: the latter, in terms apparently indicating a preternatural elongation of the lower part of the prepuce of the clitoris; as “ an excrescence of flesh at, or in, the mouth of the vulva, such as fills it up, and sometimes protrudes externally, like a tail, wherefore the ancients term it the caudal disease AlmrD Al*nbY; and this, ” he says, “ should be amputated, like as the bZr is amputated ” when preternaturally large: (Albucasis de Chirurgia, pp. 314 and 316:) in some of our medical books, the term “ caudatio ” is defined as “ an elongation of the clitoris; ” inconsistently with the foregoing description of “ the caudal disease: ”] the pl. [of mult.] of baZorN is buZuwrN, (M, Msb, K,) and [pl. of pauc.] A^aboZurN. (Msb.) yaA A@bona muqaT~iEapi AlbuZuwri [O son of her who amputates bZwr !] is an expression of contumely employed by the Arabs whether the mother of the person addressed be really a circumciser of females or not. (TA.)

baZarN Zr bZr The having a baZor: (T, S:) or the having a long baZor: (K:) a subst., (K,) or an inf. n., (T,) having no verb, (T, M, *) because it denotes an inherent quality, not one that is accidental. (T.) [But see baZirato.]
buZorapN Zr bZr bZrh bZrp , or baZarapN: see buZaArapN.
baZaArapN bZArh bZArp : see baZorN.

buZaArapN bZArh bZArp The lower extremity, (M,) or a thing in the extremity, (S, K,) or a protuberant, or prominent, thing in the lower part, (Lh, T, M,) of the vulva (Lh, T, S, M) of a ewe or goat, (Lh, T, S, M, K,) or camel, (Lh, T,) and any animal. (M.) It is metaphorically used by Jereer in relation to a woman. (M.) See baZorN. ― -b2- Also, (Lh, S, T, M, &c.,) and ↓ buZorapN, (M, K,) or ↓ baZarapN, (IAar, T,) The thing (M, K) protuberant, (M,) or a protuberant thing, (S, A, Mgh,) in the upper lip, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) in the middle thereof, (M, A, Mgh, K,) when it is somewhat long, (S,) or somewhat large: (M:) or a pro- tuberance in the lip: (IAar, T:) when not long, it is called HivorimapN: (S:) it is not every one that has it: (Mgh:) dim. ↓ buZayorapN. (T.)
buZayorapN bZyrh bZyrp : see what next precedes.
biZoriyrN bZryr (assumed tropical:) A long-tongued, (M,) clamorous woman: (M, K: [in the CK, erroneously, with p:]) but some say biToriyrN [q. v.]. (M.) [See A^aboZaru.]
bunoZurN bnZr nZr : see baZorN.
bayoZarN byZr : see baZorN. ― -b2- yaA bayoZaru is an expression of contumely addressed to a female slave. (K.)

A^aboZaru * A man uncircumcised. (M, K.) And the fem., baZoraA='u, A woman, (T, S, Msb,) or a female slave, (M, K,) having a baZor; (T, S, Msb;) or having a long baZor: (M, K:) or a woman uncircumcised: (Mgh:) pl. buZorN. (T.) yaA A@bona AlbaZoraA='i O son of the uncircumcised woman! is an expression of contumely. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A man having what is termed a buZaArap in his upper lip; (S, A, Mgh;) [i. e.] having a Hivorimap somewhat long; (S in art. Hvrm;) having a long (T, M) and projecting (M) upper lip, with a protuberance in the middle of it. (T, M.) ― -b3- Accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) Clamorous; long-tongued. (Mgh.) [See biZoriyrN.]

mubaZ~irN mbZr
A circumciser: (M, L:) and mubaZ~irapN a woman who circumcises females. (K.)

1 baEovN Ev bEv signifies The removing of that which restrains one from free action. (TA.) [And hence,] ― -b2- baEavahu, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
baEava , (A, K,) inf. n. baEavN (Mgh, L, Msb, TA) and baEavN, (L, TA,) He sent him; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a messenger; (Msb;) and, when said of God, an apostle; (A;) [and when said of a man, a letter, &c.;] as also ↓ AbtEvh: (S, A, Msb, K:) [or] the former is said of anything that goes, or is sent, by itself; and of anything that will not go, or be sent, by itself, as a letter, and a present, one says, baEava bihi: (Msb:) [thus,] baEavahu signifies he sent him, or it, alone, by himself, or by itself; and baEava bihi, he sent him, or it, by, or with, another, or others: (L:) but El-Fárábee says that the former of these two has another signification, which will be found below; and that the latter signifies he sent him, or it. (Msb.) Hence, Duriba Ealayohimu AlbaEovu The being sent to the war was appointed them and imposed upon them as an obligation. (Msb.) You say, baEavahu lika*aA [He sent him for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) [And baEava A_ilayohi bika*aA He sent to him such a thing; lit., he sent to him a messenger with such a thing.] And baEava Aljunoda A_ilaY Algazowi [He sent the army to the war]. (TA.) And baEava Ealayohimu AlbalaA='a [He sent upon them trial, or affliction;] he caused trial, or affliction, to befall them. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (A, L, TA,) inf. baEovN (Mgh, L, TA) and baEavN (L) and taboEaAvN [an intensive form], (TA,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action; (A, L, Mgh, TA;) namely, anything; (TA;) [i. e. any person or animal; and particularly,] an animal lying down, or a person sitting. (L, TA.) You say, baEava Aln~aAqapa
He roused, or put in motion or action, the she-camel; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) i. e., loosed the cord that bound her shank to her arm, and dismissed her; or he roused her, or made her to rise, she being lying down. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting 'Áïsheh, fabaEavonaA AlbaEiyra fA_i*aA AlEiqodu taHotahu [And we made the camel to rise, and to, the necklace was beneath him]. (TA.) You say also, baEavahu EalaY AlA^amori, (A,) or Al$~aYo'i, (L,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action, to do the affair, or thing: (A:) or he incited him, urged him, or instigated him, to do the thing. (L.) ― -b4- Also, accord. to El-Fárábee, (Msb,) or baEavahu mino manaAmihi, (S, A, K,) inf. n. baEavN and baEavN, (TA,) He roused him, or awoke him, from his sleep; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AbtEvhu. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- baEovN (S, K, TA) and baEavN (TA) also signify The quickening, vivifying, or revivifying, of the dead; the raising of the dead to life; (S, K, * TA;) by God, (TA,) on the day called yawomu AlbaEovi (S, TA) the day [of resurrection,] when those who are in the graves shall be raised. (A, Mgh.) You say, baEava A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa, and AlmawotaY, God quickened, vivified, revivified, or raised to life, mankind, and the dead. (TA.) -A2- baEiva, aor.
baEava , (inf. n. baEavN, TK,) He (a man, TA) was sleepless, or wakeful. (K, * TA.) [See baEivN.]
5 tabaE~ava see 7, in two places.

6 tabaAEavuwA tbAEvwA [They roused, excited, incited, urged, or instigated, one another; or put one another in motion or action; to do a thing]. One says, tawaASawoA biAlxayori wa tabaAEavuwA Ealayohi [Enjoin ye, or charge ye, one another to do good, and rouse ye, or excite ye, &c., one another to do it]. (A.)

7 AnbEv A^nbEv AnbEv {nbEv
He became sent; [i. e. he went, being sent;] quasi-pass. of baEavahu, as signifying “he sent him:” (S, Msb, K:) he rose, and went away: (TA:) he rose to go forth. (Bd in ix. 46.) You say, AnbEv lika*aA [He went, being sent, or he rose, and went away. or he rose to go forth, for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) And AnbEv fulaAnN li$aA^onihi Such a one rose, and went away, to perform his affair. (TA.) And AnbEv fiY Als~ayori He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick or swift, in going, journeying, or pace. (S.) And AnbEv Al$~ayo'u, i. e. AinodafaEa [The thing became impelled, or propelled; or went quickly, or swiftly, as though impelled or propelled; &c.]; as also ↓ tbE~v. (TA.) [Thus] you say, AnbEv AlmaA='u [The water poured out, or forth, as though impelled or propelled]. (TA in art. fjr; &c.) And [hence,] min~iYa Al$~iEoru ↓ tbE~v, i. e. AnbEv [The poetry issued quickly from me], as though it flowed (kaA^an~ahu saAla): so in the S and K: but in some of the copies of the S, in the place of saAla, we find saAra. (TA.) And AnbEv bi$ar~K [He broke forth with evil, or mischief]. (JK in art. bwq.) ― -b2- [He became roused, excited, incited, urged, instigated, or put in motion or action.] You say, AnbEvt Aln~aAqapu The she-camel became roused, or put in motion or action, and rose: (L, Mgh, TA: *) quasi-pass. of baEava Aln~aAqapa [q. v.]. (Mgh, TA.) And fulaAnN kasolaAnN laA banobaEivu [Such a one is sluggish, lazy, or indolent: he will not become roused, &c.]. (A.) ― -b3- He became roused, or awakened, from his sleep; or he awoke from his sleep. (TA.)
8 A_ibotaEava see 1, in two places.

baEovN Ev bEv an inf. n. used as a pass. part. n.; Sent; as also ↓ baEiyvN and ↓ maboEwvN: pl. of the first buEuwvN; and of the second buEuvN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- And [used as a subst., signifying] A person sent; a messenger: pl. baEovaAnN. (L.) You say also, muHam~adN xayoru ↓ maboEuwvK and ↓ mubotaEavK [Mohammad is the best person that has been sent]. (A.) And ↓ baEayvuka niEomapF, i. e. ↓ maboEuwvuka [He whom Thou (O God) hast sent (namely Mohammad) as a boon, or benefit, or favour]. (L, from a trad. [The latter word (nEmp) is written in the L without any syll. signs; but the context shows that it is in the accus. case as a specificative.]) ― -b3- A people sent from one place to another; as also ↓ baEavN: (L, TA:) a people sent in any direction; a word similar to saforN and rakobN. (TA.) baEovu Aln~aAri, occurring in a trad., means The people sent to the fire [of Hell]. (L.) ― -b4- An army; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because sent; (Mgh;) as also ↓ baEavN (K) and ↓ baEiyvN: (TA:) pl. of the first buEuwvN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and of the last buEuvN: (TA:) the first, [as also the second,] an inf. n. used as a subst. (Msb.) You say, kunotu fiY baEovi fulaAnK I was in the army of such a one, that was sent with him. (S.) And xaraja fiY AlbuEuwvi He went forth among the forces that were sent to the frontiers. (A.) ― -b5- See also baEivN.
buEovN Ev bEv : see baEovN.
baEavN Ev bEv : see baEovN, in two places: ― -b2- and see what next follows.

baEivN Ev bEv (A, L, K) and ↓ baEovN (L, TA) and ↓ buEovN, (L,) or ↓ baEavN, (TA,) Sleepless, or wakeful: (K:) a man incessantly, (A,) or often, (TA,) awaking from his sleep: (A, TA:) a man whose anxieties, or griefs, incessantly render him sleepless, or wakeful, and awake him from his sleep: pl. A^aboEAvN. (TA.)

baEovapN Ev bEv bEvh bEvp [inf. n. of un. of 1; and particularly signifying] An occasion, or occurrence, of raising, rousing, exciting, stirring up, or provoking, of sedition, or the like: pl. baEavaAtN. (TA, from a trad.)
baEiyvN Eyv bEyv : see baEovN, in three places.

baAEivN bAEv [act. part. n. of 1; Sending: &c. ― -b2- And hence, Occasioning, or causing: an occasion, or a cause; and a motive]. ― -b3- AlbaAEivu one of the names [or epithets] of God; The Quickener of mankind after death, on the day of resurrection. (TA.)

AlbaAEuwvu AlbAEwv bAEwv , (L, K,) or, accord. to some, AlbaAguwtu, q. v., with the pointed g and the double-pointed t, (TA,) [The Christian festival of Easter;] the AisotisoqaA=' of the Christians; (K;) or [rather] what is to the Christians as the AstsqA=' is to the Muslims: a Syriac word. (L.)

maboEavN mbEv [a noun of place and of time from 1; A place, and a time, of sending: &c. Hence, AlmaboEavu is particularly applied to The time of the mission of Mohammad: and it is also applied to the mission itself]. (A, TA.)
maboEuwvN mbEwv : see baEovN, in three places.
mubotaEavN mbtEv : see baEovN.

Q. 1 baEovara bEvr , [inf. n. baEovarapN,] He took, drew, or pulled, a thing out, or forth, and uncovered it, laid it open, or exposed it; (S, K;) as also baHovara: (S:) he raised what was in a thing, (S, K,) and caused it to come forth. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [c. 9], A_i*aA buEovira maA fiY A@loqubuwri When that which is in the graves is raised, and caused to come forth: (AO, S:) [see also baHovara:] or the meaning is, when the dust, or earth, in the graves is turned over, and the dead in them are raised: (Zj:) or when what is in the graves, of gold and silver, comes forth; after which the dead are to come forth. (Fr.) ― -b2- Also He examined; he searched. (K.) ― -b3- He searched for, or after, or into, news, or tidings. (TA.) ― -b4- He scattered, or dispersed, a thing, and turned it over, one part upon another: (K:) he scattered, or dispersed, his household goods, or his commodities, (Fr, S,) and turned them over, one upon another; (Fr, Zj, S;) as also baHovara, (Fr, S,) and bagovara. (Yaakoob.) ― -b5- He demolished a watering-trough or tank, and turned it upside-down. (AO, S, K.)

1 baEajahu Ej Ejp bEj bEjh bEjp , aor.
baEaja , (T, S, A, K,) inf. n. baEojN, (T, S,) He slit, ripped, or rent, it, (T, S, A, K,) namely, a belly, with a knife, (T, S, A, TA,) and moved about the knife in it, (T,) so that what was in it became displaced and apparent, hanging down; (TA;) as also ↓ bE~jhu. (K.) ― -b2- baEajato baToyahaA lizawojihaA (assumed tropical:) [She brought forth many children to her husband; i. q. navarato: see baEiyjN]. (K.) ― -b3- baEajotu lahu baToniY (tropical:) I disclosed, or revealed, to him my secret [or my whole mind]. (A.) Esh-Shemmákh uses the phrase baEajotu A_ilayohi AlbaTona [meaning the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- baEaja baToyahu laka signifies [also] (tropical:) He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual bounds, in giving thee sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel. (K, TA.) ― -b5- baEaja A^aroDahu (tropical:) He clave, or furrowed, or trenched, his land. (A.) ― -b6- baEaja AlA^aroDa A=baArFA (tropical:) He dug many wells in the ground. (A.) ― -b7- baEaja AlA^aroDa wa bajaEahaA (tropical:) He clave the earth, or land, and subdued it: said of 'Omar, in a trad., alluding to his conquests. (TA.) ― -b8- baEajato lahu Ald~anoyaA miEaAhaA (tropical:) The world disclosed to him what it contained, of treasures, and other possessions, and spoil: also said of 'Omar, in another trad. (TA.) ― -b9- baEajato h`*ihi AlA^aroDa Ea*aApN Tay~ibapu AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) A tract of good land intervened in the middle of this land [as though cleaving it]. (L.) ― -b10- baEajahu AlHub~u (tropical:) Love threw him into mourning, or sorrow; brought grief to him:
(K, TA:) [or occasioned him intense grief: for] you say, baEajahu Hub~u fulaAnK meaning (tropical:) the love of such a one occasioned him intense grief, and he mourned for him: Az says that laEajahu AlHub~u is more correct than baEajahu: but he afterwards mentions baEajahu AlA^amoru as meaning (assumed tropical:) the affair caused him to mourn, or sorrow. (L, TA.)
2 baE~aja see 1. ― -b2- bE~j AlmaTaru AlA^aroDa, (S,) or fiY AlA^aroDi, (L, TA,) inf. n. taboEiyjN, (assumed tropical:) The rain dug up the stones of the earth by its vehemence. (S, L, TA.)
5 tbE~j Als~aH~Abu tbEj AlsHAb , (S, A, K,) and ↓ AnbEj, (K,) biAlmaTari, (TA,) (tropical:) The clouds clave asunder, with, or by reason of, rain, (S, A, K, TA,) and vehement rain. (TA.)

7 AnbEj A^nbEj AnbEj {nbEj
It [a belly] became slit, ripped, or rent. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- He had his belly slit, or ripped, or rent, with a knife, so that what was in it became displaced and apparent, hanging down. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (anything, as, for instance, a valley,) became wide, or ample. (TA.) AinobaEajato dufoEapN mina AlmaTari (tropical:) [A fall of rain burst forth]. (A.) And AnbEj Als~ayolu (tropical:) [The torrent burst forth]. (A.)
baEijN Ej bEj : see baEiyjN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man who walks weakly, as though his belly were slit, or ripped, or rent. (S, K.)

baEiyjN bEyj A belly (S) slit, ripped, or rent, (S, K,) with a knife, (S,) so that what was in it is displaced and apparent, hanging down; (TA;) as also ↓ baEijN, thought to be after manner of a rel. n.; (L, TA;) and ↓ maboEuwjN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, baToniY lilokiraAmi baEiyjN, an expression used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, meaning (tropical:) My sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel, is liberally, or freely, given to the generous. (TA. [In a reading given in the S, bAlkrAm is substituted for llkrAm]) [Or it may mean (tropical:) My secret is disclosed, or revealed, to the generous: or my whole mind.] ― -b3- baEiyjN is also applied to a man, and, without p, to a woman, as signifying Having the belly slit, ripped, or rent, with a knife, so that what was in it is displaced and apparent, hanging down: pl., masc. and fem., baEojaY. (TA.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who has brought forth many children (baEajato baTonahaA, and navarato, [see 1, and see art. nvr,]) to her husband. (K.)

baAEijapN bAEjh bAEjp (assumed tropical:) The wide part of a valley; (S, K;) the place where it becomes wide. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Plain, or soft, land, that produces [the plant called] naSiY~: or the extremity of a tract of sand, and of plain, or soft, land, [extending] to what is termed quf~ [or high, or high and rugged, ground]: and [the pl.] bawaAy^iju signifies places, in sand, which are of little depth [of sand], and which, if naSiY~ grow therein, are of least depth, and best. (TA.)
maboEuwjN mbEwj : see baEiyjN.

1 baEuda Ed bEd , aor.
baEuda , inf. n. buEodN; (S, L, Msb, K;) and baEida, aor.
baEada , inf. n. baEadN; (L, K;) and ↓ AbEd, inf. n. A_iboEaAdN, which is also trans.; (Msb;) and ↓ tbAEd; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ AstbEd; (S, K, &c.;) He, or it, was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof: he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off: he alienated, or estranged, himself: he stood, or kept, aloof: contr. of qaruba: (S, L:) [but baEuda generally has the first of these significations; and ↓ AbEd, the others, as also ↓ tbAEd and ↓ AstbEd:] it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that baEida, as well as baEuda, is thus used; but some deny this; and some assert that they may be employed alike, but that baEuda is more chaste than baEida thus used. (TA.) [You say also, of a desert, and a tract of country, and the like, baEuda, meaning It extended far.] And zayodN Eani Almanozili ↓ AbEd, meaning ↓ tbAEd [i. e. Zeyd went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from the place of alighting or abode]. (IKt, Msb.) And min~iY ↓ tbAEd, and ↓ AbtEd, and ↓ tbE~d, [He went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from me; he alienated, or estranged, himself from me; he shunned, or avoided, me;] (A;) and Ean~iY ↓ tbAEd [and baEuda En~Y signify the same]. (Msb in art. k$H.) And ↓ A_i*aA A^araA*a A^aHadukumo AlHaAjapi A^aboEada, (L, Msb,) a trad., (Msb,) meaning When one of you desires to accomplish that which is needful, (i. e. to ease nature,) he goes far, or to a great distance. (L.) And fiY Alma*ohabi ↓ A^aboEadotu, meaning ↓ tabaAEadotu, (Msb,) I went far, or to a great distance, to the place of ease, i. e., to ease nature. (L.) ― -b2- [baEuda referring to a saying or the like, and an event, means It was far from being probable or correct; it was improbable, extraordinary, or strange: (see baEiydN, and see also 10:) often occurring in these senses.] And fiY nawoEihi ↓ AbEd It reached the utmost point, or degree, in its kind, or species. (IAth.) And AbEd fiY Als~awomi He exceeded the due bounds in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing. (A.) ― -b3- A^axa*ahu maA qaruba wa maA baEuda Recent and old griefs took hold upon him: a saying similar to A^axa*ahu maA qaduma wa maA Haduva. (Mgh in art. qdm.) ― -b4- [baEuda is often used, agreeably with a general rule, in the manner of a verb of praise or dispraise; and in this case is commonly contracted into buEoda, like Husona; as in the phrase, in a verse of Imrael-Keys, buEoda maA mutaA^am~alY (in which mA is redundant) Distant, or far distant, was the object of my contemplation! or (as explained in the EM p. 52) how distant, &c.!] ― -b5- baEida, aor.
baEada , inf. n. baEadN; (S, L, Msb, K;) and baEoda, aor.
baEuda , inf. n. buEodN; (L, K;) also signify He, or it, perished: (S L, Msb:) he died: (K:) it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that both these verbs are used as signifying “he perished,” and both occur in different readings of v. 98 of ch. xi. of the Kur: the former is said to be used in this sense by some of the Arabs; and the latter, by others; but some disallow the latter in this sense; and some say that the former is more chaste than the latter thus used: (TA:) or both signify he became far distant from his home or native country; became a stranger, or estranged, therefrom: (L, TA:) or the Arabs say, baEida Alr~ajulu and baEuda in the sense of tbAEd, when not reviling; but when reviling, they say, baEida, only. (Yoo, TA.) You say, laA taboEadN wa A_ino baEudota Ean~aY [Mayest thou not perish though thou be distant from me!] (A.) [And as an imprecation against a man, you say, baEidota, meaning Mayest thou perish! (See the printed edition of the Ham, pp. 89 and 90, where baEidotaAYa hlkt is an evident mistake for aEidota A^aY halakota.)] And buEodFA lahu May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him! (A, * K, TA;) i. e. may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! like suHoqFA lahu: the most approved way being to put bEd thus in the accus. case as an inf. n.; but the tribe of Temeem say, lahu ↓ buEodN, and suHoqN, like gulaAmN lahu. (TA.) -A2- baEuda is made trans. by means of [the preposition] b: see 4. (Msb.)
2 baE~ada see 4, in four places. ― -b2- [You say also, bE~dhu Eani Als~uwo'i He declared him, or pronounced him, to be far removed from evil.]

3 bAEdhu bAEd bAEdh bAEdp
He was, or became, [distant, remote, far off, or aloof, from him; or] in a part, quarter, or tract, different from that in which he (the other) was. (TA in art. jnb.) ― -b2- See also 4, in seven places.

4 AbEd A^bEd AbEd bEd , inf. n. A_iboEaAdN: see 1, in seven places. -A2- AbEdhu; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ bAEdhu, (S, K,) inf. n. mubaAEadapN and biEaAdN; (K;) and ↓ bE~dhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taboEiydN; (S;) and bihi ↓ baEuda; (Msb;) He made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof; or to go, remove, retire, or withdraw himself, to a distance, far away, or far off; he placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, or he removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it. (S, Msb.) You say, nafosaka Eano zayodK ↓ baAEido [Remove thyself far from; or avoid thou, Zeyd]: and zayodFA Eanoka ↓ baAEido [Remove thou Zeyd far from thee]. (TA, voce A_iy~aA.) And bayonahumaA ↓ baE~adotu, inf. n. taboEiydN, [I made a wide separation between them two]; as also ↓ baAEadotu, inf. n. mubaAEadapN. (Msb.) And A@ll~`hu ↓ baAEada maA bayonahumaA [May God make the space between them two far extending! may He make a wide separation between them two!]; as also ↓ baE~ada. (TA.) And bayona A^asofaArinaA ↓ rab~anaA baAEido, or ↓ baE~ido, [O our Lord, make to be far-extending the spaces between our journeys! or, put wide distances between our journeys!] accord. to different readings [in the Kur xxxiv. 18]: the former of these is the common reading: Yaakoob El-Hadramee read ↓ rab~unaA baAEada Alx [Our Lord, He hath made to be far extending &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aboEadahu A@ll~`hu means May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him! (K;) i. e., may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! (TA.) [You say also, A^aboEada A@ll~`hu AlA^axira: see A^axirN.] ― -b3- See also 10. -A3- maA A^aboEadahu mina AlS~awaAbi [How far is it (namely the saying) from what is right, or correct!]. (A.)
5 tabaE~ada see 1.

6 tbAEd bAEd tbAEd : see 1, in six places. ― -b2- [It also signifies He became alienated, or estranged, from his family or friends. ― -b3- And tbAEdwA They became distant, or remote, one from another; they went, removed, retired, or withdrew themselves, to a distance, far away, or far off, one from another; they removed themselves far, or kept aloof, one from another.] You say, kaAnuwA mutaqaAribiyna fatabaAEaduwA [They were near, one to another, and they became distant, or remote, one from another]. (A.)
8 A_ibotaEada see 1.

10 AstbEdhu A^stbEdh AstbEdh AstbEdp {stbEd {stbEdh
He reckoned it, or esteemed it, (namely, a thing, K, or a saying, A,) baEiyd [i. e. distant, or remote; or if a saying or the like, far from being probable or correct, improbable, extraordinary, or strange]; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ AbEdhu. (A.) -A2- See also 1, first sentence, in two places.

baEodu Ed bEd an adv. n. of time, signifying After, or afterwards: and allowable also, accord. to some of the grammarians, as an adv. n. of place, signifying after, or behind: (TA:) contr. of qabolu: (S, A, K:) it is a vague adv. n., of which the meaning is not understood without its being prefixed to another noun [expressed or implied]; denoting after-time. (Msb.) When it occurs without any complement, (S, K,) a noun or the like which should be its complement being intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter, (S, * TA,) it is indecl., (S, K,) because it resembles a particle, (TA,) and has damm for its termination to show that it is indecl., since it cannot have damm by any rule of desinential syntax because it cannot occur as an agent nor as an inchoative or enunciative. (S.) Sb, however, mentions [as exceptions to this rule] the phrases mino baEodK [Afterwards] and A^afoEalu h`*aA baEodFA [I will do this afterwards], as having been used by the Arabs. (K, * TA.) [The latter of these phrases is common in the present day. Another exception to the rule above-mentioned will be found in what follows.] Accord. to the primary rule, it is used as a prefixed n. governing its complement in the gen. case; (S;) [i. e., it is used in the manner of a preposition;] and when thus used, it is decl., (K,) because it does not in this case [always] resemble a particle. (TA.) You say, jaA='a zayodN baEoda EamorKw Zeyd came after 'Amr. (Msb.) And raA^ayotuhu baEodaka and mino baEodika [I saw him after thee]. (L.) The words of the Kur [xxx. 3], A@ll~`hi A@loA^amoru mino qabolu wa mino baEodu, meaning To God belonged the command before that the Greeks were overcome and after that they had been overcome, [thus read when the complements of qbl and bEd are intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter,] are also read mino qaboli wa mino baEodi, when each complement is intended to be understood as to the meaning and the letter, and also mino qabolK wa mino baEodK, meaning To God belongeth the command first and last, [when neither complement is intended to be understood either as to the letter or as to the meaning,] but the first of these readings is the best. (L.) [You say also, baEoda *`lika and mino baEodi *`lika After that: and baEoda A^ano faEalotu and mino baEodi A^ano faEalotu and baEoda maA faEalotu and mino baEodi maA faEalotu After I did, or after my doing, such a thing: &c.] Also jiy^otu baEodayokumaA, meaning baEoda kumaA, I came after you two. (K.) And h`*aA mim~aA layosa baEodahu gaAyapN fiY Aljawodapi, and fiY Alr~adaA='ap, This is of the things after, or beyond, which there is not any extreme degree in respect of goodness, and in respect of badness: and, by way of abridgement, layosa baEodahu [with nothing following this]: and hence, app., the saying of Mohammad, waA_ino kaAna layosa biAl~a*iY laA baEoda lahu, meaning [And though] it be not in the utmost degree in respect of goodness: bEd being thus used as a decl. noun. (Mgh.)

[
baEodiY Ed Edy bEd bEdY bEdy bEdyy and the like are also frequently used as meaning baEoda EahodiY and the like; as in the phrase, qado tagay~arota baEodY Thou hast become altered since I knew thee, or saw thee, or met thee, or was with thee. And similar to this are many phrases in the Kur; as, for instance, in ii. 48,] vum~a A@t~axa*otumu A@lEijola mino baEodihi Then ye took to yourselves the calf as a god, or an object of worship, after him, namely Moses, i. e., after his having gone away. (Bd.) A^am~aA baEodu (S, K, &c.) is [an expression denoting transition;] an expression by which an address or a discourse is divided; (S;) used without any complement to bEd, which in this case signifies the contr. of qabolu: (TA:) you say, A^am~aA baEodu faqado kaAna ka*aA, meaning [Now, after these preliminary words, (Abu-l- 'Abbás in TA voce xiTaAbN,) I proceed to say, that such a thing has happened: or] after my prayer for thee: (K:) or after praising God: (TA:) the first who used this formula was David; (K;) or Jacob; (TA;) or Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; (K;) or Kuss Ibn-Sá'ideh; or Yaarub Ibn-Kahtán. (TA.) ― -b2- You also use the dim. form, saying ↓ buEayodahu [A little after him, or it], when you mean by it to denote a time near to the preceding time. (Msb.) You say also, bayonK ↓ raA^ayotuhu buEayodaAti, (S, K,) and ↓ baEiydaAtihi, (K, TA, [in the CK buEayodaAtih,]) I saw him a little after a separation: (S, K:) or, after intervals of separation: (S, L:) or, after a while. (A'Obeyd, A.) And A_in~ahaA lataDoHaku bayonK ↓ buEayo*aAti Verily she laughs after intervals. (L.) [See also art. byn.] ↓ buEayodaAt is used only as an adv. n. of time. (S, L.) ― -b3- baEodu also sometimes means Now; yet; as yet. (TA.) [It is used in this sense mostly in negative phrases; as, for instance, in lamo yamuto baEodu He has not died yet. The following is one of the instances of its having this meaning in affirmative phrases: sum~iya AlHawoliY~u mino A^awolaAdi Albaqari tabiyEFA liA^an~ahu yanobaEu A^um~ahu baEodu The yearling of the offspring of cows is called tbyE because he yet follows his mother: occurring in the Mgh &c., in art. tbE.] ― -b4- It occurs also in the sense of maEa; as in the words of the Kur [ii. 174 and v. 95], famani A@EotadaY baEoda *`lika, i. e., (as some say, MF,) maEa *lk [And whoso transgresseth notwithstanding that; lit., with that]. (Msb.) ― -b5- It has been said that it also means Before, in time; thus bearing two contr. significations: that it has this meaning in two instances; in the Kur [lxxix. 30], where it is said, wa A@loA^aroDa baEoda *`lika daHaAhaA [as though signifying And the earth, before that, He spread it forth]; and [xxi. 105] where it is said, walaqado katabonaA fiY A@lz~abuwri mino baEodi A@l*~ikori [as though meaning And verily we wrote in the Psalms before the Kur-án]: (MF, TA:) but Az says that this is a mistake; that God created the earth not spread forth; then created the heaven; and then spread forth the earth: (L, TA:) and Al*kr in the latter of these instances means the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (Bd:) or Alzbwr means the revealed Scriptures; (Bd, Jel;) and Al*kr, the Preserved Tablet, (Bd,) [i. e.] the Original of the Scriptures, which is with God. (Jel.)

buEodN Ed bEd [as an inf. n. used in the manner of a subst. signifies] Distance, or remoteness; (S, A, L, K; *) and so ↓ baEadN, (L, K,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, (TA, [see baEoda,]) [and ↓ buEodapN, for] you say, bayonanaA buEodapN, meaning [Between us two is a distance] of land or country, or of relationship. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Remoteness from probability or correctness; improbability, or strangeness: see baEuda. Hence the phrase, h`*aA mina AlbuEodi bimakaAnK This is improbable, or extraordinary, or strange: often occurring in the TA &c.] ― -b3- Also i. q. ↓ buEodN: (L, K:) this latter (S, L, Msb, K) and buEodN, (L, K,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, as, for instance, in the Kur xi. 98, (TA, [see baEida,]) signifying Perdition; (S, L, Msb;) or death. (K.) ― -b4- Judgment and prudence; as also ↓ buEodapN: so in the phrase, A_in~ahu la*uw buEodK, and buEodapK, Verily he is possessed of judgment and prudence: (K:) or penetrating, or effective, judgment; depth, or profundity; far-reaching judgment. (TA.) [See also A^aboEadu.] ↓ *uw AlbuEodapi also signifies A man who goes to a great length, or far, in hostility. (L.) ― -b5- A cursing; execration; malediction; as also ↓ biEaAdN. (K.) You say, buEodN lahu, as well as buEodFA lahu: see 1, last sentence but one. (TA.)
baEadN Ed bEd : see buEodN, in two places: -A2- and baEiydN, in five places.
buEodN Ed bEd : see A^aboEadu, in two places.
buEodapN Ed Edp bEd bEdh bEdp : see buEodN, in three places.
buEaAdN EAdy bEAd : see baEiydN: ― -b2- and see also baAEidN.
biEaAdN EAdy bEAd : see buEodN.

baEiydN Eyd bEyd
Distant; remote; far; far off; (S, L, K; *) as also ↓ buEaAdN, and ↓ baAEidN: (L, K:) pl. (of the first, S, L) buEodaAnN (S, L, K) and (of the first also, L, TA) buEudN (L, K) and biEaAdN (TA) and (of the first and second, L) buEadaA='u (L, K) and of the third, ↓ baEadN, [but this (which is also used as a sing. epithet, as will be shown in what follows,) is properly a quasi-pl. n.,] like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (S.) As signifying Distant with respect to place, it is correctly used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; (L, and TA in this art. and in art. qrb, in which latter see the authorities;) but not necessarily; like its contr. qariybN: (L:) you say, hiYa baEiydN minoka [She is distant from thee; or it is] as though you said, makaAnuhaA baEiydN:
(L:) also maA A^anota min~aA bibaEiydK [Thou art not distant from us ], and maA A^anotumo min~aA bibaEiydK [Ye are not distant from us]: and in like manner, maA A^anota ↓ min~aA bibaEadK, and ↓ maA A^anotumu min~aA bibaEadK. (S, TA.) [But it receives, sometimes, the fem. form when used in this sense; for] jalasotu baEiydFA minoka and baEiydapN minoka are phrases mentioned as signifying I sat distant, or remote in place, or at a distance, or aloof, from thee; makaAnFA [and naAHiyapF or the like] being understood. (L.) You say also, ↓ manozilN baEadN A distant, or remote, place of alighting or abode. (K.) And tanaH~a gayora baEiydK (S, K) and ↓ gayora baAEidK and ↓ gayora baEadK (K) [Retire thou not far;] meaning be thou near: (S, K:) [or] the second and third of these phrases mean retire thou not in an abject, or a mean, or contemptible, or despicable, state. (S, A.) And ↓ AinoTaliqo yaA fulaAnu gayora baAEidK [Depart thou, O such a one, not far;] meaning mayest thou not go away! (L.) [And raA^ayotuhu mino baEiydK I saw him, or it, from afar: and jaA='a mino baEiydK He came from afar: and the like. And baEiydN as applied to a desert and the like, meaning Far extending.] And ↓ buEodN baAEidN A far distance. (K.) [And niy~apN baEiydapN A distant, far-reaching, or far-aiming, intention, purpose, or design.] And fulaAnN baEiydu Alhim~api [Such a one is far-aiming, or faraspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]. (A.) And hiYa baEiydapu AlEahodi [She was known, or seen, or met, a long time ago]: in this case, the fem. form, with p, must be used. (L.) And qawolN baEiydN [A saying far from being probable or correct; improbable; far-fetched; extraordinary, or strange]. (A.) And A^amorN baEiydN An extraordinary thing or affair or case, of which the like does not happen or occur. (L.) ― -b2- Also Distant with respect to kindred or relationship: in which sense, the word receives the fem. form, [as well as the dual form, and pl. forms, like its contr. qariybN,] by universal consent. (TA.) [Its pl.] buEadaA='u signifies Strangers, that are not relations. (IAth.) You say also, fulaAnN mino buEodaAni AlA^amiyri [meaning Such a one is of the distant dependents, or subjects, of the governor, or prince]. (S.) And A_i*aA lamo takuno mino qurobaAni AlA^amiyri fakuno mino buEodaAnihi [If thou be not of the particular companions, or familiars, of the governor, or prince, then be of his distant dependents, or subjects]; i. e., be distant from him, that his evil may not affect thee. (AZ, A.) ― -b3- raA^ayotuhu baEiydaAti bayonK: see baEodN in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b4- See also baAEidN.
buEayod Eyd bEyd and buEayodaAt: see baEodu in four places.

baAEidu bAEd : see baEiydN in four places. ― -b2- Also Perishing: (S, L: [in the K it is implied that it signifies dying; and so ↓ baEiydN and ↓ buEaAdN:]) or far distant from his home, or native country; in a state of estrangement therefrom. (L.)

A^aboEadu *
More, and most, distant or remote; further, and furthest: by poetic licence written A^aboEad~u: (L:) [pl. A^abaAEidu; as in the saying,] fulaAnN yasotajir~u AlHadiyva mino A^abaAEidi A^aToraAfihi [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A.) ― -b2- More, and most, extreme, excessive, egregious, or extraordinary, in its kind. (IAth.) [Hence, perhaps,] A_in~ahu lagayoru A^aboEada [in the CK A^aboEadK] and ↓ buEadK Verily there is no good in him: (K:) or, no depth in him in anything: (IAar:) [or, he is not extraordinary in his kind: see also buEodN:] said in dispraising one. (TA.) And maA Einodahu A^aboEadu and ↓ buEadN [He has not what is extraordinary in its kind: or] he possesses not excellence, or power, or riches: or he possesses not anything profitable: (L, K:) said only in dispraising one: (AZ:) or it may mean he possesses not anything which one would go far to seek; or, anything of value: or what he possesses, of things or qualities that are desirable, is more extraordinary than what others possess. (MF.) ― -b3- Remote from good: [which is the meaning generally intended in the present day when it is used absolutely as an epithet applied to a man; but meaning also remote from him or those in whose presence this epithet is used, both as to place and as to moral condition:] and, from continence: (L:) and stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; syn. HaAy^inN: (so in a copy of the S and in the L and TA:) or treacherous, or unfaithful; syn. xaAy^inN (So in two copies of the S and in a copy of the A.) It is used as an allusion to the name of a person whom one would mention with dispraise; as when one says, halaka AlA^aboEadu [May such a one, the remote from good, &c., perish!]: with respect to a woman, one says, halakati AlbuEodaY. (En-Nadr, Az.) One says also, kab~a A@ll~`hu AlA^aboEada lifiyhi, meaning [May God cast down prostrate such a one, the remote from good, &c., upon his mouth! or,] cast him down upon his face! (S.) [It is a rule observed in decent society, by the Arabs, to avoid, as much as possible, the mention of opprobrious epithets, lest any person present should imagine an epithet of this kind to be slily applied to himself: therefore, when any malediction or vituperation is uttered, it is usual to allude to the object by the term AlA^aboEad, or AlbaEiyd, as meaning the remote from good, &c., and also the remote from the person or persons present. See also AlA^axiru, which is used in a similar manner.] ― -b4- A more distant, or most distant, or very distant, relation; (Lth;) contr. of A^aqorabu: (Msb:) pl. A^abaAEidu (Lth, S, A, Msb, K) and A^aboEaduwna; (Lth;) contr. of A^aqaAribu (Lth, S, K) and A^aqorabuwna. (Lth.)
miboEadN mbEd A man who makes far journeys. (K.)

1 baEara bEr , aor.
baEara (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. baEorN (S, Msb,) said of an animal having the kind of foot called xuf~, (Mgh, Msb, K,) [i. e.,] of a camel, and also of a sheep and goat, (S,) and of a cloven-hoofed animal (Mgh, Msb, K) of the wild kind of bull or cow, but not of the domestic kind, and of the gazelle-kind, beside the other two cloven-hoofed kinds mentioned before, and of the hare or rabbit, (TA,) He voided dung. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- baEarahu He threw at him a piece of baEor. (A.) ― -b3- baEarato, said of a widow, She threw the piece of baEor; i. q. ↓ ramato biAlbaEorap; meaning she ended the number of days during which she had to wait after the death of her husband before she could marry again. (A.) [It seems to have been customary for the widow to collect a number of pieces of baEor, as many as the days she had to wait before she could marry again, and to throw away one each day: so that the saying means She threw the last piece of bEr.] -A2- baEira, aor.
baEara , (K,) inf. n. baEarN, (TA,) He (a camel) became a baEiyr. (K.)
2 baE~ara see 4.

3 baAEarato HaAlibahaA bAErt HAlbhA , [inf. n., app., biEaArN, q. v.,] said of a ewe or she-goat, (K,) and of a she-camel, (TA,) She befouled her milker with her dung. (TA voce biEaArN.) -A2- baAEarato A_ilaY HaAlibihaA She (a ewe or goat, and a camel,) hastened to her milker. (TA.)

4 AbEr AbEr
He cleansed an intestine, or a gut, of its baEor; as also ↓ bE~r, inf. n. taboEiyrN. (K.)

baEorN bEr (S, A, K) and ↓ baEarN (Msb, K) [coll. gen. ns. signifying Camels', and sheeps', and goats', and similar, dung;] dung (Msb, K) of animals having the kind of foot called xuf~, (A, Mgh, Msb, K) [i. e.,] of the camel, and also of the sheep and goat, (S,) and of cloven-hoofed animals (A, Mgh, Msb, K) of the wild kind of bull and cow, but not of the domestic kind, and of the gazelle-kind, beside the two other cloven-hoofed kinds, and of the hare or rabbit: (TA:) n. un. with p: (S, Mgh, K:) and pl. A^aboEaArN. (S, Msb, K) One says, huwa A^ahowanu EalaY~a mino baEorapK yuromaY bihaA kalobN [He is a lighter thing to me than a piece of bEr that is thrown at a dog]. (A.) And it is said in a prov., A^anota kaSaAHibi AlbaEorapi [Thou art like the owner of the piece of bEr, or A^anota fiY mivoli SaAHibi AlbaEorapi Thou art in a condition like that of the owner of the piece of bEr; (meaning the person for whom it was intended;) applied to him who reveals a thing relating to himself; (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 85;)] originating from the fact that a man had a suspicion respecting some one among his people; so he collected them to search out from them the truth of the case, and took a piece of bEr, and said, “I am about to throw this my piece of bEr at the person whom I suspect;” whereupon one of them withdrew himself quickly, and said, “Throw it not at me;” and confessed. (TA.) See also baEarato, above.
baEarN bEr : see baEorN.

biEaArN EAr EAry bEAr , a subst., [or inf. n. of 3,] The befouling of her milker with her dung, by a ewe or she-goat, (K,) or a camel: (TA:) it is reckoned a fault, because the animal that does so sometimes casts her dung into the milking-vessel. (TA.)

baEiyrN Eyr bEyr , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) sometimes pronounced baEiyrN, (K,) which latter is of the dial. of BenooTemeem, but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) A camel, male or female; (S, Msb, K;) as applied to a camel, like A_inosaAnN applied to a human being; (S, Msb;) whereas jamalN is applied only to a male camel, and naAqapN to a she-camel;
bakorN and bakorapN are respectively terms like fatnFY and fataApN; and qaluwSN is like the term jaAriyapN; so say, among others, ISk and Az and IJ; and it is added in the Mutahffidh, that the terms jml and nAqp are applied only when the animal has entered the seventh year: (Msb:) but bEyr is more commonly applied to the male camel; (Msb, K;) and only to one that has entered its fifth year; (S, K;) or that has entered its ninth year: (K:) the pl. is A^aboEirapN [a pl. of pauc.] and buEoraAnN (S, Msb, K) and biEoraAnN (K) and buEurN (TA) and (pl. of A^aboEirapN TA) A^abaAEiru (S, Msb, K) and A^abaAEiyru (K.) If one say, A^aEoTuwniY baEiyrFA [Give ye to me a bEyr], the persons so addressed, accord. to EshSháfi'ee, are not to give a she-camel: (Msb:) but the following phrases are transmitted from the Arabs: SaraEatoniY baEiyriY My she-camel threw me down prostrate: (S, A:) and Halabotu baEiyriY I milked my camel: (A, Msb:) and $aribotu mino labani baEiyriY I drank of the milk of my camel: (S:) and kilaA h`*iyoni AlbiEorayoni naAqapN Each of these two camels is a she-camel. (A.) layolapu AlbaEiyri [The night of the camel], mentioned in a trad. of Jábir, means the night in which the Prophet purchased of him his camel. (TA.) ― -b2- Also An ass: (IKh, K:) so in the Kur xii. 72; but this signification is of rare occurrence: (IKh:) and anything that carries: (IKh, K:) so in the Hebrew language [165 (see Gen. xlv. 17)]. (TA.)

baAEirN bAEr A widow throwing the piece of baEor; meaning ending the number of days during which she has had to wait after the death of her husband previously to her being allowed to marry again. (A.) [See 1.]

maboEarN mbEr and ↓ miboEarN [and ↓ maboEarapN (occurring in the K in art. xwr)] The place [or passage (as is shown in the Lexicons in many places)] of the baEor; [i. e. the rectum; the intestine, or gut, containing the baEor;] of any quadruped: (K:) pl. mabaAEiru. (TA.) It is said in a prov., A_in~a h`*aA Ald~aAEira maA zaAla yanoHaru AlA^abaAEira wa yanovilu AlmabaAEira [Verily this bad man has not ceased to slaughter camels and to cleanse the intestines containing the dung]. (A, TA.)
miboEarN mbEr : see maboEarN
maboEarapN mbErh mbErp : see maboEarN
miboEaArN mbEAr A ewe or she-goat, (K,) or a she-camel, (TA,) that befouls with her dung (tubaAEiru) her milker. (K, TA.) [See biEaArN.]

1 baEaDahu AlbaEuwDu bEDh AlbEwD , [aor.
baEaDa ,] inf. n. baEoDN, The baEuwD [or gnats, or musquitoes,] bit him; and annoyed, or molested, him. (TA.) And buEiDuwA They were bitten by the baEuwD: (A:) or were annoyed, or molested, thereby. (K.) baEaDahu is not used in relation to anything but baEuwD. (TA.) A poet says, praising a man who passed the night within a kil~ap [or thin curtain used for protection from gnats, or musquitoes], which is also called A^abuw divaArK,
laniEoma Albayotu bayotu A^abiY divaArK
A_i*aA maA xaAfa baEoDu Alqawomi baEoDaA
[Excellent indeed is the tent, the tent of Aboo-Dithár, when some of the people fear biting, and annoyance, or molestation, from gnats, or musquitoes]: by bEDA meaning EaD~FA. (TA.)

2 bEDhu ED EDp bED bEDh bEDp , inf. n. taboEiyDN, He divided it into parts, or portions, (S, A, Msb, K,) distinct, or separate, one from another. (Msb) You say, A^axa*uwA maAlahu fabaE~aDuwhu They took his property and divided it into parts, or portions. (A, TA.) And EaD~aY Al$~aApa wa baE~aDahaA [He limbed, or dismembered, the sheep, or goat, and divided it into parts, or portions]. (A, TA.) [Hence,] mino in certain cases, and bi in the like cases, as in the saying $aribotu bimaA='i ka*aA [“ I drank of, ” i. e. “ some of, such water ”], are said to be lilt~aboEiyDi [For the purpose of dividing into parts, or portions]. (Msb.)

4 AbEDwA AbEDwA
They had baEuwD [or gnats, or musquitoes], (K,) or abundance thereof, (A,) in their land. (A, K.)

5 tbE~D bED tbED
It was, or became, divided into parts, or portions. (S, K.)

baEoDN ED bED
Some, or somewhat or some one, (lit. a thing,) of things, or of a thing: Th says that it signifies thus accord. to all the grammarians; (Msb, TA;) except Hishám, as will be seen hereafter: (TA:) or a part, or portion, (A, Msb, K,) of a thing, (Msb,) or of anything; (A, K;) whether little or much: (TA:) accord. to both these explanations, it may denote the greater part; as eight of ten: (Msb:) [thus it signifies some one or more; and it relates to persons and to other things:] pl. A^aboEaADN; (S, IJ, K;) but ISd doubts whether IJ had an authority for this. (TA.) You say, baEoDu Al$~ar~i A^ahowanu mino baEoDK [Some kinds of evil are easier to be borne than some]. (A.) And jaAriyapN Hus~aAnapN yu$obihu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA [A very beautiful girl, parts of whom resemble other parts]. (A.) [And Daraba baEoDuhumo baEoDFA Some of them beat some; i. e. they beat one another.] And labivonaA yawomFA A^awo baEoDa yawomK [We have tarried a day or part of a day]. (Kur xviii. 18.) And one says to a man of a company of men, “ Who did this? ” and he answers, A^aHadunaA or baEoDunaA [Some one of us]; meaning himself. (A.) The article Al should not be prefixed to it, (K, * TA,) because it is originally a prefixed n., and as such determinate either literally or virtually, so that it does not admit another cause of being determinate; (TA;) contr. to what is said by IDrst (K, TA) and Ez-Zejjájee; for they said AlbaEoDu and Alkul~u; which, properly, as ISd says, is not allowable; and it is said in the O that IDrst, in this matter, was at variance with all the people of his age: (TA:) AHát says that the Arabs did not say Alkul~u nor AlbaEoDu, but that people used these expressions, even Sb and Akh in their two books, by reason of their little knowledge in this way: (K, * TA:) a remark, says MF, which is extr., and needs no comment: (TA:) [for who surpassed Sb and Akh in knowledge respecting matters of this kind?] AHát also relates his having told As that he had seen in the book of [that celebrated and chaste author] Ibn-ElMukaffa', AlEilomu AlkaviyrN wa l`kin~a A^axo*a AlbaEoDi xayorN mino taroki Alkul~i [Science is large; but the acquiring of part is better than the neglecting of the whole]; and that As disapproved of it most strongly, saying that the article Al is not prefixed to baEoDN and kul~N because they are determinate without it: (TA:) Az, however, says that the grammarians allow its being prefixed to these two words, (Msb, TA,) though As disallows it, (TA,) because they are meant to be understood as prefixed ns.; (Msb;) or because the article is meant to be a substitute for the noun to which they should be prefixed; or, in the case of baEoDN, because this word is equivalent to juzo'N, which receives the article Al. (MF.) It is related of AO, that he assigned also to baEoDN the contr. meaning of All; or the whole: adducing as a proof thereof the words of the Kur [xl. 29], yuSibokumo baEoDu A@l~a*iY yaEidukumo as meaning All of that with which he threateneth you will befall you: and the saying of Lebeed.
A^awo yaEotaliqo baEoDa Aln~ufuwsi HimaAmuhaA
[as meaning Or their death shall cling to all living creatures: or, accord. to another relation, Aw yarotabiTo, which means the same as Aw yEtlq]: thus also AHeyth explains the above-cited verse of the Kur; and thus Hishám explains the saying of Lebeed, erroneously asserting that bED is here a pl.: (TA:) but with respect to the former instance, the Prophet had threatened them with two things, the punishment of the present world and that of the world to come; so he says, “ This punishment will befall you in the present world; ” which is part (bED] of the two threats; without denying the punishment of the world to come: or, as Aboo-Is-hák says, he mentions the part to indicate the necessary consequence of the whole: and as to the saying of Lebeed, by bED Alnfws he means himself. (TA [app. from ISd].)

baEuwDN EwD bEwD [Gnats, or musquitoes;] i. q. baq~a [which signifies both gnats, or musquitoes, (called in Egypt naAmuws,) and also bugs]: n. un. with p: (S:) or pl. of baEuwDapN, (K,) which signifies i. q. baq~apN. (A, K.) A poet speaks of the humming of the bEwD of the water. (TA.) The author of the K says, in the B, that the word is taken from baEoDN, because of the smallness of the body of the bEwDp in comparison with other living things. (TA.) You say, kal~afaniY mux~a AlbaEuwDi (tropical:) He imposed upon me a difficult thing: (A:) or an impossible thing. (TS, K.)
A^aroDN maboEaDapN * : see baEiDapN
layolapN maboEuwDapN lylp mbEwDh lylp mbEwDp : see baEiDapN

baEaqa ,] inf. n. buEaAqN, (Lth, K, TA,) said of a man, and a camel, &c., (TA,) He uttered a vehement sound, or cry. (Lth, * K, * TA.) -A2- Also, inf. n. as above, said of a vehement rain, descending in large drops, It clave, or furrowed, the ground, and made it to flow. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And, inf. n. baEoqN, He stabbed, or stuck, a camel in the naHor, or throat, or uppermost part of the breast, (K, TA,) making the blood to flow; (TA;) and (TA) so ↓ bE~q. You say, ziq~a Alxamori ↓ baE~aqotu, inf. n. taboEiyqN, I slit, or ripped, or rent, the wine-skin. Land upon which what is termed buEaAq [i. e. either the rain or torrent so termed] has fallen, or descended. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, TA.)

1 baEala bEl , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baEala , (K,) or
baEula [contr. to rule]; (Msb;) or the pret. is baEula; (so in the Ham p. 337;) inf. n. buEuwlapN (Msb, K) and baEaAlapN also (Ham ubi suprà) [and app. baEolN, for it is said in the Ham p. 359 that the primary signification of AlbaEolu is Aln~ikaAHu]; He (a man, S) became a husband; (S, K;) as also ↓ AstbEl: (K:) he married, or took a wife. (Msb.) And in like manner, baEalato, inf. n. buEuwlapN, She became a wife: (TA:) [and it seems to be indicated in the Ham p. 359 that ↓ AbtElt and ↓ tbE~lt signify the same:] and ↓ bAElt she took to herself a husband. (K.) ― -b2- baEala Ealayohi [as though originally signifying He became a baEol, or lord, over him:] he was incompliant, or unyielding, to him; he resisted him, or withstood him. (K.) Hence, in a trad., famano baEala Ealayokumo A^amorakumo faA@qotuluwhu And whoso resisteth and disobeyeth your command, slay ye him. (TA.) -A2- baEila, (S, K,) biA^amorihi, aor.
baEala , (K,) (assumed tropical:) He became confounded, or perplexed, so that he was unable to see his right course, (S, K,) by his affair, or case, and feared, and was disgusted, (K,) and remained fixed in his place like as do the palm-trees termed baEol, (TA,) not knowing what to do. (K.)

3 bAElt bAElt : see 1. ― -b2- bAEl Alqawomu qawomFA The people intermarried with a people. (K.) You say also, banuw fulaAnK laA yubaAEaluwna The sons of such a one, none is married to them, nor are they married [to any but persons of their own tribe]. (Ham p. 337.) ― -b3- [The inf. n.] biEaAlN signifies also The playing, or toying, together, of a man with his wife; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so mubaAEalapN [also an inf. n. of the same verb], (Msb, K,) and ↓ tabaAEulN [inf. n. of 6]. (K.) You say, bAEl A@moraA^atahu He played, or toyed, with his wife. (Msb.) And tubaAEilu zawojahaA She plays, or toys, with her husband. (S.) And bayonahumaA mubaAEalapF Between them two is playing, or toying. (TA.) And ↓ humaA yatabaAEalaAni They two play, or toy, together, each with the other. (TA.) ― -b4- And metonymically, (TA,) biEaAlN signifies also (tropical:) I. q. jimaAEN; (Az, K, TA;) and so mubaAEalapN. (TK.) You say, baAEalahaA, meaning (tropical:) He lay with her. (TK.) ― -b5- And bAEl fulaAnN fulaAnFA (tropical:) Such a one sat with such a one: (K, TA:) the idea of playing, or toying, being imagined to be implied. (TA.)

5 tbE~lt tbElt : see 1. ― -b2- Also She was obedient to her husband; (K;) [so too ↓ AbtElt, as will be seen from what follows;] and so tbE~lt zawojahaA: (TA:) or she adorned herself for her husband. (K.) You say ↓ AimoraA^apN HasanapN AlAibotiEaAli A woman who is good in obedience to her husband. (TA.)

10 AstbEl AstbEl : see 1. ― -b2- Also, said of palm-trees (naxol), They became what are termed baEol, q. v., (S, TA,) and great. (TA.) ― -b3- And, said of a place, It became what is termed baEol: (K:) or it became elevated. (TA.)

baEolN bEl
A husband: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. buEuwlapN (S, Msb, K) and buEuwlN and biEaAlN. (K.) And A wife; as also baEolapN; (S, Msb, K;) like zawojN and zawojapN. (S, Msb. *) ― -b2- A lord, a master, an owner, or a possessor, (S, Msb, K,) of a thing, (K,) such as a house, and a beast, (TA,) or a she-camel: (S:) a head, chief, ruler, or person of authority. (El-Khattábee, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] A certain idol, (S, K,) of gold, (TA,) belonging to the people of Ilyás, (S, K,) who is said to be the same as Idrees, the grandfather, or an ancestor, of Noah, or to have been a grandson of Aaron, (Bd in vi. 85,) or the son of the brother of Aaron: (Jel ibid.:) it is mentioned in the Kur xxxvii. 123: accord. to one copy of the K, it belonged to the people of Jonas; and so in the Kitáb el-Mujarrad of Kr: accord. to Mujáhid, it means a deity that is not God: (TA:) or a certain king: (IAar, K:) but [SM says,] the correct explanation is the first: (TA:) or a certain idol belonging to the people of Bekk, in Syria; i. e., of the town now called Baala-Bekk: so in the Kur: (Bd, Jel: *) or it means in the dial. of El-Yemen a lord; and so in the Kur. (Bd.) ― -b4- Also One whom it is a necessary duty to obey; as a father, and a mother, and the like. (TA.) ― -b5- And A family, or household, whose maintenance is incumbent on a man. (TA.) ― -b6- And it may be a contraction of baEilN, as meaning Lacking strength, or power, or ability; unable to find the right way to accomplish his affair. (TA.) ― -b7- Also (tropical:) A weight, or burden. (K, TA.) You say, A^aSobaHa fulaAnN baEolFA EalaY A^aholihi (tropical:) Such a one became a weight, or burden, upon his family; because of his ascendency over them. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Elevated land, (S, K,) upon which comes neither running water nor torrent, (S,) or that is not rained upon more than once in the year: (K:) or (tropical:) land elevated above other land; as being likened to the man who is thus termed. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) Any palm-trees, and other trees, and seed-produce, not watered: or such as are watered by the rain: (K:) or (tropical:) palm-trees (naxol) that imbibe with their roots, and so need not to be watered: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) metaphorically so applied: (Mgh:) AA says that it is syn. with Ei*oYN, meaning what is watered by the rain: but As says that this latter word has the meaning just given, whereas bEl signifies what imbibes with its roots, without irrigation or rain: (S, Msb:) or palm-trees growing in land whereof the supply of water is near [to the surface], so that it suffices without their having irrigation or rain: (TA:) or large, so as to imbibe with the roots: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and (tropical:) a male palm-tree; (K, TA;) likened to the man who is thus termed: (TA:) and Az says that it is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) [dates such as are termed] qasob. (TA.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) The tax, or impost, that is given for the watering of palm-trees. (K.)

baEilN bEl part. n. of baEila, Confounded, or perplexed, &c. (K.) And Lacking strength, or power, or ability; unable to find the right way to accomplish his affair. (TA.) ― -b2- With p, applied as an epithet to a woman, (S,) and meaning One who does not dress, or wear clothes, well, (K, TA,) nor well adjust her personal state or condition. (TA.)
