bagaAvN bgAv (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and bugaAvN and bigaAvN; (A, Mgh, K;) only the second of these three mentioned by Sb; (TA;) but the second and third asserted to be correct by Yoo; (AZ, TA;) and the last heard by Az; (TA;) or neither of these two is allowable; (Msb;) A bird that does not prey, and such as one does not desire to make an object of prey because it is not eaten: (T, Msb:) or small birds that do not prey, such as sparrows and the like; [a coll. gen. n.;] n. un. with p: (Mgh:) or [accord. to Lth,] a certain dust-coloured bird, (T, A, K,) of the birds of the water, ash-coloured, and long-necked; as also ↓ A^abogavu; pl. [of the latter] bugovN and A^abaAgivu: (T:) [but this appears to be wrong; for AM says, in the T,] Lth makes the bgAv and the Abgv to be one, asserting them to be of aquatic birds; but in my opinion, the former is different from the latter: as to the latter, it is a well-known kind of aquatic bird, so called because it is of the colour termed bugovap, i. e. white inclining to xuDorap [explained above, voce bugovapN]: but as to the bgAv, it is any bird that is not one of prey: and the word is said to be a coll. gen. n., signifying the class of birds that are objects of prey: (TA:) ISk says that the bagaAv is a bird of a colour inclining to that of dust, (S, Msb, *) a little less than the raxamap [or vultur percnopterus], (S,) or less than the rxmp, (Msb,) slow in flight: (S, Msb:) but IB says that this is a mistake in two points of view; first, because bgAv is a [coll.] gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, like as is that of HamaAmN; and secondly, because it applies to the class of birds that do not prey; but the ↓ A^abogav is a bird of the colour of dust, and this may be a bird of prey, and it may be not a bird of prey: (TA:) AZ says that bgAv signifies the [species of vulture called] raxam; and the n. un. is with p others, the young ones of the rxm and birds of the crowkind: or [birds] like the [hawks called] sawaAdiq [pl. of sawodaqN], not predaceous: in the T, it is said to be [a kind of bird] like the [hawk called] baA$aq, that does not prey upon any other bird: (TA:) or bigaAvN and bugaAvN (ISd, K) and bagaAvN (K) signify the worst [or most ignoble] of birds, (ISd, K, [the latter giving this as a second and distinct signification,]) and such as do not prey: (ISd, TA:) Fr says, bagaAvu AlT~ayori signifies the worst of birds, and such as do not prey; and bugaAvN and bigaAvN are dial. vars.: (S:) the pl. is bigovaAnN, (Sb, T, S, Msb, K,) accord. to those who make bgAv a sing., (Yoo, S, Msb, TA,) or accord. to those who make the sing. to be with p; (T, TA;) or those who apply bagaAvapN [as a n. un.] to the male and the female make bagaAvN to be pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.]; (Yoo, S, Msb;) as is done in the case of naEaAmapN and naEaAmN: (Yoo, S:) ISd says that bagaAvapN, with fet-h, is the n. un., applied alike to the male and the female: (TA:) [and Fei says,] it is not allowable to pronounce this with damm or with kesr to the first letter: (Msb:) but Yoo asserts both of these forms to be used: (AZ, TA:) and bgAvp is said to signify a weak bird. (TA.) It is said in a prov., A_in~a AlbagaAva biA^aroDinaA yasotanosiru (S, A, Msb, K *) Verily the bgAv in our land becomes [like] a vulture, or become [like] vultures: (Msb:) applied to the low person who becomes of high rank: (A:) meaning (tropical:) the weak in our land becomes strong: (Msb:) or he who makes himself our neighbour becomes mighty, strong, or of high rank, by our means, (S, K, TA,) acquiring the might, or strength, of the vulture, after having been low, or mean, in condition. (TA.)

bagiyvN bgyv gyv
Wheat (HinoTapN and TaEaAmN [both of which signify the same, though the latter, q. v., has a a larger application,]) adulterated by being mixed with barley; (Th, K;) as also galiyvN and lagiyvN. (Th, TA.)
bugayovaA='u bgyvA=' [dim. of bagovaA='u fem. of A^abogavu, q. v.,] The place of the Haqiybap [q. v.] in a camel. (K.) [So called because of its colour, produced by chafing.]

A^abogavu *
Of a white colour inclining to xuDorap [which here app. means a dark, or ashy, dustcolour]: (T:) [or of a colour resembling that of ashes: (see 1:)] or dust-coloured: (A:) or of a colour near to that of dust: (S:) an epithet, like A^aHomaru: [fem. bagovaA='u: and] pl. bugovN: and sometimes, when used as a subst., it has for pl. A^abaAgivu. (IB, TA.) You say TaAy^irN A^abogavu A bird of the colour above described: (T, S:) whether it be a bird of prey or not: see bagaAvN in two places: (IB, TA:) and SaqorN A^abogavu [a hawk of that colour.]; (ISh, A;) as well as A^aHowaY and A^aboyaDu; i. e., that wherewith men take game. (ISh, TA.) bagovaA='u applied to sheep or goats, (S, K,) or, as in some lexicons, to sheep, (TA,) is like raqoTaA='u; (S, K;) [Black speckled with white; or the reverse;] or in which are blackness and whiteness, with predominance of the latter colour: (TA:) or $aApN bagovaA='u and ganamN bugovN signify a sheep or goat, and sheep or goats, in which are blackness and whiteness. (A.) ― -b2- Also, [as a subst.,] A certain bird, (K, TA,) dustcoloured, in truth different from the bagaAv, as shown above: see the latter word: (TA:) pl. bugovN and A^abaAgivu. (T, TA.) You say, huwa mino A^abaAgivi AlT~ayori [He is of the birds thus called]. (A.) ― -b3- And AlA^abogavu signifies The lion; (TS, K;) because he is of the colour termed bugovapN. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlbagovaA='u (tropical:) The medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men or people; or of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff, thereof; (S, A, K;) the commonalty, or vulgar, and collective body, of the people. (S.) One says, xaraja falaAnN fiY AlbagovaA='i and AlgavoraA='i (tropical:) Such a one went forth among the medley, &c., of the people. (A.) And daxalonaA fiY AlbagovaA='i (tropical:) We entered among the commonalty, or vulgar, and the collective body, of the people. (S.)

1 baga$ati Als~amaA='u * , aor.
baga$a , (S, K,) inf. n. bago$N, (S,) The sky rained a rain such as is termed bago$apN, q. v. (S, K.) ― -b2- bugi$atu AlA^aroDu The land was watered by a rain such as is termed bago$apN, (S,) or bago$N. (TA.)
bago$N * : see what next follows.

bago$apN *
A weak shower of rain; (S, K:) above what is called Ta$~ap: (S:) or weak rain, small in its drops; as also ↓ bago$N [originally an inf. n.]: or both signify a cloud that pours forth its rain in one shower: As says that the lightest and weakest of rain is that called Tal~; then, the ra*aA*; then, the bago$: the dim. of the last is bugayo$N. (TA.)

maTarN baAgi$N *
Weak rain. (S, K.)

A^aroDN maboguw$apN *
Land watered by a rain such as is termed bago$apN, (S,) or bago$N. (TA.)

1 baguDa bgD gD ; (S, A, Msb, K;) and bagaDa; aor. [of
both]
baguDa ; and bagiDa, aor.
bagaDa ; (K;) inf. n. bafaADapN, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. of the first; (TA;) He, or it, (a man, S, or a thing, Msb,) was, or became, hateful, odious, or an object of hatred. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- baguDa jad~uhu (tropical:) His fortune, or good fortune, fell; syn. Eavara. (A.) And baguDa jad~uka, (L, K, TA,) or bagaDa, (as in one copy of the K,) or bagiDa, (as in the CK,) (tropical:) May thy fortune, or good fortune, fall: syn. taEasa, (K, TA,) and Eavara: (TA:) a phrase ascribed by IB to the people of El-Yemen. (TA.) -A2- See also 4, in three places.

2 bg~Dhu A@ll~`hu A_ilaY Aln~aAsi * , (S, TA,) or liln~aAsi, (Msb,) [but this I think doubtful, from what is said in explanation of the verb of wonder, (see 4,)] inf. n. tabogiyDN, (S, K,) God rendered him hateful, odious, or an object of hatred, to men; (S, Msb; *) tabogiyDN being the contr. of taHobiybN: (K:) or very hateful or odious. (TA.) You say also, Hub~iba A_ilaY~a zayodN wa bug~iDa A_ilaY~a EamorNw [Zeyd was rendered an object of love to me, and 'Amr was rendered an object of hatred, or of much hatred, to me]. (A, TA.)

3 baAgaDotuhu bAgD bAgDth bAgDtp , inf. n. mubaAgaDapN, I rendered him [hatred, or] vehement hatred, reciprocally. (A, * TA.) You say also, bayonahumaA mubaAgaDapN [Between them two is reciprocal hatred, or vehement hatred]. (A.)

4 AbgDhu A^bgD A^bgDh AbgDh AbgDp bgD , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ibogaADN, (Msb,) He hated him. (S, A, * Msb, * K.) It is said that ↓ bagaDahu is not allowable: (Msb:) or yaboguDuniY is a bad form; (AHát, K;) used by the lower class; and sanctioned by Th only; for he explains qaAliyna, as occurring in the Kur [xxvi. 168], by baAgiDiyna, which shows that he held bagaDa to be a dial. var.; for otherwise he would have said mubogiDiyna: (AHát:) but the epithet baguwDN affords a strong evidence in favour of the opinion of Th here mentioned; for faEuwlN is mostly from faAEilN, not from mufoEilN. (TA.) -A2- maA A^abogaDahu A_ilaY~a, (S,) or liY, (K,) is [said to be] anomalous; (S, K;) because the verb of wonder is not regularly formed from a verb of the measure A^afoEala; but this is not anomalous; for it is from bagaDa fulaAnN A_ilaY~a [“ such a one was, or became, hateful, or odious, to me: ” mA AbgDh AlY~ signifying How hateful, or odious, is he to me! but mA AbgDh liY, How he hates me! for] the lexicologists and grammarians relate that maA A^abogaDaniY lahu is said when thou hatest him; and mA AbgDnY A_ilayohi, when he hates thee: (IB:) ISd says, on the authority of Sb, that mA AbgDnY lh means that thou art an object of hatred (mubogaDN [so in the TA, but this is evidently a mistake for mubogiDN, a hater,]) to him; and mA AbgDh AlY~, that he is an object of hatred with thee, or in thine estimation. (TA.) -A3- A^anoEama A@ll~`hu bika EayonFA wa A^abogaDa biEaduw~ika EayonFA, (so in the A, and the latter verb thus in the JK and in the L,) or the former verb is naEima, (L, K,) and the latter ↓ bagaDa, (K, TA,) like naSara, (TA,) or ↓ bagiDa, (CK,) is a form of imprecation (TA) (tropical:) [app. meaning May God make thine eye to be refreshed by the sight of him whom thou lovest, and make the eye of thine enemy to be pained by the sight of him whom he hateth: or may God make an eye to be refreshed by the sight of thee, and make an eye to be affected with hatred by the sight of thine enemy].

5 tbg~D A^bgD bgD tbgD
He manifested, or showed, hatred; or he became, or made himself, an object of hatred; contr. of taHab~aba. (K.) You say, taHab~aba liY fulaAnN wa tabag~aDa liY A^axuwhu [Such a one manifested love to me, or made himself an object of love to me, and his brother manifested hatred to me, or made himself an object of hatred to me]. (A, TA.)

6 tbAgD Alqawomu tbAgD Alqwm
The company of men hated one another: (Msb:) tabaAguDN is the contr. of taHaAbubN. (S, K.) You say, maA raA^ayotu A^a$ad~a tabaAguDFA minohumaA [I have not seen any more vehement in mutual hatred than they two]. (A, TA.)

bugoDN bgD gD
Hatred; contr. of Hub~u: (S, A, K:) a subst. from A^abogaDahu. (Msb.)

bigoDapN bgD bgDh bgDp gD gDp
Vehement hatred; as also ↓ bagoDaA='u, (S, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ bagaADapN [but see 1]. (TA.) -A2- See also bagiyDN.
bagoDaA='u bgDA=' : see what next precedes.
baguwDN bgwD : see what next follows.

bagiyDN bgyD gyD
Hateful; odious; and object of hatred: (S, A, Msb, * K:) hated; as also ↓ baguwDN (TA) and ↓ mubogaDN: (Msb, * TA:) pl. of the first, bugaDaA='u. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Some say that it has also the contr. signification of Hating; i. q. ↓ mubogiDN: (TA:) and Skr explains ↓ bigoDapN as signifying people hating thee. (L, TA. *)
bagaADapN bgADh bgADp gAD : see bigoDapN.
mubogaDN mbgD : see bagiyDN.
mubogiDN mbgD : see bagiyDN.
mabogaDapN mbgD mbgDh mbgDp [A cause of hatred: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]. (A.)

1 bagula bgl gl , aor.
bagula , inf. n. buguwlapN, said of a man, i. q. tabal~ada [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He affected stupidity, dulness, or want of intelligence; or he became submissive, and humble; &c.]. (TA.) [See also 2.] -A2- bagalahumo: see 2.

2 tabogiylN tbgyl , the inf. n., signifies (assumed tropical:) The being big, thick, or rude, and hard, strong, or sturdy, in body; or said of the body: and hence, accord. to some, is derived ↓ bagolN. (TA.) ― -b2- bg~l, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He was impotent and weak, or languid, and fatigued, (JK, K, TA,) in going, or pace. (TA.) ― -b3- bg~lt AlA_ibilu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (tropical:) The camels went a pace between that termed hamojalap and that termed Eanaq: (S, * K, TA:) and hence ↓ bagolN is derived accord. to IDrd: (TA:) or they went in a certain manner, with wide step: (JK:) [see also 5:] or the inf. n. signifies the going in a gentle manner: and one says, A^aEoyaA fabag~ala, i. e. [he was fatigued, so] he went an easy, but a quick, pace; syn. hamolaja. (TA.) -A2- bag~alahumo, (inf. n. as above, TA,) (tropical:) He made their children to be base-born, or ignoble, (K, TA,) by marrying among them; (IDrd, TA;) as also ↓ bagalahumo, aor.
bagala : (K:) from bagolN; because the bgl [or mule] is unable to equal the heat, or course, of the horse. (TA.)

5 tbg~l tbgl
He (a camel) became like the bagol [or mule] in the width of his step. (TA.) [See also 2.]

bagolN bgl gl The mule; i. e. the animal generated between the he-ass and the mare [or sometimes between the horse and the she-ass]; (TA;) also called ↓ bag~aAlN; so in a verse of Jereer: (S, Sgh:) pl. A^abogalN [a pl. of pauc.] (JK) and A^abogaAlN, [also] a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and bigaAlN, (JK, S, Msb, K,) a pl. of mult.; (Msb;) and quasi-pl. n. ↓ maboguwlaA='u, (K,) meaning a number of mules (bigaAl) together: (JK, * S:) the female is termed bagolapN; (S, Msb, K;) pl. bagalaAtN and bigaAlN. (Msb.) See 2, in two places. You say TariyqN fiyhi A^abowaAlu AlbigaAli [A road in which is the urine of mules]; meaning (assumed tropical:) a difficult road. (TA.) And fulaAnapu A^aEoqaru mino bagolapK [Such a woman is more barren than a she-mule]. (TA.) And Albagolu nagolN wa huwa lahu A^aholN [The mule is a bastard, and he is a relation to him]; meaning (assumed tropical:) he is a bastard. (TA.) And as the mule suggests the idea of evil disposition, or perverseness, and roughness, you say, in describing him who is low, or ignoble, huwa bagolN nagolN (assumed tropical:) [he is a mule, a bastard]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) The people of Egypt say, Ai$otaraY fulaAnN bagolapF HasonaA='a, meaning (tropical:) [Such a one bought a beautiful] female slave: and fiY bayoti baniY fulaAnK bigaAlN [(tropical:) In the house of the sons of such a one are slaves, or female slaves]: and Ai$otarayotu mino bigaAli Alyamano wa l`kino bigaAliY Alv~amano [(tropical:) I bought of the slaves, or female slaves, of El-Yemen, but for a high price]. (TA.)

bag~aAlN bgAl bgl gAl gAly [n. un. of ↓ bag~aAlapN, which is a coll. gen. n., like Ham~aArapN and jam~aAlapN, but explained by Freytag as meaning “ he who possesses many mules; ”] An owner, or attendant, (Sb, S,) of mules, (Sb, TA,) or of the mule. (S.) -A2- See also bagolN, with which it is syn.
bag~aAlapN bgAl bgAlh bgAlp bgl gAl : see what next precedes.

entryFree.key: huwa mina Alv~awori A^abogalu wa mina AlHimaAri A^avoqalu

div2.entryFree: huwa mina Alv~awori A^abogalu wa mina AlHimaAri A^avoqalu * (assumed tropical:) [He is more mulish than the bull, and more heavy, or sluggish, than the ass]. (TA.)
maboguwlaA='u mbgwlA=' : see bagolN.

1 bagamato bgmt , aor.
bagima (S, K) and
bagama and
baguma , (K,) inf. n. bugaAmN (JK, S, K) and buguwmN; (JK, K;) and ↓ tbg~mt; (K;) She (a gazelle) uttered a cry: (S:) or uttered her softest, or gentlest, cry (JK, K) to her young one: (K:) and sometimes it is said of a [wild] cow: (TA:) so too bagama said of a male gazelle: and the verb is also used transitively, said of a female gazelle uttering this cry to her young one. (JK.) Also, (S, K,) ↓ both verbs, (K,) She (a camel) uttered a cry without clearness: (S:) or uttered a broken, or an interrupted, not a prolonged, yearning cry, to, or for,
her young one: (K:) or uttered a weak cry, below that [grumbling cry] which is termed rugaA='. (Ham p. 233.) [See an ex. in a verse of Dhu-rRummeh cited voce A_il~aA.] And bagama and ↓ tbg~m said of the vayotal and A_iy~al and waEil, [all of which words are said to signify the mountain goat,] He uttered a cry. (K.) ― -b2- bagamahu, (S, K,) and bagama lahu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke to him obscurely, not expressing clearly to him the meaning of his speech to him; (S, K;) taken from the bugaAm of the she-camel; because it is a cry not uttered clearly. (TA.)

3 baAogama
bAgmhu, (K,) inf. n. mubaAgamapN, (S,) (tropical:) He talked with him with a soft, or gentle, voice: (S, K, TA:) or AlmubaAgamapN is like AlmunaAgamapu, and means the speaking [with another] faintly; taken from the bugaAm [see 1] of the gazelle and the she-camel: (Ham p. 233:) or the holding amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with another, with a soft, or gentle, voice. (TA.)
5 tabag~ama see 1, in three places.

6 tabaAogama [tabaAgamato They (gazelles) uttered cries, or their softest or gentlest cries, one to another.] One says, mararotu birawoDapK tatabaAgamu fiyhaA AlZ~ibaA='u [I passed by a meadow in which the gazelles were uttering cries, &c., one to another]: and bigizolaAnK yatabaAgamona [by gazelles uttering cries, &c., one to another]. (TA.)

bugomapN bgmh bgmp gm gmp
A thing like the qilaAdap, [a necklace,] with which women ornament themselves. (TA.) [But this is apparently post-classical, from the Turkish buwgomaqo. In the present day, it is applied to A necklace of pearls.]
bugaAmN bgAm gAm The crying, or cry, of the female gazelle, and of the she-camel, as explained above: see 1. (S.)
baguwmN bgwm A female gazelle uttering, or that utters, the cry termed bugaAm. (S, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A woman having a soft, or gentle, voice. (JK, TA.)

maboguwmN mbgwm A young gazelle, and a young camel, to which the cry termed bugaAm is addressed by its mother. (JK.) ― -b2- One says, also, bugaAmN maboguwmN [A cry &c. uttered]; like as one says, qawolN maquwlN. (TA.)
1 bagaA Al$~aYo'a * , inf. n. bagowN, He looked at the thing [to see] how it was; (K;) as also bagaY, (K in art. bgY,) inf. n. bagoYN. (TA in that art.)

1 bagaY bgY bgy gy , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
bagiYa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. bugaA='N, (S, Mgh, K, &c.,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is bagoYN, (Msb,) [but, if this be correct, the former is generally used for the latter,] and bugFY, (Lh, K,) but the first is better known, and is the chaste form, and some say, bigFY, (TA,) and bugoyapN and bigoyapN, (K,) accord. to Th, but others hold these two to be simple substs., and some mention also bagoyapN, with fet-h, (TA,) and bugaAyapN, (As, S, TA,) He sought; sought for, or after; sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find, and take, or get; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) a stray-beast, (As, S, TA,) or any other thing, (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K, * TA,) good or evil; (Lh, TA;) as also ↓ AbtgY and ↓ tbg~Y (S, Msb, K) and ↓ AstbgY: (K:) or ↓ AbtgY signifies he sought, &c., diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and bagaY signifies also he loved, or affected, a thing: (MF, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the seeking to exceed the just bounds in respect of that which one aims at, or endeavours after, whether one actually exceed or do not; and sometimes it is considered in relation to quantity; and sometimes, in relation to quality. (TA.) You say, bagaAhu bi$ar~K [He sought him with an evil purpose; or sought to do him evil]. (S and K in art. Eqb.) ― -b2- And bagaAhu He sought, &c., a thing for him; like bagaY lahu. (Lh, Mgh, * K. *) You say, bagaAhu Al$~aYo'a He sought, &c., the thing for him; (S, K;) as also Al$~aYo'a ↓ AbgAhu: (K:) thus you say, AiboginiY ka*aA or k*A ↓ A^aboginiY and Aiboga liY k*A Seek thou for me such a thing; (TA;) and DaAl~atiY ↓ A^aboginiY Seek thou for me my stray-beast: (Mgh:) or Al$~aY'a ↓ AbgAhu signifies He aided, or assisted, him to seek the thing: (Ks, K:) or ka*aA ↓ A^aboginiY signifies Seek thou for me such a thing; and also Aid thou me to seek such a thing. (JK.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 47], yaboguwnakumu Alfitonapa They seek, or desire, for you discord, or dissension; or they seeking, &c.: and in the same [iii. 94], taboguwnahaA EiwajFA Ye seek, or desire, for it, namely, the way [of God], crookedness; or ye seeking, &c.: the first objective complement of the verb being in the accus. case because of the suppression of the preposition l. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] bagaAniY daA='F It procured to me disease; it caused disease to befall me. (Ham p. 794.) And A_in~ahu la*uw bugaAyapK Verily he is one who makes much gain: (JK, K:) but in the M, *uw bugaAyapK lilokasobi, meaning a seeker of gain. (TA.) And maAbugiYa lahu Good was not appointed to betide him. (TA.) ― -b4- bagaY EalaY A^axiyhi, inf. n. bagoYN, He envied his brother; he wished that a blessing, or cause of happiness, or an excellence, might become transferred from his brother to himself: so says Lh, who holds this to be the primary signification of the verb. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlbagoYu EiqaAlu Aln~aSori [Envy is the shackle of aid from God against an enemy or a wrongdoer]. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence, (Lh, TA,) bagoYN signifies The acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (Lh, S, TA;) because the envier so acts towards the envied; his endeavour being to cause, by guile, the blessing of God upon him to depart from him: (Lh, TA:) or the seeking, or endeavouring, to act corruptly, wrongly, or unjustly: (Az, TA:) or the exceeding the due bounds, or just limits, in any way: (S:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of two kinds: one of these is approved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of equity to exercise beneficence, and beyond the bounds of obligatory duties to do what is not obligatory: the other is disapproved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of that which is true, or right, to do that which is false, or wrong, or to do acts of a doubtful nature: but in most instances it is that which is disapprove. (TA.) You say, bagaY Ealayohi, (S, K,) and bgY EalaY Aln~aAsi, (Az, Msb,) aor.
bagiYa , (K,) inf. n. bagoYN, (Msb, K,) He exalted himself against him, or above him; overpowered, or oppressed, him; (Fr, S, K;) acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards him; and deviated from the right way: (K:) and he acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards men, or the people, (Az, Msb,) and sought to annoy them, or hurt them. (Az, TA.) Lh mentions, on the authority of Ks, the saying, maA liY walilobagi baEoDikumo EalaY baEoDK [What have I to do with wrongful conduct, the wrongful conduct of one of you towards another?], for walilobagoYi; ISd thinks, because of the difficulty found in pronouncing the kesreh after the Y. (TA.) bagaY also signifies He occupied himself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct: [accord. to Fei,] from the same verb [in a sense to be mentioned below,] said of a wound. (Msb.) Also, aor.
bagiYa , (TA,) inf. n. bagoYN, (Az, TA,) He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently: (Az, TA:) because he who does so passes beyond the bounds of his proper station to a station that does not belong to him. (TA.) ― -b6- And [hence,] bagaY fiY mi$yatihi, (K,) inf. n. bagoYN, (TA,) He [app. a horse, and perhaps a man also,] was proud, or self-conceited, and quick, in his gait: (K:) or bagoYN in a horse, (S, TA,) or in the running of a horse, (JK, TA,) is the being proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness. (JK, S, TA.) ― -b7- And bagati Als~amaA='u, (S, K,) inf. n. bagoYN, (TA,) The sky rained vehemently: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or exceeded, in rain, the limit of what was wanted. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And bagaY AlwaAdiY The valley flowed with water reaching to a place to which it had not reached before. (S, TA.) ― -b8- bagato, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said of a woman, (Th, IKh, S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) or of a female slave, (so in other copies of the K,) but it is not restricted to the latter, (TA,) aor.
bagiYa , (JK, Msb,) inf. n. bigaA='N, (IKh, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or bagoYN, (ISd, K,) [but the former, only, is commonly known,] She committed fornication, or adultery; she prostituted herself; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because she who does so transgresses her proper bounds; (TA;) as also ↓ baAgato, (IKh, S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. bigaA='N (IKh, K) and mubaAgaApN, (K,) said of a female slave: (Msb:) or mbAgAp signifies the committing fornication, or adultery, with another. (KL.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 33], walaA tukorihuw fatayaAtikumo EalaY AlbigaA='i [And compel not ye your young women to prostitute themselves]. (Mgh.) And you say, ↓ xarajati AlmaroA^apu tubaAgiY [The woman went forth for prostituting herself]. (S.) Accord. to the Jema etTefáreek, bigaA='N signifies The knowing of a woman's committing fornication or adultery, or prostituting herself, and approving, or being content: but this, if correct, is an amplification in speech. (Mgh.) ― -b9- bagaY AljuroHu, (JK, S, Msb,) aor.
bagaYa , inf. n. bagoYN, (JK,) The wound swelled, (S,) and became in a corrupt state, (JK, S, Msb,) and produced thick
purulent matter. (JK.) And baraA^a juroHuhu EalaY bagoYK His wound healed having somewhat of corruption in it. (S.) ― -b10- bagaY, (K,) aor.
bagiYa , inf. n. bagoYN, (TA,) also signifies He lied; said what was untrue. (K.)

maA nabogiY mA nbgY mA nbgy , in the Kur [xii. 65], is said to mean We do not lie: and we do not act wrongfully: or it may mean what do we seek, or desire? (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. bagoYN, (TA,) He looked at a thing [to see] how it was; (K;) and so bagaA, inf. n. bagowN: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) ― -b3- And, (K,) with the same inf. n., (TA,) He looked, watched, or waited, for a person or thing. (Kr, K.)

3 baAogaYa see 1, latter part, in two places. -A2- Lh mentions the saying, addressed to a pretty woman, A_in~aki lajamiylapN walaA tubaAgiY, as meaning Verily thou art pretty, and mayest thou not be smitten by the [evil] eye: (TA in this art.:) but accord. to some, the verb in this instance belongs to art. bwg or art. byg. (TA in art. bwg.)

4 A^abogaYa see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AbgAhu Al$~aYo'a also signifies He made him, or caused him, to seek the thing; to seek for it, or after it; to seek, or desire, or endeavour, to find, and take, or get, it. (S.)
5 tabag~aYa see 1, first sentence.

6 tabaAgawoA tbAgwA
They acted wrong fully, injuriously, or tyrannically, one towards another; exalted themselves, one against, or above, another; overpowered, or oppressed, one another. (S, TA.)

7 AnbgY A^nbg A^nbgY A^nbgy A^nbgyy AnbgY Anbgy {nbgY is said in the S to be quasi-pass. of bagayotuhu, like as Ainokasara is of kasarotuhu; and Esh-Shiháb says of the aor. that it is quasi-pass. of bagaAhu, aor. yabogiyhi, in the sense of Talabahu: (TA:) [Fei says,] it has been asserted that AnbgY is quasi-pass. of bagaY; but a verb of the measure AnfEl is not used as a quasi-pass. unless it implies effort, and the consequence of an action, as in the case of kasarotuhu, of which the quasi-pass. is Ainokasara; which AnbgY does not: some, however, allow its being thus used: (Msb:) accord. to Zj, it is as though it were syn. with AinoTalaba, as quasi-pass. of Talaba, and means It was, or became, suitable, fit, meet, or proper; (Zj, TA;) [or right, and allowable; and good: or very requisite: (see explanations of exs. following:) or it behooved: and] it was, or became, facilitated, or easy; (Er-Rághib, K;) and practicable, or manageable. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Accord. to some, this verb is not used in the pret. tense, but only in the aor.: it is reckoned among verbs imperfectly inflected: (Msb, TA:) but the pret. is mentioned by AZ and Sb and Zj, and by ElKhattábee on the authority of Ks; and was often used by Esh-Sháfi'ee: it is, however, very rare. (TA.) You say, yanobagiY laka A^ano tafoEala ka*aA [It is suitable to thee, or is fit, meet, or proper, &c., for thee, or it behooveth thee, that thou shouldst do such a thing]. (S, TA.) And, accord. to Zj, AinobagaY lifulaAnK A^ano yafoEala, as meaning It was, or became, suitable to such a one, or fit, meet, or proper, for him, that he should do, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) And maA yanobagiY laka A^ano tafoEala h`*aA, (Lh, K,) and ↓ mA yubotagaY, (K, TA,) with fet-h to the g, (TA,) and mA A@nobagaY, and ↓ mA A@botugiYa; (Lh, K;) of which four phrases, the first is given by Lh as explanatory of the third and fourth, and means, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, It is not right, proper, fit, or meet, nor allowable, for thee that thou shouldst do this, or to do this; and it is not good for thee &c.; but he adds that only the aor. has been heard from the Arabs in this sense. (TA.) And yanobagiY A^ano yakuwna ka*aA It is very requisite that it should be so, or that such a thing ought be; [or it ought to be so, or such a thing ought to be; it behooves that it should be so, or such a thing behooves;] it is not well that such a thing should be neglected, or left undone. (Msb.) And Ks is related to have heard, from the Arabs, the phrase, maA yanobagiY A^ano yakuwna ka*aA, meaning It is not right that it should be so, or that such a thing should be: or it is not good &c. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxvi. 69], wamaA Eal~amonaAhu Al$~iEora wamaA yanobagiY lahu, i. e. [And we have not taught him poetry, or versification], nor is it right, proper, fit, or meet, for him: (Bd:) or nor is it easy to him, (Bd, Jel, Er-Rághib,) or practicable to him. (Bd, Er-Rághib.)
8 A_ibotagaYa see 1, first sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 7, in two places.

10 A_isotabogaYa see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- You say also, AstbgY Alqawoma fabagawohu and bagawoA lahu [He asked the people, or company of men, to seek a thing for him, and they sought it for him]. (Lh, K.)

bagoYN bgY bgy gy [originally an inf. n. (see 1)] Much of rain; or much rain: in [some of] the copies of the K, AlbTr is erroneously put for AlmTr: (TA:) [and in some, AlbagiY~u for AlbagoYu: in a MS. copy, I find AlbagiY~u Alkaviyru mina AlmaTari: and in the CK, AlbagiY~u Alkaviyoru mn Aln~aZari:] or bagoYu Als~amaA='i signifies the main portion, (As, S,) or the vehemence, and the main portion, (Lh, JK, TA,) of the rain of the sky. (As, Lh, JK, S, TA.) Hence the saying, dafaEonaA bagoYa Als~amaA='i xalofanaA (As, S, TA) or Ean~aA (Lh, TA) [lit. We drove away the main portion, or the vehemence, and the main portion, of the rain of the sky behind us or from us; meaning it was driven away behind us or from us, or it departed; as is shown in art. dfE].
bugoyapN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp : see what next follows.

bigoyapN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp and ↓ bugoyapN (JK, S, Msb, K) and ↓ bagiy~apN (K) A thing sought; (JK, K;) as also ↓ bagaAyapN [originally an inf. n. (see 1)]: (JK:) or a thing wanted, needed, or required; an object of want or need; a want, or needful or requisite thing or affair: (S, Msb:) as in the saying, liY fiYbaniY fulaAnK bagoyapN and bugoyapN [I have among the sons of such a one an object of want]: (S:) or the first signifies a state that one seeks; and the second, a thing itself that one wants: (As, S, Msb: *) and the first, (JK,) or third, (K,) signifies also a stray beast that is sought: (JK, K:) the pl. of the second is bugFY. (JK.) Airotad~ato EalaY fulaAnK bigoyatuhu [The thing that he sought was refused to such a one] is said of one who finds not what he seeks. (TA.).
baguw~N bgw : see what next follows.

bagiY~N bgY bgy gy , accord. to some, of the measure faEiylN; accord. to others, of the measure faEuwlN, originally baguwYN; [if of the former, originally meaning “ sought; ” and if of the latter, originally meaning “ seeking; ”] and therefore [in either case] not admitting the affix p: (TA:) A fornicatress, an adulteress, or a prostitute; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ baguw~N [of the measure faEuwlN, and therefore anomalous, like nahuw~N]: (M, K:) bagiY~N is not applied to a man, (Lh, Msb,) nor bagiy~apN to a woman: (Lh, TA:) pl. bagaAyaA. (S, Mgh, Msb.) [See an ex. voce mahorN.] ― -b2- Also A female slave, (JK, S, K,) whether she be a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute or not; (TA;) not meant to imply revilement, though originally applied to female slaves because of their prostitution of themselves: (S:) or a free woman who is a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute: so in the K: but correctly, or a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute, whether free or a slave: (TA:) and a female singer, though chaste; because of fornication's being originally attributable to such a person: (Msb:) pl. as above. (JK, S, TA.) One says, qaAmato EalaY ruw^usihimu AlbagaAyaA [The female slaves stood over their heads]. (S.) ― -b3- bagaAyaA also signifies The scouts, or companies of scouts, that precede an army: (S, K, TA:) but the sing. of this is ↓ bagiy~apN. (TA.)
bagiy~apN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp : see bigoyapN. -A2- Also, pl. bagaAyaA: see bagiY~N, last sentence.
bugaAyapN bgAyh bgAyp gAyp : see bigoyapN.

baAgK bAg bAgy
Seeking; seeking for, or after; seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find, and take, or get: pl. bugaApN and bugoyaAnN (K) and bug~aA='N. (TA: [there mentioned as a pl., but not said to be of baAgK, nor explained.]) baAgK wahaAdK, lit. A seeker of [stray] camels and a guide of the way, mentioned in a trad. respecting the Hijreh (as said by A booBekr to a man who asked him “ Who are ye? ”), alludes to the seeking of religion and the guiding from error. (TA.) One says, far~iquwA lih`*ihi AlA_ibili bugoyaAnFA yuDib~uwna lahaA, i. e. [Disperse ye, for these camels, seekers] to scatter themselves in search thereof. (S.) ― -b2- Acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, [&c.,] towards others: pl. bugaApN. (Msb. [See 1.]) gayora baAgK, in the Kur ii. 168, [&c.,] means Not being a revolter from the Muslims, (Jel,) or, against the Imám: (TA:) or it means not desiring to eat for the sake of enjoyment: or not seeking to exceed the limit of his want: (Az, TA:) or not seeking what he should not seek. (Er-Rághib, TA.) fiy^apN baAgiyahN A company of men revolting from the just Imám. (K.) firoqapN baAgiyapN A party occupying itself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct. (Msb.) ― -b3- A camel that does not impregnate, or get with young. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A horse that is proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness: (JK, Ham p. 210:) [but] Kh disallows its being thus used. (S.) -A2- [The pl.] bugoyaAnN also signifies What the sportsman, or hunter, seeks, of game, or objects of the chase. (JK.) mabogFY [A place where a thing is sought: and
hence, a way, or manner, in which a thing is, or should be, sought]: this is meant in the saying, ↓ bagayotu AlmaAla mino mabogaAtihi [I sought wealth by the way, or manner, whereby it should be sought]; like as maA^otFY is meant in the saying, A^atayotu AlA^amora mino maA^otaAtihi. (S.)
mabogaApN mbgAh mbgAp mbgY : see what next precedes.
AlmubotagiY AlmbtgY Almbtgy mbtgY , (K,) or, as in the Tekmileh, Almutabag~iY, (TA,) The lion: (K:) because he is always seeking prey. (TA.)
Almutabag~iY AlmtbgY Almtbgy : see what next precedes.

1 baq~a bq , (JK, M,) aor. yabiq~u; and baq~a, [first pers. baqiqotu,] aor. yabaq~u [in the TA yabuq~u, which, being anomalous, is probably a mistake,] inf. n. baq~N and baqaqN [which is of the latter verb accord. to analogy] and baqiyqN; (M;) He spoke, or talked, much; was, or became, loquacious; (JK, M, TA;) as also ↓ Abq~ (JK, S, M, TA) and ↓ baqobaqa. (M, TA.) And baq~a kalaAmFA [in which case the aor., accord. to rule, unless the noun be a specificative, is yabuq~u,] and baq~a bikalaAmK [He was, or became, profuse in speech]. (M.) And baq~a EalaY Alqawomi, (Zj, K,) or baq~a kalaAmahu, (M,) inf. n. baq~N and baqaAqN, (K,) He spoke, or talked, much against the people, or company of men; (Zj, M, * K;) as also ↓ Abq~. (K.) Hence, (TA,) qado malaA^ota AlA^aroDa baqaAqFA [Thou hast filled the earth, or land, with much discoursing], said, in dispraise, to a voluminous writer. (M, TA.) ― -b2- baq~ato and ↓ Abq~t, said of a woman, She had many children: (JK, S, M, K:) or, as Sb says, baq~ato waladFA she brought forth many children. (M, TA.) ― -b3- baq~ati Als~amaA='u, (S, M, K,) and ↓ Abq~t, (M, TA,) The sky rained much, and consecutively, or uninterruptedly: (M, TA: *) or rained vehemently. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- baq~a, (M, K,) aor. yayaq~u, (M,) or yabiq~u, (TA,) inf. n. baq~N, (M, TA,) He gave largely, or amply: (IF, M, K, * TA:) in some of the copies of the K, AlEaZamap is erroneously put for AlEaTiy~ap. (TA.) And baq~a lanaA AlEaTaA='a He made the gift large, or ample, to us. (M.) ― -b5- baq~a maAlahu He distributed, or dispersed, or scattered, his property; (K;) as also ↓ bq~qhu. (JK, * K.) ― -b6- baq~a Alxabara, inf. n. baq~N, He spread, and sent forth, the news, or information. (M.) ― -b7- baq~a Al$~aYo'a, aor. yabuq~u, He put forth, or took forth, what was in the thing. (M, TA.) Hence, (M,) baq~a EiyaAbahu, (M, L, TA,) in the K, erroneously, EiyaAlahu, (TA,) He spread out (K, TA) his [receptacles of skin, or leather, termed] EyAb, and put forth, or took forth, what was in them. (TA.) ― -b8- He clave, slit, ripped, or rent, the thing. (JK.) So in the phrase baq~a AljiraAba [He slit, ripped, or rent, and opened, (see maboquwqN,) the bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions &c.]. (K.) ― -b9- baq~a, (IF, K,) inf. n. buquwqN, (TA,) said of a plant, [app. from its cleaving the earth,] It came forth. (IF, K, TA.) -A2- baq~a AlmakaAnu, [aor., app., yabiq~u, or yabaq~u,] The place abounded with baq~ [i. e. gnats, or musquitoes; or bugs]; as also ↓ Abq~. (M, TA.)
2 baq~a3a see 1.

4 A^aboqa3a see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Abq~ waladu fulaAnK, inf. n. A_iboqaAqN, The children of such a one multiplied; became many, or numerous. (TA.) ― -b3- A^abaq~ati Alganamu fiY Aljadobi, accord. to the K, (TA,) or ↓ Ainobaq~ati Alganamu fiY EaAmi jadobK, (JK, and thus in the O, TA,) The ewes, or she-goats, being lean, or meagre, brought forth [in drought, or scarcity, or in a year of drought or scarcity]. (JK, O, K, TA.) — Abq~ AlwaAdiY The valley put forth its plants, or herbage. (O, L, TA.) In the K, xaraja baqaAqupu is erroneously put for xaraja nabaAtuhu. (TA.) ― -b4- A^abaq~ahumo xayorFA, or $ar~FA, He did to him much, or ample, good, or evil. (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K.)
7 A_inobaqa3a see 4.

R. Q. 1 baqobaqa Alkuwzu bqbq Alkwz , (S, M,) biAlmaA='i, (M,) [inf. n. baqobaqapN, q. v. infrà,] The mug made a [guggling or gurgling] sound with the water [on being dipped into it or on one's pouring out from it]. (S, * M.) And baqobaqati Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled [so as to make a sound of bubbling]. (M.) ― -b2- See also 1. ― -b3- baqobaqa EalayonaA AlkalaAma i. q. far~aqahu [lit. He scattered speech (app. meaning he jabbered) at us, or against us: compare baq~a EalaY Alqawomi, or baq~a kalaAmahu, above]. (K.)

baq~N bq : see baqaAqN. ― -b2- baq~apN A woman having many children: (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K:) and ↓ mibaq~apN a woman that brings forth many children. (M, TA.) ― -b3- A^avarN baq~N [A trace, mark, track, impression, or the like,] that is plainly apparent, or conspicuous. (JK, TA.) -A2- Also, a pl. n.; (S, TA;) [or rather a coll. gen. n.;] sing., (S, TA,) or n. un., (JK, M, Msb, K, *) baq~apN; (JK, S, M, &c.;) Gnats, or musquitoes; syn. baEuwDN: (S, M, K: *) or large baEuwD: (JK, M, Msb:) the poet 'Abder-Rahmán Ibn-El-Hakam, cited by IB, speaks of their singing [or humming]. (TA.) yaA Eayona baq~apK [O eye of a gnat or musquito] denotes smallness of the person of him to whom it is said; or of the eye, as being likened to the eye of the gnat or musquito. (Har p. 619. [See an ex. voce Huzuq~N.]) ― -b2- Also, [in the M is here added “ it is said, ” but this implies uncertainty where none exists,] A kind of insect, [namely, bugs,] (M, K,) resembling the louse, (M, TA,) [but larger,] wide, (K,) red, and stinking, (M, K,) [and hence termed baq~N munotinN,] found in bed-frames, or couch-frames, and in walls, [and therefore termed baq~u Alxa$abi and baq~u AlHiyTaAni,] (M, TA,) called also banaAtu AlHaSiyri [from being found in mats]; (TA;) when one kills them, he smells [what resembles] the odour of bitter almonds proceeding from them. (M, TA.) ― -b3- $ajarapN Albaq~i [The elmtree]: see darodaArN.
baqaqapN bqqh bqqp : see what next follows.

baqaAqN bqAq qAq A man who speaks, or talks, much; loquacious; talkative; garrulous; a great talker; (S, K;) whether incorrectly or correctly; (M;) or such is termed ↓ baq~aAqN; (so written in a copy of the M;) as also ↓ baqaAqapN, (JK, S, K,) but this has a more intensive signification, (S, TA,) and ↓ mibaq~N, (M, Sgh, K,) and ↓ baqobaAqN, (JK, S, M,) or ↓ laqolaAqN baqobaAqN, (K,) and ↓ laq~N baq~N, (K,) which last occurs in a trad., but accord. to one recital it is laqFY baqFY, in which the former word signifies “ cast away, ” and the latter is an imitative sequent thereto: (TA:) ↓ baqaqapN, also, [app. pl. of baAq~N,] is syn. with varovaAruwna [great talkers, &c.]: (IAar, TA:) and baqaAqN [thus written without teshdeed] signifies a babbler; nonsensical, irrational, foolish, or delirious, in his talk; one who speaks confusedly and improperly; or who speaks, or talks, much and badly, or erroneously. (M.) [See also 1, of which it is an inf. n.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) n. un. with p, (JK, K,) A kind of clamorous bird: (JK, K:) but Sgh writes it [↓ baq~aAqN,] with teshdeed. (TA.) -A2- Also The worthless, or mean, or vile, articles of the furniture or utensils of a house or tent, or of household-goods. (M, K.)
baqaAqapN bqAq bqAqh bqAqp qAq : see baqaAqN.
baq~aAqN bqAq qAq : see baqaAqN, in two places.

baqobaqapN bqbq bqbqh bqbqp a word imitative of The [guggling or gurgling] sound of a mug (JK, S, K) [when dipped] in water, (JK, K,) and the like: (K:) and of a cooking-pot in its boiling. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
baqobaAqN bqbAq : see baqaAqN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The mouth. (K.)
mibaq~N mbq : see baqaAqN. ― -b2- mibaq~apN [its fem.]: see baq~N.

A^aroDN mabaq~apN *
A land abounding with baq~ [i. e. gnats, or musquitoes; or bugs]; (M, TA;) like as you say maboEaDapN. (TA in art. bED.)
jiraAbN maboquwqN jrAb mbqwq [A bag, or receptacle, for travel-ling-provisions &c.] opened: (JK:) or slit, ripped, or rent, and opened. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

1 baqara bqr qr , (S, K, &c.,) aor.
baqura , (JK, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or
baqara , (K,) [but this seems to be a mistake,] inf. n. baqorN, (S, Msb,) He slit; ripped; split; cut, or divided, lengthwise. (S, Msb, K, &c.) He slit, or ripped open, an animal's belly. (A, Mgh.) One says, AuboqurohaA Eano janiynihaA Rip thou open her [a camel's] belly so as to disclose her fœtus. (S.) [See baqiyrN.] ― -b2- He opened, or laid open. (S, A, Msb.) ― -b3- He widened; made wide, or ample. (S, K.) ― -b4- He opened, and widened, or made wide, a house, or tent. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- He opened and revealed to a person a story. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- baqara AlA^aroDa said of a hudohud [or hoopoe], It looked for the place of water and saw it: (K:) [or it clave the ground and discovered water:] occurring in a trad. respecting the hdhd of Solomon [mentioned in the Kur ch. xxvii.] (T.) ― -b7- baqara fiY baniY fulaAnK He knew the state, condition, case, or affair, of the sons of such a one, and examined, or inspected, them. (K.) ― -b8- baqara Eani AlEuluwmi He inquired, and searched
to the utmost, after sciences. (A.) ― -b9- baqara AlEiloma: see 5. -A2- baqira, aor.
baqara , He (a dog) became confounded, (S, K,) and stupified, (TA,) with joy, (K,) at seeing baqar, (S, K,) i. e., baqar AlwaHo$ [wild oxen, or wild bulls or cows]; (TA;) like as one says gazila meaning “ he sported, ” or “ played, ” “ at seeing a gazelle, ” or “ a young gazelle; ” as also ↓ bayoqara: or the former, he feared, so that he was astonished, amazed, or stupified, at seeing many baqar: (TA voce baHiza:) and ↓ the latter signifies also [simply] he became confounded, or perplexed: (IAar, TA:) and he doubted respecting a thing. (K.) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. baqarN (S, K) and baqorN; (K;) but Az says, El-Mundhiree has informed me that A Heyth disallowed baqorN, saying that it is accord. to analogy baqarN, as the verb is intrans.; (TA;) He (a man) became tired, or fatigued, (S, K,) so that he could hardly see; (K;) and he became weary, or jaded; (S, K;) as also ↓ bayoqara. (S, K. *)

2 bq~r Alqawomu maA Hawolahumo bqr Alqwm mA Hwlhm
The people dug the tract around them, and made wells. (As.)

5 tbq~r A^bqr bqr tbqr
It (a she-camel's belly) became ripped open; as also ↓ Abtqr and ↓ Anbqr. (TA.) ― -b2- It became open. (As.) ― -b3- And i. q. tws~E; (As, K;) as also ↓ tabayoqara. (K.) So in the phrase tbq~r fiY AlEilomi [He enlarged himself, or took a wide range, in science, or knowledge]; (S, A, Msb;) and AlEiloma ↓ baqara, inf. n. baqorN, signifies the same. (TA.) And so in the phrase tbq~r fiY AlmaAli, (S, A, Msb,) and fY AlA^aholi, (TA,) i. e., He enlarged himself, or he became, or made himself, large, or abundant, in wealth, or camels or the like, and in family; as explained by As. (A'Obeyd.) You say also, tbq~r AlkalaAma, [meaning fiY AlkalaAmi,] i. e., He was diffuse, or profuse, in speech; syn. tafat~aqa bihi. (A.)
