And lazimahu *`lika baAligFA maA balaga: see 1: and see the sentence there next following it. (Msb.) A^ayomaAnN baAligapN, in the Kur lxviii. 39, means Firm covenants: (Jel:) or covenants confirmed by oaths in the utmost degree: (Bd:) or rendered obligatory for ever; sworn to, that they shall be constantly observed: or that have reached their utmost point: (Th, TA:) or yamiynN baAligapN means [an oath, or a covenant,] confirmed. (TA.) ― -b2- Attaining, or having attained, to puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity; applied to a boy: (T, IKoot, IKtt, Msb:) and in like manner, without p, applied to a girl; (T, IAmb, Msb, K;) thus applied, with the mention of the noun qualified by it, by Esh-Sháfi'ee (T, Msb) and other chaste persons, of the Arabs; (T, TA;) or baAligapN; (IKoot, Msb;) or the latter is also thus applied, with the mention of the noun which it qualifies, (T, Msb, K,) not being wrong because it is the original form; (T, TA;) and seems to be necessarily used when the noun which it qualifies is not mentioned, to prevent ambiguity. (Msb.) ― -b3- A good, a goodly, or an excellent, thing. (S, K.)

A^abolagu * [More, and most, effectual or efficacious: see baliygN]. ― -b2- vanaA='N A^abolagu i. q. fiyhi ↓ mubaAlagN [Praise, or eulogy, or commendation, in which the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds are exceeded; such as is egregious, or immoderate, or extravagant; &c.: see 3]. (K.)

taboligapN A^blg blg tblgh tblgp
A rope, or cord, with which the main well-rope (Alr~i$aA=') is joined to [that which is called] the karab: (K:) or a rope, or cord, that is joined to the ri$aA=' so that it may reach the water: (Z, TA:) pl. tabaAligu. (K.) ― -b2- Also A thong that is wound upon the curved extremity of a bow, where the bow-string ends, three times, or four, in order that the bow-string may become firm, or fast. (AHn, TA.)
tabal~ugN A^blg blg tblg [an inf. n. (of 5, q. v.,) used as a subst.]: see bulogapN, in two places.

mabolagN mblg [The place, and the time, which a person, or thing, reaches, attains, arrives at, or comes to: the utmost point to which, or towards which, one tends, or repairs, or betakes himself; to which one directs his course; or which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, intends, or purposes; whether it be a place, or a time, or any affair or state or event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed: (see 1, first sentence:)] the utmost point, or scope, or degree, of knowledge [and of any attainment]: (Bd and Jel in liii. 31:) [the utmost degree of proficiency: a consummate degree of goodness and of any other quality: the age of puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity: the sum, amount, or product, resulting from addition or multiplication: a sum of money: and particularly a considerable sum thereof: and] cash, or ready money, consisting of dirhems and of deenárs: in this sense, post-classical: pl. mabaAligu. (TA.) You say, balaga fulaAnN mabolagahu and mabolagatahu: and balaga fiY AlEilomi AlmabaAliga: and balaga fiY Aljawodapi mabolagFA, and mina Aljawodapi: for explanations of all which, see 1. And balagota min~aA kul~a mabolagK: see Albulagiyna.
balaga fulaAnN mabolagatahu blg flAn mblgth blg flAn mblgtp : see 1.

[
mubal~igN mblg
One whose office it is, with other persons each of whom is thus called, to chant certain words, as the A_iqaAmap &c., in a mosque. (See my “ Modern Egyptians, “ ch. iii.)]

huwa maboluwgN bihi hw mblwg bh hw mblwg bp [He is caused to reach, attain, arrive at, or come to, his appointed end, or term of life, (A^ajalahu, or the like, being understood,)] is said of the object of the phrase balaga A@ll~`hu bihi [which see, and the phrase next following it]. (TA.)
vanaA='N mubaAlagN fiyhi vnA=' mbAlg fyh vnA=' mbAlg fyp : see A^abolagu.

balogamN blgm lgm [Phlegm;] one of the four [natural constituents termed] TabaAy^iE; (S;) [i. e.] one of the humours (A^axolaAT) of the body. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) A heavy, or sluggish, person, who is a great talker, or babbler. (TA.)

[
balogamiY~N 1
Of, or relating to, phlegm; phlegmatic.]

1 baliqa * and baluqa : see 9. -A2- balaqa, (S, K, &c.,) aor.
baluqa , (MSb, TA,) inf. n. baloqN, (TA,) He opened a door wholly: (JK, S, K:) or opened it vehemently: (K:) and ↓ Ablq signifies the same. (JK, S, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] He devirginated, or defloured, a girl. (AA, K.) -A3- Also He shut, or closed, a door. (IF, K.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.)

4 Ablq blgm blgmY blgmy lgm
He (a stallion) begot offspring such as are termed buloq [pl. of A^abolaqu, q. v.]. (Zj, K.) -A2- See also 1.

7 Anblq Anblq
It (a door) became opened wholly: (JK, S, K:) or became opened with vehemence. (K.)

9 Ablq~ A^blq Ablq , inf. n. AiboliqaAqN; (IDrd, S, K;) and ↓ AblAq~, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. AiboliyqaAqN; (IDrd, TA;) and ↓ Ablwlq, inf. n. AiboliylaAqN; (TA;) and ↓ baliqa, aor.
balaqa , (JK, K,) inf. n. balqN; (K, * TA; [accord. to the CK balqN, but this is a mistake;]) and ↓ baluqa, aor.
baluqa ; (K;) but IDrd asserts only the first and second of these verbs to be known; (TA;) He (a horse) was, or became, Ablq, i. e., black and white: (S, K:) or white in the kind legs as high as the thighs. (K.)
11 A_ibolaAoq~a see 9.
12 A_ibolawolaqa see 9.

balaqN blq and ↓ buloqapN, (S, K,) the former an inf. n. of baliqa, (K, * TA,) Blackness and whiteness [together, generally in horses]: (S, K:) or the extension of whiteness in the hind legs of a horse as high as the thighs: (ISd, K:) and the latter, any colour with which white is mixed. (Golius on the authority of Meyd.)
buloqapN blqh blqp : see what next precedes.
bulayqN blyq lyq lyqp a contracted dim. of A^abolaqu. (TA.)
bal~uwqN blwq : see what next follows.

bal~uwqapN blwqh blwqp , (JK, S, &c.,) [said to be] like EajuwzapN, (K,) [but this is wrong, and is probably a mistranscription, for Eaj~uwrap, with teshdeed and the unpointed r, n. un. of Eaj~uwr,] and with damm, [↓ bul~uwqapN,] (IDrd, K,) both mentioned by AA, (TA,) but more commonly with fet-h [to the bi], (IDrd, TA,) A [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap: (AA, S, K:) or a tract of sand that gives growth to nothing except the [plant or tree called] ruxaAmaY, (As, K, * TA,) of which the [wild] bulls are fond, and the roots of which they dig up and eat: (TA:) or a wide tract of fertile land in which no one shares with thee: (Fr, TA:) or a hard place among sands, as though it were swept, asserted by the Arabs of the desert to be of the dwellingplaces of the Jinn: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) or a desert land, destitute of vegetable produce and of water, or of human beings, inhabited by none but Jinn: (TA:) or a level, soft land: (K:) or a place in which no trees grow: (JK:) or white places in sand, which give growth to nothing: (ISh, TA in art. brS:) or a piece of ground differing in colour or appearance from that which is next to it, that produces nothing whatever: as also ↓ bal~uwqN, like tan~uwrN: and, with the art. Al, particularly applied to a place in the district of ElBahreyn, asserted (as IDrd says, TA) to be of the dwelling-places of the Jinn: (K:) pl. balaAliyqu; (JK, S, K;) which is syn. with mawaAmK (A 'Obeyd, S) and sabaAriytN, meaning lands wherein is nothing: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) in poetry, balaAliqu occurs as its pl. (K, TA.)
bul~uwqapN blwqh blwqp : see what next precedes.

A^abolaqu * , applied to a horse, fem. baloqaA='u, Black and white: (S, K:) or white in the hind legs as high as the thighs: (ISd, K:) pl. buloqN: which is applied by Ru-beh to mountains: but the Arabs apply the epithet Ablq to a beast of the equine kind, and A^aboraqu to a mountain (TA) and to a sheep or goat: (Lh, TA in art. brq:) the former is also applied to a rope. (JK.) Talaba AlA^abolaqa AlEaquwqa (which is a prov., TA) means He sought an impossible thing; because Ablq is applied to a male, and Eqwq means pregnant: or AlAblq AlEqwq means the dawn; because it breaks, (lit., cleaves,) from Eaq~ahu signifying $aq~ahu. (K.)
Q. 1 baloqaEa blqE lqE , (K,) inf. n. baloqaEapN, (TA,) It (a country, or region,) was, or became, vacant, or void; destitute of herbage or pasturage, and of human beings, &c. (K.)

Q. 3 AibolanoqaEa AblnqE
It (sorrow, grief, or anxiety, such as is termed karob,) became removed, or cleared away. (K.) ― -b2- It (the dawn) shone, or shone brightly. (K.) ― -b3- It (a thing) appeared, and came forth. (TA.)

baloqaEN blqE lqE and ↓ baloqaEapN A land that is vacant, or void; destitute of herbage or pasturage, and of human beings, &c.; (S, K;) in which is nothing: (S:) or the former signifies a vacant, or void, place: (Mgh:) [or instead of using the former alone, you say A^aroDN baloqaEN; for] you say manozilN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, place of alighting or abiding], (S, TA,) and daArN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, house &c.], without p, when it is an epithet, (S, TA,) applied to a mase. subst. and to a fem.; (TA;) but if it be a subst., you say, AinotahayonaA A_ilaY malosaA='a ↓ baloqaEapK [we came at last to a smooth, vacant, or void, land]: (S, TA:) and ↓ baloqaEapN also signifies a land in which are no trees, either in sands or in plain or level tracts: (TA:) or a vacant land, in which is no one, whether there be in it herbage or not, and whether plain or not: (Ham p. 445:] pl. balaAqiEu. (S, Mgh, K.) It is said in a trad., Alyamiynu AlfaAjirapu ta*aru (S, Mgh, TA; but in the second and third of these, in the place of ta*aru, we find tadaEu;) The false oath causes the places of abode to become void, or vacant; i. e., by reason of its evil influence, the possessions and their possessors perish; (Mgh;) or the [false] swearer becomes poor, and the property that was in his house goes away; (Sh;) or God renders him in a state of disunion, and changes the blessings which He had conferred upon him: (TA:) accord. to another relation, the words of the trad. are Alyamiynu Algamuwsu Alx. (Mgh.) You say also, diyaArN baloqaEN [Vacant, or void, places of abode]; as though the places were one place: (TA:) and Ru-beh says,
faA^aSobaHato daArahumu balaAqiEaA
[And their abode became vacant]: (TA:) and it is said in a trad., A^aSobaHati AlA^aroDu balaAqiEa [as though meaning the land became altogether vacant]; the pl. being used to render the meaning intensive, as in the phrases A^aroDN sabaAsibu and vawobN A^axolaAqN; (IAth, TA;) or because every portion thereof is considered as being blqE. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, without p and ↓ with p, (tropical:) A woman devoid of every good quality. (K, TA.) ― -b3- IF says that the l in baloqaEN is augmentative. (TA.)
baloqaEapN blqE blqEh blqEp lqE : see baloqaEN, in four places.
baloqaEiY~N blqE blqEY blqEy blqEyy lqE An arrow, or a spear-head, bright, or free from rust, in the point. (K.)
SalanoqaEN balanoqaEN SlnqE blnqE is an expression applied to A road [as though meaning made bare by the feet of men and beasts]. (I 'Abbád, K.)
bal~aAnN blAn : see art. bl.

1 baliha A^blh bl blh blp , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
balaha , (Msb, K,) inf. n. balahN, (S, * Msb, K, * TA,) [and irregularly balaAhapN and bulahoniyapN, (see balahN, below,)] He was, or became, A^abolah [q. v.]; as also ↓ tbl~h; (S, K;) and ↓ Abtlh: (TA:) or he was, or became, weak in intellect. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also He was unable to adduce his argument, proof, or evidence, (K, TA,) by reason of his heedlessness, and his smallness, or lack, of discrimination. (TA.)

3 mubaAlahapN mbAlhh mbAlhp The showing stupidity [in an action or in one's actions, i. e. the acting stupidly,] with any one. (KL.) [You say, bAlhhu He acted stupidly, or in the manner of him who is termed A^abolah, with him.]

4 Ablhhu A^blh A^blhh Ablhh Ablhp
He found him, or knew him by experience, to be A^abolah [q. v.]. (K.)

5 tbl~h A^bAl A^bl A^blY bAl bl blA blh bly tbl tblh tblp wbl : see 1. ― -b2- And see 6. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He journeyed, or proceeded, or pursued his way, without any sign of the road, or any track, to guide him, (Az, K, TA,) without following the right course, (Az, TA,) and without asking [to be directed]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) He prosecuted a search after a stray, or lost, beast. (JK, K.)

6 tbAlh bAlY tbAlh tbAlp
He feigned balah, or the attribute denoted by the term A^abolah: (S:) or he made use of that attribute [as a mask]; i . q. AisotaEomala Albalaha; as also ↓ tbl~h. (K.)
8 A_ibotalaha see 1.

baloha A^blh bl blh blp is an indecl. word with fet-h for its termination, like kayofa, and means daEo [Let alone, or say nothing of]; (S;) [i. e.] it is a noun for daEo; indecl.; (Mughnee, K;) a verbal noun, meaning daEo and A^utoruko; (IAth, TA;) and the noun that
follows it, when it is thus used, is in the accus. case; (Mughnee, K;) i. e. it is indecl., with fet-h for its termination, when the noun following it is in the accus. case; so that you say, baloha zayodFA [Let alone Zeyd, or say nothing of Zeyd]; like as you say, ruwayoda zayodFA: (IB, TA:) and it is also an inf. n. in the sense of Alt~aroku; likewise with fet-h for its termination, but decl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the gen. case; (Mughnee, K;) or it is put in the place of an inf. n., meaning taroka [which is virtually the same as Autoruko and daEo], and is prefixed to a noun in the gen. case; so that you say, baloha zayodK, i. e. taroka zayodK [which is virtually the same as baloha zayodFA explained above; for taroka zayodK is originally Autoruko zayodFA tarokFA, like as faDaroba Alr~iqaAbi in the Kur xlvii. 4 is originally fA@DoribuwA Alr~iqaAba DarobFA]; (IAth, TA;) for in this case it cannot be regarded as a verbal noun, since verbal nouns are not prefixed to other nouns, governed by them in the gen. case: (IB, TA:) and it is also a noun syn. with kayofa [How?]; likewise with fet-h for its termination, indecl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the nom. case. (Mughnee, K.) A poet says, describing swords, (S, Mughnee,) namely, Kaab Ibn-Málik, (S,)
ta*aru AljamaAjima DaAHiyFA haAmatuhaA
baloha AlA^akuf~a kaA^an~ahaA lamo tuxolaqi
[They leave the skulls with their crowns lying open to the sun (let alone, or say nothing of, the hands) as though they had not been created]: (S, Mughnee:) he says, when they cut, or cut off, the crowns, then let alone, or say nothing of, the hands (fadaEi AlA^akuf~a): i. e., they are more fit for cutting off the hands: (TA:) Akh says that blh is here in the place of an inf. n.; that it is as when you say, Daroba zayodK: but AlAkf~ may be in the accus. case; so that the meaning may be daEi AlA^akuf~a: (S:) the verse is thus recited in two different ways: and also baloha AlA^akuf~u [how then must be the case of the hands?]. (Mughnee.) And hence the prov., tuHoriquka Aln~aAru A_ino taraAhaA baloha A^ano taSolaAhaA, i. e. The fire will burn thee if thou see it from a distance: then let alone, or say nothing of, (fadaEo,) thy entering into it. (TA.) A strange instance occurs in the Saheeh of El-Bukháree, in the explanation of the A=l=m= of the chapter of Als~ajodap [the 32nd ch. of the Kur]: he says, God says [by these three letters], A^aEodadotu liEibaAdiy AlS~aAliHiyna maA laA EayonN raA^ato walaA A^u*unN samiEato wa laA xaTari EalaY qalobi ba$arK *uxorFA mino balohi maA A@T~alaEotumo Ealayohi: (Mughnee, K: *) or mA A^aTalaEotuhumo Ealayohi: (so in some copies of the K:) thus blh is used as a decl. word, governed in the gen. case by mn, and deviating from the three meanings [explained above]: (Mughnee, K:) but the reading commonly known is, ElY qlb b$r baloha ma A^aTolaEotuhumo Elyh; and this is the reading in the work of J, [the S,] and in the Nh, and other lexicological works: (TA:) it has been explained by gayor; [so that the meaning of the sentence as first related above is, I have prepared for my righteous servants what eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it occurred to the mind of man, as a treasure for the future, (obviously taken from Isaiah lxiv. 4, quoted by St. Paul in 1 Cor. ii. 9,) save, or except, that with which ye have become acquainted, or that with which I have acquainted them; and the same, with the omission of “ as a treasure for the future, “ is the meaning of the sentence as related in the S and Nh &c.;] (Mughnee, K;) i. e. siwaY, as in the S; (TA;) and this corroborates, (Mughnee,) or is agreeable with, (K,) the opinion of those who reckon blh as an exceptive word: (Mughnee, K:) and as meaning A^ajalo [app. a mistranscription for A^ajol; i. e., it has been explained also as meaning I have done all this because of my promise to them; (mino A^ajoli maA A^aTolaEotuhumo Ealayohi because of that with which I have acquainted them;) and thus it may have been read by SM, for he has written Ajl without any syll. signs; and has given no other ex. of blh in the sense here intended except one commencing with the words, baloha An~iY lamo A^axuno EahodFA, which may mean because I have not broken a covenant, or yea, verily I have not &c., accord. as we read A^an~iY or A_in~iY]: or as meaning kuf~a [or rather kuf~a Eano] and daEo [let alone, or say nothing of; but this explanation must relate to the sentence as given in the S and Nh]: (K, but omitted in an excellent copy of that work:) or, accord. to El-Ahmar, it means, in this trad. [as commonly known], kayufa [how? which seems to be the least suitable of all these explanations]. (TA.) IAmb relates, on the authority of others, that baloha is also syn. with EalaY: [but I think that this is a mistake, arising from a misunderstanding of what here follows:] Fr says that he who makes it to govern a gen. case regards it as used in the manner of EalaY, and similar particles governing the gen. case. (TA.) ― -b2- maA balohaka means maA baAluka [What is thy state, or condition, or case?]: (K, TA:) or maA laka [which often has this meaning: see the letter l]. (So in some copies of the K.)

balahN A^blh bl blh blp and ↓ balaAhapN [both properly inf. ns.; see 1;] The attribute, or quality, denoted by the epithet A^abolahN [q. v.]; (S, K;) i. e. heedlessness: (K:) or heedlessness of evil; (JK in explanation of the former, and K;) &c.; (K;) and ↓ bulahoniyapN signifies the same; and stupidity and languor. (JK.)
balahaA='u blhA=' : see A^abolahu.

bulahoniyapN blhnyh blhnyp , (K,) or balahoniyapu AlEayo$i, (JK,) or mina AlEayo$i, (S,) (tropical:) An easy and a plentiful, (S, K, TA,) or a pleasant and heedless, (JK, TA, *) state, or condition, of life: (JK, S, K, TA:) from Eayo$N A^abolahu [q. v.]: (Har p. 216:) the word blhnyp is rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class by A at the end, which is changed into Y because of the kesreh before it: (S in art. blhn:) it is like rufagoniyapN and rufahoniyapN: IB says that it should be mentioned in art. blh, and means Eayo$N A^abolahu; the n and Y being augmentative, to render it quasicoordinate to xubaEovinapN: it is mentioned in the K [and S] in arts. blhn and blh: (TA in art. blhn:) the n is augmentative accord. to Sb. (S in the present art.) One says, laA zilota mulaq~FY bitahoniy^apK mubaq~FY fiYbulahoniyapK (tropical:) [Mayest thou not cease to be greeted with congratulation, and made to continue in an easy and a plentiful state of life]. (A, K.) ― -b2- See also balahN.
balaAhapN blAhh blAhp blh : see balahN.

A^abolahu *
Heedless: (K:) or heedless of evil (K, TA) by reason of his goodness: (TA:) or simple, foolish, or of little sense, without discrimination: (K:) or weak in intellect: (Msb:) accord. to En-Nadr, (TA,) one whose evilness is dead, (K, TA,) so that he is not cognizant of it: (TA:) good in disposition; having little cognizance, or understanding, of subtilties; or having little skill therein: (K:) or one whose predominant quality is freedom of the bosom, or heart, or mind, from evil affections; (S, K, TA;) and good opinion of men: (TA:) simple-hearted: (TK:) naturally disposed to goodness, and therefore heedless of evil, not knowing it: (T, TA:) or heedless with respect to the present world and its people and their corruptness and malevolence, but intelligent and skilled in the law with respect to that which is commanded and that which is forbidden: (Ah- mad Ibn-Hambal, TA:) fem. balohaA='u: (S, Msb, K: *) pl. bulohN: (S, Msb:) and ↓ bulahaA='u, a pl., [as though the sing. were baliyhN,] signifies dull, stupid, or wanting in intelligence: but this is post-classical. (TA.) Hence, $aAb~N A^abolahu [A youth, or young man, who is heedless, &c.], because of his inexperience in affairs: the epithet is applied to a youth in like manner as freedom from care, or thought, and like as insanity, are attributed to him. (S.) And xayoru A^awolaAdinaA AlA^abolahu AlEaquwlu (tropical:) [The best of our children is the heedless, &c., that has much intelligence]; (S, Msb;) a saying of Ez-Zibrikán Ibn-Bedr; (S;) meaning such as, by reason of his bashfulness, is like the Ablh, (S, Msb,) so that he feigns heedlessness, and passes over things, (Msb,) though he has much intelligence; (S;) or such as is thought to be stupid, but, when examined, is found to be [very] intelligent. (IAth, TA in art. Eql.) And A^akovaru A^aholi Aljan~api Albulohu, a trad., meaning Most of the people of Paradise are the buloh [or heedless, &c.,] with respect to the present world, because of their being little concerned thereby, while they are intelligent with respect to the world to come; (S;) or they are thus termed because they are heedless of their affairs in the present world, and unskilful in the management thereof, and busy themselves with their affairs relating to the world to come. (TA.) ― -b2- balohaA='u, applied to a woman, Generous, strong-hearted, (maziyrapN, for Almariyrapu in the copies of the K is a mistake for Almaziyrapu, with zAY, TA, [app. here meaning bold,]) inexperienced in affairs, and simple, or unintelligent. (K, * TA.) ISh cites a poet as applying this epithet to a young girl with whom he had sported, and who acquainted him with her secrets, by reason of her inexperience, and want of cunning, not knowing what that implied against her. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) That does not take fright, and flee from a thing, (ISh, A, K,) by reason of staidness,
(ISh, K,) or heaviness, (A,) as though she were stupid. (ISh, A, K.) One does not say jamalN A^abolahu. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- $abaAbN A^abolahu (tropical:) Soft, or delicate, youth; (T, A, K;) as though he who enjoys it were heedless of nocturnal accidents or calamities. (A, K.) ― -b5- And Eayo$N A^abolahu (tropical:) A soft, or delicate, or pleasant, or plentiful and easy, life: (K, TA:) or a life in which are few anxieties: (CK:) or a life in which are few griefs, or sorrows. (S.) [See also bulahoniyapN.]

1 balaAhu bl blA blAh blAp blY lAhy , (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
baluwa , (T, Msb,) inf. n. balaA='N, (S,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is balowN, (T, Msb,) He (God) tried, proved, or tested, him, (T, S, Msb,) bixayorK [by, or with, good], or bi$~arK [by, or with, evil]; (Msb;) for God tries his servant (yaboluwhu) by, or with, a benefit, to test his thankfulness; and by, or with, a calamity, to test his patience; (T;) [wherefore it often means He afflicted him;] as also ↓ AblAhu, (T, S, Msb,) inf. n. A_ibolaA='N; (T, S; [in both restrieted to good; but in the Msb it seems to be common to good and evil;]) and ↓ AbtlAh: (T, S, M, Msb:) and balawotuhu, inf. n. balowN (S, M, K) and balaA='N, (M, K,) [but from what has been said above, it seems that the latter is used only when the agent is God, and that it is properly a simple subst.,] I tried, proved, or tested, him; (S, M, Mgh, * K;) as also ↓ Aibotalayotuhu: (M, K:) each of these verbs implying two things; one of which is the learning the state, or condition, of the object, and becoming acquainted with what was unknown of the case thereof; and the other, the manifesting of the goodness or badness thereof; both of these things being sometimes meant, and sometimes only one of them, as when God is the agent, in which case only the latter is meant: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and ↓ Alt~abaAliY, also, signifies the act of trying, proving, or testing. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xxi. 36], wanaboluwkumo biA@l$~ari waA@lxayori fitonapF [And we try you by, or with, evil and good, by way of probation]. (TA.) And in the same [ii. 118], ↓ waA_i*a A@botalaY A_iboraAhiyma rab~uhu bikalamaAtK [And when his Lord tried Abraham by certain words, meaning commands and prohibitions]. (TA.) And you say, ↓ laA tubolinaA A_il~aA biA@l~atiY hiYa A^aHosanu [Try Thou not us save by those things that are best]; (T;) from a trad. (TA.) [See also 4 and 8 below.] ― -b2- [Hence,] balawotuhu also signifies (tropical:) I smelt it. (T in art. bwl, and A and TA.) ― -b3- [And balaAhu He knew it, or became acquainted with it. (See baAlK.)] ― -b4- See also 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. -A2- baliY, aor.
balawa , inf. n. bilFA, or bilFY, [in the CK, erroneously, balFY,] and balaA='N, [in the CK, erroneously, bilA',] (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the former with kesr and the latter with fet-h, (T, S, Msb,) said of a garment, (T, S, M, &c.,) It was, or became, old, and worn out: (Msb:) belonging to the present art. and to art. blY. (M.) [The inf. n., used as a subst., signifies Wear; attrition; wear and tear: see an ex. in a hemistich cited near the end of the first paragraph of art. AlA, where a dwelling is likened to a garment.] ― -b2- Also said of a plant [as meaning It became old and withered, or wasted]. (K in art. Env, &c.) ― -b3- And of a corpse, meaning It became consumed by the earth. (Msb.) ― -b4- And of a bone, meaning It became old, and decayed; syn. ram~a. (S and K &c. in art. rm.) ― -b5- And of a man's reputation, meaning (assumed tropical:) It became worn out of regard or notice. (TA in art. dvr.) ― -b6- And [hence,] baliyato, (M,) or buliyato, (K,) She (a camel, M, K, or a mare, or beast of the equine kind, M) was, or became, a balay~ip; i. e., was tied at her dead master's grave (M, K) without food or water (M) until she died (M, K) and wasted away. (M in art. blY.)
2 bal~awa see 4, in six places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

3 laA A^abaAliyhi * is from AlblA=', [inf. n. of balaAhu,] so that it signifies [properly] I shall not, or I do not, care for him, mind him, heed him, or regard him, so as to share with him my trial and his trial: (Ham p. 94:) [and hence,] one says thus, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or maA A^abaAliyhi, (M, K,) and laA A^abaAliYbihi, (Mgh, Msb,) or maA A^ubaAliY bihi, (MF, TA,) but the verb is more chastely made trans. without the preposition bi, (A, TA,) inf. n. mubaAlaApN (M, Mgh, Msb, K) and bilaA='N (M, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, balA']) and baAlapN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) said by some to be a quasi-inf. n. and by others to be an inf. n., (MF, TA,) [in the T it is said to be a subst., from AlmubaAlaApu,] originally baAliyapN, like EaAfiyapN from EaAfaAhu, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) and baAlN, [which is more strange,] (M, K,) meaning [merely] I shall not, or I do not, care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) I shall not be, or I am not, disquieted by him, or it: (Mgh, Msb:) or, as some say, laA A^ubaAliyhi is formed by transposition from laA A^ubaAwiluhu, from AlbaAlu, i. e. I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind; nor give, or pay, any attention to him, or it: (Z, TA: [and the like is said in the T:]) or the proper [or literal] meaning is, I will not, or I do not, contend with him for superiority in goodness, or excellence, by reason of my little care, or regard, for him: (Mgh:) or it was employed to denote the contending with another for superiority in glory, or excellence, as will be shown by the citation of a verse in the latter portion of this paragraph; and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, came to denote contempt, or mean estimation: (Ham p. 31:) or its original meaning is, I will not, or I do not, strive with him to be first; neglecting him, or leaving him to himself; from tabaAlaY Alqawomu as explained below; see 6. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA yubaAliyhimu A@ll~`hu baAlapF, or, accord. to one reading, laA yubaAliY bihimo baAlapF, meaning God will not hold them to be of any value or weight. (TA.) And in another, h`w^ulA='i fiY Aljan~api walaA A^ubaAliY wah`w^ulaA='i fiY Aln~aAri walaA A^ubaAliY, said to mean [These will be in Paradise, and] I shall not disapprove; [and these will be in the fire of Hell,] and I shall not disapprove. (Az, TA.) And one says, laA A^ubaAliY maA SanaEota [I shall not, or I do not, care for what thou didst, or hast done]. (IDrd, TA.) And maA A^ubaAliY A^aqumota A^amo qaEadota [I care not whether thou stand or sit]: and maA A^ubaAliY biqiyaAmika waEadamihi [I care not for thy standing and thy not doing so]. (Mughnee in art. A.) And maA baAlayotu bihi (AZ, Msb, TA) I did not care for, mind, or regard, him, or it. (TA.) And baAlaY biAl$~aYo'i [He cared for the thing; or] he was disquieted by the thing. (T.) The verb is sometimes thus used, in an affirmative manner; (Ham p. 94; [and the like is said in the TA;]) though some say that it is not; (Msb;) but it is not unless it occurs with a negative in the former part of the sentence or in the latter part thereof; as when one says, maA baAlaY bika Sadiyquka wal`kino baAlaY Eaboduka [Thy friend cared not for thee, but thy slave cared]; and as in the saying of Zuheyr,
laqado baAlayotu maZoEana A^um~i A^awofaY
wal`kino A^um~u A^awofaY laA tubaAliY
[Verily I cared for the departure of Umm-Owfà, but Umm-Owfà cares not]. (Ham p. 94.) One says also, lamo A^ubaAli and lamo A^ubalo [I did not care, &c.]: (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K: [but in the CK the latter of these is omitted:]) in the latter the A [of prolongation] is suppressed for the purpose of alleviating the utterance, like as Y is suppressed in the inf. n. [or quasi-inf. n.] baAlapN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) originally baAliyapN, (S, Msb,) and in laA A^adori: (S:) or the A is suppressed in this case to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; (Kh, Sb, M, IB;) not for the purpose of alleviating the utterance; (IB, TA;) for this is done because the l is made quiescent. (Kh, Sb, M.) And, accord. to Kh, (Sb, M,) some of the Arabs say, lamo A^ubalihi [I did not care for him, or it], (Sb, M,) or lamo A^ubali, [in the CK, erroneously, lm Aaboli,] with kesr to the l; (K, TA;) [for lm A^ubaAlihi, or lm A^ubaAli;] only suppressing the A, as they do in EulabiTN [for EulaAbiTN]. (Sb, S, M.) ― -b2- IAar says that baAlaY, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, is like ↓ A^abolaY meaning He exerted himself in a description of a war, or battle, or of generous conduct; as when one says, A^abolaY *`lika Alyawoma balaA='F HasanFA [He exerted himself well, that day, in a description of war, &c.]: and he cites the following verse [to which reference has been made above]:
waA^anota qadomat~a mina AlhuzaAli
[What hath happened to me that I see thee standing exerting thyself in a description of generous qualities, when thou hast become like one dead by reason of leanness?]: he says that he [the poet] heard him [whom he thus addresses] saying, “ We have eaten and we have drunk [with guests], and we have done [such and such things]; ” enumerating, or recounting, generous qualities or actions, and lying in doing so: (T, TA:) in another place he says that tubaAliY means looking to see which of them [or of thee and others] is best in bAl [i. e. state, or condition], while thou art dying: (TA:) he says, also, that baAlaAhu, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, signifies he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence; (T, TA; *) and [it is said that] tbAlY
in the verse here cited means thus contending; syn. tufaAxiru: (Ham p. 31:) and accord. to IAar, baAlaAhu also signifies he contended with him in contradiction. (T, TA.)

4 AblAhu A^bl A^blAh A^blY AblAh AblAp , inf. n. A_ibolaA='N: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] AblAhu A@ll~`hu A_ibolaA='F HasanFA, (T,) or balaA='a HasanFA, (S,) God did to him a good deed. (T.) [And hence,] it is said in the Kur [viii. 17], waliyuboliYa Almuw^ominiyna minohu balaA='F HasanuA (TA) And that He might confer upon the believers a great benefit, or favour, or blessing: (Bd:) or a good gift; meaning spoil. (Jel.) And A^abolayotuhu maEoruwfFA [I conferred upon him a favour, or benefit]. (S.) Zuheyr says,
jazaY A@ll~`hu biA lA_iHosaAni maA faEalaA bikumo
waA^abolaAhumaA xayora AlbalaA='i Al~a*iY yaboluw
(T, * S,) meaning, Al*Y yaboluw bihi EibaAdahu, (T,) or Al*Y yaxotabiru bihi EibaAda, (S,) i. e. [May God recompense with beneficence what they two have done to you,] and do to them two the best of the deeds wherewith He tries [the thankfulness of] his servants. (T.) ― -b3- AblAhu also signifies He made him to swear; [as though he tried his veracity by so doing;] (M, K;) or so AblAhu yamiynFA. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b4- And He swore to him: (M, K:) or this, (TA,) or AblAhu yamiynFA, [as above,] (T, S,) he swore [or swore an oath] to him, and thereby soothed, or placated, his mind. (T, S, * TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (TA,) He informed him, acquainted him, or told him. (IAar, M, K, TA.) ― -b6- [And hence, He manifested it; revealed it; made it manifest, apparent, evident, clear, or plain; whence a phrase in a verse cited voce muDomarN; and the phrase] maA lamo yuboli AlEu*ora, i. e. As long as he does not manifest, show, or make apparent, the excuse: but the verb [in this sense] is originally doubly trans.: one says, A^abolayotu fulaAnFA Eu*orFA, meaning I manifested to such a one an excuse so that I was not to be blamed after it; properly signifying I made such a one to be acquainted with my excuse, and to know the manner thereof; (Mgh;) and thus it is explained in the A: (TA: [in like manner, also, it is explained in the T:]) [or] AblAhu Eu*orFA signifies He gave him an excuse which he accepted: (M, K:) and in like manner, AblAhu juhodahu [He gave him his endeavour, or energy, in an acceptable manner]; and naAy^ilahu [his gift]. (M.) Hence, AblY Eu*orahu signifies also He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, [and thus manifested his excuse,] in work. (Mgh.) And hence, AblY fiY AlHarobi He manifested, or showed, his might, valour, or prowess, in war, or fight, [and he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, therein, (Eu*orahu being understood,)] so that men proved him and knew him. (Mgh.) See also 3, where another explanation of AblY is given, in the latter portion of the paragraph. -A2- AblY Alv~awoba [He wore out the garment;] trans. of baliYa; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ bal~aAhu; (M, K;) belonging to the present art. and to art. blY. (M.) One says to the mujid~ [i. e. him who makes, or puts on, a new garment], A^aboli wa yuxolifu A@ll~`hu [Wear out thy garment, and God will replace it with another; or, may God replace &c.]. (S.) And A^aboli wa A^ajid~a waA@Homida AlkaAsiY Wear out, and make new, [or put on new,] and praise the Clother [meaning God]. (S in art. jd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Als~afaru ↓ bal~aAhu [Journeying, or travel, wore him, or wasted him]; namely, a man; (M, K; but in the copies of the latter, ↓ balaAhu [which I think an evident mistranscription];) as also Ealayohi ↓ bl~Y; and AblAhu: (M:) and so Alham~u [anxiety], (M, K,) and the like, (M,) and Alt~ajaAribu [tryings, or trying events]: (K:) and AblAhA Als~afaru (T, S) or ↓ bl~AhA (thus in a copy of the S) [journeying, or travel, wore her, or wasted her]; namely, a she-camel. (T, S.) El-'Ajjáj says,
waAlmaro'u yuboliyhi balaA='a Als~irobaAlo
kar~uAll~ayAliY waA@xotilaAfu AlA^aHowaAlu
[And man, the returning of the nights time after time, and the alternation of states of being, wear him out as the wearing out of the shirt]: (S, M: *) he means, A_ibolaA='a AlsirobaAl, or fabaliYa balaA='a Als~irobaAl. (M.) And Ibn-Ahmar says,
labisotu A^abiY Hat~aY tamal~ayotu Eumorahu
wabal~ayotu A^aEomaAmiY wa bal~ayotu xaAliyaA
he means I lived the period that my father lived [so that I had long enjoyment of his life, and I outwore my paternal uncles, and I outwore my maternal uncle]: or, as some say, I lived with my father for the length of his life &c. (M, TA. * [In the latter, ↓ tabal~ayotu is put in the place of tamal~ayotu; and hence it is there said that tabal~aAhu is like bal~aAhu: but I think that tbl~yt is a mistranscription.]) ― -b3- A^abolayotu and ↓ bal~ayotu also signify I bound the foreshank of a she-camel to her arm at the grave of her [dead] master, and left her without food or water until she died; or I dug for her a pit, and left her in it until she died. (S, TA. [See baliy~apN, and mubal~FY.])
5 tabal~awa see 4, near the end of the paragraph.

6 Alt~abaAliY AltbAlY AltbAly [inf. n. of tabaAlaY]: see 1. -A2- tbAlY Alqawomu The people, or company of men, vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening to a little water, and drew from it. (Msb.)

8 AbtlAhu AbtlAh AbtlAp {btlAh {btlY : see 1, in three places. [Hence, AubotiliYa bika*aA (vulg. AibotalaY) He was tried, proved, or tested, by, or with, such a thing; generally meaning he was afflicted thereby, or therewith; as, for instance, by, or with, a disease.] ― -b2- Also He asked, or sought, or desired, of him information, or news, or tidings. (M, K.) And AbtlY signifies also He conjured, or adjured, and asked if any had knowledge; syn. AisotaHolafa and AisotaEorafa [explained by what here follows]. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, both the verb and the explanation are here wrong: the former is written AuboliYa; and the latter, AsotuHolifa w AsotuEorifa.]) A poet says,
tabag~aY A^abaAhaA fiY Alr~ifaAqi wa tabotaliY
wa A^awoday bihi fiY luj~api AlbaHori tamosaHu
[She seeks for her father among the travellingcompanions, and conjures, or adjures, and asks. if any have knowledge, when a crocodile has destroyed him in the depth of the great river: tabag~aY is for tatabag~aY]: he means that she says to them, “ I conjure you, or adjure you, by God, (naA$adotukumo A@ll~`ha,) [tell me,] do ye know any tidings of my father? ” (M, TA.) But Aboo-Sa'eed says that ttblY here means tries, proves, or tests; and that AlAibotilaA='u signifies the trying, proving, or testing, whether by an oath or otherwise. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also He desired it; he sought it.] It is said in a trad., Aln~a*oru maA A@botuliYa bihi wajohu A@ll~`hu, i. e. [The vow that a man makes to be binding, or obligatory, on himself is that whereby the recompense of God] is desired, or sought. (TA.) ― -b4- And He chose him, made choice of him, or elected him. (Sh and T, from a trad.)

12 AibolawolaY AblwlY Ablwly
It (herbage) became tall, so that the camels were able to avail themselves of it. (K.)

bilowu safarK blw sfr , (T, S, M, A,) with kesr to the b, (S,) and biloYu safarK, (S, A,) Worn, or wasted, by journeying, or travel; applied to a she-camel, (T, S, M, A,) and in like manner to a man, and to a he-camel: (M:) and biloYu A^asofaArK (M, K) and bilowu A^asofaArK, (K, TA,) with kesr to the b in both, (TA, [in the CK written with fet-h,]) a man worn, or wasted, by journeyings, or travels, and anxiety, (M, K, *) and the like, (M,) and tryings, or trying events: (K:) pl. A^abolaA='N. (S, M.) And bilowN $ar~K and biloYu $ar~K [both written in the CK with fet-h to the b] A man having strength, or power, to endure evil; tried, proved, or tested, thereby: (M, K:) and in like manner, bilowu xayorK and biloYu xayorK [tried, &c., by good, or prosperity]. (TA.) And A_in~ahu libalowN mino A^abolaA='i AlmaAli and biloYN [both written in the CK with fet-h to the b as before] Verily he is one of those who manage, or tend, camels, or the like, well. (M, * K, * TA.) The Y in biloY, in all these instances, is originally w, changed into Y because of the kesreh, and the weakness of the intervening letter, l; as is the case in EiloayapN: so says IJ. (M.)
balaY bl blY bly ly : see art. blY.
bilowapN bl blA blwh blwp bly : see what next follows.
biloyapN bly blyh blyp ly lyp : see what next follows.
baloway blwY blwy lwY lwy lyp : see what next follows.

balaA='N blA=' (T, S, Msb) and ↓ balowaY (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ baliy~apN (S, M, Msb, K) and ↓ bilowapN, (S, M, K,) with kesr, (S, K,) and ↓ biloyapN, (so in a copy of the S, beside the third,) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, in the place of the third, (TA,) substs. (T, M, Msb, K) from balaAhu A@ll~`hu, (T, Msb,) or from AibotalaAhu A@ll~`hu, [which is the same in meaning,] (M,) or from balawotuhu, (K,) are one [in their signification; which is A trial, as meaning a probation, or a test; and as meaning particularly a trouble or an affliction of any kind by which one's patience or any other grace or virtue is tried, proved, or tested]; (S;) and the pl. (S, TA) of ↓ baliy~apN (TA) is balaAyaA, of the measure faEaAy^ilu
changed to faEaAlaY: (S, TA:) [or] balaA='N is [properly, or originally,] an inf. n., (S, M, K,) and signifies the act of trying, proving, or testing, by, or with, good, and by, or with, evil: (S, M:) it is evil and good: (T, M: *) a trial, or an affliction, (T, K,) which is its original meaning; (T;) and a [probationary] benefit, favour, or blessing, (T,) or a [probationary] gift; (K;) the former of these requiring patience, and the latter being the greater of the two [as being commonly the more dangerous to the soul]; (TA;) [but the latter meaning is generally indicated only by the addition of an epithet: thus] balaA='N HasanN means a great benefit, or favour, or blessing, of God; (Bd in viii. 17;) or a good gift of God: (Jel ibid.:) balaA='N also means grief; as though it tried the body: (Er-Rághib, K:) and the imposition of a difficult, or troublesome, thing; a requirement; an exaction; because it is difficult, or distressing, to the body; or because it is trying. (K.) balaA='i (like qaTaAmi, S, K) is syn. with AlbalaA='u: (S, M, K:) occurring in the saying, nazalato balaA='i EalaY Alkuf~aAri [Trial, or affliction, befell the unbelievers]: (S, M, * K: *) mentioned by El-Ahmar, as heard by him from the Arabs. (S.)

bilaA='N blA=' , like kitaAbN in form, [is an inf. n. of 3, q. v.: -A2- and also signifies] Anxiety respecting which one talks to himself, or soliloquizes. (Msb. [Compare a meaning of balaA='N, above.])
baliY~N bl blY bly ly : see the paragraph next following; last sentence.

baliy~apN bly blyh blyp ly lyp : see balaA='N, in two places. -A2- Also A she-camel that has her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and is left without food until she dies: (T:) or a she-camel, (M in arts. blw and blY, and K,) or a mare, or beast of the equine kind, (M in art. blw,) that is bound at the grave of her master, (M, K,) he being dead, and is left without food or water (M) until she dies (M, K) and wastes away; for they used to say that her master would be raised from the dead upon her: (M:) or a she-camel which, in the Time of Ignorance, had her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and was left without food or water until she died: or for which was dug a pit, wherein she was left until she died: for they used to assert that men would be raised from the dead riding upon the balaAyaA, [pl. of baliy~apN in the sense above explained, (T, TA,)] or walking if their beasts whereon they rode were not bound, with the head turned backwards, at their graves: (S:) or a cow, or she-camel, or sheep, or goat, which, in the Time of Ignorance, they used to hamstring, or slaughter, at the grave: so in a trad. (TA.) Suh says that this custom proves that, in the Time of Ignorance, they held the doctrine of the resurrection of the body: but they who held it were the fewer number. (TA.) It is said that baliy~apN is originally ↓ mubolaApN or ↓ mubal~aApN. (TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
manaAzilu laA taraY AlA^anoSaAba fiyhaA
walaA Hufara Almubal~aY lilomanuwni
[Places of abode in which thou wilt not see the stones, or other things, that have been set up to be worshipped, nor the pits of the beast left by the grave of the master to die]; meaning places of abode of the people of El-Islám, exclusively of the pagans. (S.) IAar says that ↓ baliY~N and baliy~apN signify Such as is wearied, or jaded, and emaciated, and dying. (TA.)

baAlK A_l Al bA_l bAl bAly b|l |l [act. part. n. of balaAhu; Trying, proving, or testing. ― -b2- And hence,] Knowing, or being acquainted [with a thing]; as in the phrase, jaEalotuhu baAliyFA biEu*oriY I made him to be acquainted with my excuse, and to know the manner thereof. (Mgh.) -A2- Also Old, and wearing out [or worn out]; applied to a garment. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baAliyaAtN is used as meaning The places of tents. (Ham p. 492.)
mubolaApN mblAh mblAp , fem. of mubalFY: see baliy~apN.
mubol~FY mblY mbly , and its fem. mubal~aApN: see baliy~apN.

mubal~iyaAtu mblyAt
Women that stand around a man's riding-camel [which they bind, or place in a pit, by his grave, to die of hunger and thirst,] when he has died or been slain, wailing for him. (T, S. *) You say, qaAmato mubal~iyaAtu fulaAnK yanuHona Ealayohi [The women that bound, or placed, the baliy~ap by the grave of such a one stood around it wailing for him]. (T, S.)

bil~aworN blwr lwr (M, Msb, K) and bal~uwrN (Msb, K) and bilaworN, (K,) or the last only, (IAar, T,) [a coll. gen. n., signifying Crystal;] the kind of stone called mahFA, (M,) which shines by reason of its whiteness and clearness; (TA in art. mhw;) a well-known kind of stone, the best of which is brought from the islands of the Zinj (Alz~inoj); (Msb;) a well-known kind of precious stone, (K, TA,) white and transparent: (TA:) [Golius says, but I know not on what authority, if on any better ground than the resemblance of the name, “ Græc. βήρυλλος, beryllus, lapidis genus: de quo vide Plin. xxxvii. 5: aut potius, quo illum lapidem adulterari idem scribit, crystallum: ”] n. un. with p: (M:) some say that it is a kind of glass [or factitious crystal; what we term crystal-glass; and to this the word is commonly applied in the present day; though still also applied to rock-crystal]. (TA.)
1 baliYa bl blY bly ly : see art. blw.
4 AblY Alv~awoba Ably Alvwb : see art. blw.
biloYN bl blY bly ly : and biloYu safarK: &c.: see art. blw.

balaY bl blY bly ly is a particle; (S, Msb, Mughnee;) contr. of laA: (S:) not a noun: (Sb, S:) it is a replicative; (S, Mughnee;) an affirmative of what is said [in that to which it is a reply]; (S, Msb;) [with very few exceptions] relating only to a negation, which it annuls: (Msb, Mughnee:) the final letter is a radical: or, accord. to some, the word is originally balo, [after which an affirmation is to be understood,] and the final letter is augmentative: and some of these say that this letter is a denotative of the fem. gender, because it is [often] pronounced with imáleh. (Mughnee.) It is a reply to an interrogation in which is a negative, (T, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) and affirms what is said to thee [in that interrogation]; (M, K;) whether it be an interrogation in the proper sense, (Mughnee,) as when you say to another, A^alamo tafoEalo ka*aA [Didst thou not such a thing?], and he replies, balaY [meaning Yes, or yea, or ay, I did], (T,) or as when one says, A^alayosa zayodN biqaAy^imK [Is not Zeyd standing?], and you reply, balaY [Yes, he is]; or be meant to convey reproof, (Mughnee,) as in the Kur [lxxv. 3 and 4], A^ayaHosabu AlA_inosaAnu A^ano lano najomaEa EiZaAmahu balaY [Doth man think that we will not collect his bones? Yes], (Msb, Mughnee,) i. e., we will collect them; (Msb;) or be meant to make a person confess, or acknowledge, a thing, (Mughnee,) as in the Kur [vii. 171], A^alasotu birab~ikumo qaAluwA balaY [Am I not your Lord? They said, Yea]. (M, Mughnee.) It is also a reply to a simple negation, (Msb, Mughnee,) as when I say, maA qaAma zayodN [Zeyd did not stand, or has not stood], and you reply, balaY as an affirmative [meaning Yes, he did, or he has]. (Msb.) It occurs in the Kur [xxxix. 60], where it is said, balaY qado jaA='atoka A=yaAtiY [Yea, my signs have come to thee], preceded by that which is not literally a negation, but which has the force of a negation; for the preceding saying, lawo A^an~a A@ll~`ha hadaAniY [If God had directed me aright, or would that God &c.], is like the saying, maA hudiytu [I was not directed aright]. (M.) It also occurs in the books of traditions, in some instances, as a reply to an interrogation without a negative; but these instances are rare, and not to be followed in rendering revelation. (Mughnee.) Az says that when a man says to another, A^alaA taquwmu [Wilt thou not stand?], and the latter replies, balaY, he means balo A^aquwmu [Nay, I will stand], adding the alif [written Y] to make the pause good; for if he said, balo, the other would expect something more to be said after it. (TA.) It is said that the pronunciation termed imáleh is allowable in the case of balaY; and if so, its final radical letter is Y: and some of the grammarians say that this pronunciation of blY is because, by reason of its completeness and independence of meaning, so that it requires nothing after it, it resembles independent nouns, in the cases of which this pronunciation is allowable. (M.)
biloyapN bly blyh blyp ly lyp and baliY~N and baliy~apN: see art. blw.

bam~N bm [The bass in music; used in this sense in the present day: or particularly the bass notes of the lute: in this sense F seems to have understood the saying of ISd that] the bam~ of the lute is well known: (M, K: [in the CK, Albam~a mina AlEuwodi Aw Alwatari Alx is erroneously put for Albam~u mina AlEuwdi m= A^awi Alwataru Alx:]) or (so in the K) it is the thick [or bass] chord of the lute: (S, K:) the
word is foreign: (M:) [in Persian bamo:] Az says that it is not Arabic. (TA.)

bum~N bm
i. q. buwmN, q. v. (K.)
1 banV3a see 4.
2 bn~n bnn , (K,) inf. n. taboniynN, (TA,) He tied a sheep, or goat, in order to fatten it: (K:) from ban~a biAlomakaAni. (TA.)

4 Abn~ biAlomakaAni Abn bAlmkAn , (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ibonaAnN; (Lth, T;) and bihi ↓ ban~a, aor. yabin~u, (M, K,) inf. n. ban~N; (M, TA;) but As allows only the former verb; (M, TA;) He remained, continued, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) he kept, or clave, to the place. (Lth, T, TA.) Accord. to Z, it is a tropical meaning, from the ban~ap [i. e. odour] of the camels or cattle [of a stationary people]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^aban~ati Als~aHaAbapu (assumed tropical:) The cloud remained, or continued raining, (M, TA,) some days, (TA,) and kept its place. (M.)

5 tbn~n tbnn
He acted, or proceeded, deliberately, not hastily. (T, TA.) An Arab of the desert said to Shureyh, on his desiring to pronounce judgment against him hastily, taban~ano, meaning Act thou deliberately, not hastily. (T.)

bano bAn bn bnn is a dial. var. of balo, (M, K,) and so is laA bano of laA balo; or, as some say, formed by substitution [of n for l; not peculiar to any dialect]. (M.) One says, bano waA@ll~`hi laA A=tiyka [Nay, by God, I will not come to thee]: Fr says that it is of the dial. of Benoo-Saad and Kelb; and that he had heard the Báhilees say, laA bano, meaning balo [or laA balo]: but IJ says, I do not trace up bano [to any authority] as being an independent word of a particular dialect. (TA.) -A2- [bonu and boni and bona, for A@bonu &c.: see art. bnY.]

bun~N bAn bn bnn [Coffee-berries, whether green or roasted, whole or reduced to powder by pounding or grinding;] expl. in the K as $aYo'N yut~axa*u kaAlmur~iY~i [a certain thing that is taken like the condiment termed mur~iy~, which is used to give relish to food or to quicken the appetite]; Ibn-Es-Sim'ánee says, huwa$aYo'N fiY AlkawaAmiyxi [app. meaning it is a thing reckoned among what are termed kwAmyx, pl. of kaAmaxN, which signifies the same as mur~iY~N, for it seems that fY is here used in the sense of mino, or it may be a mistranscription for mino]; the physician Dáwood says, it is the produce of certain trees in El-Yemen; the berries thereof are put into the earth in A=*aAr [the Syrian month corresponding to March, O. S.], and it increases, and is gathered in A^abiyb [the Coptic month commencing on the 25th of June, O. S.; the 7th of July, N. S.]; it grows to the height of about three cubits, on a stem of the thickness of the thumb, and has a white flower, which is succeeded by a berry like the hazel-nut; sometimes it is cut like beans; and sometimes, when it is divested of its covering, it divides into two halves: it has been proved to be good for alleviating humidities, and cough, and phlegm, and defluxions, and for opening obstructions, and causing a flow of the urine: when roasted, [and pounded or ground,] and well cooked, [i. e. boiled in water,] it is now commonly known by the name of qahowap. (TA.) [Golius, I think, has misunderstood the explanation of this word in the K: after having given that explanation, and rendered it by “ res quæ sumitur instar AlmrY Múrriji, ” he adds, “ Pers. AbkAmh Abcâma dictæ: hæc sorbitio est rei ex hordeo et frumento paratæ multa cura et arte, quam Malajesa et Halimæus describunt. ” He then mentions the signification of coffee-berries as a second and distinct meaning.]

bin~N bAn bn bnn
A place having a fetid odour. (Fr, T, K.) -A2- It also signifies TiroqN mina Al$~aHomi (T, K) and Als~imani (K, TA: in the CK Als~amoni:) [said in the TA to mean quw~apN minohumaA, i. e. Strength arising from fat and from fatness: but I think that waAls~imani has been added in the K in consequence of a misunderstanding, and that the meaning is a layer of fat; this meaning seeming to be indicated by the ex. here following, and corroborated by significations of several conjugates of TiroqN, as TariyqapN and TaraqN and TiraAqN &c.] One says (T, K) of a beast (daAb~ap) when it has become fat, (T,) rakibahaA bin~N EalaYbinK (T, K *) and TiroqN EalaY TiroqK (T) [clearly I think, meaning Layer upon layer, of fat, has accumulated upon it.]

ban~apN bn bnh bnp
A sweet, or pleasant, odour; (As, AA, T, S, M, K;) such as that of the apple (T, M) and the like, (M,) or the quince: (T:) Sb says that it is a name for a sweet, or pleasant, odour, like xamoTapN: (M, * TA:) and an unpleasant odour; (As, T, S;) a fetid odour; (M, K;) whence ban~apN Algazoli [the odour of the yarn] occurring in a saying of 'Alee, respecting a weaver; (M;) which shows that A'Obeyd erred in asserting it to have only the first of the foregoing significations; (IB, TA;) which Suh, in the R, assigns also to ↓ bunaAnapN: (TA:) the odour of sheep, or goats, (S, M,) or of camels or cattle; (Z, TA;) and of the dung of gazelles; (S, K;) and of the lodging-places of sheep or goats and of oxen or bulls or cows and of gazelles: (T, M:) and sometimes the lodgingplaces themselves, of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) pl. (in all the senses, M) binaAnN. (T, S, M, K.)

bun~iY~N bn bnY bny bnyp bnyy ny
A seller of bun~ [or coffee-berries]. (TA.) -A2- Also, [vulgarly pronounced bin~iY,] A species of fish; (K;) [the cyprinus Bynni of Forskål; described by him in his Descr. Anim. p. 71;] it is white, and is the best kind [of fish], and abundant in the Nile. (TA.)

banaAnN bnAn The fingers; syn. A^aSaAbiEu: (M, Msb, K:) but whether it means peculiarly the ASAbE of the hand, or those of the foot also, [i. e. the toes,] is disputed: (TA:) or the ends, or extremities, thereof: (S, M, Msb, K:) said to be so called because by their means are ordered those circumstances whereby man continues in existence; from A^aban~a biAlomakaAni: (Msb:) mentioned in the Kur viii. 12 because therewith one fights, and defends himself: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there signifies all the limbs, or members, of the body: (Aboo-Is-hák, M:) or the fingers, or toes, and any other parts of all the limbs, or members: (Zj, TA:) or it means in the Kur the $awaY; (Lth, T, TA;) so in lxxv. 4; (M;) i. e. the arms or hands and the legs or feet: (Lth, T, TA:) accord. to El-Fárisee the meaning of the words in the Kur lxxv. 4 is, we are able to make their extremities like those of the camel, so that they should not profit by them in handicraft: (M, TA:) the n. un. is with p; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) meaning, accord. to Lth, a single A_iSobaE [i. e. finger, or toe]; or, accord. to AHeyth, the whole ASbE; or, as some say, the highest Euqodap [or joint] of the ASbE: (T:) the pl. of pauc. is banaAnaAtN; but a pl. of mult. is sometimes used as one of pauc.; and hence the saying of the rájiz,
xamosa banaAnK qaAniy^i AlA^aZofaAri
[Five fingers, or ends of fingers, intensely red from the dye of hinnà in the nails], meaning xamosFA mina AlbanaAni: and one says, banaAnN muxaD~abN [Fingers, or ends of fingers, dyed, or much dyed, with hinnà]; for every pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] between which and its sing., or n. un., there is no difference but p [added in the latter] may be treated as sing. and masc. (S.) Lth cites as an ex. of the n. un.,
layosa liHaY~K fawoqahumo banaAnaho
laAhum~a A^akoramota baniY kinaAnah
meaning [O God, Thou hast honoured the sons of Kináneh: there belongs not to any tribe] excel-lence of the measure of a finger above them. (T, TA.)

baniyinN bn bnY bnyn
Deliberate and intelligent: (AA, T, K:) from ban~a biAlomakaAni. (TA.)
banaAnapN bnAn bnAnh bnAnp n. un. of banaAnN. (Lth, T, S, M, K.) -A2- See also what next follows.

bunaAnapN bnAn bnAnh bnAnp : see ban~apN. ― -b2- Also A meadow, or verdant tract of land somewhat watery, (AA, T, M, K,) producing herbage, (M, K,) and adorned with flowers; (TA;) and so ↓ banaAnapN. (M.)

mubin~N mbn
Remaining, continuing, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. (T, TA.) Applied to a mixture of urine and dung (Eabas) upon the tail [of a camel &c.], it may mean Cleaving, and sticking: or it may be from ban~apN signifying “ a fetid odour ” [so as to mean having a fetid odour]: thus, in this case, it may be either a part. n. or a possessive epithet. (M, TA.) It signifies also Having the odour of the dung of gazelles; applied to a covert, or hiding-place, of those animals, among trees. (S, K. *)
2 bn~jhu bnj bnjh bnjp , inf. n. taboniyjN, [He dosed him, or stupified him, with banoj, q. v.;] he gave him banoj to eat. (K.) [See the act. part. n. below.]

banojN bnj [Hyoscyamus, or henbane;] an arabicized word, [said to be] from [the Persian] banoko; [but see a quotation from Hammer-Purgstall, near the close of this paragraph;] a certain plant, (Mgh,
and Har p. 365,) having an intoxicating kind of grain, or, as some say, (Mgh,) of which the leaves and peel and seeds torpify: (Mgh, Har:) it is said, in the Kánoon, (Mgh,) by Aboo-'Alee [Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna], (Har,) that it is a poison which confuses the intellect, and annuls the memory, and occasions insanity and [the disorder termed] xunaAq [or quinsy]; (Mgh, Har;) and it is red, and white: (Har:) a certain plant having a kind of grain that confuses the intellect, and occasions alienation of the mind, or insanity; and sometimes it intoxicates, when a man drinks it after it has been dissolved; and it is said to occasion forgetfulness: (Msb:) a certain torpifying plant, well known; different from Ha$iy$u AlHaraAfiy$i; disordering the intellect (muxab~iTN liloEaqoli), rendering insane, allaying the pains of humours and pustules, and the earache, (K, TA,) applied as a liniment or as a poultice; (TA;) the worst kind (K, TA) for use (TA) is the black; then, the red; and the safest kind is the white. (K, TA.) [Kzw says that the leaves of the garden-hemp (qin~ab busotaAniY~, or $ahodaAnaji, the latter of which properly signifies hemp-seed,) are the banoj which, when eaten, disorders the intellect. And ElIdreesee applies the appellation Ha$iy$iy~ap to the “ Assassins. ” This establishes the correctness of De Sacy's opinion, that the appellation “ Assassins ” is derived from the vulgar pl. Ha$~aA$iyn, (hemp-eaters, or persons who intoxicate themselves with hemp,) for Ha$~aA$iyn is syn. with Ha$iy$~ap, and the sect called by us the “ Assassins ” are expressly said by the Arabs to have made frequent use of banoj. Baron Hammer-Purgstall, correctly regarding banoj as hyoscyamus (or henbane), makes the following important observations, “ ‘ Bendj, ’ the pl. of which in Coptic is ‘ nibendj, ’ is without doubt the same plant as the ‘ nepenthe, ’ which has hitherto so much perplexed the commentators of Homer. Helen evidently brought the nepenthe from Egypt, and bendj is there still reputed to possess all the wonderful qualities which Homer attributes to it. ” (Trébutien, “ Contes Inédits des Mille et une Nuits, ” tome i. p. 12, note.)] The phrase $ariba Albanoja is used by ElKarkhee [as meaning He drank the bnj] because it is mixed with water; or [as meaning he took, or swallowed, the bnj,] according to the conventional language of the physicians. (Mgh.)
muban~ijN mbnj One who employs a stratagem by means of food containing banoj [in order to obtain some advantage over another, by stupifying him therewith; as the “ Assassins ” used to do]. (Mgh.)

banodN bnd nd is a Persian word arabicized, originally signifying A knot, or tie. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) [Any of] the stops that are put between the beads of the suboHap to mark the place where the performer of tasobiyH pauses on the occasion of a thing's diverting his attention: so in the Comm. on the Tohfeh by the seyyid 'Omar El-Basree: (MF, TA:) app. post-classical and recent. (TA.) ― -b3- A dam; a thing that stops, or dams, [water, or] from water (Al~a*iY yusokiru mina AlmaA='i). (K. [In the CK, yusokaru is put in the place of yusokiru. In this sense, also, it is of Persian origin.]) ― -b4- A stratagem, a trick, or an expedient, of which one makes use: (T, K:) a snare by which one snares men: (TA in art. qmT:) pl. bunuwdN. (T.) You say, fulaAnN kaviyrN Albunuwdi Such a one abounds in, or practises much, stratagems, tricks, or expedients, (Lth, T, A,) and mischievous, or calamitous, acts. (A.) In this sense, also, it is an arabicized Persian word. (TA.) ― -b5- An enigma. (TA.) ― -b6- A pawn that is tied (munoEaqidN, in the CK mutaEaq~idN,) by a queen in the game of chess: as though it confined and tied itself. (TA.) ― -b7- Also a Persian word, arabicized, (S, A,) signifying A large banner, standard, or ensign: (En-Nadr, S, A, K:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of a general, or leader, (T, M,) of the Greeks, (M,) under which are ten thousand men, (T, M,) or less, or more: (T:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of horsemen: (El-Hujeymee, T:) [in barbarous Latin bandum; and in Spanish, bandera; as mentioned by Golius; and in modern Arabic banodiyrN:] pl. as above: (S, M:) it has no pl. of pauc. (M.) ― -b8- [The pl.] bunuwdN also signifies, in Greece, [Provinces, or districts;] what are called A^ajonaAdN in Syria, and A^aEoraADN in El-Hijáz, and kuwarN in El-'Irak, and maxaAliyfN in El-Yemen. (Yákoot.)
banodarN bndr ndr [app. from the Persian banodaro,] A place where ships or boats anchor or moor; a port [or port-town: pl. banaAdiru]. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 banodaqa bndq
He made a thing into banaAdiq [meaning bullets, or little balls], (Mgh, K,) or like bnAdq (TA.) -A2- [In post-classical Arabic, He shot a bullet, or bullets, from a cross-bow or other weapon.] ― -b2- bndq A_ilayohi (assumed tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, at him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

bunoduqN bndq [The hazel-nut; or hazel-nuts; so in the present day;] a certain thing that is eaten; (Msb;) i. q. jil~awoz: (IDrd, K:) or, as some say, like jl~wz; brought from an island; the best whereof is the fresh, heavy, white, and sweet in taste; the old being bad: it is beneficial as a remedy for palpitation, parched with anise-seed; and for poisons, and wasting of the kidneys, and burning of the urine; and with pepper, it excites the venereal faculty; with sugar, it removes cough; and the shell thereof, burnt, and applied as a collyrium, sharpens the sight: (TA:) they assert that the suspending it upon the upper arm preserves from scorpions, (K,) i. e., from their stinging: (TA:) the moistening of the top of the head of a child with the powder of it when burnt, together with oil, removes the blueness of its eyes and the redness of its hair: and the Indian kind thereof is an antidote very beneficial to the eyes: (K, TA:) but in some copies of the K, [and so in the CK,] instead of liloEayonayoni, we here find liloEin~iyni [for the impotent in respect of the venereal faculty]: (TA:) [it is said in the Msb that most hold the n to be augmentative: but this is not the case; for] the word is Persian [arabicized, from funoduqo]: (K:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: pl. banaAdiqu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, Bullets, i. e.] certain things that one shoots, (S, Msb, K,) made of clay: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K:) the latter signifies a piece of clay, made round, which one shoots, or casts; or i. q. julaAhiqN: (Mgh:) it is said in the Shifá el-Ghaleel to be an arabicized word: (TA:) pl. as above. (S, Msb.) [See a prov. voce HidaA^apN. Hence qawosu Albunoduqi The crossbow. In modern Arabic, bunoduq is also applied to Balls of any kind of the size of hazel-nuts: n. un. with p.]

bunoduqiY~N bndq bndqY bndqy bndqyy
A garment, or piece of cloth, of fine, delicate, or thin, linen. (Sgh, K.) [SM says,] It is most probably, in my opinion, so called in relation to the land of Albunoduqiy~ap [or Venice]. (TA.) [In modern Arabic, A Venetian sequin: pl. banaAdiqapN.] bunodaqaAniY~N [app. a post-classical word,] A maker of cross-bows (qisiY~ Albunoduq). (El-Makreezee's Khitat, art. xT~ AlbndqAny~yn.)

binoSirN bnSr nSr The finger that is next to the little finger; (S in art. bSr;) [the third finger;] that which is between the little and middle fingers: (Msb in art. bSr, and K:) of the fem. gender: (K:) pl. banaASiru, (S,) or banaASirapN. (Msb.) Accord. to the author of the K, the n is a radical letter, and therefore the mention of this word in art. bSr is wrong. (TA.)

banafosajN bnfsj , of the measure qaEal~alN, like safarojalN, (Msb,) [an arabicized word, from the Persian banafo$a; The violet; viola odorata of Linn: and accord. to Forskål (Flora AEgypt. Arab. p. ciii.) applied in El-Yemen to the “ iris: ” and (p. cxx.) “ tagetes dubia? ”] what is thus called is well known: the smelling it in its fresh state is beneficial to those who are heated by wrath (AlmaHoruwriyn), and the continual smelling of it induces good sleep: the conserve made of it is beneficial for the pleurisy (*aAtu Aljanobi), and for inflammation of the lungs (*aAtu Alr~iy^api), and for cough, and for headache. (K.)

1 banaqa bnq nq , (K,) aor.
banuqa , inf. n. banoqN, (TK,) He joined [a thing to another thing, like as the baniyqap of a shirt is joined: see the pass. part. n., below]; syn. waSala. (K.)

2 bn~q AlqamiySa bnq AlqmyS , inf. n. taboniyqN, He put a baniyqap to the shirt. (K.) ― -b2- bn~q AljaEobapa (tropical:) He made the upper part of the quiver wide [by adding to it
the like of a baniyqap (see the pass. part. n., below,)], and the lower part narrow: (K, TA:) or he widened its upper part, the lower part being [or remaining] narrow. (JK.)

binayqapN bnqp bnyqh bnyqp nyq The libonap, (AZ, Abu-l-Hajjáj El-Aalam, JK, S, K,) or dixoriSap, (Abu-l-'Abbás El-Ahwal, TA,) [both of which signify the gore,] of a shirt, (AZ, S, K,) or of a garment; (JK;) or the dxrSp is longer than the lbnp: (Seer, TA:) and any piece that is added in a garment or a leathern bucket to widen it: (Abu-l-Hajjáj ElAalam, TA:) or, accord. to IDrd, the dxAryS of a shirt: (TA: [but this is app. a mistranscription for its sing. dixoriyS, q. v., a dial. var. of dixoriSap:]) or the jurub~aAn [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt: (K:) jrb~An is prefixed to Albnyqp in a verse of Jereer, governing the latter in the gen. case, to show that both these words have the same meaning: (TA:) ↓ binaqapN, also, signifies the same as bnyqp; (JK, K; [in the latter of which it is mentioned in such a manner as perhaps to denote that it has only the last of the significations above; but I think that this restriction is not meant;]) and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is ↓ binaqN: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) Th mentions banaAy^iqN and binaqN, and says that the latter is a pl. pl. ; [i. e., pl. of the former;] but this is unintelligible: (TA:) banaAy^iqN is pl. of baniyqapN, (JK, S, &c.,) and syn. with daxaAriySN. (JK.) AZ cites, from Mejnoon,
kamaA Dam~a A^azoraAra AlqamiySi AlbanaAy^iqN
(S, IB,) which is an inverted phrase; the meaning being,
kamaA Dam~a A^azoraAru AlqamiySi AlbanaAy^iqaA
[Like as the buttons of the shirt draw together the gores: if the last word mean the gores]: or, if the bnyqp of the shirt be really its jrb~An, the meaning is intelligible [without inversion]; for its jrb~An is the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons; and when one desires to draw it together, he puts its buttons into the loops, and so draws together the bosom [of the shirt, with its buttons,] to the uppermost part of the chest. (IB, TA.) Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee explains AlbnAy^q, here, as meaning the loops into which the buttons are inserted; and accord. to this explanation the meaning is plain, not requiring the supposition of inversion nor of deviation from the usual way: but the first explanation is that which is generally given. (TA.) In the saying,
↓ qado A^agotadiY wa Ald~ahoru *uw baniyqi
[in the last word of which, p is elided; lit., Sometimes I go forth early in the morning, when the time has a baniyqap;] Lth says that the whiteness of the dawn is likened to the whiteness of the bnyqp; citing another verse, in which a shirt is described as having white bnAy^q. (TA.)

jaEobapN mubn~aqapN jEbp mbnqh jEbp mbnqp (tropical:) A quiver that is widened: (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) or in the upper part of which is added what resembles a baniyqap, to enlarge it. (A, TA.) ― -b2- TariyqN muban~aqN (tropical:) A wide road. (TA.)

banuwa : see art. bnY.

1 banaAhu bAny bnA' bnAh bnAp bnY bnyp nAhy , (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
baniYa , (M, Msb,) and
banuYa , but the former is the more common, (M,) [or rather the only form commonly known,] inf. n. binaA='N (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and binFA (T, and TA as from the M [but it is not in the transcript of the M in the TT]) and banoYN and bunoyaAnN and binoyapN and bnaAyapN, (M, K,) He built it; framed it; constructed it; contr. of hadamahu; (M, K;) namely, a house, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or tent, (S, * Msb,) &c.; (Msb;) as also ↓ AbtnAh, (S, M, Msb, K,) and ↓ bn~Ahu; (M, K;) or the last has teshdeed given to it to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects; and hence you say, bn~Y quSuwrFA [He built palaces, or pavilions: or he raised them high: see the pass. part. n. below]. (S, TA.) AHn speaks of a kind of plank as being used fiY binaA='i Als~ufuni [in the construction of ships]: but binaA='N is originally used only in relation to that which does not grow; as stone, and clay, and the like. (M.) You say also, banaY A^aroDFA, for banaY fiY A^aroDK [He built in, or upon, land]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] banaY EalaY A^aholihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) or EalaY A@moraA^atihi, (Mgh,) and banaY bihaA also, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) accord. to IDrd (Mgh, Msb) and IJ, (M,) and occurring in traditions and elsewhere, though said in the S to be vulgar, (IAth, MF,) and said to be so by ISk, (T, Msb,) and by some said to be not allowable, (M,) but the former is the more chaste, (Msb,) inf. n. binaA='N; (S, TA;) as also ↓ AbtnY, (K,) i. e. AbtnY ElyhA, (ISk, Msb,) or AbtnY bihaA, (IJ, M,) He had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of the marriage: (ISk, T, S, Msb, K:) or he went in to his wife [for the first time]: (Mgh, Msb:) originating from the fact that the bridegroom used, on that occasion, to pitch a tent for her, (ISk, T, S, Mgh, Msb,) a new tent, (Mgh, Msb,) and furnish it with what was requisite, (Msb,) or a new tent was set up for him, (Mgh, Msb,) in honour of him. (Msb.) [See also bayotN.] ― -b3- binaAyapN is sometimes used in relation to nobility: (M, K:) and the verb thus used is banaY, as above, (T, M,) having [also] binFY for its inf. n., (IAar, T,) and binaA='N; held by many to be tropical, but by some to be proper. (MF.) Lebeed says,
fasamaA A_ilayohi kaholuhaA wa gulaAmuhaA
fabanaY lanaA rafiyEFA samokuhu
(M) And He (namely, God,) hath built for us a house of nobility of lofty pitch, and its (the tribe's) middle-aged and its youth have risen to it: i. e., all of them have attained to high degrees. (EM, p. 180.) ― -b4- banaY badanahu It (food) fattened his body, (K,) and made it large: (TA:) and banaY laHomahu, (T, M, K,) aor.
baniYa , (TA,) inf. n. binaA='N, (M,) or banoYN, (TA,) It (food) made his flesh to grow, (T, M, K,) and to become large. (T, TA.) ― -b5- banaY Alr~ajula He reared, brought up, or educated, the man; (M, K;) as also ↓ AbtnAhu. (M.) ― -b6- [banaY kalimapF, inf. n. binaA='N, He formed a word. ― -b7- And He made a word indeclinable, so as to end invariably with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel.] binaA='u kalimapK [when the former word is considered as the inf. n. of the pass. form buniYa, generally] signifies A word's keeping always the same mode of termination, ending with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel, not by reason of any governing word: (M, K:) as though the word resembled a fixed, immoveable building. (M.) [You say, buniyato EalaY Als~ukuwni It was made indeclinable, with a quiescent letter for its termination; and EalaY AlfatoHi with fet-h for its termination; &c. ― -b8- And in like manner you say, banaY AlqaSiydapa EalaY AlbaA='i, &c., He made the qSydp to have b, &c., for its rhyme-letter, or its chief rhyme-letter.] -A2- banati Alqawosu EalaY watarihaA The bow clave to its string (T, S, K) so that it (the latter) almost broke. (T, S.) [See the part. n. below.]
2 ban~aYa see 1, first sentence.

4 AbnAhu A^bAn A^bn A^bnAh A^bnnAh AbnAh AbnAp {bn {bnAh |b
He made him to build, frame, or construct, a house, or tent: (S:) or he gave him a building: or he gave him that wherewith to build a house: (M, K:) and AbnAhu bayotFA he gave him a house, or tent, to build or frame or construct. (T.) It is said in a prov., AlmiEozay tubohiY walaA tuboniY [Goats rend, or make holes, and render vacant, and do not afford materials for fabricating tents]; i. e., they do not yield hair of which a tent is fabricated; (T, S; *) for the tents of the Arabs [of the desert] are of the kind called TiraAf, made of skin, and A^axobiyap, made of wool or of camels' fur, and not of $aEar [by which is especially meant goats' hair], (S,) or, as is found in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl, of wool or of skin: (TA:) or the meaning is, goats rend tents, or pierce them with holes, by their leaping upon them, (T and S in art. bhw,) so that they cannot be inhabited, (S in that art.,) and do not aid in the fabrication of tents; for the goats of the Arabs of the desert
have short hair, not long enough to be spun; whereas the goats of the cold countries, and of the people of the fertile regions, have abundant hair, and of this the Akrád [or Kurdees] fabricate their tents. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He introduced him to his wife [on the occasion of his marriage]: whence the saying of 'Alee, mataY tubonyiniY, accord. to IAth properly meaning mataY tajoEaluniY A^aboniY bizawojatiY [When wilt thou make me to have my wife conducted to me? or, to go in to my wife?]. (TA.)

5 taban~ato tbnY tbnt , said of a woman sitting, (T, TA,) She became like a tent (T, IAth, K, * TA) of the kind called mibonaApN, (T, TA,) i. e., a qub~ap of skin; by reason of her fatness, (T, IAth, TA,) and largeness, (T, TA,) or fleshiness: (IAth, TA:) or she parted her legs; as though from mibonaAp, i. e. a qub~ap of skin, which, when pitched, is spread out by the ropes: so this woman, sitting cross-legged, spread apart her legs. (T, TA.) And tbn~Y, said of a camel's hump, It became fat. (M.) -A2- tbn~Ahu He adopted him as a son: (S, K:) or he asserted him to be, or claimed him as, a son: (M:) and tbn~Y bihi signifies the same. (Zj, TA.)

A^aboniyaAtN: (M, K:) and ↓ bunoyaAnN [also] has this meaning; (Msb;) [and is likewise originally an inf. n.;] or this signifies a wall; syn. HaAy^iTN; (S;) or it may be a pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n., meaning buildings, structures, edifices, or walls,] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is ↓ bunoyaAnapN, and as such may be masc. and fem: (Er-Rághib, TA:) ↓ binoyapN and ↓ bunoyapN also signify [the same as binaA='N as explained above; or] a thing that one has built, framed, or constructed; (M, K;) or, accord. to some, the former of these two relates to objects of the senses, and the latter to objects of the mind, to glory or honour or the like; (MF, TA;) and their pls. are ↓ binFY and ↓ bunFY; (K;) or, accord. to the S and M, these two appear to be sings.; (TA;) [or they may be pls. or sings.; for J says that] AlbunaY is like AlbinaY; one says, bunoyapN and bunFY, and binoyapN and binFY; (S;) [and ISd says that] binoyapN and bunoyapN signify as above, and so binFY and bunFY; or, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, binFY is pl. of binoyapN; or it may be used by poetic licence for binaA='N: (M:) accord. to IAar, binFY signifies buildings, or structures, of clay: and also [tents] of wool; (T;) and binaA='N likewise signifies a tent (M, TA) in which the Arabs of the desert dwell, in the desert, (TA,) such as is called xibaA='; (M, TA; *) and TiraAfN and qub~apN and miDorabN are names applied to dwellings of the same kind; (TA;) pl. A^aboniyapN: (M:) the moveable dwelling, such as the xayomap and miZal~ap and fusoTaAT and suraAdiq and the like, is called binaA='N as being likened to the building of burnt bricks and of clay and of gypsum. (M.) [See also baniy~apN.] ― -b2- Also The roof, or ceiling, of a house or chamber or the like; as in the Kur [ii. 20], Al~a*iY jaEala lakumu AlA^aroDa firA$FA wa Als~amaA='a binaA='F [Who hath made for you the earth as a bed, and the heaven as a roof, or ceiling]: (S, [but wanting in some copies,] and Jel:) so says AZ: (S:) or the meaning here is, as a tent (qub~ap) pitched over you. (Bd.) ― -b3- And The body, with the limbs or members. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. niToEN [A thing that is spread on the ground to serve as a table for food &c., made of leather; like mibonaApN]: occurring in a trad., where it is mentioned as spread on the ground, on a day of rain, for Mohammad to pray upon: so says Sh. (T.)

bunaY~N bn bnY bny bnyp bnyy ny , [said to be] originally bunayowN, A little son; [used as a term of endearment;] (Msb;) dim. of AibonN. (S, Mgh, Msb.) You say, yaA bunaY~i and yaA bunaY~a [O my little son, or O my child], with kesr to the Y and with fet-h also; like as you say, yaA A^abati and yaA A^abata [which see in art. Abw, voce A^abN]. (Fr, S, K.) [The fem. is bunay~apN A little daughter; dim. of binotN. And hence,] ― -b2- bunay~aAtu AlT~ariyqa The small roads that branch off from the main road; (S;) what are termed Alt~ur~ahaAtu. (S, K.) ― -b3- The Arabs say, Alr~ifoqu bunaY~u AlHilomi, meaning Alrfq is like AlHlm. (IAar, ISd.)

bunuw~apN bn bnY bnwh bnwp
Sonship: (Lth, Zj, S, M, Msb, K:) [it may be originally bunuwyapN, for Az says, app. on the authority of Zj,] it is not a decisive proof that the last radical is w, since they say futuw~apN, though the dual [of the word from which this is derived] is fatayaAni; (T;) [and ISd says that] bunuw~apN is thus because of the dammeh. (M.)

Albaniy~apu Albnyh Albnyp bnyp [properly The building, like AlbinaA='u &c.: but particularly applied to] the Kaabeh; (S, M, K;) because of its nobleness. (M, K.) One says, laA warab~i h`*ihi Albaniy~api maA kaAna ka*aA waka*aA [No, by the Lord of this building (the Kaabeh), such and such thing were not]: (S, TA:) and this was a common form of oath. (TA.) The Kaabeh is also called baniy~apu A_iboraAhiyma [The building of Abraham]; because he built it. (TA.)

ban~aA='N bnA='
A builder; [meaning one whose business is that of building;] an architect. (M.) [See also what next follows.]

baAnK bA^n bAn bAny b|n |n [Building, framing, or constructing]: accord. to A'Obeyd, its pl. is A^abonaA='N; and in like manner, A^ajonaA='N is pl. of jaAnK: and hence the prov., A^abonaAw^uhaA A^ajonaAw^uhaA, (M,) or A^ajonaAw^uhaA A^abonaAw^uhaA, i. e.
