The injurers thereof, meaning this house (h`*ihi Ald~aAr), by demolishing it, are the builders thereof. (S in art. jnY.) ISd says, I am of opinion that these two pls. are not used except in this prov.: and J says, in art. jnY, I think that the prov. is originally junaAtuhaA bunaAtuhaA; but IB affirms that it is not so: and he says that the prov. is applied to him who does, or makes, a thing without consideration, and commits a fault therein, which he repairs by undoing what he has done or made: it originated from the fact that the daughter of a certain king of El-Yemen, during his absence on a military expedition, built, by the advice of others, a house, which he, disliking it, commanded them to demolish. (TA in art. jnY. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 294.]) ― -b2- A bridegroom: from banaY EalaY A^aholihi [q. v.]. (TA.) And hence, Any one going in to his wife. (S, TA.) ― -b3- qawosN baAniypN A bow cleaving to its string (T, S, M, K) so that it (the latter) almost breaks; (T, S, M;) the doing of which is a fault; (M;) contr. of baAy^inapN [q. v.]: (S and M in art. byn:) and so ↓ baAnaApN (T, M, K) in the dial. of Teiyi: (T, M:) or the latter signifies widely separate from its string [like baAy^inapN]. (TA.)

baAnaApN A^nAp A^nY bA^nAh bA^nAp bAnAh bAnAp : see baAnK. ― -b2- Also, (in [some of] the copies of the K erroneously written bAnAt, TA,) A man bending himself over his bow-string when shooting. (M, K.) ― -b3- And Small nabol [or arrows]. (M and TA in art. byn.)

baAniyapN A_nA' bAny bAnyh bAnyp b|nyh b|nyp |ny fem. of baAnK [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also sing. of bawaAnK, (TA,) which signifies The ribs of [the breast, or of the part thereof called] the zawor: (M, K:) or the bones of the breast: or the shoulder-blades
and the four legs: (TA:) and the legs of a she-camel. (M, K.) One says, [likening a man to a camel lying down,] A^aloqaY bawaAniyhu, meaning He took up his abode, and settled, (T, M, K,) in a place; like A^aloqaY EaSaAhu. (T, M.) A^aloqaY Al$~aA^omu bawaAniyahu [meaning Syria became in a settled state] occurs in a trad. as related by A'Obeyd: and if he said bawaAy^inahu, it would be allowable; bawaAy^inu being pl. of bwAn, [i. e. buwaAnN or biwaAnN,] which is a name for any tent-pole except in the middle of the bayot, which has three poles. (T.) And it is said in another trad., A^aloqati Als~amaA='u biraka bawaAniyhaA, meaning The sky cast down the rain that it contained. (TA.)

AibonN A^bAn A^bn A^bnn Abn bAn bnY {bn |b , meaning A son; (M, Mgh, K;) because he is the father's building, made to be so by God; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and (tropical:) a son's son; and (tropical:) a descendant more remote; (Msb;) is with a conjunctive A [when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, written A@bonN]; (Zj, T, M;) [and when immediately preceded by the proper name of a man and immediately followed by the proper name of his parent, written without the A, as in zayodu bonu EamorKw Zeyd the son of 'Amr (in which case it should also be observed that the former proper name is without tenween); unless the words compose a proposition, as in zayodN A@bonu EamorKw Zeyd is the son of 'Amr; or in the case of an interrogation, as in halo zayodN A@bonu EamorKw Is Zeyd the son of 'Amr?]: the pl. is ↓ banuwna (T, S, Mgh, Msb) in the nom. case, and baniyna in the accus. and gen.; (Mgh;) and A^abonaA='N, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is a pl. of pauc.: (Msb:) [and hence it is argued that] the sing. is of the measure faEalN with the final radical letter elided and the conjunctive A prefixed; (M;) originally banaYN, (M, K,) with Y, as we judge, because [the aor.] yaboniY is more common than yabonuw: (M:) or originally banawN, (S, Msb, K,) with two fet-hahs, because it has banuwna for a pl., and the perfect pl. does not admit of change [in its vowels beyond that which is here made in banuwna for banawuwna]; (Msb;) and because it has for a pl. A^abonaA='N, like as jamalN has A^ajomaAlN; (S;) and the elided letter is w, (Akh, T, S,) as in A^abN and A^axN, (S,) because w is more commonly elided than Y; (Akh, T;) or because the fem. is binotN and [that of A^axN is] A^uxotN; for we do not see this h [or t] affixed in the fem. except when w is elided in the masc., as is shown by A^axawaAtN and hanawaAtN; (S;) though bunuw~apN is not a decisive proof that the last radical is w, for a reason stated above in the explanation of it: (T:) or, as some say, it is originally binowN, with kesr to the. b, like HimolN, because they say binotN, and a change [of a vowel] in a case of this kind is rare: (Msb:) [but J says,] it may not be of the measure fiEolN nor fuEolN, because it has banuwna with fet-h to the b, for a pl.; nor of the measure faEolN, because this has [generally] for its [broken] pl. A^afoEulN or fuEuwlN: (S:) Zj says that it is originally binoYN or binowN, or it may be originally banFA; that it is app. the last accord. to those who say banuwn; and that A^abonaA='N may be pl. of the measure faEalN and of fiEolN; that binotN favours its being of the latter; but that it may be of the measure faEalN changed to fiEolN, as faEalN is changed to fuEolN in the case of A^uxotN. (T.) Beside the pls. mentioned above, AibonN has a quasi-pl. n., namely ↓ A^abonaY, of the same measure as A^aEomaY; (Mgh, TA; *) a sing. denoting the pl.: or, as some say, AibonN has for pls. A^abonaA='N and A^abonaY. (TA.) Lh mentions the phrase, h`w^ulaA='i A^abonaA A^abonaAy^ihimo [or A^abonaY AbnAy^hm These are the sons of their sons.]. (M.) Sometimes m is affixed to AibonN [so that it becomes ↓ AibonumN or AibonamN at the beginning of a sentence, and ↓ A@bonumN or A@bunamN in other cases]: the word is then doubly declinable [like Aimoruw^N or A@moruA^N]: you say, h`*aA A@bonumN [This is a son], and raA^ayotu A@bonamFA [I saw a son], and mararotu biA@bonimK [I passed by a son]; making the n similarly declinable to the m; and the A is with kesr in every case [when the word commences a sentence, whether you make the word doubly declinable or not]: (AHeyth, * S:) [for] some make it singly declinable, leaving the n with fet-h in every case [as the r in AimoraA^N or A@moraA^N]; saying, h`*aA A@bonamuka [This is thy son], and raA^ayotu A@bonamaka [I saw thy son], and mararotu biA@bonamika [I passed by thy son]. (AHeyth, TA.) Hassán says,
waladonaA baniY AlEanoqaA='i waA@bonaYo muHar~iqK
↓ faA^akorimo binaA xaAlFA waA^akorimo binaA A@bonamaA
[We begot the sons of El-'Ankà, and the two sons of Moharrik; and how generous are we as a maternal uncle! and how generous are we as a son!], (S, K, *) i. e., A@bonaA: the m is augmentative, and the hemzeh [or rather A] is that of conjunction. (K.) And Ru-beh says,
↓ fahoYa tunaAdiY biA^abiY waA@boniymaA
bukaA='a $akolaY faqadato HamiymaA
[As the weeping of a bereft woman, who has lost a relation, therefore she calls out, With my father would I ransom thee, and a son]; meaning A@bonimaA. (TA.) The fem. of AibonN is ↓ AibonapN or A@bonapN [with the conjunctive A when not commencing a sentence] and ↓ binotN [meaning A daughter; and (assumed tropical:) any female descendant]: (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) accord. to Sb, (M,) AibonapN is formed from AibonN by affixing h [or p]; but not so binotN; for this is formed by affixing Y as a letter of quasi-coordination, and then substituting for it t: (M, K:) [but if the t be substituted for Y, it seems more probable that the Y is the final radical:] or, as some say, the t is substituted for w: (M:) [Mtr says,] the t is substituted for the final radical: (Mgh:) accord. to Ks, it is originally with h [or p], because it has a fem. meaning: (IAar, Msb:) [my own opinion is most agreeable with this of Ks; and with that of Zj, which will be mentioned below; or, perhaps, is identical with that of Zj: I think it most probable that, as AibonN is generally held to be originally banaYN or banawN, so AibonapN and binotN are both originally banayapN or banawapN, and that binotN is formed from AibonapN by suppressing the alif, transferring its kesreh to the b, making the n quiescent, and changing the p into t, which is therefore said to be not the sign of the fem. gender, either because it is not p, but is a substitute for p, or because it is preceded by a quiescent letter:] AHn says that the t is substituted for the final radical letter, which is w; and that it is not the sign of the fem. gender, because the letter [next] before it is quiescent: this [he says] is the opinion of Sb, and is the right opinion; for he says that if you were to use it as the proper name of a man, you would make it perfectly decl.; and if the t were to denote the fem. gender, the name would not be perfectly decl.: (TA:) and the same is said respecting the t in A^uxotN: (TA in art. Axw:) this t remains in a case of pause (Ks, IAar, S, Msb) as in the case of the connexion of the word with a word following: (S:) but one should not say AibinotN, (Th, T, S.) because the A is required only on account of the quiescence of the b, and is therefore dropped when this is made movent: (S:) Zj says that, in forming the pl. of binotN [and of AibonapN], the sing. is reduced to its original form, which is faEolapN [as I find it written in the transcript from the T in the TT, but it may be a mistake for faEalaPN,] with the last radical letter suppressed: (T in TT:) the pl. is banaAtN (T, S, Msb) alone: (S:) [and this is generally treated as a fem. pl. of the perfect, or sound, kind, although the t in binotN is said to be not a sign of the fem. gender; so that you say, raA^ayotu banaAtika I saw thy daughters; but sometimes] one says, raA^ayotu banaAtaka, with fet-h [as the case-ending], treating the t as a radical letter. (S.) It is said in the Bári' that when men and women are mixed together, the masc. pl. is made predominant; so that one says, banuw fulaAnK [meaning The sons and daughters, or the children, of such a one]; and even, AimoraA^apN mino banY tamiymK [A woman of the children of Temeem]; and accordingly, if banuw fulaAnK is applied to denote the persons to whom a legacy is left, the males and the females are included therein. (Msb.) ― -b2- When Aibon is applied to that which is not a human being, (IAmb, Msb,) to an irrational being, (Msb,) it has for its pl. banaAt: (IAmb, Msb:) thus the pl. of Aibonu maxaADK [A young male camel in his second year] is banaAtu maxaADK: (Mgh, Msb:) that of Aibonu labuwnK [A male camel that has entered upon his third year] is banaAtu labuwnK: (Msb:) and that of Aibonu naEo$K [Any one of the stars of the tail of Ursa Major or of that of Ursa Minor] is banaAtu naEo$K; but sometimes, by poetic licence, banuw naEo$K: and hence, or to make a distinction between the males and the females, the lawyers say, banuw All~abuwni. (IAmb, Msb.) ― -b3- ↓ banaAtN also signifies (tropical:) Dolls with which young girls play: (S, Mgh, K:) sing. binotN. (Mgh.) It occurs in this sense in a trad., in which 'Áïsheh speaks of her playing therewith (S, Mgh) when, being nine years of age, she was conducted as a bride to Mohammad. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Aibon is often prefixed to some other noun (T, M, Msb) that particularizes its signification, because of a close connexion between the two meanings: (Msb:) and so is ↓ binot. (T, M.) [Most of the
compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, as exs. of different kinds.] ― -b5- Aibonu AlT~iyni [The son of earth, or clay, meaning] Adam. (T.)

Aibonu All~ayoli Abn Allyl and Aibonu AlT~ariyqi The thief, or robber. (T.) Also the former, The wayfarer, or traveller; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so Aibonu Als~abiyli. (Msb, Er-Rághib.) Aibonu HarobK A warrior: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and Aibonu AlHarobi [the warrior; or] he who suffices for war, and who defends. (Msb.) Aibonu Ald~unoyaA The rich man. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aibonu A=waY [The jackal;] a certain beast of prey. (TA.) Aibonu EirosK The suroEuwb [or weasel]. (TA.) ― -b3- Aibonu A^adiymK A skin for water or milk made of one hide; and Aibonu A^adiymayoni one made of two hides; and Aibonu valaAvahi A=dimapK one made of three hides. (T.) ― -b4- Aibonapu Aljabali The echo. (T.) ― -b5- banaAtu biy^osK and banaAtu TabaqK and banaAtu baroHK and banaAtu A^awodaka Calamities, or misfortunes. (T.) ― -b6- Ru-beh said of a man who was mentioned to him, kaAna A_iHodaY banaAti masaAjidi A@ll~`hi; as though he asserted that He was one of the pebbles of the mosque [or rather of the mosques of God]. (S.)
AibonapN A^bAn A^bn A^bnh A^bnnh Abnh Abnp bnY {bn {bnh {bnp |b or A@bonapN: fem. of AibonN, which see.
AibonumN Abnm and AibonamN, or A@bonumN and A@bonamN: see AibonN, in three places.
A^abonaY * : quasi-pl. n. of AibonN which see.
AibonaY~N A^b A^bAn A^bnY A^bnny A^bny AbnY Abny bnY {bn {bny {bnyy |b |bny : see banawiY~N.
A@boniymaA * , for A@bonimaA: see a verse cited voce AibonN.
A^ubayonN * [an unused, or unusual, dim. of AibonN]: see what next follows.

A^ubayonK * , of the same measure as A^uEayomK, is the dim. of A^abonaY, which is like A^aEomaY, (Sb, IB, Mgh,) and is quasi-pl. of AibonN. (Mgh.) Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, A^ubayoniY laA taromuwA jamorapa AlEabaqabipi Hat~aY taToluEa Al$~amosu [O little (meaning dear) sons, cast not ye the pebble of the 'Akabeh (see jamorapN) until the sun rise], (TA,) or A^ubayoniY~a Alx [O my little sons &c.]: (Mgh, TA:) IAth says that the hemzeh is augmentative; and that there are differences of opinion respecting the form of the word and its meaning: some say that it is the dim. of A^abonaY, like A^aEomaY, a sing. word denoting a pl. meaning, or, accord. to some, a pl. of AibonN, as well as A^abonaA='N: some say that it is the dim. of AibonN; [and if so, we must read A^ubayoniY my little son;] but this requires consideration [more especially as it is followed by a pl. verb]: AO says that it is the dim. of baniY~a, pl. of AibonN with the affixed pronoun of the first pers. [sing.]; and this requires us to read A^ubayoniY~a. (TA.) J says, in the S, that the dim. of A^abonaA='N [pl. of AibonN] is ↓ A^ubayonaA='N, and, if you will, ↓ A^ubayonuwna; and he cites a verse in which occurs the expression A^ubayoniyka, [in the gen. case, meaning thy little sons,] and adds, it is as though its sing. were A_ibonN, with the disjunctive A, whence the dim. ↓ A^ubayonN, in the pl. A^ubayonuwna: but he should have said, as though its sing. were A^abonaY, like A^aEomaY, originally A^abonawu. (IB, TA.)
A^ubayonaA=' * : see what next precedes.
A^ubayonuwna * : see what next precedes.

mibonaApN mbnAh mbnAp mbnY (T, S, M, K) and mabonaApN (M, K) A niToE [like binaA='N, which see for an explanation]: (S, M, K:) and a sitor [i. e. curtain or the like]: (K:) or a thing in the form of a sitor: (M:) or a [tent of the kind called] qub~ap, made of skins, or hides: (IAar, T:) or a thing of skins, or hides, of like form to the qub~ap, which a woman places in, or at, the side of her tent (fiY kisori bayotihaA), and in which she dwells; and may-be she has sheep, or goats, and is content with the possession of these, exclusively of the other sheep, or goats, for herself and her garments [and app. for making of their skins her mbnAh]; and she has a covering (A_izaAr) [extended] in the middle of the bayot [or tent], within, to protect her from the heat, and from the violent rain, so that she and her clothes are not wetted: (Aboo-'Adnán, T:) or, accord. to As, a mat (HaSiyrN), or a niToE, which the trafficker spreads upon the things that he sells: and they used to put the mats (AlHuSur) upon the A^anoTaAE [pl. of niToE], and go round about with them [in the market]: the mbnAp is thus called because it is made of skins joined together: (T:) also a receptacle of the kind called Eayobap: (M, K:) such is said to be its meaning: (S:) pl. mabaAnK. (T.)
maboniY~N mbnY mbny [Built, &c.: see 1]. A^aroDN maboniy~apN means A^aroDN maboniY~N fiyhaA [Land built in or upon]; and is deemed a chaste phrase. (Mgh.)

muban~FY mbnY mbny
Raised high; applied to a palace, or pavilion. (M, TA.)

mubotanFY mbtnY mbtny [pass. part. n. of AibotanaAhu] is used in the place of the inf. n. [of that verb, agreeably with many other instances, or accord. to a common licence], meaning The act of building, framing, or constructing. (TA.)

1 bahaA^ bihi * , and bahiy^a, (AZ, S, Mgh, K,) [aor.
bahaAa ,] and bahuw^a, (K,) [aor.
bahuAa ] inf. n. baho'N and buhuwo'N (AZ, S, K) and bahaA='N; (K;) and bh ↓ AbthA^; (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA;) He was, or became, sociable, friendly, or familiar, with him, or it; (AZ, S, Mgh, K;) namely, a man, (AZ, S,) or a thing; (Mgh;) and loved, or liked, his, or its, nearness: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) and he became familiar with it so as to have little, or no, reverence for it, or awe of it. (Mgh, TA.) bahawoA bihi occurs in a trad., as they relate it, for bahaw^uwA bh: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and ↓ yabotahiY, in a verse of El-Aashà, for yabotahiy^u. (As, O, TS, L.) ― -b2- maA bahaA^otu lahu I did not understand it; or I did not know it; (ISk, S, K;) as also maA baA^ahotu lahu. (ISk, S.)
8 A_ibotahaAa see 1, in two places.

naAqapN bahaA='N nAqp bhA='
A she-camel familiar with, or accustomed to, her milker; (As, S;) that offers no opposition to him. (K.) -A2- bahaA='N as syn. with HusonN belongs to art. bhw. (S, &c.)

1 buhita bht bhtt , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the most chaste form of the verb in the sense here following, (S, TA,) and that which most commonly obtains, and the only form allowed by Th and IKt; (TA;) and bahita, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
bahata ; (Msb, K;) and bahuta, (S, L, Msb, K,) in which the dammeh is said to give intensiveness to the signification, as in qaDuwa Alr~ajulu, (TA,) aor.
bahuta ; (Msb, K;) and bahata, aor.
bahuta (K) and
bahata ; (TA;) inf. n. bahotN; (JK, K;) He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, and unable to see his right course; (JK, S, Msb, K;) not knowing what to prefer nor what to postpone: (TA in art. A$r:) he looked at a thing that he saw with a look of wonder: (A, TA:) he was, or became, affected with wonder: (JK:) he was, or became, cut short, (AnoqaTaEa, K, TA,) and was silent, being confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (TA:) he (an adversary in a dispute or litigation) was overcome by an argument, an allegation, or a plea. (L.) All these forms occur in different readings of the saying in the Kur [ii. 260], fabuhita A@l~a*iY kafara and fabahita &c., (IJ, TA,) explained in the Wá'ee as meaning, And he who disbelieved remained in confusion, or perplexity, not seeing his right course, looking as one in wonder: (Lb, TA:) but accord. to him who reads fabahata, the word Al*Y may hold the place of a noun in the accus. case [as will be seen from what follows]. (IJ, TA.) -A2- bahatahu, aor.
bahata , (S, Msb,) inf. n. bahotN, (S, K,) He, or it, caused him to become confounded, perplexed, or amazed, not seeing his right course: (Zj, Msb: [Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, assigns this meaning to ↓ bh~thu:]) or took him unawares, or by surprise, or unexpectedly, or suddenly. (S, K.) Zj cites as an ex. of the former meaning the saying in the Kur [xxi. 41], taA^otiyhimo bagotapF fatabohatuhumo, i. e., It shall come upon them suddenly, or unawares, and cause them to become confounded, &c.: (TA: and so Bd and Jel explain it:) or, and shall overcome them: (Bd:) J cites the same as an ex. of the latter of the two meanings in the preceding sentence; but his doing so requires consideration; for the meaning which he gives is taken from the word bgtp; not from Albahotu. (MF, TA.) [But it is said also that] mubaAhatapN [inf. n. of ↓ bAhthu] signifies The taking, or coming upon, [one] unawares, by surprise, or unexpectedly. (JK.) ― -b2- bahatahu, aor.
bahata , (S, A, K, &c.,) inf. n. bahotN and bahatN and buhotaAnN, (S, K,) or the last is a simple subst., (Msb,) He calumniated him; slandered him; accused him falsely; said against him that which he had not done: (S, A, K:) [or he did so in such a manner as to make one to be confounded, or perplexed, or amazed, at the falsity
of the charge, and not to see his right course: (see buhotaAnN, below:)] he lied against him; forged a lie, or lies, against him; and i. q. qaAbalahu biAlka*ibi [he accused him to his face falsely, or with falsehood]; (TA;) Albahotu signifies AisotiqobaAluka A^axaAka bimaA layosa fiyhi [thy accusing thy brother, or fellow, to his face, of that which is not in him]: (JK:) and bahatahaA, aor.
bahata , inf. n. bahotN, he accused her falsely of adultery; and forged a lie against her. (Msb.) [See also AigotaAbahu.] In the saying of Abu-n-Nejm,
sub~iY AlHamaApa waA@bohatiY EalayohaA
[Revile thou the mother-in-law, and calumniate her, or forge lies against her], ElY is [said by J to be] redundant, or pleonastic; for one does not say, baEata Ealayohi, but only bahatahu. (S.) Upon this, F says, in the K, that faA@bohatiY ElyhA [thus in the K] is a mistake; that J is in error, and that the right reading is faA@nohatiY ElyhA, with n: but this assertion made by F depends upon the authority of relaters of the verse in which the word in question occurs. (MF.) IB says that AbhtY may be here rendered trans. by means of ElY because it is syn. with AifotariY, which is so rendered trans., in like manner as is done in other instances, of which he gives an ex. from the Kur [xxiv. 63], yuxaAlifuwna Eano A^amorihi, meaning yaxorujuwna En Amrh: he adds that, accord. to J, En in this ex. should be considered redundant; but that En and ElY are not used redundantly like b. (TA.) ― -b3- bahata AlfaHola Eani Aln~aAqapi He removed the stallion from the she-camel in order that a stallion of more generous race might cover her. (TA.)
2 bah~ata see 1.

3 bAhthu bAhY bAht bAhth bAhtp bAhtth b|hth |hp , inf. n. mubaAhatapN: see 1. ― -b2- [Also He engaged with him in mutual calumny, slander, or false accusation: a meaning indicated, but not expressed, in the A.] You say, bayonahumaA mubaAhatapN [Between them two is mutual calumniation, &c.]: and EaAdatuhu A^ano yubaAHiva wayubaAhita [His custom is to engage with another in mutual scrutiny of secrets, or faults, or the like, and in mutual calumniation, &c.]: and walaA tamaAqatuwA ↓ laA tabaAhatuwA [Calumniate ye not one another, &c., nor hate ye one another on account of any foul, or evil, affair]. (A.) ― -b3- And He confounded, perplexed, or amazed, him (namely, his hearer,) by what he forged against him. (TA.)
6 tabaAohata see 3.
bahotN bht bhtt : see buhotaAnN. -A2- A certain well-known kind of stone. (K.)

buhotN bht bhtt : see buhotaAnN, in two places. -A2- A certain sidereal computation, or calculation; being [that of] the direct course of stars in a day: [in Persian, a planet's motion in any given time: (Johnson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict.:)] thought by Az to be not Arabic. (TA.)

buhotaAnN bhtAn and ↓ bahiytapN signify the same [when the former is used as a subst.; i. e. A calumny, slander, or false accusation]: (S, A, Msb: [see 1:]) or both signify, the former as explained by Aboo-Is-hák, and the latter as explained in the K, a falsehood by reason of which one is confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (TA; [in which it seems to be indicated that ↓ buhotN signifies the same;]) from Albahotu as meaning “ the being confounded ” &c.: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA:) the former is a subst. signifying [also] a false accusation of adultery against a woman; and a forgery of a lie against her: (Msb:) and ↓ the latter, [and the former also, simply,] a lying, or lie, or falsehood; (K;) and so ↓ buhotN (K) and ↓ bahotN. (TA.) buhotaAnFA waA_ivomFA mubiynFA, in the Kur iv. 24, is said to mean Falsely accusing of adultery, and acting in a manifestly sinful or criminal manner: (Bd:) or it means acting wrongfully &c. (Bd, Jel.) You say, ↓ ramaAhu biAlbahiytapi [He accused him with, or of, calumny, &c.]. (A.) And ↓ yaA illobahiytapi, with kesr to the [prep.] l, [i. e., O, come to my aid, or succour, on account of the calumny! &c.; for it is] a phrase used in calling for aid, or succour. (S.) [And if you would express wonder, you say, ↓ yaA allobahiytapi, with fet-h to the prep. l, i. e. O the calumny! &c.]

bahuwtN bhwt hwtp [A great, or frequent, calumniator, slanderer, or false-accuser; as also ↓ bah~aAtN, mentioned in the S only as an epithet applied to him who calumniates, slanders, or accusely falsely;] an intensive epithet from Albahotu; (IAth;) [i. e.] an intensive form of the act. part. n. from AlbuhotaAn [inf. n. of bahatahu]: (Mgh:) or i. q. ↓ mubaAhitN; (K;) i. e., one who confounds, or perplexes, or amazes, the hearer, by what he forges against him: (TA:) and one who falsely accuses a woman of adultery, and forges a lie against her: (Msb:) pl. buhutN (IAth, Mgh, Msb, K) and buhotN, and, accord. to the K, also buhuwtN; but ISd and MF hold it to be pl. of baAhitN, not of bahuwtN; the former observing, that a word of the measure faAEilN is one of those which have a pl. of the measure fuEuwlN, but not so one of the measure faEuwlN; and that, as to the saying of A'Obeyd, that Eu*uwbN is pl. of Ea*uwbN, it is a mistake; for it is only pl. of EaA*ibN, and the pl. of Ea*uwbN is Eu*ubN. (TA. [But see art. E*b.])
bahiytN bhy bhyt , see mabohuwtN, in two places.
bahiytapN bhy bhyth bhytp : see buhotaAnN, in five places.
bah~aAtN bhAt : see bahuwtN: -A2- and see mabohuwtN.

baAhitN bAhY bAht bAhtt : see mabohuwtN, in two places. -A2- Also act. part. n. [of bahatahu; signifying Causing to become confounded, &c.: and calumniating, &c.:] from AlbuhotaAnu: (Mgh:) buhuwtN, as mentioned above, is held by ISd and MF to be a pl. of this word; not of bahuwtN, q. v. (TA.)

mabohuwtN mbhwt
Confounded, perplexed, or amazed, and unable to see his right course: (S, K:) [other (similar) meanings may be seen from explanations of buhita:] accord. to Ks and the S and Sgh and the K, one should not say ↓ baAhitN nor ↓ bahiytN; but there is no reason in analogy why he who says bahata, like naSara and manaEa, should not say thus: (TA:) Lb says, in the Expos. of the Fs, that they said ↓ baAhitN and ↓ bah~aAtN [which latter is an intensive form] and ↓ bahiytN, which [last] may be considered as having the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlN, like mabohuwtN, or that of the measure faAEilN, like baAhitN; but the former is the more agreeable with analogy, and the more probable. (MF, TA) ― -b2- Also Calumniated, slandered, or falsely accused. (S.)
mubaAhitN mbAht : see bahuwtN.

1 bahuja bhj , aor.
bahuja , (AZ, S, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. bahaAjapN (AZ, S, L, K) and bahojapN (AZ, L, [but some seem to regard this as a simple subst.,]) and bahajaAnN, (L,) He, or it, was, or became, beautiful, or goodly: (AZ, S, L, Msb, K:) or beautiful in colour: or beautiful and bright or splendid: or it (a plant) was, or became, beautiful and bright; and he (a man) was, or became, characterized by a laughing, or happy, appearance of the beautiful parts of the face, as the cheeks, and the lines of the forehead: or by the appearance of joy, gladness, or happiness; or by a joyful, glad, or happy, aspect, or appearance. (L.) You say also, bahija Aln~abaAtu, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) The plant, or herbage, was, or became, beautiful [&c.]. (TA, [but this is probably a tropical signification, from bahija in the sense here following.]) ― -b2- bahija, (S, A, L, K,) with kesr, (S,) aor.
bahaja , (K,) inf. n. bahajN; (L;) and ↓ Abthj; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) You say, bahija bihi, (S, A,) and lahu; (TA;) and ↓ Abthj bihi; (A, Msb;) He rejoiced in it, or at it; or became rejoiced by it, or at it. (S, A, Msb, TA.) [See also 10.] -A2- bahaja, (S, K,) aor.
bahaja ; (K;) and ↓ Abhj; (S, A, K;) the latter of which is the more approved; (TA;) It (a thing, TA, or an affair or event, S, A) rejoiced; or made joyful, glad, or happy; (S, A, K;) a person. (S, A.)

2 bh~j bhj , (ISd, L,) inf. n. tabohiyjN, (K,) He beautified; rendered beautiful, or goodly. (ISd, L, K.) ISd says, I have not heard this, except in the saying of El-'Ajjáj,
daEo *aA wabah~ijo HasabFA mubah~ajaA
as though meaning [Leave thou this subject, and] beautify, or adorn, the more this nobility [already beautified, or adorned,] by thy describing it. (L.)

3 baAhjhu bAhjh bAhjp , (A, K,) inf. n. mubaAhajapN, (A,) He vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness; [as expl. in the TK; or in glory, or excellence;] syn. baAhaAhu (A, K) and baAraAhu, (K,) both of these meaning the same. (TA.)

4 A^abohaja see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- A^abohajati AlA^aroDu The land, or earth, became beautiful, or goodly, (S, L, K,) or beautiful and bright or splendid, (L,) in its plants, or herbage. (S, L, K.)
6 tbAhj Alr~awoDu tbAhj AlrwD (assumed tropical:) The meadows, or gardens, became abundant in blossoms or flowers [as though vying, one with another, in beauty, or goodliness: see 3]. (K, TA.)
8 A_ibotahaja see 1, in two places.

10 Astbhj Astbhj
i. q. Aisotabo$ara [i. e. He rejoiced, or became rejoiced; bihi at it, or by it; or at, or by, the annunciation of it]. (K.) [See also bahija.]
bahojN bhj , fem. with p: see bahiyjN, in two places.

bahijN bhj
Joyful, glad, or happy; (S, K;) as also ↓ bahiyjN (S, A, K) and ↓ mubotahijN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also bahiyjN.

bahojapN bhj bhjh bhjp
Beauty, or goodliness: (S, A, L, Msb, K:) or beauty of colour of a thing: or its beauty and brightness or splendour: or in plants or herbage, beauty and brightness or splendour; and in a man, the laughing, or happy, appearance of the beautiful parts of the face, as the cheeks, and the lines of the forehead: or the appearance of joy, gladness, or happiness; or joyfulness, gladness, or happiness, of aspect or appearance. (L.) You say rawoDapN *aAtu bahojapK gaAlibapK [A meadow, or garden, of surpassing beauty, &c.]. (A.) And rajulN *uw bahojapK A man possessed of beauty, or goodliness: (S:) or of beauty and brightness, &c. (L.) ― -b2- Also Happiness, joy, or gladness. (Ham p. 403.)

bahiyjN bhyj hyj
Beautiful, or goodly; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ bahijN (Ham p. 403) and ↓ bahojN: (AZ, TA:) or beautiful in colour: or beautiful and bright or splendid: or, applied to a plant, it has this last meaning; and, applied to a man, characterized by a laughing, or happy, appearance of the beautiful parts of the face, as the cheeks, and the lines of the forehead: or characterized by the appearance of joy, gladness, or happiness; having a joyful, glad, or happy, aspect or appearance: (L:) the fem. epithet is ↓ mibohaAjN. (A, K, TA: [in the CK mabohAjN.]) It is applied to a plant, or herbage, (S, A,) in the Kur xxii. 5 and l. 7. (S.) And ↓ mibohaAjN is applied to a woman, as meaning One in whom beauty, or goodliness, &c., predominates; (L, TA;) as also ↓ bahojapN; (TA;) pl. of the former, mabaAhiyju: (A, TA:) and to a camel's hump, meaning (tropical:) fat; (A, K;) because beauty, or goodliness, is combined [in this case] with fatness; pl. as above. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also bahijN.
mibohaAjN mbhAj : see bahiyjN, in two places.
mubotahijN mbthj : see bahijN.

1 baharahu bhr bhrh bhrp hr hrp , (S, A, Msb,) aor.
bahara , (Msb,) inf. n. bahorN, (S, Msb, K,) He overcame him: (S, A, Msb, K:) he overpowered him; subdued him: (TA:) he surpassed him; excelled him. (Msb.) See also 3. You say, baharato fulaAnapu Aln~isaA='a Such a woman surpassed the [other] women in beauty. (S.) And bahara [alone] He excelled in knowledge &c.; or he was, or became, accomplished, or perfect, in every excellence, and in goodliness. (S, K.) And bahara Alqamaru, (S, K,) or bahara Alqamaru Aln~ujuwma, (TA,) aor.
bahara , (K,) inf. n. buhuwrN, (TA,) (tropical:) The moon overcame with its light the light of the stars. (S, K, TA.) And baharati Al$~amosu AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) The light of the sun overspread the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bahara, aor.
bahara , (TA,) inf. n. bahorN and buhuwrN, (K,) (tropical:) It shone, or shone brightly: (K, TA:) and Als~aHaAbapu ↓ tabah~arati (tropical:) The cloud shone, or shone brightly. (K.) -A2- baharahu, (S, A,) aor.
bahara , inf. n. buhorN, (S,) also signifies (tropical:) It (a load, or burden, S, A, and running, A) [caused him to be out of breath; interrupted his breathing; (see buhorN;)] caused to pant, or breathe [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (S, A.) ― -b2- Also, (ISh, JK, TA,) inf. n. bahorN, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He stopped his breath by beating, or by squeezing his throat, or throttling him, or by any other means: (ISh, TA:) (assumed tropical:) he plied him, or worked him, (EaAlajahu,) until he became out of breath, or until he panted: (JK, TA:) (assumed tropical:) he imposed upon him a thing that was above his power, or ability. (K, TA.) A poet says,
A_in~a Albaxiyla A_i*aA saA^alota baharotahu
Verily the niggardly, when thou askest of him, thou stoppest his breath. (ISh, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] buhira, i. q. Anbhr, as explained below. (K.) -A3- baharahaA, (JK,) or baharahaA bibuhotaAnK, (TA,) inf. n. bahorN, (K,) He reproached her, or accused her, falsely; (JK;) he aspersed her; calumniated her; or brought a false accusation against her. (K, * TA.) You say, baharahaA bika*aA He reproached her falsely with, or accused her falsely of, such a thing. (JK.) [See also 8.]

3 baAohara ↓ bAhr SaAHibahu fabaharahu (K, * TA,) inf. n. mubaAharapN and bihaArN, (TA,) [aor. of the latter verb, accord. to rule,
bahura , not
bahara ,] He contended, or disputed, or vied, with his companion for glory, or superiority, or excellence, and overcame him. (K, * TA.)

4 Abhr A^bhr Abhr bhr
He did, or effected, or he said, or uttered, what was wonderful; syn. jaA='a biAlEajabi. (K.)
5 tabah~ara see 1.

7 Anbhr A^nbhr Anbhr {nbhr , (S, A, K,) and ↓ Abthr, (TA,) and ↓ buhira, like EuniYa, (K,) (tropical:) He was, or became, out of breath; his breath became interrupted, by reason of fatigue [or running, or by hard work, or bearing a heavy load; see 1]: (K:) he panted, or breathed [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (S, A.)

8 Abthr A^bthr Abthr {bthr
He arrogated to himself, or professed, a thing falsely. (S, K.) El-Akhtal says,
wamaA biY A_ino madaHotuhumu A@botihaAru
And there is not in me, if I praise them, false profession: (S:) or Abthr signifies he said what was false, and swore to it. (TA.) ― -b2- He said that he had transgressed, or acted vitiously, or committed adultery or fornication, when he had not done so. (K.) And Abthr bi*anobK He asserted himself to have committed a crime, or sin, when he had not done so. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- AbthrhA He asserted falsely that he had had sexual intercourse with her: (M, TA:) AbtArhA signifies “ he asserted the same with truth: ” (TA:) or Abthr signifies he charged, or upbraided, a person with that which was in him; (K, TA;) and AbtAr, “ he charged, or upbraided, with that which was not in him. ” (TA.) See an ex. voce baAra in art. bwr. ― -b4- Also He (a poet) mentioned her (a girl) in his poetry. (JK.) Aubotuhira bifulaAnapa He became, or was rendered, notorious, or infamous, on account of such a woman [with whom he was said to have had an illicit connexion]. (S, K.) -A2- See also 7.

11 AbhAr~ All~ayolu AbhAr Allyl , (S, A, K,) inf. n. AibohiyraArN, (S,) The night reached its middle point; (As, S, A, K;) from buhorapN signifying the “ middle ” of a thing: (A:) or reached the point when all its stars appeared and shone: (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer:) or became thickly dark: (K:) or for the most part passed: (S, K:) or reached the point when about one third of it remained. (K.) And AbhAr~ EalayonaA All~ayolu The night became long to us. (S.) And AbhAr~ Aln~ahaAru The day reached the point when the sun had become high. (TA.)

bahorN bhr hr inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) You say, bahorFA lahu, an imprecation, meaning May he be overcome! (A:) or i. q. taEosFA lahu [may he fall, having stumbled! or stumble and fall! &c.]: (AA, S, K:) and thus used [app. in the latter sense] as an imprecation, accord. to Sb, it has no verb, but is put in the accus. case on the supposition of a verb. (TA.) One says also, ↓ quhorFA wabuhorFA, with damm to each. (TA in art. qhr.) And bahorFA maA A^asoxaAhu [May he fall, having stumbled! &c.: how bountiful is he!], like as one says taEosFA lahu [when not meaning it to be understood as an imprecation]. (A.) ― -b2- It also signifies Distance, or remoteness: (K:) and remoteness from good or prosperity. (TA.) ― -b3- Disappointment. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- Wonder; syn. EajabN. (K.) One says, bahorA meaning EajabFA [for A^aEojabu EajabFA I do wonder: or wonderful!]. (S.) So [sometimes] in the phrase bahorFA lahu [I do wonder at him, or it]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- Love. (K.) Accord. to some, bahorFA lakumo means Love to you. (JK.) ― -b6- AlA^azowaAju valAavapN zawoju bahorK wazawoju dahorK wazawoju mahorK is a saying of the Arabs, meaning Husbands are three: a husband who overcomes the eyes by his goodliness, (S,) or a husband of noble race, though he may be of little wealth; (TA;) and a husband prepared for the accidents, or calamities, of fortune; and a husband from whom a dowry is got, (S,) or a husband who has not nobility of race, and who therefore doubles the dowry to make himself desired. (TA.) -A2- (assumed tropical:) Distress that affects the breath or respiration, syn. karobN, (K, TA,) [particularly] of a camel when he is spurred on, or of a man when a labour above his power is imposed upon him. (TA.)

buhorN bhr hr : see bahorN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The state of being out of breath; interruption of the breath, by reason of fatigue, (K, TA,) [or by bearing a heavy load, (see 1,)] or by hard work, and by running: (TA:) a panting, or breathing [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (S, A, TA,) -A2- Wide-spreading land; a wide tract of land; as also ↓ buhorapN [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- A country, or district; or a city, or town; syn. baladN: (K:) or the middle thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- The middle, and best part, (sir~, and xayor, for the former of which words we find $ar~ erroneously put in the copies of the K, TA,) of a valley; as also ↓ buhorapu [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

buhorapN bhr bhrh bhrp hr hrp
Plain, or even, or soft, land or ground: or a wide tract of land between mountains. (L.) ― -b2- See also buhorN, in two places. ― -b3- The middle (S, A, K) of a valley, and of the night, and of a horse, (S, K,) and of a camel's saddle, (TA,) and of a ring, (K,) or of a thing. (A.)

bahaArN bhAr hAry
A certain plant, of sweet odour; (K;) the [plant called] EaraAr, which is also called Eayonu Albaqari; [buphthalmum, or ox-eye;] it is the bahaAru Albar~i, a crisping, or curling, plant, having a yellow flower; growing in the days of the spring (Alr~abiyE), and called EaraArapN: (S:) As says, The EaraAr is the bahaAru Albar~i: and Az says, The EaraArap is the xasowap; and I regard bhAr as a Persian word. (TA.) ― -b2- Perfume. (Msb.) ― -b3- And hence applied to The flowers of the desert. (Msb.) ― -b4- And Anything goodly, or beautiful, and bright, or shining. (K, TA.)

buhaArN bhAr hAry
A certain thing with which one weighs; (S, Msb, K;) the weight of three hundred pounds: (Fr, IAar, A'Obeyd, S, K:) thought by A'Obeyd to be not Arabic, but Coptic; (S;) having this signification in Coptic; (JK;) but thought by Az to be pure Arabic: (TA:) or four hundred pounds: or six hundred: or a thousand: (K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) one half of a load (K, TA) borne by a camel, (TA,) containing four hundred pounds, (K, TA,) in the dial. of Syria: (TA:) or a load borne by a camel: (Kt:) or a camel-load of household-goods or furniture and utensils: (As:) and commodities, or utensils, or the like, of the sea; expl. by mataAEa AlbaHori [perhaps a mistranscription for mataAEa Alt~ajori or Alt~ujuri, commodities, or goods, of the merchants: the poet Bureyk El-Hudhalee speaks of camels bearing buhaAr]. (JK, K.) It is said that Talhah the son of 'Obeyd-Allah left a hundred buhaAr, in each bhAr of which was three hundred-weight of gold (S, TA) and silver; (TA;) bhAr being thus made to signify a receptacle: (S, TA:) accord. to As and Kt, the meaning is, a hundred camel-loads. (TA.)

bahiyrN bhyr hyr and ↓ mabohuwrN (A, K) and ↓ manobahirN (A) [and ↓ mubotahirN] (tropical:) Out of breath; having his breath interrupted, by reason of fatigue [or running, or by hard work, or bearing a heavy load; see 1 and 7]; panting, or breathing [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (A.)

baAhirN bAhr [act. part. n. of 1, Overcoming; &c. And particularly,] (assumed tropical:) Overcoming in light. (JK.) [Hence,] qamarN baAhirN (tropical:) A moon that overcomes with its light the light of the stars. (S, A.) And AlbaAhiru (tropical:) The moon; because it outshines the stars: (Msb:) or the full moon. (JK.)

A^aboharu * [The aorta; so in the present day;] a certain vein [or artery], (S, A, K,) in the back, (K,) lying within, or at the inner side of, the back-bone (A'Obeyd, A, TA) and the heart, (A'Obeyd, TA,) the severing of which causes death: (A'Obeyd, S, A:) it is name given to each of two veins [or arteries, or the two portions of the aorta which are called the aorta ascendens and aorta descendens,] which issue from the heart, and from which then branch off all the other arteries: (S:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) the wariyd [i. e. either the carotid artery or the external jugular vein] of the neck: (K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) [the vein in the arm called] the A^akoHal: (K:) or, accord. to the more full description of IAth, a certain vein [or artery] arising from the head, and extending to the foot, and having arteries which communicate with most of the extremities and the body: what is in the head is called the naAm~ap; and hence the saying, A^asokata A@ll~`hu naAm~atahu, meaning “God killed him,” or “may God kill him!” and it extends to the throat, and is there called the wariyd; and to the chest, and is there called [especially] the A^abohar [meaning the aorta ascendens]; and to the back, and is there called the watiyn [meaning the aorta descendens]; and the heart is suspended to it; and it extends to the thigh, and is there called the nasaA; and to the shank, and is there called the SaAfin: the ' in it is augmentative. (TA.) You say, qaTaEa A^aboharahu [It severed his aorta]; meaning (tropical:) it (pain) destroyed him. (A.) ― -b2- Also The back: (K:) or the place of the vein [or artery] so called. (As, in art. xdE of the S.) One says, fulaAnN $adiydN AlA^abohari Such a one is strong in the back: (TA:) or strong in the place of the vein [or artery] called the Abhr. (As, ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And The back of the curved part of the extremity of a bow: (K:) or the part between the TAy^if and the kuloyap: (S, K:) in the bow is its kabid, which is the part between the two extremities of its string or the like; then, next to this, the kuloyap; then, next to this, the A^abohar; then, the TaAy^if; then, the siy^ap, which is the curved part of the extremity. (As.) ― -b4- And A tent-pole. (JK.) ― -b5- And The shorter side of a feather: (K:) [or] so A^abaAhiru [which is the pl.]: (JK:) [or] the latter signifies the feathers (Lh, S) of the wing (Lh) of a bird (Lh, S) next after those called AlxawaAfiY, (Lh,) [and] next [before] those called AlkulaY: (S:) the first of them are those called AlqawaAdimu, (S,) four in number, in the fore part of the wing; (Lh;) the next, AlmanaAkibu, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) the next, AlxawaAfiY, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) the next, AlA^abaAhiru, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) and the next, AlkulaY [which are also four]. (S.)
mabohuwrN mbhwr : see bahiyrN.
mubotahirN mbthr : see bahiyrN.
munobahir mnbhr : see bahiyrN.

Q. 1 buhorija bhrj hrj , in the pass. form, (Kt, Msb,) inf. n. bahorajapN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) was taken otherwise than by, or in, the right way: (Msb:) or (tropical:) it was turned away, or conveyed by turning away, (Kt, K, TA,) from the beaten way or road, (Kt, TA,) or from the direct, or right, main road. (K, TA.) And bahoraja bihimo (tropical:) It (the road, A) lead them otherwise than in the beaten track. (T, A, TA.) [See bahorajN, from which the verb is derived.] ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a man's blood) was made to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; was made allowable to be taken or shed. (Mgh.) And bahoraja damahu (tropical:) He made his blood to be of no account, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) A^amaA A_i*o bahorajotaniY falaA A^a$orabuhaA A^abadFA (K, * TA) (tropical:) Verily, since thou hast made me [meaning my offence] to pass unnoticed, or hast taken no account of me, (hadarotaniY,) by annulling in respect of me the prescribed castigation, (K, TA,) I will not drink it (i. e. wine) henceforth: (TA:) said by Aboo-Mihjen (K, TA) Eth-Tha- kafee, (TA,) to Ibn-Abee-Wakkás. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, bahoraja AlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) He made the place free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.)

Q. 2 tabahoraja bhrj tbhrj
It (a place) became, or was made, free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.)

bahorajN bhrj hrj an arabicized word, (T, S, Mgh, L, TA,) from nabahoraho, (T, Mgh, L, TA,) which is Persian; (L, TA;) or, as some say, it is an Indian word, originally nabaholaho, meaning Bad, whence the Persian nabahoraho, and hence the arabicized bahorajN; (TA;) applied to a dirhem, as meaning bad; (Kr, S;) false; (S, El-Marzookee;) adulterated; (Shifá el-Ghaleel, El-Marzookee;) of bad silver; (A, Mgh, L, Msb;) with which one cannot buy: (IAar, TA:) or, as some say, in which the silver is predominant: or, accord. to IAar, of which the die has been falsified: (Mgh:) or not coined in the government-mint: (Lb, TA:) and ↓ muboharajN signifies the same, applied to a dirhem; (Lh, A, Mgh;) and so ↓ nabahorajN; (Lh, El-Marzookee;) but [Mtr says,] I have not found it with n, except on the authority of Lh (Mgh;) and IKh says that it is a word of the vulgar: (TA:) the pl. [of bhrj] is bahaAriju, and [of nbhrj,] nabahorajaAtu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, (Mgh,) (tropical:) Bad; (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) and false, or of no account; (S, A, Mgh, K;) applied to a thing (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb) of any kind: (A, Mgh, L:) anything rejected; not received or accepted; rejected as wrong or bad; as also ↓ nabahorajN: (TA:) and a thing is termed ↓ mubahorajN when it is as though it were cast away, and not an object of emulous desire or envy, or not in request. (El-Marzookee, TA.) You say, kalaAmN bahorajN (tropical:) Bad language. (A, L.) And EamalN bahorajN (tropical:) A bad action. (A, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Allowed or allowable [to any person, to be taken or let alone, or to be possessed or made use of or done]; made allowable, free, or lawful. (K.) You say, damN bahorajN (tropical:) Blood made to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; allowed to be taken or shed; (A, L;) as also ↓ mubahorajN. (K.) And makaAnN bahorajN (assumed tropical:) A place free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.) And ↓ maA='N mubahorajN (assumed tropical:) A water left free to those who come to water at it. (A, K, * TA.)
mubahorajN mbhrj : see bahorajN, in four places.
nabahorajN bhrj nbhrj : see bahorajN, in two places.

1 bahaZahu bhZ bhZh bhZp , aor.
bahaZa , inf. n. bahoZN, It (a load, or burden,) oppressed him by its weight, and he was unable to bear it: (S, M, TA:) or pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him. (T, TA.) [And hence,] (tropical:) It (an affair, M, K, or anything, T) oppressed him by its weight, (T, M,) and he was unable to bear it: (M:) or overpowered him, and pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him; (Jm, K;) and so bahaDahu, as heard by Aboo-Turáb from an Arab of the desert; but no one has followed him in this. (Az, TA.) You say also, bahaZa Alr~aAHilapa He loaded the riding-camel heavily, and fatigued it. (K.)

A^amorN baAhiZN *
A distressing, grievous, or difficult, affair. (S, CK, but wanting in two MS. copies of the K.) And baAhiZN [alone], (CK, but wanting in two MS. copies of the K,) or ↓ baAhiZapN, (O, TA,) (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune. (O, K, TA.)
baAhiZapN bAhZ bAhZh bAhZp : see baAhiZN.

mabohuwZN mbhwZ
Oppressed by the weight of a load, and unable to bear it. (S.) [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) Any one having a thing required of him which he is unable to do, or which he cannot find. (TA.) And qironN mabohuwZN (assumed tropical:) An opponent, or an adversary, overcome, or vanquished. (TA.)

1 bahiqa bhq , aor.
bahaqa , inf. n. bahaqN, It (the body) was, or became, affected with [the disease termed] bahaqN. (Msb.)

bahaqN bhq [The mild species of leprosy termed “alphus,” or “vitiligo alba;” in Hebrew בֹּהַק;] a whiteness, less than what is termed baraSN, that comes upon the external skin of a man; (JK;) a whiteness that affects the skin, (S,) or body, (Mgh, Msb,) differing from the colour of the latter; (S, Msb;) not from what is termed baraS, (S, Mgh,) or not baraS: (Msb:) and, accord. to IF, a blackness that affects the skin; [i. e. the species of leprosy termed “melas,” or “lepra maculosa nigra;”] or a colour differing from that of the skin: (Msb:) a thin whiteness that affects the exterior of the cuticle, by reason of a bad state of the temperament of the part, inclining to coldness, and the predominance of the phlegm over the blood: the black [species] thereof alters (yugay~iru, in the CK yaEotariY,) the skin to blackness, by reason of the mixing of the black bile with the blood. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bahaqu AlHajari (assumed tropical:) [Lichen, or liverwort;] a certain plant; (K;) i. e. Haz~aAzu AlHajari [more commonly called Haz~aAzu AlS~axori]: (TA:) or i. q. Aljawozu Aljanoduma, (K, TA,) or Aljawoza janoduma, (CK,) [evidently from the Persian jawozi Ganoduma explained in Johnson's Pers. Ar. and Engl. Dict. as “sandix-gum, juniper:” but SM says that] this is a certain plant, the body [or substance] of which is muHab~ab [app. meaning composed of globules or the like; probably a particular species of lichen, with spherical cells]. (TA.)
A^abohaqu * , applied to a man, Affected with [the disease termed] bahaqN: (JK, Msb:) fem. bahoqaA='u. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] so applied, (assumed tropical:) Very white. (TA.)

1 bahala Aln~aAqapa bhl AlnAqh bhl AlnAqp , [aor.
bahala , inf. n. baholN,] He left the she-camel without a SiraAr [bound upon her udder to prevent her being sucked]; (Bd in iii. 54;) as also ↓ AblhA: (S:) or he left her to be milked; or allowed her being milked: (Z, TA:) and ↓ the latter, he loosed her SiraAr, and left her young one at liberty to such her; (K;) and he left her to herself (K, TA) to be milked by any one who pleased. (TA.) ― -b2- And bahalahu, (S, K,) aor.
bahala , (K,) [inf. n. baholN,] He left him (S, K) to his own will, or wish, (S,) or to his own opinion, or judgment; (K;) as also ↓ Abhlhu: (S, K:) or the former is said in relation to the free man; and ↓ the latter, in relation to the slave; (Zj, K;) and signifies also [simply] he left him to himself. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) baholN signifies [also] The act of cursing. (S, Msb, K.) You say, bahalahu, aor.
bahala , inf. n. baholN, He cursed him. (Msb.) And bahala A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA May God curse such a one! (K, TA.) -A2- bahilato, aor.
bahala , inf. n. bahalN, She (a camel) had her SiraAr loosed, and her young one left to suck her. (K.)

3 mubaAhalapN mbAhlh mbAhlp The act of cursing each other: (S, Mgh, Msb:) inf. n. of bAhlhu He cursed him, being cursed by him: (Msb:) [or rather] baAhalotuhu signifies I joined with him in imprecating the curse of God upon whichever of us did wrong. (JK.) Hence the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, mano $aA='a baAhalotuhu A^an~a suwrapa AlquSoraY nazalato baEoda Albaqarapi [Whosoever will, I will contend with him by imprecating the curse of God upon whichever of us is wrong, that the shorter chapter of “Women” came down from heaven after the chapter of “The Cow”]: or, accord. to one recital, he said laA Eanotuhu: for when they differed respecting a thing, they used to come together, and say, A@ll~`hi EalaY ↓ baholapu AlZ~aAlimi min~aA [The curse of God be upon such of us as is the wrongdoer!]. (Mgh.) bAhl baEoDuhumo baEoDFA and ↓ tb~hlwA and ↓ tbAhlwA all signify They cursed one another: (K:) [or] they joined in imprecating a curse upon such of them as was the wrongdoer: (TA:) and ↓ AbthlwA signifies the like: whence, vum~a nabotahilo, in the Kur [iii. 54], (Bd, TA,) as some explain it, (TA,) meaning ↓ vum~a natabaAhalo, i. e., Then let us imprecate a curse upon such of us as is the liar. (Bd. [But see also 8 below.])

4 A^abohala see 1, in four places. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] A_ibohaAlN also signifies The sending forth, or letting flow, the water upon what has been sown, (JK, K, TA,) after having finished the sowing. (JK, TA. [In the CK, na*arotahu is erroneously put for ba*arotahu.])
5 tabah~ala see 3.
6 tabaAohala see 3, in two places.

8 A_ibotahala see 3. ― -b2- [Hence,] Abthl, (S, Msb, K,) or Abthl fiY Ald~aEaA='i, (JK,) (tropical:) He humbled, or abased, himself; or addressed himself with earnest, or energetic, supplication; syn. taDar~aEa; (S, Msb, K;) A_ilaY A@ll~`hi to God: (Msb:) he strove, or was earnest, or energetic, in prayer, or supplication; (JK, K;) and was sincere, or without hypocrisy, therein; (S, K;) with a striving, or an earnestness, or energy, like that of the mubotahiluwna [properly so called, i. e., persons who join in imprecating a curse upon such of them as is the wrongdoer]. (TA.) It is said that vum~a nabotahilo, in the Kur [iii. 54, of which one explanation has been given above, (see 3,)] means (tropical:) Then let us be sincere, or without hypocrisy, in prayer, or supplication; (S, TA;) and let us strive, or be earnest, or energetic: (TA:) or let us humble, or abase, ourselves; &c.; syn. nataDar~aEo. (Jel.)

10 AstblhA A^stblhA AstblhA {stbAl {stblh {stblhA
He milked her (namely, a camel,) without a SiraAr. (K. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- He (a young camel) pulled off her A^aSir~ap [pl. of SiraAr] to suck her, namely, his mother. (JK.) ― -b3- Astbhl Alr~aEy~apa He (the ruler) left the people, or subject, to themselves, (Lh, K,) to do what they would; not restraining them. (Lh, TA.) ― -b4- AisotabohalatohaA Als~awaAHilu (S) and Astblthm AlbaAdiyapu (K) (assumed tropical:) The shores, and the desert, left them at liberty in their abodes therein, no Sultán reaching them, so that they did what they pleased. (S, * K.)

baholapN bAhl bhl bhlh bhlp (S, Mgh, K) and ↓ buholapN (S, Msb, K) A curse: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) from bahala Aln~aAqapa in the sense first explained above. (Bd in iii. 54.) You say, Ealayohi baholapu A@ll~`hi and ↓ buholatuhu The curse of God be on him! (S.) For another ex., see 3.
buholapN bAhl bhl bhlh bhlp : see what next precedes, in two places.
baholalapN bhllh bhllp hll hllp The quality of shrinking from foul things, and of generosity, or nobleness. (JK.)

buholuwlN bhlwl One that shrinks from foul things, and is generous, or noble; applied to a man (Ibn- 'Abbád, JK) and to a woman: (JK:) pl. bahaAliylu. (Ibn-'Abbád, JK.) A lord, chief, or prince, combining all good qualities. (Seer, K.) ― -b2- A great, or frequent, laugher. (S, K.)

baAhilN A^hl bA^hl bAhl b|hl |hl A she-camel having no SiraAr upon her, (S, K, TA,) so that any one who will may milk her: (TA:) or one having no nose-rein upon her, (K, TA,) so that she pastures where she will: (TA:) or also one having no EiraAn [which is a piece of wood inserted in the partition between the nostrils]: (S:) and (so in the S, but in the K “or”) one having no mark, or brand, upon her: (JK, S, K:) pl. buh~alN (JK, S, K) and buhulN: (JK, K, TA: [the latter in the CK like burodN:]) and ↓ mubohalapN signifies left in the state of her that is termed baAhil, (S,) or having her SiraAr loosed, and her young one left at liberty to suck her: (K:) and ↓ mabaAhilu is applied in the same sense [as its pl.]. (S, K. [In the CK the latter is written mubaAhilN, as a sing.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^atayotuka baAhilFA gayora *aAti SiraArK, said by an Arab woman to her husband; (S;) by the wife of Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh, to him, on his desiring to divorce her; meaning (assumed tropical:) I made
my property lawful to thee. (TA.) ― -b3- baAhiluwna (assumed tropical:) People at liberty in their place of abode, no Sultán reaching them, so that they do what they please. (K.) ― -b4- And the sing., (tropical:) Going to and fro without work. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A pastor without a staff: (JK, K:) or, walking without a staff. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A man without a weapon. (IAar, TA.) ― -b7- And baAhilapN (assumed tropical:) A woman having no husband; (JK;) syn. A^ay~imN. (K.)

A^abohalN * The produce, or fruit, of a certain tree, which is the EaroEar [a name applied to the cypress and to the juniper-tree]: (S:) so says Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna] in the Kánoon; and he adds that it is of two species, small and great, both brought from the country of the ruwm: one species of the tree thereof has leaves like those of the sarow [or common, evergreen, cypress], has many thorns, and grows, or spreads, wide, (yasotaEoriDu,) not growing tall: the leaves of the other are like those of the TarofaA=' [or tamarisk], the taste thereof is like [that of] the sarow, and it is drier, and less hot: (TA:) or it is the produce of a kind of great tree, the leaves of which are like [those of] the TrfA', and the fruit of which is like the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree called sidor]; and it is not [the fruit of] the ErEr, as J imagined it to be: the smoke thereof expels quickly the young in the womb: used as a liniment, with vinegar, it cures what is termed daA=' Alv~aEolab [alopecia]: and with honey, it cleanses foul ulcers. (K.) [In the present day, it is applied to the juniper-tree; as is also EaroEar; and particularly to the species thereof called the savin. See qaTiraAnN.]
mubohalapN mbhlh mbhlp and mabaAhilu [its pl.]: see baAhilN.

2 bh~mwA Albahomi bhmwA Albhm , inf. n. tabohiymN, They separated the bhm [i. e. lambs, or kids, or both,] from their mothers, (S, K,) and pastured them alone. (S.) -A2- bh~mwA biAlmakaAni, inf. n. as above, They stayed, or remained, in the place; (K, TA;) did not quit it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also bh~m, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He continued looking at a thing without his being relieved by doing so. (JK.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He was silent, and confounded, or perplexed, when asked respecting a thing. (JK.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He did not fight, or engage in conflict. (JK.)

4 Abhm A^b A^bhm Abhm |b |bhm , (K,) inf. n. A_ibohaAmN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, dubious, confused, or vague, (JK, K, TA,) so that one knew not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed; (JK, TA;) as also ↓ Astbhm; (JK, K, TA;) for which grammarians often use ↓ Anbhm; but this has not been heard in the [classical] language of the Arabs: (MF, TA:) [said to be] from bahiymN denoting a colour, whatever it be, except that which is termed $uhobap, in which is no colour differing therefrom. (Har p. 50.) -A2- He closed, or locked, a door; (S, Mgh, TA;) [or, so that one could not find the way to open it; (see mubohamN;)] and stopped it up. (TA.) [And hence,] one says of the thumb, tubohimu Alkaf~a, meaning It closes upon [the palm of] the hand, as a cover. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) He made a thing, or an affair, to be dubious, confused, or vague, (JK, TA, *) so that there was no way, or manner, of knowing it, (TA,) or so that one knew not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed: (JK:) [in the former sense, or meaning (assumed tropical:) he made it to be dubious, confused, or vague,] said of speech, or language, (K in art. gmD, &c.,) and of information, or news, or a narration; (Msb;) contr. of A^awoDaHa; (TA in art. gmD;) i. q. lmo yubay~ino. (Msb.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, a thing to be vague, or indefinite. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And, said of a prohibited thing, (assumed tropical:) He made it, or held it, to be not allowable in any manner, nor for any cause: (Az, TA:) or to be prohibited unconditionally. (Mgh.) [See mubohamN.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He made a man to turn away, or withdraw, or retire, (JK, K,) Eano ka*aA from such a thing, (JK,) or Eani AlA^amori from the affair. (K.) -A3- Abhmt AlA^aroDu The land produced what is termed buhomaY: (JK, K:) or produced much thereof. (S.)
5 tabah~ama see 10.
7 A_inobahama see 4.

10 A_isotabohama see 4. ― -b2- You say, Astbhm Ealayohi AlA^amoru (tropical:) The affair was as though it were closed against him, so that he knew not the way in which to engage in it, or execute it; syn. A^urotija Ealayohi. (TA.) And Astbhm Ealayohi, (K,) or Astbhm Elyh AlkalaAmu, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Speech was as though it were closed against him; or he was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tongue-tied; (S, * K, TA;) syn. Aisotagolaqa; (S;) and Elyh kalaAmuhu ↓ tbh~m [signifies the same]; syn. A^urotija; (JK, S; *) on the authority of AZ. (S.) And Astbhm Alxabaru (assumed tropical:) The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, vague, or difficult to be understood or expressed; or was not to be understood or expressed; as though it were closed [against the hearer or speaker]; syn. Aisotagolaqa, and AisotaEojama. (Msb.)

bahomN b bhm bhym hm is pl. of ↓ bahomapN, (S, Msb, K,) as are also ↓ bahamN and bihaAmN, (K,) [or rather bahomN is a coll. gen. n., and ↓ bahomapN is its n. un., and ↓ bahamN is a quasi-pl. n., and] bihaAmN is pl. of bahomN, (S, Msb,) and bihaAmaAti is a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of bihaAmN]: (K:) ↓ bahomapN signifies A lamb, and is applied to the male and the female; (S, Msb;) or, accord. to a trad. in which it occurs, it is a name for the female; (IAth, TA;) but bihaAmN, which is applied to lambs when they are alone, as sixaAlN is to kids when they are alone, is also applied to lambs and kids together: (S, * Msb:) or, accord. to IF, bahomN signifies young lambs or goats: (Msb:) and accord. to AZ, (Msb,) or A'Obeyd, (TA,) ↓ bahomapN is applied to a lamb or goat, whether male or female, after the period when it is termed saxolapN, which is when it is just brought forth; (Msb, TA;) and its pl. is Abhm: (Msb: [so in my copy of that work, as though meant for A^abohumN; but perhaps a mistranscription for Albahomu:]) or it is applied to a lamb or goat when just brought forth, i. e., before it is termed saxolapN: (Mgh: [and this is agreeable with its application in a trad. cited by IAth:]) or to the young one, not, as in the K, young ones, (TA,) of the sheep, and of the goat, and of an animal of the bovine kind (K, TA) both wild and not wild, alike to the male and the female, while small; or, as some say, when it has attained to youthful vigour: (TA:) Lebeed applies bihaAmN to the young ones of [wild] animals of the bovine kind: (S, TA:) accord. to Th, bahomN signifies young kids. (TA.) ― -b2- saEodu AlbihaAmi One of the Mansions (K, TA) of the Moon: (TA:) or two stars which are not of the Mansions of the Moon. (S and L and K in art. sEd, q. v.)
bahamN b bhm bhym hm : see bahomN, in two places.

[
bahimN b bhm bhym hm an epithet of which only the fem. form is mentioned. You say] A^aroDN bahimapN Land abounding with what is termed buhomaY: (AHn, K:) the word bhmp is a possessive epithet. (TA.)
bahomapN bhmh bhmp bhym hm hmp : see bahomN, in four places.

buhomapN bhmh bhmp bhym hm hmp
A rock, or great mass of stone or of hard stone, (K, TA,) that is solid, not hollow. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, accord. to some, (TA,) or because his condition is such that one knows not how to prevail with him, (Ham pp. 334 and 610,) A courageous man, (K, and Ham ubi suprà,) or a horseman, (AO, S,) to whom one knows not the way whence to gain access, or whence to come, (AO, S, K,) by reason of his great might, or valour: (AO, S:) or, as in the Nawádir, rajulN buhomapN signifies a man who will not be turned from a thing that he desires to do: (TA:) it is not applied as an epithet to a woman: (IJ, TA:) pl. buhamN. (S, A.) You say, huwa buhomapN mina Albuhami, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is a courageous man, of those to whom the approach is as though it were closed against his adversaries. (A, TA.) Accord. to IJ, it is an inf. n. used as an epithet, though having no verb. (TA.) [Hence,] it applies to one and to a number of persons. (Ham p. 494.) [For] it signifies also ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) An army: (S, K:) or courageous men, or courageous men clad in armour; because one knows not the way in which to fight with them: or, as some say, a company of horsemen: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A difficult affair or case; (K, TA;) such that one cannot find the way to perform it, or manage it: pl. as above. (TA.) You say, waqaEa fiY buhomapK laA yut~ajahu lahaA (assumed tropical:) [He fell into a difficult, or an embarrassing, case, which one knew not the way to manage]. (TA.) The pl. is also explained as meaning (assumed tropical:) Dubious, confused, or vague, affairs or cases. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Blackness. (TA.) ― -b6- And Albuhamu (assumed tropical:) The three nights in which the moon does not [visibly] rise. (TA.)

buhomaY bhmY bhmy bhmyy bhym hm , a word both sing. and pl., (Sb, S, K,) its alif [written Y] being a denotative of the fem. gender, wherefore it is without tenween; (Sb, S;) or [it is written buhomFY, with tenween, for it is a coll. gen. n., and] its n. un. is buhomaApN, (S, K, and so in the JK,) its alif, some say, being a letter of quasi-coordination; but Mbr says that this is not known, and that the alif in a word of the measure fuEolY is nought but a denotative of the fem. gender; (S;) and the n. un. bhmAp is anomalous; (El-'Ash-
moonee's Expos. of the Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, § AltA^nyv;) [A species of barley-grass; app. hordeum murinum, or common wall-barley-grass;] a certain plant, (Lth, JK, S, K,) well known; (K;) the sheep and goats, (Lth, TA,) or the camels, (JK,) are vehemently fond of it as long as it is green; (Lth, JK, TA;) but when it dries up, its prickles bristle out, and it repugns; (Lth, TA;) it is of the herbs (buquwl) that are termed A^aHoraAz [app. here meaning slender and sweet] when fresh and when dry, and comes forth at first undistinguishably as to species, from the earth, like as does corn; then it becomes like corn, and puts forth prickles like those [that compose the awn, or beard,] of the ear of corn, which, when they enter the noses of the sheep or goats and the camels, cause pain to their noses, until men pull them out from their mouths and their noses; and when it becomes large, and dries up, it is a pasture that is fed upon until the rain of the next year falls upon it, when its seed that has fallen from its ears germinates beneath it. (AHn, TA.)

bahiymN bhym hAy^m
Black: (K:) pl. buhumN. (TA.) And [app. used also as a subst., signifying] A black ewe (K, TA) in which is no whiteness: pl. as above and buhomN. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, to the male and the female, (S, * Mgh, * K,) Of one, unmixed, colour; in which is no colour differing from the rest: (S, Mgh, K:) pl. buhumN. (S.) laA A^agar~u wa laA bahiymN [Not having a star, or blaze, on the forehead or face, nor of one, unmixed, colour, or not white nor black, (some such proposition as “This is a horse” being understood before lA,)] is a prov. applied to a dubious, confused, or vague, affair or case. (TA.) ― -b3- A colour of one kind, (JK,) in which is no colour differing from the rest, (JK, and Har p. 50,) whatever colour it be, except that which is termed $uhobap: (Har ubi suprà:) or a colour that is clear, pure, or unmixed, not resembling any other, (AA, K, * TA,) whether it be black or any other colour, (AA, TA,) except, as Z says, that which is termed $uhobap. (TA.) ― -b4- A night in which is no light (JK, TA) until the dawn. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A sound, or voice, in which is no trilling, or quavering, or reiteration in the throat or fauces. (JK, K, * TA. *) ― -b6- Perfect, or complete, in make; as also ↓ mubohamN: pl. buhomN: so in the phrase in a trad. (respecting the day of resurrection, TA), yuHo$aru Aln~aAsu buhomFA, i. e. Mankind shall be congregated perfect, or complete, in make, without mutilation, or defect: (JK:) or the meaning here is, sound, or healthy: (S:) or not having any of the diseases or noxious affections of the present state, as blindness, and elephantiasis, and leprosy, and blindness of one eye, and lameness, &c.: (A'Obeyd, K, * TA:) or naked; (JK, K;) not having upon them anything to conceal them: (JK:) or not having with them anything (S, TA) of worldly goods or commodities. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Unknown. (El-Khattábee, TA.) -A2- See also A_ibohaAmN.

bahiymapN bhym bhymh bhymp hAy^m [A beast; a brute;] any quadruped, (Akh, M, Msb, K,) even if in the water, (Akh, M, K,) [i. e.,] of the land and of the sea; (Msb;) and (so in the Msb, but in the K “or”) any animal that does not discriminate: (Zj, Msb, K:) pl. bahaAy^imu. (S, Msb, K.)

[
bahiymiY bhym bhymY bhymy hAy^m hymAn
Of, or relating to, beasts, or brutes.]

[
bahiymiy~apN bhymy bhymyh bhymyp The nature of beasts, or brutes.]
A^abohamu * : see mubohamN, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. A^aEojamu [app. as meaning Destitute of the faculty of speech or articulation, like the beasts]. (K.)

A_ibohaAmN A_bhAm AbhAm The thumb, and the great toe; (M, K;) the greatest A_iSobaE, (JK, T, S,) that is next to the forefinger, having two joints, so called because it closes upon [the palm of] the hand, as a cover; (T, TA;) the greatest of the A^aSaAbiE in the hand and in the foot: (M, K:) of the fem. gender, (S, Msb,) accord. to common repute; (Msb;) and sometimes masc.: (Lh, M, K:) and ↓ bahiymN signifies the same; mentioned by Az in the T, and by others; but Az adds that one should not say bihaAmN: (TA:) the pl. of AbhAm is A^abaAhiymu (JK, S, M, Msb, K) and A^abaAhimu, (M, K,) which latter is used by poetic license for the former, (M,) and A_ibohaAmaAtN. (Msb.) A^aqoSaru mino A_ibohaAmi AlD~ab~i [Shorter than the great toe of the (lizard called) Db~], and mn AbhAm AlqaTaApi [than the back toe of the (bird called) qTAp], and mn AbhAm AlHubaAraY [than the back toe of the (bird called) HbArY], are proverbs of the Arabs. (Har p. 335.)

mubohamN mbhm , applied to a door, Closed, or locked, (JK, K,) so that one cannot find the way to open it: (JK, TA:) and stopped up: (TA:) or having a lock upon it, with which it is fastened. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A wall in which is no door. (TA.) ― -b3- A chest having no lock [by means of which it may be opened]. (IAmb, TA.) ― -b4- I. q. muSomatN [as meaning Solid; not hollow; in the CK A^aSomatu, which signifies the same]; as also ↓ A^abohamu: (K:) having no fissure in it: and ↓ the latter, applied to a heart is said to mean (assumed tropical:) impenetrable by admonition. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A thing, or an affair, made to be dubious, confused, or vague; (JK;) [such that there is no way, or manner, of knowing it; (see the verb;)] or such that one knows not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed: (JK, S, Mgh, TA:) (assumed tropical:) speech, or language, [that is dubious, confused, or vague,] such that there is no way, or manner, of knowing it: (Mgh, TA:) applied to a road, (assumed tropical:) unapparent, or hardly apparent: (TA:) and, applied to the ordinance respecting the making up for the days in which one has broken a fast, [and to many other cases,] (assumed tropical:) undefined; in this instance meaning, as to whether the days may be interrupted, or whether they must be consecutive. (Mgh.) [Hence,] mubohamaAtN (assumed tropical:) Difficult things, or affairs, such that one cannot find the way to perform them. (TA.) And AlA^asomaA='u Almubohamapu, so termed by the grammarians, (assumed tropical:) The nouns of indication, (S, K,) such as h`*aA and h`w^ulaA='i and *aAka and A^uwlaAy^ika: (S:) accord. to Az, AlHuruwfu Almubohamapu signifies (assumed tropical:) the particles which have no derivatives, and of which the roots are not known, as Al~a*iY and maA and mano and Eano and the like. (TA.) ― -b6- Applied to a vow, and to [certain ordinances respecting] marriage and divorce and emancipation, (assumed tropical:) From which there is no getting out, or extricating of oneself; as though they were closed doors with locks upon them: (Mgh:) and, applied to prohibited things, (assumed tropical:) not allowable in any manner, (T, K, TA,) nor for any cause; (T, TA;) or prohibited unconditionally; (Mgh;) as the prohibition of [the marriage with] the mother, and the sister, (T, Mgh, * K, TA,) and the like: (T, TA:) such a woman is said to be mubohamapN EalaY Alr~ajuli (assumed tropical:) [absolutely prohibited to the man; as though she were closed against him, or inaccessible to him]. (Msb. [But in this last work it seems to be mvbohimapN, which is not agreeable with common usage.]) In the copies of the K, buhomN and buhumN are given as pls. of this word: but it seems that there is an omission or a misplacement in the passage; for these are said to be pls. of bahiymN, as shown above. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) In a state of swooning or insensibility, speechless, and without discrimination; in consequence of a blow [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b8- See also bahiymN.
musotabohimN Eani AlkalaAmi mstbhm En AlklAm (assumed tropical:) Debarred from the faculty of speech. (Niftaweyh, TA.)

1 bahaA b bhA , (JK, Msb, K,) aor. yabohaA, (JK,) or yabohuw; (Msb, K;) and bahuwa, aor. yabohuw; and bahiYa, aor. yabohaY; (S, * K;) and bahaY, [first pers. bahayotu,] aor. yabohaY; (K;) inf. n. bahaA='N and bahaA='apN; (JK, TA;) He (a man, S) or it, was, or became, characterized by, or possessed of, bahaA=', meaning beauty, or goodliness [&c.]. (JK, S, Msb, K.) -A2- bahawotuhu and bahayotuhu: see 3. -A3- bahiYa, (S, K,) aor.
bahawa , (K,) inf. n. bahFA, (TA,) It (a tent, S, K) was, or became, empty, or vacant: (K:) or it was, or became, rent, or pierced with holes, and rendered vacant. (S, TA.) -A4- bahiYa bihi i. q. bahaA^a bihi [q. v.]. (JK.) And bahaw^uwA bihi occurs in a trad., as they relate it, for bahaw^uwA bihi. (A'Obeyd, TA in art. bhA^.)
2 bh~Ahu bhAh bhAp , inf. n. tabohiyapN, He made it wide, or ample; or widened it; and made it; namely, a bayot [i. e. tent, or house]. (K.)

3 bAhAhu bAhAh bAhAp bAhY , (TA,) [and bAhY bihi, as will be seen from what follows,] inf. n. mubaAhaApN, (S, TA,) He vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness, or in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence; he emulated, or rivalled, him therein; or, simply, he vied with him; syn. baAraAhu; (TA in art. bhj;) and faAxarahu. (S, * TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting 'Arafeh, tubaAhiY bihimu AlmalaAy^ikapu [The angels vie with them]. (TA.) You say, ↓ baAhaAniY fabahawotuhu (Lh, JK, K *) and ↓ bahayotuhu (Lh, JK) i. e. [He vied, or competed, with me, or contended with me for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness, &c.,] and I became, (Lh,) or I was, (JK,) more beautiful, or goodly, [&c.,] than he, (Lh, JK,) or I surpassed him in beauty, or goodliness [&c.]. (K.)

4 AbhY A^bh A^bhY A^bhy A^bhyy AbhY Abhy bhy |bh |bhy |bhyy
He (a man) was, or became, beautiful, or handsome, in face. (K.) -A2- AbhAhu [He deprived
it of beauty, or goodliness; the A being a privative, as it often is, like the Greek a: this is probably the primary signification: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 604:) and hence, ― -b2- ] He made it empty, or vacant: (K:) or he rent it, or made holes in it: (JK:) or he rent it, or made holes in it, and rendered it vacant: (S:) namely, a tent. (JK, S, K.) Hence the saying, AlmiEozaY tubohiY wa laA tuboniY [explained in art. bnY]: (JK, S:) applied to him who injures and does not profit. (JK.) ― -b3- He emptied it; namely, a vessel. (A'Obeyd, JK, S, K.) ― -b4- AbhY Alxayola He freed the horses from service (JK, S, K) in warfare; (S, K;) i. e. he did not go to war upon the horses: (TA:) or he divested the horses of their furniture, and did not ride them: or he supplied the horses amply with fodder, and gave them rest: but the first is the-approved explanation. (TA.)

6 tabaAhawoA bAhY tbAhY tbAhwA
They vied, or competed, or contended for superiority, one with another, [in beauty, or goodliness, or] in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence; they emulated, or rivalled, one another therein; or, simply, they vied, one with another; syn. tafaAxaruwA. (S, K.)
8 yabotahiY ybthY ybthy occurs in a verse of El-Aashà for yabotahiy^u. (O, TS, L, on the authority of As, in art. bhA^, q. v.)

bahowN bhw hw
Ampleness; or an ample state, or condition: so in the saying, huwa fiY bahowK mina AlEayo$i [He is in an ample state, or condition, of life]: and this is [said to be] the primary signification. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Anything ample, wide, or spacious. (K.) [Hence,] naAqapN bahowapN Aljanabayoni A she-camel wide in the two sides. (TA.) ― -b3- A wide, or spacious, tract of land, (K, TA,) in which are no mountains, between two elevated tracts. (TA.) ― -b4- A wide covert, or hiding-place, of a [wild] bull, (JK, K, TA,) which he makes for himself at the foot of the kind of tree called A^aroTFY [q. v.]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^abohaA='N and [of mult.] buhuw~N and [quasi-pl.-n.] bahiY~N. (K.) ― -b5- Any vacant, or intervening, space. (TA.) ― -b6- The interior of the chest, or breast, (K, TA,) of a man and of any beast: (TA:) or the space that intervenes between the two breasts and the uppermost part of the chest (K, TA) is called bahowu AlS~adori: (TA:) or the part between [or within] the extremities of the ribs that project over the belly: (TA:) and in her that is pregnant, (JK, K,) whatever she be, (JK,) the resting-place of the fœtus, between the two haunches: (JK, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^abohaA='N and A^abohK and [of mult.] buhiY~N and [quasi-pl. n.] bahiY~N [in the TA bihiY~N, which seems to be a mistake]. (K) ― -b7- A tent that is placed in advance, before the other tents: (JK, S, TA:) pl. A^abohaA='N. (JK.) In a trad., Arabs are spoken of as removing with their A^abohaA='. (TA.)
bahK b bh bp [originally bahiwN]: see bahiY~N, in two places.

bahaA='N bhA='
Beauty, or goodliness: (S, Msb, K:) beauty of aspect, of mien, or of external state or condition: (Msb:) a beautiful aspect, that excites admiration, and satisfies the eye: (TA:) and, as an attribute of God, (Msb,) greatness, or majesty. (Msb, Har p. 271.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The froth of milk: (JK:) or the glistening of the froth of milk. (K.) -A2- As an epithet applied to a she-camel, it belongs to art. bhA^ [in which it is explained]. (S.)

bahiY~N bhY bhy
Possessing the quality, or attribute, of bahaA=' [i. e. beauty, or goodliness, &c.]; (JK, S, Msb;) the beauty of which, (JK,) or the pleasing appearance of which, (TA,) satisfies the eye; (JK, TA;) as also ↓ bahK and ↓ baAhK: the fem. of bahiY~N is bahiy~apN; of which the pl. is bahiy~aAtN and bahaAyaA: and the fem. of ↓ bahK is bahiyapN; and the pl. is A^abohiyaA='u. (TA.)

baAhK bAh bAp : see bahiY~N. -A2- Also, applied to a bayot [or tent (see bahiYa)], Empty, or vacant; (JK, S, K;) containing nothing: (S:) or containing little furniture, or few goods or utensils. (TA.) ― -b2- biy^orN baAhiyapN A wide-mouthed well. (K.)

A^abohaY * [More, and most, beautiful, or goodly;] surpassingly, or superlatively, beautiful, or goodly: fem. buhoyaA; which is applied to a woman, and, by Honeyf El-Hanátim, to a she-camel. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] one says, A_in~a h`*aA labuhoyaAYa [This is my superlatively beautiful quality; or] this is of the things in which I vie with others. (AA, ISk.)
1 bahaYa bhY bhy , as an intrans. v.: and bahayotuhu: see art. bhw.

baw~N bw
