A skin of a young unweaned camel stuffed (Lth, T, S, M, K) with straw (Lth, T, M, K) or with vumaAm [i. e. panic grass] (M, K) or with dry herbage, (M,) to which a she-camel is made to incline (Lth, T, S) when her young one has died: (S:) it is brought near to the mother of the young camel [that has died], in order that she may incline to it, and yield her milk (M, K) over it. (M.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel's young one. (M, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Stupid; foolish; having little sense, or intellect; as also ↓ baw~iY~N; (IAar, T, K;) applied to a man: (IAar, T:) fem. baw~apN. (K.) ― -b4- And Albaw~u, (K,) or baw~u AlA^avaAfiY, (Lth, T, S, M,) (tropical:) Ashes: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) so called [as being lifeless,] by way of comparison [to the stuffed skin of a young camel]. (M.)
baw~iY~N bwY bwy : see above.
bawobaApN bwb bwbAh bwbAp , mentioned in this art. in the S, and also, as well as in art. bwb, in the K: see the latter art.
juwozu baw~aA jwz bwA , also written jawozu baw~aY: see art. jwz. -A2- xayoru baw~aA='u: see art. xyr.

1 baA='a A_ilayohi bA=' Alyh bA=' Alyp , (M, Mgh, * Msb, * K,) aor. yabuwo'u, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. bawo'N, (M, Mgh,) He returned, went back, or came back, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) to it, (M, K, *) namely, a thing: (M:) or he withdrew [from a person or persons, or a place,] to it, or him; or, perhaps, he made himself solely and peculiarly a companion, or an associate, to him, or it; syn. AinoqaTaEa [q. v.]: (K:) but in some copies of the K, the latter explanation is connected with the former by wa [and] instead of A^aw. (TA.) wabaAw^uwA bigaDabK mina A@ll~`hi [in the Kur ii. 58 and iii. 108] means And they returned with anger from God; (Akh, S, Bd in ii. 58, and Jel in the same and in iii. 108;) i. e. the anger of God came upon them: (Akh, S:) or they returned deserving anger from God: (Bd in iii. 108:) or they became deserving of anger from God: from baA='a fulaAnN bifulaAnK such a one was deserving of being, or fit to be, slain in retaliation for such a one, (Ksh and Bd in ii. 58,) because his equal: (Ksh ibid.:) the primary signification of bawo'N being [said to be] that of equalling, or being equal with. (Bd in ii. 58.) [See a similar phrase, also from the Kur, below.] ― -b2- buw^otu bihi A_ilayohi [I returned with it to him: and hence,] I returned it, took it back, or brought it back, to him; (M, K;) as also ↓ A^abaA^otuhu, (Th, M, K,) and buw^otuhu, (Ks, M, K,) but this last is rare. (M.) ― -b3- baA='a biA_ivomihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (T, S,) signifies, accord. to Akh, He returned [laden] with his sin: (S:) or, accord. to As, he acknowledged it, or confessed it: (T:) or, accord. to others, (TA,) baA='a bi*anobihi, (T, * M, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawo'N and bawaA='N, (M, K,) he bore, or took upon himself, the burden of his sin, or crime, or offence; syn. AiHotamalahu; (Aboo-Is-hák, T, M, K, TA;) and became [as though he were] the abiding-place thereof: (TA:) or he became burdened, or laden, with it: (Msb:) or he became, or made himself, answerable, responsible, or accountable, for it, by an inseparable obligation; syn. Ailotazama bihi; for the primary signification of bawaA='N is [asserted to be] luzuwmN [i. e. adhesion, &c.]; and it is afterwards used in every case [so as to imply a meaning of this kind] according to the exigency of that case; as is said in the Nh, and expressly stated by Z and Er-Rághib: (TA:) or he acknowledged it, or confessed it. (M, K.) A_in~iY A^uriydu A^ano tabuwo'a biA_ivomiY wa A_ivomika, in the Kur v. 35, means Verily I desire that thou return [laden] with the sin committed against me in slaying me, and thy sin which thou hast committed previously: (Jel:) or I desire that thou shouldst bear (taHomila) my sin if I were to extend my hand towards thee, and thy sin in extending thy hand towards me: or the sin committed against me in slaying me, and thy sin for which thine offering was not accepted: and each noun is in the place of a denotative of state; i. e., [it means] that thou return involved in the two sins; bearing them: and perhaps the speaker may have meant, if that must inevitably take place, I desire that it may be thine act, not mine; so that the real meaning is, that it should not be his, not that it should be his brother's: or by the A_ivomN may be meant the punishment thereof; for the desire of the punishment of the disobedient is allowable: (Bd:) accord. to Th, the meaning is, if thou have determined upon slaying me, the sin will be in thee, not in me. (M.) fabaAw^uwA bigaDabK EalaY gaDabK
[in the Kur ii. 84] is explained by Aboo-Is-hák as meaning So they bore the burden of anger upon anger; syn. AiHotamaluwA; this being said by him to be the proper signification of the verb: or, as some say, the meaning is, [they bore the burden of] sin for which they deserved the fire [of Hell] following upon sin for which they deserved the same: or they returned [laden with anger upon anger]: (T:) or they became deserving of anger upon anger. (Ksh.) [See a similar phrase, also from the Kur, above.] It is said in a form of prayer, A^abuwo'u A_ilayoka biniEomatika, meaning I acknowledge, or confess, to Thee thy favour [towards me, as imposing an obligation upon me]. (Mgh.) You say also, baA='N biHaq~ihi; (S;) and bid~imihi; (M, K;) He acknowledged, or confessed, [himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for] his right, due, or just claim; (S;) and so [for] his blood: (M, K:) the verb expresses acknowledgment, or confession, always of something for which its agent is, as it were, indebted, or answerable; not the contrary. (S.) ― -b4- baA='a bikaf~iY, in a poem of Sakhr-el-Gheí, means It [referring to a sword] became in my hand; my hand became to it a mabaA='ap, i. e. maA^owFY [or place of abode]; it returned, and became in my hand: or, accord. to Ibn- Habeeb, i. q. Aisotaqal~a [app. a mistranscription for Aisotaqar~a it rested, or remained; the verb bA=' in this phrase being from bawaA='N signifying luzuwmN, explained above]. (Skr p. 16.) -A2- baA='N also signifies It (a thing, TA) suited, matched, tallied, corresponded, or agreed. (K.) [Hence,] baA='a fulaAnN bifulaAnK (inf. n. bawaA='N, TA) Such a one was the like, or equal, of such a one, to be slain [in retaliation] for him: (T:) or became his like, or equal, so that he was slain [in retaliation] for him: (Mgh:) and was slain for him, (AZ, T, S,) and his blood became a compensation for the blood of the other: (T:) or was deserving of being, or fit to be, slain in retaliation for him, (Ksh and Bd in ii. 58,) because his equal: (Ksh ibid.:) or was slain for him, and so became equal with him; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ A^abaA='ahu, and ↓ baAwaA^ahu. (M, K.) One says, buw^obihi, i. e. Be thou of such as are slain [in retaliation] for him. (S.) And it is said in a prov., baA='ato EaraAri bikaHolK 'Arári became slain for Kahl: these were two cows, which smote each other with their horns, and both died: the proverb is applied to any two that become equal. (S in this art.; and the same and K in art. Er. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 151.]) ― -b2- baA='a damahu bidamihi, (T, * M, K,) inf. n. bawo'N and bawaA='N, (M,) He made his blood equal with [or an equivalent for] his [i. e. another's] blood [by shedding the former in retaliation]. (M, K.) And baA='ahu, [or baA='ahu bihi,] (M,) or bh ↓ A^abaA='ahu, (T, S,) and bh ↓ AisotibaA='ahu, (S,) He slew him [in retaliation] for him; (T, S, M;) i. e., the slayer for the slain. (S.) fulaAnFA bifulaAnK ↓ A^abaA='a [He slew such a one in retaliation for such a one] is said when the Sultán has retaliated for a man upon another man: and ↓ A^abaA='ahu, inf. n. A_ibaA='apN, signifies he (the Sultán, or another,) slew him in retaliation. (T.) -A3- baA='a signifies also He exalted himself, or was proud: app. formed by transposition [of the second and third radical letters, the Y being changed into A,] from baA^aY. (Fr, T.)

2 bw~A^hu manozilFA *
He lodged him in an abode; (Fr, T, M, K;) as also bw~Ahu fiY manozilK, (M, K,) and manozilFA ↓ AbA='hu: (T, * M, K:) or, as also bw~A^ lahu manozilFA, (the latter mentioned by Fr, T,) he prepared for him an abode, (S, Mgh,) and assigned, or gave, him a place therein: (S:) and baw~aA^otuhu dArFA and bw~Atu lahu dArFA I lodged him in a house: (Msb:) and baw~aA^otuka bayotFA I took for thee a house: and ↓ tabaw~aA= liqawomikumaA bimiSora buyuwtFA [in the Kur x. 87] means take ye two, for your people, in Egypt, houses: (Akh, T:) or ↓ tabaw~uw^N [or tabaw~uw^u makaAnK] signifies a man's putting a mark upon a place, when it pleases him, that he may abide there: (El-'Itreefee, T:) or ↓ tbw~A^hu he put it [a place] into a right, or proper, state; and prepared it: (Sh, * T:) or bayotFA ↓ tbw~A^ he took a house as a place of abode, or as a dwelling: (Msb:) or manozilFA ↓ tbw~A^ he looked for the best place that could be seen, and the most level, or even, and the best adapted by its firmness, for his passing the night there, and took it as a place of abode; (Fr, T;) or he took for himself a place of abode; (T, Mgh;) or he alighted and sojourned in a place of abode: and ↓ AstbA='hu he took it as a mabaA='ap [or place of abode]: (S:) and bw~A^ AlmakaAna and bihi ↓ AbA=' (K) and ↓ tbw~A^ [i. e. tbw~A^ bihi] (Sh, T, K) he alighted in the place, and stayed, or dwelt, in it: (Sh, T, K:) or bh ↓ AbA=' he stayed, or dwelt, in it, i. e., a place: (Akh, T:) and AlmakaAna ↓ tbw~A^ he alighted and abode in the place: (M:) [whence, in the Kur lix. 9,] A@ld~aArawa A@loA_iymaAna ↓ waA@l~a*iyna tabaw~aw^uwA [and they who have made their abode in the City of the Prophet and in the faith]; the faith being likened to a place of abode; or the meaning may be makaAna AlA_iymaAni [the place of the faith]. (M.)

baw~aA^ahumo manozilFA * (AZ, M) and mnzlFA ↓ A^abaA='ahumo (AZ, TA) also signify He alighted and abode with them by the face, or front, of a mountain, where it rose from its base, (AZ, M, TA,) or next to a river, or brook. (AZ, TA.) -A2- [Hence, (see baA='api,)] bw~A^ (inf. n. tabowiyo'N, K) (assumed tropical:) Inivit [feminam]: and he married [a woman]; took [her] in marriage: syn.

nakaHa kH nkH : (M, K:) and also taz~awaja. (TA. [There mentioned as a distinct signification.]) The verb is trans. in these two senses. (TK.) -A2- bw~A^ AlrumoHa naHowahu He directed the spear towards him; (T, S;) and (T) confronted him with it; (T, M, K;) and prepared it, or made it ready [to thrust it towards him]. (TA.)
3 baAwaA^hu * : see baA='a fulaAnN bifulaAnK.

4 A^abaA^otuhu * : see buw^otu bihi A_ilayohi, near the beginning of this art. ― -b2- AbA=' AlA_ibila, (T, S, O, L, and so in some copies of the K, in other copies of which we find AbA=' biAloA_ibili,) inf. n. A_ibaA='apN, (T,) He brought back the camels to the mabaA='ap (T, S, O, L) or maEoTin, (K,) both of which signify the place where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place. (L.) And AbA=' AlA_ibila, (T, M,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He made the camels to lie down [in the mabaA='ap], one beside another. (T, M.) And AbA=' Ealayohi maAlahu He drove back, or brought back, to their nightly resting-place, for him, his cattle, (S, M, TA,) i. e., his camels, or his sheep or goats. (S, TA.) And [hence,] A^abaA='a A@ll~`hu Ealayohimo naEamFA laA yasaEuhaA AlmuraAHu [God bestowed upon them cattle (i. e. camels &c.) which the nightly resting-place thereof would not contain]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2, in four places. ― -b4- AbA=' AlA^adiyma He put the skin, or hide, into the tanning liquid. (K.) In the O, the action is ascribed to a woman. (TA.) -A2- AbA=' minohu He fled from him. (M, K.) ― -b2- falaApN tubiYo'u fiY falaAopK A desert that extends (lit. goes away) into a desert, (T, S, K,) by reason of its amplitude. (TA.) -A3- A^abaA^otuhu I made him to acknowledge, or confess. (M.) [It seems to be indicated in the M that one says, A^abaA^otuhu bidami fulaAnK, meaning I made him to acknowledge, or confess, himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for the blood of such a one.] -A4- See also 1, (towards the end of the paragraph,) in four places.

5 tabaw~aAa see 2, in eight places. ― -b2- Alr~ajulu yatabaw~aA^u mino A^aholihi kamaA yatabaw~aA^u mino daArihi The man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house; syn. yasotamokinu minohaA. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- See also 10.

6 tabaAwaA= tbAwA=
They two (namely, two slain men, M) became equal [by being slain, one in retaliation for the other]. (M, K.) It is said in a trad., A^amarahumo A^ano yatabaAwaw^uwA; incorrectly related as being yatabA='awoA; (S, Mgh;) meaning He (the Prophet) ordered them that they should be equal in retaliation, in their fighting: (Mgh:) the occasion of the order was this: there was a conflict between two tribes of the Arabs, and one of the two tribes had superior power over the other, so they said, “ We will not be content unless we slay, for the slave of our party, the free of their party; and for the woman, the man: ” A'Obeyd holds the former reading to be the right. (T.)

10 AstbA='hu AstbA='h AstbA='p : see 2. ― -b2- In the following verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Abee-Sulmà,
walamo A^arajaAra bayotK yusotabaA='u
falamo A^ara maEo$arFA A^asaruwA hadiy~FA
ISk says that the hadiY~ is one who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection; and that ystbA=' is syn. with ↓ yutabaw~aA^u, meaning whose wife is taken as a wife [by another man]: but Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee says that ystbA=' is from AlbawaA='u, meaning “ retaliation: ” [and accord. to this interpretation, which is the more probable, the verse may be rendered, And I have not seen a company of men who have made captive one entitled to respect, or honour, or protection, nor have I seen one who has begged the protection of the people of a house, or of a tent, slain in retaliation:] for, he says, he came to them desiring to beg their protection, and they took him, and slew him in retaliation for one of themselves. (T.) See 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b3- AisotabaA^otu AlHakama, and biAloHakam, I asked the judge to retaliate upon a slayer; to slay the slayer for the slain. (M.)

baA='N b*A=' : see baA='apN. -A2- A libidinous man. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.) -A3- The name of the letter b, q. v.; as also baA: pl. of the former baA='aAtN; and of the latter A^abowaA='N. (TA ubi suprà.) The dim. is buyay~apN, meaning A little b: and a b faintly pronounced: [and app. buway~apN also, as the medial radical is generally held to be w:] and in like manner is formed the dim. of every similar name of a letter. (Lth, on the letter HaA=', in TA, bAb AlAlf Allyn~p.)

baA='apN bA='h bA='p : see mabaA='apN, in three places. -A2- Also, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ baA='N, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) and baAhapN, with the ' changed into h, (TA,) and baAhN, (IAar, T, Msb,) with A and h, but IKt asserts this last to be a mistranscription, (Msb, TA,) [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] and IAmb says that baA='apN is sing., or n. un., of baA='N, and baA='N [or baA='apN] has for pl. baA='aAtN, (TA,) (tropical:) Coïtus conjugalis: and marriage: syn. jimaAEN (T, Msb) and nikaAHN (As, Fr, T, S, M, Mgh, K) and tazowiyjN: (T:) from baA='apN signifying a place of abode; [see mabaA='apN;] (T, S, * Mgh, Msb;) because it is generally in a place of abode; (Mgh, Msb;) or because the man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house: (S, Mgh, Msb: see 5:) baA='apN is applied [also] to the marriage-contract; because he who takes a woman in marriage lodges her in a place of abode. (T.) [See also baAhN, in art. bwh.] It is said in a trad., mani A@sotaTaAEa minokumu AlbaA='a pa faloyataz~awjo He who is able, of you, to marry, let him marry: (T:) or a prefixed noun is here suppressed; the meaning being, he who finds [or is able to procure] the provisions (muw^an) of marriage, let him marry. (Msb, TA.) And one says, fulaAnN HariySN EalaY AlbaA='api Such a one is vehemently desirous of marriage. (As, T.)

biyoy^apN * a subst. from baw~aA^ahu manozilFA. (M, K.) [See 2; and] see also mabaA='apN. ― -b2- A mode, or manner, of taking for oneself a place of abode: (M:) and [hence,] a state, or condition. (AZ, T, S, M, K.) You say, A_in~ahu laHasanu Albiyoy^api Verily he has a good mode, or manner, of taking for himself a place of abode: (M:) or verily he is of good state or condition. (S.) And baAta bibiyoy^api He passed the night in an evil state or condition (AZ, T, S, * M.) bawaA='N Equal; equivalent; like; alike; a match; (Akh, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) and particularly, if slain in retaliation for another. (M.) It is applied to one, and to two, and to more: so that you say, fulaAnN bawaA='N fulaAnN Such a one is the equal, &c., of such a one if slain in retaliation for him: (M:) and huwa bawaA='N He is an equal, &c.; and so hiYa she: and humo bawaA='N They are equals, &c.; and so hun~a they, referring to females: (Mgh:) and humo bawaA='N fiY h`*aA AlA^amori They are equals in this affair. (T.) Hence, in a trad. of 'Alee, respecting witnesses, A_a*a kaAnuwA bawaA='N When they are equals in number and rectitude. (Mgh.) And maA fulaAnN lifulaAnK bibawaA='N Such a one is not an equal, &c., to such a one. (T.) And damu fulaAnK bawaA='N lidami fulaAnK The blood of such a one is an equivalent for the blood of such a one. (S.) And AljiraAHaAtu bawaA='N Wounds are to be retaliated equally: a trad. (T, Mgh.) And Alqawomu EalaY bawaA='i The people, or company of men, are in a state of equality. (T.) And qusima AlmaAlu bayonahumo EalaY bawaA='K The property was divided among them equally. (T. [A similar ex. is given in the Mgh, and explained in the same manner; but there I find Eano bawaA='K; perhaps a mistranscription.]) And kal~amonaAhumo faA^ajaAbuwA Eano bawaA='K waAHidK [in a copy of the M EalaY bwA=' wAHd] We spoke to them, and they replied with one reply: (T, S, O, K: *) i. e., their reply was not discordant: Eano being here used in the sense of bi. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Retaliation. (T.) [See 1, near the end of the paragraph: as well as in other places.] It is related in a trad., that Jaafar Es-Sádik, being asked the reason of the rage of the scorpion against the sons of Adam, said, turiydu AlbawaA='a [It desires retaliation]; i. e., it hurts like as it is hurt. (TA.)
baAy^iY~N * and ↓ baAwiy~N rel. ns. of baA='N and baA the names of the letter b; (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np;) and ↓ bayawiY~N is a rel. n. of the same. (M in art. b.)
baAwiY~N bAwY bAwy see baAy^iY~N.
bayawiY~N bywY bywy see baAy^iY~N.

mabaA='apN mbA='h mbA='p The nightly resting-place of camels; (T;) the resting-place of camels, where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place; (T, S, * M, * L, K; *) and of sheep or goats likewise; also termed ↓ mutabaw~aA^N: (L, TA:) or the place to which camels return; (Mgh;) as also ↓ baA='apN: (Mgh, Msb:) this is the primary signification. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) A place of abode (T, S, M, K) of a people, in any situation; (T, S;) as also ↓ mubaw~aA^N (Bd and Jel in x. 93) and ↓ biyoy^apN (M, K) and ↓ baA='apN; (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, * K;) which last is hence applied in another sense, explained before, voce bA='apN: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place where people alight and abide next to a valley, or to the face, or front, of a mountain, where it rises from its base; [see baw~aA^ahumo manozilFA;] as also ↓ baA='apN. (T.) [Hence,] huwa raHiybN AlmabaA='api (assumed tropical:) He is largely bountiful. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The covert of the wild bull. (S, K. *) ― -b4- A nest of bees in a mountain: (M, K:) or, accord. to the T, the nightly resting-place of bees; not there restricted by mention of the mountain. (TA.) ― -b5- The part of the womb where the child has its abode; (M;) the part thereof which is the child's ↓ mutabaw~aA^. (K.) ― -b6- A well has what are termed mabaA='ataAni, which are The place where the water returns to [supply the place of] that which has [before] collected in the well [and been drawn], (M,) or the place where the water collects in the well; (TA voce maA='abapN;) and the place where stands the driver of the saAniyap [q. v.]. (M.) [See also mavaAbapN; and mavaAbN.]

HaAjapN mubiyoy^apN *
A want that is vehement, or pressing, (K, TA,) and necessary. (TA.)
mubaw~aA^N * see mabaA='apN, in three places.
mutabaw~aA^N * see mabaA='apN, in three places.

1 baAba lahu bAb lh bAb lp , aor. yabuwbu, (M, K,) quasi-inf. n., if there be such a verb, biwaAbapN, with the w not changed into Y because it is not an inf. n. properly speaking, but a subst., (Lth, T,) He was, or became, a door-keeper, or gate-keeper, to him; (M, K;) namely, a Sultán (M) [or other person].

2 bw~b bwb wyb [app., (assumed tropical:) He practised what are termed A^abowaAbu AlHarobi, meaning the expedients, tricks, or stratagems, of war, battle, or fight. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He charged upon, attacked, or assaulted, the enemy. (AA, T.) -A2- baw~abotu AlA^a$oyaA='a (assumed tropical:) I made the things to be divided into distinct A^abowaAb [meaning kinds, or sorts; or I disposed, arranged, distributed, or classified, the things under distinct heads]. (Msb.) And bw~b AlA^abowaAba (assumed tropical:) [He disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order, the kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like]. (TA voce A^aS~ala, q. v.) And bw~b Almuw^al~ifu kitaAbahu (assumed tropical:) [The author disposed, or divided, his book in, or into, distinct chapters]. (A.) [See baAbN.]
5 tbw~b bwb tbwb , (A,) or tbw~b baw~aAbFA, (S, M, K,) He took for himself a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (S, M, A, K.)

baAbN A^b A_b bA^b bA_b bAb b|b |b , originally bawabN, (M, Msb,) A door; a gate; a place of entrance: and the thing with which a place of entrance, such as a door or gate, is closed; of wood &c.: (MF, TA:) pl. A^abowaAbN (S, M, Msb, K) and biybaAnN (M, K) and A^abowibapN, (S, M, K,) [a pl. of pauc., said to be] only used for conformity with another word mentioned therewith, as in the saying (of Ibn-Mukbil, so in a copy of the S),
hat~aAku A^axobiyapK wa l~aAju A^abowibapK
[A frequent render of tents, a frequent enterer of doors], (S, M,) not being allowable when occurring alone; (S;) but IAar and Lh assert that it is a pl. of bAb without its being used for conformity with another word; (M;) and this is extr.; (M, K;) for bAb is of the measure faEalN, and a word of this measure has not a pl. of the measure A^afoEilapN [by rule]. (M.) You say, baAbN Ald~aAri [The door of the house]; and baAbu Albayoti [the door of the house, and of the chamber, and of the tent]; (Msb;) and baAbu Albaladi [the gate of the town or city]. (The Lexicons &c. passim.) And Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim assigns a bAb to a grave; calling the latter a bayot. (M.) It is also applied to an opening, or a channel, made for water, to irrigate seed-produce: pl. A^abowaAbN. (Mgh.) [And in Egypt, it is applied also to A sepulchral chamber, grotto, or cave, hewn in a mountain; from the Coptic βηβ: pl. biybaAnN only.] ― -b2- Hence, i. e. in a secondary application, the primary signification being “ a place of entrance, ” it is used as meaning (tropical:) A means of access, or of attainment, to a thing: (B, Kull, TK:) as in the saying, h`*aA AlEilomu baAbN A_ilaY Eilomi ka*aA (tropical:) This science is a means of attainment to such a science. (B, TK.) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) An expedient, a trick, a stratagem, or a process, by which something is to be effected pl. A^abowaAbN: as in A^abowaAbu AlHarobi the expedients. &c.
of war, battle, or fight; and baAbN mina Aln~ujuwmi a process of the science of the stars, meaning astrology or astronomy; and baAbN mina Als~iHori a process of enchantment; see an ex. voce siHorN. Compare Matt. xvi. 18, πύλαι ᾅδου οὐ κατισχύσουσιν αύτης, probably meaning “ the stratagems of Hell shall not prevail against it. ”] ― -b4- [Also (assumed tropical:) A mode, kind, sort, class, or category.] Suweyd Ibn-Kuráa uses metaphorically the pl. A^abowaAb in relation to rhymes; saying,
A^atayotu biA^abowaAbi AlqawaAfiY kaA^an~amaA
A^a*uwdu bihaA sirobFA mina AlwaHo$i nuz~aEaA
(tropical:) [I gave utterance to the various kinds of rhymes as though I were driving with them a herd of wild animals desirous of the males, or of their wonted places of pasture]. (M, L.) [You say also, huwa mino h`*aA AlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) It is of this mode, kind, sort, class, or category: a phrase of frequent occurrence in lexicons &c. See also baAbapN.] ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) A chapter; and sometimes a section, or subdivision, of a chapter; of a book or writing;] conventionally, (assumed tropical:) a piece consisting of words relating to matters of one kind; and sometimes, to matters of one species: (Kull:) pl. A^abowaAbN. (A.) See also baAbapN. ― -b6- [Also (assumed tropical:) A head, or class of items or articles, in an account, or a reckoning; as in the saying,] bay~anotu lahu HisaAbahu baAbFA baAbFA (assumed tropical:) [I explained, or made clear, to him his account, or reckoning, head by head, or each class of items or articles by itself]; a phrase mentioned by Sb: (M:) [or, sometimes,] baAbN (M, K) and ↓ baAbapN (T, M, K) are used in relation to Huduwd [which here means the punishments so termed], and to an account, or a reckoning, (T, M, K,) and the like, (T, M,) as signifying the extreme term or limit; syn. gaAyapN; (M, K;) but IDrd hesitated respecting this, and therefore it is not mentioned in the S. (TA.)

baAbapN A^bh bA^bh bAb bAbh bAbp b|bh |b |bh (assumed tropical:) A mode, or manner; syn. wajohN: (ISk, K:) pl. baAbaAtN. (K.) [See also baAbN, which has a similar, and perhaps the same, signification.] Hence, h`*aA mino baAbatiY means (assumed tropical:) This is of the mode, or manner, that I desire; (TA;) this is suitable to me: (IAmb, TA:) and h`*aA $aYo'N mino baAbatika, (S,) or h`*aA baAbatuka, (A,) (assumed tropical:) this is a thing suitable to thee: (S, A:) and h`*aA baAbatuhu (assumed tropical:) this is suitable to him. (K.) Accord. to most of the critics, it is tropical. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN A^ahowanu baAbaAtihi Alka*ibu (assumed tropical:) Such a one, the lightest of the kinds (A^anowaAE) of his wickedness is lying. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A habit: a property; a quality; nature; natural disposition: or a practice; or an action: syn. xaSolapN. (Abu-l-'Omeythil, TA.) [Hence, perhaps, the last of the exs. cited above from the A.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A condition; syn. $aroTN: as in the saying, h*aA baAbapu h`*aA (assumed tropical:) [This is the condition of this]. (M, K. *) ― -b4- baAbaAtu AlkitaAbi (assumed tropical:) The lines of the book or writing: (M, A, K:) or it may mean its ↓ A^abowaAb [i. e. chapters, or sections of chapters]: (M:) this has no sing.: (A, K:) [ISd says,] I have not heard any sing. of it. (M.) ― -b5- See also baAbN; last signification.

bawobaApN bwb bwbAh bwbAp
A desert; or a desert in which is no water; syn. falaApN: (T, IJ, M, K:) as also mawomaApN; (T, MF;) the b being changed into m, as is often the case. (MF.) [It is mentioned in the S, and again in the K, in art. bw, as syn. with mafaAzapN.]
biwaAbapN bwAb bwAbh bwAbp The office, or occupation, of a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (M, K.) [See 1.]

baw~aAbN bwAb
A door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (S, * M, Msb, K, TA.)

A^abowaAbN mubaw~abapN * (assumed tropical:) [Kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like, disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order,] is a phrase similar to A^aSonaAfN muSan~afapN. (S.) You say also kitaAbN mubaw~abN (assumed tropical:) [A book disposed in, or divided into, distinct chapters]. (A.)

div2.head: Quasi bwj
div2.entryFree: baAjN bAj ; pl. A^abowaAjN: see art. bA^j. AZ mentions it as without ': ISk, as with '. (ISd, TA.)

1 baAHa A^H bAH bA^H , (A, Msb, K,) aor. yabuwHu, (Msb,) inf. n. bawoHN, (A, Msb,) It (a secret, A, or a thing, Msb) became apparent, or manifest. (A, Msb, K.) You say, baAHa maA katabotu [What I concealed became apparent]. (A.) And A^aEuw*u biA@ll~`hi m$no bawoHi Als~ir~i waka$ofi Als~itori [I seek protection by God from the appearing of the secret, and the removing of the veil, or covering]. (A.) -A2- baAHa bihi, (S, A, Msb, K,) [aor. as above,] inf. n. bawoHN and buw^uwHN and buw^uwHapN, (K, TA,) He revealed, or disclosed, it; (S, A, Msb, K;) namely, a secret, (S, A, K,) or a thing; (Msb;) as also ↓ AbAHhu. (A, Msb, K.) It (the former) is said to be from ↓ AlA_ibaAHahu [the inf. n. of the latter] signifying The showing a thing to the beholder in order that he who will may take it. (TA.) You say, sir~FA fabaAHa bihi ↓ A^abaAHahu He revealed to him a secret, and he (the latter) [revealed it, i. e.,] did not conceal it. (TA.) And buHo biA@somika wa laA takoni Eanohu [Reveal thou thy name, and make not a mere allusion to it]. (A.)

4 AbAH A^bAH AbAH , inf. n. A_ibaAHapN: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- A_ibaAHapN and ↓ AisotibaAHapN are used as syn.: but it is said that the former signifies The making a thing allowable, or free, to him who desires it, or seeks it: and the latter, the taking a thing as allowed, allowable, free, or lawful. (MF.) You say, AbAH Al$~aYo'a He made the thing allowable, or free. (L.) And AbAH maAlahu He gave permission either to take or let alone his property; made it allowable, or free, either way one might choose to take. (Msb.) And A^abaHotuka Al$~aYo'a I made, or have made, the thing allowable, free, or lawful, to thee, (S, L, K, TA,) to take it, [or let it alone,] or do it, [or make use of it,] or possess it; but not by the law of the religion, for to do this belongs to God and his apostle; except in the language of this law. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is said that] A_ibaAHapN bears a signification similar to that of nuhobaY [i. e. Spoliation; a taking of spoil; or the taking a thing as spoil; a signification more properly belonging to the inf. n. of 10, q. v.]. (L.)

10 AstbAHhu AstbAHh AstbAHp {stbAH {stbAHh {stbAHp
He deemed it, or esteemed it, to be allowed, allowable, free, or lawful; namely, the property of another: (A:) or he took it as allowed, allowable, &c. (A, * MF.) See 4. ― -b2- He took it as spoil, or plunder. (TA.) ― -b3- He made an attack upon it; namely, the property of another. (Msb.) ― -b4- He took him captive, making him as a lawful possession to him. (TA.) ― -b5- And AisotabaAHahumo, (K,) or AisotabaAHuwhumo, (S,) He, or they, extirpated, or exterminated, them. (S, K.)

buwHN bwH has the following various significations assigned to it in explanations of the saying, Aibonuka A@bonu buwHika ya$orabu mino SabuwHika: (S, TA:) The penis: (S, K, Har p. 336:) the faroj [or pudendum, app. meaning, of a woman]: (K, Har p. 328 on the authority of AO:) the nafos [meaning one's self]: (IAar, T, S, Meyd, L:) coitus; syn. waTo'N (S) or jimaAEN: (K:) and accord. to the last but one of these renderings, [and virtually accord. to the others also,] the saying means Thy son is the son of thyself, [who drinks of thy morningdraught]; (T, TA;) he whom thou hast begotten, not he whom thou hast adopted: (IAar, and Mtr in Har p. 328:) or bwH, here, is pl. of baAHapN; (A, TA, Har p. 336;) and the meaning is, he who has been born within the courts of thy house; (A;) or, in the court of thy house, (TA, Har,) not in the house of another: (TA:) or bwH is here a subst. from baAHa Al$~aYo'i; and the meaning is, thy son is he whom thou hast openly acknowledged (buHota bihi), and whom his mother hath also, agreeably with thee: (Har p. 328:) [accord. to some,] it signifies also i. q. A^aSolN [i. e. origin; or race, or stock, which it may mean in the saying above: or original, or primary, state, or condition]; (K, Har p. 328;) [for] one says, rajaEa A_ilaY buwHihi [He returned, or reverted, to his original, or primary, state, or condition]. (Har p. 328.)

baAHapN A^H bAH bAHh bAHp bA^Hh The court; or a spacious vacant part, or portion, in which is no building; syn. saAHapN, (S A, K,) and EaroSapN; (A, TA;) of a house or dwelling: (S, TA:) pl. buwHN [q. v.]. (A, TA.) Hence [is said to be derived] buHobuwHapu Ald~aAri [mentioned in art. bH]. (TA.) One says also, naHonu fiY baAHapi Ald~aAri, meaning We are in the middle, or midst, or best part, of the abode, or district, or country; i. e. A^awosaTihaA. (TA.) And hence, accord. to Fr, tabaHobaHa [explained in art. bH]. (Az, TA.) It is said in a trad., layosa liln~isaA='i mino baAHapi AlT~ariyqi $aYo'o, meaning [Women have no right] in the middle of the road. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The main part or body of water: (K:) applied by most of the lexicologists to the sea. (TA.) [In the present day applied to A deep part of the sea, distant from land; the deep; the main, or main sea.] ― -b3- And Many palm-trees. (Aboo-Sárim El-Bahdalee, IAar, K.)

A^amarahu bimaEoSiyapK bawaAHFA *
He ordered him to disobey, or rebel, openly. (K.) The last word occurs in this sense in two trads.; but in one of them, accord. to one recital, it is baraAHFA. (TA.)

huwa baw^uwHN bimaA fiY Sadorihi *
He is one who reveals, or discloses, what is in his bosom; as also bayoHaAnN and bay~aHaAnN; (K;) the Y being originally w. (TA.)

mubaAHN mbAH
Allowed or allowable [to be taken, or let alone, or done, or made use of, or possessed; see 4]; made allowable, free, or lawful; contr. of maHoZuwrN. (S, A.)

AlmubiyHu AlmbyH
The lion. (K.)

1 baAxati Aln~aAru bAxt AlnAr , (S, A, L, K,) aor. tabuwxu, inf. n. bawoxN and buw^uwxN and bawaxaAnN, (L,) The fire abated; or became allayed: (S, L, K: *) or became extinguished, or quenched. (A.) And bAx AlHar~u The heat abated, or became allayed. (S, A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baAxati AlHum~aY (assumed tropical:) The fever abated, or became allayed. (S.) And bAx Eanohu Alwirodu (tropical:) His fever abated, or remitted. (A, TA.) And bAx gaDabuhu (tropical:) His anger abated, or became assuaged. (S, * A, K. *) And bayonahumo HarobN maA yabuwxu saEiyruhaA (assumed tropical:) Between them is war of which the fire does not become extinguished, or quenched. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] bAx likewise signifies (tropical:) He became fatigued, (S, L, K,) and out of breath. (L) You say, EadaA Hat~a=Y baAxa (S, A, L) (tropical:) He ran until he became fatigued (S, L) and out of breath. (L.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) flagged; or became remiss, or languid. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. buw^uwxN, (assumed tropical:) It (flesh-meat) became altered, or changed in odour or otherwise for the worse, (K, TA,) And corrupted, or tainted. (TA.)

4 AbAx AbAx
He extinguished, or quenched, fire. (A, K.) And He (God) abated, or allayed, the heat. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AbAx Aln~Ay^irapa bayonahumo (tropical:) [He extinguished, or assuaged, the discord, or rancour, or enmity, that was between them]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And A^abixo Eanoka mina AlZ~ahiyripa (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the midday-heat shall have become allayed, and the air be cool. (IAar, TA in art. fyH and in the present art.)

buwxN bwx
A state of confusion, or perplexedness. (S, K.) You say, humo fiY buwxK mino A^amorihimo They are in a state of confusion, or perplexedness, with respect to their affair, or case. (S, K. *) And it is said in a prov., waqaEuwA fiY duwkapK wa bawxK, meaning They fell into evil, or mischief, and altercation. (Meyd, TA.)
1 baAda A_d bA_d bAd bAdy , inf. n. bawodN and bawaAdN: see art. byd.

1 baAra bAr b|r |r , (S, M, Msb,) aor. yabuwru, (Msb,) inf. n. bawaArN (Lth, T, S, M, K) and baworN, (M, K,) or buwrN, (Msb,) He, (S,) or it, (Msb,) perished. (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K.) You say, baAduwA wa baAruwA [They became extinct, and perished]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baArati AlA^aroDu (tropical:) The land was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state, and uncultivated; (K, * TA;) was unsown. (A.) ― -b3- And baAra Eamaluhu (assumed tropical:) His work was, or proved, vain, or ineffectual: such is the signification of the verb in the Kur xxxv. 11. (S, K.) ― -b4- And baAra, (T, S, &c.,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawaArN, (Msb,) (tropical:) It (a thing, Msb, or commodity, T, S, A, Mgh) was, or became, unsaleable, or difficult of sale, or in little demand: (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb:) because a thing, when neglected, becomes of no use, and thus resembles that which perishes. (Msb.) ― -b5- And baArati Als~uwqu, (T, M,) inf. n. baworN and bawaArN, (K,) (tropical:) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (T, M, K.) ― -b6- And baArati AlA^ay~imu, (A,) inf. n. bawaArN, (T, S, K,) (tropical:) The woman without a husband was not desired, or sought for: (A:) or remained in her house long without being demanded in marriage. (T, K.) ― -b7- [baAra is also used as an imitative sequent of HaAra; like as baAy^irN is of HaAy^irN: see exs. in art. Hwr.] -A2- baAra Aln~aAqapa, (T, S, A, K,) aor. as above, (T, S, A,) inf. n. baworN, (S,) He brought the she-camel to the stallion to see if she were pregnant or not: (T, S, A, K:) for if she is pregnant, she voids her urine in his face (S, K) when he smells her. (S.) ― -b2- Also He (the stallion) smelt the she-camel to know if she were pregnant or not; (T, S, M, K;) and so ↓ AbtArhA. (S, M.) ― -b3- Hence the saying, buro liY maA Eanoda fulaAnK (tropical:) Try thou, or examine, and learn, for me, what is in the mind (nafos S) of such a one. (S, A. *) You say, baArahu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (T, S,) inf. n. baworN; (T, M, K;) and ↓ AbtArhu, (M,) inf. n. AibotiyaArN; (S, K;) meaning (tropical:) He tried him; assayed him; proved him by experiment or experience; examined him. (T, S, M, K.) ElKumeyt says,
↓ pi A_im~aA A@botihaArFA w A_im~aA A@botiyaAraA
qabiyHN bimivoliYa naEotu AlfataA
(T, S) (tropical:) It were foul in the like of me to characterize the damsel either by false accusation or by trying, with speaking truth, to elicit what is in her mind (maA EinodahaA [i. e. maA fiY nafosihaA, agreeably with an explanation given above]): (S, TA:) or ↓ AbtyArA, which is without ', here signifies by asserting with truth my having had sexual intercourse with her: (TA:) [for] AbtArhA signifies he asserted with truth that he had had sexual intercourse with her; and AbthrhA “ he asserted the same falsely: ” (A 'Obeyd, T:) and the former signifies also he had sexual intercourse with her (K, TA) by force; he ravished her: (TA:) or AbtAr signifies he charged, or upbraided, a person with that which was not in him; and Abthr “ he charged, or upbraided, with that which was in him. ” (TA in art. bhr.)

4 AbArhu A^bAr A^bArh AbArh AbArp bArY by^r |bArh
He (God) destroyed him; caused him to perish. (S, M, A, K.)
8 A_ibotawara see 1, in four places.

A^aroDN baworN * , (A 'Obeyd, T, &c.,) in which the latter word is an inf. n. [of 1] used as an epithet, (IAth,) (tropical:) Land not sown; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, IAth;) as also ↓ bawaArN, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] of which the pl. is buwrN: (A, IAth:) or land before it is prepared for sowing (AHn, M, K) or planting: (AHn, M:) or land that is left to lie fallow one year, that it may be sown the next year: (K:) and ↓ A^aroDN baAy^irN, (Zj, M, K,) and ↓ baAy^irapN, (Zj, K,) and ↓ buwrN, [which is originally an inf. n.,] (K,) or AlA^aroDi ↓ buwru, [in which the former word may be pl. of bawaArN, mentioned above,] (M,) (tropical:) land that is in a bad state, and uncultivated, (K, * TA,) unsown, (M, TA,) and not planted: (TA:) or left unsown. (Zj, M.) You say also, A^aSobaHato ↓ manaAziluhumo buwrFA (assumed tropical:) Their abodes became void, having nothing in them. (Fr, T.) ― -b2- See also buwrN.

buwrN b*r b*wr A bad, or corrupt, man; (S, A, K;) and one (M, K) in a state of perdition; (S, M, A, K;) in whom is no good; (S, K;) originally an inf. n., (Fr, T,) and [therefore, as an epithet,] applied also to a female, (AO, T, S, M, K,) and to two persons, and more: (AO, T, M, K:) [but see what here follows:] ↓ baAy^irN, also, signifies bad, or corrupt; destitute of good; (Zj, M;) a man in a state of perdition; (AO, T, S;) and its pl., (K,) or rather quasi-pl., (M, TA,) is ↓ baworN, (M, K,) like as nawomN is of naAy^imN, and SawomN of SaAy^imN; (M, TA;) and another pl. of the same is buwrN, (AO, T, S, M,) like as HuwlN is of HaAy^ilN, or, accord. to some, as Akh states, this is a dial. var., not a pl., of baAy^irN. (S.) ― -b2- See also baworN, in three places. -A2- A_in~ahumo lafiY HuwrK wa buwrK (A, TA [but in the latter, jwr is put for Hawr]) Verily they are in a state of deficiency, or detriment. (TA.) See also baAy^irN. [And see HaworN.] You say also, *ahaba fulaAnN fiY ↓ AlHawAri wa AlbawaAri Such a one went away in a defective and bad state. (L, TA in art. Hwr.)

baAriY~N A^ry bA^ry bAr bArY bAry bAryy b|ry |r |ry and ↓ buwriY~N and ↓ baAriy~apN (As, S, M, K) and ↓ buwriy~apN (M, K) and ↓ baAriyaA='u and ↓ buwriyaA='u, (S, M, K,) all arabicized words, from the Persian, (M,) A woven mat, (M, K,) made of reeds; (S;) what is called in Persian buwriyaA: (As, K:) or a rough HaSiyr [or mat]. (Msb in art. brY [to which the words belong accord. to Fei, and the same is asserted to be the case by some others].) [The pl. is bawaAriY~u.] It is said in a trad., kaAna laA yaraY ↓ baA^osFA biAlS~alaApi EalaY AlbuwriY~i explained as meaning He did not see any harm in praying upon a mat made of reeds. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, (M,) A road; syn. TariyqN: (K, M:) [so, perhaps, in the trad. cited above:] arabicized. (K.)

buwriY~N bwr bwrY bwry wrY : see baAriY~N, in two places. -A2- Also A kind of fish; [a species of mullet, the mugil cephalus of Linnæus, of the roe and milt of which is made what the Italians call botargo, and the Arabs baTaArix, and, accord. to Golius, bwtrgA;] so called from a town in Egypt, named buwrapu, (K,) between Tinnees and Dimyát, of which there are now no remains. (TA.)
baAriy~apN A^ry bA^ryh bAr bAryh bAryp b|ryh b|ryp |ry : see baAriY~N.
buwriy~apN bwry bwryh bwryp : see baAriY~N.
baAriyaA='u bAryA=' : see baAriY~N.
buwriyaA='u bwryA=' : see baAriY~N.

bawaArN bwAr , an inf. n. of 1: see buwrN, last sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] bawaAri, like qaTaAmi, [an indecl. noun,] Perdition: (El-Ahmar, S, M, K:) as in the saying, nazalato bawaAr EalaY Alkuf~aAr Perdition fell upon the unbelievers. (El-Ahmar, S, TA.) -A2- See also baworN.

bawaAriY~N bwAr bwArY bwAry
A seller of mats of the kind called baAriY~N &c. (K.)

baAy^irN * : see buwrN. ― -b2- You say also rajulN HaAy^irN baAy^irN, (T, S, M, A, K,) and ↓ fiY HuwrK wa buwrK, (A,) meaning A man who does not apply himself rightly, (T, S, TA,) or has not applied himself rightly, (K,) to anything; (T, S, K;) erring; losing his way; (T;) who will not do right of his own accord, nor obey one directing him aright: (K:) it may be from the signification of laziness, or sluggishness, and it may be from that of perdition: (M:) [or] bAy^r is here an imitative sequent of HAy^r. (S.) [Respecting the latter phrase, see also art. Hwr.] ― -b3- See also baworN, in two places.

faHolN mibowarN fHl mbwr
A stallion-camel that knows the state of the female, whether she be pregnant or not. (M, A, K.)
mubiyrN mbyr A destructive man, acting exorbitantly in destroying others. (TA, from a trad.)

baAzN A^z bA^z bAz bAzy
i. q. baAzK; [see art. bzw;] (S, K;) a dial. var. of the latter; (S;) as also baA^ozN: (IJ, TA:) dual.
baAzaAni bAz bAzAn : (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^abowaAzN and [of mult.] biyzaAnN: (S, K:) the dual of baAzK is baAziyaAni; (K;) and the pl. is buzaApN (S, K) and bawaAzK. (K.)

1 baAsahu A^s bA^sh bAs bAsh bAsp b|sh |s , aor. yabuwsuhu, (S,) inf. n. bawosN, a Persian word, arabicized, (S, A, K,) He kissed him. (S, A, K.) You say also, baAsa lahu AlA^aroDa He kissed the ground to him. (A, TA.)

mabuwsN mbws
Kissed: you say, Alyawoma bisaATuka mabuwsN wa gadFA A^anota maHobuwsN [To-day thy carpet is kissed, and to-morrow thou art imprisoned]. (A.)

1 baA$a * , aor. yabuw$u, inf. n. bawo$N, He mixed, or confounded. (Fr.) See also $aAba, in art. $wb. ― -b2- He associated with bawo$, meaning, people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort. (IAar.) ― -b3- baA$uwA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (A, K,) They (mixed people, A, K, of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, TA) cried out, or vociferated; or did so calling for aid or succour; or in distress and impatience; or in fear. (A, K.)
2 bw~$wA * , inf. n. tabowiy$N, They became mixed, or confused: (K:) or numerous, and mixed or confused: (TA:) and ↓ tbw~$wA signifies the same. (K.)
5 tabaw~a$a see 2.

bawo$N *
A mixed or confused assembly or company: (A, K:) or an assembly, or a company, of mixed or confused people: (S:) or only of different tribes: or a multitude of men: as also ↓ buw$N, in these several senses: (K:) and, accord. to the women of Temeem, of beasts also: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA in art. hw$:) or people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort: (IAar:) or a family, or household: (ISd:) and [it is said by F that] it also signifies sons of the same father, when assembled together: (K:) resembling a contr. signification to that mentioned above, which restricts the application to such as are of different tribes: but it is said in the O, that banuw AlAbA', [app. a mistake for banuw AlA^abi, meaning sons of the same father,] when assembled together, are not called by this name: (TA:) A^awobaA$N is a pl. of this word, formed by transposition. (S.) You say, jaAw^uwA fiY hawo$K wa bawo$K They came in assemblage and multitude. (A.) And jaA='a mina Aln~aAsi Alhawo$u wa Albawo$u The multitude of the people came: (AZ:) or the assembly and family or household. (ISd.) And tarakotuhumo hawo$FA bawo$FA I left them [in great numbers and] in confusion. (K.) And ↓ bawo$N baAy^i$N, (S, K,) or ↓ baAy^i$N ↓ buw$N, (CK,) [app. A numerous, or large, assembly of mixed or confused people.] And ↓ jaA='a biAlbawo$i AlbaAy^i$i He came with multitude, or the multitude. (TA.)
buw$N * : see bawo$N, in three places.
bawo$iY~N * A poor man having a numerous family or household: (S, K:) or having a family or household: (Aboo-Sa'eed:) and one of the baser and common sort of men: as also ↓ buw$iY~N. (K.)
buw$iY~N * : see what next precedes.
baAy^i$N * : see bawo$N, in three places.

1 baAEa bAE , (S, TA,) aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (S, K, TA,) He extended his arms to their full reach; expl. by basaTa baAEahu; (TA;) and the inf. n. by mad~u AlbaAEi; with a thing; as also ↓ tbw~E. (K.) ― -b2- He (a camel) stretched forth his fore legs to the full (mad~a A^abowaAEahu); as also ↓ tbw~E; and in like manner a gazelle: (TA:) and he (a horse) stepped far, or took long steps, in his running; (S, K;) and in like manner one says [baAEat] of a she-camel. (S.) You say, mar~a yabuwEu, and ↓ yatabaw~aEu, He went along stretching forth his fore-legs to the full extent of his step. (L.) ― -b3- baAEa biAlmaAli, aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (Lth, K,) He extended his arm, or hand, [liberally, or bountifully,] with the property. (Lth, K, TA.) You say also, buEo buEo, meaning (assumed tropical:) Stretch forth thine arms, or hands, (baA Eayoka,) in acts of obedience to God. (IAar.) And lilomasaAEiY ↓ tabaw~aEa (tropical:) He stretched forth his arms (mad~a baAEahu) [to attain means of honour and elevation]. (TA.) And ↓ maA yudoraku tabaw~uEuhu (assumed tropical:) The point to which he has reached is not to be attained: (K, TA:) and, as Lh says, ↓ laA taboluguwna tabaw~uEahu (assumed tropical:) Ye will not, or shall not, reach the point to which he has attained: originally, his length of step. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ A_i*aA baAEa A@nobaAEa When he accomplishes his want, he goes away. (Har p. 592.) -A2- baAEa AlHabola, (Msb, TA,) first pers. buEotuhu, (S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, Msb, TA,) He measured the rope by the bAE [or fathom]; (Msb;) he extended his bAE [or arms stretched to the full reach] with the rope; (S;) or he extended the rope with his bAE; or, which is nearly the same in meaning, he extended his arms with the rope until it became a bAE [or fathom in measure]; (TA;) like as you say, $abarotuhu from Al$~iboru. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] yabuwEu AlA^aroDa He traverses the ground with wide step and quick motion. (Ham p. 720.)
5 tabaw~aEa see 1, in six places: ― -b2- and see 7.

7 AnbAE A^nbAE AnbAE {nbAE and ↓ tbw~E, said of a rope, signify the same [app. It was measured by the bAE, or fathom]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AnbAEt AlHay~apu The serpent extended itself, after gathering itself together and coiling itself, in order to spring. (Lh, K.) ― -b3- Also AnbAE, said of a man, He leaped, or sprang, after being still: or he made an assault; or leaped, or sprang, and made a violent seizure. (TA.) [Hence,] muxoranobiqN liyanobaAEa Silent in order to leap, or spring, (K, and S in art. xrbq,) when he finds an opportunity; (S in that art.;) on account of a misfortune which he desires [to effect]; (S, K, in that art.;) or in order to make an assault: (TA:) or looking, or waiting, for an opportunity to leap, or spring, upon his enemy, or the object of his want, when able to do so; and in like manner, muxoranoTimN liyanobaAEa: (TA in art. xrbq:) a prov., (K,) applied to a man who is silent respecting a misfortune [which he desires to effect]; (TA;) or applied to a man who is long silent until he thinks his object inadvertent, and who is possessed of cunning: (As, TA in art. xrbq:) accord. to one relation, liyanobaAqa, i. e. to bring about, or effect, a baAy^iqap, meaning a calamity, or misfortune: (K:) or lynbAE may be for layonabaE, from nabaEa AlmaA='u. (Har p. 62.) [Hence also,] AnbAE Al$~ujaAEu mina AlS~af~i The courageous man went, or came, out, or forth, from the rank. (AAF.) ― -b4- AnbAE liY fiY siloEatihi He treated me in an easy manner in the sale of his commodity, or article of merchandise, and strained himself (Aimotad~a) to give his consent to it. (K, TA.) And hence, ↓ AinobayaAEN, as used by Sakhrel-Ghei in describing the conduct of a man towards a beautiful woman, or, accord. to one relation, ↓ AibotiyaAEN, The acting, or behaving, towards another, boldly, in a free and easy manner, or without shyness; syn. AinobisaATN; as also bayoEN (TA.) ― -b5- AnbAE also signifies He ran in a gentle manner, with a bending and a twisting of himself; from baAEa, aor. yabuwEu. (Ahmad Ibn-'Obeyd.) ― -b6- And he went away. (Har p. 592: see 1.) ― -b7- And It (sweat) flowed: (Msb, K:) or, as El-Fárábee says, extended. (Msb.) 'Antarah says, describing the sweat of a she-camel,
yanobaAEu mino *iforaY gaDuwbK jasorapK
[Flowing, or extending, from the part behind the ear of a she-camel quickly angered, spirited, or tall, or tall and bulky, or strong, and bold to
endure travel]: ynbAE being originally yanobawiEu; or, as most of the lexicologists say, originally yanobaEu, the A being inserted after the fet-hah of the b to render its sound full. (TA.)
8 AibotiyaAEN AbtyAE {btyAE : see 7, in the latter half of the paragraph.

baAEN bAE
A fathom; the space that is between [the extremities of] the two hands when they are extended to the right and left; (Msb;) the measure of the extension of the two arms (S, K, TA) with what is between them of the body; (TA;) as also ↓ bawoEN and ↓ buwEN; (K;) the last of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) said by AHát to be of the masc. gender: (Msb:) pl. A^abowaAEN (Msb, K) and biyEaAnN. (Ham p. 475.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The body, including the limbs; [because a fathom in height;] as in the phrase rajulN Tawiylu AlbaAEi (assumed tropical:) A man tall in the body; which has also another meaning, to be seen below: but you do not say, qaSiyru AlbaAEi as meaning short in the body. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also The arms; and particularly when extended to their full reach; as also the pl.: and in like manner, the fore legs of a beast: see several examples in the first paragraph of this art.] ― -b4- [And hence, (tropical:) Reach; power; or ability.] You say, huwa qaSiyru AlbaAEi (tropical:) He is lacking in power, or ability: a phrase which has also another meaning, to be seen below. (TA.) And qaSura baAEuhu Eano *`lika (tropical:) He was unable to attain, or to do, or effect, that: in this case, ↓ bwE is not used. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Reach, power, or ability, in the means, or causes, of attaining honour; or in generous, or honourable, qualities or actions: (TA:) (tropical:) eminence; nobility; honour; generosity: (Lth, S, K:) in which senses, ↓ bwE is not used. (Lth.) A poet says,
lahu fiY Almajodi saAbiqapN wa baAEu
[He has precedence and eminence in glory, honour, dignity, or nobility]. (Lth.) And rajulN Tawiylu AlbaAEi (tropical:) A man of large generosity. (TA.) And qaSiyru AlbaAEi (tropical:) Niggardly: a phrase which has also another meaning, mentioned above. (TA.)
bawoEN bwE and buwEN: see baAEN, in four places. -A2- The former also signifies A place that is broken, or crushed, (makaAnN munohaDimu,) in a small ravine (liSob) of a mountain. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
baAEapN bAE bAEh bAEp bAy^E The court (saAHap) of a house: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)
baw~aAEN bwAE wAEy (assumed tropical:) A large-bodied camel. (TA.)

baAy^iEN *
A young gazelle that stretches forth its fore legs to the full (yabuwEu) in going along: (K, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) pl. buwEN (K) and bawaAy^iEu. (TA.) And ↓ A^abowaAEu, a determinate noun, is applied to The ewe, because she does so in going along: and she is called to be milked thereby; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) by saying, A^abowaAEu A^abowaAEu. (Ibn-'Abbád.) You say also naAqapN baAy^iEapu A she-camel that steps far, or takes long steps: pl. bawaAy^iEu. (TA.) And ↓ farasN bay~iEN, (K,) originally bayowiEN, (TA,) A horse that steps far, or takes long steps. (Z, K.)
bay~iEN byE : see baAy^iEN.
A^abowaAEu * : see baAy^iEN.
munobaAEN mnbAE Anything that flows; or extends: (Msb:) anything sweating, or exuding sweat. (TA.)

1 baAqa bAq bAqy , (K,) aor. yabuwqu, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He came with, or brought, or effected, evil, or mischief, and altercations. (K.) ― -b2- baAqati Ald~aAhiyapu The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell, betided, or happened. (Msb.) And baAqatohumu Ald~ahiyapu, (S,) or AlbaAy^iqapu, (JK, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell them, or smote them; (S, K;) as also Ealayohimo ↓ AnbAqt: (JK, * K:) and Ealayohimo baAy^iqapu $ar~K ↓ AnbAqt A calamity, &c., burst upon them; syn. Ainofataqato; (S, K; *) like AnbAjt, (S,) from which IF thinks it to be changed: (TA:) and Ealayohimu Ald~ahoru ↓ AnbAq Fortune assaulted them, or assailed them, with calamity, like as the sound issues from the trumpet (Albuwq): (S:) and buqotuhumo [I assaulted them, or assailed them, with a calamity, &c.]. (JK.) And in like manner, one says, baAqatohumo baw^uwqN, (S, TA,) inf. n. bawoqN and buw^uwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster befell them, or smote them. (TA.) ― -b3- Also baAqa, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He wronged a man; treated him wrongfully, or unjustly: or he came upon a people, or company of men, suddenly, or unawares, without their permission; as also ↓ AnbAq: (K:) [or,] as some say, baAquwA Ealayohi they slew him: (TA:) and bihi ↓ AnbAq he wronged him. (K.) And baAqa bika He (a man, JK) came up, or forth, upon thee, from a low, or depressed, place. (JK, K.) And baAqa bihi He encompassed, or surrounded, him. (JK, K.) And baAqa Alqawomu Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) The people, or company of men, gathered themselves together against him, and slew him wrongfully: (K, * TA:) but some say that it means, as explained before, they slew him. (TA.) And baAqahumo, (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K,) aor. as above, (JK,) inf. n. bawoqN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA,) He stole from them; robbed them. (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K.)

7 A_inobawaqa see 1, in five places. muxoranobiqN liyanobaAqa, a prov., thus related by some, instead of liyanobaAEa, means Silent in order to bring about, or effect, a baAy^iqap, i. e., a calamity, or misfortune: (K in art. bwE, q. v.:) or, to launch forth, and manifest what is in his mind. (TA.) You say also, AnbAq EalayonaA biAlkalaAmi He broke forth upon us with evil speech. (JK.) And AnbAq biAlD~aHika He broke forth with laughter. (JK.) And AnbAqt AlmaTorapu The shower of rain poured forth with vehemence. (TA.) And AnbAq AlmaA='u The water became copious, or much in quantity. (JK.)

bawoqN bwq
Abundance of rain; as also ↓ buwqN. (TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

buwqN bwq [A trumpet;] a certain thing in which one blows; (IDrd, S, Mgh, K;) in which one blows as in a musical pipe: (Kr, K:) [mostly used in war, but] mentioned by a poet, cited by As, as used by the Christians: (S:) IDrd says, The Arabs used this word, but I know not its origin: Esh-Shiháb says, in the 'Ináyeh, that it is arabicized, from [the Persian] buwriY: (TA: [but this is obviously improbable:]) pl. buwqaAtN (Mgh, Msb) and biyqaAnN (Msb [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, biyaqaAtN]) [and A^abowaAqN, a pl. of pauc., commonly used in the present day]. nafaxa fiY Albuwqi [He blew the trumpet, lit., in the trumpet,] means [also] (tropical:) he spoke that in which was no profit. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) One who does not conceal a secret; (Lth, JK, K;) as also ↓ bawoqN. (K.) ― -b3- Also A certain thing in which the miller blows; (JK, K;) accord. to the copies of the K, resembling a minoqaAb; but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is a thing resembling a [shell of the kind called] minoqaAb, the hole of which is twisted; and sometimes the miller blows in it, raising his voice; and what he means thereby is known. (Lth, TA.) -A2- See also bawoqN.

baAqapN A^qp bA^qp bAqh bAqp
A bundle of herbs, or leguminous plants. (S, K.) [And in modern Arabic, A bunch of flowers.]

buwqapN bwq bwqh bwqp wqp
A shower, fall, or storm, of rain, (JK, S,) that has burst forth with a dash: (S, TA:) or such as is vehement; or disapproved, disliked, or deemed evil: (K:) pl. buwaqN. (JK, K.)
baw^uwqN * , or daAhiyapN baw^uwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, applied to a man, Thievish; a great thief. (JK.)

baAy^iqapN *
A calamity, misfortune, or disaster; (JK, S, Msb, K;) a vehement evil or mischief; (Msb;) a trail that befalls a people: (TA:) pl. bawaAy^iqN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., laA yadoxulu Aljan~apa mano laA yaA^omanu jaArahu bawaAy^iqahu, meaning, accord. to Katádeh, [He will not enter Paradise whose neighbour is not secure from] his wrongful, or injurious, conduct: or, accord. to Ks, his malevolent, or mischievous, dispositions, and his evil conduct. (S.) IF says, in the “ Makáyees, ” that bwq is not an accredited root, and that there is not, in his opinion, any correct word belonging to it. (TA.) [But this is a strange assertion.]

1 baAla A_l Al bA_l bAl bAly b|l |l , (T, S, &c.,) aor. yabuwlu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. bawolN (M, Msb) and mabaAlN, (Msb,) [He urined, discharged his urine, made water, or staled;] said of a man, (M, Msb,) and of a beast, (Msb,) &c. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baAla bawolFA $ariyfFA faAxirFA (tropical:) He (a man) begat offspring resembling him (El-Mufaddal, T, TA) in form and natural dispositions. (El-Mufaddal, TA.) ― -b3- A poet, using the verb metaphorically, says,
baAla suhayolN fiY AlfaDiyxi fafasado
(tropical:) [Canopus made water in the beverage prepared from unripe dates, and it became spoiled, or marred]: (M:) meaning, that when Canopus
rises [aurorally, which it does, in central Arabia, early in August, the making of that beverage is stopped, for] the season of unripe dates has passed, and they have become ripe. (L in art. fDx.) baAla suhayolN is also a prov., said when winter has come. (MF in art. xrt.) [See suhayolN.] ― -b4- bawolN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The having vent, so as to flow forth: (K:) whence baw~aAlN as an epithet applied to a wine-skin: see this word below. (TA.) ― -b5- And baAla (assumed tropical:) It melted, or dissolved: (K:) said of fat. (TA.)
2 bw~l A^aSola Al$~ajarapi * (K in art. qzH) [He made water upon the root, or stem, of the tree: or] he put urine at the root of the tree to render its fruit abundant. (TK in that art.)
3 laA A^ubaAwiluhu * , from AlbaAlu, I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind. (Z, TA in art. blw. See laA A^ubaAliyhi in that art.)

4 AbAl Alxayoli AbAl Alxyl , and ↓ AstbAlhA, [He, or it, made, or caused, the horses to stale: or] he stopped the horses for the purpose of [their] staling. (TA.) One says, (in threatening, PS,) lanubiylan~a Alxayola fiY EraSaAtikumo [We will assuredly make the horses to stale in your courts]. (S.) And it is said in a prov., A^aHomirapN ↓ baAla HimaArN faA@sotabaAla An ass staled, and caused some (other) asses to stale: applied to a case in which people help one another to do what is disagreeable. (Meyd.)

10 AstbAl AstbAl {stbAl
He desired, or required, to make water. (KL.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- El-Farezdak says,
wa A_in~a Al~a*iY yasoEaY liyufosida zawojatiY
kasaAEK A_ilaY A^usodi Al$~araY yasotabiyluhaA
meaning [And verily he who strives to corrupt my wife is like one betaking himself to the lions of Esh-Sharà (a certain road abounding with those animals)] to receive their urine in his hand. (S.)

baAlN A_l Al bA_l bAl bAly b|l |l
A state, condition, or case; syn. HaAlN (T, S, Msb, K) and $aA^onN: (T:) or a state, condition, or case, for which one cares; wherefore one says, maA baAlayotu bika*aA, inf. n. baAlapN, meaning “ I cared not for such a thing: ” (TA:) or a thing [or things] for which one cares: (Har p. 94:) and AlbaAlu signifies also baAlu Aln~afosi, i. e. care, or concern; and hence is [said to be] derived baAlayotu, having for its inf. n. baAlapN. (T.) One says, maA baAluka What is thy state, or condition, or case? (S.) [See the Kur xii. 50 and xx. 53: and see an ex. in a verse cited in this Lex. voce A_iyhi.] When it was said to a man, in former times, “ How hast thou entered upon the morning? ” he used to reply, bixayorK A^aSolaHa A@ll~`hu baAlakumo [With good fortune: may God make good your state, or condition]. (Ham p. 77.) wa yuSoliHu baAlahumo, in the Kur [xlvii. 6], means And He will make good their state, or condition, in the present world: (I'Ab, T:) or their means of subsistence in the present world, together with their recompense in the world to come. (M.) One says also, huwa raxiY~u AlbaAli He is in ample and easy circumstances (T, Msb) of life; (T;) he is not straitened in circumstances, nor troubled: (T:) or he is in an easy, or a pleasant, state or condition: (TA in art. rxw:) or he is easy, or unstraitened, in mind: (S:) [for] AlbaAlu, (T, M, K,) or raxaA='u AlbaAli, (TA,) signifies ampleness and easiness of life: (T, M, K, TA:) or AlbAl signifies an easy, or unstraitened, state of the mind. (S.) And huwa kaAsifu AlbaAli He is in an evil state or condition: (TA:) or he is straitened in his hope, or expectation: for AlbAl is said to signify hope, or expectation: (T:) so says El-Hawaázinee. (TA.) And layosa h`*aA mino baAliY This is not of the things for which I care. (S.) And it is said in a trad., kul~u A^amorK *iY baAlK lamo yubodaA^o fiyhi biHamodi A@ll~`hi fahuwa A^abotaru, i. e., Every honourable affair, for which one cares, and by which one is rendered solicitous, [in which a beginning is not made by praising God, is cut off from good, or prosperity:] or every affair of importance, or moment. (TA in two places in this art.) ― -b2- Also The heart, or mind; syn. qalobN, (T, S, Msb, K,) and xaladN, (Ham pp. 76 and 77,) and nafosN, (AZ, T,) and xaATirN. (M, K, Kull p. 179.) You say, xaTara bibaAliY, (Msb, Kull ubi suprà,) and EalaY baAliY, (Kull ibid.,) i. e., [It (an affair, or a thing, Kull) occurred to, or bestirred itself in, or moved,] my heart, or mind. (Msb, Kull.) And lamo yaxoTuro bibaAliY *`lika AlA^amoru, i. e., [That affair did not occur to, or] did not move me, or distress me. (T.) And maA yaxoTuru fulaAnN bibaAliY, i. e. [Such a one does not occur to, or move,] my heart, or mind. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence, Mind, or attention. You say, A^aEoTiniY baAlaka Give me thy mind, or attention. And] laA A^uloqiY A_ilayohi baAlFA [I will not, or I do not, give, or pay, any attention to him, or it]. (Z, TA in art. blw.) -A2- [The whale;] a great fish, (S, K,) of the fish of the baHor [here meaning sea]; (S;) a certain bulky fish, called jamalu AlbaHoru; (M;) it is a fish fifty cubits long: (MF:) [Kzw describes it as being from four hundred to five hundred cubits in length, and says that it sometimes shows the extremity of its fin, like a great sail, and its head also, and blows forth water rising into the air higher than an arrow can be shot: these and other exaggerated particulars he mentions in his account of the Sea of the Zenj: and in a later place he says, that it eats ambergris, and dies in consequence; and a great quantity of oil is procured from its brain, and used for lamps:] the word [in this sense] is not Arabic: (S:) in the O it is said to be arabicized, from [the Persian] waAlo. (TA.) -A3- The spade (mar~ [in the CK erroneously written mur~]) with which one works in land of seed-produce. (M, K.) -A4- See also baAlapN, in three places.

bawolN bwl , originally an inf. n., (Msb,) [Urine; stale:] pl. A^abowaAlN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A^abowaAlu AlbigaAli The seminal fluid of mules. (As, TA.) And hence, as being likened thereto, because it is fruitless, (As, TA,) (assumed tropical:) The saraAb [or mirage: in the CK Al$~arAbu]. (As, K, TA.) It is also applied to the road of El-Yemen, which is not travelled but by mules: see also art. bgl. (TA.) ― -b3- bawolu AlEajuwzi (assumed tropical:) Cow's milk. (TA.) ― -b4- bawolN signifies also (tropical:) Offspring. (M, K, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A large number. (K, TA.) ― -b6- See also A^abowalu.

baAlapN *Al b*Alh b*Alp
A [flask, or bottle, such as is called] qaAruwrap: (M, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ baAlN. (TA.) ― -b2- A [bag such as is called] jiraAb, (T,M, K,) small and large, in which mush is put: (T:) or (M [in the K “ and ”]) the receptacle of perfume: (S, M, K:) a Persian word, (S, M,) arabicized; (S;) in Persian biyolah, (T, S, M,) or baAlah: (M:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] ↓ baAlN. (T.) ― -b3- It is said to signify also An odour; a smell; (T;) on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer; (TA;) from balawotuhu meaning “ I smelled it, and tried, proved, or tested, it; ” originally balowapN; the w being transposed, and changed into A. (T.) ― -b4- And A staff with a pointed iron at the end, used by the hunters of El-Basrah, who throw it at the game: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] ↓ baAlN. (T, TA.) ― -b5- And hence it is applied by the vulgar to A small elongated sword. (TA.) -A2- It is also an inf. n. of baAlaY, which see in its proper art. (TK.)
bawolapN bwl bwlh bwlp wlh The origin (manobit [so in copies of the K accord. to the TA)] or daughter (binot [so in some copies of the K]) of a man; (K;) on the authority of El-Mufaddal. (TA.)

biylapN byl bylh bylp a subst. from baAla, (S, M, K,) [meaning A discharging of urine, making water, or staling: or a mode, or manner, thereof; as appears probable from its form, and from J's adding that it is] like jilosapN and rikobapN; (S;) [and also from the following phrase:] A_in~ahu laHasanu Albiylapi [Verily he is one who has a good mode of discharging his urine]; from Albawolu. (M.)
buwalapN bwl bwlh bwlp wlh That discharges much urine; syn. kaviyru Albawoli; (M, K;) applied to a man; (M;) and so ↓ baw~aAlN applied to a camel. (TA.)

bawaAlN bwAl wAly
A disease occasioning much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]: (M, K:) a disease that attacks sheep, or goats, such that they discharge urine until they die. (Ham p. 77.) You say, A^axa*ahu buwaAlN He was taken with much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]. (S.)

baw~aAlN bwAl wAly : see buwalapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A wine-skin from which the wine runs out. (TA.) ― -b3- And $aHomapN baw~aAlapN (assumed tropical:) A piece of fat that quickly melts or dissolves. (IAar, TA.)

A^abowalu mino kalobK *
More frequent in making water than a dog: or it may mean more abundant in offspring. (Meyd. [Freytag adds, in his Arab. Prov. i. 199, on the authority of Sharaf-ed-Deen, that ↓ bwl (i. e. bawolN) may signify urine or coitus or offspring.])
mabaAlN mbAl mbAly [The place of urine, or of the urinary discharge; meaning] the faroj [or pudendum of a man and of a woman]: whence the phrase, mabaAlN, fiY mabaAlK occurring in a trad. (TA,)
mabowalapN mbwlh mbwlp [A diuretic; a provocative of urine]. You say, kavorapu Al$~araAbi mabowalapN, (S, K, *) i. e., Much beverage occasions a discharging of urine. (TA.)
mibowalapN mbwlh mbwlp [A urinal;] a vessel (kuwz) in which one makes water. (S, K,*)

buwmN bwm and buwmapN A certain bird; [namely, the owl;] each word applying to the male and the female: (S, K:) or the former signifies the male, or males, (so in different copies of the M,) of the haAm [or owl-kind]; and the latter is its n. un.: (M, TA:) said by Az to be genuine Arabic: (TA:) pl. of the former A^abowaAmN. (IB, TA.)
buwmN baw~aAmN bwm bwAm [An owl, or male owls,] that cries, or that cry, much. (TA.)

1 baAnahu A^np bA^n bA^nh bA^np bAnh bAnp b|nh |n , aor. yabuwnu, (S in art. byn, Msb, K,) inf. n. bawonN, (Msb, TA,) i. q. baAnahu aor. yabiynu, (S ubi suprà K,) inf. n. bayonN, (TA,) meaning He excelled him; (S* ubi suprà, Msb;) he surpassed him in excellence and in manly virtue: so in the Iktitáf. (TA.)

baAnN bA^n bAn bAny b|n |n [a coll. gen. n., The ben-tree; a species of moringa; so in the present day;] a kind of tree, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) well known: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb:) its seed, or grain, [called Hab~u AlbaAni and jawozu AlbaAni and fusotuqu AlbaAni, the glans unguentaria, or nux unguentaria, or ben-nut,] has a good, or pleasant, [fragrant] oil, (K,) called duhonu AlbaAni [oil of ben], (S, Mgh, Msb,) and simply baAnN, the prefixed noun being suppressed: (Mgh:) [Az says,] it is the pl. of baAnapN. which is a certain tree having a fruit, or produce, which is perfumed with aromatics, after which its oil is expressed, of a good [or fragrant] quality: (T in art. bnY: its seed, or grain, is good for [removing] the [affections of the skin termed] bara$ and nama$ and kalaf and HaSaf and bahaq and saEafap and the mange, or scab, and for the peeling of the skin, applied in the form of a liniment with vinegar; and for hardness of the liver and the spleen, made into a beverage with vinegar; and a mivoqaAl thereof, drunk, is an emetic, which loosens crude phlegm: (K:) AHn says, (TA,) it is a kind of tree that grows tall, in a straight, or an erect, manner, like as grows the [species of tamarisk called] A^avol, and its leaves are [of the kind termed] hadab, like those of the Avl, but its wood has no hardness: the n. un. is with P: Aboo-Ziyád says, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and has long hdb, intensely green; it grows upon [hills, or what are termed] haDob; and its fruit resembles the pods of the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaA=', except that its greenness is intense; and in it is a seed, or grain, from which is extracted the oil of the bAn: on account of the straightness of its growth and of the growth of its braches, and their length and tenderness, the poets liken thereto the tender girl of tall and beautiful, or just, stature; saying kaA^an~ahaA baAnapN [As though she were a ben-tree], and kaA^an~ahaA guSonu baAnK [As though she were a branch of the ben-tree], &c.: thus does Keys Ibn-El-Kha- teem: (M in art. byn:) and so does Imra-el- Keys. (TA.) [See an ex. voce barahorahapN.] ― -b2- [It is also applied in the present day to A species of willow, the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus, properly called in Arabic xilaAf: and this is said to be meant by modern Arab poets when they liken an elegant girl to a twig of the bAn; but probably from their erroneously supposing this tree to be meant in the same case by the older poets.]

bawonN bwn wn
Excellence: an excellent quality; (S in art. byn, Msb;) as also ↓ bawonapN: (IAar; T:) or the distance, space, or interval, between tow things; as also darr; buwnN. (M, K.) You say, bayonahumaA bawonN baEiydN (T, S, Msb*) and bayonN baEiydN (T, S) [Between them two (meaning two men) is a wide distance]; i. e. between their tow degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Msb:) the former phrase is the more chaste: (S:) when corporeal distance is meant, one says, bayonahumaA bayonN, with Y; (Msb;) or in the case of [literal] distance, one says, A_in~a bayonahumaA labayonFA; not otherwise. (S.)
buwnN bwn wn : see bawonN.
bawonapN bwn bwnh bwnp wn : see bawonN ― -b2- Also Mutual separation. (IAar, T.)

1 baAhahaA bAhhA , (JK, K,) [aor. yabuwhu,] inf. n. bawohN, (TA,) He lay with her; syn. jaAmaEahaA; (K;) like baAkahaA. (JK.) -A2- baAha lahu, aor. yabuwhu, (JK, K,) inf. n. bawohN; (K;) as also baAha lahu, aor. yabaAhu, (JK,* K,) inf. n. bayohN; (K;) His attention became roused to it; (K;) he knew it, or understood it; or knew, or had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it: (JK, TA:) like baA^aha, and A^abaha or A^abiha. (TA.) And maA buhotu lahu; as also maA bihotu lahu; I did not know it, or understand it; or did not know,or had not knowledge, of it; was not cognizant of it: (JK, S,- K:) the inf. n. of the former is bawohN; and that of the latter, bayohN. (TA.)

baAhN bAh bAp a dial. var. of baA='apN (IAar, S) and of baA='N, (IAar, TA,) signifying Coitus: (S K:*) and marriage: (K, * TA:) as also ↓ baAhapN: (TA:) or a share of coitus; (JK, TA;) occurring in this sense in a trad., in which a woman is mentioned as having adorned herself for it: (TA:) also venereal passion: (TA in art. xf$:) [or the venereal faculty; as when one says of a drug or some other thing, yaziydu fiY AlbaAhi It increases the venereal faculty:] IKt says, of this word, baAhN, [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] that it is a mistranscription [app. meaning for baA='N]. (Msb and TA in art. bwA^.) [See also baA='apN.]

baAhapN bAhh bAhp b|hp |hp : see baA'N. -A2- Also The court of a house; or a spacious part, or portion, of a house, in which is no building; (JK, K, TA;) where people alight, or lodge: (JK:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)

baAhiY~N bAhY bAhy
That strengthens the venereal [faculty or] appetite. (TA in art. jzr, &c.)

2 bay~ayotu Al$~aYo'a * , (T, K,) inf. n. taboyiY~N, (K,) I made the thing apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous. (As, T, K*) -A2- Also, (K, as in the TA,) or Al$~aY'a, ↓,tab~ayayotu (M, and so in several copies of the K,) [both confirmed by what follows,] i. q. taEam~adotuhu [meaning I directed myself, or my course, or aim, to, or towards, the thing; made for it, or towards it; made it my object; &c.]. (M, K.) ― -b2- In the saying, Hay~aAka A@ll~`hu wa bay~aAka, the phrase HyAk All~h means May God make thee to have dominion: (S, M:) or may God prolong thy life: (M:) and by~Ak means AiEotamadaka biAlt~aHiy~api [may He bring thee prolongation of life; lit. may He direct himself to thee, or the like, with the gift of prolongation of life]; (As, S;) or qaSadaka biAlt~aHiy~api [which is the same]: (IAar, T:) or AiEotamadaka biAlomuloki [may He bring thee dominion]; (M;) so too says IAar: (TA:) or may He make thy state, or condition, to be good: (TA:) or may He make thee to laugh: (T, S, M, K:) so some say, accord. to As: (T:) and it is related that these words were addressed to Adam, in consequence of his having remained a hundred years without laughing after his son had been slain: (T, S:) so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr: (T:) or it means may He bring thee near [unto Himself]: (Aboo-Málik, As, T, M, K:) or may He bring thee: (IAar, S, M:) or may He prepare for thee an abode; i. q. baw~aA^aka, (K,) or baw~aA^aka manozilFA; the verb being here altered in order to assimilate it to the preceding verb, Hay~aA: (El-Ahmar, T, S:) this explanation was approved by As: (S:) the meaning intended thereby is, may He lodge thee in an abode in Paradise: (TA:) or, as some say, the verb in this case is an imitative sequent to that preceding it: (A'Obeyd, S K: *) but this is naught: (K:) A'Obeyd says that in his opinion it is not an imitative sequent, because an imitative sequent is scarcely ever coupled with what precedes it by w. (S.) As an ex. of bay~aA in the sense of qar~aba, Aboo-Málik cites this verse:
Aalokiboda waAlmaloHaA='a wa Als~anaAmaA
bay~aA lahumo A_i*o nazaluwA AlT~aEaAmaA
[He brought near to them, i. e., placed before them, when they alighted, the food, namely, the liver, and the flesh of the back extending from the withers to the rump, and the hump]. (T.) And IAar, explaining by~Ak as meaning qSdk bAltHy~p, cites the following verse:
A^aEoTaY EaTaA='a All~aHizi All~ay^iymi
A^abaA tamiymi ↓ lam~aA tab~ayayonaA
(T.) Accord. to J, the meaning in this instances may be agreeable with the explanation of by~Ak by AEtmdk bAltHy~p [so that the verse may be rendered When we betook ourselves with salutation to the father of Temeem, or, as the verse is cited in the S, to the brother of Temeem (A^axaA tmym), he gave the gift of the niggardly, the mean]: or it may mean we brought: and the verb admits of the same double rendering in other instances. (TA.) -A3- bay~ayotu baA='F HasanapF and HasanFA [I made, or wrote, a beautiful b]. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)

5 tby~A tbyA
It was, or became, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous, being near; syn. tabay~ana mino qurobK. (As, T.) -A2- See also 1, in two places.

AlbaY~N A^lbY A^lby AlbY Alby by lbY
The low, ignoble, mean, or contemptible, man; as also ↓ Aibonu bay~aAna, (IAar, T, K) and Abn hay~aAna, (IAar, T,) and Abn baY~, (K,) or haY~u bonu baY~, and ↓ hay~aAnu bonu bay~aAna: (Lth, T:) or the last two signify he whose stock and branch are unknown: (M:) or the same two, he who is unknown, and whose father also is unknown: (K in art. hY; and so the latter of them is explained in the S, both there and in the present art.:) and one says, maA A^adoriY A^aY~u haY~i boni baY~K huwa, meaning I know not what man he is.. (S.) Accord. to some, (Lth, T,) haY~u bonu baY~K was one of the sons of Adam, that went away in the earth when the rest of his children dispersed themselves, and no trace of him was afterwards perceived. (Lth, T, K.)
Aibonu bay~aAna Abn byAn : see AlbaY~u, in two places.
bayawiY~N bywY bywy rel. n. of baA='N or baA: whence qaSiydapN bayawiy~apN [as also baAy^iy~apN and baAwiy~apN] A qSydp of which the rawiY~ is b. (M in art. b.)
Albiyabo Albyb byAnw see A^abN, in art. Abw.

1 baAta bAt b|t |ty , (T, S M, &c.,) aor. yabiytu and yabaAtu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. bayotuwtapN (Lth, T, S A, Msb, K) and mabiytN (Msb, K) and mabaAtN (Msb) and bayotN and bayaAtN, (K,) has two meanings: in that which more commonly obtains, the action is restricted to the night: (Msb:) it is by night, or in night; not in sleep: (M:) you say, baAta yafoEalu ka*aA, meaning He did such a thing by night, or at night: (S, Msb, K:) [or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, doing such a thing: and he passed, or spent, the night, or a night, or a part thereof, or, as will be seen below, he entered upon the night, doing such a thing:] like as one says, Zal~a yafoEalu ka*aA as meaning “ he did such a thing by day, ” or “ at day-time: ” (S, Msb;*) IKoot and Es-Sarakustee and IKtt say that it has this meaning, and not “ he slept: ” (Msb:) [F adds,] wa layosa mina Aln~awomi, (K,) which is said to mean, “ and the action is not one of sleep;
