” so that when one sleeps by night, or at night, it is not correct to say, baAta yanaAmu: or, accord. to some, “ its meaning is not that of sleeping; ” so that one may say, baAta zayodN naAy^imFA [Zeyd was in the night, &c., or passed, or spent, the night, &c., sleeping]: (MF:) [Fei says,] it is only when one remains awake in the night: and hence the saying in the Kur [xxv. 65], waA@l~a*iyna yabiytuwna lir~abihimo suj~adFA waqiyAmFA [And those who pass the night prostrating themselves to their Lord and standing up in prayer]: (Msb:) Fr says that baAta Alr~ajulu means The man remained awake all the night, engaged in acts of obedience or of disobedience: (T, Msb:) [or it means the man entered upon the night; or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, in any state, or engaged in any action; for] Zj says, (M,) baAta is said of any one whom the night has overtaken, (M, K, *) whether he have slept or not slept: (M:) and Lth says, Albayotuwtapu signifies the entering upon the night: one says, bit~u A^aSonaEu ka*aA wa ka*aA [I entered upon the night doing such and such things]: and he adds, (T,) he who says baAta as meaning he slept commits an error; for you say, bit~u A^uraAEiY Aln~ujuwma [I entered upon, or passed, the night] looking at the stars: and how can he be sleeping who is looking at them? (T, Msb:) but Mullà 'Abd-El-Hakeem, in his Commentaries on the Mutowwal, says that baAta sometimes means he remained, continued, stayed, or dwelt, and he alighted and abode, by night, or at night, whether he slept or not: (MF:) and Ibn-Keysán says that it may be used in the same manner as naAma [he slept]; and also, [as will be explained below,] in the same manner as kaAna. (TA.) You say, baAta bayotuwtapF SaAliHapF (T) or Tay~ibapF (A) [He passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, in a good manner]. And bit~u Alqawoma and bit~u bihimo and bit~u Einodahumo [I passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, with, or at the abode of, the people, or company of men: the last of these phrases is the most common]. (A 'Obeyd, M, K.) ― -b2- Secondly, it is used in the sense of SaAra [He became]; (Msb;) or in the same manner as kaAna [he was]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) One says, baAta bimawoDiEi ka*aA He became [or was] in such a place; whether in night-time or in day-time. (Msb.) And hence the saying of the lawyers, baAta Einoda A@moraA^atihi layolapF He became [or was] with his wife one night; [which is the same as he passed a night &c.; though this, it will be observed, is not in this instance the signification of the verb alone;] whether sleeping or not. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Thus it is used both as a “ complete, ” i. e. an attributive, verb, and also as an “ incomplete, ” i. e. a non-attributive, verb.] ― -b4- baAta, aor. yabiytu, (T, A,) inf. n. bayotN, (T, M, K,) also signifies (tropical:) He married, or took a wife: (T, A:) [see bayotN below:] or (assumed tropical:) he gave in marriage; syn. of the inf. n. tazowiyjN. (Kr, M, K.)

2 by~t Albayota byt Albyt
He constructed, or built, the bayot [i. e. tent, or house, &c.]. (M.) -A2- by~t AlA^amori, [inf. n. as below,] He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, by night, or at night: (M:) and he thought, or meditated, upon it, considering its end, or issue, or result, (Zj, T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) or entered into it, (Zj, T,) by night, or at night. (Zj, T, S, M, &c.) And one says, buy~ita bilayolK, (T, A,) meaning the same as dub~ira bilayoli [It was thought, or meditated, upon, &c., by night, or at night]: (T:) [for] buy~ita Al$~aYo'u also signifies [simply] the thing was thought upon, and considered as to its end, issue, or result; syn. qud~ira. (S.) Accord. to El-Marzookee, they say of a thing that is not done deliberately, and with good consideration of its issue or result, h`*aA A^amorN qud~ira bilayolK; [in the text from which this is taken, without the syll. signs;] and hence the saying in the Kur [iv. 83], bay~ata TaAy^ifapN minohumo gayori A@l~a*iY taquwlu [A part of them meditateth by night upon doing otherwise than that which thou sayest; as is indicated in the M, where this is cited; and in like manner, yubay~ituwna, in the continuation of the same passage of the Kur, is explained in the T as meaning yudab~iruwna, and yuqad~iruwna, (i. e. mina Als~uwo'i,) layolFA]: but Aboo-Hilál says that a thing is meditated upon in the night in order that one may apply himself to it with strong purpose, and not be diverted by other things, so that it may be done with more firmness; and he cites the same passage of the Kur. (Ham p. 130.) And hence, in the Kur [iv. 108], A_i*o yubay~ituwna maA laA yaroDaY mina Alqawoli When they meditate, &c., (S, M, Bd, Jel,) by night, (S, M,) [what He will not approve, of speech,] and prepare it [in their minds] (yuzaw~iruwnahu [see art. zwr]). (Bd.) It is said in a trad., laA SiyaAma limano lamo yubay~iti AlS~iyaAma There is no fasting to him [meaning his fasting is null] who does not purpose it from the night. (TA. [See another reading, voce bat~a.]) And you say, bay~ata Aln~iy~apa He decided upon the purpose, or intention, by night, or in night-time. (Msb.) And bay~ata raA^oyahu He thought upon his opinion, and concealed it, or conceived it, in his mind. (TA.) ― -b2- bay~atahumo, (inf. n. taboyiytN, (Msb, TA,) He came upon them, (Mgh, but the verb is there pl.,) or made a sudden attack upon them, and engaged with them in conflict, (Msb,) or made a great slaughter among them, or engaged with them in vehement conflict, (S, M, K,) namely, the enemy, (S, Mgh, K,) or a people, (M,) by night: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) he came upon them (the sons of such a one) in the night, and made a sudden attack upon them, while they were heedless: (T:) he attacked them (the people of a house or place of abode) by night: he went to them (the enemy) in the night, without their knowledge, and took them by surprise. (TA.) ― -b3- kaAna laA yubay~itu maA lAFA walaA yuqay~iluhu He used not to retain property until night, nor to retain it until noon, when it came to him; but used to hasten the dividing of it. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also 4. -A3- by~t Aln~axola He trimmed, or pruned, the palm-trees, by cutting off the stumps of the branches, or by cutting off the straggling branches, not in the best part thereof. (K.) -A4- See also 5.

4 AbAthu A^bAt A^bAth AbAth AbAtp |by , inf. n. A_ibaAtapN, He (God) made him, or caused him, to pass, or spend, the night, [or a part thereof,] or to enter upon the night. (T, M, K.) You say, A^abaAtaka A@ll~`hu HasanapF [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night with happiness], (S,) and A_ibaAtapF HasanapF [in a good manner of doing so]. (T, A.) And [in like manner,] ↓ bay~ataka A@ll~`hu fiY EaAfiyapK [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night in health and safety]. (A.) And A^abaAtahu A@ll~`hu A^aHosana biytapK God made him to pass, or enter upon, the night in the best manner of doing so. (M, K. *)

5 tby~thu Eano HaAjatihi tbyth En HAjth tbyth En HAjtp [so in the TA and in a MS. copy of the K: in the CK ↓ bay~atahu:] He withheld,
or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted. (K.)

10 A_isotaboyata [AstbAt seems to signify He asked for, or required, biyt, or biytap i. e. food: (see musotabiytN:) and also to have the contr. signification; i. e. ― -b2- He possessed food: for you say,] laA yasotabiytu layolapF He possesses not a night's food. (T, K.) And laA yasotabiytu He has not food. (A.)

bayotN byt bytt [signifies A tent; properly, having more than one pole; but often applied without this restriction: and also a house; a chamber; an apartment; a closet; and the like]: a bayot is [a tent] of [goats'] hair ($aEar), (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of wool: (Mgh:) a byt of hair [i. e. hair-cloth] is that kind [of tent] which has more than one pole: the word is masc.: and applies to small and large: (M:) tents of goats' hair are peculiar to people of cold countries and of fertile regions, where the goats have abundant hair; for the goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun: (T in art. bnY:) a xibaA=' is a small byt of wool or of hair: a byt is what is larger than a xbA=': next is the miZal~ap, which is larger than the byt; but the term byt is also applied to a mZl~p when it is large and muraw~aq [i. e. furnished with a riwaAq, q. v.]: (T:) Ibn-El-Kelbee says that the Arabs have six kinds of byt; namely, a qub~ap, which is of skins, or tanned hides; a miZal~ap, of hair; a xibaA=', of wool; a bijaAd, of soft hair (wabar); a xayomap, of trees; an A^uqonap, of stone; and a sawoT, of hair; or this is the smallest of them: El-Baghdádee says that the xbA' is a byt made of soft hair (wabar), or of wool, or of hair [commonly so called] ($aEar), upon two poles, or three; and that a byt is [a tent] upon six poles, or more, to the number of nine: in the Towsheeh it is said that the term xbA' is applied to a byt of any kind: (TA:) a byt is also [a structure] of clay, or tough or cohesive clay or earth; (A, K;) [and of baked bricks; and of stone;] the name being likewise applied to a structure of a kind other than the structures which are called A^axobiyap [or tents]; (M;) signifying a habitation [of any kind; an abode; a dwelling]: (Msb:) a man's house; syn. daArN: (T:) [and particularly a chamber; i. e.] a single roofed structure (Mgh, Kull) having a place of entrance; manozilN being applied to what comprises more than one [such] byt, and a roofed SaHon [or vacant part, and a kitchen, inhabited by a man with his family]; and daArN, that which comprises more than one [such] byt and more than one [such] manozil and a [court, or] SaHon without a roof: (Kull:) the pl. is buyuwtN, (S, M, K, &c.,) also pronounced biyuwtN, (TA,) and A^aboyaAtN, (S, M, K,) the latter a pl. of pauc.; (TA;) and pl. pl. buyuwtaAtN (M, Mgh, K) and A^abaAyiytu (Sb, S, M, K) and A^aboyaAwaAtN, (Fr, M, K,) which last is extr.: (M:) the dim. is ↓ buyayotN, also pronounced ↓ biyayotN; (S, K;) and the vulgar say, buwayotN, (S,) which is not allowable. (K.) You say, huwa jaAriY bayota bayota, (T, S, M,) He is my neighbour [tent to tent, or house to house, i. e.,] by contiguity [of our habitations]: byt byt being made indecl. with fet-h for the termination because they are two nouns made one: (S:) Sb says that some of the Arabs make them [thus] indecl., like xamosapa Ea$ara, and some make the former a prefixed noun governing the latter in the gen. case, [saying bayota bayotK,] except when used as a denotative of state: (M:) one says also, bayotFA libayotK, and bayotN libayotK; (Fr, T;) which last, or bayotN A_ilaY bayotK, is the original form. (Har p. 353.) banaY fulaAnN EalaY A@moraA^atihi [lit. Such a one constructed a tent over his wife,] means such a one had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of his marriage, and brought her, or had her brought, into a pitched tent, having conveyed thither the utensils and furniture and other things that they required. (T.) And A^aholu bayotu Aln~abiY~i [The people of the house of the Prophet,] means the Prophet's wives and his daughter and 'Alee: and so A^ahola A@lobayoti [i. e. yaxuS~u A^ahola Albayoti He means particularly, or peculiarly, the people of the house], in the Kur xxxiii. 33: banuw and maEo$ar and A^ahol and A=l, as prefixed nouns, being, as Sb says, the nouns most frequently occurring in the accus. case [for the reason indicated above, or, as the Arabian grammarians express it,] EalaY AlAixotiSaASi. (M.) ― -b2- It also signifies A [pavilion, palace, or mansion, such as is called] qaSor: (T, K:) whence the saying of Gabriel, ba$~iro xadiyjapa bibayotK mino qaSabK, i. e. [Rejoice thou Khadeejeh by the announcement of] a pavilion (qSr) of hollow pearls, (T, TA,) or of emerald. (TA. [See also art. qSb.]) buyuwtFA gayora masokuwnapK [Uninhabited houses], in the Kur xxiv. 29, means buildings for the reception of travellers, or for merchants and their goods, and the shops of the merchants and places in which things are sold, the entering of which is allowed by their owners: or ruins which a man enters for the purpose of easing nature. (M.) And the buyuwt which God has permitted to be raised, mentioned in the same chapter, verse 36, are Mosques, or places of worship: or, accord. to El-Hasan, Jerusalem (bayotu Almaqodisi); the pl. being applied to it as a mark of honour. (Zj, M.) Albayotu [The House] applies particularly to (tropical:) the Kaabeh [of Mekkeh]; (K;) as also bayotu A@ll~`hi [the House of God]; (AAF, M;) and Albayotu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred House]; (T;) and Albayotu AlEatiyqu [the Ancient House]; (S and K &c. in art. Etq;) and accord. to some, Albayotu AlmaEomuwru, q. v. (Bd in lii. 4.) [bayotu AlmaAli signifies The treasury of the state. And bayotu AlmaA='i is a euphemism for The privy; because water is put there for the purpose of ablution: also called bayotu AlfaraAgi, &c.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The ark of Noah: so in the Kur lxxi. last verse. (T.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A grave; (M, IAth, K;) app. by way of comparison. (M.) So in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr: kayofa taSonaEu A_i*aA maAta Aln~aAsu Hat~aY yakuwnu Albayotu biAlwaSiyfi, meaning How will thou do when men shall die so that the grave shall be sold for the [servant-] boy? (IAth.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The habitation of the surofap, which it constructs in a beautiful manner, (A'Obeyd, M,) of fragments of sticks; (Yaakoob, M;) and of the SayodanaAniY~, which it makes in the interior of the earth, and covers over: (A'Obeyd, M:) and (assumed tropical:) the burrow, or hole, of the Dab~ &c.: and (assumed tropical:) the web of the spider: all, app., as being likened to the bayot of a man. (M.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A man's household. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The wife (As, IAar, T, M, A) of a man. (M, A.) So in the saying,
A^akibarN gay~araniY A^mo bayotu
[Hath old age altered me, or a wife?]: (As, T:) or here it means a household. (S.) ― -b8- The nobility of the Arabs; (T, Msb, K; *) as when one says, bayotu tamiymK fiY baniY HanoZalapa [The nobility of Temeem is in the sons of Handhaleh]: (T, Msb: *) or the family that comprises the nobility of a tribe; as A=lu HiSonK of the fazaAriy~uwn, and A=lu Aljud~ayoni of the $ayobaAniy~uwn, and A=lu Eabodi AlmadaAni of the HaAriviy~uwn; which three were asserted by Ibn-El-Kelbee to be the highest of the families thus called of the Arabs: (M:) [see a verse of El-Lahabee cited voce A^axoDaru:] pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN, (T, M,) the latter being pl. of the former. (T.) You say, huwa mino A^aholi AlbuyuwtaAti He is of the people of nobility: and mino bayotK kariymK [of a generous, or noble, house, or family]. (A.) [See also banaY.] ― -b9- A noble person: (M, Mgh, K:) pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN bayotu qawomihi Such a one is the noble person of his people. (Abu-l-'Omeythil El-Aarabee, M.) ― -b10- (tropical:) The [furniture termed] faro$, (A, Mgh, K,) or mataAE, (TA,) of a tent or house, (Mgh, K,) or that is sufficient for a tent or house. (A.) You say, tazaw~ajotu fulaAnapa EalaY bayotK (tropical:) I married, or took as a wife, such a woman for [my giving] furniture sufficient for a tent or house, (A,) or furniture of a house or tent. (Mgh.) [See 1, last sentence.] ― -b11- A bayot of poetry, (T, S, M, Msb,) or of the poet, (K,) is (tropical:) [A verse; i. e.] what consists of certain known divisions [or feet] called A^ajozaA='u Alt~afoEiyli; being termed byt metaphorically, because of the conjoining of its component parts, one to another, in a particular manner, like as those of a tent are conjoined in its construction; (Msb;) because it consists of words collected together in a regular manner, and so resembles a tent, which is composed of a saqof and kifaA=' and riwaAq and Eumud: (T:) it is derived from the same word signifying a xibaA=' [or tent], and applies to the small and the great, as the rajaz and the Tawiyl; and is [said to be] thus called because it comprises words like as the tent comprises its inhabitants; wherefore its component parts are termed A^asobaAb and A^awotaAd, as being likened to the AsbAb and AwtAd of tents: (M:) pl. A^aboyaAtN and buyuwtN, (M, A, Msb,) the latter mentioned by Sb and IJ, (M,) [but rare,] and [pl. pl.] A^abaAyiytu: (A:) Abu-l-Hasan says that if the byt of poetry be likened to the byt which is a tent or other kind of structure, there is no reason why it should not have the same pl. forms as the latter has. (L.) By the following words of a poet,
wabayotK EalaY Zahori AlmaTiY~i banayotuhu
biA^asomara ma$oquwqi AlxayaA$iymi yaroEufu
[Many a byt upon the back of the camel have I
constructed with a lawny thing slit in the nose and bleeding], is meant, many a byt of poetry have I written with the reed-pen. (S.) [Albayota, written after a quotation of a part of a verse of poetry, means AiqoraA^i Albayota Read thou the verse.] bayotu AlqaSiydapi [The chief verse of the poem] is a phrase employed when a person composes a poem in praise of any one from whom he would obtain some object of desire and want, being applied to that verse of the poem in which the author's want is mentioned: and is a proverbial expression relating to that which is extraordinary and strange, and used in denoting the superiority of a part of a thing over the whole of it [regarded as a whole]: [hence,] one says, fulaAnN A^aw~alu Aljariydapi wabayotu AlqaSiydapi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is the first of the detachment of horsemen, and the chief verse of the poem]. (Har p. 441.)
biytN byt bytt : see biytapN, in two places.

biytapN byt byth bytp bytth a subst. from baAta: and signifying A manner or mode, and state, or condition, of passing, or entering upon, the night. (M.) [See 4; last sentence.] -A2- Food, or victuals; and so ↓ biytN: (A, K:) [or particularly, of a night: for] you say, layolapK ↓ maA lahu biytu, (S M, A, K.) and biytapN layolapK, (T, S, M, A,) mina Alquwti, (T,) He has not a night's food, or victuals. (T, S, M, A, K.)

bayaAtN byAt
A coming upon the enemy by night; (Mgh;) a sudden attack upon, and conflict with, the enemy by night; (Msb;) a great slaughter (S, M) among the enemy, (S,) or a people, (M,) and vehement conflict with them; (S, M;) a coming upon people in the night, and making a sudden attack upon them, while they are heedless; (T;) an attack upon a people by night; a going to the enemy in the night, without their knowledge, and taking them by surprise: (TA:) a subst. from 2; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) like salaAmN from sal~ama. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A^ataAhumu AlA^amoru bayaAtFA The thing, or event, happened, or came, to them in the latter part of the night. (T.)
buyayotN byyt , also pronounced biyayotN, dim. of bayotN, q. v. (S, K.)

bay~uwtN byt bywt
That has remained throughout a night [and so become stale; stale from being a night old]; as also ↓ baAy^itN: both, in this sense, [but the latter more usually,] applied to bread. (S, K.) ― -b2- Cold, or cool, water, (M, K,) that has become so from its having remained throughout a night: (M:) or water that remains during the night beneath the sky: (Ham p. 553:) or water that has been cooled in the leathern bag by night; and in like manner, milk; for [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say, AisoqiniY mino bay~uwti Als~iqaA='i, meaning Give thou me to drink of the milk that has been milked at night and left in the skin so that it has become cold, or cool, by night. (T.) In the saying,
faSab~aHato HawDa qirFY bay~uwtaA
the meaning seems to be, qiraY HawoDK bay~uwtaA, i. e., [And they (app. camels) came in the morning to] the collected water of a trough, which water had remained throughout the night and so become cold, or cool; the phrase being inverted. (M.) ― -b3- A^amorN bay~uwtN (assumed tropical:) An affair, or event, for which, or on account of which, one passes the night in anxiety or grief. (S, K.) ― -b4- ham~N bay~uwtN (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, or grief, that has remained during the night in the bosom. (M.) ― -b5- sin~N bay~uwtapN A tooth that does not fall out, or become shed. (K.)
baAy^itN * [Passing, or spending, the night, or a night, or a part thereof; or entering upon the night; &c.;] act. part. n. of 1. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also bay~uwtN.

mabiytN mbyt
A place in which one passes, or enters upon, the night. (M, A.)
mutabay~itapN mtbyth mtbytp A woman who has obtained a bayot [i. e. tent or house, or the furniture thereof,] and a husband. (M, K.)

musotabiytN mstbyt
Poor, or needy; [as though meaning asking for, or requiring, biyt or biytap, i. e. food; or possessing food, and nothing beside;] syn. faqiyrN [q. v.]. (IAar, T, K.)

div2.head: Quasi byH
div2.entryFree: bayoHaAnN byHAn and bay~aHaAnN: see baw^uwHN, in art. bwH.

1 baAda A_d bA_d bAd bAdy , aor. yabiydu, inf. n. bayodN (T, S, M, &c.) and buyuwdN (S, M, L, Msb, K) and bayaAdN (M, L, Msb, K) and bayoduwdapN (Lh, M, L, K) and bawaAdN (L, K) and bawodN, (CK,) the last but one disapproved by MF, (TA,) [and the last equally doubtful,] He, or it, perished; (T, S, A, Mgh, L, Msb;) went away; passed away; became cut off, or extinct; came to an end. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- baAdati Al$~amosu, inf. n. buyuwdN, The sun set. (Sb, M, K.)

4 A^abaAdahumo *
He (God) destroyed them; (T, S, A, Mgh, * Msb;) caused them to go away, pass away, become cut off or extinct, or come to an end. (M. *)

bayoda byd yd , (T, S, M, L, Mughnee, K,) as also ↓ baAyada, (L, K,) or baAy^ida, (so in the Mughnee and in a MS. copy of the K and in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K omitted,) a noun inseparably prefixed to A^an~a with its complement, (Mughnee,) used as syn. with gayor, (Ks, T, S, M, &c.,) but never otherwise than in the accus. case, nor as an epithet, nor otherwise than as an exceptive in a case in which the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made. (Mughnee.) You say, huwa kaviyru AlmaAli bayoda A^an~ahu baxiylN He is possessed of abundant, or much, wealth, but he is niggardly. (ISk, S, M, A, Msb, Mughnee.) ― -b2- Also as syn. with EalaY, (M, K,) as some say; (A'Obeyd, M;) but to render it in the former manner is preferable. (M.) Accord. to some, (L,) it is syn. with EalaY in the following trad.: naHonu AlA=xiruwna Als~aAbiquwna yawoma AlqyaAmapi bayoda A^an~ahumo A^uwtuw AlkitaAba mino qabolinaA wa A^uwtiynaAhu mino baEodihimo [We, the latter people, shall be those who will precede on the day of resurrection, although they were given the Scripture before us, and we were given it after them]: (T, L:) El-Umawee holds it to be so: (T:) but Ks says that it here signifies gayor [as in the former ex.]: (T, L: [and so says IHsh in the Mughnee:]) accord. to one recital, it is bAyad; (L;) or baAy^ida; so in the Musnad of the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee: (Mughnee:) IAth says, I have not found this in the classical language in the sense of EalaY: some say that it is biA^ayodK, i. e. by means of strength, or power; and that the meaning is, we shall be those who will precede to Paradise on the day of resurrection by means of strength, or power, given us by God. (L.) ― -b3- Also, [accord. to some,] as meaning mino A^ajoli: (L, Mughnee, K:) as in the saying of Mohammad, A^anaA A^afoSaHu AlEarabi bayoda A^an~iY mino qurayo$K wana$aA^otu fiY baniY saEodK [I am the most chaste in speech of the Arabs because I am of the tribe of Kureysh and I grew up among the children of Saad]: (T, L: [in the Mughnee given somewhat differently:]) but Ibn-Málik and others say that it here, also, means gyr, after the manner in which the latter is used in the saying [of a poet],
walaA Eayoba fiyhimo gayora A^an~a suyuwfahumo
bihin~a fuluwlN mino qiraAEi AlkataAy^ibi
[And there is no blemish in them, save that their swords have in them notches from the conflicting of the troops]. (Mughnee.) This manner of praising is termed by Abu-l-'Abbás Mohammad Ibn-Yezeed AisotivobaAtN. (Ham p. 474.) ― -b4- mayoda is also a dial. var. of the same. (A'Obeyd, T, Mughnee.)

bayodaA='u bydA='
A desert; or a waterless desert: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or one that is plain, or level, in which horses are made to run: (M:) or one wherein is nothing: (TA:) so called, accord. to IJ, because it [often] destroys him who alights, or sojourns, in it: (M, Msb: *) or a plain tract, slightly elevated, with few trees, and without herbage, extending to the distance of a day's journey, or half a day's journey, or less, rugged and hard, and only in a country of mould, or clay: (ISh:) pl. biyodN: (S, M, Msb, K:) it has a pl. of a form proper to epithets because it is originally an epithet: (M:) by rule it should be bayodaAwaAtN. (M, K.)

bayodaAnapN bydAnh bydAnp
A she-ass; a subst. applied to that animal: (S:) or a wild she-ass: (M, K:) or one that inhabits a desert (bayodaA='); (T, K;) [an epithet;] not a subst. applied to the animal; J being in error in asserting it to be such: (K:) the [wild] she-ass is thus called, accord. to most of the lexicologists, because it inhabits the bydA'; and if so, the n is an augmentative letter: or, accord. to some, because it is large in the body (Albadan); and if so, the n is a radical letter: (L:) the pl. is bayodaAnaAtN. (L, K.)
baAyada bA^yd bAyd yd , or baAy^ida: see bayoda.

div2.head: Quasi byr
div2.entryFree: biyorN byr ; pl. of pauc. A^aboyaArN: see biy^orN, in art. bA^r.
waqaEa fiY HaASi baASi wqE fy HAS bAS , and HayoSa bayoSa, &c.: see art. HyS

bayoSN byS
Difficulty; straitness; (IAar, K;) as also ↓ biySN. (K.) See above.
biySN byS : see above.

1 baADahu bAD bADh bADp , (S, K,) first pers. biDotu, (M,) aor. yabiyDu, for which one should not say yabuwDu, [though it would be agreeable with a general rule respecting verbs denoting surpassingness,] (S, O,) He surpassed him in whiteness. (S, M, O, K.) -A2- baADato, (S, M, Msb, K, except that in the M and Msb we find the masc. form, baADa, followed by AlT~aAy^iru,) aor. tabiyDu, (Msb,) inf. n. bayoDN, (M, Msb,) said of an ostrich, (M,) or a hen, (K,) or any bird, (S, M, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) She laid her eggs, (M, Msb, TA,) or egg. (Msb.) ― -b2- baADa Als~aHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds rained. (IAar, O, K.) A poet says, [using a phrase from which this application of the verb probably originated,]
baADa Aln~aEaAmu bihi fanaf~ara A^aholahu
A_il~aA Almuqiyma EalaY Ald~awaY AlmutaA^af~ini
(IAar,) i. e. (tropical:) The nEAm, meaning the naEaAy^im, [or Twentieth Mansion of the Moon,] sent down rain upon it, and so put to flight its occupants, except him who remained incurring the risk of dying from disease, wasting away: [the last word being in the gen. case, by poetic license, because the next before it is in that case; like xaribK in the phrase h`*aA juHoru Dab~K xaribK:] the poet is describing a valley rained upon and in consequence producing herbage; for the rain of the asterism called AlnEAy^m is in the hot season, [when that asterism sets aurorally, (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl,)] whereupon there grows, at the roots of the HaliY~, a plant called na$or, which is poisonous, killing beasts that eat of it: the verse is explained as above by El-Mohellebee: (IB:) or, as IAar says, the poet means rain that falls at the nawo' [by which we are here to understand the setting aurorally] of AlnEAy^m; and that when this rain falls, the wise flees and the stupid remains. (O.) ― -b3- baADa biAlmakaAni (tropical:) He remained, stayed, or abode, in the place [like as a bird does in the place where she lays her eggs]. (O, K.) ― -b4- baADati AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The earth produced kamoA^ap [or truffles, which are thus likened to eggs]: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the earth produced the plants that it contained: or (assumed tropical:) it became changed in its greenness to yellowness, and scattered the fruit, or produce, and dried up. (M, TA.) ― -b5- baADa AlHar~u (tropical:) The heat became vehement, or intense. (S, A, K.) -A3- baADa Alqawoma; &c.: see 8, in three places.

2 by~D byD , (S, M, K,) inf. n. taboyiDN, (S,) He whitened a thing; made it white; (S, M;) contr. of saw~ada. (K.) He bleached clothes. (M.) [He whitewashed a wall &c. He tinned a copper vessel or the like.] You say, bay~aDa A@ll~`hu wajohahu [lit., God whitened his face: or may God whiten his face: meaning (tropical:) God rendered his face expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or rejoiced, or cheered, him: or may God &c.: and also God cleared his character; or manifested his honesty, or the like: or may God &c.: see the contr. saw~ada]. (TA.) And by~D lahu [He left a blank space for it; namely, a word or sentence or the like: probably post-classical]. (TA in art. $ms; &c.) ― -b2- [He wrote out fairly, after having made a first rough draught: in this sense, also, opposed to saw~ada: probably post-classical.] ― -b3- (tropical:) He filled a vessel: (M, A, K: *) or he filled a vessel, and a skin, with water and milk. (S, O.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He emptied (A, K) a vessel: (A:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.)

3 bAyDhu 4 , (S, M,) inf. n. mubaAyaDapN, (TA,) He contended with him for superiority in whiteness. (S, M.) ― -b2- baAyaDaniY fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one acted openly with me; syn. jaAharaniY: from Aln~ahaAri ↓ bayaADu [the whiteness of day, or daylight]. (A, TA.)

4 A^aboyaDato * and A^abaADato
She (a woman) brought forth white children: and in like manner one says of a man [A^aboyaDa and A^abaADa, meaning He begat white children]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also 9, in two places.

8 AbtAD A^yD bA^yDh bAyDh bAyDp
He (a man, S) put upon himself a bayoDap [or helmet] (S, K, TA) of iron. (TA.) -A2- AbtADhumo He entered into their bayoDap [or territory, &c.]: (A, TA:) and AbtADwA Alqawoma They exterminated the people, or company of men; they extirpated them; (M, K; *) as also ↓ baADuwhumo: (M:) and AubotiyDuwA [originally AubotuyiDuwA; in the CK, incorrectly, AbtayaDuwA;] They were exterminated, or extirpated, (K, TA,) and their bayoDap [or quarter, &c.,] was given up to be plundered: (TA:) and AibotaDonaAhumo We smote their byDp [or collective body, &c.,] and took all that belonged to them by force; as also ↓ biDonaAhumo: and ↓ biyDa AlHaY~u The tribe was so smitten &c. (TA.)

9 AbyD~ A^byD AbyD bAD byD {byD , (S, M, Msb, K,) and, by poetic license, AiboyaDaD~a, [of which see an ex. voce xafaDa, and see also 9 in art. Hw,] (M, TA,) inf. n. AiboyiDaADN, (S, Msb,) It was, or became, white; (S, M, Msb;) contr. of Aisowad~a; (K;) as also ↓ AbyAD~, inf. n. AiboyiyDaADN;. (S;) contr. of AisowaAd~a; (K;) and ↓ A^abaADa: which ↓ last also signifies it (herbage or pasture) became white, and dried up. (M, TA.) [You say also, AbyD~ wajohuhu, lit., His face became white: meaning (tropical:) his face became expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or he became joyful, or cheerful: and also his character became cleared; or his honesty, or the like, became manifested: see 2.]
11 A_iboyaAoD~a see 9.
bayoDN byD : see bayoDapN, in three places.

bayoDapN byD byDh byDp
An egg (Msb) of an ostrich, (Mgh,) and of any bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like, i. e. of anything that is termed SamuwxN [or having merely an ear-hole] as distinguished from such as is termed A^a*uwnN [or having an ear that is called A^u*unN]: so called because of its whiteness: (TA:) n. un. of ↓ bayoDN: (S, M, * Msb, K:) pl. [of the former] bayoDaAtN (M, Sgh, K) and bayaDaAtN, which latter is irreg., (M, Sgh,) and only used by poetic license; (Sgh;) and (of bayoDN, M) buyuwDN. (M, K.) You say, A^aforaxati AlbayoDapu The egg had in it a young bird. (ISh.) And A^aforaxa bayoDapu Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) What was hidden, of the affair, or case, of the people, or company of men, became apparent. (ISh.) [See also art. frx.] bayoDapu Albaladi signifies The egg which the ostrich abandons. (S, M, K.) And hence the saying, huwa A^a*al~u mino bayoDapi Albaladi (tropical:) He is more abject, or vile, than the egg of the ostrich which it abandons (S, A, * K) in the desert. (TA.) You say also, huwa bayoDapu Albaladi in dispraise and in praise. (IAar, Aboo-Bekr, M.) When said in dispraise, it means (tropical:) He is like the egg of the ostrich from which the young bird has come forth, and which the male ostrich has cast away, so that men and camels tread upon it: (IAar, M:) or he is alone, without any to aid him; like the egg from which the male ostrich has arisen, and which he has abandoned as useless: (TA:) or he is an obscure man, or one of no reputation, whose lineage is unknown. (Ham p. 250.) And when said in praise, it means (tropical:) He is like the ostrich's egg in which is the young bird; because the male ostrich in that case protects it: (IAar, M:) or he is unequalled in nobility; like the egg that is left alone: (M:) or he is a lord, or chief: (IAar, M:) or he is the unequalled of the balad [or country or the like], to whom others resort, and whose words they accept: (K:) or he is a celebrated, or wellknown, person. (Ham p. 250.) [See also art. bld. And for another meaning of bayoDapu Albaladi see below.] ― -b2- (tropical:) A helmet of iron, (AO, S, * M, * Mgh, * K, *) which is composed of plates like the bones of the skull, the edges whereof are joined together by nails; and sometimes of one piece: (AO:) so called because resembling in shape the egg of an ostrich: (AO, M, Mgh: *) in this sense, also, n. un. of ↓ bayoDN. (S, K: [in the CK, for wAlHadiydu we should read wAlHadiydi.]) This may be meant in a trad. in which it is said that a man's hand is to be cut off for his stealing a bayoDap. (Mgh.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A testicle: (S, K:) pl. biyDaAnN. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The bulb of the saffron-plant [&c.]: as resembling an egg in shape. (Mgh.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [A tuber: for the same reason.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A kind of grape of Et-Táïf, white and large. (M.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The core of a boil: as resembling an egg. (M.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The fat of a camel's hump: for the same reason. (M.) ― -b9- bayoDapu Albaladi, in addition to its meanings mentioned above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) The white truffle: (O, K:) or simply truffles; syn. AlkamoA^apu; (TA;) or these are called AlA^aroDi ↓ bayoDu. (A.) ― -b10- bayoDapN also signifies (tropical:) The continent, or container, or receptacle, (Hawozap,) of anything. (S, K, TA.) And [hence] bayoDapu AlA_isolaAmi (tropical:) The place [or territory] which comprises El-Islám [meaning the Muslims]; like as the egg comprises the young bird: (Mgh:) or this signifies the congregation, or collective body, of the Muslims. (AZ, M.) And bayoDapu Alqawomi
(tropical:) The quarter, tract, region, or district, of the people, or company of men: (S, K:) the heart; or midst, or main part, of the abode thereof: (S, TA:) the principal place of abode (A^aSol) thereof; (M, TA;) the place that comprises them; the place of their government, or regal dominion; and the seat of their dEwp [i. e. diEowap or kindred and brotherhood]: (TA:) the midst of them: (M:) or, as some say, their [kinsfolk such as are termed] Ea$iyrap: (TA:) but when you say, A^ataAhumu AlEaduw~u fiY bayoDatihimo, the meaning is [the enemy came to them in] their principal place of abode (A^aSol), and the place where they were congregated. (TA.) And bayoDapu Ald~aAri (tropical:) The midst of the country or place of abode or the like: (AZ, M, TA:) the main part thereof. (TA.) And bayoDapu Almuloki i. q. Hawozatuhu (assumed tropical:) [The seat of regal power: or the heart, or principal part, of the kingdom]. (S and K in art. Hwz.) ― -b11- bayoDapu Alxidori (M, A, K) (tropical:) The damsel (M, K) of the xdr [or curtain &c.]: (K: [in the CK, jaAriyatuhaA is erroneously put for jaAriyatuhu:]) because she is kept concealed within it. (TA.) You say also, hiYa mino bayoDaAti AlHijaAli (tropical:) [She is of the damsels of the curtained bridal canopies]. (A, TA.) bayoDapN is used by a metonymy to signify (tropical:) A woman, by way of likening her thereto [i. e. to an egg] in colour, and in respect of her being protected as beneath the wing. (B.) [See Kur xxxvii. 47.] ― -b12- bayoDapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) White land, in which is no herbage; opposed to sawodapN: (TA:) and ↓ biyDapN, with kesr, white, smooth land; (K;) thus accord. to IAar, with kesr to the b: (Sh:) and ↓ A^aroDN bayoDaA='u signifies smooth land, in which is no herbage; as though herbage blackened land: or untrodden land: as also bayoDapN. (M.) ― -b13- bayoDapu Aln~ahaAri The whiteness of day; [daylight;] i. q. ↓ bayaADuhu; (K;) i. e. its light. (Har p. 222.) You say, A^atayotuhu fiY bayoDapi Aln~ahaAri I came to him in the whiteness of day. (TA.) ― -b14- bayoDapu AlHir~i (assumed tropical:) The vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (M.) And bayoDapu AlqayoZi (tropical:) The most vehement, or intense, heat of summer, or of the hottest period of summer, from the [auroral] rising of Ald~abaraAn to that of suhayol; [i. e., reckoning for the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, from about the 26th of May to about the 4th of August, O. S.;] (A, * TA;) as also AlqayoZi ↓ bayoDaA='u. (A, TA.) And bayoDapu AlS~ayofi (assumed tropical:) The main part of the Syf [or summer]: (M, TA:) or the vehement, or intense, heat thereof. (Ham p. 250.)
bayDapN byD byDh byDp : see bayoDapN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

bayaADN byAD
Whiteness; contr. of sawaAdN; in an animal, and in a plant, and in other things; and, accord. to IAar, in water also; (M;) the colour of that which is termed A^aboyaDu: (S, Msb, * K:) they said bayaADN and ↓ bayaADapN, (S, M, K,) like as they said manozilN and manozilapN: (S:) bayaADapN being applied to a whiteness in the eye. (M.) You say, h`*aA A^a$ad~u bayaADFA mino ka*aA [This is whiter than such a thing]: (S, K: *) but not ↓ A^aboyaDu mnohu: (S:) the latter is anomalous; (K;) [like A^asowadu minohu; q. v.;] but it was said by the people of El-Koofeh, (S, K,) who adduced as authority the saying of the rájiz,
jaAriyapN fiY diroEihaA AlfaDofaADi
A^aboyaDu mino A^uxoti baniY A_ibaADi
[A damsel in her ample shift, whiter than the sister of the tribe of Benoo-Ibád]: Mbr, however, says that an anomalous verse is no evidence against a rule commonly approved: and as to the saying of another,
A_i*aA Alr~ijaAlu $atawoA waA@$otad~a A^akoluhumu
faA^anota A^aboyaDuhumo sirobaAla Tab~aAxi
[When men experience dearth in winter, and their eating becomes vehement, thou art the whitest of them, or rather the white of them, in respect of cook's clothing, having little or nothing to do with entertaining them], the word in question may be considered as an epithet of the measure A^afoEalu that is followed by mino to denote excess: but it is only like the instances in the sayings huwa A^aHosanuhumo wajohFA and A^akoramuhumo A^abFA, meaning Hasanuhumo wajohFA and kariyimuhumo A^abFA; so it is as though he said faA^anota muboyaD~uhumo sirobaAlFA; and as he has prefixed it to a complement which it governs in the gen. case, what follows is in the accus. case as a specificative. (S.) This latter verse is by Tarafeh, who satirizes therein 'Amr Ibn-Hind; and is also differently related in respect of the first hemistich, and the first word of the second. (L, TA.) ― -b2- bayaADu Aln~ahaAri: see 3; and see bayoDapN, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b3- bayaADN is also used elliptically for *uw bayaADK; and thus means (assumed tropical:) White clothing; as in the saying, fulaAnN yalobasu Als~awaAda waAlbayaADa Such a one wears black and white clothing. (Mgh.) [Hence, also, it has other significations, here following.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Milk. (K.) See an ex., voce sawaAdN. ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) The white of an egg.] ― -b6- bayaADu AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) That part of land wherein is no cultivation nor population and the like. (M.) ― -b7- bayaADu Aljilodi (assumed tropical:) That part of the skin upon which is no hair. (M.) ― -b8- (tropical:) bayaADN also signifies (tropical:) A man's person; like sawaAdN; syn. $axoSN; as in the saying, laA yuzaAyilu sawaAdiY bayaADaka (tropical:) My person will not separate itself from thy person. (As, A, TA.)

bayuwDN bywD A hen that lays many eggs; (S, M, A, * K; *) as also ↓ bay~aADapN: (M:) [but in the Msb it is evidently used as signifying simply oviparous:] pl. (of the former, S, M *) buyuDN (S, M, A, K) and biyDN, (S, M, K,) the latter in the dial. of those who say rusolN for rusulN, the b being with kesr in order that the Y may remain unchanged; (S, M;) but sometimes they said buwDN. (M.)
bayaADapN byAD byADh byADp : see bayaADN.

baAy^iDN * A hen, (Az, K,) or bird, (S, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) laying an egg or eggs: (Az, S, * Msb, K: *) without p because the cock does not lay eggs: (Az, TA:) or it is applied also to a cock, (M, TA,) and to a crow, (M, A, TA,) [as meaning begetting an egg or eggs,] in like manner as one uses the word waAlidN. (M, TA.)

bay~aADN byAD
A bleacher of clothes; as a kind of rel. n.; not as a verbal epithet; for were it this, it would be mubay~iDN. (M.) ― -b2- A seller of eggs. (M.) ― -b3- bay~aADapN: see bayuwDN.

A^aboyaDu *
White; contr. of A^asowadu; (A, K;) having whiteness: (Msb:) fem. bayoDaA='u: (Msb:) pl. biyDN, originally buyoDN, (S, Msb, K,) the damm being converted into kesr in order that the Y may remain unchanged, (S, K,) [i. e.] to suit the Y. (Msb.) In the phrase A^aEoTiniY A^aboyaD~aho, mentioned by Sb, as used by some of the Arabs, meaning A^aboyaDa, [i. e. Give thou to me a white one,] h is subjoined as it is in hun~aho for hun~a, and the D is doubled because the letter of declinability cannot have h subjoined to it; wherefore the letter of declinability is the first D, and the second is the augmentative, and for this reason it has subjoined to it the h whereof the purpose is to render plainly perceivable the vowel [which is necessarily added after the doubled D]: Aboo-'Alee says, [app. of the h,] that it should properly have neither fet-h nor any vowel. (M.) ― -b2- Applied to a man &c., it was sometimes used to signify White in complexion: but in this sense they generally used the epithet A^aHomaru. (IAth, TA in art. Hmr.) They also said, fulaAnN A^aboyaDu Alwajohi and fulaAnapu bayoDaA='u Alwajohi, meaning Such a man, and such a woman, is clear, in face, from freckles or the like, and unseemly blackness. (Az, TA.) And they used biyDaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. of A^aboyaDu, (TA,) in the contr. of the sense of suwdaAnN, (S, K,) [i. e. as signifying Whites,] applied to men: (S:) though they applied the appellation A^abuw AlbayoDaA='i to the Abyssinian: (TA in art. Ewr:) or to the negro: and A^abuw Aljawoni to the white man. (ISk.) But accord. to Th, A^aboyaDu applied to a man signifies only (tropical:) Pure; free from faults: (IAth, TA in art. Hmr:) or, so applied, unsullied in honour, nobility, or estimation; (Az, K;) free from faults; and generous: and so bayoDaA='u applied to a woman. (Az.) [In the lexicons, however, (see, for ex., among countless other instances, an explanation of baD~apN in the S,) and in other post-classical works, it is generally used, when thus applied, in its proper sense, of White; or fair in complexion.] ― -b3- katiybapN bayoDaA='u An army, or a portion thereof, upon which the whiteness of the [arms or armour of] iron is apparent. (M.) ― -b4- And bayoDaA='u alone, [as a subst.,] A piece of paper [without writing]. (Har p. 311.) ― -b5- AlA^aboyaDu The sword: (S, A, K:) because of its whiteness: (TA:) pl. biyDN. (S.) ― -b6- Silver: (A, K:) because of its whiteness: like as gold is called AlA^aHomaru [because of its redness]. (TA.) ― -b7- The saliva (rDAb) of the mouth. (Ham p. 348.) ― -b8- A certain star in the margin of the milky way. (A, K.) ― -b9- AlbayoDaA='u The sun: because of its whiteness. (M.) ― -b10- Waste, or uncultivated, or uninhabited, land: (K, * TA: [in the CK AljirAbu is erroneously put for AlxaraAbu:]) opposed to Als~awodaA='u: because dead lands are white; and when planted, become black and green. (TA.) See also bayoDapN, near the end. ― -b11- Wheat: (K:) as also Als~amoraA='u. (TA.) ― -b12- Fresh [grain of the kind called] sulot. (El-
Khattábee, K.) ― -b13- A certain kind of wood; that which is called AlHawaru: (K in art. Hwr:) because of its whiteness. (TA in that art.) [See HawarN.] ― -b14- The cooking-pot; as also A^um~u bayoDaA='a. (AA, K.) ― -b15- The snare with which one catches game. (IAar, K.) ― -b16- AlA^aboyaDaAni Milk and water. (ISk, S, M, A, K.) A poet says,
wamaA liYa A_il~aA AlA^aboyaDayoni $araAbu
[And I have not any beverage except milk and water]. (ISk, S, M.) ― -b17- Bread and water: (As, M, K:) or wheat and water: (Fr, K:) or fat and milk. (AO, K.) ― -b18- Fat and youthfulness (AZ, IAar, M, A, K.) You say, *ahaba A^aboyaDaAhu His fat and youthfulness departed. (TA.) ― -b19- maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o A^aboyaDaAni I have not seen him for, or during, two days: (Ks, M, A, K:) or two months. (Ks, M, K.) ― -b20- A^ay~aAmu AlbiyDi, (Msb, K,) or simply AlbiyDu, (Mgh,) for A^ay~aAmu All~ayaAliY AlbiyDi; [The days of the white nights;] i. e. the days of the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the month; (Mgh, Msb, K;) so called because they are lighted by the moon throughout: (Msb:) or of the twelfth and thirteenth and fourteenth nights: (K:) but this is of weak authority, and extr.: the former is the correct explanation: (MF, TA:) you should not say AlA^ay~aAmu AlbiyDu: (Ibn-El-Jawá- leekee, IB, K:) yet thus it is in most relations of a trad. in which it occurs; and some argue for it; and the author of the K has himself explained AlA^awaADiHu by AlA^ay~aAmu AlbiyDu. (TA.) ― -b21- sanapN bayoDaA='u (assumed tropical:) A year [of scarcity of herbage,] such as is a mean between that which is termed $ahobaA=' and that which is termed HamoraA='. (TA in art. $hb.) ― -b22- kalaAmN A^aboyaDu (tropical:) Language expounded or explained. (M.) ― -b23- kal~amotuhu famaA rad~a EalaY~a sawodaA='a walaA bayoDaA='a (tropical:) I spoke to him, and he did not return to me a bad word nor a good one. (M.) ― -b24- yadN bayoDaA='u (assumed tropical:) A demonstrating, or demonstrated, argument, plea, allegation, or evidence. (M.) ― -b25- And (assumed tropical:) A favour, or benefit, for which one is not reproached; and which is conferred without its being asked. (M.) [See also yadN.] ― -b26- Almawotu AlA^aboyaDu (assumed tropical:) Sudden death; (K, TA;) such as is not preceded by disease which alters the complexion: or, as some say, death without the repentance, and the prayer for forgiveness, and the accomplishment of necessary duties, usual with him who is not taken unawares; from bay~aDa signifying “ he emptied ” a vessel: so says Sgh: opposed to Almawotu AlA^aHomaru, which is slaughter. (TA.) ― -b27- bayoDaA='u also signifies (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune: (Sgh, K:) app. as a term of good omen; like saliymN applied to one who is stung by a scorpion or bitten by a serpent. (TA.) ― -b28- bayoDaA='u AlqayoZi: see bayoDapN, last sentence but one. -A2- h`*aA A^aboyaDu mino ka*aA; &c.: see bayaADN.

mabiyDN mbyD
A place for laying eggs. (ISd, TA in art. fHS.)
mubiyDapN mbyD mbyDh mbyDp A woman who brings forth white children: the contr. is termed musowidapN: (Fr, K:) but muwDiHapN is more commonly used in the former sense. (O.)

[
muboyaD~apN mbyD mbyDh mbyDp The fair copy, or transcript, made from a first rough draught; which latter is called musowad~apN: probably post-classical.]

mubay~iDN mbyD A man wearing white clothing. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, Almubay~iDapu A sect of [the class called] the vanawiy~ap, (S, K,) the companions of Almuqan~aE; (S;) so called because they made their clothes white, in contradistinction to the musaw~idap, the partisans of the dynasty of the 'Abbásees; (S, K, *) for the distinction of these was black: they dwelt in Kasr 'Omeyr. (TA.) [See also AlHaruwriy~apu.]

1 baAEahu bAE bAEh bAEp bAy^E , (S, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yabiyEu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. bayoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and mabiyEN, (S, Msb, K,) which latter is anomalous, (S,) the regular form being mabaAEN, (S, K,) has two contr. significacations: He sold it: and he bought it: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and ↓ AbAEhu is a dial. var. of the same: (IKtt, Msb:) [but app. only in the former sense:] or this last signifies he offered it for sale; or exposed it to sale: (S, K:) and ↓ AbtAEhu, as well as baAEahu, signifies he bought it. (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K.) The primary signification of bayoEN is The exchanging, or exchange, of property; or the making an exchange with property; as in the phrases bayoEN raAbiHN [an exchange of property bringing gain], and bayoEN xaAsirN [an exchange of property occasioning loss]: and this is a proper signification when it relates to real substances: but it is tropically used to signify the making the contract [of sale and purchase]; because this is the means of giving [and obtaining] possession: [though this signification is what is termed HaqiyqapN Eurofiy~apN, i. e., a sense so common as to be conventionally regarded as proper:] the phrase SaH~a AlbayoEu, or baTala, and the like, mean Safoqapu AlbayoEi; [i. e. The contract of sale, or purchase, was valid, or was null;] but the prefixed n. being suppressed, and its complement [alone] used for it, and this being masc., the verb is made masc. (Msb.) baAEa [mostly signifies He sold; and] is doubly trans., both by itself and by means of mino prefixed to the second object; (Mgh, Msb;) this prep. being thus used as a corroborative: (Msb:) you say, baAEahu Al$~aYo'a and baAEahu minohu [He sold to him the thing and He sold it to him]: (Mgh:) and biEotu zayodFA Ald~aAra and biEotu mino zayodK Ald~aAra [I sold to Zeyd the house: (see also an explanation of the phrase AisotabaEotuhu Al$~aYo'a: and see baAEahu mina Als~uloTaAni: to which might be added countless similar instances; for when bAE signifies he sold, mino is generally prefixed to the noun or pronoun denoting the person to whom the thing is sold:)] and sometimes li is put in the place of mino; so that you say, biEotuka Al$~aYo'a and biEotuhu laka [I sold to thee the thing and I sold it to thee]; the l being redundant [when the verb has this meaning, though not when it has the contr. meaning, as will be seen below]. (Msb.) Of the contr. signification we have an ex. in the saying of ElFarezdak,
A_in~a Al$~abaAba laraAbiHN mano baAEahaA
waAl$~ayobu layosa libaAy^iEiyhi tijaAru
[Verily youthfulness, he who buys it is a gainer; but hoariness, there are no traffickers for its sellers; the part. a. being here from the verb in the former sense]: (S, TA:) and [often in a case in which the verb is followed by l; as] in baAEa lahu Al$~aYo'a He bought for him the thing; (Mgh;) [the l not being redundant when the verb is used in this sense;] and as in the saying of Tarafeh,
wayaA^otiyka bAloA^axobaAri mano lamo tabiEo lahu
bataAtFA walamo taDoribo lahu waqota mawoEidi
[And he will bring thee tidings for whom thou hast not bought travelling-provisions, and for whom thou hast not assigned an appointed time for his bringing them]: (TA:) and in the saying, baAEa dunoyaAhu biA=xiratihi (tropical:) [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]: (Z, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, zayodN Ald~aAra ↓ AbtAE, meaning Zeyd bought the house: and ligayorihi ↓ AbtAEhA He bought it for another person. (Msb.) The verb has this signification, also, in the trad., laA yabiEo baEoDukumo EalaY bayoEi A^axiyhi [One of you shall not buy in opposition to the buying of his brother when an agreement has been manifested but the contract has not been concluded]; (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb; [but in the S and Msb and by IAth, the trad. is related thus; laA yaxoTubi Alr~ajulu EalaY xiTobapi A^axiyhi walaA yabiEo EalaY bayoEi A^axiyhi; (see art. xTb;)]) as is shown by the relation of Bkh, Alr~ajulu EalaY bayoEi A^axiyhi ↓ laA yabotaAEu: (Mgh, Msb:) or it may here have the contr. meaning: (IAth:) Az says that the seller and buyer are equal in offence when either of them does thus to another. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying, laA yasuwmu Alr~ajulu EalaY sawomi A^axiyhi: see art. swm. See also baAEa EalaY bayoEihi below, used in a tropical sense.] You say also, baAEa Ealayohi AlqaADiY, meaning The judge sold against his will; (Mgh;) sold without his consent. (Msb.) ― -b2- The pass. form is biyEa [It was sold: and it was bought]: (S, K:) optionally either [thus] with kesr to the b, or [buyoEa] with damm to the b, (S,) [or rather with a sound between that of damm and that of kesr, which pronunciation is termed A_i$omaAmN;] and some say buwEa; (S, K;) changing the Y into w: and thus in the cases of kiyla and qiyla and the like: (S:) [but Ibn-Málik requires damm or A$mAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is Y, and kesr or A$mAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is w, to prevent the mistaking of an active verb for a passive in such cases as biEotu and sumotu: others, however, only prefer what Ibn-Málik absolutely requires in these cases. (See I'Ak p. 131.)] ― -b3- You say also, baAEahu mina Als~uloTaAni, [lit. He sold him to the Sultán,] meaning (tropical:) he slandered him, or calumniated him,
to the Sultán. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And baAEa fulaAnN EalaY bayoEihi, [of which the lit. meaning has been shown above,] meaning (tropical:) Such a one superseded him, or occupied his place, in respect of honourable and elevated station or rank, and gained the mastery over him; (K, * TA;) and so Hal~a biwaAdiyhi: (TA:) or baAEa fulaAnN EalaY bayoEi fulaAnK means (tropical:) such a one gained the mastery over such a one, and wrested from him that which he sought to obtain from him; and is an old proverb, applied by the Arabs to a man who contends with another, and seeks to obtain a thing from him by superior power or force, when he has succeeded in doing as above explained; and similar to it is the saying $aq~a fulaAnN gubaAra fulaAnK. (El-Mufaddal Ed-Dabbee, TA.) One also says, maA baAEa EalaY bayoEika A^aHadN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Not any one has equalled thee. (TA.) -A2- bayoEN is also used in the sense of AinobisaATN. (TA in art. bwE. [See AinobaAEa in that art.])

3 baAyaEotuhu bAyE bAyEth bAyEtp , (S, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. mubaAyaEapN and biyaAEN, (TA,) is from AlbayoEu; and so is ↓ Alt~abaAyuEu; (S, TA;) this being syn. with AlmubaAyaEapu. (K, TA.) You say, baAyaEaA and ↓ tabaAyaEaA, meaning They two sold and bought, each with the other: (TK:) and ↓ tabaAyaEonaA [We sold and bought, one with another]: (Mgh:) and bAyEhu also signifies He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him. (TA.) [See 1; where a citation from the Msb indicates that this latter is the primary signification accord. to the author of that work.] ― -b2- It is also from AlbayoEapu; and so is ↓ Alt~abaAyuEu: (S, TA: *) AlmubaAyaEapu and ↓ Alt~abaAyuEu from AlbayoEapu signifying The making a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like; as though each of the two parties sold what he had to the other, and gave him his own special property, and his obedience, and all that pertained to his case. (TA.) [Hence,] bAyE AlA^amiyra He promised, or swore, allegiance to the prince; making a covenant with him to submit to him the judgment of his own case and of the cases of the Muslims [in general], not to dispute with him in respect of anything thereof, but to obey him in whatever command he might impose upon him, pleasing and displeasing: in doing which, it was usual for the person making this covenant to place his hand in the hand of the prince, in confirmation of the covenant, like as is done by the seller and buyer; wherefore the act was termed bayoEapN, an inf. n. [of un.] of baAEa. (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 256 — 7.) [And hence the phrases, buwyiEa biAlixilaAfapi and buwyiEa lahu biAlxilaAfapi He had the promise, or oath, of allegiance made to him as being Khaleefeh.] You say also, bAyEhu Ealayohi, inf. n. mubaAyaEapN, He made a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like, with him, respecting it, or to do it: and ↓ tbAyEwA EalaY AlA^amori [they made a covenant, &c., respecting, or to do, the thing, or affair]; like as you say A^aSofaquwA Ealayohi. (TA.)
4 A^aboyaEa see 1, first sentence.
6 tabaAoyaEa see 3, throughout.

7 A_inobayaEa
AnbAE It was, or became, saleable, or easy of sale; it had an easy, or a ready, sale: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) as though quasi-pass. of baAEahu [and therefore primarily signifying it was, or became, sold, or bought]. (TA.)
8 A_ibotayaEa see 1, in four places.

10 AisotabaEotuhu Al$~aYo'a *
I asked him to sell the thing to me; expl. by saA^alotuhu A^ano yabiyEahu min~iY; (S, K; *) for instance, Eabodahu [his slave.] (Mgh.)

bayoEN byE inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- It also signifies The hire, or hiring, of land. (TA.) -A2- Also A thing sold, or bought: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) a subst. in this sense: (Mgh, TA:) pl. buyuwEN: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) which is also used as a pl. of the inf. n., to signify Kinds of selling and buying. (Mgh.) See also biyaAEapN.

bayoEapN byE byEh byEp [inf. n. of un. of baAEa. ― -b2- Hence,] A striking together of the hands of two contracting parties in token of the ratification of a sale. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] The act of mubaAyaEap [or promising, or swearing, allegiance and obedience, as explained above, (see 3,)] and submission, or obedience. (Msb, TA.) Whence, A^ayomaAnu AlbayoEapi [The oaths of allegiance and obedience]; (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 257; and Msb;) which the Khaleefehs exacted; (Ibn-Khaldoon;) and which El-Hajjáj appointed, including hard, or difficult, matters, relating to divorce and emancipation and fasting and the like. (Msb.)

biyEapN byE byEh byEp
A mode, or manner, of selling or buying. (S, Mgh, K.) Hence, SaAHibu biyEapK [A person occupying himself in any kind of selling or buying]: occurring in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar. (Mgh, TA.) And A_in~ahu laHasanu AlbiyEapi [Verily he is good in the manner of selling or buying]. (S, Mgh, TA.) -A2- [A Christian church;] a place of worship (K) pertaining to the Christians: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as some say, a synagogue of the Jews: (TA:) pl. biyaEN, (K, TA,) or biyoEN. (Msb: [but this I think a mistake: if correct, it is a coll. gen. n.])
bayuwEN byE bywE : see bay~iEN.

bayaAEapN byAE byAEh byAEp
An article of merchandise; (Lth, S, K;) as also ↓ bayoEN [q. v. suprà]: (Mgh:) pl. of the former biyaAEaAtN. (K.)

bay~iEN byE : see baAy^iEN, in five places. ― -b2- Also A man who sells, or buys, well; and so ↓ bayuwEN: fem. of the former with p: pl. mase. bay~iEuwna, and pl. fem. bay~iEaAtN; neither the masc. nor the fem. having a broken pl. (TA.)
bay~aAEN byAE A man who sells, or buys, much. (TA.)

baAy^iEN *
Selling, or a seller: and buying, or a buyer: (Msb, K, * TA:) as also ↓ bay~iEN: (K:) the former signification is the more obvious when bAy^E is used without restriction: (Msb:) and ↓ bay~iEN also signifies [accord. to some] a bargainer, or chafferer; (K, TA;) not a seller nor a buyer; but Esh-Sháfi'ee and Az deny that this epithet is applied to a man before he has concluded the contract: (L, TA:) the pl. of bAy^E is baAEapN: (ISd, K:) and the pl. of ↓ by~E is biyaEaA='u [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and A^aboyEaA='u: (K:) and Kr holds that baAEapN is pl. of by~E. (TA.) ↓ Albay~iEaAni signifies The seller and the buyer; (S, Mgh;) and so ↓ AlmutabaAyiEaAni. (TA.) It is said in a trad., biAlxiyaAri maA ↓ Albay~iEaAni lamo yatafar~aqaA, and in another, ↓ AlmutabaAyiEaAni, [The seller and the buyer have the option of cancelling the contract as long as they have not separated.] (TA.) ― -b2- AimoraA^apN baAy^iEN (tropical:) A woman who easily obtains a suitor; or who is much in demand; by reason of her beauty: (K, TA:) as though she sold herself: like naAqapN taAjirapN. (Z, TA.)

mabiyEN mbyE
Sold: and bought: as also ↓ maboyuwEN: (S, K:) in the latter sense syn. with ↓ mubotaAEN. (Msb.) Kh says that the letter suppressed in mabiyEN is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, because it is augmentative: but Akh says that the letter suppressed is the medial radical; for when they made the Y quiescent, they transferred its vowel to the letter before it, so that it became madmoomeh, [the word thus being altered to mabuyowEN,] then they changed the dammeh into kesreh because of the Y after it, then the Y was suppressed, and the w was changed into Y, like the w of miyzaAnN, because of the kesreh: accord. to El-Mázinee, each of these sayings is good; but that of Akh is the more agreeable with analogy. (S.)
maboyuwEN mbywE : see mabiyEN.
mubotaAEN mbtAE : see mabiyEN.
mutabaAyiEN mtbAyE : see baAy^iEN, in two places.

bayoluwnN bylwn [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] the yellow [or rather yellowish, or yellowish gray, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth known by the name of Tafol. (TA, from Esh-Shiháb El-'Ajamee.)

1 baAna bA^n bAn bAny b|n |n , (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor. yabiynu,] inf. n. bayonuwnapN and buyuwnN (M, Mgh, K) and bayonN, (M, K,) It (a thing) became separated, severed, disunited, or cut off, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) Eani Al$~aYo'i from the thing. (Mgh.) And baAnato, (M, K,) or baAnato biAlT~alaAqi, (Msb,) She (a wife) became separated by divorce, (M, Msb, K,) Eani Alr~ajuli from the man. (M, K.) And baAnatN said of a girl, [She became separated from her parents by marriage;] she married: (ISh, T:) as though she became at a distance from the house of her father. (ISh, TA.) And baAna, (M,) or baAna bimaAlK, aor. yabiynu, (T,) inf. n. buyuwnN (T, M) and bayonN, (M,) He became separated from his father, or mother, or both, by property [which he received from him, or her, or them,] (AZ, T, M,) to be his alone: (AZ, T:) and ElFárisee states, on the authority of AZ, that one]
says also, baAna Eanohu and baAnahu [the former app. meaning he became separated thus from him, i. e., from his father; and the latter being syn. with A^abaAnahu, q. v.]. (M.) And baAna AlxaliyTu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, [The partner, or copartner, or sharer, &c., became separated from the person, or persons, with whom he had been associated.] (T.) And baAnato yadu Aln~aAqapi Eano janobihaA, inf. n. buyuwnN, [The fore leg of the she-camel became withdrawn, or apart, from her side.] (T.) And baAna, (S, M, Msb,) and baAnuwA, (K,) aor. yabiynu, (S,) inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He separated himself, or it separated itself; (S; [in one copy of which it is said of a thing;]) and they separated themselves: (K:) or it (a tribe, M, Msb) went, journeyed, went away, or departed; and went, removed, retired, or withdrew itself, to a distance, or far away, or far off. (Msb.) ― -b2- baAna, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yabiynu, (T, Msb,) inf. n. bayaAnN; (T, S, Mgh, K;) and ↓ AbAn, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. A_ibaAnapN; (T, Msb;) and ↓ by~n, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. taboyiynN; (S;) and ↓ tby~n; and ↓ AstbAn; (T, S, M, &c.,) all signify the same; (T, M, Msb;) i. e. It (a thing, T, S, M, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) was, or became, [distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and it was, or became, known. (K.) You say, baAna AlHaq~u [The truth became apparent, &c.; or known]; as also ↓ AbAn. (T.) And
AlS~uboHu li*iY Eayonayoni ↓ qado bay~ana
The dawn has become apparent to him who has two eyes: a prov.: (S, M:) applied to a thing that becomes altogether apparent, or manifest. (Har p. 542.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 257], Alr~u$odu mina AlgaY~i ↓ qado tabay~ana [The right belief hath become distinguished from error]. (TA.) And the lawyers, correctly, use the phrase, kaSawotK laA minohu HuruwfN ↓ yasotabiynu [Like a sound whereof letters are not distinguishable]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [It seems to be indicated in the TA that baAna, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, also signifies It was, or became, united, or connected; thus having two contr. meanings; but I have not found the verb used in this sense, though bayonN signifies both disunion and union.] -A2- baAnahu, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN: see baAnahu, aor. yabuwnu, inf. n. bawonN, in art. bwn. -A3- See also 2, in two places.

2 by~n byn bynn yn , intrans., inf. n. taboyiynN: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, by~n Al$~ajaru The trees, (K,) or the leaves of the trees, (TA,) appeared, when beginning to grow forth. (K, TA.) And by~n Alqaronu (tropical:) The horn came forth. (K, TA.) -A2- by~n binotahu: see 4. ― -b2- by~nhu, (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. taboyiynN (T, S) and ↓ tiboyaAnN (T, S, * K *) and taboyaAnN; (K;) the second of which three is an anomalous inf. n., (T, S, K,) for by rule it should be of the measure tafoEaAlN; (T, S;) but taboyaAnN is not known except accord. to the opinion of those who allow the authority of analogy, which opinion is outweighed by the contrary; (TA;) and tiboyaAnN is the only inf. n. of its measure except tiloqaA='N, (T, S,) accord. to the generality of the leading authorities; but some add timovaAlN, as inf. n. of mav~ala; and El-Hareeree adds to these two, in the Durrah, tinoDaAlN, as inf. n. of naADalahu; and Esh-Shiháb adds, in the Expos. of the Durrah, ti$oraAbN, as inf. n. of $ariba Alxamora; asserting ta$oraAbN also to have been heard, agreeably with analogy; [and to these may be added tabokaA='N and timo$aA='N, and perhaps some other instances of the same kind;] but some disallow tifoEaAlN altogether as the measure of an inf. n., saying that the words transmitted as instances thereof are simple substs. used as inf. ns., like TaEaAmN in the place of A_iToEaAmN; (MF, TA;) and Sb says that tiboyaAnN is not an inf. n.; for, where it so, it would be taboyaAnN; but it is, from bay~anotu, like gaArapN from A^agarotu; (M, TA;) [He made it distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] he made it (namely, a thing, T, S, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AbAnhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ibaAnapN; (Msb;) and ↓ tby~nhu; (S, * Msb, K;) and ↓ AstbAnhu: (Mgh, Msb, K:) [by~nhu is the most common in this sense: and often signifies he explained it: and he proved it:] and ↓ all these verbs signify also he made it known; he notified it: (K:) or ↓ Aisotabanotuhu signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) I knew it, or became acquainted with it, [or distinguished it,] (S, Mgh,) clearly, or plainly; (Mgh;) and so ↓ tabay~anotuhu; (S, * Mgh;) [and bay~anotuhu, as appears from an ex. in what follows, from a verse of En-Nábighah:] ↓ binotuhu and ↓ A^abanotuhu and ↓ Aisotabanotuhu and bay~anotuhu all signify the same as ↓ tabay~anotuhu [app. in all the senses of this verb]: (M:) or, of all these verbs, ↓ baAna is only intrans.: (Msb:) and ↓ Aisotabanotuhu signifies I looked at it, or into it, (namely, a thing,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order that it might become apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, to me: (T, TA:) and ↓ tby~nhu he looked at it, or into it, (namely, an affair, or a case,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, or deliberately, in order to know its real state by the external signs thereof. (T.) A poet says,
wamaA xifotu Hat~aY bay~ana Al$~irobu waAlA^a*aY
↓ bqaAniy^apK A^an~iY mina AlHaY~i A^aboyanu
[And I feared not until the drinking, or the time of drinking, and molestation, made manifest, or plainly showed, by a deep-red (sun), that I was separated from the tribe: see qaAniy^N]. (M.) And it is said in the Kur [xvi. 91], waA^anozalonaA Ealayoka AlkitaAba tiboyaAnFA likul~i $aYo'K [And we have sent down to thee the Scripture to make manifest everything]; meaning, we make manifest to thee in the Scripture everything that thou and thy people require [to know] respecting matters of religion. (T.) See also bayaAnN, in the latter half of the paragraph. En-Nábighah says,
A_il~aA AlA^awaAriY~a m~aA A^ubay~inuhaA
[Except the places of the confinement of the beasts: with difficulty did I distinguish them]; meaning ↓ A^atabay~anuhaA. (S.) You say also, maA ↓ tabay~ana yaA^otiyhi, meaning He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or discover, what would happen to him, of good and evil. (M in art. bSr.) [See also 5, below.]

sabiyla Almujorimiyna sbyl Almjrmyn ↓ walitasotabiyna, in the Kur [vi. 55], means And that thou mayest the more consider, or examine, repeatedly, in order that it may become manifest to thee, the way of the sinners, O Mohammad: (T:) or that thou mayest seek, or endeavour, to see plainly, or clearly, &c.; syn. walitasotawoDiHa sabiylahumo: (Bd:) but most read, waliyasotabiyna syblu Almjrmyn; the verb in this case being intrans. (T.)

3 bAynhu bAy^n bAyn bAynh bAynnh bAynp , (K,) inf. n. mubaAyanapN, (S,) He separated himself from him; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him: (S, TA:) or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him; or cut him off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him; or cut him, or ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him. (K.) [And It became separated from it.]

4 AbAn A^bAn A_bAn AbAn , intrans., inf. n. A_ibaAnapN: see 1, in two places. -A2- AbAnhu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He separated it, severed it, disunited it, or cut it off. (M, Msb, K, TA.) You say, Darabahu faA^abaAna raA^osahu (S, K) He smote him and severed his head, mino jasadihi from his body. (S, TA.) And AbAn AlmaroA^apa He (the husband) separated the woman, or wife, by divorce. (Msb.) And AbAn binotahu, and ↓ by~nhA, (T, K,) inf. n. of the former as above, and of the latter taboyiynN, (TA,) He married, or gave in marriage, his daughter, (T, K,) and she went to her husband: (T:) from bayonN signifying "distance:" as though he removed her to a distance from the house, or tent, of her mother. (TA.) And AbAn A@bonahu bimaAlK, (M,) or AbAnhu A^abawaAhu, (T,) He separated from himself his son, (M,) or his two parents separated him from themselves, (T,) by [giving him] property, (T, M,) to be his alone: (T:) mentioned on the authority of AZ. (T, M.) And AbAn Ald~alowa Eano TiY~i Albiy^ori He drew away the bucket from the casing of the well, lest the latter should lacerate the former. (M.) ― -b2- See also 2, in three places. ― -b3- [Hence, AbAn signifies also He spoke, or wrote, perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, as to meaning; or, with eloquence: from bayaAnN, q. v.] And AbAn Ealayohi He spoke perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, and gave his testimony, or evidence, or gave decisive information, against him, or respecting it. (TA.) [The verb thus used is for AbAn kalaAmahu, and $ahaAdatahu.] One says of a drunken man, maA yubiynu kalaAmFA He does not speak plainly, or distinctly; lit., does not make speech plain, or distinct. (Ks, T in art. bt.) ― -b4- [maA A^aboyanahu How distinct, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, is it! See an ex. voce basula. ― -b5- And How perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, is he in speech, or writing! how good is his bayaAn!]

5 tby~n A^bAn bAn byn tbyn tbynn , intrans.: see 1, in two places. -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2, in seven places. ― -b2- [Hence,
AlA^amora being understood,] He sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge [of the thing], until he knew [it]; he examined, scrutinized, or investigated: (Bd in xlix. 6:) he sought, or endeavoured, to make the affair, or case, manifest, and to settle it, or establish it, and was not hasty therein: (Idem in iv. 96:) or he acted, or proceeded, deliberately, or leisurely, in the affair, or case; not hastily: (Ks, TA:) or it has a signification like this: in the Kur ch. iv. v. 96 and ch. xlix. v. 6, some read fatabay~anuwA, and others fatavab~atuwA; and the meanings are nearly the same: Alt~abay~unu was said by Mohammad to be from God, and AlEajalapN [i. e. "haste"] from the devil. (T.)

6 tbAynA bAyn tbAyn tbAynA tbAynnA
They two (namely, two men, and two copartners,) became separated, each from the other: (M, TA:) or they forsook, or abandoned, each other; or cut each other off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, each other. (K.) And tbAynwA They, having been together, became separated: (Msb:) or they forsook, or abandoned, one another; or cut one another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, one another. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence, They two were dissimilar: and they two (namely, words,) were disparate; whether contraries or not: and they two (namely, numbers,) were incommensurable.]
10 AstbAn AstbAn {stbAn , intrans.: see 1. -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2, in six places.
baAnN bA^n bAn bAny b|n |n a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: see art. bwn.

bayonN byn bynn yn has two contr. significations; (T, S, Msb;) one of which is Separation, or disunion [of companions or friends or lovers]. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) Hence, *aAtu Albayoni as meaning Enmity, and vehement hatred: and the saying liA_iSolaAHi *aAti Albayoni, i. e. For the reforming, or amending, of the bad, or corrupt, state subsisting between the people, or company of men; meaning for the allaying of the discord, enmity, rancour, or vehement hatred: (Msb:) [but this has also the contr. meaning, as will be seen below: and it is explained as having a vague import; for it is said that] fiY A_iSolaAHi *aAti Albayoni means In the reforming, or amending, of the circumstances subsisting between the persons to whom it relates, by frequent attention thereto. (Mgh.) [Hence also,] guraAbu Albayoni [The raven of separation or disunion; i. e., whose appearance, or croak, is ominous of separation: said by some to be] the grAb termed A^aboqaEu [i. e. in which is blackness and whiteness; or having whiteness in the breast]; (S, K;) so described by the poet 'Antarah: (S:) or that which is red in the beak and legs; but the black is called AlHaAtimu, because it makes [or shows] separation to be absolutely unavoidable, (Abu-1-Ghowth, S, K,) according to the assertion of the Arabs, i. e., by its croak: (Msb in art. Htm:) [or it is any species of the corvus:] Hamzeh says, in his Proverbs, that this name attaches to the grAb because, when the people of an abode go away to seek after herbage, it alights in the place of their tents, searching the sweepings: (Har p. 308:) but accord. to the Kádee of Granada, Aboo-'Abd-Allah Esh-Shereef, this appellation, so often occurring in poetry, properly signifies camels that transport people from one district, or country, to another; and he cites the following verses:
galiTa Al~a*iyna raA^ayotuhumo bijahaAlapK
yaloHawona kul~uhumu guraAbFA yanoEaqu
maA Al*~anobu A_il~aA liloA^abaAEiri A_in~ahaA
mim~aA yu$at~itu jamoEahumo wayuqar~iqu
A_in~a AlguraAba biyumonihi tudonuw Aln~awaY
watu$at~itu Al$~amola AljamiyEa AlA^ayonuqu
[Those have erred whom I have seen, with ignorance, all of them blaming a raven croaking: the fault is not imputable save to the camels; for they are of the things that scatter and disperse their congregation: verily the place that is the object of a journey is brought near by the raven's lucky omen; but the she-camels discompose the united state]: and Ibn-'Abd-Rabbih says,
zaEaqa AlguraAbu faqulotu A^ako*abu TaAy^irK
A_in l~amo yuSad~iqohu rugaA='u baEiyri
[The raven cried; and I said, A most lying bird, if the grumbling cry of a camel on the occasion of his being laden do not verify it]. (TA in art. grb.) ― -b2- Also Distance, (S, M, Msb, K,) by the space, or interval, between two things. (Msb.) You say, bayona Albaladayoni bayonN Between the two countries, or towns, &c., is a distance, of space, or interval: (Msb:) and bayonahumaA bayonN Between them two is a distance, with Y when corporeal distance is meant: (Idem in art. bwn:) or A_in~a bayonahumaA labayonN [Verily between them two is a distance], not otherwise, in the case of [literal] distance. (S.) And you say also, bayonahumaA bayonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, S, M *) and bawonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, S, M, * Msb * in art. bwn) Between them two [meaning two men] is a [wide] distance; (M;) i. e. between their two degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Msb in art. bwn:) in this case, the latter is the more chaste. (S.) You also say, [using byn to denote An interval of time,] laqiytuhu buEayodaAti bayonK [I met him after, or a little after, an interval, or intervals,] when you have met him after a while, and then withheld yourself from him, and then come to him. (S, M, K. See also baEodu.]) -A2- Also Union [of companions or friends or lovers]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) the contr. of the first of the significations mentioned above in this paragraph. (T, S, Msb.) [Hence *aAtu Albayoni as meaning The state of union or concord or friendship or love subsisting between a people or between two parties; this being likewise the contr. of a signification assigned to the same expression above: whence the phrase, A_ifosaAdu *aAti Albayoni (occurring in the S and K in art. Abr, and often elsewhere,) The marring, or disturbance, of the state of union or concord &c.: and] hence the saying, saEaY fulaAnN liA_iSolaAHi *aAti Albayoni mino Ea$iyratihi [Such a one laboured for the improving of the state of union or concord &c. of his kinsfolk; but in this instance, the meaning given in the second sentence of this paragraph seems to be more appropriate]. (Ham p. 569.) ― -b2- *aAtu bayonihimo may also be used as meaning The vacant space (saAHap) that is between their houses, or tents. (Ham p. 195.) -A3- bayon is also an adverbial noun, [as such written bayona,] (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) capable of being used as a noun absolutely: (M, K:) it relates only to that which has space, as a country; or to that which has some number, either two or more, as two men, and a company of men; and denotes [intervention in] the interval between two things, or the middle, or midst, of two things, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or the middle of a collective number: (S:) [thus it signifies Between, and amidst, and among:] its meaning is [therefore] vague, not apparent unless it is prefixed to two or more [words, or to a word signifying two or more], or to what supplies the place of such a complement: (Msb:) it must necessarily be prefixed, and may not be otherwise than in the manners just explained: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it may not be prefixed to any noun but such as denotes more than one, or to a noun that has another conjoined to it by w, (M,) not by any other conjunction, (M, Msb,) acc0ord. to the usage commonly obtaining. (Msb.) You say bayona Alr~ajulayoni [Between the two men]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [The property is between the company of men]: (M, Msb, Er-Rághib: *) and AlmaAlu bayona zayodK waEamorKw [The property is between Zeyd and 'Amr]: and huwa bayoniY wabayonahu [He, or it, is between me and him]: (M:) and jalasotu bayona Alqawomi I sat in the middle of [or amidst or among] the company of men: (S, K:) and bayonakumaA AlbaEiyra faxu*aAhu, with AlbEyr in the accus. case, [See between you two the camel, therefore take him], a saying heard by Ks: (Lin art. End:) and fasada maA bayonahumo [The state subsisting among them became bad, or marred, or disturbed]: (S and K in art. myT:) and bayona AlA^ay~aAmi (M and K in art. ndr) and fiymaA bayona AlA^ay~aAmi (S and Msb in that art.) [In, or during, the space of (several) days]: and EawaAnN bayona *`lika, in the Kur [ii. 63], is an ex. of its being prefixed to a single word supplying the place of more than one; (Mgh, Msb;) the meaning being, Of middle age, between that which has been mentioned; namely, the faAriD and the bikor. (Bd.)
