Some allow that two words to the former of which bayona is prefixed may be connected by fa, citing as an evidence the phrase used by Imra-el-Keys, bayona Ald~axuwli faHawomali [as though meaning Between Ed-Dakhool and Howmal]: but to this it has been replied that Aldxwl is a name applying to several places; so that the phrase [means amidst Ed-Dakhool &c., and] is similar to the saying, AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [mentioned above, or jalasotu bayona Alqawomi, also mentioned above]. (Msb.) [You say also, bayona A^aZohurihimo, and bayona Zahorayohimo &c., meaning In the midst of them. (See art. Zhr.) And bayona yadayohi, and bayona yadayohimo, meaning Before him, and before them. bayon is also often used absolutely as a noun: thus it is in the Kur lxxxvi. 7, yaxoruju mino bayoni AlS~ulobi waAlt~araAy^ibi Coming
forth from between, or amidst, the spine and the breast-bones: and in xxxvi. 8 of the same, wajaEalonaA mino bayoni A^ayodyhimo sad~FA And we have placed before them (lit. between their hands) a barrier.] It is said in the Kur [vi. 94], laqado taqaT~aEa bayonukumo, as some read; or bayonakumo, as others: (T, S, M:) the former means Verily your union hath become dissevered: (AA, T, S, M:) the latter, that which was between you; (maA bayonakumo, Ibn-Mes'ood, T, S, or A@l~a*iY kaAna bayonakumo, IAar, T;) or the state wherein ye were, in respect of partnership among you: (Zj, T:) or the state of circumstances, or the bond, or the love, or affection, [formerly subsisting] among you, or between you; or, accord. to Akh, bayonakumo, though in the accus. case as to the letter, is in the nom. case as to the place, by reason of the verb, and the adverbial termination is retained only because the word is commonly used as an adv. n.: (M:) AHát disapproved of the latter reading; but wrongly, because what is suppressed accord. to this reading is implied by what precedes in the same verse. (T.) ― -b2- [It is often used as a partitive, or distributive; as also maA bayona: for ex.,] you say, humo bayona HaA*ifK waqaA*ifK, (S and TA in art. q*f,) or humo maA bayona HaA*fK wqA*fK, (TA in art. H*f,) i. e. [They are partly, or in part,] beating with the staff, or stick, and [partly, or in part,] pelting with stones; [or some beating &c., and the others pelting &c.] (S and TA, both in art. q*f, and the latter in art. H*f.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce xayoTapN.] ― -b3- h`*aA bayona bayona means This (namely, a thing, S, or a commodity, Msb) is between good and bad: (S, Msb, K:) or of a middling, or middle, sort: (M:) these two words being two nouns made one, and indecl., with fet-h for their terminations, (S, Msb, K,) like xamosapa Ea$ara. (Msb.) Alhamozapu Almuxaf~afapu [i. e. the hemzeh uttered lightly] is called hamozapN bayona bayona, (S, M, K, *) i. e. A hemzeh that is between the hemzeh and the soft letter whence is its vowel; (S, M;) or hamozapu bayoni bayonK, the first byn with kesreh but without tenween, and the second with tenween, (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab,) [i. e. the hemzeh &c.:] if it is with fet-h, it is between the hemzeh and the alif, as in saAala, (S, M,) for saA^ala; (M;) if with kesr, it is between the hemzeh and the yé, as in sayima, (S, M,) for say^ima; (M;) and if with damm, it is between the hemzeh and the wáw, as in lawuma, (S, M,) for law^uma: (M:) it is never at the beginning of a word, because of its nearness, by reason of feebleness, to the letter that is quiescent, (S, M,) though, notwithstanding this, it is really movent: (S:) it is thus called because it is weak, (Sb, S, M,) not having the power of the hemzeh uttered with its proper sound, nor the clearness of the letter whence is its vowel. (M.) 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras says,
taHomiY HaqiyqatanaA wabaEo Du Alqawomi yasoquTu bayona bayonaA
i. e. [Thou defendest what we ought to defend, or our banner, or standard, while some of the people, or company of men,] fall, one after another, in a state of weakness, not regarded as of any account: (S:) or it is as though he said, between these and these; like a man who enters between two parties in some affair, and falls, or slips, or commits a mistake, and is not honourably mentioned in relation to it: so says Seer: (IB, TA:) or between entering into fight and holding back from it; as when one says, Such a one puts forward a foot, and puts back another. (TA.) ― -b4- ↓ bayonaA and ↓ bayonamaA are of the number of inceptive Huruwf: (M, K:) this is clear if by Hrwf is meant "words:" that they have become particles, no one says: they are still adv. ns.: (MF, TA:) the former is bayona with its [final] fet-hah rendered full in sound; and hence the A; (Mughnee in the section next after that of wA, and K;) [i. e.,] it is of the measure faEolaY [or faEolaA] from Albayon, the [final] fet-hah being rendered full in sound, and so becoming A; and the latter is bayona with maA [restrictive of its government] added to it; and both have the same meaning [of While, or whilst]: (S:) or the A in the former is the restrictive A; or, as some say, it is a portion of the restrictive mA [in the latter]: (Mughnee ubi suprà:) and these do not exclude bayona from the category of nouns, but only cut it off from being prefixed to another noun: (MF, TA:) they are substitutes for that to which bayona would otherwise be prefixed: (Mgh:) some say that these two words are adv. ns. of time, denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; and they are prefixed to a proposition consisting of a verb and an agent, or an inchoative and enunciative; so that they require a complement to complete the meaning. (TA.) One says, bayonaA naHonu ka*`lika A_i*o Hadava ka*aA [While we were in such a state as that, lo, or there, or then, such a thing happened, or came to pass]: (M, Mgh, * K: *) and bayonamaA naHonu ka*aA [While we were thus]: (Mgh:) and
bayonaA naHonu naroqubuhu A^ataAnaA
[While we were looking, or waiting, for him, he came to us]; (S, M;) a saying of a poet, cited by Sb; (M;) the phrase being elliptical; (S, M;) meaning bayona A^awoqaAti naHonu naroqubuhu, (M,) i. e., bayona A^awoqaAti riqobatinaA A_iy~aAhu [between the times of our looking, or waiting, for him]. (S, M.) As used to put nouns following bayonaA in the gen. case when bayona might properly supply its place; as in the saying (of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, which he thus recited, with kesr, S),
bayonaA taEan~uqihi AlkumaApa warawogihi
yawomFA A^utiyHa lahu jariYo'N salofaEu
[Amid his embracing the courageous armed men, and his guileful eluding, one day a bold, daring man was appointed for him, to slay him]: (S, K:) in [some copies of] the K, taEan~ufihi; but in the Deewán [of the Hudhalees], tEn~qh: [in the Mughnee, ubi suprà, taEaAnuqihi:] the meaning is bayona taEaAnuqihi; the A being added to give fulness to the sound of the [final] vowel: (TA:) As used to say that the A is here redundant: (Skr, TA:) others put the nouns following both bayonaA and bayonamaA in the nom. case, as the inchoative and enunciative. (Skr, S, K.) Mbr says that when the noun following bynA is a real subst., it is put in the nom. case as an inchoative; but when it is an inf. n., or a noun of the inf. kind, it is put in the gen., and bynA in this instance has the meaning of bayona: and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says the like, but some persons of chaste speech treat the latter kind of noun like the former: after bynmA, however, each kind of noun must be in the nom. case. (AA, T.) [See an ex. in a verse cited towards the end of art. A*.]
bayonaA byn bynA bynnA yn see bayonN
bayonamaA bynmA see bayonN

biynN byn bynn yn
A separation, or division, (T, M, K,) between two things, (T,) or between two lands; (M, K;) as when there is a rugged place, with sands near it, and between the two is a tract neither rugged nor plain: (T:) an elevation in rugged ground: (M, K:) the extent to which the eye reaches, (T, M, K,) of a road, (T,) or of land: (M:) a piece of land extending as far as the eye reaches: (T, S:) and a region, tract, or quarter: (AA, T, M, K:) pl. buyuwnN. (S, TA.)

bayaAnN byAn yAn is originally the inf. n. of baAna as syn. with tabay~ana, and so signifies The being [distinct or] apparent &c.; (Kull;) or it is a subst. in this sense: (Msb:) or a subst. from bay~ana, [and so signifies the making distinct or apparent &c.,] being like salaAmN and kalaAmN from sal~ama and kal~ama. (Kull.) ― -b2- Hence, conventionally, (Kull,) The means by which one makes a thing [distinct,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (S, Er-Rághib, TA, Kull:) this is of two kinds: one is [a circumstantial indication or evidence; or] a thing indicating, or giving evidence of, a circumstance, or state, that is a result, or an effect, of a quality or an attribute: the other is a verbal indication or evidence, either spoken or written: [see also bay~inapN:] it is also applied to language that discovers and shows the meaning that is intended: and an explanation of confused and vague language: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the eduction of a thing from a state of dubiousness to a state of clearness: or making the meaning apparent to the mind so that it becomes distinct from other meanings and from what might be confounded with it. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Perspicuity, clearness, distinctness, chasteness, or eloquence, of speech or language: (T, S:) or simply perspicuity thereof: (Har p. 2:) or perspicuity of speech with quickness, or sharpness, of intellect: (M, K:) or perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, speech, declaring, or telling plainly, what is in the mind: (Ksh, TA:) or the showing of the intent, or meaning, with the most eloquent expression: it is an effect of understanding, and of sharpness, or quickness, of mind, with perspicuity, or chasteness, or eloquence, of speech: (Nh, TA:) or a faculty, or principles, [or a science,] whereby one knows how to express [with perspicuity of diction] one meaning in various forms: (Kull:) [some of the Arabs restrict the science of AlbyAn to what concerns comparisons and tropes and metonymies; which last the Arabian rhetoricians distinguish from tropes: and some make it to include rhetoric altogether:] Esh-Shereeshee says, in his Expos. of the Maká- mát [of El-Hareeree] that the difference between bayaAnN and ↓ tiboyaAnN is this: that the former denotes
perspicuity of meaning; and the latter, the making the meaning to be understood; and the former is to another person, and the latter to oneself; but sometimes the latter is used in the sense of the former: (TA:) or the former is the act of the tongue, and the latter is the act of the mind: (Har p. 2:) or the former concerns the verbal expression, and the latter concerns the meaning. (Kull.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a mina AlbayaAni siHorFA (S) or lasiHorFA (TA) [Verily there is a kind of eloquence that is enchantment: see this explained in art. sHr]. The saying in the Kur [lv. 2 and 3], xalaqa A@loA_inosaAna Eal~amahu A@lobayaAna means He hath created the Prophet: He hath taught him the Kur-án wherein is the manifestation of everything [needful to be known]: or He hath created Adam, or man as meaning all mankind: He hath [taught him speech, and so] made him to discriminate, and thus to be distinguished from all [other] animals:(Zj, T:) or He hath taught him that whereby he is distinguished from other animals, namely, the declaration of what is in the mind, and the making others to understand what he has perceived, for the reception of inspiration, and the becoming acquainted with the truth, and the learning of the law. (Bd.) ― -b4- It is also applied to Verbosity, and the going deep, or being extravagant, in speech, and affecting to be perspicuous, or chaste, therein, or eloquent, and pretending to excel others therein; or some byAn is thus termed; and is blamed in a trad., as a kind of hypocrisy; as though it were a sort of self-conceit and pride. (TA.)

biy^orN bayuwnN *
A well of which the rope does not strike against the sides, because its interior is straight: or that is wide in the upper part, and narrow in the lower: or in which the drawer of water makes the rope to be aloof from its sides, because of its crookedness: (T:) or deep and wide; (S, K;) because the ropes are wide apart from its sides; (S;) as also ↓ baAy^inapN: (S, TA:) or that is wide between the two [opposite] sides: (M:) pl. [regularly of the latter epithet] bawaAy^inu. (T, S.)

bay~inN byn bynn yn [Distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (T, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ baAy^inN (T) and ↓ mubiynN: (T, S:) pl. [of mult.] A^aboyinaA='u (S, K) and [of pauc.] bayinapN. (K.) Hence, AlkitaAbu ↓ AlmubiynN [as applied to the Kur, q. v. in xii. 1, &c.,] The clear, plain, or perspicuous, book or writing or scripture: or, as some say, this means the book &c. that makes manifest all that is required [to be known]: (T:) or, of which the goodness and the blessing are made manifest: or, that makes manifest the truth as distinguished from falsity, and what is lawful as distinguished from what is unlawful, and that the prophetic office of Mohammad is true, and so are the narratives relating to the prophets: (Zj, T:) or, that makes manifest the right paths as distinguished from the wrong. (M, TA.) And kalaAmN bay~inN Perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste, or eloquent, language. (T.) ― -b2- A man, or thing, bearing evidence of a quality &c. that he, or it, possesses. (S and K and other Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- A man (M) perspicuous, or clear, or distinct, in speech or language; or chaste therein; or eloquent; (ISh, T, M, K;) fluent, elegant, and elevated, in speech, and having little hesitation therein: (ISh, T:) pl. A^aboyinaA='u (T, M, K) and buyanaA='u and [of pauc.] A^aboyaAnN: (Lh, M, K:) the second of these pls. is anomalous: the last is formed by likening faEiylN to faAEilN: [for bay~inN is a contraction of bayiynN:] but the pl. most agreeable with analogy is bay~inuwna: so says Sb. (M.)

bay~inapN byn bynh bynnh bynp yn
An evidence, an indication, a demonstration, a proof, a voucher, or an argument, (Mgh, TA,) such as is manifest, or. clear, whether intellectual or perceived by sense; (TA;) [originally bayiynapN,] of the measure faEiylapN, from bayonuwnapN, [see 1, first sentence,] and bayaAnN [q. v.]: (Mgh:) and the testimony of a witness: pl. bay~inaAtN. (TA.)

baAy^inN *
In a state of separation or disunion; or separated, severed, disunited, or cut off; (M, * Msb;) as also ↓ A^aboyanu, occurring in a verse cited above, voce bay~ina. [Hence,] AimoraA^apN baAy^inN A woman separated from her husband by divorce; (M, Msb, K;) as also ↓ mubaAnapN: the former without p: (Msb:) like TaAliqN and HaAy^iDN: you say [to a wife] A^anoti baAy^inN [Thou art separated from me by divorce.] (Mgh.) ― -b2- TalaAqN baAy^inN is a tropical phrase; and so is TaloqapN baAy^inapN; (Mgh;) [signifying the same as] taToliyqapN baAy^inapN (S, M, Msb, K) (tropical:) A divorce that is [as it were] cut off; i. q. ↓ mubaAnapN [in the second and third of these phrases, and ↓ mubaAnN in the first]: (ISk, Msb:) bAy^np being here used in the sense of a pass. part. n.: (S, Sgh, Msb:) or it [is a possessive epithet, and thus] means having separation: this kind of divorce is one in the case of which the man cannot take back the woman unless by a new contract; (TA;) nor without her consent. (MF in art. bt.) ― -b3- qawosN baAy^inapN, (S, M, K,) and baAy^inN, (M, K,) A bow that is widely separate from its string: (S, M, K:) contr. of baAniyapN; (S, M;) this signifying one that is so near to its string as almost to stick to it: (S:) each of these denotes what is a fault. (S, M.) ― -b4- biy^orN baAy^inapN: see bayuwnN. ― -b5- naxolapN baAy^inapN A palm-tree of which the racemes have come forth from the spathes, and of which the fruit-stalks have grown long. (AHn, M.) ― -b6- AlbaAy^inu also signifies He who comes to the milch beast [meaning the she-camel, when she is to be milked,] from her left side; (S, K;) and AlmuEal~iY, he who comes to her from her right side: (S:) or the former, he who stands on the right of the she-camel when she is milked, and holds the milking-vessel, and raises it to the milker, who stands on her left, and is called AlmusotaEoliY: (T:) two persons are engaged in milking the she-camel; one of them holds the milking-vessel on the right side, and the other milks on the left side; and the milker is called AlmusotaEoliY and AlmuEal~iY; and the holder, AlbAy^n: (M:) pl. buy~anN. (T.) It is said in a prov., Aisotu AlbaAy^ini A^aEorafu, or, as some say, A^aEolamu; meaning (assumed tropical:) He who has superintended an affair, and exercised himself diligently in the management thereof, is better acquainted with it than he who has not done this. (T. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 606.]) ― -b7- TawiylN baAy^inN Excessively tall, far above the stature of tall men. (TA.) -A2- See also bay~inN.

Talaba A_ilaY A^abawayohi AlbaAy^inapa *
He asked, or begged, of his two parents, the separation of himself from them, by [their giving him] property, (AZ, T, M,) to be his alone. (T.)
A^aboyanu * : see baAy^inN. -A2- fulaAnN A^aboyanu mino fulaAnK Such a one is more perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste, or eloquent, in speech or language, than such a one. (S, TA.)
tiboyaAnN tbyAn an anomalous inf. n. (T, S, K) of 2, q. v.: (T:) or a subst. used as an inf. n.; (MF, TA;) i. e., a subst. from 2. (Sb, M, TA.) See bayaAnN.
mubaAnN mbAn mbnY ; and its fem., with p: see baAy^inN, in three places.

mubiynN mbyn
Separating, severing, disuniting, or cutting off; (S, K;) as also muboyinN, like muHosinN: (K:) but [the right reading in the K may be wamubiynN kamuHosinK, meaning "and mubiynN is like muHosinN:" if not,] muboyinN is a mistake. (TA.) -A2- See also bay~inN, in two places.

mabaAyinu AlHaq~i mbAyn AlHq [in which the former word is app. pl. of mubiynapN] signifies The things that make the truth to be apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain; or the means of making it so; syn. mawaADiHuhu. (TA.)
1 baAha lahu bAh lh bAh lp , aor. yabaAhu, inf. n. bayohN; and maA bihotu lahu: see 1 in art. bwh.
